site_title: GE2015: PAP, WP teams file papers to contest for Marine Parade GRC
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) and Peoples Action Party (PAP) have filed their nomination papers to contest the Marine Parade Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore's 2015 general election. The WP candidates include Yee Jenn Jong, Terence Tan, Firuz Khan, He Ting Ru, and Dylan Ng, while the PAP candidates are Tan Chuan-Jin, Goh Chok Tong, Fatimah Lateef, Seah Kian Peng, and Edwin Tong. The filing of nomination papers marks the start of the election process.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
The PAP's Marine Parade GRC team (from left) Fatimah Lateef, Goh Chok Tong, Tan Chuan-Jin, Seah Kian Peng and Edwin Tong at the press conference on Aug 26, 2015.

site_title: GE2015: MacPherson set for 3-way fight between PAP, WP and NSP
summary: The MacPherson single member constituency is set for a three-way fight in the 2015 GE, with incumbent Tin Pei Ling from the PAP, Bernard Chen from the WP, and Cheo Chai Chen from the NSP submitting their nomination papers. Initially, the NSP planned not to field a candidate but later decided to participate. However, Steve Chia later withdrew due to online abuse. The election is expected to be a closely contested battle between the PAP and the WP.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: PBOC said to impose reserve requirement on yuan forwards trading
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), is imposing a 20% reserve requirement on financial institutions trading in yuan forwards for clients, effective October 15, to curb speculation and limit capital outflows. The move aims to prevent macro financial risks, particularly after China's yuan devaluation in August, which caused the currency to decline 2.6% in the month. The rule change is expected to drive technical convergence in the onshore and offshore yuan curve and increase the cost of speculation in the forwards market.

site_title: GE2015: PAP to face WP at Nee Soon GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its lineup for the Nee Soon Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore's 2015 general election. The team consists of K Shanmugam, Lee Bee Wah, Faishal Ibrahim, Louis Ng, and Henry Kwek. They will face the Workers' Party team led by Kenneth Foo, Cheryl Denise Loh, Luke Koh, Ron Tan, and Gurmit Singh. The election is set to take place, with the PAP team looking to retain the GRC.

site_title: GE2015: WP and PAP Hougang SMC nomination papers up
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) and People's Action Party (PAP) have filed nomination papers for Hougang Single Member Constituency (SMC) in Singapore's General Election 2015. WP candidate Png Eng Huat, who won the 2012 by-election, faces PAP's Lee Hong Chuang, a new face. The WP has held Hougang since 1991, and Mr. Png won with 62.1% of the votes in the 2012 by-election. The nomination papers were filed at the Poi Ching nomination centre, marking the start of the election process.

site_title: GE2015: Nominations close with few surprises
summary: Singapore's General Election 2015 nominations closed with no major surprises, with last-minute changes in Aljunied GRC not materializing. Meanwhile, globally, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and policymakers face pressure. In other news, Citigroup predicts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026, and Thaksin Shinawatra is confident his daughter will be cleared in an ethics case. In regional news, Asean agrees that Myanmar's election is not a priority, and the UK economy shrinks for the second month in a row.

site_title: GE2015: First WP rally on Wednesday
summary: Workers' Party chief Low Thia Khiang announced the party's first rally will be held at Hougang on Wednesday, a stronghold for the party that has held the single-member constituency for over two decades.

images.alt_text: Workers' Party (WP) secretary-general Low Thia Khiang (R) gestures to his team of candidates as they arrive to submit papers during nomination day, ahead of the general elections in Singapore on Sep 1, 2015.

site_title: Singapore stocks open marginally higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened marginally higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index up 0.88 points to 2,922.32. The most actively traded stock was Ezra Holdings, which rose 2.3% to 13.3 Singapore cents. Losers outnumbered gainers 86 to 61, despite overall gains.

site_title: South Korea president says labour reforms vital, urges unions to cooperate
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye urged labour unions to cooperate with the government's push for labour reforms, calling for "major surgery" to revamp the country's rigid labour structure. The government aims to make wages dependent on function and performance, ease hiring and firing, and shorten working hours. Despite relatively low unemployment, a large wage divide exists between regular and temporary workers. Unions are resisting proposals, citing concerns over harsh measures, but the country's business lobby groups welcomed the reforms. The government plans to submit amendments to labour laws for parliament's approval later this year.

site_title: GE2015: East Coast GRC pits Lim Swee Say-led PAP against Gerald Giam-led WP
summary: The 2015 General Election (GE2015) in Singapore saw East Coast GRC, considered one of the most contested constituencies, pitted against each other the People's Action Party (PAP) led by Lim Swee Say and the Workers' Party (WP) led by Gerald Giam. The PAP team, comprising Lim Swee Say, Lee Yi Shyan, Mohamad Maliki Osman, and Jessica Tan, faced off against the WP team, consisting of Gerald Giam, Daniel Goh, Leon Perera, and Mohamed Fairoz Shariff. East Coast GRC had previously been the PAP's worst-performing GRC in the 2011 General Election.

site_title: GE2015: PAP to face off with SingFirst in Jurong GRC
summary: The 2015 Singapore General Election (GE2015) sees a straight fight between the People's Action Party (PAP) and Singaporeans First in Jurong GRC. The PAP team, led by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, will face off against SingFirst, led by chemist David Foo. The PAP team won 66.96% of the vote in the 2011 polls, but SingFirst claims Jurong residents want change, leading to the party's decision to contest the five-seat GRC. The nine-day campaign period begins immediately.

site_title: GE2015: DPP-SPP to challenge PAP in Bishan-Toa Payoh
summary: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Singapore People's Party (SPP) have formed a joint team to challenge the incumbent People's Action Party (PAP) in the Bishan-Toa Payoh ward during the 2015 General Elections. The PAP team, led by Ng Eng Hen, will face opposition from the DPP-SPP team, which includes Ben Pwee, Hamim Aliyas, and others. This move marks a significant challenge to the PAP's dominance in the area.

site_title: GE2015: Charles Chong and Lee Li Lian to face off in Punggol East SMC
summary: In the 2015 Singapore general election, incumbent Lee Li Lian will face People's Action Party candidate Charles Chong in the Punggol East SMC. Chong, a 62-year-old veteran politician, seeks to win the seat from Lee, who won it in a 2013 by-election with 54.5% of the vote.

site_title: Update: Malaysia stocks rally most since 2013 as Bersih protests end, oil jumps
summary: Malaysia's stocks surged 2.9% on Tuesday, the largest gain since May 2013, after Bersih protests calling for Prime Minister Najib Razak's resignation ended peacefully. Oil producers rallied, with SapuraKencana Petroleum jumping 8.1%, and the ringgit strengthened 0.9% against the US dollar. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index rose to 1.1% and the nation's markets closed for holidays on Monday. This marks a reversal of the 15% decline in the index since July 2014 due to political uncertainty and slumping oil prices.

site_title: GE2015: Campaign should focus on issues concerning Singapore's future, says PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged the nine-day GE2015 campaign to focus on issues concerning the country's future, rather than just party loyalty. He emphasized that the campaign should discuss the candidates' characters, records, and abilities. The PAP team filed their nomination papers to contest in Ang Mo Kio GRC.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: GE2015: SDP's line-up in 5 battlegrounds; Chee Soon Juan set to lead Holland-Bukit Timah GRC team
summary: Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) chief Chee Soon Juan is set to lead a team in the Holland-Bukit Timah Group Representation Constituency, his first contest since 2011. The team, comprising Paul Tambyah, Sidek Mallek, and Khung Wai Yeen, will contest the upcoming election.

site_title: GE2015: PAP's Khaw seeks support for plans; NSP wants to be people's "voice"
summary: Singapore's General Election 2015: The People's Action Party (PAP) candidate Khaw Boon Wan sought support for his party's plans, while the National Solidarity Party (NSP) leader Spencer Ng announced the party's intention to contest the Sembawang GRC in a straight fight with the PAP, vowing to represent the electorate and hold the incumbents accountable.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down, tracking regional bourses; China fears in focus
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 1.2% on Tuesday, following Asian markets, amid concerns over China's slowing economy. Economists predict China's factory activity contracted at its fastest pace in three years in August, fuelling fears of a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy. The TAIEX index closed at 8,076.58, down from the previous session's close of 8,174.92.

site_title: GE2015: SDA is confident, committed, says chief Desmond Lim
summary: The Singapore Democratic Alliance (SDA) is confident and committed to contesting the Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC in the 2015 General Election, with Chairman Desmond Lim Bak Chuan leading the team. The SDA is expected to face the People's Action Party team, led by Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean.

site_title: Vietnam, in economic reform drive, eases foreign ownership caps on some stocks
summary: Vietnam has eased foreign ownership caps on some stocks, allowing for up to 100% foreign shareholdings in eligible firms. This move is part of the country's economic reform drive and aims to increase investor appeal. Vietnam is also bidding to have its VN Index included in MSCI's emerging market index, which could further boost investor interest. However, confusion over which sectors are eligible may dim investor appeal.

site_title: Oil prices drop 3% as investors retreat from overnight gains
summary: Oil prices dropped 3% in Asian trade on Tuesday, reversing overnight gains of over 8%. Investors covered short positions and took profits after Brent and US crude surged due to Opec's willingness to discuss price stability. US crude climbed 27.5% in the previous session, the largest three-day increase since 2011, driven by lower US output data. Despite the fall, the global oil market remains over supplied, and a decline in US production is likely in 2016, according to Morgan Stanley.

site_title: China official services PMI falls to 53.4 in August
summary: China's official non-manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 53.4 in August, down from 53.9 in July, indicating a cooling growth in the services industry. This adds to concerns about a potential sharper slowdown in the world's second-largest economy. A reading below 50 points suggests a contraction, further raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: GE2015: Tanjong Pagar GRC to see first contest in 27 years
summary: Singapore's Tanjong Pagar GRC will hold its first electoral contest in nearly 30 years, with the PAP team led by Chan Chun Sing facing off against a SingFirst team led by Tan Jee Say. The PAP lineup includes Chan Chun Sing, Melvin Yong, Joan Pereira, Indranee Rajah, and Chia Shi-Lu. The contest comes after former PM Lee Kuan Yew's death in March.

site_title: Gold gains as equities, dollar retreat; Fed hike view caps rise
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to $1,139.60 an ounce, driven by equities' decline and dollar weakness, amid expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike this month. Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer said inflation may rebound, allowing the Fed to gradually raise rates. However, gold's upside potential is limited by the Fed's potential rate hike, which could also boost the dollar.

site_title: GE2015: Residents will make choices on national and local issues, say ministers
summary: Singaporean residents will vote in the 2015 general election to choose their representatives for national and local issues. The election will involve three levels of decision-making: choosing the government, selecting parliament members, and electing town council representatives. Law and Foreign Affairs Minister K Shanmugam emphasized the importance of residents making informed choices on these levels to ensure their aspirations and needs are represented. The election is expected to take place, but no specific date has been announced.

site_title: GE2015: Gan Kim Yong responds to PPP chief's debate challenge
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong responded to People's Power Party chief Goh Meng Seng's debate challenge on healthcare issues, stating he does not see a need for an open debate. Gan cited extensive public consultations, including Our Singapore Conversations, as evidence that healthcare policies have been thoroughly discussed. He also mentioned separate consultations on Medishield Life and ageing population matters, indicating the government has already engaged with the public on these issues.

site_title: Ringgit climbs with Malaysian stocks as political rallies pass peacefully
summary: Malaysian stocks rose for a fifth day, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index increasing 0.6% to 1,622.73, as the ringgit appreciated 0.9% to 4.1560 per US dollar after weekend protests calling for Prime Minister Najib Razak's resignation ended peacefully. The rally was aided by an overnight surge in oil prices, following a 17-year low of 4.2990 reached on August 26. Markets reopened after the National Day holiday, providing a boost to the local economy.

site_title: Chinese Global Investors to resume trading; selling waterproofing unit
summary: Chinese Global Investors Group shares resumed trading on Tuesday after being halted since August 28. The company reported a 34.5% net profit growth for the year ended June 2015, with a net profit of S$867,066 for its fiscal fourth quarter. Additionally, the investment holding company plans to sell its core waterproofing subsidiary for S$3.28 million.

site_title: GE2015: Nominations up for Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC
summary: Nominations have been put up for the Marsiling-Yew Tee Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore's 2015 general elections. The People's Action Party (PAP) team consists of Lawrence Wong, Halimah Yacob, Ong Teng Koon, and Alex Yam, while the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) team comprises John Tan, Bryan Lim Boon Heng, Damanhuri Abas, and Wong Souk Yee. The GRC was created this year to address population growth in the area.

site_title: Asia: Shares nervous ahead of China data
summary: Asian shares were nervous on Tuesday ahead of China's economic data, which could raise fears about its economy. The dollar struggled, and US stock futures fell 1% as investors braced for potential US interest rate hike in September. China's official factory sector activity likely shrank at its fastest pace in three years, and its shares skidded 12% in August. Asian neighbors, such as South Korea and Japan, also reported declining exports and stock indexes. The Australian dollar edged down ahead of interest rate decisions, and commodities trading was affected by US employment data that could influence interest rates.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall as Toshiba plunges on new accounting problems
summary: Tokyo's stocks fell for a second day, with the Topix index posting its worst monthly loss in three years, due to concerns about China's slowing economy and Toshiba's new accounting problems. Toshiba plummeted after discovering 10 new cases of irregularities, while Pioneer Corp jumped 5.5% after developing an inexpensive optical system for self-driving cars. The Nikkei 225 Stock Average also fell 1.5% to 18,601.78, amid a weakening yen and a predicted decline in China's manufacturing industry.

site_title: South Korea's exports fall most since 2009 in August
summary: South Korea's exports plummeted 14.7% in August, the largest decline since 2009, due to weaker overseas demand. The nation's exports, which generate half of its GDP, are unlikely to post growth this year. Imports fell 18.3% to leave a trade surplus of $4.35 billion. The decline is attributed to uncertainties in emerging economies, including China, and increasing competition from Chinese companies.

images.alt_text: Shipping freight rates for transporting containers from ports in Asia to Northern Europe jumped 29 per cent to US$763 per 20-foot container (TEU) this week data from the Shanghai Shipping Exchange showed.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index falls more than 3.0% in afternoon trade
summary: Tokyo shares plummeted 3.21% in late afternoon trading on Tuesday, following Chinese shares lower due to disappointing manufacturing data. The Nikkei index dropped 606.34 points to 18,284.14, while the Topix index fell 3.37% to 1,485.28. The decline is attributed to a slowdown in Asia's top economy.

site_title: GE2015: Straight fight in Bukit Panjang SMC, Holland-Bukit Timah GRC
summary: In the 2015 Singapore general election, incumbent MP Dr. Teo Ho Pin (PAP) will face a straight fight from SDP's Khung Wai Yeen in the Bukit Panjang SMC. Dr. Teo, 55, has held the seat since 2006. Meanwhile, PAP's lineup in the Holland-Bukit Timah GRC remains unchanged, with Vivian Balakrishnan leading the team. The election marks a rematch between Dr. Teo and Khung, who was first elected in 2011.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Thailand approves stimulus measures to help stumbling economy
summary: Thailand's military government approved stimulus measures to boost rural spending power, aiming to lift economic growth. The measures include soft loans via village funds and speedy disbursement for smaller projects. The government aims to help low-income earners, struggling to cope with the stumbling economy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SembMarine, Singtel, Chinese Global Investors
summary: SembCorp Marine clinched a US$1 billion contract to build topsides for the Culzean Field development in the North Sea. Singapore Telecommunications completed its purchase of Trustwave for US$770 million, down from the initial US$810 million price. Chinese Global Investors Group shares will resume trading after being halted, despite announcing a 34.5% net profit growth and plans to sell its core subsidiary. Croesus Retail Trust reevaluated its acquisition strategy amid market turmoil, citing increased risk.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Marine has clinched a more than US$1 billion engineering, procurement and construction contract to build three topsides for the Culzean Field development in the North Sea.

site_title: GE2015: PAP and NSP file Tampines GRC nomination papers
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has filed nomination papers for the Tampines Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore's 2015 general election, defending its seat against the National Solidarity Party (NSP) team led by Sebastian Teo. The PAP won the GRC in 2011 with 57.22% of the vote. This marks the start of the election campaign in the constituency.

images.alt_text: Education minister, Heng Swee Keat leads the team for Tampines GRC.

site_title: GE2015: Ravi Philemon wants to give security and hope to Hong Kah North
summary: Ravi Philemon, a candidate for the Hong Kah North Single Member Constituency, has filed his nomination papers as part of the Singapore People's Party. He aims to provide security and hope for the future to the constituency's residents, competing against incumbent Amy Khor of the People's Action Party.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: GE2015: Reform Party contests in West Coast GRC again
summary: The Reform Party (RP) will contest against the People Action's Party (PAP) in the West Coast GRC for a second time, with a team led by Kenneth Jeyaretnam. The RP secured 33.43% of the vote in West Coast in 2011, while PAP won 66.6%. The RP's team claims to be a more relatable alternative, promising to press the government on national issues for a better deal. The election is part of the 2015 General Election in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Reform Party (RP) will be contesting against the incumbent People Action's Party (PAP) in the West Coast GRC for a second time.

site_title: Yahoo's chief Marissa Mayer says expecting twins in December
summary: Marissa Mayer, Yahoo's CEO, announced she is pregnant with identical twin girls due in December. Mayer plans to take limited time away from her role and work throughout the pregnancy, as she did with her son. The news has been shared with the board and executive team, and Mayer stated that both her family and Yahoo will require "hard work and thoughtful prioritization" as the company prepares to spin off its Alibaba stake in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Marissa Mayer, chief executive officer of Yahoo! Inc, said she is pregnant with identical twin girls that are due in December.

site_title: Australia: Shares down sharply as China PMIs inflame export worries
summary: Australian shares plummeted 2.1% to their lowest close in a week as China's manufacturing activity contracted in August, fuelling export worries. The Reserve Bank of Australia's decision not to cut interest rates also contributed to the downturn. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 5,096.4, its lowest finish since August 24, marking a 10% decline since the start of August.

site_title: Macau's gambling revenue tumbles 35.5% in August
summary: Macau's gambling revenue plummeted 35.5% in August from the same period last year, marking the 15th consecutive month of decline, due to China's economic slowdown and a broader crackdown on conspicuous spending. Casino revenues dropped to 18.6 billion patacas, matching June's figures, with forecasted declines ranging from 36-38%. The slump is attributed to a combination of factors, including the economic downturn and increased regulations.

site_title: Explosions at factory in southern Japan
summary: Explosions occurred at an aluminium plating factory in Kitakyushu, southern Japan, on Tuesday. Multiple explosions and a fire damaged the plant, but no one was injured as six employees escaped. The fire was under control by mid-morning. The cause is believed to be vapour explosions from a furnace, possibly triggered by water entering the melting process.

site_title: GE2015: SDP to contest in Yuhua SMC
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) announced its candidate for the Yuhua Single Member Constituency (SMC) in the 2015 General Election, Jaslyn Go, a sales director and mother of two. She will contest against incumbent Member of Parliament Grace Fu from the People's Action Party (PAP). This marks Go's second attempt at contesting Yuhua, having previously been considered in 2011.

site_title: Japan Q2 capex growth slows, keeps pressure for more economic stimulus
summary: Japan's corporate capital expenditure grew 5.6% in Q2, slowing from the previous quarter and adding to economic concerns. The data, which excludes software spending, fell 2.7% seasonally-adjusted from the previous quarter. Corporate profits jumped 23.8% and sales rose 1.1%, but economists worry about persistent weakness in private consumption and exports. Policymakers are under pressure to top up stimulus, with a possible GDP growth rebound expected to be modest in the current quarter due to rising costs and sluggish demand.

images.alt_text: Japanese corporate capital expenditure increased 5.6 per cent in April-June from a year ago, slowing from the previous quarter and adding to signs of an economy struggling to recover from a slump.

site_title: Australia city home prices rises 0.3% in Aug: RPData
summary: Australia's major cities saw a 0.3% increase in home prices in August, according to CoreLogic RP Data. This slowdown in growth, from 2.8% in July, is a positive sign for regulators cracking down on lending to property investors. However, annual growth remains high, with Sydney experiencing a 17.6% gain and Melbourne a 10.6% gain. Regulators have tightened lending standards to keep annual growth in credit at 10% or less. The housing market will be tested in the spring season, with listings and buyer demand to be closely monitored.

site_title: GE2015: Ang Mo Kio GRC's and Sengkang West SMC's line-up finalised
summary: Singapore's 2015 general election is set to take place on September 11, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's People's Action Party (PAP) team facing off against the opposition Reform Party (RP). The PAP's Ang Mo Kio GRC team will remain unchanged, while the RP's team will also retain its original lineup. In Sengkang West SMC, incumbent Minister of State for Health Lam Pin Min will compete against Workers' Party candidate Koh Choong Yong.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: GE2015: Worker's Party Aljunied team set to defend ward
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) in Singapore's Aljunied GRC appears set to defend the ward on Nomination Day, with incumbent MPs expected to retain their seats. Party chief Low Thia Khiang arrived at the WP Hougang Town Council to meet supporters and discuss the election campaign.

site_title: GE2015: Three-cornered fight for MacPherson SMC between PAP, WP and NSP
summary: In Singapore's 2015 General Elections, a surprise twist emerged in the MacPherson Single Member Constituency (SMC) as National Solidarity Party (NSP) candidate Cheo Chai Chen announced his candidacy on Nomination Day. The SMC was initially expected to be a two-cornered fight between the People's Action Party (PAP) and the Workers' Party (WP). However, Cheo's entry adds a third contender, potentially altering the electoral dynamics.

site_title: Australia keeps interest rates at record low
summary: Australia's central bank kept interest rates at a historic low of 2.0% on Tuesday, citing moderate economic expansion and contained inflation. The Reserve Bank of Australia played down recent global volatility, noting the global economy was expanding at a moderate pace. Analysts say the decision suggests further rate cuts have receded, with Westpac predicting rates to remain on hold over the next two years.

site_title: Singtel completes Trustwave acquisition at lower price
summary: Singtel has completed its acquisition of Trustwave for US$770 million, a US$40 million reduction from the initial price of US$810 million. The deal was completed after working capital adjustments. Trustwave chairman Robert J McCulen retains a 2% stake in the firm. The acquisition is part of Singtel's efforts to expand its cyber security capabilities.

site_title: China new home prices in first annual rise for 11 months: survey
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.15% year-over-year in August, marking the first annual increase in 11 months, according to a survey by the China Index Academy. The average cost per square meter rose to 10,787 yuan, with prices increasing 0.95% on a month-on-month basis. The central bank's monetary easing policies and reduced reserve requirements have boosted demand, with the government also lowering minimum downpayment levels for second homes to 20%. This move aims to support the property sector, a key driver of China's economy.

site_title: Peter Seah appointed SIA deputy chairman
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) appointed Peter Seah as its deputy chairman, effective September 1, 2025. Seah, a 69-year-old banking veteran with over 30 years of experience, brings extensive business expertise from various boards, including DBS Group Holdings, Fullerton Financial Holdings, and Global Crossing.

site_title: US weighs China sanctions after cyber hack
summary: The US is considering economic sanctions against Chinese firms and individuals involved in cyber attacks on American targets. Following a series of hacking attacks blamed on China, the administration plans a "comprehensive strategy" including diplomatic engagement, trade policy tools, law enforcement mechanisms, and sanctions. The move comes after President Barack Obama signed an executive order allowing for tougher sanctions against "malicious cyber actors." Sanctions could have global consequences and are likely to be controversial, particularly with China President Xi Jinping's upcoming state visit to Washington.

site_title: Thai August consumer prices fall for 8th straight month
summary: Thai consumer prices dropped 1.19% in August, the eighth consecutive month, due to lower oil prices. This decline gives the central bank leeway to keep interest rates low, supporting a sputtering economy. The core inflation rate fell to 0.89% in August, down from 0.94% in July. The central bank has limited scope to ease monetary policy further, with economists expecting no change in its policy review on September 16.

images.alt_text: Thailand's annual headline consumer prices dropped for an eighth straight month in August, mainly due to lower oil prices, giving the central bank leeway to keep interest rates low to support a sputtering economy.

site_title: Oil prices leap 8% on lower US output, Opec signal
summary: US oil benchmark West Texas Intermediate jumped 8.8% to $49.20 a barrel, while Brent crude rose 8.2% to $54.15 a barrel, following the US Department of Energy's lower domestic production estimate and Opec's signal that it's "ready to talk" about multi-year low prices, which analysts cast doubt on.

images.alt_text: Oil prices surged higher on Monday as the US government lowered its domestic production estimate and Opec said it was "ready to talk" to producers about multi-year low prices.

site_title: GE2015: Amy Khor, Ravi Philemon file nomination papers for Hong Kah North
summary: Amy Khor of the People's Action Party (PAP) and Ravi Philemon of the Singapore People's Party (SPP) have filed their nomination papers to contest Hong Kah North Single Member Constituency in the upcoming general election. Dr. Khor, the incumbent and Senior Minister of State for Health and Manpower, is seeking a fourth term. Ravi Philemon, a blogger and social worker, has quit his job to contest the election due to employment contract restrictions. The general election is set to take place, with the outcome expected to influence the future of Singapore's government.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

Amy Khor of People's Action Party (left) and Ravi Philemon of Singapore People's Party (SPP) have filed their nomination papers to stand as candidates for Hong Kah North Single Member Constituency in the upcoming general election.

site_title: Going strong for sustainable growth
summary: Sudima International, a timber trading company under the LNJ Group, has achieved sustainable growth through its focus on long-term sustainability and corporate social responsibility. Founded in 1994, Sudima has expanded its interests to over 17 countries, offering a range of products and services. The company prioritizes relationship building and maintaining trust with customers and suppliers, which has enabled it to weather the 2008 global financial crisis. Sudima's efforts in forward integration and diversification have also helped it achieve accelerated growth of around 10% annually.

site_title: Yuan opens firmer on higher official fix
summary: China's yuan opened firmer at 6.3750 per dollar after a higher official fix of 6.3752 per dollar. The spot market traded at 6.3750, 13 pips below the previous close. The offshore yuan was 1.05% below the onshore spot. This firmer opening comes amid concerns about China's GDP growth slowing, which may put pressure on policymakers.

site_title: GE2015: Policy debates, no smearing: PPP chief
summary: Singapore's People's Power Party (PPP) chief Goh Meng Seng focused on policy debates during the 2015 general election, rejecting smear campaigns against opposition candidates. Goh challenged health minister Gan Kim Yong to a debate on healthcare issues. The PPP nominated candidates for the Chua Chu Kang GRC, while the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) retained its team, including Gan Kim Yong and Low Yen Ling.

images.alt_text: The People's Power Party (PPP) chief Goh Meng Seng on Tuesday said he is only interested in policy debates this election, not smearing.

site_title: India grows slower than estimated, increasing pressure on Modi
summary: India's GDP grew 7% in the April-June quarter, slower than the estimated 7.4% and down from a 7.5% expansion in the previous quarter. This boost pressure on Prime Minister Narendra Modi to make progress in overhauling the country's economy. Despite this, India is expected to be less impacted than other countries by developments in China, which is also experiencing slowing growth.

site_title: Fitch warns of downgrade risk in Malaysia's rating outlook
summary: Fitch Ratings warns of a potential downgrade in Malaysia's credit rating due to the country's deteriorating currency position, shrinking current account surplus, and ongoing political uncertainty. The warning comes after a recent Wall Street Journal article sparked a political storm surrounding Prime Minister Najib Razak's alleged ties to a state fund. Fitch's Head of Asia-Pacific Sovereigns Rating, Andrew Colquhoun, notes that the controversy could distract policymakers and undermine reform momentum, posing a risk to the country's credit rating.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide at open
summary: Europe's stock markets declined on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.96% to 6,187.93, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 falling 1.81% to 10,073.74. The Paris CAC 40 dropped 1.43% to 4,586.33. Investors were concerned about the Chinese economy, while US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty also weighed on markets.

site_title: Brazil government budget goes into the red
summary: Brazil's government presented a 2016 budget that projects a primary deficit of 0.5% of GDP, marking the first time the country's economy will operate in the red. The budget predicts 5.4% inflation and 0.2% GDP growth, sparking worries about the country's investment-grade rating. Markets reacted sharply, with the real plummeting 1.1% and the Sao Paulo stock market losing 1.12%. The budget's failure follows recent downbeat economic news and political turmoil, raising concerns about the country's ability to manage its debt load.

site_title: Globalisation is quietly rewriting economic rules
summary: Globalisation is rewriting economic rules, with recent financial turmoil highlighting its international nature. China's economic slowdown and devaluation of the renminbi triggered a global stock market downturn, affecting commodity prices and fueling concerns about emerging markets. The rapid shift of capital across borders has created new vulnerabilities, including currency mismatches and a "global savings glut" that can influence long-term interest rates. Economists argue that globalisation has diminished countries' control over their interest rates, particularly for emerging markets, and that the internationalisation of finance has created new economic risks.

site_title: Scandal-hit Toshiba keeps Muromachi as president
summary: Toshiba has appointed Masashi Muromachi as president, amid an accounting scandal that may cost the company at least $1.2 billion. Muromachi, 65, has spent 40 years with Toshiba in its semiconductor business and was chosen due to his management skills. The company expects to report a net loss for the 12 months ended March and has taken steps to revitalize its board and prevent future improprieties. No charges have been filed against Toshiba or its executives, and the company has lowered pay for eight executives.

site_title: 'Largest ever' gas field in Mediterranean found off Egypt
summary: Italian energy giant Eni announced the discovery of the "largest ever" offshore natural gas field in the Mediterranean, located off Egypt's territorial waters. The Zohr project is estimated to hold 30 trillion cubic feet of gas and could meet Egypt's natural gas demands for decades. The discovery is expected to be developed in four years, with Eni's CEO stating that it could transform Egypt's energy scenario. The find is significant, given Egypt's strategic and economic interest to Italy and comes as the country faces a wave of attacks by the Islamic State group.

site_title: GE2015: Three-cornered fight looming at Bt Batok SMC
summary: A three-cornered fight is brewing in Bukit Batok Single Member Constituency in Singapore's 2015 general election, with independent candidate Samir Salim Neji joining the contest between PAP incumbent David Ong and Singapore Democratic Party candidate Sadasivam Veriyah. The constituency was carved out as a single seat under new electoral boundaries revealed last month. The election is significant, as Bukit Batok was previously part of the Jurong Group Representation Constituency. The outcome will be closely watched, as it may indicate a shift in the balance of power in Singapore.

images.alt_text: At Bukit Batok SMC, the candidates are PAP's David Ong, SDP's Sadasivam Veriyah and independent Samir Salim Neji.

site_title: Belgium plans collection of plane, train, ferry users' data
summary: Belgium plans to collect data on airline passengers, as well as international train and ferry travelers, following a foiled attack on a train between Belgium and Paris. Interior Minister Jan Jambon proposed a European PNR system, which has been considered since 2011, to tighten security on trains. The plan aims to check identities and prevent potential threats, with the goal of implementing the system by the end of the year. This is the first time a country has suggested extending the measure to trains and boats.

site_title: Asia: Stocks extend losses as Shanghai hit by more weak data
summary: Asian stocks extended losses on Tuesday, with Shanghai plummeting 3.20% due to weak data on China's manufacturing activity. The Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 49.7, its lowest since August 2012, sparking concerns about the global economy. Other regional markets, including Hong Kong and Tokyo, also declined. Investors are seeking safer assets, such as gold and the yen, amid fears of a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: GE2015: Party candidates moving out to nomination centres
summary: Candidates for the 2015 Singapore general election began moving to nomination centers, with some experiencing minor issues such as bus breakdowns. The election is expected to take place soon. In unrelated news, a Malaysian agency is set to seize approximately RM3 billion in assets from Daim Zainuddin, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

images.alt_text: Some PAP candidates including Khaw Boon Wan (right) heading to the nomination centre.

site_title: GE2015: Independent candidate Tan Lam Siong pulls out of Potong Pasir
summary: Independent candidate Tan Lam Siong has pulled out of the Potong Pasir SMC contest, making it unlikely for a three-cornered fight at the polls. He would have faced incumbent Sitoh Yih Pin from the People's Action Party and challenger Lina Chiam of the Singapore People's Party.

site_title: GE2015: List of designated sites for election rallies
summary: Singapore police have released a list of designated sites for election rallies for the 2015 general election, which can be held between 7am and 10pm from September 2-9. The list will be announced after permit applications close on September 1.

site_title: BOC Aviation H1 profit up on higher revenue, lower impairment
summary: BOC Aviation reported a 5% increase in first-half net profit to US$171.5 million, driven by a 2.9% rise in revenue to US$535 million. Impairment on aircraft decreased to US$13.6 million from US$38.8 million last year. The company's credit rating was upgraded to "A-" and its average annual cost of debt is at 2%. BOC Aviation added two new airline customers, increasing its reach to 61 airlines in 30 countries, and has 195 aircraft on order with deliveries scheduled through 2021.

site_title: ForeScout hopes to replicate cybersecurity peers' IPO success
summary: ForeScout Technologies Inc, a cybersecurity company specializing in network access control, aims to replicate the success of its peers who went public in the past year. Under CEO Mike DeCesare, the company expects revenue to reach $150 million this year, driven by a surge in demand for cybersecurity solutions amid high-profile data breaches. ForeScout has raised $80 million from investors and is preparing for a listing in 2016, capitalizing on the trend of companies like FireEye and Palo Alto Networks.

site_title: South Korea Q2 short-term external debt burden rises vs Q1
summary: South Korea's ratio of short-term external debt to foreign exchange reserves rose to 32.3% in Q2, the highest in nine months, as debt increased faster than reserves. Short-term external debt rose to $121.2 billion, while foreign reserves increased to $374.8 billion. This marks a reversal from Q1, when reserves outpaced debt. The data suggests South Korea's debt burden is rising, but still remains below past levels.

site_title: US: Stocks close lower: S&P loses 0.84%
summary: US stocks closed lower on Monday, with the S&P 500 losing 0.84%, as investors sold down shares amid worries over China's slowdown. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 114.98 points, finishing at 16,528.03. Global markets also declined, with Tokyo and Shanghai exchanges falling and Europe's major bourses sagging, except for London, which was closed for a banking holiday. The US market's losses followed a turbulent week, with investors seeking caution amid trade uncertainty and tariff concerns.

site_title: SpaceX delays next launch after blast
summary: SpaceX has delayed its next launch of the Falcon 9 rocket by a couple of months due to the June explosion that destroyed a cargo mission to the International Space Station. The blast occurred just minutes after takeoff from Cape Canaveral, Florida, and caused NASA to lose at least $110 million in equipment. SpaceX's chief operating officer, Gwynne Shotwell, stated that the company is being cautious in its pursuit of safety, taking extra time to ensure that no similar issues arise. The new launch date is still set for September.

site_title: SembMarine wins US$1b North Sea contract
summary: SembCorp Marine has secured a US$1 billion contract to build three topsides for the Culzean Field development in the North Sea. The project includes a central processing facility, bridges, wellhead platform, and living quarters platform for Maersk Oil North Sea UK. The contract, won by SembCorp Marine's unit SMOE Pte Ltd, involves engineering, procurement, construction, and onshore pre-commissioning services. The project is valued at over US$1 billion, with detailed engineering work to be performed by a subcontracting partner.

site_title: GE2015: Mountbatten SMC candidates confirmed
summary: The People's Action Party's Lim Biow Chuan will defend his seat in Mountbatten SMC against Singapore People's Party's Jeanette Chong-Aruldoss in the 2015 General Election.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Surprise fall in Japan's July industrial output
summary: Japan's industrial output unexpectedly fell 0.6% in July, contrary to expectations of a 0.1% increase, due to high inventories and weak overseas demand. This decline follows a 1.1% rise in June. Some economists are scaling back their expectations, suggesting a possible recession, and are calling for fiscal stimulus. The Bank of Japan is concerned about the impact on inflation, which it aims to reach 2%. The economy is expected to recover in July-September, but growth could be weaker than forecast due to weak domestic and export demand.

site_title: GE2015: PAP team points out error in RP form, averting possible walkover in West Coast GRC
summary: In the 2015 Singapore general election, a team of PAP candidates discovered an error in the nomination forms of the Reform Party (RP) candidate for the West Coast GRC. The error was pointed out to RP leader Kenneth Jeyaretnam, potentially averting a walkover victory for the RP. The incident highlights the meticulous nature of the nomination process in Singapore's electoral system.

site_title: GE2015: Opposition set to challenge PAP in all 29 electoral divisions
summary: Singapore's General Election 2015: Up to eight opposition parties are set to contest all 29 electoral divisions, including 16 group representation constituencies and 13 single-member constituencies. The opposition parties have announced they will contest 89 seats, marking the first time since Singapore's independence that all seats will be contested. Nomination Day is scheduled for September 11, 2015.

images.alt_text: Singapore Democratic Party chief Chee Soon Juan at a walkabout in Bukit Timah on Aug 30.

site_title: GE2015: WP Aljunied team defends seat against PAP
summary: The Aljunied team from the Workers' Party (WP) will defend its seat against the People's Action Party (PAP) in the 2015 General Election. WP candidates include Low Thia Khiang, Sylvia Lim, and Pritam Singh, while the PAP team consists of Yeo Guat Kwang, Victor Lye, and Chua Eng Leong. The election will take place this year, with the outcome yet to be determined.

images.alt_text: WP outside the nomination hall at Raffles Institution.

site_title: Apple partners to boost business use of iPads-iPhones
summary: Apple and computer network titan Cisco have partnered to optimize Cisco networks for Apple's iOS devices, aiming to boost business use of iPhones and iPads. The partnership will provide a "fast lane" for devices and applications running on iOS. Apple CEO Tim Cook stated that nearly every Fortune 500 and Global 500 company uses iOS as part of their mobile strategy. The partnership aims to simplify business operations and improve overall efficiency.

site_title: SunMoon: Debt restructuring reaped benefits
summary: SunMoon, a Singapore-based fruit distributor, has benefited from debt restructuring, saving S$2 million annually in interest. The 2013 restructuring, led by Gary Loh's private equity firm, prevented the company from becoming insolvent and restored its Ebitda to positive territory since 2009. SunMoon reported a Q2 profit of S$66,000, a 20% increase in revenue, and a market capitalisation of S$12.8 million. The company is facing a challenge from shareholders seeking to oust Loh as executive chairman at an extraordinary general meeting on October 5.

site_title: Obama to test wilderness skills on Bear Grylls TV show
summary: President Barack Obama will appear on the TV show "Running Wild" with British adventurer Bear Grylls in an Alaska adventure, marking the first time a US president has been on the show. The episode will test Obama's wilderness survival skills and explore the effects of climate change on the area. The show will be taped and air on NBC later this year. This appearance comes during Obama's three-day visit to Alaska focused on climate change.

images.alt_text: President Barack Obama will test his wilderness survival skills with an appearance on the television show "Running Wild" in an Alaska adventure that will air later this year, the network NBC said on Monday.

site_title: Greeks fight ballot box fatigue with Internet jokes
summary: Greeks are using internet humor to cope with election fatigue, with comedienne Lila Stabouloglou joking that "electoral tourism" could be a money-maker for the cash-strapped Greek government. The idea is to promote Greece as a tourist destination during the election period, which starts in three weeks. This lighthearted approach aims to lift spirits and make voting more appealing, as Greeks face their third election in eight months.

images.alt_text: Called to the ballot box for the third time in eight months, some Greeks are responding to election fatigue with a bailout-sized dose of Internet humour.

site_title: GE2015: All 89 seats to be contested for the first time since Independence
summary: Singapore is set to hold its 9th general election, with all 89 seats to be contested for the first time since Independence. Three-corner fights have been confirmed in Bukit Batok, MacPherson, and Radin Mas Single Member Constituencies. Incumbent Sam Tan will face off against independent candidates in Radin Mas, while rookie candidate Bernard Chen of the Workers' Party will contest MacPherson against PAP and NSP candidates. The other 10 single-seat wards and 16 Group Representation Constituencies will see straight fights.

site_title: Quota system that helps India's disadvantaged castes comes under attack from the Patels
summary: Indian politician Hardik Patel, a 22-year-old leader of the Patel caste, has sparked widespread protests against the country's quota system, which reserves jobs and college slots for disadvantaged castes. Patel demands that his caste, considered too well-off to qualify, be included in the system, challenging the entrenched policies defended by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The protests, attended by 500,000 Patels, have raised questions about India's quota system and Modi's "Gujarat model" of prosperity, which has been called into question by Patel's supporters.

site_title: Asian market turmoil forces Croesus Retail Trust to rethink deal terms
summary: Croesus Retail Trust, a Singapore-based mall operator in Japan, is rethinking its deal terms due to the turmoil in global markets, which has led to a decline in real estate investment trusts in Asia. The trust's assets rose 28% to 100 billion yen in the year ended June 30, but its units slid 3.3% in August. Despite the caution, Croesus will continue to seek acquisitions outside of Tokyo, focusing on cities with good demographics and population growth. The trust's co-founder, Jeremy Yong, expects markets to stabilize in 2-3 weeks, allowing for sharper pricing and risk assessment.

images.alt_text: Croesus Retail Trust, which holds shopping malls in Japan, said the turmoil that has roiled global markets has forced the mall operator to rethink its acquisition strategy and deal terms to account for increased risk.

site_title: GE2015: Contesting teams file papers for Sembawang, Marsiling-Yew Tee, Nee Soon
summary: In Singapore, the contest for the Sembawang, Marsiling-Yew Tee, and Nee Soon Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) has begun, with opposition parties challenging the ruling People's Action Party (PAP). The Workers Party contests the PAP at Nee Soon GRC, while the National Solidarity Party (NSP) challenges the PAP at Sembawang GRC. The PAP has nominated prominent leaders, including Minister Khaw Boon Wan, for the Sembawang GRC.

site_title: New technology on trial may make fourth telco a viable proposition
summary: MyRepublic's upcoming trials of small cell technology in Singapore's Jurong Lake District area may pave the way for the country's fourth telco operator. The technology, which eliminates the need for expensive base stations, is being tested as part of the government's Smart Nation project. The trials aim to prove the feasibility of small cell technology and may lead to MyRepublic bidding for spectrum when the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) auctions 225 MHz of spectrum early next year. The goal is to increase competition in the mobile telephony market and drive innovation.

site_title: Solar, wind power costs drop as fossil fuel costs rise: IEA
summary: The cost of producing electricity from renewable sources like solar and wind has dropped significantly, with solar costs declining from $500 to $200 per megawatt hour over the past five years. In contrast, the median cost of generating electricity from natural gas, coal, and nuclear reactors increased from $200 to $100 per megawatt hour. This shift is seen as a key factor in efforts to curb climate-altering gases ahead of a Paris climate agreement in December. The International Energy Agency attributes the decline in renewable costs to decreasing resource costs and labor expenses.

site_title: China: Stocks fall at market open
summary: China's major stock indexes opened down, with the CSI300 index falling 2.1% to 3,296.53 points, and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 1.5% to 3,157.83 points, at 1:28 GMT on Tuesday.

site_title: Australia leaves rates unchanged as falling Aussie dollar cushions China-led commodity drop
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank left interest rates unchanged at a record-low 2% as predicted, citing a declining currency's cushion effect on lower commodity prices and China's weaker outlook. The currency has dropped over 2 US cents since the last meeting, reducing the need for further rate cuts. Despite a weakening economy, the labor market remains resilient, with unemployment at 6.3% in July, and economists predict a 2.2% growth rate in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Glenn Stevens and his board kept the cash rate at a record-low 2 per cent, as predicted by markets and economists following reductions in May and February.

site_title: GE2015: WP slate confirmed for East Coast GRC
summary: The Workers Party has confirmed its slate for the East Coast Group Representative Constituency in Singapore's 2015 general election. The team consists of Gerald Giam, Daniel Goh, Leon Perera, and Mohamed Fairoz Shariff. They will face PAP incumbents led by Lim Swee Say and Jessica Tan.

site_title: GE2015: Bukit Batok now a 3-cornered fight
summary: In the Bukit Batok single-member constituency, three candidates will contest the Singapore General Election 2015: David Ong of the People's Action Party (PAP), Sadasivam Veriyah of the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP), and independent candidate Samir Salim Neji. The three names were confirmed after Nomination Day proceedings on September 1. This marks a three-cornered fight for the constituency, where residents will have three options to choose from on polling day on September 11.

site_title: CapitaLand doubling EV charging stations in its S'pore properties (Amended)
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean property developer, is doubling its electric vehicle (EV) charging stations in its properties across Asia and Europe, with over 100 stations to be offered in more than 40 locations. This expansion will increase the number of public EV charging locations in Singapore to 31, with CapitaLand's properties accounting for nine locations. The move aims to support the growing demand for EVs, with global stock expected to reach 20 million by 2020.

site_title: Ex-US special agent pleads guilty to taking US$800k in Bitcoin
summary: A former US Secret Service special agent, Shaun Bridges, pleaded guilty to taking over $800,000 in Bitcoin during an investigation into the "Silk Road" online black market. Bridges, 32, admitted to money laundering and obstruction of justice. The Silk Road's creator was previously sentenced to life in prison for charges including money laundering and drug trafficking. Bridges' guilty plea was made while he was assigned to an electronic financial crime unit.

site_title: GE2015: People's Power Party team for Chua Chu Kang GRC revealed for the first time
summary: The People's Power Party (PPP) has announced its team for the Chua Chu Kang Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore's 2015 General Election. Led by party founder Goh Meng Seng, the team includes finance manager Low Wai Choo, property consultant Lee Tze Shih, and managing consultant Syafarin Sarif. The announcement comes after a secretive campaign, with the team not formally introducing its candidates until now. The PPP is contesting the sole battleground at the September 11 polls.

site_title: India's tribal people spin their way out of poverty, thanks to silkworms
summary: In eastern India, thousands of tribal villagers, like 40-year-old Munia Murmu, are breaking the cycle of poverty by rearing wild silkworms, which produce high-demand silk threads. The silkworms, traditionally used to make tasar copper-colored silk, are now being farmed using modern techniques, attracting new farmers and supplementing their traditional rice farming. The industry, which is India's second-largest silk producer, has helped the tribal communities improve their socio-economic status, earning them a relative fortune of $670 per month during the breeding season.

site_title: China's exports to improve in August, economy stable: NDRC
summary: China's exports are expected to improve in August, with the country's economy remaining stable, according to the National Development and Reform Commission. Vice chairman Ning Jizhe attributed recent housing market growth to stabilizing investment in the coming months. Despite persistent economic concerns, China's economic indicators in July were deemed normal fluctuations, not signs of a hard landing. Investors should focus on China's reform progress alongside GDP growth, Ning advised.

site_title: London's Notting Hill Carnival kicks off
summary: London's Notting Hill Carnival kicked off on Sunday with a vibrant display of Caribbean culture, despite grey skies. About 1 million people attended the two-day event, featuring colorful costumes, music, and Caribbean food. Police reported 92 arrests, including for thefts and assaults, amid concerns of gang-related violence and robbery. The carnival, which started in the 1960s, has become one of Europe's biggest street parties, with 6,000 police on duty on Sunday and 7,000 on Monday. The event is expected to continue despite predictions of lightning and heavy downpours on the finale parade.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall on China manufacturing data
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.54% on Tuesday after China's manufacturing sector contracted in August, according to official data. The Hang Seng Index dropped 116.49 points to 21,554.09. This latest data highlights a slowdown in the mainland economy, contributing to the decline in Hong Kong shares.

site_title: Samsung market value down US$44b over five months
summary: Samsung Electronics' market value dropped by US$44 billion over five months due to tepid demand for its newest Galaxy smartphones, with shares slumping 8.1% this month. This is Samsung's fifth consecutive monthly decline, the longest since December 1983. The company lost almost US$12 billion in value in August alone, surrendering market share to Apple and Chinese competitors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 43.74 points to 1655.47. The market saw 43.3 million lots traded worth RM45.6 million, with gains outnumbering losses 124 to 61.

site_title: US drafting potential sanctions, curbs over China cyber hacking: sources
summary: The US is drafting potential sanctions and curbs on China for its persistent cyber hacking of corporate networks, with measures including economic sanctions, curbs on US business, and cyber retaliation. The administration is considering actions against China, Russia, and other nations, but is cautious not to trigger further online warfare. The actions come amid tensions over Russia's actions in Ukraine and China's place as the US's second-largest trading partner. The US is also concerned about the theft of US trade and commercial data, with some officials believing China is seeking to blackmail or bribe officials with access to classified information.

site_title: Top Hong Kong banker says dollar peg vital for stability
summary: A top Standard Chartered China executive, Benjamin Hung, has stated that Hong Kong's dollar peg to the US dollar is crucial for maintaining market stability. He advises the government on financial policy and believes the peg has "tremendous value" in maintaining investor and business confidence. If the peg is removed, Hong Kong risks losing a vital tool for maintaining stability. The comments come amid speculation about the peg's future, following China's economic slowdown and capital outflows.

site_title: GE2015: Workers' Party line-ups revealed in 10 battlegrounds
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has released its line-ups for 10 battlegrounds in Singapore's 2015 general election, including WP chief Low Thia Khiang, Sylvia Lim, Pritam Singh, and full-MPs Chen Show Mao and Muhamad Faisal Abdul Manap. They will defend the Aljunied GRC.

site_title: Developers offer to buy Tianjin blast homes
summary: Chinese property developers have formed an alliance to buy back homes damaged in the Tianjin blasts, offering a repurchase price based on the market price before the blast or the original purchase price. Homeowners can also choose to have their homes renovated for free or receive a resettlement allowance if they haven't received their homes yet. The move comes after hundreds of residents protested for compensation, citing concerns about long-term health effects and government negligence.

site_title: Tools to manage risks from large economies long overdue
summary: A series of articles published in 2013 highlighted the need for ad hoc risk management instruments for the Chinese economy, warning of potential global economic damage. Since then, little progress has been made, with financial innovation focused on short-term client needs rather than forward-thinking and innovative solutions. The author argues that the lack of incentives for financial sector actors to foster long-term innovation contributes to the problem. He advocates for the development of derivatives aimed at managing risks from large economies, including China's, to promote sustainable capitalism and efficient markets.

site_title: Comcast plans next-gen cable technology to rival Google Fiber
summary: Comcast plans to roll out next-gen cable technology, aiming to compete with Google Fiber's gigabit speeds of 1 Gbps per second. The company's 22 million broadband subscribers could be upgraded to gigabit-enabled within 2-3 years, requiring a new cable modem and a possible fee. This move could make Comcast one of the nation's largest gigabit Internet providers, potentially edging out competitors like AT&T and Google Fiber. The company's goal is to future-proof its technology for 10 Gbps speeds, which would support cities' internet-enabled infrastructure and businesses' media-rich communications.

site_title: Swift leads winners at Video Music Awards
summary: Taylor Swift led the winners at the 2015 Video Music Awards, taking home four Moonman statuettes, including video of the year for her revenge song "Bad Blood." Swift's reunion with Kanye West on stage, where West declared his intention to run for president in 2020, was the show's highlight. West's acceptance of the Michael Jackson Video Vanguard award came after a standing ovation, during which he criticized awards shows and MTV for replaying the infamous 2009 incident.

site_title: US$ slips on fears China may hit global growth
summary: The US dollar slipped against the yen and euro on Monday due to fears that China's economic malaise could drag on global growth, reversing a rally fueled by expectations of a September US rate rise. The US dollar weakened to 121.10 yen and the euro rose to US$1.1249, amidst concerns about China's economic slowdown.

site_title: PAP all set for battle to win hearts of voters
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) is set to compete in Singapore's 12th general election, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong seeking a mandate to lead the country for the next 50 years. The party is fielding 89 candidates, including 21 first-time contestants, to contest 29 seats. PAP leaders are focusing on bread and butter issues, immigration policies, and integrity, while also addressing the leadership and succession crisis, with many senior ministers nearing retirement age. The election is seen as a crucial test of the PAP's ability to maintain its dominance.

site_title: SPP candidate launches Mountbatten manifesto
summary: Singapore People's Party candidate Jeannette Chong-Aruldoss has launched a manifesto for Mountbatten ward, promising to set up a social mobility bursary, keep rental prices affordable, and conserve Dakota Crescent. The 52-year-old lawyer, who previously ran in the 2011 election, has the full backing of the SPP and plans to raise $100,000 for the pilot project. She aims to make Mountbatten a community-focused area, not just a place to live.

site_title: S'pore leads in pursuit of green buildings
summary: Singapore has emerged as a model for Asian governments and city planners in developing and adapting urban solutions into green building industries. The country aims to reduce its national emissions intensity by 36% by 2030, with 80% of buildings meeting the Building and Construction Authority's Green Mark standards by 2030. The Green Mark certification programme has been adopted by over 250 projects in 75 cities from 14 countries, and Singapore is sharing its green building expertise through international collaborations. The country is now focusing on moving from value-adding to value-creation in its green building industry, with a focus on holistic improvements to quality of life.

site_title: China market was bound to slump after rapid expansion
summary: China's rapid expansion of its Shanghai stock market was bound to lead to a slump, according to Yale professor Koichi Hamada. The market's price increase by "two and a half times" over a year created instability, which ultimately led to its collapse. Hamada attributes the rapid expansion to a "price-keeping operation" by Chinese authorities, possibly to enable state-owned firms to list on the stock exchange and repay debts. The recent devaluation of the yuan may have short-term negative spillovers on the US economy, but it is unlikely to lead to a currency war.

site_title: GE2015: Sitoh Yih Pin unveils campaign slogan, 5-year plan for Potong Pasir
summary: Singaporean MP Sitoh Yih Pin announced his campaign slogan for the 2015 general election, focusing on improving Potong Pasir through unity and bettering the lives of three generations. He also outlined a 5-year plan if re-elected. Meanwhile, global economic trends are shifting, with China's GDP growth expected to slow and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quoted at a taxable book-entry rate. Creative Technology warns of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is named OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong who is retiring. MAS and PBOC to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks experience a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Chua Chu Kang GRC unveils S$385m upgrading works under Master Plan
summary: The Chua Chu Kang Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore has unveiled its Master Plan for the next five years, totaling S$385 million in upgrading projects. The projects include improved public transport access, new community facilities, and cycling paths. The plan also includes upgrading lifts, energy-efficient lighting, and home improvement programs for residents. The Master Plan will be open for public viewing and feedback before major decisions are made.

site_title: DC rate for industrial use cut but left unchanged in other use groups
summary: Singapore's development charge (DC) rates for industrial use have been cut by an average of 3% as of September 1, 2015, marking the first change in seven years. The rates remain unchanged in four major use groups: commercial, landed and non-landed residential, hotel/hospital, and place of worship and civic institutions. Market observers attribute the rate cuts to weak fundamentals in the industrial property market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Indian Oil seeking to build US$3b petrochemicals plant in Iran: sources
summary: Indian Oil Corp plans to build a $3 billion petrochemicals plant in Iran, contingent on access to cheap natural gas as feedstock. The project aims to diversify the company's revenue streams and capitalize on India's growing energy demands. The move is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to secure energy investments in Iran, despite ongoing sanctions. Indian Oil will compete with state-run Chinese energy giants and major oil majors like Royal Dutch Shell and Total SA for the project.

site_title: Master of slasher horror films Wes Craven dies at 76
summary: Wes Craven, a master of horror cinema, died at 76 due to brain cancer. He was best known for creating the iconic villain Freddy Krueger in "A Nightmare on Elm Street" (1984) and directing the "Scream" franchise. Craven's career spanned over four decades, including films like "The Hills Have Eyes" (1977), "The Serpent and the Rainbow" (1988), and "The People Under the Stairs" (1991). He began his career in the 1970s, directing low-budget films and teaching English before transitioning to mainstream horror.

site_title: Alaska pipeline anxiety spurs governor's plea for Obama to open oil taps
summary: Alaska Governor Bill Walker is urging President Barack Obama to allow the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System to operate while it still can, as the pipeline is nearing capacity and a halt in operations could spell the end of oil on the North Slope for a long time. The pipeline, which has been Alaska's economic lifeline for 40 years, is expected to shut down if North Slope oil production drops below 300,000 barrels a day. Environmental groups dispute the notion of a imminent shutdown, citing the pipeline's ability to continue operating for decades with reduced flows.

site_title: Citi aims to resurrect equities franchise as its rivals retreat
summary: Citi plans to revive its underperforming equities franchise by courting hedge funds and investing in technology, research, and financing. The bank aims to capitalize on a retreat by rivals, such as Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse, which are re-aligning their investment banking businesses. Citi's four-point plan includes hiring key executives, expanding research, and boosting its financing, with a focus on mid-sized hedge funds. Despite the challenges, Citi is ready to strategically invest in the unit, which has been under-invested for years.

site_title: External events will impact stocks more than GE outcome: analysts
summary: Analysts predict the outcome of Singapore's upcoming general election will have little impact on local stocks, citing external macroeconomic factors such as China's slowing economy and the US's interest rate hike as more influential. Historically, a better PAP showing has been correlated with a boost in the Straits Times Index, but available data does not indicate a clear trend. Instead, analysts focus on global economic indicators and market trends, such as Citigroup's mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index.

site_title: Opportunity in volatility despite China concerns
summary: China's recent devaluation of its currency has sparked market panic, with many emerging markets experiencing volatility. However, experts believe the renminbi's depreciation is likely to remain relatively controlled as the government moves towards a more market-driven environment. Despite concerns about China's economic growth, the authors expect moderation, not a recession, and see opportunities in Asian markets such as Malaysia and Mexico. They also anticipate significant divergences in monetary policies, with the US Federal Reserve expected to raise interest rates in the second half of 2015.

site_title: Ferry travel disrupted as protesting French sailors blockade Calais port
summary: French sailors from the bankrupt firm Scop SeaFrance blockedaded the port of Calais on Sunday, stranding thousands of ferry passengers. About 15 sailors took to the water in two lifeboats, blocking traffic and leaving thousands stranded. The protest is over plans to sell off ferries to Danish firm DFDS, which could lead to hundreds of job losses. The blockage comes on the eve of a meeting aimed at resolving the dispute, and Calais port authorities are monitoring the situation, hoping to resume normal operations as soon as possible.

site_title: Indonesia said to favour China over Japan in railway bid
summary: Indonesia is leaning towards China to build its first high-speed railway, a 150km line connecting Jakarta and Bandung, due to a more financially burdensome proposal from Japan. China's bid includes a 50-year loan with a 2% interest rate, while Japan's offer has a 10-year grace period and higher local content. The decision will be made by a cabinet-level committee and is expected to be announced within days. The winner will likely become a frontrunner for other high-speed rail projects in Asia.

site_title: China and US rate hike fears hit stocks
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 1.2% to 2,921.44 on Monday, amid renewed volatility in China and worries of a potential US interest rate hike. US Federal Reserve vice-chair Stanley Fisher's comments on inflation sparked concerns, with futures contracts on the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing almost 200 points. Brokers attributed the fall to weak sentiment and fragile market conditions, with the FOMC meeting and non-farm payrolls data set to influence investor decisions next week.

site_title: A delivery-tracking app that arose from logistics hell
summary: Detrack, a Singapore-based delivery-tracking app, was born out of a florist's struggles with last-minute orders and poor communication with anxious customers on Valentine's Day. Founders Dason Goh and Fanny See created the app to provide real-time tracking and proof of delivery for businesses, and it has since become popular in over 30 countries, completing over a million delivery jobs. Despite initial challenges, the company has reported revenue of over US$100,000 and has grown its team from three to five members. Detrack plans to expand its services into niche markets and translate its app into non-English languages, aiming to become a Silicon Valley-style company based in Singapore.

site_title: ST Aerospace revamps aircraft leasing business
summary: ST Aerospace Resources and Wings Capital Partners Holdings have terminated their joint venture, WingStar, due to differing views on strategic focus and operational plans. ST Aerospace will continue to build a portfolio of mid-life and end-of-life aircraft assets, focusing on single-aisle aircraft. The decision was mutually agreed upon and marks the end of a boutique aircraft leasing company.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Waves of venture capital cash recede amid market turmoil
summary: Venture capital firms are seeing a decline in funding rounds amid market turmoil, with investors becoming more selective and less willing to write large cheques for start-ups. The number of IPOs trading at less than their offering prices has increased, bolstering concerns that some companies may not be worth their current valuations. Despite this, some of the largest and fastest-growing companies, such as Uber, are likely to be insulated from the market unease, and are continuing to raise funding rounds.

site_title: Neurologist, writer Oliver Sacks dies
summary: Renowned neurologist and writer Oliver Sacks died on Sunday at 82 after a battle with cancer. Sacks, known for his best-selling books such as "Awakenings" and "The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat," passed away at his home in New York's Greenwich Village surrounded by loved ones. He had been diagnosed with terminal cancer after a rare melanoma of the eye spread to his liver, and had written about his impending death in an essay. Sacks was a professor of neurology at New York University's School of Medicine and had gained a broad public following through his writings, which explored the mysteries of the human brain and behavior.

site_title: Dubai Properties CEO says revenue will be higher this year
summary: Dubai Properties Group CEO Abdullatif Al Mulla predicts higher revenue for 2015, driven by a rising population and demand for residential properties. The company, a major player in Dubai's real estate market, expects its 2015 profit and revenue to be higher than in 2014. Al Mulla attributes the positive outlook to the emirate's population growth and the company's focus on retail and leasing. DPG's rivals, Emaar Properties and Nakheel, also reported rising profits, with Emaar posting nine consecutive quarters of profit growth.

site_title: Europe Stocks Post Worst Month Since 2011 on Fed, China Concern
summary: Europe's Stoxx Europe 600 Index posted its worst month in four years, dropping 8.5% due to concerns over the Federal Reserve's interest rate trajectory and China's economic stability. Investors await clear guidance from the Fed on rate hikes, while China's market faces a two-month slump amid worries about government intervention. Worldwide shares plummeted by over $5 trillion this month, with European stocks also declining amid low trading volume and volatility.

site_title: Mitsubishi Estate to build new Tokyo office, retail complex
summary: Mitsubishi Estate Co plans to build a massive office and retail complex in central Tokyo, adjacent to Tokyo Station, at a cost of over 1 trillion yen (S$11.6 billion). The 3.1-hectare complex will feature four towers, including Japan's tallest office tower at 390 meters high. The project aims to add more space to Tokyo's capital, marking a significant development in the city's real estate market.

site_title: Singapore market value falls 8.8% in August to S$854b
summary: Singapore's market value plummeted 8.8% in August to S$854 billion, with a S$83 billion loss in market capitalization, amid global market volatility. The decline marked a fourth consecutive month of losses. Key sectors, including blue chips and smaller stocks, were affected, with oil and gas stocks taking the biggest hit. Analysts expect a slower growth and higher risk environment, with a possible bottom of 2,250 points for the Straits Times Index.

site_title: Upgrade at the click of a finger
summary: IamThirsty.com.sg, Singapore's first online training portal, has listed over 10,000 courses from 55 industries. Founded by Winnie Khoo, the platform aims to encourage people to upgrade their skills for better job prospects. Initially a lead generation platform, IamThirsty.com.sg plans to develop into an online lead platform and eventually allow students to sign up and take courses online. The platform's launch coincided with the government's SkillsFuture initiative, and Khoo believes it will help attract more overseas students to Singapore.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Global banks plough resources into bitcoin technology
summary: Global banks are investing heavily in bitcoin technology, exploring its potential to disrupt foreign currency trading. Executives from top financial institutions, including Barclays and JPMorgan Chase, believe the blockchain technology underlying bitcoin can enable faster, cheaper, and more transparent transactions. Central banks, such as the Federal Reserve, are also examining the technology. The innovation could change the fundamental model of finance, allowing banks to directly exchange money and assets without relying on middlemen.
