site_title: Hot stock: Olam deal at premium sends Noble Group toward monthly advance
summary: Noble Group Ltd shares rose 5.8% to 54.5 Singapore cents, extending its first monthly advance since November, after Mitsubishi Corp agreed to pay a 44% premium for a 20% stake in Olam International Ltd. The deal, worth S$1.53 billion, reflects growing demand for food in Asia. Noble's shares have fallen over 50% since Iceberg Research questioned the company's accounting practices in February. The company's shares have climbed 19% this month, driven by efforts to restore investor confidence and boost annual operating income to over $2 billion within five years.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, GuocoLeisure, Sim Lian
summary: Mitsubishi Corp is acquiring a strategic stake in Olam International for S$1.53 billion, issuing 12% of new shares. GuocoLeisure reported a 23% rise in net profit to US$47.9 million, while Sim Lian's net profit surged 41% to S$240.4 million. These moves come as Singapore stocks notch a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Australia: Stocks open up 1.05 per cent
summary: Australian stocks rose 1.05% at the open on Friday, following a strong rally in the US, with miners leading the way on the back of a 10% jump in oil prices. The benchmark S&P/ASX200 index rose 55.2 points to 5,288.5. BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto surged, with BHP up 4.90% and Rio Tinto up 3.26%. The strong performance in Chinese stocks on Thursday also contributed to the positive market sentiment.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on back of Wall Street's extended gain
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened higher by 1.31% or 38.71 points at 2,984.14 on Friday, driven by Wall Street's biggest two-day gain since the 2008 global financial crisis. The benchmark index was fueled by strong US economic data and expectations of a delayed interest-rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. Gainers outnumbered losers 185 to 19, with active stocks including Olam International, QT Vascular, and Noble Group.

site_title: British service sector growth surges in August: CBI
summary: British services sector growth surged in August, with the Confederation of British Industry's survey showing the biggest influx of work since 1998. The sector's growth is driven by increased business volumes and profitability, with firms investing in people and capital. Official figures confirm the economy grew 0.7% quarter-on-quarter in the April-June period. Despite this, concerns remain about the sector's reliance on consumer spending and manufacturing's disappointing performance.

site_title: SoftBank US$6.9b value drop spurs biggest Japan risk jump
summary: SoftBank's US$6.9 billion market value drop has led to a significant increase in Japan's bond risk, with the company's credit-default swap index rising 6 basis points. The decline in SoftBank's market capitalization has also led to a decrease in founder Masayoshi Son's net worth by about US$600 million. Analysts attribute the rise in bond risk to SoftBank's debt-fueled expansion and unrealized gains on investments decreasing due to market turmoil. Despite this, SoftBank's domestic business is seen as stable, and the company is expected to continue raising funds from individual investors.

site_title: For a good cause
summary: The Only Watch Charity Auction, held in Geneva this year, will feature over 40 unique timepieces to raise funds for muscular dystrophy research. The auction, which aims to surpass the record-breaking €5 million raised in 2013, will showcase a range of complications, classics, and avant-garde watches from luxury brands. The event, which will take place in November, promises to be a significant fundraiser for the charity, which has already raised over €15 million since its inception.

site_title: Energy sector could see more deals after US$15b Cameron sale
summary: Schlumberger agreed to buy Cameron International Corp for about US$66.36 a share in cash and stock, valued at US$15 billion. This deal, the second-largest oil and gas services deal on record, could inspire more dealmaking in the energy sector. Analysts predict other targets, such as FMC Technologies Inc and Dril-Quip Inc, could be in play due to the low oil price and the need for companies to offer complete and lower-cost bundles of services.

site_title: Europe: Shares recoup week's losses as US cheers markets
summary: European shares rose 3.6% on Thursday, recouping losses from the week, following market expectations of a US rate hike being pushed back and revised economic growth figures. The FTSEurofirst 300 index closed up 3.5%, with Bouygues rising 5% and Pernod Ricard falling 1.7%. Despite persistent fears of a Chinese economic slowdown, US monetary policy may be less likely to be affected, with the US economy showing strong domestic demand growth.

site_title: Europe has 'means to resist' impact of China crisis: EU economics commissioner
summary: Europe has the means to resist the impact of China's slowing economy, according to EU Economic Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici. Despite China's yuan devaluation and weak economic data, European markets have shown signs of a rebound, with fundamentals of the European recovery appearing solid. Moscovici also emphasized the importance of labor market reforms in France, citing rules permitting easier job entry and greater flexibility as key to increasing growth and employment.

site_title: Huawei brings online smartphone brand Honor to Europe
summary: Huawei has launched its online smartphone brand Honor in Europe, focusing on digitally savvy consumers. The Honor 7, priced at £249.99 in Britain, has achieved high customer satisfaction levels, with over 1.5 million sales in China since June. Huawei aims to sell over 100 million phones this year, surpassing Xiaomi's target of 80-100 million. The Honor brand will be mainly promoted and sold online in Europe, with Huawei's vMall e-commerce platform now available across the continent.

site_title: UK consumer confidence bounces back to 15-year high in Aug: GfK
summary: UK consumer confidence has reached a 15-year high in August, according to market research company GfK, with its monthly sentiment index jumping to +7 from +4 in July. This matches June's figure, the highest since January 2000. Low inflation, rising wages, and record low interest rates are contributing to the boost in confidence, despite global economic concerns and a slowdown in China's economy.

images.alt_text: A man chooses apples in an Asda store in northwest London, Britain on Aug 18, 2015. British consumer morale unexpectedly rose in August to match June's 15-year high, as low inflation and a recent pick-up in wages made Britons more upbeat about their financial prospects.

site_title: Oil soars over 10%, biggest gain in six years as shorts scramble
summary: Oil prices surged 10.25% to $47.56 a barrel, the largest one-day gain in six years, as recovering equity markets and reduced crude supplies sparked a short-covering rally by bearish traders. The rally was fueled by news of diminished Nigerian oil exports and a revision in US economic growth. Front-month Brent crude rose $4.42 to its highest level since March 2009, with US crude settling up 10.3% to $42.56 a barrel, its biggest one-day gain since March 2009.

images.alt_text: Oil rocketed more than 10 percent higher on Thursday, posting its biggest one-day rally in over six years as recovering equity markets and news of diminished crude supplies set off a short-covering scramble by bearish traders.

site_title: Japan's core inflation vanishes again in July as oil tumbles
summary: Japan's core inflation gauge fell to zero in July for the third time this year, as tumbling energy prices countered Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's efforts to reflate the economy. Consumer prices excluding fresh food remained unchanged from a year earlier, contrary to economists' forecasts of a 0.2% drop. The decline in oil prices is expected to keep core consumer prices below year-earlier levels "for the foreseeable future," with some economists predicting additional monetary easing in October.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan's key inflation gauge slumped to zero for a third time this year, as tumbling energy prices counter Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's effort to reflate the world's third-biggest economy.

site_title: Mitsubishi to buy 20% in grain trader Olam for S$1.53 billion
summary: Mitsubishi Corp agreed to buy a 20% stake in Olam International Ltd, a Singapore-based grain trader, in two deals worth S$1.53 billion. The investment is a sign of confidence in the company, which has been facing financial questions. Mitsubishi will become the second-largest shareholder after Temasek Holdings, and the deal reflects a 29% premium to Olam's 2014 trading average. The move is part of a trend of Asian trading houses investing in agriculture to meet growing demand for food in the region.

site_title: Canadians spend more on taxes than bare necessities: study
summary: A study by the Fraser Institute found that Canadians spend more on taxes (42.1% of income) than on basic necessities (36.6% of income) in 2015, a trend that has persisted since the early 1980s. This represents a 149.2% increase in taxes since 1961, outpacing rises in food, shelter, and clothing costs. The study's findings have sparked questions about tax policies ahead of Canada's election.

site_title: Facebook celebrates one billion users in single day
summary: Facebook reached a milestone of one billion users in a single day, with 1 in 7 people on Earth using the platform to connect with friends and family. The milestone was announced by CEO Mark Zuckerberg, who declared it an "important benchmark" in the company's pursuit of Internet ubiquity. Facebook also introduced new technology to help video creators guard against unauthorized uploads and "freebooting." The social network plans to test the new matching technology with a select group of partners.

site_title: US: Wall St logs biggest two-day gain since financial crisis
summary: Wall Street experienced its largest two-day gain since the 2008 financial crisis, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 2.27% to 16,654.77 and the S&P 500 jumping 2.43% to 1,987.66. The rally was fueled by strong US economic data and decreased expectations of a September interest-rate hike. The S&P 500 recovered half of its 11% meltdown from a six-day losing streak, with major sectors including energy, technology, and consumer goods rising sharply.

site_title: Stocks suffer bouts of bipolar mood swings
summary: Stocks in Singapore and the region experienced significant mood swings, with the market reversing its downward trend for the fourth time in four days to gain 2.5% on Thursday. The rally was driven by dovish comments from a US central banker, who stated that the case for raising interest rates in September was "less compelling." This led to a rebound in Asian markets, with the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong rising 3.6% and the CSI 300 Index of Shanghai and Shenzhen stocks gaining 5.95%.

site_title: Sonic boom
summary: The watchmaking industry has made significant strides in mastering minute repeaters, a complex mechanism that sounds the hours, quarters, and minutes on demand. Brands such as IWC, Cartier, and Patek Philippe have developed innovative designs, including push-button and slide mechanisms, to activate the striking mechanism. The use of cathedral gongs, which produce a richer tone, has also become increasingly popular. Recent innovations, such as Audemars Piguet's new striking mechanism regulator, demonstrate that the art of minute repeaters is alive and evolving, with many brands pushing the boundaries of horology.

site_title: Asia markets rally, but China bogeyman still lurking in shadows
summary: Asia markets experienced a relief rally on Thursday, with China's Shanghai Composite leading the gains, as investors took advantage of oversold conditions. The rally was fueled by dovish comments from the US Federal Reserve, which reduced the likelihood of a September interest rate hike. However, analysts caution that the rebound may be short-lived, as fundamentals remain unchanged and the region's growth concerns persist. The market's recent rebound is also attributed to the fact that regional markets are still undervalued compared to stress levels and currency weakness.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: PBOC moves manage to tame high financing costs
summary: China's central bank, the PBOC, implemented measures to tame high financing costs, reducing interest rates, offering cheap loans, and injecting cash into the financial system. The overnight rate broke a 39-day record increase, while money market rates decreased. The PBOC auctioned 150 billion yuan in seven-day reverse-repurchase agreements and lowered its one-year lending and deposit rates by 25 basis points each. The move aims to stabilize funding costs and support the economy ahead of a reserve requirement ratio cut on September 6.

site_title: Up to 50 dead in Austria as migrant crisis rages
summary: Austrian police discovered the decomposing bodies of up to 50 migrants in an abandoned truck on a motorway near the Slovakia and Hungary borders. The vehicle, with Slovakian and Hungarian markings, was found on Thursday. European leaders are meeting to address the migrant crisis, which has led to a cross-border hunt for people-smugglers. The incident is the latest in a series of tragedies in the Europe-wide crisis, with tens of thousands of people seeking refuge in the European Union.

site_title: Falling prices, not markets, the real headache for Chinese firms
summary: China's manufacturing sector is facing a decline in profits due to nearly four years of price deflation, with wholesale prices hitting their lowest point since 2009. The erosion of profits is largely due to intense competition among small companies, which forces them to cut prices and reduce sales volumes. The lack of access to traditional financial markets and the dominance of state-owned enterprises in certain sectors also contribute to the problem. China's central bank has attempted to stabilize the economy with monetary easing, but the effects are limited for private firms like You Zhenming's factory, which is struggling to stay afloat amidst increased domestic competition and rising factor costs.

site_title: Google says EU anti-trust accusations 'wrong'
summary: Google has rejected EU anti-trust regulators' accusations of illegally abusing its market dominance, stating that the preliminary conclusions are "wrong as a matter of fact, law, and economics." The US internet giant's general counsel, Kent Walker, made the statement in a blog post, leaving the decision to pursue further action to EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager. This response marks Google's first formal reaction to the European Union's official complaint filed in April.

site_title: Exporters run for high ground as China growth story unravels
summary: China's economic slowdown is prompting European exporters to shift focus to premium goods and services, potentially sacrificing volume for higher margins. As Chinese rivals gain expertise in various sectors, prices are falling even in areas thought insulated from local competition. Companies like ThyssenKrupp, Philips, and Tate & Lyle are adjusting to lower growth and intensifying price wars. The Chinese government's efforts to stimulate local consumption and production, including a rate cut and bank lending restrictions, underscore its determination to promote domestic growth.

site_title: Yen nurses losses as stocks rally cheers mood
summary: The yen lost against the dollar due to improved risk sentiment and a decline in demand for safe haven currencies. A Federal Reserve official's comments downplayed the likelihood of a September interest rate hike, boosting market confidence. The dollar rose 0.3% against the yen, while the euro fell against the dollar. Analysts expect the European Central Bank to respond to market volatility by increasing its asset purchase program, which could weigh on the euro.

site_title: Net migration into UK rises to record in 12 months to March
summary: The UK saw a record net migration of 330,000 in the year ending March 2015, exceeding Prime Minister David Cameron's target of below 100,000. This represents a 94,000 increase from the previous year, with EU citizens making up the majority of arrivals. The government's efforts to curb migration have been unsuccessful, with the opposition Labour Party criticizing the government's approach as "broken promises" and "deeply disappointing."

site_title: A successful pairing of Old and New World
summary: Opus One, a Napa Valley wine combining New-World fruit with Old-World Bordeaux restraint, has achieved success. The iconic wine was born in 1979 through a partnership between Robert Mondavi and Baron Philippe de Rothschild. The 1988 vintage was the first, featuring 85% Cabernet Sauvignon, with a blend of Merlot, Cabernet Franc, and Malbec. Opus One's unique blend has helped create a distinct middle ground, avoiding blockbuster quality and the austerity of Old World Bordeaux. The wine's balance and equilibrium have contributed to its success, making it a great pleasure to drink.

site_title: Productivity Council in tie-up to boost process construction and maintenance sector
summary: Singapore's Productivity Council has formed a 3-year partnership with the Construction Industry Institute (CII) to boost the process construction and maintenance (PCM) sector, a key industry in the country. The partnership aims to introduce best practices, metrics, and benchmarking for the sector, with the goal of improving productivity and positioning Singapore as a leader in the industry. The council will develop a certification system and work groups will focus on benchmarking, best practices, and mechanization initiatives to drive industry-wide adoption.

site_title: Sweden's housing subsidy won't help shortage, say builders
summary: Sweden plans to subsidize housing construction with 3.2 billion kronor (S$527 million) annually for 250,000 new homes by 2020. However, the Swedish Construction Federation says this measure won't solve the housing shortage in major cities, citing the need to loosen regulations, increase mobility, and make capital entry easier. Factors driving demand include financial assets, taxation, mortgage rates, and employment, which aren't addressed by the investment support. The government aims to build 15,000 new rental flats per year, but experts doubt it will reach the target.

site_title: New Indonesia stimulus starts with expanded tax perks
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo's economic team has announced a stimulus plan to boost the country's slowing economy. The plan includes expanded tax perks for companies investing over 1 trillion rupiah, offering lower taxes for 5-15 years. The move aims to increase investment flows and strengthen the rupiah, which has been under pressure due to global market turmoil and a recent cabinet reshuffle. The government also plans to deregulate and improve the investment climate, despite challenges such as poor infrastructure and corruption.

site_title: Top mining CEOs differ on state of China's economy
summary: Top mining CEOs, including Andrew Mackenzie of BHP Billiton and Ivan Glasenberg of Glencore, differ on the state of China's economy, with Mackenzie expressing confidence in his ability to understand the country's growth, while Glasenberg admits he can't "read" China. Despite China's economic woes, including a slowdown in expansion and a stock market rout, mining companies remain optimistic about long-term demand. CEOs predict continued growth in Chinese demand for commodities, with Rio Tinto forecasting a 7% growth rate this year.

site_title: Companies can't wait until short-sellers strike to build defences
summary: Singapore's new chief regulatory officer, Tan Boon Gin, advises companies to quickly respond to short-seller attacks to maintain market trust. However, a prompt response alone is insufficient, as companies must have already built trust with investors. Short-sellers, or "vultures," can reveal market weaknesses, but they can also be malicious or wrong. Companies must focus on cultivating trust with investors and the broader market to prevent attacks. This requires transparent corporate governance, education, and investor relations, rather than just reacting to short-seller attacks.

site_title: The Portugieser ushers in IWC's new movements
summary: IWC Schaffhausen introduces its new Portugieser movement, the 52000 calibre, marking the brand's expertise in watchmaking. The movement boasts a seven-day power reserve and features two barrels, ceramic parts, and complications such as an annual calendar and perpetual calendar. The Portugieser 75th anniversary collection includes six new and improved watches, including the Portugieser Annual Calendar, Perpetual Calendar Digital Date-Month, and Portugieser Hand-Wound Eight Days. The new movement is set to be followed by the 69000 and 42000 calibres in the coming years.

site_title: GE2015: WP unveils more candidates, reiterates 'responsible opposition' role
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) of Singapore unveiled its second batch of candidates for the 2015 general election, with four new faces including lawyer Terence Tan and sales consultant Cheryl Denise Loh. The candidates emphasized the party's "rational and responsible opposition" role, with Tan calling for a focus on long-term implications and Loh advocating for improved education. WP chairman Sylvia Lim stated that the party's presence in Parliament has led to a more responsive government, and the party will continue to promote its "Empower Your Future" campaign theme.

site_title: An ocean of emotions
summary: The Black Arm Band, an Australian Aboriginal music group, performs songs in endangered languages through their music, evoking emotions despite limited understanding of the lyrics. Formed in response to Australia's dismissal of its Indigenous history, the band's music is a celebration of community and togetherness. With a mix of traditional and modern instruments, the group's powerful vocals convey messages of hope, loss, and connection. The performance includes ritualistic gestures, such as paying respect to the land, and showcases the band's authentic and moving music.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
The Black Arm Band alternates uplifting songs of hope with plaintive cries of loss in Dirtsong.

site_title: Artistic bare movements
summary: Roger Dubuis unveiled its new collection featuring skeleton movements in a star-shaped design, showcasing the brand's artistry and inventiveness. The Excalibur Spider Skeleton Double Flying Tourbillon, made of titanium, black DLC-titanium, and red aluminium elements, is priced at S$395,000. This collection highlights Roger Dubuis's expertise in crafting skeleton calibres and timepieces.

site_title: PayPal to roll out One Touch check-out in Europe, Australia
summary: PayPal is expanding its One Touch payments product to 13 new markets in Europe and Australia, simplifying the checkout process for online shoppers and merchants. The program, which already has millions of users in the US, UK, and Canada, eliminates repeated data entry, improving conversion rates by 50% or greater. Existing PayPal users can opt-in, and merchants that accept PayPal will see One Touch automatically enabled. The goal is to create better buying experiences for consumers, leading to higher conversions for merchants.

site_title: Fairmined limited edition
summary: CHOPARD has released a limited edition watch, the L.U.C XPS Fairmined, made from 18-carat Fairmined rose gold. This is the second Chopard watch to feature Fairmined certification, following the L.U.C Tourbillon QF Fairmined launched last year. The watch is priced at S$24,100 and features a 39.5 mm case with a subtle sunburst satin-brushed dial. Chopard aims to continue using responsible and fair mining practices, ensuring the miners are fairly compensated.

site_title: Diageo sees China rising to 5% of sales despite market gyrations
summary: Diageo aims to increase China sales to 5% of its revenue within 5-10 years, despite market volatility and a crackdown on lavish spending. The company seeks to shift consumers towards Scotch whisky, such as Haig Club, instead of local baijiu, which accounts for over half of China's alcoholic beverage sales. Diageo has seen a significant turnaround in its Chinese baijiu business, but Scotch sales remain a challenge, with a 17% decline in mainland China last fiscal year. The company also faces challenges in Indonesia and Thailand, where governments are curbing excessive drinking.

images.alt_text: Diageo Plc wants China to contribute 5 per cent of sales in the next 10 years, and to do so the beverage maker will need to convince locals to pour Scotch with dinner instead of the local specialty, baijiu.

site_title: Europe takes stock of threats posed by drones to flight safety
summary: The European Commission has charged its aviation safety agency with developing common rules for operating drones in Europe amid increasing reports of near-misses with commercial aircraft. Proposals include no-drone zones, software to block flights into sensitive areas, and registration rules. The rise in drone usage has raised concerns about the potential for devastating consequences, with pilots' associations calling for geo-fencing technology and registration. The European Commission recognizes the threat, stating that "drone accidents will happen," and expects the proliferation of drones as technology becomes cheaper.

site_title: Architect sought for Obama library
summary: The Barack Obama Foundation has launched a global competition to select the architect for the US President's presidential library in Chicago, with a global search for firms. The foundation is seeking a diverse group of participants, with most firms based in Chicago, and has asked them to submit statements of interest by September 16. The selected firms will then be asked to provide proposals for the library, with the goal of selecting an architect by the end of the year. The library is expected to cost up to $1 billion and will feature a state-of-the-art archive, museum, innovation labs, and community garden, with a focus on sustainability and inclusivity.

site_title: Lanxess reiterates concern about Singapore's energy costs
summary: Lanxess, a German multinational chemical firm, has expressed concern over Singapore's energy costs, which could become a significant issue for the petrochemical industry in the long term. Despite improvements in energy prices, Singapore's energy costs remain high compared to other chemical manufacturing sites worldwide. Lanxess has invested heavily in Singapore, with a new plant opening on Jurong Island, and is working with the government on energy efficiency projects. Minister for Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang stated that Singapore is committed to reducing carbon footprint through such projects.

site_title: Latest President watch more energy efficient
summary: Rolex's Day-Date watch, also known as "the Presidents' watch," has undergone a significant update. The new model features a Calibre 3255 automatic movement that extends the power reserve to three days, making it more energy efficient and dependable. The watch is now available in 40mm and 36mm sizes, with prices ranging from 33,200 Swiss francs for yellow gold to 59,500 Swiss francs for platinum. The new movement also features improved resistance to shocks and magnetism, and is certified as a Superlative Chronometer Officially Certified.

images.alt_text: Rolex's Day-Date Platinum (above) and yellow gold.
Rolex's Day-Date Platinum and yellow gold (above).
For everyday wear, Calibre 3255, the new movement, has passed tests twice as exacting as those for an official certification for a chronometer

site_title: Singapore can do more to promote its financial centre: panel
summary: Singapore's financial centre is well-established but can improve in areas such as attracting institutional investors, promoting innovation and technology, and developing deep skills and capabilities. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's Financial Centre Advisory Panel (FCAP) discussed strategies to grow the financial centre, with members noting strong gains in asset and wealth management, reinsurance, and foreign exchange. The panel aims to attract more institutional investors, promote digital distribution and innovations, and enhance liquidity in Asian bond markets. The FCAP plans to meet biannually, with its next meeting scheduled for January 2016.

site_title: Dive into the cutting edge of dance
summary: A cutting-edge contemporary dance event, SIFA Dance Marathon, took place in Singapore, featuring works from Japanese and Indian choreographers. The event showcased diverse and innovative dance pieces, including "The Male Ant Has Straight Antennae" by Mandeep Raikhy, which explored masculinity and male posturing, and "Lay/ered" by Yukio Suzuki and Fuyuki Yamakawa, a rock-punk theatre piece with a mesmerizing soundscape. Other notable pieces included "Wall Dancing" by Padmini Chettur and "Real Reality" by Mikuni Yanaihara. The event highlighted the artistic talent of Asian choreographers and the Archive Box project, which archives and responds to contemporary dance creations.

site_title: US commercial mortgages worry Fed amid defaults
summary: The US commercial mortgage market is raising concerns among analysts and investors due to a surge in defaults and potential losses. Banks are selling mortgage-backed securities at the fastest clip since 2008, fueled by near-zero interest rates and investors seeking higher yields. The Federal Reserve has warned of an overheated market, citing rising commercial property prices and loosening underwriting standards. A recent default in Ohio's Creekside project, where a $25 million loan was sold to pension funds and sold as a bond with a AAA rating, is seen as a potential harbinger of more widespread pain.

site_title: UK house prices grow at slowest annual pace since June 2013
summary: UK house prices rose 3.2% year-on-year in August, the slowest annual pace in over two years, according to Nationwide. This is the weakest annual rate since June 2013. Economists had expected a 3.1% rise. On a monthly basis, prices rose 0.3%, in line with expectations. The slowdown may not persist unless construction activity increases significantly, according to Nationwide's chief economist.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister announced a 1.9% fare reduction for public bus and rail fares by end-2015. This move, aimed at reflecting lower energy costs, has raised concerns among analysts, with some predicting a negative impact on SMRT's Q1 FY16 and Q1 FY17 forecasts. Despite this, some analysts remain positive on the company, citing the transition to a new rail financing framework and the potential for growth in the sector.

site_title: No sign of China's calm, stable Goat year so far
summary: China's "Goat" year, symbolizing calmness and stability, has not shown signs of calmness or stability, with markets plummeting 9% after a failed intervention. Global economic data remains dull, and concerns over growth prospects have fueled fears of market liquidity and high frequency trading. European equities have fallen below 15x earnings, offering a high dividend yield, but are still supported by the European Central Bank's quantitative easing. Investors are advised to remain cautious and accept higher risk to generate returns, as the market volatility reflects a period of financial repression.

images.alt_text: The equity markets have fallen so quickly that they are known as "oversold" which would suggest they can soon stabilise while players reflect on what has happened. This process and a bounce would not mean that everything is okay and investors could safely buy the dip as previously.

site_title: Vacheron Constantin waxes Harmony
summary: Vacheron Constantin has launched the Harmony collection, its first in-house chronograph and part of its 260th birthday celebration. The collection features seven models, including a platinum Ultra-Thin Grand Complication Chronograph and a Tourbillon Chronograph Caliber 3200. The brand aims to produce all future timepieces with in-house movements, with the Harmony collection adopting a distinctive cushion shape. The flagship piece, the Ultra-Thin Grand Complication Chronograph Caliber 3500, is a limited edition of 10 pieces priced at S$518,200.

site_title: ECB faces inflation headache even as lending improves
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) reported the fastest eurozone lending growth since early 2012, with credit to companies increasing 0.9% and lending to households rising 1.9% in July. However, inflation remains low at 0.2%, partly due to external factors such as falling oil prices and a slowdown in China. The ECB may still face pressure to boost stimulus measures, with economists expecting downwardly revised inflation forecasts and further policy steps. ECB President Mario Draghi's preferred inflation expectation rate is below the target of 2%.

site_title: Twice the fun
summary: Richard Mille releases two anniversary watches, the RM 056 Tourbillon and RM 011, to celebrate its 10-year partnership with Brazilian F1 driver Felipe Massa. The limited edition RM 056 Tourbillon features a tourbillon and split-seconds chronograph combo, while the RM 011 is a flyback chronograph and annual calendar. Both watches showcase Massa's racing colours and his signature is engraved on the back. Additionally, Richard Mille introduces the Tourbillon RM 27-02 Rafael Nadal, a watch paying homage to tennis, and its first precious metal bracelet, the "Open Link".

site_title: The general election in a social media age
summary: The 2011 General Election in Singapore highlighted the power of social media in shaping public opinion. Candidates' online presence and responses to criticism can significantly impact their campaign. The People's Action Party (PAP) successfully managed its candidate Tin Pei Ling's online image, while the National Solidarity Party (NSP) struggled with its candidate Kevryn Lim. To harness social media's power, parties should cultivate a strong online presence, engage in active conversations, and monitor online reactions to their announcements and candidates. This requires a well-coordinated social media team and a proactive approach to managing online perceptions.

site_title: On the record with a new retail concept
summary: A new retail concept, The Analog Vault, opened in Singapore on August 15, offering a curated collection of vinyl records, books, and magazines. Co-founded by Eugene Ow Yong, the store caters to audiophiles and bibliophiles, featuring a range of music genres and eclectic publications. Ow Yong aims to provide an immersive experience, where customers can engage with physical media and discover new interests. The store's success is driven by the growing demand for vinyl records and the tactile experience it provides, which is often lacking in digital options.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lum Chang Holdings reported a 19% rise in net profit to S$29.8 million for the 12 months ended June 30, driven by revenue growth from two construction projects. Raffles Education's net profit slumped 69% to S$16.98 million due to a lack of one-time gains. Aspial Corp raised S$146.7 million from its retail bond offering, with its public tranche 8.7 times subscribed.

site_title: Cadillac purchases are on hold in China
summary: A stock rout in China has hit growth plans for automakers, including General Motors and Volkswagen, as would-be buyers have less cash to spend due to the market's biggest plunge since 1996. Dealers report lost sales, and companies are bracing for more pain as the once-hot car market slows. Despite efforts to lure buyers with incentives, the Shanghai Composite Index has sunk below 3,000, and carmakers will now manufacture fewer vehicles locally this year.

site_title: Ringgit drop not good for Singapore, says Shanmugam
summary: Singapore Law and Foreign Minister K Shanmugam expressed concerns over the weakening Malaysian ringgit, which could impact Singapore's strong economic links with Malaysia. The weakened currency may benefit Singaporean shoppers but poses significant implications for Singapore's investments and stability. Shanmugam also warned of rising religious influence in Malaysian politics and the growing US-China-Japan rivalry in Asia, which may pressure Singapore to take sides with one of the three economic powers.

site_title: Jaeger-LeCoultre unveils thinnest watch
summary: Jaeger-LeCoultre unveiled the world's thinnest hand-wound mechanical watch, the Master Ultra Thin Squelette, measuring 3.6mm thick. The watch beats Piaget's Altiplano 900P by 0.05mm to claim the title. The new model features a 1.85mm thick movement with a 33-hour power reserve, compared to the 900P's 48 hours. The watch is available in limited edition of 100 pieces, priced at S$84,000 in pink gold and S$88,000 in white gold.

site_title: Choosing a politician is like falling in love?
summary: Conservative Republicans may continue to support Donald Trump due to an emotional connection rather than purely rational considerations. Research suggests that voters often fall in love with a candidate, rather than just making decisions based on policy issues. This emotional connection can be driven by factors such as personality, values, and tribal identity. Trump's ability to tap into these emotional connections, despite his unconventional behavior and lack of traditional conservative credentials, may explain why many conservative Republicans continue to support him.

site_title: Barcelona mayor's crackdown puts Airbnb in firing line
summary: Barcelona's new mayor, Ada Colau, is cracking down on uncontrolled tourism, threatening to fine Airbnb and Booking.com for marketing apartments to tourists without proper registration. The city fears this could drive out poor residents and spoil the city's charm. Colau wants rental websites to hand over property owner information and has already frozen new hotel licenses. Airbnb and Booking.com claim they comply with local rules, but Colau says there are thousands of unlicensed apartments in the city, leading to a surge in tourism and pressure on local residents.

site_title: A sensory apocalypse
summary: Versus, a production by Cake Theatrical Productions, is a two-hour sensory experience exploring big themes like faith, power, and human existence. The show features a scattershot approach, jumping between ideas without fully developing them. Despite this, the technical design shines, with stunning costumes, video projections, and sound. Director Natalie Hennedige's direction and the story's archetypal nature are notable, but the abridged storylines may leave audiences unsatisfied. The show's memorable moments, such as a soldier's reflection on suffering, are a highlight, but more emotional resonance is desired.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Where Versus excels is in its extraordinary technical design. Physical theatre virtuoso Natalie Hennedige directs the piece with the kind of daredevilry her theatre company Cake has become known for.

site_title: GE2015: SDP unveils psychologist and auditor as candidates
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) unveiled two new candidates for the 2015 General Election: John Tan, a psychologist, and Sidek Mallek, an auditor. Tan, who is married with three children, has been a party member since 2011, while Mallek, married with four children, is a compliance auditor. They join the party's existing six candidates, who will contest various constituencies. SDP leader Dr. Chee Soon Juan, who was declared bankrupt in 2006, is set to contest the election for the first time since 2001, promising to champion issues such as the cost of living and the Central Provident Fund (CPF) Minimum Sum.

images.alt_text: John Tan (left) and Sidek Mallek were on Thursday introduced to the media. Mr Tan said he wished to be a voice for the people; Mr Mallek said the SDP had good alternative policies, and it was time for them to be heard.

site_title: China slowdown won't hit Japanese exports, says BOJ chief
summary: Bank of Japan (BOJ) governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed optimism that China's slowdown won't significantly harm Japan's exports, citing China's potential for 6-7% annual growth. Kuroda also stated that the BOJ can achieve its 2% inflation target next year with current monetary easing initiatives, and may ease policy further if needed. However, the Japanese government lowered its assessment of consumer spending and exports for August, suggesting a mild recovery. Kuroda's comments helped calm markets, with Japan's Nikkei-225 stock index closing 1.07% higher.

images.alt_text: Mr Kuroda after his speech at the Japan Society in New York on Wednesday. He said that falling oil prices would not stop the BOJ from hitting its inflation target.

site_title: An overlooked classic revived
summary: Zenith has revived its classic Elite 6150 watch, which features an updated in-house calibre with improved performance and a 100-hour power reserve. The 42mm steel case is part of the Elite base movement, launched in 1994 and previously used in ultra-thin and gem-set models. The Elite 6150 is to be the basis of future variations and is priced at US$8,300.

site_title: MB&F's HM6 in 5N red gold
summary: MB&F has launched the HM6 RT, a timepiece in 5N red gold, a mix of 75% gold and 25% copper. This material, combined with palladium, reduces copper tarnishing and maintains the watch's appearance over time. The HM6 RT features a spaceship-like design, previously seen in the HM6 "Space Pirate" model in titanium. The new model is priced at S$360,200, compared to S$324,200 for the original edition, which was limited to 50 pieces.

site_title: Hautlence stays on avant-garde path
summary: Hautlence has released its latest watch, Vortex, continuing its avant-garde path with a unique 3-D titanium case that showcases an innovative movement. The watch features a multi-level display of time, materials that emphasize transparency, and non-conformist shapes. The regulating organ's cage turns 60 degrees every 60 minutes, creating a mesmerizing mechanical piece of art. Vortex is the second installment in Hautlence's Concept d'Exception collection, which was first launched in 2010. The watch embodies the brand's design codes and pushes the boundaries of timepiece design.

site_title: Property stock rally could be short-lived
summary: Singapore's property counters staged a rebound on Thursday, driven by a rising Wall Street market and China's stimulus measures, but a mixed earnings report from developers and sluggish residential transactions cast a pall over their earnings prospects. The rally may prove short-lived, with Voyage research chief executive Roger Tan predicting the property market will remain challenging until 2016. Despite a few bright spots, the average share price change of the 10 largest property stocks was still a negative 3.77% year-to-date.

images.alt_text: Singapore's largest property counters staged a rebound on Thursday, buoyed by a rising tide in the equities market spurred by an overnight rally on Wall Street and news of fresh stimulus measures by China.

site_title: Big success makes Bubble a major part of Corum's heritage
summary: Corum's Bubble watch, launched 15 years ago, has become a major part of the brand's heritage due to its big success. The original 44mm watch featured an oversized crystal and unusual shape, characteristics still present in the 2015 model with a 47mm stainless steel case. The new watch retains its design codes while offering a snug fit on the wrist due to short, curved lugs. The Bubble watch has become a recognizable and iconic timepiece in the watch industry.

site_title: Back to basics
summary: Swiss luxury watchmakers are refocusing on accuracy and reliability in timepieces amid the impact of a strong Swiss franc, which led to a 1.2% drop in Swiss timepiece shipments and a 20.8% decline in exports to Hong Kong. The trend towards smaller, classic-looking watches with fewer precious stones and lower prices is gaining momentum, with brands like Omega, Rolex, and Vacheron Constantin introducing new collections with improved movements and precision. Watchmakers are also prioritizing in-house movements to reduce dependence on suppliers, with brands like Oris, Tudor, and Vacheron Constantin investing in their own production.

site_title: Rolls-Royce strikes gold with Kazakhstan's wealthiest
summary: Rolls-Royce has found a lucrative market in Kazakhstan, where the average person's income is $330 a month, making the country's wealthy class big enough to support high-end car brands like Rolls-Royce and Bentley. The company has seen strong demand for its luxury vehicles, with more people in Kazakhstan ordering Bentleys than in neighboring Russia. The country's growing luxury market is expected to grow 9% annually through 2020, driven by frontier markets like Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan.

site_title: Charm of the chimes
summary: Hublot's Big Bang Alarm Repeater watch features a programmable alarm that chimes at set times, indicated by a counter between 4-5 o'clock. The alarm lasts around 16 seconds, and a hammer strikes a gong to produce the sound. The watch also includes a second time zone display with a 24-hour counter at 11 o'clock. A home time setting is available, while local time is displayed on a larger off-centered dial.

site_title: The only Lange platinum watch under S$50k now
summary: A Lange & Sohne released the 1815 "200th" Anniversary FA Lange watch to commemorate the 200th birthday of its founder Ferdinand Adolph Lange. The limited-edition timepiece features a 40mm platinum case, hand-wound movement with hand-engraved balance cock, and a black solid-silver dial. Priced at S$48,300, it is the only Lange watch under S$50,000 with a platinum case, marking a unique milestone in the brand's history. Only 200 pieces were produced, each engraved with a serial number.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to hire several hundred in Warsaw over 3 years
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to hire several hundred employees for its Warsaw-based technology and operations units over the next three years, following similar expansions by UBS and Credit Suisse. The move aims to benefit from Poland's relatively inexpensive and skilled labor force. The expansion will be phased, with the goal of reaching an office size of several hundred employees, supporting services for clients and Goldman's own operations.

site_title: More accurate and comfy
summary: Glashutte Original introduces the updated Senator Observer watch, a modern interpretation of its 2012 observation watch designed by Julius Assman. The new model features a stainless steel case, automatic movement, and improved comfort for the wearer. Highlighted with green Super-LumiNova, the watch is designed for clarity and readability, priced at S$18,300. The Senator Observer pays homage to Assman's precision timepieces used by navigation officers and explorers.

site_title: American fliers may be reaching breaking point with surcharges and poor service
summary: American airline passengers are experiencing a breaking point due to surcharges and poor service, with consumer complaints rising 20% for the first six months of 2015. The Department of Transportation reported 9,542 complaints, up from 7,935 in the same period last year. Meanwhile, fare-watchers predict that air ticket prices will drop to record lows this fall due to lower fuel prices and decreased seasonal demand. This trend may be a relief for frustrated passengers.

site_title: Taking an inventive look at complex issues
summary: Pixar's Inside Out, a children's film, explores complex issues like emotions and core memories through cartoon characters. The film follows 11-year-old Riley as her emotions - Joy, Sadness, Fear, Anger, and Disgust - navigate her growing up and a family move. The emotions must work together to stabilize Riley's personality and prevent a disaster. The film highlights the importance of Sadness in the human experience and growing up, offering a thoughtful and inventive look at essential issues.

site_title: Deepening downturn in India's building sector eats into growth
summary: India's building sector is experiencing a deepening downturn, with over half a million workers losing their jobs in the last 18 months. Indebted developers are cutting staff and slowing work on projects to clear a backlog of 700,000 unsold homes. The slowdown is attributed to a law to clamp down on "black money" flows and a decline in housing starts. Moody's has cut India's growth forecast to 7% for the fiscal year, and economists predict that lower interest rates and infrastructure spending will eventually revive construction.

site_title: Asia grain importers make rare forward buys
summary: Asian grain importers are making rare forward purchases, locking in deals for shipments up to the middle of next year due to a sharp drop in grain prices. Thailand bought 300,000 tonnes of feed wheat from the Black Sea region for $208-$210 per tonne, while Indonesian buyers covered up to December for corn, soyameal, and distiller's dried grains. This unusual move allows buyers to secure supplies at lower prices, taking advantage of the price drop.

site_title: Bigger, more colourful Oyster Perpetuals
summary: Rolex has launched a new collection of Oyster Perpetual watches with larger cases (26, 31, 34, and 39mm) and additional colours, including red grape, olive green, champagne, and dark rhodium. The watches retain their hallmark features, including a waterproof 100m stainless steel case, a Swiss chronometer movement, and a focus on accurate time display. This marks the first time the 39mm case has been introduced for the model, which was originally unveiled as the world's first waterproof wristwatch in 1926.

site_title: Samsung tells 'PenGate' complainers: Read the manual first
summary: Samsung is facing criticism over its Galaxy Note 5, known as "PenGate," after users reported the stylus breaking when inserted backward into the storage slot. The company advises customers to read the manual, stating that the issue is due to the stylus's uniform width and potential misuse. Samsung claims the device is not defective and offers repair services at local service centers. The issue is reminiscent of Apple's previous missteps, such as AntennaGate and BendGate, which the company previously addressed with free repairs.

site_title: How Pantone is still turning colour into money
summary: Pantone, a US-based color matching company, has released 210 new colors, including shades like Ballet Slipper and Jurassic Gold. The company, which has 53 years of experience in color creation, monetizes its products by selling them to fabric mills, printers, and designers. Despite the widely available technology to measure and print specific colors, Pantone's business has grown significantly in 2014, with no financial details disclosed. The company's "Plus Series" and "Fashion, Home + Interiors" color guides remain popular among designers, and Pantone has injected mystique into its color creation process to differentiate itself from competitors.

site_title: Relationships provide the inspiration for his love songs
summary: Indie singer-songwriter Joshua Radin has released his sixth studio album, Onwards and Sideways, which explores themes of romance and relationships. The album was inspired by a love letter to a Swedish woman he met in New York, and Radin wrote the songs over a couple of months. His music has appeared in over 75 TV shows and movies, and he cites his unique vocal style as a key factor in its success. Radin's latest album has been well-received, and he will perform at the Esplanade Concert Hall in Singapore on September 4.

site_title: 40 and still going strong
summary: Bulgari has launched new models to celebrate its Bulgari Roma's 40th birthday, including updated versions and innovative designs. The Bulgari Roma Finissimo features a 41mm case with a hand-wound movement, while the Bulgari Roma Finissimo Tourbillon boasts the world's thinnest flying tourbillon movement. Additionally, Bulgari has unveiled the Diagono Magnesium, a watch made with magnesium, PEEK, and ceramic materials, priced at S$5,970. The new models include limited-edition versions, with prices ranging from S$17,600 to S$162,000.

Bulgari Roma Finissimo Tourbillon

site_title: Cheaper, thinner, smaller
summary: Greubel Forsey has launched the Tourbillon 24 Secondes Vision, a 10% cheaper timepiece than its entry-level creation. This new watch is the thinnest and smallest from the brand, featuring a 43.5mm white gold case and a 2.5mm slimmer profile. The watch boasts a hand-wind movement and tourbillon complication, and will be produced in only 22 pieces. The Tourbillon 24 Secondes Vision is priced at around S$435,000, making it a more accessible option while still retaining the brand's superior qualities.

site_title: New owner, old spirit
summary: Ulysse Nardin, a luxury watch brand, remains under the French luxury group Kering's ownership while maintaining its independent and innovative spirit. The brand has introduced the FreakLab, a hand-wound tourbillon watch with a seven-day power reserve and the UlyChoc safety system. Additionally, Ulysse Nardin has released the Hannibal Minute Repeater Westminster Carillon Tourbillon Jaquemarts and the Anchor Tourbillon, both showcasing the brand's commitment to innovation and craftsmanship. The watches feature advanced complications, such as silicon escapements and constant force escapements, ensuring greater reliability and accuracy.

site_title: Millennium sequel hits bookstores
summary: Swedish author David Lagercrantz released the sequel to Stieg Larsson's best-selling Millennium crime trilogy, "The Girl in the Spider's Web," in 25 countries, including Sweden. Lagercrantz wrote the book in a manic depressive state, citing it as a "good thing" for his writing process. The book, which follows Lisbeth Salander and Mikael Blomkvist, was met with both praise and criticism, with some fans unhappy about the decision to continue the series and others questioning Lagercrantz's ability to live up to Larsson's legacy.

site_title: Patek's exhibition for the masses
summary: Patek Philippe hosted a 12-day exhibition in London, showcasing its 175-year history and heritage through 400 timepieces. The event, held at the Saatchi Gallery, offered free admission and featured interactive rooms, watchmaking demonstrations, and a collection of museum timepieces. The exhibition paid homage to London, with timepieces inspired by English porcelain tea services and iconic buildings. Over 50,000 visitors attended, including young people and families, with the goal of inspiring a new generation to pursue a career in watchmaking.

site_title: Homage to Vasco da Gama
summary: Montblanc has launched its Heritage Chronometrie collection, inspired by Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama, who discovered a new sea route to India in 1498. The collection features new in-house movements, precise timekeeping, and traditional Swiss watchmaking features. Models include the Ultra Slim, ExoTourbillon Chronograph Vasco da Gama, Quantieme Annual Vasco da Gama, and a dual time zone complication. Prices range from S$8,700 to S$355,000, with limited edition pieces available. The collection is a tribute to Vasco da Gama's precision and perfection.

site_title: Business receipts in services industry rise 3.5% year on year in Q2
summary: Singapore's services industry saw a 3.5% year-on-year growth in Q2, driven by business services and information & communications services. The recreation & personal services segment declined 18.3% year-on-year. Financial & insurance services grew 9.5%, while health & social services saw an 8.9% increase. Overall, business receipts edged up 1.4% from the first quarter, with education services experiencing the largest decline of 10% quarter-on-quarter.

site_title: Tech connection
summary: Swiss luxury watchmakers are embracing wearable technology, partnering with tech giants like Google and Intel to develop "connected watches." Brands such as TAG Heuer, Montblanc, IWC, Bulgari, and Frederique Constant unveiled new smartwatches and digital devices at BaselWorld 2015, showcasing their ability to combine horological expertise with modern technology. Despite some skepticism, many brands see wearable tech as an opportunity to innovate and stay competitive, with some even announcing plans to release 10 variants of wearable technology by the end of the year.

site_title: Best ultra-tough diver's watch of its time
summary: The Edox Hydro-Sub, a 50-year-old ultra-tough diver's watch, celebrates its 50th birthday with a limited edition of 515 pieces. The watch features a 46mm stainless steel case, automatic movement, and water resistance to 500 meters. It has undergone rigorous testing, including a recent dive with Austrian champion free-diver Christian "The Iceman" Redl, who wore it under the polar ice cap. The updated model retains its original features, including a cushion case, bright orange bezel, and indices, and is priced at S$2,664.90.

site_title: Windows 10 spreads to more than 75 million devices
summary: Windows 10 has reached over 75 million devices worldwide since its release on July 29, 2015. The operating system is powering 90,000 different computer and tablet models, including some from 2007. Microsoft is hoping to gain traction in the mobile sector and in emerging technologies for computing. The company is offering Windows 10 as a free upgrade for most devices, allowing for voice, pen, and gesture input, and biometric identification for improved security. This growth comes despite a forecast of 8.7% decline in worldwide personal computer shipments this year.

site_title: Ezra to sell half of subsea arm to Japan's Chiyoda
summary: Ezra Holdings, a Singaporean offshore services firm, agreed to sell half of its subsea business, EMAS AMC, to Japan's Chiyoda for $180 million, valuing the unit at $360 million. The deal, worth $1.25 billion, aims to catapult the business onto a bigger stage and reduce Ezra's debt burden. Analysts see the sale as a short-term pain and long-term gain, allowing Ezra to take on larger projects and increasing its earnings potential. The deal is expected to be accretive in 3-5 years, with Chiyoda's cash injection lowering Ezra's gearing and improving its liquidity position.

site_title: Revised GDP expands 3.7% in Q2, more than forecast
summary: The US economy grew 3.7% in the second quarter, exceeding forecasts, driven by bigger gains in consumer and business spending. Household consumption grew 3.1% and business investment rose 8.6%, while inventories surged, but may pose a short-term headwind. The growth rate signals the economy is back on track, but Federal Reserve policymakers may debate whether it's strong enough to withstand interest rate hikes.

site_title: Fastest Growing 50 list features 22 young firms
summary: Singapore's Fastest Growing 50 list features 22 young firms, with 10 in the commerce-wholesale sector and seven in the top 10. The list, compiled by DP Info, identifies companies with a minimum 10% turnover growth every year for three years. This year, 28 Singapore companies made the list, with 18 from the commerce-wholesale sector, and 34 companies having a credit rating comparable to 'investment grade' rated securities. The list highlights Singapore's attractiveness as an international trading hub and good risk fundamentals.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Rationalisation helps FJB trim FY15 loss to S$17m
summary: FJ Benjamin's net loss for FY15 narrowed to S$16.99 million from S$22.1 million, as the company restructured its portfolio to focus on core South-east Asian markets, resulting in a 20% revenue decline to S$293.4m. The group rationalized its store portfolio, incurring impairment charges, but achieved productivity gains and improved gross margin to 41.5%. Operating loss narrowed to S$9.46 million, and the company plans to complete store closures by end December 2015.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Dynamic combi
summary: Blancpain introduces the L-Evolution Tourbillon Carrousel, a 47.4mm platinum watch featuring a flying tourbillon and flying carrousel, paired with an innovative bezel design and multiple-level dial. The hand-wound movement is priced at S$517,200, with only 50 pieces available. The watch showcases the complexity of its open-work movement, redefining the concept of a complication timepiece.

site_title: Omega sets a record
summary: Omega sets a record with its Globemaster watch, becoming the first to earn the Master Chronometer title. The watch features Omega's most advanced mechanical movement and has passed tests by the Swiss Official Chronometer Testing Institute (COSC) and the Swiss Federal Institute of Metrology (METAS). It is certified for its accuracy in magnetic fields of 15,000 gauss and is powered by the new Master Co-Axial movement. Prices range from S$9,800 to S$57,500, and the watch is a nod to Omega's contributions to the Apollo programme, with a limited edition of the Speedmaster Apollo 13 Silver Snoopy Award also being released.

site_title: Mentoring programme launched to boost skills in SMEs' finance function
summary: Singapore has launched the SME Business & Financial Management Programme (SME BFM) to upskill the finance function of small and medium enterprises (SMEs). The programme, developed by the Singapore CFO Institute, Singapore Business Federation, and Singapore Management University, aims to enhance SMEs' capabilities to compete in the regional and global economy. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Teo Ser Luck emphasized the importance of building SME capabilities to take advantage of the Asean Economic Community, with the goal of enabling SMEs to expand beyond shores and contribute to the region's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Valuing Malaysian art
summary: Malaysia's art market is experiencing a slowdown due to the country's currency crisis, but a recent auction by Henry Butcher Art Auctioneers may provide a boost. The lower ringgit could encourage foreign collectors to invest, redirect local aficionados towards local artists, and lead to a resurgence in Malaysian art sales. Local gallerists believe the market remains solid, with collectors becoming more cautious, but still purchasing high-quality works. The art market's resilience is comparable to Indonesia's, which has seen a slowdown in the past five years. A successful auction could help Malaysian artists regain confidence and attract new buyers.

site_title: From poor start to IWC's most popular line
summary: IWC's Portugieser watch line, launched in 1939, initially struggled due to its large size and outdated design. However, after a customer's positive feedback in the 1990s, the brand revived the collection, starting with a limited Jubilee edition in 1993. The Portugieser has since become IWC's most popular line, with various models released, including the Portugieser Minute Repeater, Automatic Chronograph, and Grande Complication, showcasing the brand's innovation and expertise in watchmaking.

site_title: YouTube Gaming set to challenge Twitch
summary: YouTube Gaming launched on August 27, 2015, as a response to Twitch, allowing gamers and companies to share live or recorded video game content. The new section provides a centralized platform for video game content, targeting the growing market of watching others play video games. This move aims to give YouTube an official home for gaming content and provides advertisers with a simple way to reach the coveted gaming audience.

site_title: A front-row seat to a star's unravelling
summary: A documentary film "Amy" chronicles the life of singer Amy Winehouse, from her rise to fame as a soulful jazz singer to her tragic downfall due to substance abuse. Director Asif Kapadia weaves together home videos, voice-overs, and interviews to create an intimate portrait of Winehouse, who struggled with personal demons despite her incredible talent. The film portrays her tumultuous relationship with Blake Fielder-Civil, the inspiration behind her hit album "Back to Black," and her struggles with fame, as well as her family's inability to help her. The film is a cautionary tale of the devastating consequences of self-destruction.

site_title: More watches, fewer launches
summary: Audemars Piguet has unveiled two concept watches and two special editions, as part of its efforts to streamline its annual watch launches and focus on other projects. The Royal Oak Concept RD#1 features a minute repeater and tourbillon, while the Royal Oak Concept Lap-timer Michael Schumacher chronograph measures consecutive lap times. Two limited editions, one for Indonesia and one for The Hour Glass, have also been released, with proceeds from the Indonesian edition going to a local museum.

site_title: GE2015: Veteran PAP MP Charles Chong to contest in Punggol East
summary: Veteran PAP MP Charles Chong, a six-term MP, will contest in Punggol East against incumbent Lee Li Lian of the Workers' Party in next month's general election. Chong, 62, aims to wrest the single seat ward back from the opposition. This is his first election challenge since joining the PAP in 2001.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Maybank expects lower loan growth as Malaysia economy slows
summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest lender, expects lower loan growth due to a slowing economy, with consumption expected to be weaker following the implementation of a new goods and services tax. The bank reported a net profit of RM1.58 billion in the second quarter, its highest quarterly net interest income since 2010. Despite this, Maybank's future growth may be hampered by a region-wide economic slowdown and depreciation of currencies. The bank remains optimistic about consistent earnings drivers in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Mr Farid said the outlook for the equity capital market remained soft in view of the weak market sentiment.

site_title: Still capable of springing surprises
summary: Patek Philippe unveiled three notable watches at BaselWorld 2015, including the Calatrava Pilot Travel Time Ref 5524G priced at S$62,800. The pilot watch was a surprise hit, with many considering it an "un-Patek" timepiece. Meanwhile, news from the region includes a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit, US weekly jobless claims falling unexpectedly, and China urging South-east Asia to back openness amid US tariffs. Additionally, Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector, while Reliance Jio delays its India IPO.

site_title: Sun-drenched mines look to the skies to cut fuel costs
summary: A solar farm is being built at the DeGrussa copper and gold mine in Australia, replacing about 5 million litres of diesel per year and potentially cutting energy costs by half. The move is part of the industry's shift towards renewable energy, joining other chemical producers and steelmakers in adopting clean energy sources. The project is expected to reduce the mine's reliance on diesel and contribute to a more sustainable future for the industry.

site_title: New movements
summary: Rolex has introduced the Calibre 3255, a new movement that optimizes the Swiss lever escapement's efficiency by 15% and features a 50% increase in power reserve to 70 hours. The movement also boasts twice the chronometric precision of an official chronometer. Additionally, Tudor has launched the MT5621 automatic movement, and Patek Philippe has introduced the Ref 5370, a pure split-second chronograph. Other brands, such as HYT, Omega, Hamilton, Chanel, and Blancpain, have also unveiled innovative timepieces, including the HYT H3, which uses fluids to tell time, and the Omega Seamaster Aqua Terra "James Bond" watch.

site_title: French business morale at four-year high, but investment still missing
summary: French business confidence reached a four-year high in August, with the business sentiment indicator and industrial morale index both increasing. However, business investment remains stagnant, with manufacturers planning a 2% increase this year, down from a previous forecast of a 7% increase. The government hopes for a recovery in business investment to boost growth, but Finance Minister Michel Sapin says the improvement in business sentiment surveys suggests the second-quarter weakness was temporary. Unemployment remains near record highs, but new home sales surged 22% in the second quarter.

The Open Farm Community will host a Farmers' Market on August 29-30, featuring local farms and businesses. A Week with Remy Martin is a cognac appreciation event running from August 29 to September 4, with workshops and a closing party. Margaret Leng Tan will perform Cabinet of Curiosities.

site_title: Indie zone
summary: Independent watch brands offer unique perspectives and emotive creations, distinct from mainstream luxury brands. Three brands stand out: Laurent Ferrier, H. Moser & Cie, and Nomos Glashutte. Ferrier's Galet Square features a cushion-shaped case and in-house automatic movement, while H. Moser & Cie's Dual Time Midnight Blue Fumé Venturer showcases a tourbillon and Straumann double hairspring. Nomos Glashutte's Tangente Automatik offers a minimalist design and in-house movement, all at affordable prices. Additionally, Bremont's Boeing Model 1 Ti-GMT and Hautlence's HL Black Ceramic highlight the diversity of independent watchmaking.

site_title: GE2015: 'Pick MPs who can help steer S'pore through challenges'
summary: Singaporean Minister Lim Swee Say emphasized the need for MPs to contribute to running the country, particularly in addressing the challenges of aging population and workforce growth. The government's strategies, which worked well in the past, are no longer sustainable, and voters must think carefully about the type of person they want to elect. The People's Action Party (PAP) has introduced its four-member team for the East Coast GRC, including new candidate Cheryl Chan, who aims to help vulnerable groups such as the elderly and children.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
The PAP slate for East Coast GRC are (from left) Lee Yi Shyan, Maliki Osman, Jessica Tan and Lim Swee Say, a four-member team hoping to win another term.

site_title: Promoting translations of S-E Asian writing
summary: A new non-profit organisation in Singapore, the Select Centre, aims to promote South-east Asian writing by raising translation standards, creating a wider audience for works in native languages. The centre, founded by William Phuan and Tan Dan Feng, will offer development programs and raise awareness of translation, focusing on languages within the region and beyond. Initial initiatives include a five-day translation workshop in Myanmar and an online Translators Lab, with a three-year seed grant from the National Arts Council. The centre hopes to expand its intercultural work, including adaptations of art forms.

images.alt_text: Singapore poet, writer and playwright Alfian Sa'at (right) was one of two writers in residence at a recent translation workshop in Yangon.

site_title: India's Modi among leaders with most to gain from cheap oil prices
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's stalled reform agenda is being revitalized due to cheap oil prices, which benefit India by shielding it from China's economic turmoil. India's economy has seen a 13% increase in foreign exchange reserves, inflation halved, and a narrowed current account deficit. Modi's government aims to implement structural reforms, including a unified tax regime and easier land acquisition, to further strengthen the economy. Despite the opportunity, the government has yet to pass key reforms, with legislative wins seen as crucial to bolstering sentiment in emerging markets like India.

site_title: Channel technology optimally to make Singapore a 'smart city'
summary: Singapore is striving to become a "smart city" through technology and sustainable practices. A recent meeting of industry and government leaders emphasized the need to channel technology effectively to ensure the city's growth is smart, clean, and efficient. The government has already demonstrated a strong approach to renewable energy, such as through the SolarNova program, and is now focusing on energy efficiency to reduce CO2 emissions and costs. The goal is to create a holistic and sustainable approach to urban development, prioritizing the well-being of citizens and the environment.

site_title: Making the most of horse racing
summary: Longines, a 183-year-old Swiss watch brand, has launched its updated DolceVita collection, a women's line inspired by the Italian sweet life, in celebration of the Prix de Diane Longines horse race in France. The collection features four steel and four diamond-set steel models, priced starting at S$1,750, and is available in various strap and bracelet options. Longines has also introduced new men's lines, including the Conquest Classic Moonphase and Pulsometer Chronograph, as well as the Equestrian collection, with prices ranging from S$1,590 to S$6,360. The new collections were launched at an evening garden party in Chantilly, France, attended by Indian actress Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Longines' ambassador of elegance.
