site_title: Swiss watch exports dipped after Apple Watch's debut
summary: Swiss watch exports, including those to Singapore, dropped 9.3% in July to 1.9 billion Swiss francs, the largest decline since 2009. The Apple Watch's launch in April is believed to be the cause, with analysts estimating 1.9 million units sold in June. The decline was particularly sharp in Asia, with shipments to Hong Kong and China falling 28.7% and 39.6%, respectively. The strong Swiss franc also had an adverse effect on exports, with shipments to Asia down 8.1%.

site_title: Carbotech, the next Bronzo
summary: Panerai has introduced a new Luminor Submersible collection featuring a rotating bezel, inspired by a 1956 watch for the Egyptian Navy. The Carbotech 3 Days Automatic, priced at S$24,800, boasts a unique case made from a composite material called carbotech, a first in watchmaking. The 47mm case is modelled on the Laminar 1950 case and features a self-winding movement with three days' power reserve. Other models unveiled include the Luminor Submersible 1950 Chrono Flyback Automatic Titanio and the Mare Nostrum chronograph, which features a titanium case and a hand-wound movement.

site_title: Rowsley strikes deals with former Manchester United stars
summary: Rowsley, a Singapore-listed real estate company, has struck deals with former Manchester United stars Gary Neville and Ryan Giggs. Rowsley is investing £40 million in a 75% stake in St Michael's, a £200 million mixed-use project in Manchester, with the footballers owning 2% each. Additionally, Rowsley has acquired a hotel, cafe, and hotel management company owned by the Class of 92 Manchester United footballers, including Neville and Giggs, for £29.1 million. The deals aim to tap into Manchester's growing vibrancy and growth, with Rowsley seeking to develop and acquire hotels in prime locations.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: LionGold replies to SGX, says it's able to operate as going concern
summary: LionGold Corp, a Singapore-listed gold miner, has responded to a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query, stating it can operate as a going concern despite its external auditor PwC's disclaimer of opinion. The company will seek shareholder approval for a proposed S$100 million fund raising issue, which will repay outstanding convertible bonds and fund operations. LionGold's first tranche of S$50 million will be sufficient to cover these obligations, and the company believes it will be able to raise sufficient funds to continue operating.

site_title: Many investors avoid world's biggest bank at cheapest levels
summary: Investors are hesitant to buy Chinese banks, despite their low valuations, due to concerns about bad loans and the slowing economy. Fund manager Arthur Kwong at BNP Paribas Investment Partners believes Chinese banks' balance sheets are questionable, while analysts like Ma Kunpeng at Sinolink Securities Co argue that investors are pricing them too low. The Chinese central bank's interest rate cut has added pressure on margins, but also mitigated bad-loan risks. Despite the low valuations, some analysts see it as a buying opportunity, with forecasts of 6.9% GDP growth this year and efforts to cut high-cost debt.

site_title: Education startup HotChalk in talks to raise new funding
summary: HotChalk, an educational technology startup, is in talks to raise at least $75 million from private investors, valuing the company at $500-800 million. The company, which helps universities create online degree programs, has hired Citigroup to assist with the fund-raising. This would be HotChalk's largest funding round since the financial crisis and its first since 2008. The company plans to announce new customers in the coming months, including Concordia University-Portland.

site_title: GE2015: Reform Party names candidates for West Coast GRC and Radin Mas SMC
summary: The Reform Party of Singapore has announced its candidates for the 2015 General Election, including Kumar Appavoo in Radin Mas SMC and a team in West Coast GRC. The party's secretary-general, Kenneth Jeyaretnam, stated that the slate will be finalized on Nomination Day on Sept 1. The party's manifesto includes initiatives such as a monthly pension for senior citizens and child benefits, as well as financial transparency and a minimum wage. The party has also attracted controversy with its inclusion of blogger Roy Ngerng and lawyer M Ravi, who are contesting in Ang Mo Kio GRC.

site_title: GE2015: WP's Daniel Goh weighs in on PAP's unveiling of candidates at coffee shops
summary: Workers' Party candidate Daniel Goh criticized the People's Action Party's (PAP) approach of introducing candidates in coffee shops, calling it "symbolic tokenism." Goh stated that such introductions would be "extremely uncomfortable" and "appropriates our living space for my own political profit." This comes ahead of the 2015 general election in Singapore.

site_title: GuocoLeisure posts 23% rise in net profit on cost management
summary: GuocoLeisure reported a 23% rise in net profit to US$47.9 million for the 12 months ended June 30, driven by better cost management, including lower finance costs and operating expenses. Despite revenues impacted by the depreciation of the Great British pound, the group's earnings improved. This was attributed to cost management efforts, rather than revenue growth.

site_title: WP's potential candidate Daniel Goh denies allegations of extramarital affair
summary: Workers' Party potential candidate Daniel Goh has denied allegations of an extramarital affair with a student, stating he "categorically refutes the baseless allegations." Goh questioned the timing of the allegations, which surfaced after his candidate introduction. The allegations were made via an email to the press.

site_title: World risks third food-price surge in a decade
summary: El Nino, a global weather pattern, is predicted to be the strongest since records began in 1950, potentially leading to a third food-price surge in a decade. Rising demand and crop shortfalls could trigger price surges, particularly in countries with high food expenditures, such as Bangladesh, Algeria, and Egypt. Nomura analysts warn that shortages could be compounded by hoarding, speculation, and trade protectionism, potentially leading to economic growth shrinkage and inflation in affected nations.

site_title: Singapore's financial centre can do better in many areas, says panel
summary: Singapore's financial centre is well-established but can improve in areas such as attracting institutional investors, promoting innovation, and developing digital capabilities. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's Financial Centre Advisory Panel (FCAP) discussed strategies to grow the centre, with members noting strong gains in asset and wealth management, reinsurance, and foreign exchange. The panel also identified opportunities to promote digital distribution, advanced analytics, and other innovations to drive growth in the insurance industry. The FCAP plans to meet biannually, with its next meeting scheduled for January 2016.

site_title: French home sales picking up as investors return
summary: French new home sales have rebounded with a 22% increase in the second quarter, the highest since 2009. Investors returned to the market, with sales to investors jumping 66% and those to aspiring homeowners rising only 5%. However, homebuilding remains in a slump, with new housing starts dropping over 7% in June. Despite this, property developers like Bouygues are optimistic about the recovery, with CEO Martin Bouygues predicting the effect won't be felt until mid-2016. The rebound is seen as a positive sign for the euro zone's second-largest economy.

site_title: Behind the crash - the commodities bubble
summary: A global commodities bubble has burst, driven by a surge in demand from China's rapid growth, but ultimately fueled by unsustainable price levels. Prices of commodities such as oil, iron ore, copper, and wheat have dropped sharply, with declines of 48-60% since 2012. The collapse is attributed to a shift in China's economic growth, from 10% in 2010 to 6.8% in 2015, leading to a surplus of production capacity and reduced demand. This has had a profound impact on emerging market economies, with stock markets in countries such as Brazil, Indonesia, and South Africa also experiencing declines. Economists warn of potential loan defaults and bankruptcies, but also note that lower commodity prices may strengthen consumer spending.

site_title: Commodity slide makes mockery of Draghi's Jackson Hole speech
summary: Mario Draghi's 2014 Jackson Hole speech aimed to boost inflation, but a collapse in commodity prices has pushed bond investors' inflation expectations lower. The ECB's 1.1 trillion euro bond-buying program has helped, but analysts predict yields will stay low, with Germany's 10-year bund yield forecast to remain below 1%. The five-year, five-year forward inflation swap rate has dropped to 1.59%, down from 2% at the time of Draghi's speech, indicating falling inflation expectations. This may prompt further stimulus from the ECB to reach its goal of just below 2% annual consumer-price growth.

site_title: China expands debt-for-bond swap plan to US$499b
summary: China has expanded its debt-for-bond swap programme to US$499.7 billion, aiming to ease financing pressure on heavily indebted local governments. The programme, initially launched to support inefficient building projects, has been steadily expanded since its inception. Despite policy measures, signs point to a deepening economic slowdown, with a private survey showing China's factory sector activity shrinking at its fastest pace in 6-1/2 years in August.

site_title: Update: Olam to plan sale of more than 10% stake to Mitsubishi Corp
summary: Olam International Ltd., a Singapore-based food commodity trader, plans to sell more than 10% stake to Mitsubishi Corp. The deal will involve issuing new shares to Mitsubishi, with Temasek Holdings retaining its 58% stake. The move is part of Olam's efforts to expand in agriculture, following its acquisition of a US$1.3 billion cocoa business. The company's shares have surged 13% on the news, marking the largest gain since April 2009.

site_title: Twists and turns Cartier-style
summary: Cartier unveils its new collection, bending traditional watchmaking rules with unique shapes and complications. The Cle De Cartier features a round bezel and tapered horns, while the Crash Skeleton Watch Calibre 9618 MC is inspired by a damaged Cartier watch from 1967. The brand also introduces a grand complication watch, the Ballon Bleu de Cartier with vibrating diamonds, and a ladies' watch with a pack of panther decorations. Prices range from 13,760 euros for the Cle De Cartier to 126,000 euros for the diamond-paved version and 600,000 euros for the platinum grand complication.

site_title: Girard Perregaux returns to its roots
summary: Girard Perregaux, an acquired brand by Kering, is revisiting its classic models with a modern twist. The iconic Tourbillon with Three Bridges, introduced in 1889, is being reimagined with a contemporary look. This timepiece, which won a gold medal at the Universal Exhibition in Paris, has been a defining feature of the brand's identity since its inception. The updated model is expected to incorporate the same minimalist architecture that has made it a benchmark in watchmaking.

site_title: Breguet's 2015 novelties
summary: Breguet unveiled its 2015 novelties, including the limited-edition Marine Chronographe "200 ans de Marine" in platinum, priced at S$78,000, and the Tradition Chronographe Independent 7077 with two independent trains, priced at S$114,500. The Reine de Naples Princesse Mini collection was also introduced, featuring a self-winding movement and prices starting at S$22,300 for steel and S$36,800 for rose gold. These new timepieces mark the bicentenary of Abraham-Louis Breguet's appointment as chronometer-maker to the French navy.

site_title: US economy grew 3.7% in Q2
summary: The US economy grew 3.7% in the second quarter, exceeding the initial estimate of 2.3% and analysts' expectations of 3.1%. The revision was driven by higher investment, state and local government spending, and consumer spending. This marks a significant improvement from the 0.6% growth in the first quarter, largely due to severe winter weather and West Coast port strikes.

site_title: Salute to FA Lange
summary: Ferdinand Adolph Lange, a German watchmaker, marked the 200th birthday of his company A Lange & Sohne in 2015. Born in 1815 in Dresden, Germany, Lange trained as a clockmaker and later honed his skills in France, Switzerland, and England. He returned to Germany in 1841 and established A Lange & Comp in Glashutte, creating precision watches that won a first prize at the World Exhibition in London in 1851. Lange's innovative designs and commitment to the metric system helped revive German watchmaking, and his legacy continues to shape the industry today.

site_title: Tudor unveils latest North Flag, Pelagos, Fastrider
summary: Tudor unveiled its 2015 watch novelties, the North Flag, Pelagos, and Fastrider. The North Flag, inspired by the British North Greenland Expedition team, features a 40mm steel case and a double bezel, priced at $3,550 in leather strap and $3,675 in steel bracelet. The Pelagos, a diver's watch, has a 42mm titanium case and is water-proofed to 500 meters, priced around $4,400. The Fastrider, a chronograph, features a 42mm steel case and an automatic movement, priced around $4,399. All three watches are powered by Tudor's first in-house movement, certified by the Official Swiss Chronometer Testing Institute.

images.alt_text: Left: Tudor Fastrider. Right: Tudor North Flag

site_title: GE2015: SDP reveals third batch of new faces
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) unveiled two new candidates, psychologist John Tan and auditor Sidek Mallek, at a press conference on August 27, 2015, as part of its 2015 general election campaign. The candidates' positions were not disclosed.

site_title: Raffles Education FY net profit slumps 69%
summary: Raffles Education's FY net profit plummeted 69% to S$16.98 million, primarily due to the absence of one-time gains from the previous year. Revenue declined 4% to S$119.9 million, while other operating income dropped 87% to S$7.9 million. The group recognized a net fair value gain of S$23 million from revaluation of investment properties. A dividend of one cent per share was declared, unchanged from the previous year.

site_title: Malaysia turns to 1998 currency peg architect as markets bleed
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak has formed an economic task force, led by former premier Mahathir Mohamad's ringgit peg architect, to address the country's declining confidence in its currency and markets. The task force, which includes business leaders and former finance officials, aims to stem a decline in confidence and prevent a further loss of capital. Najib has vowed not to return to capital controls, but the move is seen as a response to pressure from investors and foreign funds that have dumped billions of dollars in Malaysian shares this year.

site_title: Aspial raises S$146.7m from retail bond offering
summary: Aspial Corporation Limited raised S$146.7 million from its maiden retail bond offering, with an overwhelming response from investors. The public tranche received S$217.3 million of valid applications, while the placement tranche received S$75 million. The five-year bonds offer 5.25% interest, guaranteed by Aspial and issued by its subsidiary. DBS Bank Ltd was the sole lead manager and bookrunner for the offer, which saw a subscription rate of 3.9 times the original offer size.

site_title: Hu An Cable warns of H1 loss due to impairments
summary: Hu An Cable Holdings Ltd issued a profit warning, expecting a loss for the six months ended June 30, due to impairments from doubtful prepayments to suppliers and slow debt collection. The company attributed a 310 million yuan (S$67.7 million) loss to a supplier's bankruptcy and liquidation. This slump in sales and gross margins is attributed to market demand and competition.

site_title: Jaquet Droz ups the ante
summary: Jaquet Droz has unveiled two new timepieces, the Lady 8 Flower and The Eclipse, showcasing the brand's mastery of watchmaking and craftsmanship. The Lady 8 Flower features a blooming lotus flower and a delicate butterfly, while The Eclipse boasts a complication with moon phase, day, month, and date indications. The brand has also introduced the Grande Seconde Deadbeat, a limited edition watch featuring an independent seconds mechanism, and the Bird Repeater Geneva, a timepiece celebrating Geneva's watchmaking heritage with eight animations.

site_title: Ezra to sell half of subsea arm to Japan's Chiyoda for US$180 million
summary: Ezra Holdings is selling half of its subsea services business, EMAS AMC, to Japan's Chiyoda for US$180 million. The deal values EMAS AMC at US$360 million and includes US$530 million in third-party debt and US$360 million in long-term funding. The sale will allow Ezra to focus on larger deepwater projects, with CEO Lionel Lee stating the company is tendering for around US$9 billion worth of projects. The deal is subject to Chiyoda's due diligence and Ezra's shareholder approval.

site_title: Master of ultra-thin timepieces
summary: Piaget has introduced the Altiplano Chronograph, the world's thinnest chronograph watch, measuring 4.65mm thick and 8.24mm thick. The hand-wound calibre is paired with a 41mm white or pink gold case. This ultra-thin creation is priced at S$41,700, comparable to the Altiplano 900P. The Altiplano Chronograph is the first complication in the Altiplano collection, solidifying Piaget's status as a master of ultra-thin timepieces.

site_title: Oris's ProPilot Calibre set for December landing here
summary: Oris has released its first in-house movement, Calibre 111, in the Big Crown ProPilot Calibre 111 watch. The 44mm stainless steel case features a non-linear power reserve indicator and anti-reflective sapphire crystal. The watch is designed for pilots and will arrive in Singapore in December. Prices start at S$7,200 for a steel bracelet and S$7,500 for a crocodile leather strap. This marks Oris's return to movement manufacturing after almost 35 years.

site_title: ASL Marine secures S$140m in shipbuilding contracts
summary: ASL Marine Holdings Ltd announced the securing of S$140 million in shipbuilding contracts for the construction of tugs and barges for overseas customers in the mining and marine infrastructure industries. The projects will be executed in Singapore and Indonesia, with revenue recognized over the contract period. The contracts are not expected to have a material impact on the company's net tangible asset and earnings per share for the financial year ending June 30, 2016.

site_title: Malaysia says cooperating with Indonesia in palm oil industry
summary: Malaysia and Indonesia agreed to improve cooperation in the palm oil industry amid a grim global economic environment and low prices. Benchmark Malaysian palm prices reached a 6-1/2 year low due to a drop in financial markets, particularly in China, a major palm oil consumer. The two countries aim to enhance the perception of palm oil, including its nutritional and sustainable production. Improved cooperation may reduce the discount between crude palm oil and other vegetable oils, potentially leading to better palm oil prices.

site_title: LionGold responds to SGX query on auditor's disclaimer of opinion
summary: LionGold Corp, a Singapore-listed gold miner, has responded to a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query on its auditor's disclaimer of opinion, stating it can operate as a going concern. The company will seek shareholder approval for a proposed S$100 million redeemable convertible bond issue. LionGold's notes to its annual report said the first tranche of S$50 million will fund operations and repay outstanding convertible bonds, despite a material uncertainty casting doubt on its ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares bounce on Wall Street, mainland rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks experienced their largest one-day percentage gain since July 9, with the Hang Seng index rising 3.6% to 21,838.54, and the China Enterprises Index gaining 4.6% to 9,863.61 points. The rally was fueled by sharp gains on the US Wall Street and in mainland China. Trading volume reached 3.3 billion shares.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore's services sector saw a 3.5% year-on-year increase in business receipts in Q2, with all but the recreation & personal services segment experiencing growth. A new industry-led productivity council partnered with the Construction Industry Institute to study and implement best practices for project management. Agri-trader Olam International is set to announce a strategic partnership with a Japanese peer. The Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) rose 2.5% at close, following dovish remarks by a US central banker.

images.alt_text: Business receipts for the services industry in Singapore rose 3.5 per cent year on year in the second quarter of 2015, with all but the recreation & personal services segment experiencing turnover growth, data released by the Department of Statistics (DOS) on Thursday showed.

site_title: Exporters run for high ground as China growth story unravels
summary: European exporters are accelerating their move into premium goods and services as China's economic slowdown pushes for higher margins. China's economic slowdown is exposing unneeded supply and weak demand, leading to falling prices in previously insulated areas. China's interest rate cut and loosening of bank lending restrictions aim to boost local consumption and production, but may not be enough to reverse the economic slowdown.

site_title: Sacked Singaporean legal officer in 1MDB probe thanks Malaysia for not revoking her PR
summary: A Singaporean legal officer involved in the 1MDB probe, Jessica Gurmeet Kaur, has expressed gratitude to Malaysia's Immigration director-general for not revoking her permanent residency. Kaur, who was sacked from her position, thanked her lawyers and requested media respect for her privacy. This decision comes after Malaysia's Immigration Department confirmed her PR status was not revoked. The move appears to be a relief for Kaur, who can now move forward with her life.

images.alt_text: Swiss authorities said on Wednesday they had frozen funds in Swiss banks amid a probe into people linked to Malaysia's troubled state investment fund, 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB), on suspicion of corruption and money laundering.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble Group surges 14% to lead gains on Singapore benchmark
summary: Noble Group Ltd surged 14% to 51.5 Singapore cents, leading gains on Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index, its largest advance in three weeks. The stock is still trading at less than half its February price after criticism of its accounting methods. Noble pledged to boost its annual operating income to over $2 billion within five years. Short interest in the company reached a record 14.5% on Tuesday, with some analysts citing bargain hunting as a possible driver of the surge.

images.alt_text: Noble Group Ltd, the commodities trader facing criticism of its accounting methods, jumped by the most in three weeks to lead gains on Singapore's benchmark equity measure.

site_title: Eurozone loans to private sector increase: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank reported a 1% increase in loans to the private sector in July, a 0.6% increase in June, and a 5.3% increase in the overall eurozone money supply from the previous year. This suggests that the ECB's monetary policy measures are finally having a positive impact on the economy, ending a period of contraction. The increase in private sector loans and money supply is a positive sign for economic health, and could indicate a potential end to the financial crisis in the eurozone.

site_title: Ezra said to near sale of subsea unit stake to Japan's Chiyoda
summary: Ezra Holdings Ltd, a Singapore-based offshore marine services provider, is nearing a deal to sell about 50% of its subsea business to Japanese engineering firm Chiyoda Corp for over $1 billion, including debt. This comes after Ezra sold its offshore marine operations for $520 million last year. The sale is part of Ezra's efforts to focus on the growing subsea services market, where it competes with global rivals. Ezra's shares have fallen 64% this year, and the company has suspended trading pending an announcement.

site_title: US: Stocks advance after stronger GDP data
summary: US stocks rose, following their biggest gains since 2011, amid a relief rally in global markets. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index rose 1.3% to 1,965.08, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 1% to 16,453.67. Data showed the economy grew 3.7% annualized in Q2, exceeding estimates, and jobless benefits filings declined to a three-week low. The GDP report may influence the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates, with some arguing for a delay due to the global stock plunge.

images.alt_text: US stocks rose, following their biggest gains since 2011, amid a relief rally throughout global markets and as data showed the economy grew more than previously estimated.

site_title: GE2015: Is this the final line-up of the SPP-DPP team for Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC?
summary: A leaked mock-up of an election poster for the Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC team of the Singapore People's Party-Democratic Progressive Party may reveal the opposition's final lineup. The poster features three SPP members and two DPP members, including party chief Benjamin Pwee and chairman Hamim Aliyas. The lineup could be the opposition's final selection for the five-member GRC. The leak comes ahead of the Singapore General Election, with the exact slate yet to be confirmed.

site_title: MyRepublic to start mobile network trial in October
summary: MyRepublic, Singapore's third-largest telco, will start an eight-week trial of its mobile network service on October 22 in the Jurong East area. The trial is a step towards the company becoming Singapore's fourth telco, joining Singtel, StarHub, and M1.

site_title: Singapore agri-trader Olam to unveil partnership with Japanese peer: sources
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-based agri-trader majority owned by Temasek, is set to announce a strategic partnership with a Japanese peer, Mitsubishi Corp or Mitsui & Co. The talks include one of the Japanese firms investing in Olam, with the potential for a joint venture to leverage global reach. Olam's shares surged 13% before a trading halt, pending an announcement. The partnership aims to cut debt, boost cash flow, and generate profits for the company. Details of the partnership are expected to be revealed shortly.

site_title: Racing to beat China, Japan's PM sweetens bid for Indonesia rail project
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Abe has sent a special envoy to Indonesia to offer a sweeter deal for a high-speed rail project between Jakarta and Bandung, competing with China's bid. Japan is offering a 40-year loan at 0.1% interest, while China has offered a $5.5 billion loan with a 50-year tenure. Indonesia is set to announce a winner soon, with the government seeking to avoid upsetting either trading partner. The project is seen as a symbol of national pride and development in Japan, and business relations between Japan and Indonesia are expected to remain normal regardless of the outcome.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end more than 20 points higher
summary: Malaysian stocks ended higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 21.33 points to 1,601.7. A total of 2.1 billion lots valued at RM2.31 billion were traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 726 to 206.

site_title: STI climbs 2.5% at close
summary: Singapore stocks rose 2.5% at close, reversing a four-day decline, after a US central banker made dovish remarks. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,945.43, with Noble Group being the most actively traded stock, jumping 14.4% to 51.5 cents. About 1.96 billion shares changed hands for S$1.61 billion.

site_title: GE2015: WP unveils second batch of candidates
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) in Singapore unveiled its second batch of candidates for the upcoming General Election, including Cheryl Denise Loh, Firuz Khan, Luke Koh, and Terence Tan. Khan, a UK-based chocolate factory owner, highlighted his experience working with children and his exposure to poverty and abuse. Loh, a sales consultant, aims to champion education causes. The WP's candidates follow the introduction of its first batch in July.

site_title: Rubber market to worsen first before recovering around 2020: Lanxess
summary: German synthetic rubber producer Lanxess predicts a worsening rubber market over the next two to three years, but expects it to recover by 2020. The company will gradually ramp up production of its new neodymium butadiene rubber plant in Singapore. Despite a slowdown in China, Lanxess sees the country's economy growing at a faster clip than Europe and North America, and believes demand for rubber will improve in the mid to long term, driven by the tyre industry's growth. The company has made investments with a long-term view, expecting to accelerate production again in 2020.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rallied 2.5% in opening trade on Thursday, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street and Asia. The FTSE 100 index rose 2.46%, the DAX 30 jumped 2.74%, and the CAC 40 soared 2.47%. This follows a US Federal Reserve official's comments that the turmoil in global markets weakened the case for a September interest rate rise, snapping a six-day losing streak for US stocks.

site_title: Malaysia, Thailand to use their currencies in trade, investment
summary: Malaysia and Thailand have agreed to use their currencies, the Malaysian ringgit and Thai baht, in trade and investment between the two countries, aiming to reduce exposure to global market volatility and lower transaction costs. The central banks signed a memorandum of understanding to promote the use of their currencies, paving the way for greater financial integration in the Asean region. This move follows a trend of emerging economies seeking to diversify their economic exposure and reduce reliance on global settlement currencies.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks surge 5.34% by the close on US rally
summary: Shanghai stocks surged 5.34% by the close on Thursday, driven by a US stock rally and a domestic interest rate cut. China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rose 156.30 points to 3,083.59 on turnover of 404.3 billion yuan. The Shenzhen Composite Index also jumped 3.33% to 1,752.21. The gains followed a late surge, which briefly pushed the index into negative territory.

site_title: Hot stock: Olam jumps by most in 6 years before halting shares from trade
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-based commodity trading company, surged 13% to its highest in six years before halting trading. The company's shares rose to S$1.91, giving it a market value of S$4.7 billion. This marks the biggest jump for Olam since April 2009. The halt comes as the company prepares to announce a major deal, a US$1.3 billion acquisition of Archer-Daniels-Midland's cocoa unit, expected to close by the end of the year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close higher, foreigners sell for 16th day; won flat
summary: Seoul shares closed higher on Thursday, rising 0.7% to 1,908.0 points, driven by Wall Street rallies and a Chinese stock market rebound. However, foreigners sold domestic shares for the 16th consecutive session, netting a 4.116 trillion won loss. The won remained nearly flat at 1,185.2, weighed down by foreign selling.

site_title: Philippine economic growth quickens to 5.6% in Q2
summary: The Philippine economy experienced a 5.6% growth in the second quarter, outpacing the 5.0% growth in the previous quarter. Higher government spending and public construction contributed to the growth. The country's economic fundamentals remain strong, with growth averaging 5.3% in the first half. The government projects a realistic growth range of 6.0-6.5% for the full year, below the target of 7.0-8.0%. Despite global economic concerns, the Philippines is considered the third-fastest-growing economy in the region.

site_title: GE2015: Reform Party unveils candidates for West Coast GRC, Radin Mas SMC
summary: The Reform Party (RP) has announced candidates for the Singapore General Election, including Mr. Kumar Appavoo in Radin Mas SMC against incumbent MP Sam Tan, and no candidates for the West Coast GRC.

site_title: Trash talk trumps civility on US campaign trail
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump is leading the charge in mudslinging on the campaign trail, criticizing rivals and others with harsh language. Trump's lack of civility has raised concerns, with some observers noting that his behavior is fueling a divisive and negative atmosphere. Despite the RNC's warning that name-calling needs to stop, Trump continues to use insults to gain attention and tap into the sentiment of Americans' dissatisfaction with the economy and politics.

images.alt_text: Five months before early primary voting, America's presidential race has devolved into mudslinging, with Republican Donald Trump leading the charge to the bottom by lambasting his many rivals

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda says China slowdown unlikely to hit Japan exports much
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that China's economic slowdown is unlikely to significantly impact Japan's exports in the coming years. Despite China's predicted 6-7% GDP growth this year and next, Kuroda believes Japan's competitive capital goods will mitigate any negative effects. He also noted that China's monetary easing is a necessary step to mitigate any impact, adding that some market players have become overly pessimistic about the Chinese economy.

site_title: Silicon Valley wary as Pentagon chief comes to court innovators
summary: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter is visiting Silicon Valley to bridge the divide between the Pentagon and tech companies wary of excessive surveillance and privacy violations. The mission aims to counter cyber threats and adapt new commercial technology for defense applications. Carter seeks to recruit top innovators like Apple and Google to join traditional defense contractors on the front lines. The Pentagon is requesting $5.5 billion for cyberspace activities and plans to shift focus to offensive and defensive cyber capabilities. The trip is part of a broader effort to build trust and foster partnerships between the Pentagon and Silicon Valley, but faces significant hurdles due to perceptions and practices.

images.alt_text: With malware joining missiles among the threats to America's security, leading technology innovators such as Apple and Google are being recruited to join traditional defense contractors on the front lines.

site_title: China's richest man says time for government to abandon high growth rate 'fantasy'
summary: China's richest man, Wang Jianlin, says the government should abandon its goal of maintaining high economic growth rates of 7-8% as "fantasy" and focus on sustainable and safe growth. He suggests China needs to shift from investment and exports to consumption-driven growth. The comments come amid concerns over a slowing Chinese economy, which is expected to expand around 7% this year, the lowest in over two decades. Wang believes the recent market meltdown won't affect his company's operations, and he expects to surpass its 2015 targets.

site_title: Tata motors unveils new small truck as Maruti plans challenge
summary: Tata Motors unveiled the Ace Mega, a small cargo truck with a 1-ton capacity, priced at 431,000 rupees (US$6,530). The company aims to bolster its market share in the segment, where Maruti Suzuki plans to challenge its dominance. Sales have begun in seven states, with plans to extend to the rest of the country by next month. Tata Motors is counting on a pickup in economic activity to drive demand for its small trucks, despite a 18% decline in light truck deliveries in the April-July period.

site_title: Indonesia to unveil policy package to help rupiah
summary: Indonesia is set to unveil a policy package aimed at supporting the rupiah, the country's currency. The package, announced by Coordinating Minister for Economics Darmin Nasution, includes tax holidays for investors and new deregulation policies. The measures are expected to take effect next week, aiming to boost economic activity and attract foreign currency. The move comes as the rupiah has been under pressure.

site_title: China arrests 12 over Tianjin blasts: Xinhua
summary: Chinese police have arrested 12 people, including the chairman and senior managers of Rui Hai International Logistics, over the Tianjin blasts that killed 139 and injured hundreds. Prosecutors are also investigating 11 officials for "abuse of power" and "dereliction of duty." The blasts, which occurred two weeks ago, have sparked outrage over alleged safety violations and possible official collusion. The incident is China's highest-profile industrial accident in years, and the investigation is seen as a test of the government's commitment to safety regulations.

images.alt_text: This general view shows the damage to shipping containers in Tianjin on August 17, 2015.

site_title: Indonesia hands out tax holidays to attract industry investment
summary: Indonesia offers tax holidays to attract industry investment, with new companies investing at least one trillion rupiah (S$98.6 million) eligible for reduced taxes of 10-100% for 5-15 years. The move aims to boost the economy, which has grown at its slowest pace in over five years, with growth slowing to 4.67% in the second quarter. The announcement follows a cabinet reshuffle by President Joko Widodo to improve coordination and policy making, and a major deregulation effort to improve the investment climate.

site_title: OCBC, Lion Global create private-equity fund with external investors
summary: OCBC Bank and Lion Global Investors have successfully closed the Lion-OCBC Capital Asia Fund I, L.P., a private-equity fund investing in small and medium companies in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, and China. The fund, launched in November 2014, has grown to S$550 million, exceeding its initial target of S$400 million. It took nine months to secure investor subscriptions, with institutional investors and high net worth individuals attracted to the fund's superior returns and unique positioning as a bank-sponsored investment. The fund's internal rate of return has consistently exceeded 20% over the past six years.

site_title: UK annual house price growth lowest since mid-2013: Nationwide
summary: British house prices rose 3.2% year-on-year in August, the lowest annual growth since mid-2013, according to a Nationwide survey. This is down from a 3.5% rise in July. Economists had expected a 3.1% growth rate. On a monthly basis, prices rose 0.3%, in line with expectations. This marks the weakest annual pace in over two years, indicating a slowdown in the UK housing market.

images.alt_text: British house prices increased this month at the slowest annual pace in more than two years, a survey from mortgage lender Nationwide showed on Thursday.

site_title: Maybank expects lower loan growth as Malaysian economy slows
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank) expects Malaysia's economy to slow, leading to lower loan growth and spending. The bank's group president and CEO Abdul Farid Alias attributed this to the implementation of a new goods and services tax and weak market sentiment. Despite posting its highest quarterly net interest income since 2010, Maybank's future growth may be hampered by a region-wide economic slowdown and depreciation of currencies. The bank expects consistent earnings drivers in the second half of the year, with its shares gaining 1.41% prior to the earnings release.

site_title: Update: Asia stocks take heart from Wall Street rally, China gains
summary: Asian stocks rose on Thursday, extending gains after a sharp rebound on Wall Street and gains in Chinese shares. The dollar rallied as risk aversion eased, while European shares slid nearly 2% overnight. The US Federal Reserve's New York President William Dudley said a September rate hike "seems less compelling" given recent market turmoil. Chinese shares rose, with the CSI300 index adding 2.5%, after Beijing rolled out policy easing steps. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 1.8%, pulling away from a three-year low.

site_title: QE back in focus turns rally of euro and yen into two-day wonder
summary: The euro and yen experienced a two-day surge against the dollar before being reined in by investors' renewed focus on European and Japanese quantitative easing. The euro fell 2% versus the dollar after European Central Bank Executive Board member Peter Praet hinted at expanding the ECB's asset-buying program. Meanwhile, Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated the central bank has "many options" to bolster easing. Analysts predict the euro may drop to parity with the dollar by next year, while the yen could rise to 122 in a calmer scenario.

site_title: Gold coasts along as stocks perk up, possible Fed hike delay supports
summary: Gold prices steadied on Thursday after a 1.3% drop in the prior session, with spot gold rising 0.2% to $1,127.35 an ounce. Asian stocks rebounded, led by Chinese markets, and a possible delay in a US rate hike supported gold prices. US gold for December delivery edged up 0.2% to $1,127.10 an ounce, as New York Fed President William Dudley suggested the September rate hike was less compelling. Gold remains up nearly 5% from its 5-1/2-year low in July.

site_title: Singapore services sector business receipts up 3.5% in Q2
summary: Singapore's services sector saw a 3.5% year-on-year increase in business receipts in Q2 2015, with the financial & insurance segment experiencing the highest growth of 9.5%. The health & social services segment followed with an 8.9% growth, while the recreation & personal services segment declined 18.3%. Quarterly growth was 1.4%, with mixed performance.

site_title: Temasek joins MBK-led consortium to bid for Tesco's South Korea unit: sources
summary: Asia-focused private equity firm MBK Partners has partnered with Singapore state investor Temasek Holdings to bid for Tesco's South Korea unit valued at about $6 billion. They are competing against Affinity Equity Partners/KKR & Co and Carlyle Group LP. This move comes as Tesco seeks to sell its South Korea arm amidst declining sales. The bid is the latest development in the ongoing sale process, which has been ongoing since last year.

site_title: 10-day Grand Prix Season Singapore begins on Sept 11
summary: The 10-day Grand Prix Season Singapore, themed "One Stop Non Stop," will begin on September 11 and run until September 20. The event will feature over 100 activities and promotions islandwide, with in-circuit concert headliners such as Bon Jovi and Pharrell Williams. The 2015 Formula 1 Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix will remain the only night street race in the global Formula One circuit.

site_title: China's yuan firms slightly, supported by rise in stocks
summary: China's yuan rose slightly against the dollar midday Thursday, supported by a 1.55% rebound in the Shanghai Composite Index. The recovery in the stock market, partly fueled by a strong Wall Street rebound, boosted sentiment on the currency. The stronger rebound calmed global markets after days of volatility. This was partly due to a series of easing policies, which have also boosted the stock market.

site_title: Update: Oil prices up in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices rose in Asian trade on Thursday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate gaining 86 US cents to $39.46 and Brent crude rising $1.07 to $44.21. The US Department of Energy reported a 5.5 million barrel decline in crude inventories, but production remained steady. Despite this, gasoline supplies increased, fueling concerns of a global energy glut. The mixed report compounded negative sentiment, which saw oil prices hit their lowest levels since early 2009. Analysts predict a rebound in commodities markets, with prices stabilizing or even edging higher.

site_title: Australia: Shares close up 1.17 per cent
summary: Australian stocks closed 1.17% higher on Thursday, following a strong rally on US markets after a top Federal Reserve official downplayed the case for a September rate hike. Fears over China's slowing growth eased, allowing for a surge in Asian stocks. The S&P/ASX200 index finished at 5,233.3, after falling to a two-year low earlier in the week.

site_title: Singapore, US institute seek to improve project management
summary: Singapore and the US-based Construction Industry Institute (CII) have launched a 3-year partnership to improve project management in the process, construction, and maintenance sector. The partnership aims to implement best practices and a certification system for productivity. Three working groups will be formed to develop a benchmarking program, certification, and mechanization initiatives. The goal is to establish a Centre of Excellence to retain knowledge and manage the certification program, with potential benefits for the energy and chemicals industry in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Singapore Refining Company (SRC) plant at 1 Merlimau Road. SRC, a company in the energy and chemicals industry, work with its process, construction and maintenance (PCM) contractors to adopt mechanisation tools.

site_title: Oil industry needs to find half a trillion dollars to survive
summary: The oil industry is facing a severe financial crisis, with producers needing to repay half a trillion dollars in debt. The number of oil and gas company bonds with yields of 10% or more has tripled in the past year, and the ratio of net debt to earnings is the highest in two decades. If oil prices stay at around $40 a barrel, the shakeout could be profound, with 168 firms in North America, Europe, and Asia holding distress debt. Smaller players may struggle to meet repayment schedules, while larger companies are likely to emerge intact.

site_title: Japan to cut cost for Olympic stadium by a third: lawmakers
summary: Japan plans to cut construction costs for its Tokyo 2020 Olympic stadium by a third, from $2.1 billion to around $1.87 billion. The government has set a cap of 160 billion yen for the project, which will be designed to hold 68,000 people and expand to 80,000 spectators if Japan wins the World Cup. The decision comes after public backlash over rising costs and a meeting of ministers is set to approve the new plan on Friday.

images.alt_text: Japan's Olympics minister Toshiaki Endo says the original deadline of April 2020 was already a tight schedule for completion of Tokyo's new Olympic stadium.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 1.65% higher
summary: Tokyo shares opened 1.65% higher on Thursday, following a Wall Street rally, as investors remained optimistic despite concerns over the Chinese economy. The Nikkei-225 index rose 303.64 points to 18,680.47. This move was seen as a response to hints that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise more than 1%; won gains to a 1-week high
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.1% to 1,915.47 points, driven by bargain hunting and rebounding US and Chinese markets. Foreigners sold 260.8 billion won worth of shares, but the local market was up for a third consecutive session. Semiconductor chipmaker SK Hynix rose 5.2% on earnings expectations. The won reached a one-week high against the dollar after China's markets opened up, with risk-on sentiment continuing despite caution over Chinese shares.

site_title: Amazon to launch video streaming service in Japan
summary: Amazon plans to launch its video streaming service in Japan for Prime members, offering a broad lineup of US and Japanese films, TV shows, and cartoons. The service will be available in Japan for 3,900 yen (S$45.60) a year, a year before Netflix's planned entry into the country in September.

site_title: China: Shanghai stocks open up 1.73%
summary: China's Shanghai stocks opened up 1.73% on Thursday, reversing losses from a day earlier, following the central bank's interest rate cut to boost the economy. The Shanghai Composite Index jumped 50.74 points to 2,978.03, while the Shenzhen Composite Index added 1.64% to 1,723.54.

site_title: Australia's NAB seals maiden Islamic financing deal
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) has closed its first onshore Islamic financing deal, a $19.9 million arrangement to fund a real estate purchase by Sydney-based asset manager Crescent Wealth. The four-year financing, known as wakala, is sharia-compliant and removes transaction risk for foreign investors. This deal marks a significant moment for the industry in Australia, as it opens the country to Islamic investors from the Gulf and Southeast Asia. The arrangement also helps to address tax issues that have hindered Islamic financing in Australia, with Crescent Wealth planning to secure a second asset by year-end.

site_title: GE2015: Veteran PAP MP Charles Chong to contest WP-held Punggol East SMC
summary: Veteran PAP MP Charles Chong will contest the Punggol East SMC in the upcoming Singapore General Election, marking a surprise move by the ruling party. Chong, 62, will face opposition-held Punggol East, a single-member constituency that the PAP is seeking to regain. This marks a departure from the PAP's traditional practice of announcing candidates at a media conference. The election is scheduled to take place, with the outcome expected to determine the party's control of the constituency.

site_title: Yuan opens weaker on Thursday after hint of Fed rate hike delay
summary: China's yuan opened weaker on Thursday after a US official hinted at a potential delay in a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.4085 per dollar, its lowest level since 2011. The offshore yuan traded -1.06% away from the onshore spot rate of 6.4155 per dollar. This move came as global market volatility increased, raising concerns about China's economic growth, which is expected to slow.

site_title: Wal-Mart to stop selling AR-15, other semi-automatic rifles
summary: Wal-Mart announced it will stop selling AR-15 and other semi-automatic rifles due to sluggish demand, shifting focus to "hunting and sportsman firearms." The decision, made despite high-profile incidents like the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting, is seen as a shift in the company's approach to social issues. The move comes after pressure from investors and amid a broader debate on gun ownership in the US.

site_title: Panasonic to stop making batteries in Beijing, cut 1,300 jobs
summary: Panasonic to stop producing lithium-ion batteries at its Beijing factory, cutting 1,300 jobs, due to weak demand for basic mobile phones and digital cameras. The 15-year-old factory will be closed this month, as the company restructures its business to focus on higher-margin electric car batteries. Panasonic acquired the plant from Sanyo Electric in 2010 but has since struggled to compete with Asian rivals, leading to the decision. The move is part of Panasonic's efforts to shift its focus towards more profitable areas of the electronics industry.

site_title: Kuroda says Bank of Japan can still achieve its inflation target
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank can achieve its 2% inflation target with current monetary stimulus levels, despite potential risks from global market volatility. Kuroda emphasized the central bank's flexibility to adjust policy if needed. Meanwhile, data forecast to show the BOJ's main inflation gauge dropping below zero, raising concerns about deflationary pressure.

site_title: J&J sells popular Splenda sugar substitute to Heartland Food
summary: Johnson & Johnson is selling its popular Splenda sugar substitute to privately held Heartland Food Products Group for an undisclosed price. The move aims to focus on other consumer brands, particularly in healthcare categories. Splenda, introduced in 1999, features a calorie-free sweetening agent called sucralose. The sale follows fierce competition from cheaper generic Chinese rivals and is expected to close before the end of the year. J&J will focus on its healthcare categories, including babycare, skincare, and pain treatment products.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares opens higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.31 points to 1,584.680. The market saw 233 gainers and 84 losers, with a total trading volume of 118.04 million lots worth RM52.75 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 1.08% after Wall Street rally
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.08% on Thursday following a Wall Street surge, driven by speculation that the US Federal Reserve won't raise interest rates next month. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 18,574.44, while the Topix index rose 1.45%. The rally was influenced by a strong US stock market, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks ended higher on Thursday, in line with a broad rally across Asia following upbeat US data while a weaker yen provided support to Japanese exporters.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares jump 3.22% at open
summary: Hong Kong shares surged 3.22% at the open on Thursday, following Wall Street's rally after US Federal Reserve hints it would not raise interest rates. The benchmark Hang Seng Index rose 678.23 points to 21,758.62. This comes amid global economic uncertainty, with US-China trade tensions and split views on Fed interest rate hikes.

site_title: Straits Times Index up more than 2% in early session
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 2.19% or 62.98 points to 2,935.98 in the early session on August 27, 2015, driven by a surge in Asian stocks following Wall Street's rally. The positive sentiment was fueled by hints that the US Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates, easing concerns over the Chinese economy.

site_title: GE2015: PAP unveils its slate for East Coast GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled its slate for the East Coast Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore's 2015 general election, with Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say leading the team. The lineup includes Senior Minister of State Lee Yi Shyan, Minister of State Mohamad Maliki Osman, and two-term backbencher Jessica Tan. This is expected to be one of the most contested GRCs in the election.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks jump on Wall St; TSMC, Ilitek rally
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 1.4% to 7,826.83 points, driven by a Wall Street rally. Technology exporters TSMC and Ilitek led the gains, with TSMC adding 2% and Ilitek jumping 10% after Mediatek's subsidiary plans to acquire it. The electronics subindex rose 1.9% and the financials subindex gained 0.6%. The Taiwan dollar firmed against the US dollar, closing at T$32.451 per dollar.

site_title: GE2015: PAP introduces new face Cheryl Chan to contest Fengshan SMC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its candidate for the Fengshan single-member constituency (SMC) in the 2015 Singapore General Election: 38-year-old grassroots leader Cheryl Chan. The announcement came after weeks of speculation, and marks the end of Chan's involvement in the East Coast group representation constituency (GRC) slate. The PAP's slate for the GRC was also unveiled on the same day.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on possible delay in Fed rate hike
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.43% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index opening at 2,914.20, driven by a possible delay in the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. The benchmark index saw 151.6 million shares traded worth S$121.5 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 180 to 22. The rally came amid a strong performance on Wall Street, where investors were emboldened by expectations of a Fed delay.

site_title: Elections Department issues reminders on campaigning rules
summary: The Elections Department in Singapore has issued reminders on campaigning rules for organizations participating in election activities. These activities, including endorsing candidates, publishing ads, and issuing press statements, must comply with the Parliamentary Elections Act. The department has also introduced new conditions for election rallies, including requiring central executive committee members and candidates to speak publicly and have their faces visible. The goal is to ensure public safety and accountability.

site_title: Asia: Stocks up as Wall Street rally calms markets, dollar surges
summary: Asian stocks rose on Thursday as a rebound on Wall Street calmed market nerves, while the dollar surged amid easing risk aversion. The rally followed Beijing's policy easing steps, which helped soothe concerns over China's economic health. Japanese and South Korean stocks gained strongly after U.S. stocks posted their biggest one-day gain in four years. Asian markets, including Singapore, also extended their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Global life expectancy rises, but people live sicker for longer
summary: Global life expectancy has risen by 6.2 years since 1990, from 65.3 to 71.5 years, but healthy life expectancy has only increased by 5.4 years, from 56.9 to 62.3 years. This means people are living longer but also living sicker lives for longer. Despite progress against infectious diseases, the challenge now is to prevent or treat major causes of illness and disability. Significant variations exist between countries, with Japan having the highest healthy life expectancy at 73.4 years and Lesotho having the lowest at 42 years.

site_title: Greece's Tsipras rules out forming national unity government
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras ruled out forming a national unity government if he fails to win an outright majority in snap elections, set to be announced by the end of the week. Tsipras stated he won't cooperate with previous governments if the polls are inconclusive, citing his party's desire to break with the old system. The elections come after a major rebellion within Tsipras' Syriza party over Greece's new international bailout.

images.alt_text: Outgoing Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras on Wednesday ruled out forming a national unity government should he fail to win a outright majority in snap elections triggered after he resigned last week.

site_title: In history of global stock tumults, China still in back of pack
summary: China's stock market has experienced a significant decline, losing $5 trillion in two months, but its intensity of price swings is relatively low compared to past market meltdowns. The Shanghai Composite Index has dropped 43% since its peak, which is less severe than other global economic debacles such as the 2000 dot-com bubble and 1998 Russian market crash. Experts believe the economic impact will be limited, with the stock market playing a marginal role in company funding, and the market correction is likely a price adjustment to a frothy valuation rather than a financial crisis.

site_title: YouTube Gaming launches as e-sports arena
summary: YouTube launches YouTube Gaming as an e-sports arena, blending gaming videos and live streams. The service, which was in a test phase since E3 in June, is now available in countries where YouTube is accessible. YouTube Gaming incorporates Google's search smarts to surface fresh content, and a mobile app is available for mobile devices. This move counters Amazon's Twitch, the largest video game broadcasting network, which was acquired by Amazon last year for $970 million. YouTube aims to bring gamers closer to the games, gamers, and culture that matter to them.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GuocoLand, Union Steel, Hupsteel
summary: Stocks Guocoland, Union Steel, and Hupsteel reported significant losses in their fourth quarter earnings. Guocoland's net profit slumped 42% to S$107.31 million due to lower revenue and fair-value gain on investment properties. Union Steel Holdings incurred a net loss of S$8.4 million, while Hupsteel reported a net loss of S$9.3 million due to inventory write-downs and goodwill write-offs. The losses reflect challenging market conditions and reduced sales in their respective industries.

site_title: Australia: Shares open up 1.58 per cent
summary: Australian stocks opened 1.58% higher on Thursday, driven by a strong rally on US markets following a top Federal Reserve official's comments weakening the case for a September rate hike. The S&P/ASX200 index rose 81.8 points to 5,252.6. Key gainers included Commonwealth Bank (1.56%), Westpac (1.92%), BHP Billiton (1.34%), and Rio Tinto (1.08%). The rebound is attributed to bargain hunting and a degree of decoupling between China's equities and global markets, with volatility expected to remain high.

site_title: Best Buy to sell Apple Watch in all stores
summary: Best Buy will sell the Apple Watch in all 1,047 of its US big-box stores by the end of September, expanding distribution 10-fold after initial sales exceeded expectations. The device, initially available online and at 100 locations, will be offered in 900 stores starting September 4. This move is part of Best Buy's plan to give more space to Apple's products and may indicate the Apple Watch's mass appeal. The retailer's partnership with Apple has been crucial in revamping its stores, with 520 upgraded Apple departments expected by the holiday shopping season.

site_title: Swiss get the bill for SNB U-turn as economy seen in recession
summary: The Swiss National Bank's (SNB) decision to scrap its currency cap in January has led to a recession in Switzerland. The country's economy is expected to shrink 0.1% in the last quarter, marking the first recession in six years. Declining exports, stagnant manufacturing, and plummeting prices are contributing factors. Economists forecast this data to be released on Friday, further solidifying the concerns about the SNB's policy U-turn.

site_title: Facebook adding virtual assistant to Messenger app
summary: Facebook has begun testing a virtual assistant, dubbed "M", in its Messenger app, allowing users to complete tasks and seek information with the assistance of AI. Unlike existing AI services, M can perform tasks on behalf of users. Facebook's David Marcus stated that M goes beyond current AI programs. The virtual assistant aims to enhance user experience and provide more personalized services.

site_title: Gap Inc to end 'on-call' shifts for workers Aug 26
summary: Gap Inc will end on-call shifts for its workers by August 26, with at least 10-14 days' notice. The decision follows a New York State attorney general inquiry into the practice, which may have violated state law requiring paid shifts for scheduled work. The change affects all 13 retailers, including Target and JC Penney, and will be phased in by early 2016. Gap's decision comes after similar moves by Abercrombie & Fitch and Victoria's Secret to end on-call shifts for hourly workers.

images.alt_text: Apparel retailer Gap Inc said it would end on-call shifts at all of its stores and improve scheduling policies to provide employees with at least 10-14 days' notice.

site_title: Nasdaq executive urges China authorities to use circuit breakers
summary: Nasdaq executive Hans-Ole Jochumsen urges China authorities to implement circuit breakers to prevent panic selling in the stock market. The country's stocks have experienced the largest five-day drop in two decades following the devaluation of the yuan and a rate cut by the People's Bank of China. Jochumsen notes that circuit breakers, similar to those in Europe and the US, can help avert flash crashes and allow investors to think before making decisions. China's government has already taken measures to stabilize the market, but Jochumsen believes circuit breakers would be a more effective solution.

site_title: Malaysia turns to 1998 currency peg architect as markets bleed
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak has established an economic task force, echoing former premier Mahathir Mohamad's National Economic Action Council in 1998, to stem a decline in confidence in the country's currency and economy. The task force includes business leaders and former officials who helped design Malaysia's currency peg in 1998. The move comes as the ringgit has weakened beyond the peg set by Mahathir in 1998, with foreign funds dumping over $3 billion of the nation's shares this year. The task force aims to find ways to minimize the impact of economic issues and strengthen the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Najib Razak is taking a page out of the playbook of mentor-turned-nemesis, former premier Mahathir Mohamad. To stem a decline in confidence in Malaysia, he's even tapping the expertise of Mr Mahathir's ringgit peg architect.

site_title: Governance in group entities still a potential weak spot
summary: Major multinational corporations still struggle with corporate governance standards at their subsidiaries, according to experts. Despite some companies taking proactive steps, a significant minority remain unaware of the risks. Governance failures often occur within group entities, not just the listed parent company, and can result in financial and reputational damage. Experts recommend that parent boards take responsibility for overseeing subsidiaries, and regulators play a key role in driving change. Improving governance at the subsidiary level is crucial to minimize the risk of failures and protect the entire group.

site_title: Oil dips after mixed US petroleum supply report
summary: Oil prices dropped after a mixed US petroleum supply report, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate shedding 71 cents to $38.60 a barrel and European benchmark Brent losing seven cents to $43.14 a barrel. US crude supplies fell 5.5 million barrels, while production remained steady at 9.3 million barrels. Gasoline supplies increased 1.7 million barrels, further weakening the market. The decline in oil prices follows concerns over the slowing Chinese economy and a heavily supplied global market, with US oil prices falling below $40 a barrel this week.

site_title: IMF chief Lagarde to visit Indonesia next week
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde is set to visit Indonesia next week, from September 1-2, for talks with senior officials and a high-level Asian finance conference. The visit comes amid heightened volatility in Asian financial markets, following China's economic slowdown and falling commodity prices. Lagarde will meet with President Joko Widodo and Bank Indonesia Governor Agus Martowardojo to discuss recent economic developments and Indonesia's prospects as an emerging power. The visit aims to exchange views on Indonesia's role globally and in the region.

site_title: Projects under Juncker investment plan starting to roll out
summary: The European Commission's Juncker investment plan, aimed at pumping 315 billion euros into the EU economy, is starting to roll out with projects in Denmark, Italy, Finland, and France. The plan's European Investment Bank is expected to take more risk in picking projects, while the European Investment Fund focuses on start-up firms and smaller companies. Financial analysts, however, remain skeptical about the plan's effectiveness, citing concerns about the lack of clear quantitative targets and the reliance on national promotional banks to amplify its aims.

site_title: Broker's take: Wilmar skating on thin ice, says research house
summary: Singapore-headquartered agribusiness group Wilmar International is under scrutiny, with research house Religare initiating a "sell" call and setting a target price of S$2.27. The company's intense capital expenditure programme has delivered poor returns, and its core refining business is threatened by severe overcapacity. Wilmar is valued at 14x enterprise value/earnings before interest, tax, depreciation & amortisation, making it overvalued for its risks.

site_title: US: Wall St rallies but markets still gripped by China fears
summary: US stocks rallied on Wednesday, with the S&P 500, Dow, and Nasdaq closing with gains of 3.90%, 3.95%, and 4.24%, respectively. The rally came after a top Federal Reserve official hinted that interest rates may not be raised in September, citing concerns over China's slowdown in the economy. Despite the US gains, global markets remain gripped by worries about China's market meltdown, with Shanghai falling 1.27% and European shares losing 1.47%. Analysts see the Fed as likely to weigh the global turbulence in making its decision on interest rates.

site_title: Investors now struggling to find true safe havens
summary: Investors are struggling to find safe havens, with traditional assets like US and German bonds, the Swiss franc, and the dollar experiencing erratic behavior. Despite market volatility, money has flowed into the euro, which has seen a 1% rise in value. Investors are repatriating funds, possibly unwinding currency hedges, but the reasons behind these flows are unclear. Traditional safe havens have become hard to find, leaving investors uncertain about where to park their money.

site_title: July orders for capital goods post largest rise in more than a year
summary: US capital goods orders rose 2.2% in July, the largest increase in over a year, driven by a 1.4% rise in non-military equipment bookings excluding planes, according to Commerce Department data. This marks the most significant increase since June 2014.

site_title: Oil industry crash leaves Wall St playing catchup
summary: The US oil industry is experiencing a severe crash, with half of the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 Index falling at least 40% below analyst targets. This marks the worst collapse in a quarter century. The oil glut worsened after China's economy slowed, raising concerns about global demand. Despite this, some analysts, like Brad Carpenter, expect share prices to rebound, while others, like Marathon Oil Corp and Range Resources Corp, have seen their share prices drop by 95% and 82%, respectively.

site_title: Brazil builders seek debt relief as housing market plummets
summary: Brazil's real estate industry is facing a severe crisis, with builders seeking debt relief amid a recession, soaring inflation, and high interest rates. Industry giants like PDG Realty and Rossi Residencial have hired advisers to restructure debt and review strategies. The industry, which accounts for 10% of Brazil's economy, has seen a 99% decline in stock market value since 2010, with home sales plummeting 14% in the first half of 2015. Experts predict a prolonged recession and weak consumer demand, with interest rates likely to remain high.

site_title: Dollar gains as Wall St rebounds from 6-day rout
summary: The US dollar strengthened on Wednesday, rebounding from a six-day rout, as a strong US equities rally and a better-than-expected manufacturing report boosted market appetite for risk. The euro fell to $1.1312, while a top Fed official downplayed the potential for interest rate hikes in September. The dollar's gains were fueled by a desire to take on risk after China's surprise currency devaluation two weeks ago. The dollar is now in positive territory for the week, with a modest winning streak.

site_title: Spurred on by investors, US oil firms keep drilling despite the supply glut
summary: US oil firms continue to drill despite a supply glut, driven by investors who prioritize growth over returns. Despite a 20% decline in crude prices in August, companies such as Cimarex Energy and Pioneer Natural Resources plan to increase their rig count, citing improved efficiency and lower costs. US oil production has remained high, frustrating OPEC's efforts to balance the market. Executives say growth is key, even at lower oil prices, and investors are starting to take notice, with some companies' stocks rising despite the market slump.

site_title: Consultants to offer US firms anti-hacking solutions
summary: US cybersecurity technology developed at Los Alamos National Laboratory will be made available to banks and businesses through a partnership with Ernst & Young LLP. The technology, called PathScan, detects abnormal activity on networks that indicates the presence of hackers. The partnership aims to promote cutting-edge research and collective cybersecurity, but some security analysts question its value and relevance to private sector needs. The technology has already shown promise in testing at five companies, but its long-term success is uncertain.

site_title: Qatar Airways relaxes grip on flight attendants as carrier grows up
summary: Qatar Airways is relaxing its policies for flight attendants, including allowing them to use mobile phones in public and permitting marriage and pregnancy without penalty. The airline has also pledged to review its curfew and other restrictions. With a rapid expansion planned, Qatar Airways aims to retain crew members, citing the need to mature workforce. The airline has already backed off some rules, such as firing employees for marrying or becoming pregnant within the first five years. Changes aim to improve working conditions and address Western views on women's rights.

site_title: Boeing raises forecast for China aircraft demand
summary: Boeing has raised its forecast for China's aircraft demand over the next 20 years, expecting 6,330 aircraft to be needed, a 5% increase from last year's estimate. This valuation is worth $950 billion. China's commercial airplane fleet is expected to nearly triple from 2,570 in 2014 to 7,210 in 2034, making it the world's largest domestic air travel market. Boeing attributes the growth to new carriers and low-cost airlines, with single-aisle and widebody airplanes driving demand. This optimism is crucial for both Boeing and Airbus, which rely on China for growth.

site_title: Stock markets adjusting to lower global growth
summary: Stock markets worldwide are adjusting to lower global growth, contrary to the prolonged boom fueled by quantitative easing. The US Federal Reserve's tightening monetary policy, combined with China's economic restructuring, has led to a decoupling of stock prices from liquidity. Despite a significant 30% decline in global growth from 4.5-5% to 3.3-3.4%, stock markets continue to rise. The correction is driven by economic realities, rather than monetary policy, and is expected to lead to lower global stock market prices.

site_title: Millennial bright sparks throw up great ideas at OCBC's Innovation Lab
summary: OCBC's Innovation Lab, launched in 2013, has seen over 7,000 ideas from 1,500 employees, with 200 implemented to date, resulting in savings of S$3 million. Millennials, known for their tech savviness and unconventional thinking, are driving the innovation, with strengths including honesty and a willingness to break norms. Ideas have led to successful products like the OneTouch Biometrics mobile banking app and digital paperless branches, while also benefiting employees with apps like Flex and shuttle buses. The lab's focus on speed and iteration has given OCBC a competitive edge in the industry.

site_title: Panicking investors need time-out on a China in transition
summary: China's economy is experiencing a slowdown, with manufacturing activity at a six-year low and a 7% growth rate in the first half of 2015. However, foreign investors are panicking, responding to China's devaluation and decision to allow market forces to drive down the Shanghai Composite Index. This is despite clear signals from President Xi Jinping that the country is committed to reform and a "new normal." Investors are sending a message that China should prioritize stability over reform, potentially leading Beijing to shelve its efforts and clamp down on personal freedoms.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GuocoLand reported a 42% slump in net profit for the fourth quarter, with revenue down 48% to S$254.7 million. Union Steel Holdings swung to a net loss of S$8.4 million, while Imperium Crown posted a net profit of S$11.98 million for the year ended June 30, driven by net fair value gains on investment properties.

site_title: Opec must now plan for a retreat
summary: Opec's ability to control oil prices is dwindling due to the expansion of the energy universe, with US shale producers adding over 4 million barrels per day since 2011. Despite Opec's hopes of knocking out shale producers, the cartel is unlikely to achieve its aim in the near term. Iranian production is expected to swell Opec supplies, and demand has not been strong enough to prevent a renewed price collapse. With growing disquiet within the cartel, Opec may need to plan for a retreat, as its budget is driven by oil revenues and it faces growing fiscal pressures.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ST Engineering's stock price has declined, making it more attractive due to index selling. Analysts UOB Kay Hian and CDW Holding upgraded the company's target price, citing a record orderbook and guidance for a stronger 2H15. The Ministry of Defence's higher defence budget will also benefit the company. Meanwhile, 800 Super Holdings was upgraded to 'Buy' by Phillip Capital, citing its defensive business model, resilient earnings, and superior ROE. Analysts attribute the decline in CDW Holding's stock price to the loss of market share in the China smartphone market.

site_title: Stock market rout adds to China banks' woes
summary: China's banks face further challenges as a stock market rout is expected to curb fee-generating business, leading to higher non-performing loans and smaller profit growth. The country's five biggest lenders are expected to report higher bad debts and smaller profit growth when they announce interim results this week. China's interest rate cuts have reduced bank net interest margins, and banks are shifting focus to fee and commission income, which currently makes up 20-30% of total income.

site_title: Saudis could face revolt from Opec members
summary: Saudi Arabia's decision to let the oil market determine prices has inflicted significant economic pain on fellow Opec members and other oil producers, leading to intense financial and economic strain. Despite this, the Saudis show no indication of altering course, with financial markets predicting continuity. However, stresses within Opec may pressure the Saudis to rethink their strategy, particularly as the financial burden on Opec outsiders, such as Iraq and Angola, increases. The upcoming Opec meeting may see a revolt from Opec outsiders, who feel the Saudi decision serves Saudi interests rather than Opec's general interest.

site_title: US bond fund manager sold 25% of assets in two months on danger signs
summary: US bond fund manager John Lekas trimmed 25% of his $1.4 billion portfolio in two months due to "danger signs" in the market, including interest rate volatility and emerging market debt crises. Lekas predicts a deeper fallout in emerging markets and higher interest rates, fuelling sovereign debt crises.
