He warns of "defaults" and currency devaluation, citing examples of Greece, Puerto Rico, and Ukraine. The fund manager now buys short-term US Treasuries and predicts a storm in the market.

site_title: Tech's real China syndrome victims are yet to fall
summary: Tech companies like Facebook, Apple, Amazon, and Microsoft have lost nearly $200 billion in value in the past week due to concerns over China's economic slowdown. However, the problem lies in investors' excessive faith in growth, rather than China's direct impact. Public tech stocks may recover, but private companies like Uber and Palantir will take a bigger hit due to their high valuations. The issue is a shift in perception, with investors becoming skeptical of earnings growth and prone to panic selling.

site_title: A tower rises deep in Amazon jungle to study climate change and rainforests
summary: A 325-meter-tall tower in the Amazon jungle, Brazil, has been built to study climate change and rainforests. The Amazon Tall Tower Observatory (ATTO) is a remote, German-Brazilian funded project that aims to collect pure data on the Amazon's role in global warming. The tower, which cost $7.4 million, will be used to understand the impact of the Amazon on local and global climates, and to better understand the role of trees in capturing carbon dioxide. The 20-30 year study will provide valuable insights into the Amazon's vital role in regulating the climate.

site_title: Three-month SOR jumps to 1.4%, highest level since Jan 2009
summary: The three-month Singapore swap offer rate (SOR) jumped to 1.40236%, its highest level since January 2009, due to the Asian FX weakness, particularly the yuan devaluation on August 11. Economists attribute the increase to market speculation about further decline in the Singapore dollar and Asian FX versus the dollar. The SOR has risen sharply since the yuan devaluation, with some predicting a depreciation of the yuan to 7 to the US dollar by the end of the year.

site_title: Analysts sceptical about M'sia economic task force
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak has announced an economic task force to restore investor confidence, but analysts are skeptical due to concerns over a troubled state fund and the absence of the central bank chief. The committee, which includes top bankers, will propose measures to strengthen the economy, but its effectiveness is limited by the ongoing political storm surrounding 1MDB and the absence of key officials. Analysts question the committee's ability to address the country's economic issues, which were created by the prime minister himself.

site_title: Amazon expands Prime Now, offers alcohol deliveries
summary: Amazon expands its Prime Now service to Seattle, offering wine, beer, and spirits deliveries in addition to its existing grocery delivery. This marks the first time the company has delivered alcohol to US customers. The expansion is part of Amazon's efforts to test new services, including on-demand grocery delivery, which is a growing market in the US. Prime Now customers can order using an app and have their items shipped from smaller warehouses in Seattle and Kirkland, Washington.

site_title: Two private-sector leaders in PAP's Nee Soon slate
summary: Businessman Henry Kwek and animal-rights activist Louis Ng are among the five candidates contesting in Singapore's Nee Soon group representation constituency (GRC) under the People's Action Party (PAP) banner in the upcoming general election. The ruling party introduced them on Thursday, a day after the writ of election was issued.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Trump-style bashing of foreigners offers no solutions
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's economic nationalism and China bashing have drawn criticism for offering no solutions. Trump has proposed bringing back jobs from China, Mexico, and Japan, but fails to explain how he plans to do so without forcing American wages down. His criticism of China's currency devaluation as "devastating" for the US is also misinformed, as the move aligns with international demands for a more market-oriented yuan exchange rate. Trump's approach risks perpetuating protectionism and ignoring the complexities of the global economy.

images.alt_text: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump speaks to guests gathered for a campaign event at the Grand River Center on Aug 25, 2015 in Dubuque, Iowa.

site_title: S$3b national plan to help Singapore's seniors age well
summary: Singapore launches a S$3 billion, 5-year plan to help seniors age actively, with 60 programmes covering 12 areas, including enrichment classes, job skills, and transport infrastructure enhancements. The plan, developed after consulting over 4,000 Singaporeans and grassroots leaders, aims to transform Singapore into a more age-friendly nation.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Election digest
summary: Singapore election updates: Reform Party leader Kenneth Jeyaretnam declares interest in Pioneer SMC, while the Workers' Party faces a tough battle to retain Aljunied ward against the PAP, according to former PAP chairman Lim Boon Heng. The SDP unveiled two new candidates, and NSP president Sebastian Teo denounced mud-slinging tactics against him and his party. The NSP plans to contest 12 seats, including MacPherson.

site_title: AEC's debut will heat up race to bag top finance talents: survey
summary: A survey by PwC and CPA Australia found that the Asean Economic Community's (AEC) rollout will intensify the "war to snag top finance workers" in the region. Finance teams will become leaner, with CFOs taking on more strategic roles and administrative tasks being automated or outsourced. By 2030, nearly 60% of CFOs expect finance teams to be more focused on strategic business partnering, requiring better real-time business performance and stakeholder management skills. Over 50% of CFOs also expect to need a deputy due to the increased workload.

site_title: Opposition can't take credit for PAP govt policies: Chok Tong
summary: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong has dismissed opposition parties' claims of pushing the ruling PAP government to work harder, likening them to a "rooster that goes around claiming its crowing causes the sun to rise." Goh cited his own leadership transition and policies, such as manpower and transport initiatives, which he says have been in place for years, not just since the 2011 elections. He also highlighted the PAP's community-level initiatives and promised to address concerns of private property dwellers, who he believes are being excluded from government programs.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Alibaba CEO to workers: Ignore share plunge
summary: Alibaba CEO Daniel Zhang urged employees to ignore the company's plummeting stock price, which fell below its initial public offering price for the first time. Zhang wrote a memo to focus on customers, not market turmoil, amid concerns about the company's sales growth and a slowing Chinese economy. The company's shares rose 4.2% to $68.57 after closing at $65.80 on Monday, outlasting a US market rally. Zhang cited Alibaba's 102-year journey, referencing a phrase from co-founder Jack Ma's IPO prospectus, to encourage employees to stick to their principles.

site_title: Tokyo's iconic Hotel Okura awaits the wrecking ball
summary: Tokyo's iconic Hotel Okura, a 1960s-era Japanese Modernist landmark, will be demolished next week to make way for a new, 41-story hotel ahead of the 2020 Olympics. Despite a petition with nearly 9,000 signatures and international support, the hotel's owners have decided to proceed with the demolition. The new hotel will feature a tea ceremony room and Japanese garden, and some of the original furnishings and decor may be preserved. Fans of the hotel lament the loss of its unique public spaces, including the lobby and the Orchid Bar, which will be replaced by a new complex.

site_title: Search for safe haven takes a pause as stocks recover
summary: The dollar rose as markets calmed, with Wall Street futures pointing to a firm start and European shares recovering from losses. China's central bank injected $21.8 billion into the money market, but investors remain cautious due to recent volatility. The US Federal Reserve's William Dudley is set to speak, potentially shedding light on the central bank's thinking on monetary policy. The euro fell 0.8% and the yen rose 0.6% against the dollar, as investors unwound carry trades amid market turmoil.

site_title: Silverlake Axis suffers another heavy blow
summary: Silverlake Axis, a software solutions provider, suffered another significant drop in its stock price after resuming trading following a trading halt sparked by an anonymous report. The stock closed at 46 Singapore cents, down 27.6% from its previous close, after reaching an intra-day low of 35.5 cents. The report, which was allegedly made by those with short positions, alleged impropriety in related party transactions. Silverlake has denied the allegations and is seeking legal advice. The company has also announced a share buyback.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Redeveloping Funan a better option for CapitaLand Mall Trust
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) is considering the redevelopment of its 80-year-old Funan DigitaLife Mall in Singapore, with potential for an 80% increase in gross floor area to 868,212 sq ft. The trust could either sell the asset for a one-time gain or redevelop it into a novel product that provides a future income stream. Market watchers suggest that an office and retail scheme would be a suitable combination, with the potential for disruption to current operations. CMT is exploring its options, including possible disposal or redevelopment, and has a debt headroom to support the redevelopment.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Croesus Retail Trust posts higher DPU for Q4 and full year
summary: Croesus Retail Trust (CRT) reported a 1% year-over-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q4 and a 2.8% increase for the full year. The trust's gross revenue rose 25.5% to 1.99 billion yen, driven by the acquisition of One's Mall and tenants' renewal exercise. Administrative expenses decreased, contributing to the increase in DPU. The trust's portfolio comprises seven retail properties in Japan, with the aggregate value increasing 7.9% compared to prior valuation.

images.alt_text: Croesus Retail Trust (CRT), Asia-Pacific's first retail business trust with an initial portfolio located in Japan, has posted a one per cent year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter to 2.02 Singapore cents.

site_title: Slower sales in Malaysia, HK hit Eu Yan Sang
summary: Eu Yan Sang International, a Singapore-based integrative health and wellness company, reported a net loss of S$3.6 million for its fourth quarter, with revenue falling 15% to S$72.25 million. The full-year net profit was S$4.56 million, down from S$15.03 million a year ago, due to challenges in Hong Kong and Malaysia. The company cited weaker sales and lower gross margins as major contributors to the loss. Despite this, the group expects revenue growth in Singapore and Australia, and plans to rationalize underperforming outlets.

images.alt_text: Richard Eu, Group CEO of Eu Yan Sang International.

site_title: Dubai property slowdown due to tighter rules, not oil slump
summary: Dubai's property slowdown is attributed to tightened rules, not oil prices, according to industry experts. The emirate's well-balanced supply and demand for properties should keep prices stable, despite a 51% house price increase in 2013 and subsequent price drops. The government's measures to curb speculation, including doubling property registration fees and raising minimum mortgage deposits, have led to a decline in demand. Analysts predict a stable market, but warn that prolonged low oil prices could lead to a UAE construction slowdown.

site_title: Market seen range-bound for now
summary: The Singapore market is seen as range-bound for now, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.5% to 2,873 on Wednesday after a brief rally the previous day. China's rate cut failed to prevent a slide in the Shanghai market, which saw a 1.3% drop. Other regional markets showed mixed results, with Tokyo surging 3.2% and Seoul advancing 2.6%. Analysts expect the STI to consolidate, with some seeing opportunities for long-term trades.

site_title: World becomes cheaper for Japanese firms
summary: Japanese companies are capitalizing on the country's low funding costs and a strengthening yen to make record overseas acquisitions. This year, Japanese firms have announced $70.2 billion in overseas deals, the fastest pace in at least 15 years. The yen's appreciation is making investments more attractive, with companies like Kirin Holdings and Meiji Yasuda Life Insurance Co. taking advantage of cheaper funding costs to acquire US companies. Experts say the stronger yen is an opportunity for Japanese companies to expand globally, despite potential challenges in meeting the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target.

images.alt_text: With Japanese companies sitting on record cash of 241 trillion yen and dim growth prospects at home, Canon Inc to Hitachi are making investments overseas.

site_title: Malaysia, Indonesia rapid response teams to fight soaring piracy
summary: Malaysia and Indonesia are deploying rapid reaction teams to combat soaring piracy in the Malacca and Singapore straits, where over 70 ships have been attacked this year, the highest number since 2008. The Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agency and Indonesian navies are forming a special task force to respond to robbery and hijacking incidents, with the teams also deployed on merchant ships operated by Malaysian government-linked firms. Shipping and security experts welcome the move, but urge a more proactive approach to combat maritime armed robbery and piracy, which has become the world's hotspot, registering 84 out of 106 global incidents in the first half of this year.

images.alt_text: Malaysia and Indonesia are deploying rapid reaction teams to combat a soaring number of attacks on merchant vessels in one of the world's busiest shipping chokepoints, a Malaysian admiral said on Wednesday.

site_title: Russia asks retailers to withdraw batches of foreign detergents
summary: Russia's consumer safety watchdog Rospotrebnadzor has asked retailers to withdraw batches of foreign detergents from shelves due to non-compliance with toxicological safety criteria. Retailer Metro has removed products from its stores in response. The move follows Russia's expansion of its ban on EU and US food imports, and restrictions on flower imports from the Netherlands. The extent of the withdrawal is unclear, but Rospotrebnadzor is conducting tests on household chemicals and detergents. Foreign companies such as Henkel & Co, Procter & Gamble, and Clorox Co are affected.

site_title: CPFIS funds lose 1.5% in Q2 as money flees Asia
summary: CPFIS funds in Singapore experienced a 1.53% decline in Q2, marking the first negative returns after three quarters of positive growth. Volatility is expected to persist into H2, driven by uncertainties over interest rates and China. Research firm Lipper attributes the outflows to capital fleeing Asia, with US$197.5 billion leaving the region in the first half of 2015. Bond funds in the CPFIS outperformed global benchmarks, while mixed-asset funds suffered the worst losses.

site_title: Urgent action needed to reform banks' corporate culture
summary: Major banks must reform their corporate culture to regain public trust, as pressures on regulators rise. A report by the Group of 30, a steering committee of finance leaders, recommends a comprehensive approach to reform, focusing on values, ethics, and employee conduct. The report urges banks to prioritize customer service, respect whistleblowers, and hold executives accountable for wrongdoing. To achieve change, banks must challenge conventional wisdom on regulatory barriers, engage in regular cultural assessments, and impose substantial sanctions on employees who fail to uphold the corporate values.

site_title: Burger King floats McWhopper of an idea
summary: Burger King has proposed a temporary truce with McDonald's by collaborating on a pop-up restaurant, the McWhopper, on September 21, the International Day of Peace. The McWhopper combines elements of both companies' burgers and will donate proceeds to Peace One Day. The idea aims to raise awareness and create action around world peace, with employees from both companies participating in the event.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall on China jitters
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 down 1.68% and the CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropping 1.4% and 1.29%, respectively. Investors remained cautious amid China-related jitters, despite a positive start to the week in Singapore.

site_title: Toyota said to move towards Tianjin plant restart
summary: Toyota begins trial production at its China plants, which were shut after explosions in Tianjin, with about 100 cars to be produced on a trial basis. The plants were closed for two weeks after the August 12 blasts killed at least 123 people and injured 67 Toyota workers. Toyota plans to resume full production once it confirms the safety of its facilities and surrounding area. The company has not set a specific date for resuming full production, with a decision expected this week.

site_title: Coutts likes equities, particularly Europe's
summary: Coutts, a private bank and wealth manager, maintains a favorable stance on equities, particularly in Europe, and remains underweight on bonds. The investment strategy committee believes global equities will find a floor and recover due to robust growth indicators in the US and Europe, as well as low commodity prices and falling unemployment. Emerging markets are expected to benefit from a pickup in developed market manufacturing, despite China being a wild card. Global equities have become relatively cheap, with prices below long-term averages in some major markets.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Creative Technology warns it may miss H2 revenue targets, citing similar operating losses to H1. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks experience a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. OCBC appoints Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing Helen Wong who is retiring. The MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Imperium Crown's net profit rises to S$11.98m for year ended June
summary: Imperium Crown, a Singapore property company, reported a net profit of S$11.98 million for the year ended June 30, 2015, up from S$3.06 million in the previous year. The increase was driven by net fair value gains of S$19.2 million on its investment properties in Japan. The company will not pay a dividend for FY2015. Its earnings per share rose to 3.02 cents and net asset value per share rose to 11.55 cents. The company aims to build a portfolio of conveniently-located properties in Tokyo and other major Japanese cities.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Ex-Tibetan monk accused of defrauding Chinese real estate investors in US
summary: A former Tibetan monk, Lobsang Dargey, has been accused of securities fraud by the US Securities and Exchange Commission. Dargey, who raised $125 million from 250 investors, including mostly Chinese nationals, is accused of using the funds for personal projects, including a home and casino trips. He allegedly told investors their money would help them gain US residency through the EB-5 Program, but instead used some funds for other projects not disclosed. Dargey's assets have been frozen, and he is prohibited from soliciting new investors.

site_title: Japan govt downgrades consumer spending, exports as economy stutters
summary: Japan's government downgraded its assessment of consumer spending and exports in August, citing a tepid recovery from a contraction in the April-June quarter. Consumer spending has plateaued, and exports are weakening due to China's market turmoil, which may undercut policymakers' efforts to spur inflation. The government stands by its assessment that Japan's economy is on track to recover but warns of downside risks posed by China and other overseas economies.

site_title: Call for Swiss private bankers to double client assets
summary: The new head of Barclays' Swiss unit, James Buchanan-Michaelson, is urging private bankers to double client assets to 28 billion Swiss francs (S$41.55 billion) by 2019, aiming to boost the unit's fortunes. This move comes as international competitors exit Geneva and Zurich, the world's largest hub for offshore wealth. The goal is to increase Swiss assets, including loans, to achieve profitability. Buchanan-Michaelson's target is ambitious, given the unit's current barely break-even status.

site_title: Israel, China medical technology incubators set up shop in S'pore
summary: Two medical technology incubators, one from Israel and one from China, have set up shop in Singapore, aiming to develop healthcare products for commercialization in China and the US. Israel-based Trendlines, which has a presence in China via its partner Venturecraft, is looking to list on the Singapore Exchange in November and has already screened over 500 medtech proposals yearly. The incubators aim to capitalize on the growing healthcare market in Asia, with China's health spending as a share of GDP being 5.6% in 2013, compared to 8.9% in the OECD average.

site_title: Conversion to serviced apartments a costly affair for Newfort Realty
summary: Newfort Realty, a private firm, has incurred S$10 million in taxes after changing its plans to convert a freehold site off Orchard Road into serviced apartments. The developer initially pulled the brakes on a 68-unit residential project due to the abysmal residential market, but succeeded in converting the property into a 98-unit serviced residence after committing to keep the freehold property as a serviced residence for at least 50 years. The conversion costs an additional S$25-30 million, on top of the S$92.2 million paid to acquire the freehold estate in 2012.

site_title: Cajuns losing Louisiana island home to erosion
summary: A Louisiana island community, home to the Native American tribe of the same name, is losing its land to severe erosion. Isle de Jean Charles is being swallowed by the sea, threatening the island's 250 residents. The US Army Corps of Engineers has been working to relocate the community, but progress has been slow. The island's unique ecosystem and way of life are at risk, prompting calls for urgent action to preserve the community's cultural heritage. The situation highlights the vulnerability of low-lying coastal communities to climate change and the need for effective relocation strategies.

site_title: WP says it has brought a more responsive govt
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) in Singapore has urged citizens to support greater opposition, citing a more responsive government since the party's election wins in 2011. WP Secretary-General Low Thia Khiang questioned the country's prevailing big-government approach, stating it may not be suitable for modern circumstances. The party introduced its first batch of candidates, including three new faces, and emphasized the need for debate and checks against government policies. WP Chairman Sylvia Lim said the party aims to empower Singaporeans and prevent government overreach, with 20 Opposition MPs from one party considered healthy for checks and balances.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall back, banks and commodity stocks underperform
summary: European shares fell 2.6% on Wednesday, following similar declines in global markets due to concerns over China's economy. The FTSEurofirst 300 index, which had risen 4.3% on Tuesday, suffered its worst one-day loss since November 2008. Investors remained worried about a Chinese economic slowdown and deflationary pressures resulting from Beijing's currency devaluation. Bank and mining stocks underperformed, with analysts citing anaemic global economic growth as the main reason for the downtrend.

site_title: Singapore: Shares close down 0.5%
summary: The Singapore market closed 0.5% lower, falling 13.29 points to 2,873, due to a mix of large-cap losses, including DBS, Singtel, and Keppel Corp. A rate cut in China failed to prevent a slide in the Shanghai market. This marks a brief respite after a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Update: September rate hike now 'less compelling', says Fed's Dudley
summary: Federal Reserve official William Dudley said the economic turmoil in China has reduced the urgency for raising interest rates in September, citing a potential slowdown in global growth. The slowdown in China's economy, sparked by the stock market crash, may lead to less demand for the US economy. Dudley's comments have sparked concerns among economists, who have called for the Fed to reconsider a potential interest rate increase, which would be the first in nine years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 16.43 points to 1,580.37, with 2.15 billion lots valued at RM2.27 billion traded. The market saw 407 losers and gainers.

site_title: Malaysia's Genting posts lowest quarterly earnings in 6-1/2 years
summary: Genting Bhd, a Malaysian conglomerate, posted its lowest quarterly earnings in 6-1/2 years, with a 81.7% drop in net profit to 67.9 million ringgit (S$22.5 million) in the April-June period. Revenue also declined 5.5% to 4.17 billion ringgit, mainly due to weaker gaming and plantation businesses. The company's shares have dropped 24% year-to-date, following a 1.48% decline in the Kuala Lumpur stock exchange. Impairment charges and fair value adjustments on derivative instruments contributed to the poor results.

site_title: Construction boom in South Florida makes its way up north
summary: A construction boom is underway in Broward County, Florida, as developers migrate north from Miami Beach in search of cheaper oceanfront land. The area is seeing a surge in luxury residential complexes, hotels, and retail space, with 83 new towers announced or under construction. Prices per square foot are often half or less of what similar condos have been fetching in Miami Beach, making it an attractive option for foreign investors. The boom is expected to continue, with some developers predicting prices will rise as the area gains recognition, but for now, buyers can find oceanfront units for significantly lower prices.

site_title: Oakwood Asia Pacific clinches management contract from Newfort Realty
summary: Oakwood Asia Pacific has secured a 10-year management contract from Newfort Realty to manage the freehold property Chateau Eliza off Orchard Road as a 98-unit serviced residence. The property was originally acquired for S$92.2 million in 2012 with plans for redevelopment, but the lacklustre market led to a change in plans to convert it into serviced apartments. The refurbishment costs are being borne by Newfort Realty, with the property set to open in November next year.

site_title: A 21st-century migrant's checklist: food, shelter, smartphone
summary: Thousands of migrants, including Syrians, Afghans, and Pakistanis, are using smartphones and social media to navigate their perilous journeys to Europe. With essential tools like maps, GPS apps, and WhatsApp, migrants can stay in touch with family and friends, post real-time updates, and even advertise traffickers' services on Facebook. This shift has led to a decline in traffickers' profits, with prices dropping by half since the conflict began. The technology is also transforming interactions between refugees and aid agencies, enabling them to exchange information and interact more actively.

site_title: GuocoLand Q4 profit plunges 42%
summary: GuocoLand Limited reported a 42% decline in net profit for Q4, to S$107.31 million, due to lower revenue and fair value gain on investment properties. Revenue fell 48% to S$254.7 million, mainly affected by lower revenue from China projects. Despite the drop, gross margin rose to 41% due to a change in sales mix. The group ended the year with a 26% drop in net profit to S$226.4 million, citing challenging operating conditions and uncertainty in the property market.

site_title: China, Japan in heated battle to build Indonesia's first bullet train
summary: China and Japan are in a heated competition to build Indonesia's first high-speed railway, with China offering a lower price to win the contract. The project, worth billions, is seen as a key test of the Asian giants' influence in South-east Asia. China is trying to challenge Japan's long-standing dominance in infrastructure funding in the region. The competition is intensifying as time runs out for Jakarta to make a decision, with the winner expected to be announced soon.

site_title: Gulf PE firms fight for Saudi supermarket chain Al Raya
summary: Gulf private equity firms Abraaj Group, Fajr Capital, and Gulf Capital are competing for a majority stake in Saudi supermarket chain Al Raya For Foodstuff Co, with a potential deal worth up to $300 million. The sale comes despite economic disruption in Saudi Arabia, and the stakeholders would triple their investment in around three years. Levant Capital and Citi Venture Capital International originally bought the stake in 2012 for $100 million. The second-round bids are due in two weeks, with the final price tag likely to be near the initial estimate.

site_title: Hupsteel swings into the red for Q4, full-year
summary: Hupsteel Limited reported a net loss of S$9.3 million for Q4, due to an inventory write-down, goodwill write-off, and provision for doubtful debts. The company's full-year net loss was S$7.95 million, down from a net profit of S$3.55 million in 2014. Revenue dropped 36.3% to S$17.4 million, driven by softening demand for steel products. The board proposes a final dividend of 0.1 cent per share, down from 1 cent in the previous period.

site_title: Cnooc first-half profit drops 56% on plunging crude prices
summary: Cnooc Ltd, China's largest offshore oil and gas explorer, reported a 56% decline in first-half profit due to plummeting crude prices. The company's net income dropped to 14.73 billion yuan (S$3.2 billion) from 33.59 billion yuan last year. This exceeded analyst estimates of 13.9 billion yuan.

site_title: US durable-goods orders rise for second month in July
summary: US durable-goods orders rose 2.0% in July to $241.1 billion, exceeding analyst expectations. This marks the second consecutive month of increases in orders for goods lasting at least three years, driven by a 4.7% rise in transportation orders. Excluding transportation, durable goods orders rose 0.6%, led by a 2.2% increase in non-defense capital goods. The data suggests a rising trend in non-oil spending, which may offset potential declines in oil firms' spending due to lower oil prices.

site_title: Update: Oil trades below US$40 as China turmoil adds to oversupply concern
summary: Oil prices fell below $40 a barrel amid concerns of China's slowing fuel demand and global oversupply. The US stock market's decline in China's fuel demand fueled the drop, with US crude inventories likely increasing to 457.7 million barrels. Oil prices have dropped 35% this year, with Brent crude trading at $43.42 a barrel, a 3.99 premium to WTI. The market's volatility is attributed to growth fears in China, which may continue to impact commodities and crude oil prices.

site_title: GE2015: NSP's Sebastian Teo denounces mud-slinging, writes post to 'set the record straight'
summary: National Solidarity Party (NSP) president Sebastian Teo denounced "mud-slinging tactics" against him and his party following the abrupt resignations of two central executive council members and revelations about his 1970s corruption conviction. The party was plunged into crisis, with Teo seeking to "set the record straight" in a post. This comes ahead of the Singapore General Election.

site_title: ECB sees increased risk to inflation goal: Praet
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) Executive Board member Peter Praet stated that the risk of missing the 2% inflation target has increased due to commodity price falls and weakness in some overseas economies. Praet warned that the governing council will closely monitor information and be prepared to act if necessary, indicating a potential shift in monetary policy.

site_title: ECB ready to tweak QE if needed to counter inflation risks
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is prepared to expand or extend its bond-buying program to combat inflation risks, according to Executive Board member Peter Praet. Commodity price slumps and global economic growth risks threaten the bank's 2% inflation goal. Praet stated that the ECB is willing and able to act if needed to achieve its inflation target, indicating a potential tweak to its quantitative easing (QE) program. This move aims to mitigate the impact of economic uncertainty on inflation.

site_title: Risk of technical recession looms with sharp drop in July manufacturing
summary: Singapore's industrial production contracted 6.1% year-on-year in July, marking the sixth straight month of decline. The drop was sharper than expected, with all clusters except chemicals experiencing a decline. Economists are divided on the impact on monetary policy, with some predicting a technical recession and others believing a policy change is unlikely until the labour market deteriorates further. A technical recession, defined as two consecutive quarters of sequential GDP contraction, is now considered more likely, with some economists estimating a 50% chance.

images.alt_text: The odds of Singapore entering a technical recession in the third quarter have risen significantly after July's industrial production contracted far more than expected.

site_title: US: Stocks surge in opening trade
summary: US stocks surged in opening trade on Wednesday, ending a six-day losing streak. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rose 2.25% and 2.35% respectively, driven by solid US economic data and a major oil-services acquisition by Schlumberger. The Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 2.35%. The rally follows a strong performance in Asia, where markets extended their gains despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Sinopec profit drops 22% as oil slide outweighs higher refining
summary: Sinopec, China's largest oil refiner, reported a 22% decline in first-half profits due to a slump in oil prices. The company's net income dropped to 25.4 billion yuan from 32.5 billion yuan in the same period last year. The decline outweighed the benefits of cheaper crude to its refining business.

site_title: IEV unit files writ against Indonesian company
summary: IEV Holdings' subsidiary, PT IEV Gas, has filed a writ against Indonesian company PT Indonesia Pelita Pratama, seeking 25.2 billion rupiah (S$2.52 million) in damages for losses and damage caused by PT IPP's unilateral construction of a barrier blocking the main road to IEV Gas' mother station. The dispute arose from PT IPP's actions, which have prevented IEV Gas from operating from its existing station and forced it to use alternative CNG supply sources. The outcome is not expected to impact IEV Holdings' consolidated earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Carlsberg said to plan more cuts in Russia, Europe and Asia
summary: Carlsberg, the world's fourth-largest brewer, plans more job cuts across Russia, Europe, and Asia to control costs amid tough market conditions. The reductions will be in the hundreds and affect operations in these regions, following the elimination of 180 office jobs in its Copenhagen headquarters. The company has cut its annual profit forecast and is undergoing a strategic review of its business in Russia, focusing on its most promising 15 markets. Carlsberg aims to make "all the changes necessary" to cope with the tougher environment.

site_title: GE2015: Reform Party stakes claim on Pioneer SMC, wants to contest seat if NSP pulls out
summary: The Reform Party has expressed interest in contesting the Pioneer SMC seat in the upcoming Singapore General Election, contingent on the National Solidarity Party withdrawing or failing to field a strong candidate. The party emphasized that it will not participate in a three-cornered contest. Meanwhile, news from other regions includes Malaysia's plan to seize RM3 billion in assets from Daim Zainuddin, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for the second consecutive month.

images.alt_text: The Reform Party said that it is interested in fielding a candidate in Pioneer SMC, and will do so if the National Solidarity Party withdraws or cannot field a strong candidate.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Ministerial Committee on Ageing unveiled a S$3 billion national plan to help Singaporeans age well, focusing on family and community bonds. The plan's key features include increasing support for caregivers and promoting intergenerational relationships. Meanwhile, Singapore's factory output declined 6.1% in July, marking the sixth straight month of contraction. The 3-month SOR jumped to 1.4%, a level not seen since 2009. Consumer confidence rose to 130.5 in August, driven by an increase in respondents feeling it's a good time to buy major household items.

site_title: 3-month SOR jumps to 1.4%, level not seen since Jan 2009
summary: The 3-month swap offer rate (SOR) in Singapore jumped to 1.40236, a level not seen since January 2009, due to China's yuan devaluation on August 11. Analysts attribute the increase to speculation that the yuan will weaken further, putting upward pressure on the Singapore dollar. This has led to higher interest rates, with the 3-month Sibor remaining unchanged at 1.00208%. The market is caught in a negative feedback loop between emerging market weakness and fear of outflows, exacerbating the moves.

site_title: China interbank liquidity crunch eases, but relief may be fleeting
summary: China's interbank liquidity crunch appears to have eased after the central bank cut interest rates and bank reserve ratios on Tuesday, providing support to the struggling stock market. The benchmark seven-day repurchase agreement rate fell 18 basis points to 2.37% and the one-day yield dropped 13 points to 1.73%. However, analysts warn that relief may be fleeting unless the central bank addresses capital outflows and yuan depreciation, which are expected to continue. The recent rate cut may benefit long-term bonds but its impact on short-term rates remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Rising short-term funding stress in the interbank market, which has complicated Beijing's efforts to support the stock market, appears to have eased after Tuesday's aggressive policy easing.

site_title: Shanghai: Shares end down 1.27% despite rate cut
summary: Shanghai stocks closed down 1.27% on Wednesday, despite a central bank interest rate cut aimed at boosting the economy. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 37.68 points to 2,927.29 on 461.8 billion yuan in turnover. The Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 3.05% to 1,695.76 on 432.2 billion yuan. The rate cut failed to stabilize the market, which has been experiencing days of falls.

site_title: GE2015: Workers' Party unveils first batch of candidates
summary: The Workers' Party in Singapore unveiled its first batch of candidates for the upcoming general election, including associate professor Daniel Goh, engineer Redzwan Hafidz, and RHB bank wealth manager Dylan Ng. This marks the party's first set of potential candidates.

site_title: GE2015: SDP introduces two more of its 11 candidates for GE2015, 7 left to go
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) announced two new candidates, Jaslyn Go and Paul Tambyah, for the 2015 general election. This brings the total number of SDP candidates to 11. The party's chief, Chee Soon Juan, introduced the new candidates without revealing their election constituencies. The announcement was made at the party's headquarters in Yio Chu Kang.

site_title: Japan govt downgrades consumer spending, exports as economy stutters
summary: Japan's government downgraded its assessment of consumer spending and exports in August, citing a patchy recovery from a contraction in the April-June quarter. The economy is expected to resume growing in the current quarter, but global worries may hurt household and corporate sentiment. The downgrade marks the first time in 11 months that the government downgraded its view of consumer spending, which was weakened by cool weather and declines in spending on summer clothes and air conditioners. Exports also weakened, amid global share market turmoil sparked by concerns over China's economy.

site_title: Quick Take: Singapore's July industrial output suggests more speed bumps ahead: ANZ
summary: Singapore's industrial output declined 6.1% year-on-year in July, with all clusters except chemicals experiencing a production drop. According to ANZ economist Weiwen Ng, this suggests "speed bumps ahead" for manufacturing amid regional weakness. The decline indicates more challenges for the manufacturing sector, raising concerns about the economy's growth prospects.

site_title: China police summon 11 over stock market activities: reports
summary: Chinese police have summoned 11 individuals, including a financial journalist, to assist in investigations into illegal stock market activities. The government has targeted volatility on the exchanges following a 30% decline in the stock market since mid-June. A financial journalist, Wang Xiaolu, was accused of spreading false information on securities and futures trading, while eight people from Citic Securities are suspected of illegal trading. The China Securities Regulatory Commission has also cracked down on short-selling and funded a state company to buy shares on its behalf.

images.alt_text: Chinese police have summoned 11 people including a financial journalist to assist investigations related to illegal stock market activities, state media reported, as the government targets volatility on the exchanges.

site_title: GE2015: Elections Department issues advisory for organisations planning to participate in campaigning, political activities
summary: The Elections Department in Singapore has issued an advisory to organisations planning to participate in election campaigning and political activities, stating that they must have a constitution allowing such activities. Advertisements and statements must comply with the Parliamentary Elections Act. The police have also introduced new conditions for obtaining permits for election meetings, including prohibiting central executive committee members and candidates from speaking at rallies for other parties and requiring them to reveal their faces. The right of individual voters to freely decide remains unchanged.

site_title: Australia: Shares in late rally after early fall
summary: Australian stocks rallied late in the session, closing 0.69% higher at 5,172.8 after falling earlier due to global sell-off concerns. The rally followed China's interest rate cut and reserve reduction, with IG Markets' Chris Weston attributing the response to the move. The benchmark S&P/ASX200 index rebounded 2.72% on Tuesday after a 4.09% loss on Monday. The market's response may also be influenced by US Federal Reserve President Bill Dudley's speech later in the day, potentially indicating a delay in interest rate hikes.

site_title: Dollar ticks up after China moves to calm market turmoil
summary: The US dollar rose against the yen on Wednesday as Chinese authorities cut interest rates and lowered cash reserves to calm market turmoil. The dollar reached 119.36 yen, its highest level since Tuesday, following a global stock market bloodbath fueled by fears of slowing Chinese growth. The euro also rose, and analysts now predict the Federal Reserve may delay lifting interest rates, a move that would benefit the dollar.

site_title: GE2015: Workers' Party unveils election theme, first batch of candidates
summary: The Workers' Party in Singapore unveiled its election theme "Empower Your Future" and introduced its first batch of candidates, including three new faces, to contest the upcoming General Election. The party's Secretary-General, Low Thia Khiang, emphasized the importance of Singaporeans thinking about the future and the need to question the effectiveness of the current government's model. The party's candidates will compete against the ruling People's Action Party, with the election expected to take place in the near future.

images.alt_text: The Workers' Party on Wednesday unveiled its campaign theme - Empower Your Future - as it urged Singaporeans to check if they want a government that casts "a long shadow" over their lives.

site_title: Malaysia names economic committee to help it cope with market turmoil
summary: Malaysia establishes a special economic team, led by Prime Minister Najib Razak, to address market turmoil and boost confidence in the ringgit and stocks. The nine-member committee will formulate strategies to maintain economic growth through domestic and foreign investment, reporting weekly to the prime minister. The team will operate in the short-term until the global economy stabilizes.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down 1.52% after volatile day
summary: Hong Kong shares closed 1.52% lower on Wednesday, following a late slump in Shanghai, despite a Chinese interest rate cut. The Hang Seng Index fell 324.57 points to 21,080.39, with turnover reaching HK$108.89 billion. Investors shrugged off the rate cut, citing volatility and uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended barely changed on Thursday, as most Asian markets stabilised after jitters over Turkey's downing of a Russian fighter jet abated.

site_title: Union Steel swings into the red in Q4 and FY15
summary: Union Steel Holdings Limited reported a net loss of S$8.4 million for Q4 2015, down from a net profit of S$2.1 million a year ago, due to a 37.2% fall in revenue and a S$6.7 million impairment of inventory. The group's gross profit margins fell to 6.1% from 12.5% in the previous year. For FY15, the group recorded a net loss of S$7.5 million, with revenue falling 8.2% to S$133.7 million. The company attributed the decline to adverse market conditions and will attempt to integrate its recent acquisition, Gee Sheng, to weather the challenging times.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post sharpest gain in 2 years, won rises
summary: South Korean shares posted their largest daily gain in two years on Wednesday, rising 2.6% to 1,894.09 points, driven by hopes that China's interest rate cut would stabilize its plunging stock markets. The won also gained against the dollar. Despite the boost, foreigners sold KOSPI shares for a 15th straight session, netting a 3.73 trillion won loss. The finance minister's comments urging a long-term view also supported the market.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end 3.2% higher after China rate cut
summary: Tokyo shares surged 3.2% on Wednesday, rebounding from six days of losses, after China cut interest rates to bolster its economy. China's central bank reduced interest rates and lowered reserve requirements, sparking a rebound in Tokyo's benchmark index. Global stock markets had fallen earlier due to concerns about China's slowdown, but the rate cut lifted major Japanese exporters and currency markets. The Nikkei 225 index jumped 570.13 points to 18,376.83, while the Topix index rose 3.23% to 1,478.97.

site_title: Singapore factory output shrinks 6.1% in July, more than market forecasts
summary: Singapore's factory output declined 6.1% in July, exceeding market forecasts, marking the sixth consecutive month of contraction. The electronics cluster, which accounts for 33.4% of the index, fell 5.8%, while transport engineering, precision engineering, and general manufacturing clusters dropped 6.1%, 6.2%, and 3.2%, respectively. However, the chemicals sector, excluding biomedical, grew 4.1% driven by a 4.4% increase in the specialties segment.

site_title: China, Japan battle to build Indonesia's first bullet train
summary: China and Japan are competing to build Indonesia's first high-speed railway, with China making a counteroffer to Japan's initial bid. Japan, a major investor in Indonesia, initially seemed destined to win the project, but China's offer has narrowed the gap. The rivalry is part of China's effort to challenge Japan's dominance in Southeast Asia's infrastructure funding. The project is a significant deal for both countries, with implications for their economic influence in the region.

site_title: Gold struggles as equities recover after China rate cut
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.4% to $1,135.26 an ounce on Wednesday, following a 1.2% drop on Tuesday, amid recovering equities and China's interest rate cut. The metal's fall is attributed to the potential US interest rate hike this year, which could reduce its appeal. Despite a seven-month high last week, gold may only rally to $1,200 if a rate hike is ruled out. Other precious metals, including palladium and platinum, also saw fluctuations due to market uncertainty.

site_title: GE2015: PAP unveils its slate for Marine Parade GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled its candidate slate for the Marine Parade Group Representative Constituency (GRC) in the 2015 Singapore General Election. The five-man team includes Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong, Minister Tan Chuan-Jin, and three veteran backbenchers. The PAP has been an MP in Marine Parade since 1976. The team will contest the newly-absorbed Joo Chiat ward in the GRC.

site_title: GE2015: Mood in Aljunied has changed, but PAP still faces uphill task, says Lim Boon Heng
summary: Former PAP chairman Lim Boon Heng says the mood in Aljunied has shifted since the last elections, with residents becoming more open and friendly, but it's unclear if this translates to increased support for the PAP. Despite the PAP team's hard work on the ground, Lim stopped short of revealing the candidates for the upcoming election, leaving room for last-minute tactical changes. The PAP still faces a tough task in regaining the ward from the Worker's Party.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby Q4 profit sinks 17%
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby reported a 17% year-on-year decline in Q4 net profit to 988.7 million ringgit, due to falling commodity prices and poor sales in key markets like China. Quarterly revenue rose 2.80% to 12.86 billion ringgit. The conglomerate attributed the decline to bearish commodity prices and volatile market conditions. This marks a 2.3 billion ringgit net profit for the full financial year, down 31% from the previous year. Sime Darby expects to face headwinds due to an economic slowdown, particularly in China, where it operates.

site_title: US businesses in Asean remain optimistic: survey
summary: US businesses in ASEAN remain optimistic about business prospects, with 72% reporting increased trade and investment over the past two years. 86% expect this trend to continue over the next five years. However, concerns over corruption, burdensome laws and regulations, and exchange rate volatility remain major obstacles. The US Chamber of Commerce and AmCham Singapore emphasize the need for improved regional economic integration, particularly in overcoming non-tariff barriers to trade. The upcoming Asean Economic Community launch is seen as a positive development, but priorities for the post-launch agenda will determine the region's attractiveness to investors.

site_title: Fed rate hike biggest risk to South Korea's economy: BOK board member
summary: A Bank of Korea board member warned that the US Federal Reserve's pending interest rate hike poses the biggest risk to South Korea's economy in the second half of the year. The Fed's rate hike could lead to extreme volatility in global financial markets. The government and central bank are preparing responses to potential risks, including economic troubles in China and uncertainties from other emerging markets.

images.alt_text: The biggest risk facing South Korea's economy in the second half of the year is the US Federal Reserve's pending interest rate hike, a Bank of Korea board member said on Wednesday.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall as China easings shrugged off; TSMC, Mediatek down
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.8% on Wednesday, with the TAIEX index at 7,613.24 points, amid fragile sentiment following a Wall Street decline despite China's central bank easing. TSMC and Mediatek, key electronics players, dropped 1.6% and 2% respectively. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$32.568 per US dollar. The market's resilience was undermined by lingering concerns and China's recent easing, which was seen as insufficient to boost investor confidence.

site_title: GE2015: PAP not afraid of competition in Marine Parade
summary: Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong dismissed concerns about the Workers' Party's potential threat to the Marine Parade GRC, citing his 40 years of experience in the area. He emphasized the PAP's track record in managing the town council finances and services. The PAP candidate line-up includes Goh, Tan Chuan-Jin, Fatimah Lateef, Seah Kian Peng, and Edwin Tong, who will run in the Joo Chiat division. The PAP aims to reassure residents that they will not be left out of government assistance due to their private home addresses.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Broker's take: Coutts continues to favour equities, particularly in Europe
summary: Coutts, a private bank and wealth manager, maintains its favor for equities, particularly in Europe, and remains underweight on bonds. Despite global market volatility, Coutts is confident that global equities will find a floor and recover due to strong growth indicators in the US and Europe. Emerging markets are expected to benefit from a pickup in developed market manufacturing, and China's economy is seen as a "wild card" with few signs of a hard landing. The recent falls in equity prices have made global equities cheaper, with prices relative to earnings now in line with or below their long-term averages.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Toyota said to move toward China plant restart after blasts
summary: Toyota Motor Corp is restarting trial production at its China plants that were shut after explosions in Tianjin, with a test run of about 100 cars set to begin on August 26. The plants were closed for two weeks following the August 12 blasts that killed at least 123 people and damaged 4,700 vehicles. Toyota will assess the safety of its facilities before deciding whether to resume full production. The company has not set a specific timeline for the restart, but shares rose as much as 3.7% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp is beginning trial production of cars at the China plants that were shut after explosions in the city of Tianjin.

site_title: Broker's take: Selloff in China is a correction, not full-blown crash, says Pictet
summary: Pictet Wealth Management's chief strategist Christophe Donay believes China's recent stock market selloff is a correction, not a full-blown crash, as the country adjusts to a more mature economy. Donay expects China's growth to stabilize at around 5% within 4-5 years, with the Chinese authorities retaining considerable firepower to stabilize the economy. However, a full-blown financial and economic crash in China poses a significant risk to the global economy and financial markets, particularly in Europe, where vulnerability is greater.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
The selloff on Chinese stock markets that has sent tremors throughout the global financial markets is a sharp correction to earlier excesses rather than the start of a long-term bear market

site_title: Smartphone growth creating etiquette challenges
summary: A survey by the Pew Research Centre found that 77% of Americans believe it's acceptable to use smartphones while walking down the street, and 75% think it's okay to use them on public transportation. However, there is a clear consensus that smartphones should be turned off during family dinners and in church. The survey highlights the growing etiquette challenges posed by smartphone use in various social settings, with users struggling to find rules for when and where to use their devices.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB denies Abu Dhabi's IPIC pulling out of debt plan
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB state fund has denied Abu Dhabi's IPIC is considering pulling out of a debt restructuring plan, contrary to a report by Singapore's Business Times. IPIC had agreed to help restructure 1MDB's US$11 billion debt just three months ago. 1MDB stated it remains engaged in discussions with IPIC to conclude the transaction as announced. The move comes amid multiple investigations into 1MDB's financial mismanagement and graft allegations.

images.alt_text: Malaysian state fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd said on Wednesday that it strongly denies that Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Co (IPIC) is considering pulling out of a plan to help restructure 1MDB's debts.

site_title: Seoul: Shares and won rise in volatile trade after China's cuts rates
summary: Seoul shares rose 1.2% to 1,868.75 points on Wednesday, following China's interest rate cuts and bank reserve requirements reduction to support its economy. Winners outnumbered losers 3.6 to 1, with technology giants Samsung and LG Electronics gaining 2.5% and 5.1%, respectively. The South Korean won rebounded 0.5% against the dollar, despite concerns over Chinese share markets. Foreign investors remained net sellers for a 15th consecutive session, offloading 316 billion won worth of KOSPI shares.

site_title: Ringgit slumps to 17-year low on 1MDB debt woes, growth concern
summary: Malaysia's ringgit hit a 17-year low against the US dollar, depreciating 1.3% to 4.2680 as of 10:17 am, amid concerns over 1MDB debt woes and economic growth. The decline follows a 1.2% gain on Tuesday and a 18% drop in 2015. International Petroleum Investment Co's potential pullout from a debt restructuring plan and China's interest rate cut failed to stabilize the currency, which has been weakened by a slowing economy and a scandal involving Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: South Korea says willing to discuss North's demand to lift sanctions
summary: South Korea has expressed willingness to discuss North Korea's demand to lift sanctions imposed in 2010 following a naval attack that killed 46 sailors. The two sides agreed to hold talks to improve ties after a landmark pact was reached, with North Korea expressing regret over a landmine incident that wounded South Korean soldiers. The South is prepared to discuss the May 24, 2010, issue through dialogue, with the goal of lifting sanctions.

images.alt_text: South Korean National Security Adviser Kim Kwan Jin (right) shaking hands with Mr Hwang Pyong So (left), the top military aide to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, after talks in Panmunjom, in this photo released yesterday.

site_title: Currency volatility upsets Asian growth plans
summary: Asian economies are facing significant challenges due to currency volatility triggered by China's 2% devaluation in August. Currencies and stock markets in the region have plummeted to multi-year lows, with deflation risks and falling exports exacerbating the situation. Central banks have deferred rate cuts, putting growth and stimulus plans on hold, and some countries, like Indonesia, are struggling with low forex reserves and heavy foreign debt. Experts warn that Asian authorities must stomach high interest rates for a while to stabilize their currencies, and some countries may even be forced to raise rates to combat the sell-off.

site_title: South-east Asian companies grapple with foreign debt worries
summary: South-east Asian companies face foreign debt worries due to the weakening of the rupiah and ringgit currencies. Foreign currency debts for 100 large firms in the region have ballooned to nearly a third of total debt, with 40% of companies now holding foreign currency debts exceeding 50% of their total debt. To address this, companies may be forced to raise equity funds at steep discounts and restructure debt, with Indonesia and Malaysia being the most affected. Smaller companies and those without government links face the tightest squeeze, and refinancing requirements are prominent in Indonesia.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.49% higher
summary: Tokyo shares opened 0.49% higher on Wednesday after the Chinese central bank slashed interest rates for the fifth time in nine months to support the world's second-largest economy. The Nikkei-225 index rose 87.59 points to 17,894.29.

site_title: Gold little changed as equity markets swing on China concern
summary: Gold prices remained relatively stable, changing little, as Asian stocks fluctuated following China's latest monetary easing. China's stocks swung between gains and losses, weighing the impact of interest-rate cuts on global financial markets. Mohamed El-Erian warned that volatility will hinder the Federal Reserve's ability to raise interest rates in September.

site_title: Boeing 777 makes emergency landing in Japan: ANA
summary: A Boeing 777 operated by All Nippon Airways made an emergency landing in Osaka, Japan, on August 26, 2015, after the plane suffered engine trouble. The flight from Osaka to Tokyo left at 7:18 am, but the crew requested an emergency landing due to power output problems with the left engine and abnormal temperatures. None of the 246 passengers or 11 crew members were injured, and all safely exited the plane after landing at 7:50 am. The airline is investigating the incident.

images.alt_text: An All Nippon Airways (ANA) jetliner(back) rolls over for take off at Haneda International airport in Tokyo.

site_title: Singapore shares open 1.09% lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index opened 1.09% lower at 2,854.83 on Wednesday, despite China's interest rate cut to boost its economy. The benchmark recorded 566.3 million shares worth S$138.7 million trading hands, with 57 gainers to 157 losers.

site_title: Air New Zealand posts record annual profit
summary: Air New Zealand reported a record annual net profit of NZ$327 million, a 24.3% increase from the previous year, driven by strong demand, cost-cutting, and lower fuel prices. The airline achieved its fourth consecutive year of growth, with Chief Executive Christopher Luxon citing "superior commercial results." The company predicts significant earnings growth in the current financial year.

site_title: Singapore consumer confidence gets an SG50 boost
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence index rose to 130.5 in August, the highest in over a year, driven by increased optimism over buying major household items. This marks a 4.1-point increase from the previous month and a 11.5-point year-over-year gain. 31% of respondents reported their families are financially better off, while 9% said worse off.

site_title: Government panel unveils key features of S$3b plan to help Singaporeans age well
summary: Singapore's Ministerial Committee on Ageing has unveiled a S$3 billion national plan to help Singaporeans age well, with three key thrusts: providing opportunities for all ages, creating a "Kampong for all ages", and developing a "city for all ages". The plan includes initiatives such as a National Silver Academy, a National Seniors' Health Programme, and a transport plan to refresh infrastructure. The full Action Plan report is expected to be released next year, aiming to build and maintain strong bonds within families and communities, and make Singapore a model for successful ageing.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise 0.14%
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.14% on Wednesday, following China's interest rate cut to restore confidence in its slowing economy. The Hang Seng Index increased 29.29 points to 21,434.25. This move comes as investors look to the US-China trade talks and the impact of tariffs on global markets.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slip as China rate cuts fail to calm nerves
summary: Asian stocks declined on Wednesday as investors remained skeptical about China's rate cuts, fearing they wouldn't be enough to stabilize the economy or halt a stock market collapse. China's key indexes attempted to rise but were met with selling pressure, with shares plummeting 20% in three days. The People's Bank of China cut interest rates and lowered reserve requirements late Tuesday, but economists deemed the move long overdue. The region's stocks fell as investors awaited further support from the government and central bank.

images.alt_text: Asian stocks fell on Wednesday as investors feared fresh rate cuts in China would not be enough stabilise its cooling economy or halt a collapse in its stock markets.

site_title: Mood getting worse on Wall Street as S&P 500 floor eludes bulls
summary: US stocks fell, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 442 points, or 4%, after a rally vanished in the final hour. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite China's interest-rate cut, which failed to provide a floor for US equities. The Shanghai Composite Index has lost 22% in four days, and exchange-traded funds tracking China's A-shares pared gains. The decline dashed hopes that China's stimulus would prop up US stocks, which have been volatile due to US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Hot stock: Silverlake falls further on nagging jitters following allegations in report
summary: Silverlake Axis shares resumed trading lower on Wednesday, down 28.346% to S$0.455 a share, amid concerns over allegations made by an anonymous report. The company denied the allegations, which suggested possible impropriety in related party transactions, and announced an independent review by Deloitte Singapore. UOB Kay Hian downgraded Silverlake to a hold, citing a complex corporate structure and slower-growing license segments.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Shares of software solutions provider Silverlake Axis resumed trading lower on Wednesday as investors remained spooked by concerns over allegations made by an anonymous report.

site_title: Dollar rises against euro amid China market turmoil
summary: The US dollar rose 0.5% against the euro on Tuesday amid concerns over China's economy and market volatility, following steep losses on Monday. US stocks fell for the sixth straight session, contributing to the dollar's rebound. The euro fell to US$1.1518, its lowest level in nearly a week. Market turmoil and worries about China's slowing GDP growth are putting pressure on policymakers and investors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares opens lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.76 points to 1,556.180. Volume was 101.5 million lots worth RM38.70 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 157 to 84.

site_title: China: Stocks rise at open after cuts to interest rates, reserve requirements
summary: China's major stock indexes rose 0.7% and 0.5% at open on Wednesday, following the central bank's aggressive monetary easings announced on Tuesday. The CSI300 index rose to 3,062.57 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained to 2,980.79 points. The benchmark indexes had tumbled 19% in the previous three sessions. The moves came after China's central bank cut interest rates and reserve requirements to stabilize the market.

site_title: Oil near 6-1/2 year lows as China economy fears linger
summary: Crude oil futures dropped to 6-1/2 year lows as investors worried about China's economy, despite the central bank's efforts to boost growth. US stock futures declined, and Asian shares were cautious, following a previous session's gains. Brent oil fell 10 cents to $43.11 a barrel, settling at $43.21 the previous day. The limited success of China's monetary easing has fueled concerns about a supply glut, contributing to the decline in oil prices.

images.alt_text: Malaysia said it agreed with Indonesia to improve cooperation in the palm oil industry given the grim global economic environment that has stoked worries about demand and pushed down prices.

site_title: Yuan opens weaker on Wednesday after central bank cuts interest rates, bank reserve requirements
summary: China's yuan weakened on Wednesday after the People's Bank of China cut interest rates and reduced reserve requirements, setting a midpoint rate of 6.4043 per dollar, its weakest level since August 2011. The spot market opened at 6.4181 per dollar, 57 pips away from the previous close. The central bank's move is seen as a long-awaited easing to boost weak exports and the cooling economy, but economists caution that China's strong trade surplus limits further depreciation.

site_title: End of the world not at hand (yet) as the equity bubble bursts
summary: A global equity market bubble is bursting, but experts say the current situation is different from the 2008 financial crisis. Unlike previous crises, this one is primarily driven by the equity market rather than deep-seated financial institution issues. The bursting of the bubble is a natural correction, rather than a catastrophic event. While the outcome is uncertain, there are grounds for optimism that Doomsday is not imminent. The market rout may lead to a shakeout, but it is not a sign of Armageddon.

site_title: Broker's take: Muted outlook for Singapore Reits
summary: OCBC Investment Research notes that Singapore Reits' Q2 CY2015 results were mixed, with four hospitality Reits underperforming expectations and the rest meeting in-line targets. Despite the positive boost from the SEA Games, tourist arrivals and corporate sentiment remain weak, leading to moderation in rental reversions. OCBC maintains a 'neutral' outlook on the S-Reits sector, but recommends four selective stocks: Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Keppel DC Reit, Frasers Commercial Trust, and Starhill Global Reit, with target prices ranging from S$0.93 to S$2.24.

site_title: Ex-JPMorgan analyst charged with insider trading
summary: A former JPMorgan Chase analyst, Ashish Aggarwal, and two friends were arrested in California on charges of making over $600,000 through insider trading deals. Aggarwal, who worked at JPMorgan from 2011 to 2013, allegedly shared confidential information about technology industry acquisitions with his friends, resulting in significant profits. The Justice Department made the arrest on Tuesday.

site_title: BHP Billiton A+ rating fragile in FY16, S&P warns
summary: BHP Billiton's A+ credit rating is fragile due to weak commodity prices and a sharp cut in capital spending, according to Standard & Poor's. The company's debt to earnings balance may temporarily put it out of the range needed to hold the rating. S&P believes BHP's commitment to a progressive dividend policy reduces its financial flexibility in times of deteriorating market conditions. However, the agency expects the rating to withstand a dip in earnings ratios as long as the metrics recover by the following fiscal year.

site_title: Jurong Region MRT Line may be connected to Circle Line: Lui Tuck Yew
summary: Singapore's Jurong Region MRT Line may be connected to the Circle Line, enhancing rail connectivity between the western parts of the city and the city centre. The Land Transport Authority will study the possibility of a West Coast extension, with a connection at the Haw Par Villa station. The 20km line is expected to be completed in 2025, serving Choa Chu Kang, Boon Lay, and future developments in Tengah. Minister for Transport Lui Tuck Yew hopes the connection will increase the overall resilience of the MRT network.

site_title: GE2015: PAP introduces 2 new faces in Nee Soon GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced two new faces, Louis Ng, an animal-rights activist, and Henry Kwek, a food-supply company executive, to run in the Nee Soon GRC for the upcoming general election.

images.alt_text: The PAP's Nee Soon GRC team (from left) Lee Bee Wah, Henry Kwek, K. Shanmugam, Louis Ng and Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim at their press conference.

site_title: LA to become largest US city with Uber and Lyft at LAX
summary: The Los Angeles City Council voted 9-6 to permit Uber and Lyft to pick up and drop off passengers at Los Angeles International Airport, making it the largest US city to do so. The decision aims to ensure safety, transparency, and accessibility for passengers. The council also calls for state regulators to establish a protocol for fingerprinting and background checks of drivers. This move follows similar regulations in 54 US cities and states, and comes after Georgia Governor Nathan Deal signed regulations for Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport in Atlanta.

site_title: Oil picks up after rout, but US crude still below US$40
summary: Oil prices rebounded after a sharp fall, with US crude rising to $39.31 a barrel, its first time below $40 in six years. Brent North Sea crude rose to $43.21 a barrel. Despite the rebound, analysts say bearish sentiment remains due to robust OPEC production, particularly from Saudi Arabia and the US. The market is awaiting Wednesday's US petroleum inventories report, with expectations of a build in crude oil storage numbers.

site_title: China to restrict stock index futures trading to curb speculation: exchange
summary: China's China Financial Futures Exchange will restrict trading in stock index futures to curb speculation, effective Wednesday. The measures include raising margin requirements, restricting daily open positions, and adding transaction fees. The move follows two consecutive days of 10% daily slumps in index futures contracts. The goal is to reduce speculative trading and stabilize the market.

site_title: How the silver standard wrecked China's economy: editorial
summary: China's economy suffered greatly during the Great Depression due to its adherence to a silver standard, which allowed its currency to depreciate and shield it from the worst effects of the global economic crisis. In contrast, countries that pegged their currencies to gold, such as the US, experienced crippling deflation. The US's decision to abandon the gold standard in 1933 allowed it to expand its money supply and recover more quickly. Meanwhile, China's efforts to stem the flow of silver overseas failed, leading to a sharp decline in exports and a devastating economic collapse.

site_title: Internet roulette
summary: The "Internet of Things" (IoT) poses significant risks despite its potential benefits, including increased efficiency and cost savings. With the number of connected devices expected to grow to 50 billion by 2020, experts warn of heightened vulnerabilities to hacking, cyberwarfare, and software glitches. Cybersecurity experts identify cyberterrorists and other nations as the main threats, while companies may be reluctant to invest in security measures due to unknown and unknowable costs. A study by McKinsey estimates worldwide benefits from IoT could reach $11 trillion by 2025, but this comes with the risk of exposing society to catastrophic failures, such as a hacked electrical grid or urban water systems.

site_title: Chinese smartphone market expected to cool this year: report
summary: The Chinese smartphone market is expected to grow 1.2% this year, a significant slowdown from 19.7% growth last year, according to a report by International Data Corporation. This decline marks a cooling of the once-hot market, which accounted for nearly a third of all new handsets shipped. Despite the slowdown, China remains a crucial market for smartphone manufacturers, with the report noting that it "clearly remains a very important market."

site_title: Australia: Shares drop 1.0% at open
summary: Australian stocks dropped 1.0% at the open on Wednesday, following a European and US market rally that fizzled out on Wall Street. The benchmark S&P/ASX200 index fell 51.4 points to 5,085.9. This comes after Australian stocks rebounded on Tuesday, with the big banks leading the way. The decline defies Monday's global sell-off as bargain hunters moved in.

site_title: China cuts rates and reserve ratio after stocks plunge again
summary: China's central bank cut interest rates and reduced reserve requirements to support the country's stuttering economy and plunging stock market, which has sent shockwaves globally. The People's Bank of China lowered the one-year benchmark bank lending rate by 25 basis points to 4.6% and reduced the reserve requirement ratio by 50 basis points to 18%, injecting $101 billion into the economy. The moves aim to shore up economic fundamentals rather than underpin stocks, as China's economy faces concerns of a "hard landing" and a slowdown in growth.

site_title: Markets greet China rate cut with caution after S&P 500 retreats
summary: China's latest rate cut failed to boost markets, with Asian index futures signaling a mixed day for stocks and the yuan retreating offshore. The S&P 500 fell 1.4% and futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average also declined. Shanghai stocks extended their tumble, capping the worst four-day rout since 1996, amid speculation the government was stepping back from supporting the market. The decision to reduce rates for the fifth time since November fueled European stock gains but failed to sustain a recovery in China's stock market, which will depend on further reform from policymakers.

site_title: Keppel, MPA, and Wilmar CSR award winners
summary: Keppel Land, Wilmar International, and the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) won top awards for demonstrating social responsibility and sustainability excellence in their business practices. Keppel Land took the top honours in the "large organisations" category, while Wilmar International received a special recognition award. MPA won in the "small and medium organisations" category. The awards recognized companies that prioritize employee and community welfare, and stakeholders expect this of businesses.

site_title: Fox News boss seeks apology after Trump Twitter tirade
summary: Fox News chairman Roger Ailes demanded an apology from Donald Trump after Trump resumed his criticism of TV host Megyn Kelly on Twitter, calling her a "bimbo" and stating her show was better without her. Trump's comments re-ignited the feud between the broadcaster and the Republican frontrunner, who had previously clashed after a debate in August. Kelly likely had a "terrible vacation" because she was "really off her game," Trump tweeted. The incident has sparked a renewed controversy between the two.

site_title: Rio de Janeiro city council votes to ban Uber
summary: Rio de Janeiro's city council voted 42-1 in favor of banning unregulated ride-sharing services like Uber, with the decision awaiting approval from Mayor Eduardo Paes within 15 days. The ban aims to regulate unlicensed drivers and level the playing field for taxi services. Uber has vowed to continue operating in the city, calling the vote against technology and citizens' choice. The move follows similar bans in Sao Paulo, Brasilia, and other cities worldwide, citing concerns over Uber's lack of regulation and unfair advantage over taxi drivers.

site_title: Cancelled or suspended deals cloud Hanergy outlook
