summary: Hanergy Thin Film Power Group Ltd, a Hong Kong-based solar panel manufacturer, faces a bleak outlook after cutting ties with its parent Hanergy Holding, which accounted for 62% of its sales in 2014. The company warned of a potential first-half net loss, its first since 2009, due to the unravelling of contracts. Analysts say thin film solar panels are inefficient and make it difficult for the company to find external clients. The stock has been suspended since May 20, with some predicting it may never trade again.

site_title: Collaborative workspace for startups debuts in Prinsep St
summary: A new collaborative workspace, The Hub Singapore (THS), was unveiled in Prinsep Street, offering affordable real estate to entrepreneurs, creatives, and techies. The 8,000 sq ft space has 140 co-working and permanent desks, and will support startups through an Investor-in-Residence program and a Hub Alumni Fund. Anchor tenants include Mashable and Our Better World, and the facility aims to facilitate collaborations across the ecosystem, with plans to pair corporates with entrepreneurs and creatives.

site_title: Singapore's electoral system
summary: Singapore's electoral system remains unchanged. No updates or announcements were made regarding changes or reforms.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Norway fund among bidders for Asia Square Tower 1: sources
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund is among bidders for BlackRock's Asia Square Tower 1 in Singapore, along with CapitaLand and Keppel Land. The office building, valued at over S$3.5 billion, is among several properties BlackRock may sell, including Asia Square Tower 2, which could be worth S$7 billion. The agreement could be reached within 60 days, with the fund seeking to expand its Asian real estate investments.

images.alt_text: BlackRock said earlier this year that it has received expressions of interest for Asia Square Tower 1 and could get more than S$4 billion for the building.

site_title: Doing well by doing good
summary: Keppel Land, a Singapore property developer, has achieved significant sustainability excellence, ranking fourth in the Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations in the World 2015. The company has implemented various initiatives, including setting a benchmark for Green Mark GoldPLUS rating in its projects, reducing carbon emissions intensity by 16% by 2020, and investing S$130 million in green features. Keppel Land has also established a dedicated CSR committee and trained over half of its project and property managers as Green Mark Professionals. The company aims to combine its quality management, environmental management, and occupational health and safety management systems into a single framework.

site_title: Govt does more to defray early child-raising costs
summary: The Singapore government has introduced the Jubilee Marriage & Parenthood Package, which includes a S$2,000 increase in the Baby Bonus cash gift and a S$1,000 increase in the Medisave Grant for Newborns. The package aims to support families during the child's first 18 months of life, with families receiving at least S$3,000 more per child. The enhanced cash gift will be disbursed between 12 and 18 months after birth, and is available for the first four children, with an additional S$2,000 for the fifth child and beyond.

site_title: Too early to pick up shares in developing markets: Mobius
summary: Mark Mobius advises investors to wait for emerging markets to stabilize before buying shares, citing short-lived rebound potential amid price swings. The MSCI Emerging Markets Index has seen a 1.8% gain, but 15 of the 30 largest equity markets have extended losses of 20% or more, meeting the definition of a bear market. Mobius suggests Chinese policymakers could use monetary and fiscal policies to boost equities, and warns against getting "excited" and rushing to buy, instead advising a wait-and-see approach.

site_title: Net sells by global funds pip net buys in 3 months to August
summary: Global mutual funds sold more Singapore stocks than they bought in the 3 months to August 19, with net sells of S$1.19 billion and net buys of S$883.9 million. The top-selling stock was UOB with a volume of S$210.7 million, while the top-buying stock was DBS Group Holdings with a volume of S$195.5 million.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang's Q4, FY2015 results hit by weaker sales in Hong Kong, Malaysia
summary: Eu Yan Sang International reported a net loss of S$3.60 million for Q4 FY2015, down from a net profit of S$1.61 million a year ago. Revenue fell 15% to S$72.25 million, primarily due to challenges in Hong Kong and Malaysia. The company remains cautious on its business outlook due to macro-environmental issues, but expects a turnaround in Australia and Singapore. Store rationalisation and a focus on online and wholesale channels are planned to mitigate the impact of weaker sales.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

Eu Yan Sang International on Wednesday reported that it has sunk into the red, with a net loss of S$3.60 million for the fourth quarter ended June 30, 2015, compared to a net profit of S$1.61 million a year ago.

site_title: Croesus Retail Trust's Q4 FY2015 DPU up 1%
summary: Croesus Retail Trust reported a 1% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q4 FY2015, reaching 2.02 Singapore cents. Income available for distribution rose 23.9% to 876.7 million yen, driven by foreign-exchange gains and lower administrative expenses. The trust's gross revenue increased 25.5% to 1.99 billion yen, mainly due to the acquisition of One's Mall in 2014. DPU for FY2015 rose 2.8% to 8.08 Singapore cents, translating to a 20.7% increase in income available for distribution. The company expects robust and stable cash flows in the next reporting period.

images.alt_text: Croesus Retail Trust (CRT) posted a one per cent year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter to 2.02 Singapore cents, lifted by foreign-exchange gains and lower administrative expenses.

site_title: US: Markets rally fizzles as China worries persist
summary: US stocks closed down 1.35% on Tuesday, despite a strong early session, as investors locked in gains and took cover from potential turmoil. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones ended down 1.35% and 1.29%, respectively. The rebound fizzled out after China's central bank cut interest rates for the fifth time in nine months, boosting markets in Frankfurt, Paris, and London. However, emerging-market economies remain vulnerable due to capital outflows and concerns over China's economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened slightly higher Thursday as markets remained volatile on concerns about global growth and the prospect of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike.

site_title: STI gain a technical rebound: analysts
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rallied 1.5% to 2,886.29, snapping a six-day losing streak, as local banks and energy-related stocks recovered from the previous day's losses. Trading volumes jumped to 2.14 billion shares, with conglomerate Keppel Corp and offshore stocks like Ezra and Ezion seeing notable jumps. Analysts largely viewed the rebound as a technical bounce, with some warning of potential further declines and others expecting cheaper buying opportunities ahead.

site_title: Euro emerging as haven in market rocked by yuan devaluation
summary: The euro has surged 4% against a basket of developed-nation peers in the past month, becoming a haven in times of market turmoil. This gain, coupled with the European Central Bank's quantitative-easing program, has complicated the ECB's efforts to stimulate the economy. A stronger euro could curb exports and slow inflation, while investors are unwinding carry trades funded in euros, supporting the euro's rally. The euro rose above $1.17, its highest level since January 2015, as growing skepticism about a US interest rate hike in September and China's economic slowdown also contributed to the surge.

site_title: Firm dong weighs on Vietnam rubber exports
summary: Vietnam's rubber exports are expected to decline due to the depreciation of its currency, the dong, which has lost about 3% since June, compared to other rival exporters. This makes Vietnam's exports less attractive to Chinese buyers, who account for 40-50% of its natural rubber sales. The country's exports rose 13% in the first seven months of the year, but the trend may not be sustained, with analysts suggesting Vietnam should reduce dependence on China and boost quality to maintain competitiveness.

site_title: Strong quarterly exports highlight China risks to German growth
summary: Germany's economy expanded 0.4% in the second quarter, driven by a 2.2% increase in exports, despite a slowdown in China, the world's second-largest economy. The growth is a concern as China's slowdown poses a risk to global trade, particularly for German companies. Despite this, business confidence rebounded in August, and domestic spending is expected to support the economy. The German economy minister downplayed concerns about China's impact, citing positive momentum in Europe and lower oil prices.

site_title: Air-traffic towers in US wasted US$850m: watchdog
summary: The US federal government has wasted over $850 million in six years due to inefficient air-traffic control towers, according to a Transportation Department audit. The inefficiency cost the government over $140 million annually from 2008-2013, with the bulk of the extra costs at larger facilities. The FAA has disputed the audit's findings, citing differences in factors such as air traffic volume and facility size. A proposed nonprofit corporation to manage the FAA's air-traffic system may be created to address the issue.

site_title: Hybrid megayachts for the eco-conscious
summary: Dutch ship builder Feadship has launched the world's first hybrid megayacht, Savannah, a 274-foot vessel that combines a diesel engine with electric power for increased fuel efficiency. The eco-friendly boat, which can deliver one million watts of power, has amenities such as a swimming pool, gym, and underwater lounge. With its advanced engine system, Savannah is 30% more fuel-efficient than comparable megayachts. The success of Savannah has sparked interest in hybrid megayachts, with several other companies already producing similar vessels.

site_title: A cut above the rest
summary: The Global Compact Network Singapore has praised three winners of the Singapore Apex CSR Awards 2015 for their sustainability practices. Keppel Land was recognized for its proactive risk management, while Wilmar International was commended for its 'No Deforestation, No Peat and No Exploitation' policy. Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore received special recognition for its sustainability culture and efforts to set a benchmark for the maritime industry. The awards highlight these organizations' commitment to sustainability and responsible business practices.

site_title: Shipping magnate 'very worried' about China
summary: Shipping magnate John Fredriksen expressed concern about the turmoil in China, stating he's "very worried" about its impact on global shipping markets. The turmoil, which Fredriksen described as "big problems," is likely to negatively affect the shipping industry.

site_title: Rebound could be technical move
summary: Chinese stocks fell 7.6% on Tuesday, with the Shanghai Composite closing at 2,964.97, amid the absence of state buying intervention. The government has stopped supporting the market, citing limited domestic impact and high costs. The rebound in Asian markets, including Japan and Singapore, is seen as a technical move rather than a genuine recovery. Investors are advised to exercise caution, and the situation remains volatile, with the US market's performance in the coming sessions set to influence the outcome.

site_title: Analysts: Soaring yen could undo Abenomics gains
summary: Japan's currency, the yen, surged to 116 against the US dollar, sparking concerns it could undo Abenomics gains. Finance Minister Taro Aso hinted at possible foreign-exchange market intervention, while a JPMorgan strategist warned the yen could reach 105 if short-selling continues. Tokyo stocks fell for a sixth consecutive day, with the Nikkei index down 4% due to worries about China's slowing economy, Japan's second-largest trading partner. Analysts predict a further yen surge if short positions are unwound, potentially derailing Japan's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: At the start of Tokyo trading on Tuesday, the yen was at a strong 116 to the greenback. It see-sawed through the day, fell to 120 at one point and closed at around 119.

site_title: Jet lag 'cures' aplenty, but none that work for all
summary: A business professor and frequent traveler, Rita Gunther McGrath, struggles with jet lag despite trying various remedies. Research suggests that there is no one-size-fits-all solution to prevent or deal with jet lag, as it depends on individual genetic profiles. Scientists propose creating personalized plans based on an individual's genetic blueprint to combat the issue. Experts recommend adjusting sleep schedules, using medications, melatonin supplements, and light exposure timing, but these methods do not work for everyone.

site_title: Intel makes a strategic move to software for the cloud
summary: Intel invests $75 million in Mirantis, a startup specializing in open-source cloud software, to remain competitive in the growing cloud computing market. The investment aims to bolster Intel's resources for working with Mirantis-type products, which can manage up to 1,000 servers. The move follows Intel's shift away from relying on traditional enterprise customers and towards partnering with younger, agile companies like Mirantis to stay ahead in the industry.

site_title: Indonesia steps up efforts to protect shaky markets
summary: Indonesia steps up efforts to protect its financial markets from global volatility, imposing new daily limits on share price fluctuations and launching a share buyback program. The country's stock index has slumped around 20% this year, while the rupiah has fallen to a 17-year low against the US dollar. Authorities have also eased regulations, allowing listed firms to buy back shares, and are diversifying away from US dollars for trade with China. Economic growth is expected to slow to 4.7-5.1% this year, with a forecast of 5.3-5.7% for next year.

site_title: Gold mines cutting output offers little relief
summary: Gold mine production is expected to decline for the first time since 2008, with some producers losing money, despite efforts to cut output. The global mine output surged 24% in a decade, but prices have tumbled 40% from a record high in 2011 due to investors unloading metal and a stronger dollar. Producers expect a "big dip" in production, with some predicting a 18% decline by the end of the decade, as prices remain below the industry's break-even point of $1,200 per ounce.

site_title: Deflation risks suggest Fed should hold off on interest rate hikes till 2016
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to hold off on interest rate hikes until 2016 due to deflation risks. Despite low unemployment, inflation remains below the Fed's 2% target, with core inflation at 0.1% in July. Recent economic developments, including China's yuan devaluation and energy price drops, have accelerated deflation concerns. A rate hike could compound the problem, triggering a further rise in the US dollar and more deflation. The Fed has never indicated a September rate hike, and experts agree that the time for rate hikes is not yet here.

images.alt_text: On Sept 16, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) of the US Federal Reserve will meet to decide whether it should increase the benchmark Fed Funds rate for the first time since 2006.

site_title: Championing sustainability
summary: The Singapore Apex CSR Awards 2015 was established to honour local companies that exhibit the highest level of corporate social responsibility (CSR) excellence in Singapore. The inaugural winners, Keppel Land, Wilmar International, and the Maritime Port Authority, have successfully integrated CSR and sustainability into their businesses. The awards aim to raise awareness and drive adoption of CSR, setting a national benchmark for best practices and inspiring more companies to map out their sustainability strategy.

site_title: Hot tech startups may face a long and bumpy fall
summary: Venture capitalists are concerned about the potential long-term impact of the current stock market rout on private tech startups, particularly in Silicon Valley. The number of startups valued at $1 billion or more has increased, and venture funding has more than doubled since 2010. However, experts believe that a downturn will likely affect only those companies that need to raise capital, with well-run companies with achievable business plans continuing to attract capital. The prices of private company stocks reset only when founders raise new money, and investors will focus on business model viability and path to profitability, potentially leading to "down rounds" that can be debilitating for struggling companies.

site_title: Unmanned ships to be reality soon
summary: China's Maritime Safety Administration has approved a research and development project on unmanned multifunctional maritime ships, with several companies, including Rolls-Royce and DNV-GL, working on autonomous vessel projects. Industry experts believe unmanned ships are inevitable and could improve safety, citing statistics that 90% of shipping accidents are caused by human error. However, practical issues such as mooring, machinery breakdowns, and rescue systems need to be addressed. Autonomous ships are already in use in the defense and oil-and-gas industries, and experts predict they could become a reality within a decade, potentially solving issues like seafarer shortages and fatigue.

site_title: GE2015: First time Polling Day falls on a Friday, but not first time polls held on a weekday
summary: Polling Day in Singapore's 2015 General Election will take place on September 11, a Friday, marking the first time since independence in 1965 that it has not fallen on a Saturday. This is the third instance of this occurrence.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Silverlake Axis reported "unusual price movements" in its shares on August 21, attributing it to an anonymous online report alleging impropriety in related party transactions. The company views the allegations as "clearly baseless" and will investigate the source. In response, Silverlake will engage Deloitte Singapore for an independent review. The company's shares fell 27% before a trading halt, and shares were last traded at S$0.635.

site_title: Taking green steps forward
summary: Singapore is taking steps towards sustainable development and climate change solutions, with the country submitting its Intended Nationally Determined Contribution to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change in April. The Second National Climate Change Study warns that if no action is taken, Singapore will face extreme weather events and rising sea levels by 2030. To address this, the Singapore Compact, a network promoting corporate social responsibility and sustainability, is expanding its membership and outreach programs, including a youth membership and a CSR award. The compact aims to accelerate the pace of change and secure a truly sustainable future for Singapore.

images.alt_text: When Mr Kwek first joined the Singapore Compact as president in 2012, one of his goals was to increase the level of awareness in CSR among youths in tertiary institutions so that they will be able to champion CSR and responsible business practices once they enter the workforce.

site_title: BlackRock to start financing US rental-home investors: sources
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, plans to start financing US rental-home investors, capitalizing on the country's low homeownership rate. The company will buy loans from partners offering financing to its specifications, starting next month. This move joins other companies like Cerberus Capital Management, Blackstone Group LP, and Colony Capital Inc, which are competing to finance smaller landlords and bundle loans into bonds to increase returns. The new debt may make more money available to single-family home landlords as Americans struggle to get mortgages.

site_title: Toshiba's 'tough as nails' target-setter
summary: Toshiba's former president Atsutoshi Nishida's management style, characterized by aggressive sales targets and tough leadership, has come under scrutiny following a $1.2 billion accounting scandal. An outside panel found that Nishida and his successors pushed division heads to unrealistic targets, leading to questionable accounting tactics. The panel's report described "channel stuffing," a practice where Toshiba sold high volumes of parts to contract manufacturers at a significant mark-up, boosting earnings but violating Japan's financial laws. The scandal has raised questions about Toshiba's governance structure and regulatory sanctions, with the company planning to restate its earnings and facing a probe by Japan's Securities Exchange and Surveillance Commission.

site_title: Silverlake appoints Deloitte to review allegations raised in short-seller report
summary: Silverlake Axis appointed Deloitte Singapore to review allegations raised in an anonymous short-seller report, calling them "clearly baseless and without merit". The report questioned related party transactions involving the company's founder and chairman. Silverlake disputes these allegations, citing improved financial performance, rising net profit, and increased market capitalization. The company will publish the findings of the independent review, which will provide additional comfort to shareholders.

site_title: Asia's legal framework has to be trade-ready
summary: Asia's legal framework must be harmonized to support and facilitate Asian cross-border trade and investment flows. The region's diverse legal systems, influenced by various traditions, pose significant challenges to businesses. To address this, a coordinated, ground-up approach is needed, involving the business community, legal fraternity, and regional policymakers. A proposed Asian Business Law Institute and the launch of an international conference in 2016 aim to promote convergence of Asian business laws and develop model laws and practical guidelines. Harmonization efforts will help reduce legal uncertainty, increase trade and investment flows, and unlock the region's growth potential.

site_title: Asian equities: coast is far from clear
summary: Asian equities remain volatile despite a Chinese central bank interest rate cut for the fifth time since November. Panic selling appears to have abated, but analysts warn of further selling due to a "perfect storm" of fears. A bounce in European markets and an uplift in US stock index futures followed the rate cut, but strategists advise caution. Investors should prepare for more market turbulence as a result of dollar asset diversification, trade tensions, and shifting safe havens. The coast to clear is far from it, and caution is advised.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

DBS Wealth pointed out that while major indices such as the S&P 500, Nikkei-225 and the Euro Stoxx 50 may stage a technical bounce, the selling isn't over. "Any bounce would be opportunities to take some money off the table."

site_title: Birth pains of China's 'new normal' growth grip the globe
summary: China's economy is experiencing a "new normal" of slower growth, prompting concerns about its impact on global markets. The country's stock market has plummeted 40% since mid-June, with the central bank cutting interest rates to boost economic activity. Analysts attribute the market's collapse to a crisis of confidence and lack of leadership, citing China's weak economic indicators and failed market-saving measures. The country's shift from export-driven to domestic consumer-driven growth is also causing uncertainty, with some experts warning of a potential implosion of an equity market bubble.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's IPIC mulls pulling out of 1MDB's debt plan
summary: Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Company (IPIC) may withdraw from a debt restructuring plan for 1MDB, a Malaysian state-backed firm at the center of a huge scandal. The plan aimed to cut 1MDB's debt by RM16 billion in exchange for undisclosed assets. If IPIC pulls out, it would be a significant blow to 1MDB, which is already under a global probe and facing financial pain. The move could also impact Prime Minister Najib Razak, who is embroiled in the scandal.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Tiong Woon full-year profit falls 46%
summary: Tiong Woon Corporation reported a 46% slump in its net profit for the fiscal year ended June 30, reaching S$12 million, due to a decline in business activities across all segments. Revenue fell 12% to S$145.7 million, and gross profit margin dropped to 27.8%. The company managed to reduce other operating expenses and recorded a currency translation gain. The board proposed a final dividend of 0.4 cent per share, unchanged from the previous year. Despite a challenging operating landscape, Tiong Woon aims to focus on delivering its best to customers and shareholders.

site_title: Weak demand seen for two industrial sites put up for sale by JTC
summary: Two industrial sites in Singapore, one at Tampines Industrial Drive and the other at Ubi Avenue 1, were launched for sale through public tender. Despite being strategically located near established industrial parks, consultants expect weak demand due to short 20-year tenures. The top bids for the sites were S$4.94 million and S$19.86 million, respectively, with analysts attributing muted interest to the cooling measures implemented by the government and increased supply.

site_title: Brands see 'normcore' creators as 'millennial whisperers'
summary: A group of five 20-somethings, known as K-HOLE, created an art project in 2014 that predicted the "normcore" trend, which emphasizes being purposefully normal-looking. Now, they have released a 36-page report on a new concept called "chaos magic," which they believe can create change through belief. The report, filled with colorful images and ramblings, has been sought after by corporations, including Coach and Stella Artois, who see the group as "millennial whisperers." K-HOLE's unique approach, which combines art and observation, has raised questions about the credibility of their predictions and the role of "normcore" in popular culture.

site_title: Palm oil nears bear market as Chinese demand outlook worsens
summary: Palm oil prices plummeted 0.5% to near a bear market, trading at 1,906 ringgit per metric ton, as rising supplies threaten to swell stockpiles amid concerns of China's economic slowdown curbing demand. This marks the fifth consecutive day of decline, with prices down 16% this year, heading for the fourth annual loss in five years. Analysts predict a potential surge in stockpiles to 2.49 million tons this month, and a further increase to 3 million tons by the end of November, as global supply is expected to rise by 6.6 million tons in the 2015-2016 marketing year.

site_title: Investors fleeing longer-dated sukuk
summary: Malaysia's Islamic bond market is experiencing a flight to quality as investors flee longer-dated sukuk amid accelerating inflation and a global emerging-markets selloff. The yield difference between 2025 Shariah-compliant securities and three-year debt widened to 67 basis points in August, the highest since May 2014. Foreign ownership of bonds in Malaysia fell to its lowest level since 2012, while inflation rates reached 3.3% in July, exceeding economists' predictions. Longer-dated borrowing costs are expected to rise further as the Federal Reserve prepares to raise interest rates.

site_title: Chefs for the day
summary: Hong Leong Foundation hosted a mooncake-making party for nearly 20 children from the Singapore Children's Society, teaching them how to make traditional pastries under the guidance of chef Lap Fai. The event, held at Orchard Hotel, was part of the foundation's support for the society's annual walkathon, Walk For Our Children, which it will present sponsor on September 6. This is the foundation's first such initiative, aiming to provide disadvantaged children with unique experiences and skills.

images.alt_text: Chef Lap Fai and Mr Kwek at the mooncake-making party for nearly 20 children from Singapore Children's Society.

site_title: GE2015: Approved symbols for candidates with no party symbol include whale, ceiling fan
summary: In the 2015 Singapore General Election, 15 approved symbols for candidates with no party symbol were released. The list included a whale and a ceiling fan. This move allowed independents to use these symbols in the election.

site_title: Defensive stocks safe but US bonds safer
summary: Singapore's defensive stocks, such as Unilever and Sheng Siong, remain relatively stable despite the global market crash. However, the US bond market is safer than Singaporean stocks, with the 10-year US bond yield at 2% compared to Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index decline of 15% this year. The market is considered cheap, but not at a bottom, as corporate profitability remains low. The macroeconomic environment in Asia remains tough, with China's slowing economy affecting Singaporean assets and the Singapore dollar. Investors should diversify and be cautious, waiting for signs of growth and improved corporate profitability.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian with an umbrella walks past a digital screen displaying stocks index data at the financial district in Singapore on Aug 25, 2015.

site_title: Tsipras's prize: debt relief like West Germany in 1953
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has successfully negotiated a large-scale debt relief deal, similar to West Germany's 1953 debt conference, worth €86 billion. The new bailout will extend loan repayments until 2075, with some debts not repaid until 2010. Tsipras appears to have outmaneuvered German Chancellor Angela Merkel, who also promised unrealistic goals to her electorate. The deal is seen as a victory for Tsipras, who is likely to continue as Prime Minister, and may set a precedent for other large-scale debtors worldwide.

site_title: Budget deficit may fall by US$60b as revenue jumps
summary: The US budget deficit is expected to fall by $60 billion in 2015 due to strong revenue gains, according to the Congressional Budget Office. The deficit is now estimated at $426 billion, down from a previous forecast of $486 billion. Consumer confidence rebounded in August, with a 101.5 index reading, and new home sales rose 5.4% in July, the largest gain this year. These positive economic indicators may temper demands for deeper spending cuts and weaken resistance to lifting spending caps.

site_title: Rush for ringgit eases as rate offered is not as expected
summary: The Malaysian ringgit's value against the Singapore dollar has eased, with money changers offering rates of 2.95-2.97, down from earlier expectations of lower rates. Many people have turned away without buying, and smaller transactions are being made, as the ringgit continues to fall. The value of the ringgit has slid 1.11% to 4.1960 against the US dollar, and outlet managers expect continued queries throughout the week, particularly from Malaysians receiving their end-of-month paychecks. The decline is attributed to China's recent yuan devaluation and the nation's economic woes.

site_title: UK property values are in bubble territory again: analyst
summary: UK property values are in bubble territory again, according to Mike Prew, an analyst at Jefferies Group LLC. He downgraded several UK real estate companies, citing overpayment for property outside southeast England and falling income at shopping malls. Property values are expected to fall 1.1% next year, with retail being the worst affected. The analyst also warned that proposals to limit tax exemptions on debt could hurt real estate shares, which tend to have higher debt levels.

site_title: Japan minister concerned about yen's rapid rise
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso warned of the yen's rapid rise following the US dollar's plunge to a seven-month low due to fears over China's economy and global growth. The yen rose to 119.60 yen against the US dollar, while the euro strengthened to 137.95 yen. Aso criticized China's yuan devaluation move, saying it sparked global fears and hurt Japanese exporters. The yen's rapid rise poses a threat to Japan's competitiveness and repatriated profits, with Economy Minister Akira Amari calling for a "cool-headed approach".

site_title: Promoting green practices
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is promoting sustainability within the maritime community, aligning with the international regulatory framework's shift towards a sustainable global maritime transport system. The agency has launched the Maritime Singapore Green Initiative (MSGI) and established the MPA Sustainability Office to promote good practices in governance, resource management, and environmental sustainability. MPA has also published its inaugural Sustainability and Integrated Report and introduced initiatives to enhance bunkering processes and technology, such as the use of liquefied natural gas (LNG) as a cleaner fuel.

site_title: Gold's strength may prove short-lived
summary: Gold prices have reached a seven-week high, but analysts believe this strength may be short-lived, driven by investors' anticipation of a rate hike in December rather than the coming month. Despite a recent rally, physical gold demand in the second quarter was at its weakest since 2009, and institutional investor interest remains low. Experts expect the gold price to fall further, averaging US$1,050 per ounce in the fourth quarter of 2015 and US$1,000 per ounce in 2016.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound from global rout
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded on Tuesday from the "Black Monday" rout, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 3.09%, the CAC 40 in Paris jumping 4.14%, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 gaining 4.97%. The rebound followed China's central bank announcement of new measures to stimulate its slowing economy.

site_title: A month that hedge funds would sooner forget
summary: A sudden and rapid selloff across global markets began late last week, catching many hedge fund managers off guard, with losses exceeding 3-7% in August. The decline was attributed to economic woes in China and looming rate increases in the US, as well as forced sales of stocks bought on credit. Hedge funds, which had gone into the selloff bullish with $1.5 trillion in long positions, were hit hard, with some funds losing up to 11% in the month. The selloff was attributed to a combination of factors, including China's stock market plunge and emerging market currency devaluation.

site_title: Emerging markets the true victims of financial turmoil
summary: Emerging markets are facing significant currency turmoil, with many currencies hitting record lows. The standard approach to measuring currency depreciation does not account for the current-account deficit and trade elasticities, leading to a misunderstanding of the market's equilibrium. In reality, exchange rates are driven by financial considerations in the short run, with small changes in fundamentals having large effects. Foreign-currency debts and financial constraints contribute to overshooting, where the exchange rate depreciates further than necessary to adjust the current account. This phenomenon is particularly relevant for emerging-market economies with large foreign-currency debts, including countries such as Brazil, India, and Mexico.

site_title: Dollar jumps 1% after China cuts interest rates
summary: The US dollar surged 1% against a basket of major currencies after China cut interest rates, with the People's Bank of China lowering its one-year benchmark bank lending rate to 4.6%. The move boosted risk appetite, lifting US stock futures and commodities. The dollar rose 1.6% to 120.23 yen, while the euro fell 1.3% to US$1.4785. The rate cut is seen as a relief rally, with economists predicting a boost to the dollar in the long term.

site_title: BHP Billiton expects China's growth to "drift down" in coming years
summary: BHP Billiton's CEO Andrew Mackenzie expects China's economic growth to slow down to around 6-7% in coming years, leading to reduced demand for commodities such as iron ore, copper, coal, and oil. This will impact BHP's steel demand forecast and volatility in commodity prices. However, a successful transition to a middle-income economy could benefit copper and oil prices. China's growing focus on services and consumption-based economy may lead to substitution of copper with aluminum, posing a threat to copper production.

site_title: PAP MPs putting final touches on GE preparations, say they are ready to go
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) MPs in Singapore are ready for the upcoming general election, set to take place on September 11, despite the surprise announcement of a weekday Polling Day. The party's incumbent MPs expressed confidence, unfazed by the unexpected date. The election has rarely occurred on a Friday, with most expecting it to be on September 12. The PAP is now putting the final touches on their preparations for the election.

site_title: Daimler still confident about China
summary: Daimler AG, the owner of Mercedes-Benz, remains confident about investing in China despite its biggest stock-market rout since 2007. Hubertus Troska, head of Daimler China, stated he is still positive about the company's sales projections for China, aiming to sell over 300,000 units this year. This confidence is driven by China's expected growth in car demand.

site_title: Haitong, GF, Huatai face China probe for client rules violation
summary: China's market regulator is investigating three of its largest brokerages, Haitong Securities Co, GF Securities Co, and Huatai Securities Co, for suspected rule violations. The China Securities Regulatory Commission is probing the firms for failing to review and verify client identities and for non-compliance with "know-your-client" requirements. The firms have stated they will cooperate with the regulator and fulfill any obligations. Haitong was previously suspended from adding margin-finance accounts for three months due to similar issues. The investigation is ongoing, but the companies' businesses remain under normal operations.

site_title: Saying no to deforestation
summary: Wilmar International, a Singapore-based agribusiness group, has been a proponent of sustainability in the palm oil industry. The company has achieved RSPO certification and unveiled a "No Deforestation, No Peat and No Exploitation" policy in 2013, which aims to protect forests, peatlands, and human rights. The policy has led to a surge in sustainability pledges from businesses covering over 85% of the palm oil trade, and Wilmar aims to extend it to other product sectors and commodities.

site_title: Polling Day on Sept 11
summary: Singapore will hold its general election on September 11, with Nomination Day set for September 1, where all 89 seats in 29 constituencies are likely to be contested. The election date was confirmed by President Tony Tan Keng Yam after Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong dissolved the 12th Parliament.

site_title: No basis for continued yuan depreciation: Premier Li
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang stated that there is no basis for continued yuan depreciation, saying the currency can maintain a "reasonable and balanced level." This comes as the country's economic fundamentals have not changed, and the government can achieve its main economic targets for the year. The yuan's devaluation on August 11 was described by the central bank as a free-market reform, but some saw it as the start of a long-term depreciation to spur exports.

site_title: SDP unveils first two candidates for GE
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) has announced its first two candidates for the upcoming General Election (GE): Chong Wai Fung, 45, administrator of Ren Ci Nursing Home (Moulmein), and Khung Wai Yeen, 34, an accounts manager. Both candidates joined the SDP in 2011 and will contest in various constituencies, including Holland-Bukit Timah and Marsiling-Yew Tee group representation constituencies, and Bukit Panjang and Bukit Batok single-member constituencies. SDP party chief Chee Soon Juan highlighted the party's readiness for the election, citing concerns over the timing of the GE, which coincides with Singapore's Golden Jubilee celebrations.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended higher on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 31.8 points to 1,563.94. A total of 2.78 billion lots, valued at RM2.76 billion, were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 487 to 381.

site_title: Tritech unit to receive 120m yuan of capital injection from Chinese firm
summary: Tritech Group Limited has entered into an investment framework agreement with Chinese firm Zhong Xu Kang Yi to inject 120 million yuan (S$26.14 million) in cash as paid-up capital of its wholly-owned unit Tritech Vavie Health Care Technologies Co Ltd. In exchange, Zhong Xu Kang Yi will acquire a 60% stake in Tritech Vavie. The deal aims to leverage the financial strength of Zhong Xu Kang Yi to expand into the Chinese market and further develop Tritech Vavie's water dispenser and bottled drinking water business.

site_title: US new home sales rebound in July, supply improves
summary: US single-family home sales rose 5.4% in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 507,000 units, beating economists' expectations. This marks a rebound from the previous month's sales pace of 481,000 units. The housing market is gaining strength, driven by a tightening labor market and solid job growth, which is boosting confidence among Americans and encouraging young adults to move out. However, supply remains constrained by a persistent shortage of homes available for sale, with the stock of new houses for sale increasing 1.9% to 218,000 units.

site_title: Tiong Woon full-year net profit slumps 46%
summary: Tiong Woon Corporation Holding reported a 46% slump in its net profit for the fiscal year ended June 30 to S$12 million due to declining revenue and margins. Revenue fell 12% to S$145.7 million, and gross profit margin dropped to 27.8%. Despite challenges, the company remained profitable and is committed to delivering its best to customers and shareholders, with a proposed dividend of 0.4 cents per share.

site_title: SDP announces first two candidates for the Singapore general election
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) announced its first two candidates for the upcoming general election: Chong Wai Fung and Khung Wai Yeen. The party's secretary general, Chee Soon Juan, introduced the candidates, stating they will provide different views for policies and push for better life for Singaporeans.
