site_title: Norway's oil investment forecasts cut, further drop expected
summary: Norway's oil investment forecasts have been cut, with investments in the continental shelf expected to be around 20% lower in 2016 than in 2014. The downward revision is mainly due to lower estimates for exploration, and economists predict further scaling back of ambitions as oil prices continue to fall. The cutbacks have led to cost cuts, layoffs, and a 10-year high of Norwegian unemployment, with economists expecting sharp downward adjustments to investments in the coming years.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Thai Beverage's share price fell due to concerns over the Thai tourism industry after a recent explosion. However, the company's long-term growth remains intact, driven by its defensive alcohol portfolio. In contrast, Wilmar International is overvalued and at risk due to its intense capex programme, severe overcapacity, and volatile trading gains. GSS Energy has taken a S$33 million writedown on its investment in Cepu Sakti Energy but remains debt-free, with execution risks being the key concern.

site_title: US: Stocks rally after 5 straight losses on China woes
summary: US stocks surged in opening trade on Tuesday, ending a five-day losing streak, as investors regained confidence following a rally in European equities. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 301.98 points (1.90%) to 16,173.33, while the S&P 500 gained 38.58 points (2.04%) to 1,931.79. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 108.71 points (2.40%) to 4,634.95, with Apple, JPMorgan Chase, and Procter & Gamble leading the gains. The rally is seen as a response to the recent plunge in China's stock market.

site_title: German exports drives Q2 growth: data
summary: German exports drove the country's economy to grow 0.4% in the second quarter of 2015, up from 0.3% in the first quarter, according to official data. Exports rose 2.2% quarter-on-quarter, contributing 0.7 percentage points to growth, while domestic demand decreased slightly, knocking off 0.3 percentage points from the overall growth rate.

site_title: BI lowers Indonesia GDP forecast for 2015 and 2016
summary: Bank Indonesia lowered its GDP forecast for 2015 and 2016, predicting 4.7-5.1% growth this year and 5.3-5.7% growth next year, down from previous estimates. The country's economy expanded 4.67% in the second quarter, the slowest since 2009. This move follows a slowdown in Southeast Asia's largest economy.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore is set for a general election on September 11, with Nomination Day on September 1. The Jurong Region MRT Line may be extended to improve connectivity. The Baby Bonus cash gift for families with babies born on or after January 1, 2015, has been increased to S$2,000. JTC Corporation has launched two industrial sites for sale by public tender. The Singapore market rallied 1.5% on Tuesday, ending a week of declines, and the STI is expected to target 1,150 by mid-2026.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans will go to the polls on September 11, with Nomination Day taking place ten days earlier on September 1.

site_title: Taiwan to tap US$15.3b stocks stabilisation fund
summary: Taiwan has approved a US$15.3 billion fund to stabilize its stock market, which plummeted 7.49% on Monday due to China's economic slowdown and weak global demand. The National Financial Stabilisation Fund will be used to mitigate market volatility, with Executive Secretary Wu Tang-chieh deciding on investments. Shares rebounded 3.58% on Tuesday after the announcement. Companies are also supporting the market with share buybacks, including HTC Corp.'s plan to buy up to 6% of its outstanding shares.

site_title: Commodities recover ground after China-led rout
summary: Commodities prices rebounded in Asia, with crude oil trading at US$38.92 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude at US$43.31 a barrel, following a global sell-off sparked by China's faltering economy. This marks the first time US$40 has been breached since February 2009. Despite the recovery, prices remain under pressure.

site_title: Update: China cuts interest rates by 0.25 percentage points
summary: China's central bank cut benchmark interest rates and reserve requirement ratio by 0.25 percentage points each, aiming to boost the world's second-largest economy. The moves follow similar cuts in June and are aimed at supporting the real economy. The lending rate was cut to 4.60 percent and the deposit rate to 1.75 percent. China's GDP growth rate remains under pressure, and the cuts are seen as a necessary step to support the real economy and boost economic activity.

images.alt_text: China's central bank on Tuesday cut its benchmark interest rates and the amount of cash banks must keep on hand, the latest stimulus aimed at boosting the world's second-largest economy as it battles a collapse in share prices.

site_title: Elections Department releases list of 9 Nomination Centres, election deposit set at $14,500
summary: The Elections Department of Singapore has released a list of 9 Nomination Centres for the upcoming general election. Candidates will file their nomination papers on September 1. The election deposit has been set at SGD 14,500. The Singapore General Election is scheduled to take place, but the article does not provide further details.

images.alt_text: Candidates contesting in the 16 group representation constituencies (GRCs) and 13 single-member constituencies (SMCs) will file their nomination papers on Sept 1.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound despite new China losses
summary: European stocks rebounded on Tuesday, reversing heavy losses from "Black Monday" as London's FTSE-100 rose 1.3%, Frankfurt's XETRA up 1.74%, and Paris's CAC-40 opened 1.7% higher. Despite China's overnight sell-off, mining and healthcare shares supported European markets. The rally comes ahead of US-EU trade talks, which have sparked uncertainty.

site_title: Enough to make Mona Lisa smile: Taiwan boy falls through US$1.54 million Italian masterpiece
summary: A 12-year-old boy in Taiwan tripped and punched a hole in a $1.54 million Italian masterpiece, "Flowers" by Paolo Porpora, at an exhibit showcasing Leonardo da Vinci's artwork. The boy, influenced by the Marx Brothers, was listening to a guide and didn't notice where he was going. He and his family expressed regret and the painting was immediately repaired on site. The incident occurred after a 12-year hiatus, and the painting is now back on display.

site_title: Singapore Parliament dissolved, election to be called
summary: The Singapore government dissolved Parliament on August 25, 2015, with the Nomination Day and Polling Day of the general election to be held within three months. The new electoral boundaries were released on July 24, 2015.

site_title: Creative posts net loss of US$2.66m in Q4
summary: Creative Technology recorded a net loss of US$2.66 million in Q4, down 22% from last year, and a full-year net loss of US$33.39 million, up 53% from 2014. Revenue declined 8% to US$21.16 million in Q4 and 14% to US$99.48 million for the full year. Loss per share was 4 cents in Q4 and 47 cents for the full year, up from 5 cents and 31 cents respectively.

site_title: Singapore: Shares up 1.5%; weakness could persist
summary: The Singapore market surged 1.5% on Tuesday, ending a week of daily declines. The Straits Times Index rose 42.9 points to 2,886.29, driven by gains in banks and energy counters. However, analysts caution that the rebound may be technical, and weakness could persist. The most actively traded stock, Noble, jumped 13.4% on 131.6 million shares. The rally came ahead of GDP data, with gainers outnumbering losers 326 to 177.

site_title: Nomination Day set for Sept 1, Polling Day on Sept 11 for Singapore's general election
summary: Singaporeans will vote on September 11, with Nomination Day on September 1. The Writ of Election was issued by President Tony Tan, dissolving the 12th Parliament. Approximately 2.46 million citizens are eligible to vote, higher than the 2.35 million who voted in the 2011 election. Nine schools will serve as nomination centres. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged support for his team, stating the election is about Singapore's future.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks tumble almost 4% as Hong Kong, Shanghai slump
summary: Tokyo's benchmark index plummeted nearly 4% on Tuesday, hitting a six-month low, amid concerns over China's growth. Hong Kong and Shanghai also experienced significant losses, erasing morning gains. This is the sixth-straight losing session for Tokyo's Nikkei 225, with the lowest finish since mid-February. The decline was driven by worries over China's economic slowdown, impacting investor sentiment and global stock markets.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks end up 3.6% on hopes of govt fund buying
summary: Taiwan's main index closed 3.6% higher at 7,675.64 points on Tuesday, rebounding from a near three-year low on Monday. The government's National Security Fund, led by Vice Finance Minister Wu Tang-chieh, is expected to buy shares to shore up market confidence. Techs and banks jumped more than 3% in the session, with no details provided on the fund's plans. The rebound is seen as a response to the government's reassurance, despite ongoing market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Taiwan stocks rebounded from steep losses in the prior session on hopes the government would soon step in to shore up market confidence after the key index plunged to a near three-year low on Monday.

site_title: CK Hutchison H1 profit at HK$14.46b, meets forecasts
summary: CK Hutchison Holdings reported a first-half profit of HK$14.46 billion, meeting forecasts. The result was driven by solid growth in its retail and European telecom units, despite a weak euro and a fall in oil prices affecting its energy assets. The company created a new entity in February, segregating its property assets and increasing its exposure in overseas markets. A joint venture with Vimpelcom to combine their Italian mobile operations was also announced earlier this month.

images.alt_text: Li Ka-shing's CK Hutchison Holdings said on Tuesday total profit attributable to shareholders was HK$14.46 billion (S$2.61 billion) in the first half, as growth in its retail and European telecom units was partly offset by a weak euro.

site_title: Australia: Shares stage solid recovery
summary: Australia's shares rebounded 2.7% on Tuesday, recovering more than half of Monday's 4.1% drop, the largest decline in over six years. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 5,137.3, driven by investors buying beaten-down bank stocks. Early in the session, the benchmark briefly dipped below 5,000 for the first time in two years.

site_title: Hong Kong: Key share index snaps 7-day losing streak
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 0.7% on Tuesday, breaking a 7-day losing streak, as investor sentiment improved. However, the China Enterprises Index fell 0.9% for the 8th straight day due to panic-selling in mainland markets. The Hang Seng index closed at 21,404.96, while the China Enterprises Index ended at 9,514.04 points. The recovery in some regional markets contributed to the improvement in investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended barely changed on Thursday, as most Asian markets stabilised after jitters over Turkey's downing of a Russian fighter jet abated.

site_title: Jurong Region MRT Line might be extended: Lui Tuck Yew
summary: Minister for Transport Lui Tuck Yew announced the possibility of extending the Jurong Region MRT Line to connect it to the Circle Line, improving rail connectivity between western Singapore and the city centre. The West Coast extension, including stations in the West Coast and Pasir Panjang area, is expected to be completed around 2030, supporting future developments in the west and enhancing the overall resilience of the MRT network.

site_title: Billionaire 'very worried' about China's fallout on global shipping markets
summary: Billionaire John Fredriksen expresses concern over the impact of China's economic turmoil on global shipping markets. Since China's yuan devaluation, over $5 trillion has been erased from global stocks, causing commodity prices to sink and emerging market currencies to weaken. Fredriksen, who owns assets in oil drilling and fishing, believes the decline in crude prices will negatively affect oil rig demand, leading to a "mega consolidation" in the industry within the next year. His company, Frontline Ltd, fell 15% in Oslo trading.

site_title: Seoul: Shares snap 6-day losing streak, won up as border dispute ends
summary: South Korean shares snapped a six-day losing streak, rebounding 0.9% to 1,846.63 points after a military standoff with North Korea ended. The won rose 0.3% to 1,195.3 against the dollar. Foreigners continued to sell shares, marking a 14th consecutive session, with a net loss of 3.19 trillion won.

site_title: Malaysia plans special committee to spur growth amid market rout
summary: Malaysia plans to establish a special economic committee to boost investor confidence amid a market rout. The move comes as the country faces a sharp fall in commodity prices, hurting government revenue and foreign funds dumping over $3 billion of the nation's shares this year. Prime Minister Najib Razak stated that the country remains committed to market-friendly policies and has a strong financial system resilience. The committee's details have not been provided, but Najib emphasized that Malaysia's economic growth momentum will continue, despite the current economic challenges.

images.alt_text: Palm oil slumped for a fifth day to trade near a bear market as rising supplies threatened to swell stockpiles amid concerns that China's economic slowdown will curb demand for raw materials.

site_title: Indonesia stock exchange caps daily share price declines at 10%
summary: Indonesia's stock exchange has capped daily share price declines at 10% in an effort to cushion the impact of global market volatility. The move comes as Indonesia's stock index is the worst performer in Southeast Asia, having lost about 20% this year. The stock index rose 3.3% after the government announced plans to spend at least $1 billion to buy back shares from state-owned enterprises. The debt and risk management office also plans to spend at least $3 trillion on buybacks to support the sovereign bond market.

site_title: DSM cutting 1,000 jobs, expects 125m-150m euros in savings
summary: DSM, a Dutch pharmaceutical and food supplement maker, is reorganizing operations to cut costs after recent joint ventures. The company will cut around 1,000 jobs, resulting in one-time charges of 150-175 million euros, and annual savings of 125-150 million euros by 2017. These cost-cutting measures follow the company's recent deals, including a manufacturing deal for a multiple sclerosis drug and a joint venture for high-performance plastics.

site_title: Malaysian sukuk curve steepens as inflation adds to outflow risk
summary: Malaysia's Islamic bond market is experiencing a significant outflow due to accelerating inflation and a global emerging-markets selloff. The yield curve for sukuk has steepened, with the difference between 10-year and three-year securities widening to 67 basis points in August. Foreign investors have cut their holdings of Malaysian sovereign and corporate notes, contributing to the rise in yields. The country's central bank has kept its benchmark policy rate at 3.25% for the past year, and a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve is expected to further increase borrowing costs.

site_title: China policies stirring concerns in markets: Aso
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso criticized China's recent market intervention, saying it goes against common sense for a nation aiming to have an international currency. China's devaluation of its currency two weeks ago accelerated a global sell-off, causing the yen to surge the most since 1998. The yen's jump may counter Japan's efforts to revive its economy, which has been stagnant for two decades. Aso stated that officials from the Group of Seven and G-20 are keeping in contact but haven't made a joint response to China's moves.

site_title: JTC launches two industrial sites for sale by public tender
summary: JTC Corporation has launched two industrial sites for sale by public tender in Singapore. The sites, located at Tampines Industrial Drive and Tanjong Penjuru, are zoned for Business-2 development and have 20-year tenures. The tenders for both sites close on October 20, 2015. The government aims to offer more choices for industrial development with this launch.

site_title: Singapore's public service to implement enhanced paternity leave scheme
summary: Singapore's public service will implement an enhanced paternity leave scheme, allowing male officers to take up to two weeks of leave after the birth of a child born on or after January 1, 2015. This is part of the government's efforts to strengthen the family-friendly environment in Singapore, recognizing the father's role in caring for and raising children. The paternity leave can be taken within 12 months of the child's birth.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Singapore's public service will take the lead in implementing the enhanced paternity leave scheme announced by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at the National Day Rally on Sunday.

site_title: Global economy not at risk of recession despite China weakness: Goldman
summary: Goldman Sachs stated that the global economy is not at risk of a recession despite concerns over China's economy and weak commodity prices. The bank lowered its short-term outlook for global stock markets to "neutral" but remains "overweight" for the long-term. Analysts attributed the drop in commodity prices to excess supply, not weak demand. Goldman Sachs also adjusted its outlook for US and European equities, setting a neutral short-term outlook for US equities and lowering European equities to neutral.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up 2% on government support moves
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 2.4% on Tuesday, rebounding from a 7% drop the previous day, as the central bank lowered the interbank rate for the sixth time and officials hinted at a large government fund buying local equities. This support helped the TAIEX index reach 7,588.17 points. The Taiwan dollar also strengthened to T$0.216 to T$32.744 per US dollar, despite a brief six-year low. The rally comes as investors seek to offset concerns about slowing growth in China.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 22 points to 1,509.720. Losers outnumbered gainers 452 to 43, with 187.5 million lots traded worth RM94.09 million.

site_title: Malaysian 10-year bond yield rises to highest level since 2008
summary: Malaysia's 10-year government bond yield rose to its highest level since 2008, reaching 4.45% as the weak ringgit, low oil prices, and a political scandal eroded demand for government bonds. The yield has increased 18 basis points in a four-day streak and is up 38 points this month. The decline in the ringgit, which has fallen 18% this year, and a rout in global stock markets have contributed to the surge in yields. Analysts expect the yield to continue rising, with some predicting it may reach 4.5% or higher.

site_title: Singapore STI swings back into positive territory, up 2.82%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,923.62, up 2.82% or 80.23 points, after starting 1% lower. The STI plummeted 4.3% on Monday, its largest drop since the 2008 global financial crisis. The rally comes after a 5-day streak of gains, ahead of GDP data release. Gainers beat losers 264 to 140, with 642 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Update: Asian shares bounce off 3-year lows while China's suffering goes on
summary: Asian shares bounced off three-year lows on Tuesday, with the MSCI's Asia-Pacific index rising 1.7% after a brief dip. This followed a 5% drop in Chinese shares, which fell another 5% despite a 15% decline in the past three days. The US stock market also showed signs of recovery, with futures gaining 2.0% in Asia. However, concerns over China's economy and the US Federal Reserve's interest rate plans continue to weigh on markets, with the S&P 500 Index falling to a 10-month low on Monday.

site_title: Baby Bonus cash gift increased by S$2,000; Medisave Grant for Newborns up by S$1,000
summary: Singapore has increased the Baby Bonus cash gift for families with babies born on or after January 1, 2015, to S$2,000, on top of the existing S$6,000 for the first and second children, and S$8,000 for the third and fourth children. The enhanced gift will be disbursed between 12th and 18th months after birth. The Medisave Grant for Newborns has also been increased by S$1,000 to S$4,000. Minister Grace Fu announced the changes to support larger families and foster a more family-friendly environment in Singapore.

site_title: Asian shares fall as panic grips world markets
summary: Asian shares plummeted Tuesday, following a 6.41% decline in Chinese stocks, as investors feared the world economy was weakening. The Shanghai market's sharp drop sparked a global equities rout, with US and European markets also falling. The dollar weakened against other currencies, and oil prices remained low, wiping off over $5 trillion in global equity value since China's yuan devaluation on August 11. The sell-off has raised concerns about the outlook for the world economy and prompted calls for more intervention from Beijing to support its free-falling markets.

images.alt_text: Asian shares tumbled Tuesday after a meltdown in Chinese stocks sparked a global equities rout and fuelled mounting fears over the outlook for the world economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares down 2.6% in early trade
summary: Tokyo shares plummeted 2.6% in early trade on August 25, 2015, amid global sell-offs due to concerns over China's economy. The Nikkei-225 index fell 484.25 points to 18,056.43, marking its lowest finish in six months. This follows a 4.61% slump on Monday.

images.alt_text: Tokyo shares opened 2.61 per cent lower on Tuesday amid a global sell-off triggered by worries over the state of the Chinese economy.

site_title: Australia: Shares open 1.41% lower
summary: Australian stocks opened 1.41% lower on Tuesday, amid growing concerns over China's economy slowdown. The benchmark S&P/ASX200 index fell 70.4 points to 4,930.9, despite a better-than-expected performance. This follows a 4.09% drop on Monday.

site_title: Yuan opens firmer after higher official fix, rebounds from lows
summary: China's yuan strengthened at the open on Tuesday, closing at its weakest level since 2011 the previous day. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.3987 per dollar, firmer than the previous day's close. The offshore yuan traded 1.06% higher than the onshore spot rate at 6.479 per dollar. The stronger yuan may ease pressure on policymakers as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, according to recent reports.

site_title: Apple limits losses as tech clobbered in market rout
summary: Apple's stock price plummeted 2.5% on Monday due to concerns about China's economy, but then rebounded after a rare public reassurance by CEO Tim Cook. The tech sector was battered by fears of an economic slowdown in China, resulting in a tumultuous day for global markets. Apple's market value saw billions of dollars in worth come and go, ultimately ending the formal trading day at $103.12.

site_title: PBOC injects US$23.4b as yuan intervention drains funds
summary: China's central bank injected US$23.4 billion into the financial system through open-market operations to prop up the yuan, the most funds added since January 2014. The move comes as currency-market intervention strains the supply of cash and major banks sell dollars on most days. The injection removes funds from the financial system, risking higher borrowing costs unless additional cash is released. China's foreign-exchange reserves are expected to drop by US$40 billion a month for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: China's central bank added the most funds to the financial system in open-market operations since Jan 2014 as currency-market intervention to prop up the yuan strained the supply of cash.

site_title: China: Stocks tumble more than 6% at open
summary: China's major stock indexes plummeted more than 6% on Tuesday, with the CSI300 index falling 6.3% and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 6.4%. The decline was exacerbated by a lack of impact from the central bank's 150 billion yuan injection, which was seen as a short-term measure. The sell-off has left benchmark indexes entering negative territory for the year, amid growing concerns about China's economic growth and the effectiveness of the government's efforts to stabilize the market.

site_title: Gold holds below 7-week high as dollar, equities recover
summary: Gold prices hovered below a seven-week high on Tuesday as the US dollar and equities rebounded from a selloff fueled by concerns over the Chinese economy. The dollar rose 0.6% versus a basket of currencies, and spot gold was flat at $1,154.60 an ounce. A near-9% dive in China shares boosted investor appetite for safe-haven assets, but a key Federal Reserve official stuck to his view that a US interest rate hike would happen this year, potentially limiting gold's upside potential.

images.alt_text: Gold hovered below a seven-week high on Tuesday as equity markets and the US dollar rebounded from a brutal selloff in the prior session that was fuelled by fears over the fate of the Chinese economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.67% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.67% in early trade on Tuesday, continuing a global market rout due to concerns over growth. The Hang Seng Index dropped 142.86 points to 21,108.71. This decline follows a broader trend in world equities markets.

site_title: Consumers using Visa online finish transactions more than PayPal
summary: Visa Inc reported that online shoppers using its payment service are 17% more likely to complete transactions than PayPal users. 66% of Visa Checkout customers completed purchases after adding items to their cart, compared to 49% of PayPal Express Checkout customers. This convenience feature, which allows users to store payment information, contributed to the higher completion rate.

images.alt_text: Visa Inc said on Monday online shoppers using its payment service are 17 per cent more likely to complete their purchases than those using PayPal.

site_title: SCDF reports decline in fire cases but more ambulance calls in H1
summary: The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) reported a 5% decline in fire cases in the first half of 2015, with 2,406 responses. However, emergency ambulance calls increased by 14,063, reaching 81,686. The majority of fires were caused by dropped lights, and SCDF saw a rise in verbal and physical abuse of its staff, with 10 reported cases in the first six months of 2015. The SCDF also conducted 8,244 fire-safety enforcement checks, an 18% increase from the previous year.

site_title: Facebook 'Spam King' guilty for sending 27 million messages
summary: A Las Vegas man, Sanford Wallace, known as the "Spam King," pleaded guilty to sending over 27 million unsolicited messages through Facebook's servers in 2008 and 2009. He gained access to about 500,000 accounts and admitted to violating a court order, causing $250,000 in fines and up to 3 years in prison. Wallace, 47, was released on bond and is scheduled for sentencing on December 7.

site_title: Stocks to watch: STI, Kingsmen Creatives, 800 Super Holdings
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.3% to close at 2,843.39 on Monday, following the Chinese stock market crash and concerns over the global economy. Kingsmen Creatives accepted an offer to acquire a 5,251 sqm land for S$7.07 million, and 800 Super Holdings posted a nearly doubled net profit to S$17.56 million, driven by revenue growth and a one-time gain from property disposal.

site_title: Philippines is regional star as gloom descends in Asia
summary: The Philippines is emerging as a regional safe haven due to its relatively low foreign investment levels, lack of raw materials, and stability under President Benigno Aquino. The country's local-currency sovereign bonds returned 2.9% over the last three months, and its peso has held up better than its peers. The Philippine economy expanded 5.7% last quarter, driven by a burgeoning business-process outsourcing industry, and has benefited from falling crude prices. The country's consumption-based economy and steady dollar inflows make it less vulnerable to global economic fluctuations.

site_title: Oil trades below US$39 after global rout as US glut seen rising
summary: Oil futures held losses near a six-year low after a global commodities selloff, as US government data forecasted an expansion of oil stockpiles for a second week. Oil prices have slumped 35% since June due to a persistent global glut, with US supplies exceeding the five-year average. Experts predict the market will continue to decline, potentially reaching December 2008 lows. Oil prices closed at $38.21 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate, down 3 cents from the previous day.

site_title: Britain's women managers "work for free" for nearly 2 hours a day
summary: Britain's female managers work for nearly 2 hours a day without pay, with women earning 22% less than men, equivalent to an unpaid 1 hour 40 minutes daily. The gender pay gap in Britain now stands at over 8,500 pounds, with women making up 67% of the workforce in entry-level roles but only 43% of senior managers. The gap persists despite Prime Minister David Cameron's vow to end it in a generation, with many employers preferring not to know the extent of the issue.

site_title: Asia's richest person lost US$3.6b as market rout deepens
summary: Asia's richest person, Wang Jianlin, lost US$3.6 billion due to a market rout, particularly in China's stock markets, which saw their biggest decline since 2007. His stake in Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties Co plummeted 17% and Wanda Cinema Line Co fell 10% on Monday, resulting in a loss of nearly $1 billion. Wang's fortune is now valued at US$31.2 billion.

site_title: Auckland house prices keep central bank awake at night, says official
summary: New Zealand's central bank is concerned about Auckland's rapidly rising house prices, which surged 21% in the past year due to a housing shortage and record immigration. Deputy Governor Grant Spencer says the current weakness in the economy and low inflation mean interest-rate increases are unlikely for now. To address the issue, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) will cut the cash rate by 25 basis points to 2.75% and introduce stricter regulations, including a 30% deposit requirement for Auckland property investors.

site_title: Boeing eyes 'several hundred' layoffs in satellite division
summary: Boeing is expected to cut up to "several hundred" jobs in its satellite division due to a downturn in US military spending and delays in commercial satellite orders. The company cited uncertainty about the future availability of financing from the US Export-Import Bank, whose government charter lapsed on June 30. Boeing officials said the reductions are necessary to remain competitive and that some affected employees could find work in other parts of the company. The move comes as the US government and business executives debate the future of the EXIM bank, which can no longer write new loans and trade guarantees.

site_title: US Air-Traffic Towers wasted more than US$850m
summary: The US federal government has wasted over $850 million over six years due to inefficient air-traffic control towers, according to a watchdog audit. The Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) facilities at airports vary widely in efficiency, with larger hubs accounting for most of the wasted costs. The most efficient airports include LaGuardia and Newark Liberty International, while poor-performing ones are in Orlando and Salt Lake City. A proposed nonprofit corporation to manage the FAA's air-traffic system may be created to address the issue.

site_title: Asia wakes to US meltdown as futures mixed on what comes next
summary: Asian markets are bracing for further losses as the global selloff continues, with the S&P 500 Index entering a correction. US stock-index futures rose, but Asian markets are skeptical, with futures on Japanese stocks mixed and those tracking Chinese indexes signaling another slump. The risk-off vibe persists, with currency markets and commodity futures also declining. The US stock market experienced a violent session on Monday, with the Dow Average losing 588 points, or 3.6%, as concerns over China's slowdown and oil demand continue to weigh on markets.

site_title: Japan says yen rises "rough," undesirable for economy
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso stated that the yen's recent spike against the dollar is "rough" and undesirable for the economy, as it may damage Japan's weak exports. The yen reached a seven-month high against the dollar due to investor concerns about China's slowdown, seeking the Japanese currency as a safe haven. This sharp rise poses a concern for Japanese policymakers, who worry about its impact on the country's economy. Aso emphasized the need for gradual and steady economic growth rather than sudden, rough movements.

site_title: Swiss law aims to return foreign funds stashed by erstwhile leaders
summary: Switzerland plans to adopt a new law by the end of the year to return illicit funds stashed by former leaders, with the goal of speeding restitution for thousands of "politically exposed persons" holding bank accounts. The law aims to return $40 million to Tunisia and $60 million to Egypt, despite a slowdown in cooperation due to the killing of Egypt's general prosecutor. The law will be the most comprehensive worldwide, following Switzerland's return of $1.8 billion in stolen funds over the past 25 years.

site_title: Fed's Lockhart sees rate hike sometime this year
summary: US Federal Reserve President Dennis Lockhart has tempered expectations for a September interest rate hike, saying the Fed will likely begin raising rates "sometime this year." Lockhart cited recent market turmoil, a strengthening dollar, and a drop in oil prices as complicating factors. Despite this, he reiterated his bank's baseline forecast of moderate economic growth and gradual inflation, and expects interest rates to normalize gradually.

site_title: Artist Sarah Sze's installation based on precise randomness
summary: Artist Sarah Sze is preparing for her first solo gallery show in the US in five years at the Tanya Bonakdar Gallery in New York. For Sze, the installation is an integral part of her creative process, involving the precise placement of dried paint strips. The exhibition is set to open on September 10.

site_title: Singapore shares open 1% lower after markets tumble globally on China fears
summary: Singapore shares opened 1.01% lower, or 28.62 points, at 2,814.77, following a global market slump triggered by concerns over China's economy. The Straits Times Index fell 4.3% on Monday, its largest drop since the 2008 global financial crisis. Other Asian bourses also declined, with Japan's Nikkei 225 down 3.7% and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 down 1%. The decline was partly due to China's Shanghai Composite dropping 8.5% on Monday, its worst day since 2007, and US stocks finishing sharply lower.

images.alt_text: A man passes a stock index board showing the Straits Times Index falling 4.3 percent at the Singapore Exchange in the central business district on Aug 24, 2015.

site_title: Asian central banks ready to act against market volatility
summary: Asian central banks are prepared to intervene in market volatility, with the RBI chief signaling support for the rupee and Seoul officials discussing measures to calm markets. The selling pressure is largely attributed to China's slowdown and its recent exchange rate regime change, triggering a yuan loss of two decades. Market downturns have occurred across Asia, with China's share prices falling the most since 2007. Policymakers are under pressure to address the economic slowdown, with the MSCI's global equity index expected to reach 1,150 by mid-2026.

site_title: Global markets selloff deepens on China worries
summary: Global stock markets experienced a significant selloff on August 24, 2015, with China's Shanghai index plummeting 8.49% and other major markets declining by 4% or more. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 3.58% and the S&P 500 lost 3.94% as investors grew concerned about China's economic downturn. Volatility was not limited to equities, with oil prices falling below $40 a barrel and industrial metals reaching six-year lows. Analysts predict volatile trading in the coming weeks as investors await signs of an economic cycle turn.

images.alt_text: A view of a board on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange showing the Dow Jones Industrial average at the end of the trading day in New York, on Aug 24, 2015.

site_title: Unlike 1997, Asian economies are expected to bend, not break
summary: Asian economies are expected to withstand global market turmoil, unlike 18 years ago, due to stronger economic fundamentals and the absence of currency pegs. Unlike the 1997 crisis, Asian economies have addressed regulatory oversight lapses and are better equipped to handle shocks. However, a significant slowdown in China's growth could still pose a threat, particularly for countries dependent on Chinese demand for commodities.

site_title: US: Wall St has worst day in four years, S&P now in correction
summary: US stock indexes plummeted 4% on Monday, marking the S&P 500's worst day in four years and confirming it's in a correction. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.57%, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 3.82%. The sell-off was fueled by concerns over China's economy, with the yuan's devaluation sparking a global market downturn. Apple's stock dropped 2.5% despite CEO Tim Cook's reassurances, and oil prices fell 6% to 6-1/2-year lows.

images.alt_text: A view of a board on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange showing the Dow Jones Industrial average at the end of the trading day in New York, on Aug 24, 2015

site_title: Putin seeks to seal China gas deal during September visit
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is set to visit China in September to finalize a natural gas supply contract, but Beijing has dampened hopes of a deal. Despite positive talks between Gazprom and China, the Chinese government has expressed concerns over the economic slowdown. The visit marks a crucial test for Russia's energy pivot towards Asia amidst slumping oil prices.

site_title: China selloff sparks global bloodletting
summary: China's economic selloff led to a global market downturn, with diminished expectations of US interest rate hikes in September, bearish views on Asian currencies and commodities, and a bearish outlook on regional equities. This destruction in risk markets is on par with the global financial crisis seven years ago. The Singapore stock market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while other markets, such as Europe and the US, also saw positive trends despite ongoing trade uncertainty and tariff issues.

images.alt_text: The runaway Chinese train ploughed through a broad swathe of risk markets on Monday to wreak a destruction scale not seen since the global financial crisis seven years ago.

site_title: Syriza secretary quits; eurosceptic rebels try to form government
summary: Greece's ruling Syriza party suffered another blow when its secretary, Tasos Koronakis, quit in protest of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's decision to call early elections, despite an earlier proposal to hold a party congress to address a rebel faction. The move comes as eurosceptic rebels are given a mandate to try to form a government, further weakening the embattled party.

site_title: MND releases details on Proximity Housing Grant and other changes
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) in Singapore has announced several changes to housing policies, effective August 24, 2015. The Proximity Housing Grant (PHG) will be introduced, providing up to S$20,000 for eligible Singaporeans to buy a resale flat with or near their parents or married child. The income ceilings for new HDB flats and executive condominiums will also be raised. Additionally, the Special CPF Housing Grant (SHG) will be doubled to S$40,000, and the Fresh Start Housing Scheme is being studied for implementation.

site_title: Train heroes given highest French bravery honour
summary: President Francois Hollande awarded France's highest bravery honour to Americans and a Briton who overpowered a Moroccan gunman on a train in Brussels. The gunman, 25-year-old Ayoub El Khazzani, was armed with a rifle and pistols. The heroes, whose names were not released, displayed "courage and cool composure" in overpowering El Khazzani, who was questioning by anti-terror investigators. Hollande praised the group's actions, saying the whole world "admires their courage".

site_title: Making immigration the Trump card
summary: US presidential frontrunner Donald Trump has capitalized on attacks on illegal immigrants, gaining popularity. A key fact is that birthright citizenship, allowing children born in the US to become citizens, is based on the 14th Amendment to the US Constitution. This policy would automatically grant citizenship to a child born in the US, regardless of their parents' citizenship status.

site_title: China capital opening is wealth manager 'game changer,' DBS says
summary: China's capital account opening is expected to be a game-changer for wealth managers, as millions of rich Chinese gain access to global markets. DBS Group Holdings Ltd. sees this as a major opportunity, with 28 branches on the Chinese mainland and plans to expand through partnerships. China has 4 million millionaire households, more than any country except the US, and recent moves to allow overseas use of the yuan are signals that wealth managers need to prepare. DBS is studying ways to expand in China and may consider further acquisitions to tap into the market.

site_title: Oil tumbles up to 6% to new lows as China fears intensify rout
summary: Oil prices plummeted 6% to new 6-1/2-year lows, falling to $42.69 a barrel, as China's economic fears intensified global markets. A near 9% decline in Chinese shares sent the Dow Jones down over 1,000 points, with oil's slide temporarily easing before resuming. The decline is attributed to China's economic outlook, rather than fundamental oil market factors, with fears of a hard landing and loss of control.

site_title: Japan bond traders warn of Fed rate misstep
summary: Japan's bond traders warn that the Federal Reserve's planned interest rate hike may be premature, potentially choking off what little inflation is left in the US economy. Deflation, not inflation, is the risk, and the Fed may need to reverse course if it raises rates in September or December. As a result, investors are loading up on longest-maturity Treasuries, which tend to perform well in down economies. The bond market expects consumer prices to fall 1.45% in the next 12 months, with long-term expectations painting a bleak picture for inflation.

site_title: Which will be the next billion-dollar unicorns?
summary: CB Insights analyzed 50 startups globally, identifying potential billion-dollar unicorns, with 131 existing unicorns worth $485 billion to investors. The list includes companies from San Francisco, Silicon Valley, China, and India, with a focus on service-oriented startups and emerging tech sectors. The analysis suggests investors may become cautious if public tech stocks don't recover, but many entrepreneurs remain optimistic about the potential of being on the list, with some expressing skepticism about the merits of unicorn status.

site_title: Doubling of paternity leave: SMEs fear impact on manpower
summary: Singaporean Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) are hesitant to adopt the government's plan to double paternity leave to two weeks due to concerns over manpower and rising operational costs. The tight labour market and existing flexible HR frameworks make the benefit less appealing. The ASME chief, Kurt Wee, notes that reimbursement alone is not the primary issue, and firms must consider the overall impact on their business.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
SHRI president Erman Tan says longer paternity leave can be a good way to test the robustness of a firm's staff backup system. It is also something that society expects today.

site_title: Market turmoil threatens Fed's rate hike plans
summary: US Federal Reserve plans to raise interest rates in September appear increasingly unlikely due to turmoil in global financial markets and fears of a China-led economic slowdown. A 9% drop in Chinese shares triggered sharp sell-offs worldwide, prompting investors to scale back bets on inflation and a rate hike. Market volatility and concerns about the global economy's health make a September rate hike "insane" and reduce the chances of a hike, with Barclays now expecting a rate hike in March.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC.

site_title: Silverlake Axis Q4 buoyed by associate's IPO
summary: Silverlake Axis reported a 1% rise in net profit for Q4 to RM74.7 million, driven by an accounting gain from its associate Global InfoTech Co Ltd's IPO. Revenue slipped 8% to RM126.4 million, mainly due to software licensing and credit processing. The company's shares fell 27% following an anonymous report recommending short-selling, but trading was halted. Silverlake Axis plans to pursue business opportunities in Asia and prioritize existing software implementation projects. The company reported a 14% rise in full-year net profit to RM282.7 million.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Olam International updated its US$5 billion euro medium term note programme, with DBS Bank, HSBC's Singapore branch, and Standard Chartered Bank as arrangers. Spackman Entertainment Group entered into an engagement letter for a Hong Kong IPO, while 800 Super Holdings reported a 22% revenue growth and proposed a final dividend. Hai Leck Holdings saw a 32.5% slump in net profit, and Kingsmen Creatives accepted an offer to acquire a vacant leasehold land. CSC Holdings won an arbitration award against a third party, determining they were not entitled to liquidated damages.

site_title: The world's richest people lost another US$124 billion on Monday
summary: The world's richest people lost $124 billion on Monday as global markets slid, pushing the S&P 500 into its first correction in nearly four years. Billionaires including Bill Gates, Jeff Bezos, and Carlos Slim saw significant losses, with Gates dropping $3.2 billion and Bezos falling $2.6 billion. Chinese shares plummeted, Germany's DAX fell into a bear market, and commodities hit a 16-year low, with Brent crude reaching a low of $45 a barrel. This marks the second significant loss for the world's richest people in recent months.

site_title: World looks to China to act as circuit break for rout it started
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, is seen as a potential circuit breaker to stop a global market rout. With $5.5 trillion in reserves, it has a strong monetary policy arsenal, including a 4.85% interest rate. The US Federal Reserve's expected policy tightening is shaking global confidence, and China's ample firepower may be the only force to arrest the rout. The global economy is also facing other challenges, including slowing GDP growth in China and a shrinking UK economy.

site_title: Franklin Templeton makes big bets on Malaysian bonds
summary: Franklin Templeton, a global money manager, has been buying Malaysian bonds as other funds flee the market due to probes into Prime Minister Najib Razak's dealings. The firm's funds added RM9.64 billion to Malaysian government bonds, taking its total claim to RM23.1 billion. Despite the turmoil, Franklin Templeton's chief investment officer believes in the long-term value of the investment, citing the Malaysian economy's strength compared to the 2008 global financial crisis and the late 1990s Asian crisis.

site_title: Sydney homeowners join forces to exploit boom
summary: In Sydney, homeowners are banding together to sell their properties as a development block, exploiting the city's housing boom. By pooling their resources, they can command higher prices, with some selling for five times their individual value. This trend is driven by Sydney's acute housing shortage and booming house prices, with developers and real estate agents reaping the rewards. Experts say this approach can help address the affordability challenge by increasing supply, but warn that over-supply could lead to a housing market bubble.

images.alt_text: Record Sydney house prices worry regulators who fear the market may be entering a bubble and could potentially hurt a banking system that is heavily reliant on mortgages.

site_title: S-E Asia's dwindling reserves exacerbate risk of currency war
summary: S-E Asia's foreign-exchange holdings are dwindling, exacerbating the risk of a currency war. Malaysian reserves have fallen 19% to US$94.5 billion, and Indonesia's stockpile has shrunk 6.9% in the past five months. Central banks are struggling to stem the decline of their currencies, with Indonesia's rupiah down 12% in 2015. Policymakers are facing pressure to allow weaker exchange rates, increasing the risk of a currency war.

site_title: Yuan rebalancing signals reform urgency
summary: China is rebalancing its economy away from investment towards consumption, amid concerns over financial market volatility and policy uncertainty. The People's Bank of China has made significant interventions, including setting interest rates at a record low and depreciating the currency, sparking international criticism of Beijing's mercantilist interests. The IMF has declared it believes China's currency is not undervalued, and a decision on whether to include the yuan in the Special Drawing Right is pending, with a possible extension until September 2016.

site_title: A moveable glut looking for new bubbles
summary: A global economic glut is seeking new bubbles, sparking uncertainty among investors. Despite recent good US economic news, the world economy continues to stumble, with global crises emerging when one region recovers. The US cannot insulate itself from these global woes. Experts point to the inherent unpredictability of stock market movements and the limitations of economic forecasting. The world economy's accident-prone nature has persisted for seven years, with no clear explanation or solution in sight. Investors remain jittery, seeking new opportunities in a volatile market.

site_title: Six out of 13 S-Reits miss Citi's Q2 forecasts
summary: Citi analysts reported that six out of 13 Singapore Real Estate Investment Trusts (S-Reits) missed their Q2 forecasts, with only Mapletree Industrial Trust beating expectations. Operational weakness led to lower top-line results, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of misses. This indicates deeper concerns about the S-Reits' performance, despite sequential improvements in distributions.

site_title: Fresh face on US$10 bill? Not so fast, say Hamilton's fans
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew is planning to put a woman on the US$10 bill, but prominent women in economics and finance, including Abby Joseph Cohen and Carmen Reinhart, argue that Alexander Hamilton should not be diminished on the currency. They suggest putting a woman on the US$20 bill instead, citing Hamilton's significant contributions to American finance. The Treasury Department plans to redesign the US$10 bill in 2020 to coincide with the 100th anniversary of the passage of the 19th Amendment.

site_title: Deutsche Bank says rout 'very serious' as growth outlook dims
summary: Deutsche Bank's global head of equities, Henning Gebhardt, described the current market meltdown as "very serious" due to its impact on global growth prospects. The low oil price and weakened emerging markets are expected to trigger global earnings cuts. This adjustment is expected to be particularly significant in the second half of the year.

site_title: Franchising as a growth strategy
summary: Entrepreneurs in Singapore can expand their businesses through franchising and licensing with the help of the Franchising and Licensing Association of Singapore. This strategy can elevate brands to an international platform. However, some businesses, such as Royal Healthcare, are shutting down or relocating due to poor footfall and vacant units. Meanwhile, OCBC aims to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028.

images.alt_text: Amanda Chai

site_title: Shanghai leads slump in Asia as world equity rout deepens
summary: Asian stocks plummeted on Monday, with Shanghai falling 8.49% to its lowest point in eight years, as concerns over China's slowing economy dragged on global growth. Oil prices also tumbled, breaking below $40 a barrel for the first time since 2009. The global equity rout has lost over $5 trillion in value since China's currency devaluation on August 11. Chinese authorities have launched measures to support shares, but investors fear even Beijing's efforts may not be enough to stop the rout.

site_title: Fed credibility test looms as market doubts Sept rate rise
summary: Futures traders are betting the Federal Reserve will delay raising interest rates, with odds of a September increase decreasing to 28% from 54% in August. However, strategist Kay Van-Petersen says Janet Yellen should proceed with rate hikes to restore credibility and prepare for future economic downturns. Despite concerns over inflation, the US economy is showing readiness for higher rates, and the Fed has been holding rates at rock-bottom levels since 2008.

site_title: Singapore bond market resilient amid stockmarket rout
summary: Singapore's bond market has shown resilience amid a stock market rout, with bond prices remaining stable. The Markit iBoxx Singapore corporates total return index stood at 113.5925, just fractionally off its all-time high, while the Singapore Fixed Income Indices rose 0.18% for the week ended Aug 21. This contrasts with the Singapore equity market's 4.60% decline, its largest weekly drop since 2011. Long-term investors in SGD bonds, often private banking clients, are driving the market, with lower volatility expected during risk-aversion periods.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee says there's little panic selling as fixed income investors stay the course in the flight to quality.
Mr Gopalakrishnan says a key supporting factor is that most investors in SGD bonds are local.

site_title: Abandoned homes dot suburbs of Tokyo
summary: Japan's suburbs are plagued by abandoned homes, with nearly eight million dwellings unoccupied, a significant rise from previous years. Many of these homes have been inherited by individuals unable to sell them due to a lack of interested buyers. The government has introduced a law to promote demolition of the most dilapidated homes, but experts say the trend will continue. Demolition costs and property rights issues hinder efforts to address the issue, with some cities attempting creative solutions such as offering cash payments to outsiders who buy unoccupied homes.

site_title: Singapore an exciting market: phone maker
summary: Singapore is an exciting market for startups, particularly in the smartphone industry, according to Carl Pei, co-founder of OnePlus. The country's smartphone users are looking for unique options, making it an attractive market for innovative companies. OnePlus's first self-made smartphone, the OnePlus One, sold over 1 million units in its first year, exceeding its target. Singapore is also home to various AI-focused innovation hubs, including a new office of AI and Digital Innovation at the Singapore University of Technology and Design, and an AI hub established by Mining giant BHP, Oracle, Grab, and PwC.

site_title: Malaysian developers tout weak ringgit as key selling point
summary: Malaysian developers are marketing properties in the country as a value proposition due to the weak ringgit, which has fallen to a new 17-year low. The plunge in the ringgit has provided a lower entry cost for investors, but economists and forex strategists remain bearish on the currency. Developers face a dilemma, with higher marketing expenses in Singapore and the risk of the ringgit falling further. Some developers, such as GuocoLand and E&O Group, are seeing interest from international investors, particularly from Singapore, Hong Kong, and Cambodia.

site_title: Commercial crimes jump in H1, driving up overall crime cases
summary: Commercial crimes in Singapore increased 6.7% in the first half of 2015, driven by a 55.3% rise in online cheating cases, including e-commerce scams, credit-for-sex, and Internet love scams. The total number of crime cases rose to 16,575. Despite this, violent/serious property crimes, housebreakings, and thefts declined, with some categories improving due to public education efforts. The authorities will continue to investigate and disrupt these scams, urging the public to exercise caution when engaging in online transactions.

site_title: A healthy business based on customer satisfaction
summary: Fortuna Scientific, a Singapore-based medical equipment distributor, has achieved success by prioritizing customer satisfaction and loyalty. Founded in 2003 by Roshan Mani, the company has expanded to become a leading distributor in Singapore and Indonesia, with a strong partnership management program that prioritizes employee, customer, and supplier satisfaction. By focusing on employee welfare, providing excellent customer service, and building strong relationships with suppliers, Fortuna Scientific has gained a reputation for exceptional business practices and has won numerous awards, including the "Award for Outstanding Customer Care" from GE Healthcare.

site_title: Citic thinking of listing some of its units
summary: Citic Ltd, a Chinese conglomerate, is considering listing some of its unlisted subsidiaries, citing undervalued assets with high potential. Chairman Chang Zhenming stated that listing these businesses could be a solution, and the company may team up with other companies to attract overseas investors. Real estate assets are likely to be listed first, with no move expected until next year. Citic's net income rose 46% in the first half, driven by financial services. The move comes amid China's worsening economy and concerns about government support for the market.

site_title: American eateries devise systems to replace tipping
summary: Restaurateurs in the US are experimenting with no-tipping policies to manage rising labor costs, prompted by new minimum-wage proposals. Some, like Ivar's in Seattle, have raised prices 21% and adopted an all-inclusive menu, while others, like The Walrus and the Carpenter, have imposed a 20% service charge. However, the idea has been met with resistance from customers and servers, who worry about higher prices and potential backlash. Only a few restaurants have adopted the no-tipping model, and many industry veterans are uncertain about how to respond to the changing business model.

images.alt_text: Restaurant owners, customers and staff have long railed against the tyranny of tipping, but like a love affair gone bad, it has proved difficult to quit.

site_title: STI dives 4.3% in worst post-crisis fall
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 4.3% to 2,843.39, its worst post-crisis fall since 2008, amid uncertainty over the US Fed's interest rate decision and concerns over China's economy. The decline was driven by a mix of factors, including a sharp drop in crude oil prices, capital flight out of Asia, and fears of a global economic downturn. Analysts warn that the market may still have room to fall, and caution against making investment decisions too soon.

site_title: Rate hike tantrum will pass as 'lower for longer' still holds sway
summary: Investors are rushing into safe havens amid fears of a recession, causing a sharp decline in US 10-year yields to below 2%. However, experts believe the "lower for longer" mantra will hold, with supportive central banks keeping bond yields low. The global economic recovery remains weak, and inflation is nowhere to be found in developed markets. Despite concerns over China's slowdown and looming rate hikes, analysts see opportunities for bargain hunters in emerging markets, citing stronger fundamentals and reformist governments in key countries.

site_title: BlackGold diversifies from coal into gold
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources, a Singapore-based coal mining firm, is diversifying into gold mining by acquiring Ensbury International for an estimated US$100 million. The deal includes five mining concessions in Central Kalimantan, with one block already producing gold since 2011. BlackGold aims to increase efficiency, ore grade, and production, with plans to sell gold internationally after ramping up production. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to diversify assets and revenue streams, with Indonesian businessman Johanes Budisutrisno Kotjo set to become a shareholder.

site_title: Ringgit races pass RM3 mark against Sing dollar
summary: The Malaysian ringgit has reached a record low of RM3.0198 against the Singapore dollar, with a 12% decline in value this year. The currency's fall is attributed to a combination of factors, including a commodities slump, rising capital outflow, and political uncertainty in Malaysia. The decline has also led to a decrease in foreign reserves, which fell below the US$100 billion mark for the first time in five years. Analysts expect the currency's volatility to persist unless domestic political risks subside.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Against the greenback, the ringgit sinks to a fresh 17-year low of RM4.2538 on Monday.

site_title: Oscars in search of a new overseer
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is searching for a new producer for the Oscars, following a 15% drop in viewership for the 2015 ceremony. The search is ongoing, with several potential candidates including Reginald Hudlin, known for his work on House Party and Django Unchained, and Michael Shamberg, who has experience with youth-oriented films and digital outreach. The academy's president and executive director have examined at least a half-dozen possible producers, with a planned meeting of the governing board set for Tuesday to potentially accelerate the decision-making process.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: Singapore's Ministry of National Development (MND) released details on the Proximity Housing Grant and new housing measures, following Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's National Day Rally speech. Singapore's inflation eased to -0.4% in July, while Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and policymakers face pressure. UK economy contracted for the second month, and US trade talks with South Korea are ongoing.

site_title: Fortescue full-year earnings plunge 88% on iron ore collapse
summary: Fortescue Metals Group Ltd, led by billionaire Andrew Forrest, reported a 88% plunge in full-year profits to US$317 million due to a global iron ore price collapse. The company's net income missed analyst estimates, sending its stock to the lowest in almost seven years. Fortescue's iron ore prices have fallen due to increased production by competitors and a slowdown in China's steel industry, with prices expected to slump 30% over the next 18 months. The company plans to maintain current shipments amid weaker prices.

site_title: NSP says it still intends to contest in MacPherson, contradicts Facebook post by Steve Chia
summary: The National Solidarity Party (NSP) has reaffirmed its intention to contest in the MacPherson single-member constituency, despite a Facebook post by Steve Chia stating otherwise. NSP party organising secretary Spencer Ng confirmed the decision, stating that the collective decision to contest in MacPherson was not affected by Chia's withdrawal.

images.alt_text: The National Solidarity Party (NSP) is committed to contesting in the MacPherson single member constituency, party organising secretary Spencer Ng confirmed on Monday, stressing that Mr Steve Chia's withdrawal did not affect their decision.

site_title: Debtors, banks to feel strain of falling emerging market currencies
summary: Emerging market currencies are experiencing significant volatility, causing strain on importers and local borrowers of foreign currencies. The US dollar has appreciated by 96% against the Russian rouble, 53.8% against the Brazilian real, and 30.3% against the Mexican peso, impacting exporters and companies with dollar-denominated loans. Foreign investors are also feeling the pain, with non-resident investors holding 30% of local currency bonds, down from 13% in 2008. Economists predict that devaluations of these currencies will benefit raw materials producers, but importers will face higher costs unless they hedge against potential depreciation.

site_title: Catering to the millennials
summary: Orange Clove Catering, a seven-year-old Singaporean company, has successfully targeted millennials in the workforce to drive innovation and customer focus. With 80% of its 165 staff members being millennials, the company has implemented a culture of grooming and nurturing, promoting leadership skills and empowerment. By adopting digital platforms and modern technology, Orange Clove has differentiated itself and expanded into new industries such as weddings and food trucks. The company's low staff turnover and remarkable growth rate, with a 40-50% annual increase, demonstrate its commitment to its vision of building people and staying ahead of the market.

images.alt_text: Amanda Chai

site_title: Europe: Stocks plummet on global economic concerns
summary: Europe's main stock markets plummeted on Monday due to concerns over China's economic woes, which may drag on global growth. London's FTSE 100 sank 4.67%, the CAC 40 in Paris dropped 5.35%, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 lost 4.70%. These declines were attributed to fears of a slowdown in global economic growth.

site_title: Hedge funds fleeing crops amid big supply
summary: Hedge funds are fleeing crop markets amid a bumper global harvest, with prices dropping 16% this year. Combined inventories of corn, soyabeans, and wheat are expected to reach a record, prompting money managers to lower their bets on higher prices for a fifth straight week. Volatility in the agricultural space has increased, with the Bloomberg Agriculture Index reaching its highest 60-day volatility since 2012. The US Department of Agriculture has unexpectedly raised its estimates for domestic corn and soybean crops, but a Midwest crop tour suggests the harvest may be smaller than forecast.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Agriculture expects combined inventories of corn, soyabeans and wheat to rise for a third year. The Bloomberg Agriculture Index of eight farm products is down 16 per cent this year.

site_title: Venture capital firms find good startup targets in Europe
summary: German venture capitalist Klaus Hommels' firm Lakestar is launching a 350 million euro fund, doubling its previous investment. Hommels plans to focus on European startups, with a focus on industries transforming daily life, and may also back American startups. This fundraising is part of a surge in European venture capital, with 131 unicorns valued over $1 billion, and a 63% increase in European VC firms' fundraising in the second quarter of 2015. However, concerns about a European tech bubble have been raised, with Hommels dismissing these fears due to the widespread adoption of smartphones and cloud computing.

site_title: Chinese authorities need to raise economic game
summary: China's economy is experiencing a slowdown, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling to its largest drop in eight years. Authorities' efforts to support the stock market and real economy are seen as inadequate, with some experts calling for aggressive interest rate cuts and tax cuts to stimulate consumption. Despite a surprisingly upbeat GDP growth figure, the country's economic growth has been on a downward trend for several years, and retail activity has yet to fill the expected role.

site_title: Shares of brokers lose shine as US commercial property market starts cooling
summary: US commercial property market shows signs of cooling, with shares of brokers CBRE Group and Jones Lang LaSalle losing 8% and 8.7% respectively this month. A slowdown in real estate transactions, rising interest rates, and decelerating credit expansion are contributing factors. Analysts expect profit growth to weaken, citing a natural maturing of the real estate cycle. Despite this, property service providers remain bullish, diversifying away from investment sales to more predictable revenue streams.

site_title: Performance bonus spat may be just the tip of an iceberg
summary: Two independent directors of Lian Beng, Sitoh Yih Pin and Wan Soon Bee, resigned on July 10 citing differences in opinion with management over the computation of the performance bonus for executive directors. The company's first response stated that the bonus is based on "net profits of the group before tax and before extraordinary items as reflected in the audited accounts". This has been interpreted as a potential issue with the company's corporate governance and executive remuneration practices, which may be part of a larger problem in family-controlled and family-run firms.

images.alt_text: Between FY2013 and FY2014, the total remuneration of the chairman and MD (above) moved from the S$2.75-3 million band to the S$5.25-5.5 million band, while those for the other two EDs moved from the S$1.5-1.75 million and S$1-1.25 million bands to the S$2.75-3 million and S$2-2.25 million bands respectively.

site_title: Indonesian state firms to buy back more than US$700m worth of shares
summary: Indonesian state-owned enterprises will spend at least $1 billion to buy back shares, starting from Tuesday, to reduce market fluctuation. The move follows a 4% drop in the Jakarta stock market, which has fallen 25% this year. The government aims to support the market and maintain investor confidence.

site_title: Commodities slump to 16-year low
summary: Commodities, including Brent crude, have reached a 16-year low due to concerns over China's economic slowdown, leading to a global equity slump. The Bloomberg Commodity Index fell 1.8% to 86.2645 points, while shares in miners and explorers plummeted. Brent crude dropped below $45 a barrel for the first time since 2009.

site_title: Toyota falls as China plants stay shut after Tianjin blasts
summary: Toyota Motor Corp plummeted 6.7% in Tokyo trading, its largest decline since the 2011 Japan tsunami, after China plants shut down due to deadly explosions. The company's largest Chinese production site will remain closed for at least two weeks, affecting its global production. The yen's strengthening further exacerbated the decline, outpacing Japan's benchmark Topix index. The move weighed on global stocks, with the yen's rise pummeling exporters. Toyota's decline was the steepest since March 2011.

site_title: Tencent creates roadblocks for Uber's China expansion
summary: Uber's China expansion faces a significant setback after Tencent, the owner of the popular WeChat app, removed the company's account, citing anti-competitive practices. Uber's accounts disappeared from WeChat in March, with the company spending US$1 billion in China this year. Didi Kuaidi, a Chinese ride-hailing app, is far ahead, accounting for 78% of the country's private car business. Tencent's move is seen as a response to Uber's aggressive expansion, with rivalries in China's technology industry running deep. Uber remains hopeful that Tencent will eventually back down, citing partnerships with cities and local investors.

site_title: Overall inflation eases in July, but core inflation rises
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rate eased to -0.4% in July, its ninth consecutive month in negative territory, as expected. However, core inflation rose to 0.4% from 0.2% in June, driven by higher services inflation and a decline in electricity tariffs. Economists believe prices may dampen further due to lower oil prices and weaker rentals, but expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to maintain its monetary policy stance until October, citing no signs of a technical recession or softer job market.

site_title: Australia winemakers court Asian taste buds
summary: Australian winemakers are experiencing a surge in demand for their products in Asia, particularly in China, with exports increasing by 32.1% in the year to June. This growth is driven by the region's burgeoning middle and upper classes seeking new gastronomical adventures. To cater to local tastes, vintners are designing lighter and less full-bodied wines. Companies like Sirromet and Peter Thompson are developing wines with Asian-inspired labels, such as a gold dragon, to appeal to consumers. This trend is expected to continue as consumption is projected to grow strongly in Asia.

site_title: Founding PAP member and union leader, Bernard Rodrigues, has died
summary: Bernard Rodrigues, a founding PAP member and former union leader, died at 82 on August 17 in Australia's Westmead Hospital. He was an MP in Singapore's first Parliament in 1965, representing Telok Blangah. Rodrigues' death marks the loss of a significant figure in Singapore's political history.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:

SMRT's share price has fallen 33% due to disruptions in train services and weak 1QFY16 numbers. The company may continue to face cost pressure and loss in its rail division until reforms are implemented.
