Global Invacom is initiated with a buy recommendation, expecting a strong turnaround in FY16 due to demand from new satellite launches and product sales. Genting Hong Kong's 1H15 results showed a weak VIP segment, but expect earnings recovery in 2H15 with a modest core earnings growth.

site_title: Swiss 1MDB probe focuses on two executives, unknown persons
summary: Switzerland's Office of the Attorney General has opened a criminal proceeding against two 1MDB executives and unknown persons for suspected corruption and money laundering. The investigation is linked to Malaysia's 1MDB fund, which has faced accusations of financial mismanagement and graft. Swiss authorities are examining suspected corruption of foreign officials, misconduct in public office, and money laundering. The 1MDB fund has a US$11 billion debt and has been dogged by controversy. The probe is part of a broader investigation into the fund's activities by Malaysian authorities.

site_title: Silverlake Axis Q4 profit bolstered by accounting gains
summary: Silverlake Axis reported a 1% increase in net profit for Q4 to RM74.7 million, driven by a significant surge in other income, mainly due to an accounting gain of RM19.2 million from an associate in China. Revenue declined 8% to RM126.4 million, primarily due to a decline in software licensing and credit processing. The group reported a 14% rise in full-year net profit to RM282.7 million. A final dividend of 1.2 Singapore cents per share was proposed, with existing shareholders to receive an equivalent of 4.44 cents per share.

site_title: Apple shares rebound as Cook says China growth remains strong
summary: Apple shares rebounded after CEO Tim Cook stated the company has seen strong growth in China this summer, with iPhone activations accelerating in recent weeks. Cook described China as an "unprecedented opportunity" for long-term growth. The stock initially dropped 13% before rising less than 1% to $106.50 following the report. Analyst Daniel Ives maintained his outperform rating, citing the upcoming iPhone 6S and a potential $100 billion market opportunity in China over the next three years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower in global stock rout
summary: Malaysian shares dropped 42.53 points to 1,532.14 on Monday, with 2.58 billion lots valued at RM2.5 billion traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 941 to 100. This comes as global stocks face a rout, with no specific reason given for the decline.

site_title: AIIB appoints Jin Liqun as president: Xinhua
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has appointed Jin Liqun, a former Chinese deputy finance minister, as its president. The AIIB, led by China, was officially created in June and aims to rival the World Bank in development work in Asia.

images.alt_text: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has appointed Jin Liqun, a former Chinese deputy finance minister, as its president, state news agency Xinhua said on Monday.

site_title: 800 Super's FY profit almost doubles on one-time gain, higher revenue
summary: 800 Super Holdings' FY profit nearly doubles to S$17.56 million, driven by a one-time gain and 22% revenue growth to S$140.3 million. The company proposes a final dividend of S$0.02 per share, pending shareholder approval. Shares slipped 9.1% amid a broad equities market rout.

site_title: Khaw says his housing policies have little to do with the general election
summary: Singapore's Minister of National Development Khaw Boon Wan says his housing policies have little to do with the general election, despite the recent introduction of measures benefiting middle to higher-income groups, singles, and home renters. The measures target middle to higher-income groups, singles and home renters, now that the Build-To-Order (BTO) backlog for first-timer newly-weds has mostly been cleared. Khaw believes the market will regulate itself, but acknowledges that there will be market shifts, including potential competition for BTO flats and higher prices for executive condominiums.

images.alt_text: Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan speaking to reporters on housing policy changes in the sales display area of HDB Hub on Monday.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit fresh 7-month low after Chinese stocks slide
summary: European stocks fell sharply at the open on Monday, hitting a 7-month low, as Chinese stocks slid and global markets were affected by concerns over a China-led economic slowdown. The FTSEurofirst 300 index dropped 3.6% and is its largest one-day fall since September 2011. Beijing offered no policy move to support equities, fueling fears of a China-led slowdown and prompting a global exodus from riskier assets.

site_title: Kingsmen Creatives buys land from JTC for S$7.07m to build new HQ
summary: Kingsmen Creatives Ltd has acquired a 5,251 sq m vacant leasehold land at Changi Business Park for S$7.07 million from JTC Corporation. The company plans to construct a multi-storey building to serve as its new headquarters, addressing the need for additional space due to anticipated expansion of its operations. The acquisition and construction will be funded through internal resources and bank borrowings, with no expected impact on earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Euro, yen surge as risk aversion intensifies; dollar takes a hit
summary: The euro and yen surged against the dollar as investors sought safe-havens amid concerns about a slowdown in the Chinese and global economies. The euro hit a 6.5-month high and the yen reached a 3-month peak, while the dollar index fell 0.9% to its lowest in two months. The euro jumped to $1.15 and the yen dropped to 120.25 yen, increasing the chances of the dollar/yen breaking below 120.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall for 7th day, down more than 5%
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted for the seventh consecutive day, falling over 5% as global market turbulence and concerns over China's economy weighed heavily. The Hang Seng index dropped 5.2% to 21,251.57, while China's main indexes fell nearly 9%. Analysts predict further market decline due to economic slowdown, yuan depreciation, and capital flight from emerging markets. Investors sold shares across the board, amid soured sentiment from mainland China's market downturn.

site_title: Thai police deactivate bomb in Bangkok house
summary: Thai police have deactivated a bomb found in a house in Bangkok's Sukhumvit 81 area, a week after a bombing that killed 20 people. The trail has gone cold in the hunt for the bomber, and it's unclear if the chief suspect is still in the country. The bomb was discovered in the home of a construction worker, and police plan to destroy it. The incident marks the country's worst ever bomb attack.

site_title: Ignore stock bloodbath and buy back 2015's winners, Golub says
summary: US stocks experienced a brief "bloodbath" in biotechnology and tech, but RBC Capital Markets' chief US market strategist, Jonathan Golub, believes it's temporary. Golub stated that investors should focus on buying stocks that won't be negatively impacted by potential downside events, rather than reacting to short-term market fluctuations. This approach, Golub said, would lead to better investment decisions.

site_title: Update: US markets tumble, extending global rout; Dow -3.0%
summary: US stocks plummeted, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 3.02% to 15,962.74, while the S&P 500 fell 2.30% to 1,925.54 and the Nasdaq Composite Index sank 2.20% to 4,602.39. The decline was triggered by a 8.49% drop in Chinese stocks, raising concerns about the world's second-largest economy. The US Federal Reserve's plan to raise interest rates is also being questioned, with a 10-year Treasury yield falling to 1.92%.

site_title: Treasury yield falls below 2% as stock rout drives safety demand
summary: US 10-year Treasury yields fell below 2% for the first time since April as stocks plummeted, boosting demand for the safest fixed-income assets. The sell-off in stocks and commodities led to a fourth consecutive day of gains for US government securities, driven by concerns over slowing Chinese growth and its impact on global economic momentum. A bond-market gauge of inflation expectations dropped to its lowest level since January, increasing the odds of rate cuts in developed markets.

site_title: Australia: Stocks close 4.09 per cent lower
summary: Australian stocks closed 4.09% lower on Monday, marking their lowest levels in two years, due to falling oil prices and concerns over the Chinese economy. The S&P/ASX200 index ended 213.3 points lower at 5,001.3. Major stocks like Commonwealth Bank, BHP Billiton, and Rio Tinto fell 4.13%, 5.02%, and 5.15% respectively. Analysts attribute the decline to the impact of China's economic slowdown.

site_title: Abe admits the BOJ's 2% inflation target is tough to achieve
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe acknowledged that the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target is becoming increasingly difficult to achieve, amid a global sell-off and plunging oil prices. The BOJ's key inflation gauge is forecast to fall below zero for the first time in over two years, posing a challenge to its policy. Despite this, Abe expressed confidence in BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda and stated that his reflationary policies have lifted the economy's "dark, heavy atmosphere".

images.alt_text: Mr Abe's comments in parliament suggested that the government was sympathetic with Mr Kuroda's plight, at least for the time being.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 4.61% as Asian markets slump
summary: Tokyo's benchmark stock index dropped 4.61% to a six-month low, following a global equities rout as China's economy worries deepen. The Nikkei 225 ended at 18,540.68, with bank shares and Toyota losing over 6%. The broader Topix index shed 5.86% to close at 1,480.87. This decline marks the lowest point since February, amid concerns about China's economic slowdown and global market uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore: Shares close down 4.3% on fears over China economy
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index plummeted 4.3% on Monday, with the blue-chip index opening 127.62 points lower at 2,843.39. The decline was attributed to deepening fears over China's economy, as the Shanghai Composite and Hang Seng fell 8.5% and 5.2% respectively. Local shares saw a dismal 10 losers for every one gainer, with Stratech Group and Golden Agri-Resources among the top losers. The market's decline was the latest in a series of losses, with the Straits Times Index notching a 5-day rally earlier in the week.

site_title: Chinese authorities need to raise economic game: analysts
summary: Chinese authorities face growing pressure to address the country's slowing economy, with the Shanghai Composite Index experiencing its largest fall in over eight years. Analysts say the government's rescue program is failing to support the stock market, and measures to boost consumer spending and investment are lacking. Economists recommend more aggressive interest rate cuts and tax cuts to stimulate the economy, but the government appears to be devoting too much attention to a military parade. The country's economic growth has been declining, with some analysts warning that confidence in the economy is dwindling, putting pressure on global markets.

site_title: Singapore stock market plunges 3.27%, Shanghai tumbles 8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index plummeted 3.27% as China's slowing economic growth rate spooked the market, with the Shanghai Composite index shedding 8.16%. Other Asian markets, including Taiwan and Indonesia, also fell sharply. Global equities are expected to worsen before buying opportunities emerge, with some experts advising investors to consider short-selling and buying inverse ETFs. The US Federal Reserve may postpone raising interest rates if the current plunge worsens, according to a quantitative research expert.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Quick takes: Still negative inflation, say local banks
summary: Local banks in Singapore, UOB, OCBC, and DBS, are expressing concerns about negative inflation, citing global growth and inflation landscape developments. Despite sustained contraction in headline inflation, core inflation accelerated to 0.4% in July, driven by higher services inflation. The banks maintain their inflation forecasts, but note that downside risks to prices remain, potentially leading to policy actions from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. They expect the Singapore dollar to remain stable against the US dollar, with a projected end-of-year rate of 1.43/USD.

site_title: Latest housing measures not an election package, says Khaw
summary: Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan denied that the latest housing measures targeting middle to higher-income groups are an election package, stating that his policies focus on specific groups and are not influenced by the general election. He believes the market will adjust to the changes, with potential buyers shifting between different housing options. Khaw emphasized that the measures are aimed at resolving the BTO backlog for first-time buyers and are not a response to the election.

site_title: Taipei: Shares plunge as much as 7.49% in worst ever intra-day drop
summary: Taipei's stock market plummeted 7.49% in its worst-ever intra-day drop, led by a decline in Chinese equities and a stagnant domestic economy. The weighted index fell 583.85 points to 7,203.07, with the government holding an emergency meeting to discuss market intervention. Vice-premier Chang Shan-cheng urged pension funds to play a greater role in the market. Taiwan's economic growth has slowed due to China's economic struggles and increased competition from Chinese manufacturers, with the country slashing its 2015 growth forecast to 1.56%.

site_title: Commercial crime cases up 55%, others decline in first half of 2015
summary: Commercial crimes in Singapore increased by 55.3% in the first half of 2015, with 3,893 cases recorded, led by online scams such as "cheating involving e-commerce" and "credit-for-sex". Other crimes, including violent/serious property crimes, housebreaking, and thefts, declined. The police warned the public to exercise caution when engaging in online transactions and emphasized the importance of public awareness in preventing online scams.

site_title: Brokers' take: Expect 'gap-down' day in Singapore markets
summary: Singapore markets are expected to experience a gap-down day, following a 500-point drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average last Friday. The Straits Times Index (STI) is likely to fall to its next support level at 1,880, with a temporary bounce possible but capped at around 2,000. The STI broke below 3,000 support on Friday, and a further correction to the 2,800 region is possible, with support found around 2,698.

images.alt_text: DBS Group Research: Expect another gap-down day for the benchmark Straits Times Index, in reaction to the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling more than 500 points last Friday.

site_title: Brent crude falls below US$45 for first time since 2009 on surplus
summary: Brent crude oil prices fell below $45 a barrel for the first time since 2009 due to concerns over slowing Chinese demand and rising US and Iranian oil supplies. The 4.8% drop in Brent futures, extending a 7.3% decline last week, was attributed to forecasts of the weakest Chinese growth since 1990. Iran's Oil Minister vowed to expand output "at any cost," while US oil rigs rose for the seventh time in eight weeks, further exacerbating the global surplus.

site_title: Spackman Media ropes in KGI for proposed HK listing
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group announced the appointment of KGI Capital Asia as the sole global coordinator and sponsor for the proposed Hong Kong IPO of its associated company, Spackman Media Group Pte Ltd. The move aims to unlock value for shareholders by assigning a separate valuation to SMG. The restructuring exercise is in its preliminary stages and subject to regulatory approvals in Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: Seoul: Shares suffer biggest fall since June 2012; won's loss capped
summary: Seoul shares plummeted 2.5% on Monday, their largest daily percentage loss since June 2012, due to investor caution amid sharp Chinese stock market declines. Foreigners sold local shares for a 13th straight session, netting a 2.65 trillion won loss. The South Korean won also fell 0.3% to 1,199.0 to the dollar, but losses were capped by suspected dollar-selling smoothing operations by foreign exchange authorities amid North-South tensions.

images.alt_text: Seoul shares had their sharpest daily percentage loss in more than 3 years on Monday as investors avoided bets on riskier assets following sharp drops in Chinese stock markets.

site_title: Goldman Sachs lowers Asian stock outlook amid growth concerns
summary: Goldman Sachs has lowered its Asian stock outlook, cutting its price targets for the MSCI Asia Pacific Excluding Japan Index by up to 18% due to growth concerns. The bank's three-month price estimate for the index was reduced to 405 from 495, citing "continuing near-term vulnerability" and a risk of downgrade to earnings estimates. Goldman Sachs expects a recovery in Chinese stocks to be at least six weeks away, with a potential stabilization in China's economic data in the fourth quarter prompting a decent snap back.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group Inc is sticking with its bullish view on Chinese stocks in Hong Kong, saying valuations are inexpensive and improving economic data will spur a rebound.

site_title: Commodities slump to 16-year low as China slowdown roils markets
summary: Commodities have reached a 16-year low due to China's economic slowdown, which has led to a surplus of raw materials and energy. The Bloomberg Commodity Index dropped 1.7% to its lowest level since 1999, with Brent crude falling below $45 a barrel for the first time since 2009. Resources stocks and agricultural commodities also declined, with soybeans, wheat, and corn losing value in Chicago. Experts attribute the decline to concerns of oversupply and a risk-off move in the market, with some speculating that it may prompt the Federal Reserve to delay interest rate increases.

site_title: Update: China's stocks sink most since 2007 as state intervention fails
summary: China's stocks plummeted 8.5% to 3,209.91 on the Shanghai Composite Index, marking the largest decline since 2007. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index fell 6.5% in Hong Kong, and the CSI 300 Index futures declined 10% daily limit. Government support measures, including allowing pension funds to buy shares, failed to halt the market's downward spiral. Economic data showed a slowdown in China's economy, with a 6.6% growth rate in July, and signs of capital outflows. The market's valuation has increased to 61 times reported earnings, and stocks on mainland bourses have fallen by the most on record.

images.alt_text: Shanghai stocks closed down 1.27 per cent in volatile trading on Wednesday, extending days of falls despite a central bank interest rate cut aimed at boosting the flagging economy and slumping shares, dealers said.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stock plunge is fastest since 1987 crash on China woes
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index plummeted 5.1% on Monday, its largest decline since the 1987 crash, due to concerns over China's economy. The index has fallen 25% from its April high amid a $4 trillion selloff in mainland Chinese equities and a yuan devaluation. Traders warn that the momentum is still down, making a rebound difficult, but longer-term investors may see potential for a rebound if they can stomach volatility.

site_title: Japan's Abe: Acceptable for BOJ to miss price goal
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that it's acceptable for the Bank of Japan to miss its inflation target, as oil prices continue to fall. Abe expressed confidence in the economy's recovery and said the BOJ's explanation for missing the deadline was understandable. The BOJ has revised its forecast to reach 2% inflation by September 2026, which some analysts consider too ambitious. Abe assured the government won't meddle in monetary policy decisions, trusting BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's handling.

site_title: Stock rout was inevitable to Leuthold's Ramsey, and will worsen
summary: Doug Ramsey, chief investment officer of Leuthold Weeden Capital Management, predicts US stocks will continue to decline, with losses in the Standard & Poor's 500 Index reaching 20%. Last week's 7.5% decline left the benchmark index down from its May record. Ramsey believes the selling will worsen, describing the current trends as "ugly."

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks extend losses to 2% tracking US, regional bourses
summary: Taiwan's stocks plummeted by over 2% on Monday, mirroring losses in US and regional bourses. The decline was driven by concerns over slowing growth in China, which has implications for global economies.

site_title: Philippines: Stocks plunge 6.4% by midday
summary: The Philippine stock market plummeted 6.4% by midday on August 24, 2015, due to a sharp fall in stocks in China and the US. The country's benchmark index fell 466.15 points, wiping out all 2015 gains. Analysts attributed the downturn to global sell-off concerns, with 80-90% of the sell-off linked to China and US developments. Despite this, analysts believe the Philippines' fundamentals remain intact.

site_title: Taiwan says does not rule out possibility of propping up stocks
summary: Taiwan's vice finance minister, Wu Tang-chieh, expressed concern over the island's stock market, which plummeted 5% to its lowest level in nearly three years. The benchmark index fell to 7,394.83 points, prompting speculation that the government's National Security Fund, worth T$500 billion, might be used to prop up the market. Wu did not rule out this possibility, indicating a potential government intervention to stabilize the market.

site_title: Selling frenzy grips markets as traders tally losses from rout
summary: Global markets experienced a selling frenzy on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite Index plummeting 8.5% and European shares retreating to their largest decline since 2011. Investors rushed for the exits, prompting margin calls and a surge in stock exchange volume. Commodities prices sank to a 16-year low, while currencies of Russia and South Africa weakened against the dollar. The economic slowdown in China and potential US interest rate hikes are prompting investors to reassess their holdings, with some seeing opportunities in higher volatility.

site_title: Sembcorp unit completes divestment of stake in Zhumadian China Water
summary: Sembcorp Industries has completed the divestment of its 51% stake in Zhumadian China Water Co to Beijing Enfei Environmental Protection Co for 90 million yuan (S$20 million). The sale, based on the fair value of the asset, will not impact the group's earnings per share and net asset value per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2015. Zhumadian China Water, which runs a municipal water facility in Henan, will cease to be part of the group following the transaction.

site_title: Thailand to speed up projects, plans economic measures: Deputy PM
summary: Thailand's new Deputy Prime Minister, Somkid Jatusripitak, plans to speed up infrastructure projects and introduce short-term economic measures to boost the flagging economy. He stated that the country's economic fundamentals remain strong and will meet with the business sector to seek their cooperation. The measures aim to help low-income earners and farmers, as the military government seeks to revitalize Southeast Asia's second-largest economy.

site_title: India: Shares slump more than 2% tracking global markets
summary: Indian shares plummeted 2.94% in pre-open trading on August 24, 2015, following a rout in Chinese equities that triggered global market unrest. The NSE index fell 2.94% and the BSE index dropped 2.32%. The decline was part of a broader Asian market downturn, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index of shares excluding Japan falling 4.6%.

site_title: Yuan opens weaker despite firmer guidance
summary: China's yuan weakened slightly to 6.3948 per dollar at open on Monday, despite a firmer guidance rate of 6.3862. The offshore yuan was trading 1.11% lower at 6.4665 per dollar. This move follows a previous day's closing quote of 6.3887. The People's Bank of China allowed the spot rate to trade within a 2% range above or below the official fixing.

site_title: Update: Thailand plans economic measures, to speed up investment: Deputy PM
summary: Thailand's military government plans short-term economic measures to boost investment and support low-income earners and farmers, amid a stagnant economy that has missed targets and put pressure on the junta. Deputy PM Somkid Jatusripitak aims to distribute growth across the nation, while speeding up major investments and seeking international cooperation. The country's economic fundamentals are seen as strong, but growth forecasts have been cut to 2.7-3.2% for this year, down from 3.0-4.0%. The government will also meet with the business sector to drive the economy forward.

site_title: China traders say stock intervention misguided amid slowdown
summary: China's stock market continues to decline amid a slowdown in the economy, with the Shanghai Composite Index plummeting 12% last week. Economic data shows a deepening slowdown, with industrial output, exports, and retail sales all declining. Experts predict further falls, with some forecasting a 29% decline in the Shanghai Composite by next year. The government's intervention has failed to convince investors that gains will be sustainable, leading to a stock outflow of over $7 billion.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Perennial, Straco, Frasers Centrepoint
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings has entered a joint venture with Shangri-La Asia to develop a US$250 million integrated mixed-use development in Accra, Ghana. site_title: Hong Kong: Shares tumble in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted by 3.89% in early trade on Monday, extending heavy losses amid global sell-off concerns about China's economy. summary: Asian stocks plummeted Monday, with Shanghai leading the decline, falling over 8% due to deepening concerns about China's slowing economy. The downturn is attributed to weak Chinese manufacturing data and a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy.

images.alt_text: Asian stocks were a sea of red Monday, with Shanghai slumping more than eight percent as deepening concerns about China's stalling economy rattled equity investors around the world.

site_title: Singapore inflation eases to -0.4% in July
summary: Singapore's inflation rate eased to -0.4% in July, down from -0.3% in June, primarily due to lower costs of private road transport and accommodation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry reiterated their full-year inflation forecasts, projecting core inflation at 0.5-1.5% and headline inflation at -0.5-0.5%.

images.alt_text: While Singapore's headline inflation rate eased to -0.4 per cent in July from June's -0.3 per cent, core inflation rose to 0.4 per cent last month from 0.2 per cent in June.

site_title: Asia: Stocks head for two-year low as global equity rout deepens
summary: Asian stocks plummeted, nearing a two-year low, as a global equity rout deepened. site_title: Australia: Shares hit one and a half year lows on China fears
summary: Australian shares plummeted to a 1.5-year low on Monday, falling 2.4% as fears of a Chinese economic slowdown triggered global selling. China is Australia's top trading partner, and the grim economic indicators led investors to dump stocks worldwide.

site_title: The Fed Is looking at a very different dollar than Wall Street
summary: The Federal Reserve's trade-weighted dollar index has surged 1.3% beyond a 12-year high, contrasting with Wall Street's view that the dollar has traded sideways for six months. The divergence may lead to further jawboning from officials looking to cool the dollar's broad gains, potentially triggering a jolt for investors.

summary: Seoul shares fell 2% to a two-year low, reaching 1,833.57 points, amid growing volatility after Chinese shares plummeted. This marks the lowest point since July 10, 2013. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index dropped as much as 2.3% during the session.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks drop 2.1% at open after Wall Street tanks
summary: Tokyo's benchmark stock index dropped 2.10% at the open on Monday, following a 3.0% decline on Friday, amid global equities sell-off due to worries about China's economy. The Nikkei 225 fell 408.52 points to 19,027.31.

site_title: China: Shanghai shares open down more than 3%
summary: Shanghai shares plummeted over 3% on Monday, despite China's state pension fund authorization to invest in stocks. site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 21.00 points to 1,553.67, with losers outnumbering gainers 315 to 25. The index closed at RM23.06 million in volume.

site_title: Brent and US oil fall to fresh 6-1/2-year lows over China
summary: Brent and US crude oil futures hit fresh 6-1/2-year lows on Monday, as investors worry about weak demand amid China's slowing economy and global supply surplus. site_title: Japan PM Abe to skip visit to China for WW2 anniversary: media
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will not attend events in China to mark the 70th anniversary of World War II due to concerns over China's military expansion. China will hold a military parade on September 3 to commemorate the "Victory of the Chinese people's war against Japanese aggression". The decision reflects ongoing strained relations between Japan and China, with ties still affected by Japan's past occupation of parts of China.

site_title: Olam updates US$5b Euro medium term note programme
summary: Olam International has updated its US$5 billion Euro medium term note programme, established in 2012. DBS Bank, HSBC's Singapore branch, and Standard Chartered Bank are the arrangers, while dealers include The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and StanChart. Olam has also issued an updated offering circular and entered into a supplemental trust deed with The Bank of New York Mellon. An application has been made to Singapore Exchange (SGX) for permission to deal in and list the notes on the official list of the exchange.

site_title: Singapore: Stocks open almost 2% down as China and Fed continue to spook
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index plummeted 1.85% to 2,915.99, driven by a plunge in New York and concerns over China's economy. Banking stocks led the losers, with UOB, DBS, and OCBC down 22-46 cents. site_title: MND gives details on Proximity Housing Grant and timelines for new measures
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) announced details on the Proximity Housing Grant (PHG), a new measure to help Singaporeans buy resale flats near their parents or married children. Starting Aug 24, 2015, eligible families will receive a PHG of S$20,000, while singles buying with their parents will receive S$10,000. This complements existing priority schemes to support families living together. The PHG aims to support families in achieving their housing goals.

site_title: Greek eurosceptics to take government mandate amid early election row
summary: Greek eurosceptics from the Syriza party, known as Popular Unity, are set to form a government after President Prokopis Pavlopoulos offers them a mandate. The move comes after Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras resigned following an anti-bailout mutiny by his party's eurosceptics, ending his parliamentary majority. The country is expected to hold a snap election on September 20, as the opposition parties are unlikely to secure enough support for a majority in the 300-seat parliament.

site_title: Templeton bets on Malaysia as Hasenstab says declines overshot
summary: Franklin Templeton, a San Mateo-based money manager, has been buying Malaysian debt amid global funds fleeing the market. The firm has become the largest holder of Malaysian government local-currency bonds, adding 9.64 billion ringgit (S$3.25 billion) to its holdings this year. Despite the country's economic challenges, including plunging oil prices and a selloff in emerging markets, Franklin Templeton's chief investment officer, Michael Hasenstab, believes in the long-term value of the investment. He attributes Malaysia's economy as stronger today than during the 2008 global financial crisis or the Asian crisis of the late 1990s.

site_title: Hong Kong can't escape the turmoil next door: editorial
summary: Hong Kong is facing a series of challenges, including a tumbling tourism industry, a precarious property bubble, and a leader struggling to address basic issues. The city's economy is also closely tied to China's, which is experiencing a slowdown. China's devaluation has led to a 9% drop in the Hang Seng Index, making Hong Kong's valuations the lowest relative to global equities since 2003. As investors lose confidence in China's economy, Hong Kong's growth is at risk, with some warning of a potential repeat of Macau's decline.

site_title: Equity and equality
summary: Singapore's government and citizens must work together to reduce income inequality and increase social mobility. Experts agree that a strong economy, government-led initiatives, and corporate social responsibility are key. The government should finance social costs, mainly through taxation, and companies should give back to society through philanthropy and community engagement. Implementing a minimum wage system, improving education, and leveraging technology can also help. The government should also focus on progressive taxation, upgrading skills and competencies, and cultivating a strong social compact to ensure sustainable growth and fairness.

site_title: UK employers raise growth outlook, see earlier BoE rate move
summary: The UK's economy is expected to grow 2.6% in 2015 and 2.8% in 2016, according to the Confederation of British Industry, beating previous forecasts. A strong household spending and investment growth will offset a decline in foreign trade, with the Bank of England likely to raise interest rates in the first quarter of 2016, earlier than previously predicted. The growth outlook is driven by stronger wage increases and low inflation, but productivity concerns remain, particularly in the manufacturing sector.

site_title: HDB, executive condo income ceilings to rise: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced four housing policy changes to boost home ownership and promote inclusiveness. The income ceiling for HDB flats and executive condos will be raised to $12,000 and $14,000, respectively. The Special CPF Housing Grant will be extended to cover more households with an increased income ceiling of $8,500. Additionally, a "Fresh Start Housing Scheme" will help second-timer rental households own a two-room flat, and a Proximity Housing Grant will be introduced for couples buying a resale flat near their parents or parents near their children.

site_title: Pentagon confirms blast at US military post in Japan
summary: A blast occurred at a US military post near Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, causing a fire but no injuries were reported. The explosion happened at a warehouse at the US Army Sagami General Depot in Sagamihara, 40km south-west of Tokyo. Japanese firefighters are waiting for information on the contents of the warehouse before tackling the blaze, which is being investigated. The cause of the explosion is unknown and Commander Bill Urban of the US Navy has stated that the depot did not store hazardous materials.

site_title: Buying by directors, companies jumps
summary: In the third week of August, buying activity surged at the Singapore Exchange, with 76 purchases worth S$7.65 million and 142 repurchases worth S$167 million. This follows a lengthy lay-off, with several companies and directors resuming buying due to a sharp drop in share prices. Notable buybacks include Bumitama Agri, Overseas Union Enterprise, and IFS Capital, with some companies purchasing shares at lower than their IPO prices. The buying trend contrasts with the rare sales among directors, with some companies, such as Breadtalk Group and Sembcorp Industries, resuming buying back at lower than their acquisition prices.

site_title: Pilot fights for life, 7 killed in UK airshow crash
summary: A pilot in a historic Hawker Hunter jet crashed into a busy road during the Shoreham Airshow in the UK on Saturday, killing seven people and injuring 14. The plane failed to complete a loop manoeuvre, hitting several cars and creating a fireball. The pilot is in critical condition in hospital, while four people with minor injuries were taken to hospital. Eyewitnesses described the scene as chaotic, with one witness saying the plane "ploughed straight into the road and the trees" before exploding. The incident has led to the cancellation of the airshow's second day.

site_title: In Uber's quest to win over China, Tencent blocks the way
summary: Uber's efforts to expand in China have been hindered by Tencent, the owner of WeChat, which has blocked the app's presence on its platform. Uber's accounts began disappearing on March 16, with the customer support profile in Hangzhou and Beijing being the first to vanish. This move has significantly limited Uber's ability to reach WeChat's 600 million active users in China, a crucial market for the company's growth. The blockage is seen as a major setback for Uber's quest to win over the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: hina's dominant ride-hailing app has powerful friends. Among the backers of the car-booking app Didi Kuaidi is Tencent, owner of the country's most popular messaging app, WeChat.

site_title: Stocks toppled from Japan to Australia as traders turn to havens
summary: Asian stocks plummeted to a two-year low as a global selloff intensified, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index falling 1.8% for a seventh straight day. The Dow Jones Industrial Average corrected, and US index futures sank. Haven assets like Australian bonds and the yen rose, while gold and Treasuries held gains. Concern over a global glut and China's faltering economy fueled the sell-off, with over $5 trillion wiped from global stocks since China devalued the yuan. The selloff is expected to continue unless rate cuts and policy easing in China materialize.

images.alt_text: Asian stocks slid to a two-year low as the selloff that has spread to almost every corner of the global equity market intensified, spurring demand for haven assets.

site_title: Malaysia ringgit hits pre-peg 17-year low on risk aversion
summary: Malaysia's ringgit hit a 17-year low against the US dollar, falling 0.9% to 4.2200 per dollar, due to sustained concerns over China's economy and global risk aversion. The currency's pre-peg value, set in 1998, has not been seen since August 1998. Malaysia's international reserves fell to $94.5 billion, down from $96.7 billion in July. This decline in reserves and currency devaluation are linked to the weakening global market, with European and Wall Street stocks experiencing their largest one-day drop in nearly four years.

site_title: MCL Land sells 247 units at Sol Acres
summary: MCL Land sold 247 units of its Sol Acres executive condominium in Choa Chu Kang Grove, with the average price at S$780 per square foot (psf). This marks the best-selling EC project so far this year, surpassing City Developments' 185 units sold in The Brownstone. The project's popularity was attributed to reasonable pricing and pent-up demand for ECs in the area, with three-bedders being the most sought-after units.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Telemedicine: the way forward for the health sector
summary: Singapore is addressing its ageing population's increased healthcare needs by leveraging technology, particularly telemedicine. The country aims to enhance healthcare services through Smart Health Assist, a concept that enables elderly and patients with chronic illnesses to proactively monitor their health at home. With the global telehealth market expected to grow at 18.4% annually, Singapore is positioning itself to benefit from this trend, with initiatives such as remote health monitoring and digital health systems.

site_title: New housing grant, enhanced Baby Bonus for parents
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced four family-friendly policies to support parents, including a new Proximity Housing Grant, an enhanced Baby Bonus scheme, an increased Medisave Grant for Newborns, and longer paternity leave. The new housing grant will help extended families live closer together, while the Baby Bonus will be increased for every child, providing greater support for larger families. The Medisave Grant for Newborns will also be raised to cover healthcare-related expenses until age 21. The additional paternity leave will be implemented voluntarily for private companies and immediately for the public service.

site_title: 1MDB says it has not been contacted by Swiss
summary: Malaysia's state fund 1MDB stated it has not been contacted by Swiss authorities regarding an investigation into suspected corruption and money laundering. The fund is being examined by authorities investigating financial mismanagement and graft allegations. Prime Minister Najib Razak's leadership is under scrutiny following a Wall Street Journal report that nearly $700 million was deposited into his private bank account, which he denies took place for personal gain. The fund remains committed to cooperating with any investigation.

site_title: S$800 a month: that's how much the young save
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) of Singapore has launched the CPF Starter app, which crowdsources financial data and provides useful tips to users. The app found that the median savings rate of users under 35 is 20%, significantly higher than the 6% savings rate of Americans. The app also projects how much users will have in their CPF accounts in the future and provides basic tips on personal finance. With over 15,000 downloads by mid-August, the app aims to encourage users to save more and plan for retirement.

site_title: Serial System to invest in food manufacturing and catering
summary: Serial System Ltd's subsidiary, Serial System International Pte Ltd, will buy a 21% stake in four food manufacturing and catering companies for S$4.468 million. The companies, Tong Chiang Group, Edith-United International, Eunice Food Catering, and Imperial Kitchen Catering, will sell their business and assets to Tong Chiang Group, becoming investment holding companies. The acquisition is expected to provide a stable higher margin to the company, and the consideration will be funded by internal funds and/or bank borrowings.

site_title: Higher re-employment age by 2017
summary: Singapore to legislate a higher re-employment age by 2017, raising the age from 65 to 67. This follows an agreement between the government, unions, and employers to give companies time to adjust. The move aims to allow workers to continue working productively and combat ageism. The government plans to announce an Action Plan on helping Singaporeans age well, aiming to make the city-state a model for successful ageing.

site_title: Arrest of Bitcoin CEO leaves crucial questions unanswered
summary: Mark Karpeles, the former CEO of MtGox, was arrested in Japan on a fresh warrant over allegations of stealing millions of dollars from clients, including $48,000 spent on a luxury canopy bed. Karpeles, 30, denies the claims and was initially held without formal charges for three weeks. Despite a lengthy investigation, police have yet to determine where the missing $480 million in Bitcoins went, sparking questions about Karpeles' involvement and potential additional crimes. The case raises complex challenges for Japanese police and financial watchdogs trying to regulate digital money.

site_title: US ed-tech darling Blackboard losing market share to nimble competitors
summary: Blackboard, a leading education technology company, is losing market share to nimble competitors. After peaking in 2007 at $49 per share, its market share has dwindled from 90% in 2006 to 44% today. This decline comes as the education technology industry experiences slow growth. Competitors such as Amazon Web Services and Oracle are vying for market share, forcing Blackboard to adapt to the changing landscape. The company's stock performance and market share have been steadily declining over the past two decades.

site_title: Wilhelmshaven port ready for supersize ships
summary: Germany's deep-water port, Wilhelmshaven's Jade-Weser-Port, is poised to become a major player in the European container shipping market, with its operators aiming to attract supersize ships. The port, which was initially met with difficulties after its 2012 inauguration, is now seeing increased activity with long-distance services to China, Japan, and India. With its 18-metre deep port, Wilhelmshaven is better equipped to handle the new giant container ships, and its operators expect the port to reach full capacity of 2.7 million TEUs per year in 10-15 years.

site_title: North, South Korea on high alert amid talks to end standoff
summary: North Korea and South Korea are on high alert amid ongoing talks to ease tensions after an artillery fire exchange brought the peninsula to the brink of armed conflict. The two sides met at the Panmunjom truce village, with North Korea deploying twice its usual artillery strength at the border, and discussed ways to resolve tension and improve ties. The talks were open-ended, with the South's Blue House expected to announce results after they conclude, and the United Nations, US, and China calling for calm. The crisis escalated after North Korea fired four shells into the South and Seoul responded with 29 artillery rounds.

site_title: A fly on the wall of the US Fed
summary: US Federal Reserve minutes suggest the central bank is nearing the end of its accommodative monetary policy stance. The labour market has improved, with solid job gains and declining unemployment, but inflation remains below the 2% target. Participants expect inflation to rise gradually, but some are concerned about the risk of premature policy tightening and its potential impact on financial stability. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates soon, with a gradual pace of normalization anticipated to support sustained economic growth and inflation.

images.alt_text: Participants generally expected consumer spending to rise moderately over the near term. Consumer credit conditions were also seen as favourable, with business contacts pointing to steady loan growth, especially for car loans and credit cards.

site_title: Singapore Institute of Technology to move to new campus in Punggol
summary: Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) will move to a new campus in Punggol, integrated with the housing estate and creative industry cluster. The move aims to provide students with hands-on learning opportunities. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the plan at the National Day Rally, highlighting the importance of education for self-reliance and staying ahead of globalization. The new campus is expected to increase undergraduate intake to 3,500 in 2020, offering 36 degree programs in partnership with overseas universities.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Wanted: A fresh mandate to govern, to take Singapore into next phase
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced plans for a general election, citing the country's 50-year independence milestone. He emphasized the need for a new mandate to govern the next phase of Singapore's nationhood. Lee stressed that voters will determine the direction of the country for the next 15-20 years, painting two possible scenarios: a special nation or an ordinary one with intractable problems. He also highlighted the need for leadership renewal, citing the aging of the current team and the importance of introducing younger talent.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Can S$ sustain parity exchange rate with the A$?
summary: The Singapore dollar has reached parity with the Australian dollar, its weakest level since 2009, due to slowing global demand for Australia's commodities and disappointing economic data. This could benefit Singapore families and tourists, but harm local companies with investments in Australia. The parity exchange rate is expected to drive foreign exchange rates towards equilibrium, but Australia's economy is vulnerable to lower commodity prices and global uncertainty.

site_title: Selling pressure to continue amid few positive catalysts
summary: Singapore shares are expected to continue declining amid few positive catalysts, following a 11.7% drop from the end of 2014. The Straits Times Index closed below 3,000 points on Friday and may remain there or drop further. Global stock markets, including the US Dow Jones and S&P 500, also experienced significant corrections. Investors are cautious, viewing the current market as a "falling knife."

site_title: Dutch defends no-money-down mortgages
summary: The Netherlands is the last Western European country where homebuyers can borrow up to 103% of the purchase price, allowing for a no-money-down mortgage. This policy, implemented seven years after the global financial crisis, sets the Netherlands apart from other European countries.

site_title: New tool to assess costs and benefits of US cancer therapy
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has developed a new tool to assess the costs and benefits of US cancer therapy options, providing a clearer picture of medication value, particularly for expensive treatments with minimal survival benefits. This move aims to help patients and healthcare providers make informed decisions.

site_title: Caesars to pay US$20m penalty to government
summary: Caesars Entertainment Corp has agreed to pay a US$20 million penalty to settle charges over anti-money laundering lapses, including failing to properly police sports book activity at its Las Vegas casino. The company will enter into a deferred prosecution agreement with the Justice Department, satisfying both criminal and civil allegations by the US Treasury Department's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network. This settlement comes after weeks of pressure from FinCEN, which had threatened to settle its civil investigation unilaterally.

site_title: Petals on the water bid farewell to Bangkok bomb victim
summary: Kritsuda Narongplaian bid farewell to her boyfriend, Yutthanarong Singro, who was killed in a bomb blast at Bangkok's Erawan Shrine last Monday. The bombing, which also killed 19 others, occurred when Singro was delivering a document near the monument. Singro was 38 years old. The incident marked a somber moment for the couple, who had released orange marigold petals onto the river in a symbolic gesture of farewell.

site_title: US risk takers drawn to Australian shale
summary: US risk-taker Aubrey McClendon is investing in Australia's shale oil reserves, following a wave of major oil companies exiting the market. McClendon's American Energy Partners is negotiating two acquisitions worth over $160 million for drilling rights spanning an area the size of New York state. The move comes as global crude prices drop 59% in the past 14 months, and McClendon sees an opportunity to fill the "vacuum" left by major oil companies.

site_title: Banking on new aviation products, growth markets
summary: Rockwell Collins aims to fuel its growth in Asia by catering to evolving trends in the aviation industry. The company is banking on new products and services, such as border management systems and business jet solutions, to meet consistent growth rates. Asia-Pacific accounts for 40% of the air freight market, and the region's growing affluence is driving demand for business jets and customized services. Rockwell Collins is also eyeing new markets, including Myanmar, and is looking to expand its presence in existing markets, such as China and South Asia.

site_title: Mutual fund investors race to escape growing risk in global bonds
summary: Mutual fund investors are rapidly withdrawing from emerging-market bond funds, with a record $2.5 billion pulled out in the past week. This sharp decline in global markets is attributed to growing risk in these investments. The large mutual funds, which previously fueled rapid growth in developing countries, are now hastily retreating, contributing to market volatility.

site_title: Flextronics is remaking itself as an IoT firm
summary: Flextronics, a 46-year-old electronics manufacturer, is transforming itself into a leading Internet of Things (IoT) firm. The company aims to capitalize on the growing IoT market by creating intelligent, connected devices for various industries. With annual revenue of $26.1 billion, Flextronics has seen a 9% decline since 2011, but its profit margins have risen to 2.2% this year. The company has created a library of 130 component designs and opened 23 R&D labs to support its IoT business, including collaborations with Intel and Farm2050.

site_title: PM Lee makes call to keep Singapore special for the next 50 years
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the country's potential for future success in a National Day Rally speech, despite facing challenges. He cited three key factors behind the country's "exhilarating journey" to SG50: a multi-racial society, a "rugged society" with self-reliance and mutual support, and high government-trust levels. Lee promised to maintain "a strong team of lions" to overcome future challenges, including tough immigration policies. He also announced various housing and family-friendly measures, including increased income ceilings for HDB flats and enhanced parenthood benefits.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Goodbye Crimea, hello Odessa: Ukrainians flock to new spot
summary: Ukrainians are flocking to Odessa, a historic port city 150km west of Crimea, as a summer destination due to Russia's seizure of the peninsula. Tourism has increased, with many opting for Odessa's affordable prices and lively nightlife. However, the influx has put pressure on the city's infrastructure, and analysts warn that the Ukrainian economy's woes, including a 10% shrinkage forecast and a 65% drop in the currency's value, may deter further growth.

site_title: Market misreading China's rebalancing economy, says leading economist
summary: China's economy is undergoing a rebalancing, with the services sector overtaking the industrial sector as the largest contributor to GDP. Despite official claims of 7% growth, some analysts, including former Goldman Sachs Asia vice-president Kenneth Courtis, believe the underlying growth is lower. Courtis argues that China's transition to a more service-centric and higher-value-added economy is well underway, driven by rising consumer spending and urban job growth. This is masking a potential slowdown, but the authorities are taking steps to manage the transition and keep the economy stable.

site_title: Quake-hit Nepal opens Mt Everest for autumn season
summary: Nepal has opened Mount Everest for the autumn season, issuing its first climbing permit four months after a deadly earthquake triggered an avalanche at its base camp. The decision comes after a shutdown in 2014 following the deaths of 16 Nepalese guides in an avalanche. Japanese climber Nobokazu Kuriki will attempt to reach the summit solo, while 14 teams have applied for climbing permits. The move aims to boost Nepal's tourism industry, which was severely impacted by the earthquake, with the country expecting to see an increase in international visitors.

site_title: Train attack in Europe exposes vulnerability of US rail passengers
summary: A train attack in Europe where an armed man was thwarted by passengers has raised concerns about US rail security, citing the lack of stringent screening measures at most stations. The US has a police force of about 500 Amtrak officers, but smaller commuter rail services lack any type of armed presence. Despite measures such as armed Amtrak police and security teams, experts say trains remain vulnerable to terrorist attacks. Plans for airport-style screening at railroad stations have been debated but stalled due to cost and passenger resistance.

site_title: Lack of equipment hampers hunt for Bangkok bomber
summary: A six-day investigation into the Bangkok shrine bombing that killed 20 people is ongoing, with authorities urging patience as they lack modern equipment to track down the bomber. The police chief admitted that Thailand lacks facial recognition technology and other tools to enhance security camera footage, hindering the investigation. A suspect in a yellow T-shirt has been identified on CCTV, and a bounty of over $300,000 has been offered for his arrest, but no arrests have been made. The police are working around the clock, but the main suspect could have left the country, and the investigation is considered complicated.

site_title: With stocks cheap, Indonesia investors ready to buy
summary: Indonesia's largest fund manager, BPJS Ketenagakerjaan, plans to invest in the country's equities market as stocks are "relatively cheap" following a 5.4% decline last week. This move comes as the Jakarta Composite Index is trading at its cheapest levels in 20 months amid a weakening economy, slumping commodity prices, and US interest rate speculation. Foreign investors have pulled $1.35 billion from Indonesian stocks in the past 12 months, with a record $185.4 million outflow on August 20.

site_title: Shell's Bukom refinery fire occurred at a section under maintenance: spokeswoman
summary: A fire broke out at Royal Dutch Shell's 500,000 barrels-per-day refinery on Pulau Bukom island off Singapore on Friday, occurring at a section under scheduled maintenance. The fire was extinguished within an hour, and three contract workers were hospitalized with burns, with two discharged and one still being monitored. The cause of the fire was not disclosed, and there was no impact on the site's operations.

site_title: Improving remuneration governance
summary: A Singaporean article emphasizes the importance of effective remuneration governance in corporate boards. Key steps include clarifying responsibilities, aligning compensation with company objectives, and disclosing remuneration details. Boards should establish clear objectives, consider both short-term and long-term goals, and use objective measures like profits before tax or economic value added. Disclosure of remuneration is crucial, as it helps assessors of corporate governance and investors evaluate a company's remuneration practices. Poor practices can lead to intrusive regulation, and companies are encouraged to adopt good corporate governance standards to avoid this.

site_title: China gives pension funds access to stock market
summary: China has allowed pension funds to invest in the stock market for the first time, enabling hundreds of billions of yuan to potentially stabilize the country's struggling equity market. The move comes as investor sentiment remains fragile amid a slowing economy. Pension funds can invest up to 30% of their net assets in stocks, equity funds, and other assets, with assets totaling over 2 trillion yuan. This could channel around 600 billion yuan into the market, according to state media estimates. The rules were published on June 30, following a stock market slump last week.

site_title: Oil plumbs 6 1/2-year low on glut, China woes
summary: Oil prices plummeted to a 6.5-year low near $40 per barrel, driven by fears of oversupply and weak demand, particularly from China. The drop was fueled by China's central bank devaluing its currency and a surprise rise in US stocks. Despite a decision by the US and OPEC to keep production levels high, markets remain oversupplied, leading to a decline in prices for other commodities such as gold, copper, and industrial metals. The decline in oil prices is seen as a bad sign for energy demand and global growth.

site_title: Despite grim outlook, all is not lost for market bulls
summary: US stocks remain a bright spot despite the global economic downturn, with the US growth rate accelerating despite trouble with trade partners. Major stock indexes declined last week, finishing in official correction territory, but the US could still follow China into bear-market territory if the Federal Reserve raises interest rates. The US economy's consumer-dependent industries, such as housing, technology, and pharmaceuticals, are showing pockets of strength, but a global recession is feared if China's economic slowdown persists. The US unemployment rate has been decreasing, and the oil patch remains a significant employer, but the price of oil remains depressed.

site_title: No easy options in policies on immigration, foreigners: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that there are no easy options in policies on immigration and foreigners, as closing the doors to foreign workers would harm the economy and letting too many in would negatively impact society. He emphasized that trade-offs will occur and that he will make a judgment on what Singapore needs, accounting for his decisions to Singaporeans.

site_title: Singapore to raise re-employment age to 67 by 2017: PM Lee
summary: Singapore plans to raise its re-employment age from 65 to 67 by 2017 to ensure re-employed workers remain productive and not a burden on firms. The decision follows an agreement between the government, unions, and employers. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the plan in his National Day Rally speech. The goal is to give companies sufficient time to adjust to the change, allowing re-employed workers to remain employed until they reach 67.

site_title: Frackers in Texas turn to toilet water
summary: Pioneer Natural Resources Co, a top US shale oil producer, has signed an 11-year deal with the city of Odessa, Texas, to use millions of gallons of treated municipal wastewater daily for its oilfields. The deal, worth $117 million, aims to cut costs and mitigate water scarcity risks in the arid Permian Basin. The treated wastewater, considered non-potable, will replace fresh water used in fracking operations, with Pioneer aiming to eliminate its use in 5-10 years.

images.alt_text: Water acquisition and transport can account for up to 10 per cent of the cost of drilling and fracking a well, a consultant says.

site_title: EM currencies allowed to slide after yuan
summary: Emerging economies are allowing their currencies to slide, following China's yuan devaluation and the US dollar's strength due to expected US rate hikes. Currencies in Asia, such as the Kazakh tenge and Vietnamese dong, have dropped significantly, while others like the South African rand and Indonesian rupiah have also fallen to historic lows. Analysts attribute this to fears of global growth slowdown, depressed oil prices, and speculation about US interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The world's emerging economies are allowing their currencies to slide in a quest to remain competitive, following China's devaluation of the yuan and the US dollar's strength in anticipation of US rate hikes.

site_title: PM Lee to call for GE 'soon', urges voters to support his PAP team
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that a general election will be called "soon" to secure a new mandate and pave the way for the next 50 years of nationhood. Lee emphasized the need for a fresh team of leaders, citing the aging of his current core team. The election will determine the leaders for the next five years and the team for the next 15-20 years.

site_title: Food with substance, but lacking in style
summary: Alma, a restaurant at the Goodwood Park Hotel, received a mixed review for its food, which is often good but lacks style. The decor remains largely unchanged from its predecessor Gaia, giving it a tired look.

site_title: Two dead in shooting at New York federal building
summary: A gunman shot and killed a private security guard at a US federal building in downtown New York's SoHo neighborhood. The shooter then killed himself, with police ruling out a terrorism link. The motive for the attack remains unclear. The incident occurred at 201 Varick Street, home to an immigration court and a veterans' office, shortly after 5:00 pm on Friday.

site_title: China rocked by second deadly chemical plant blast in two weeks
summary: A deadly chemical plant blast in eastern China's Shandong province killed one person and injured nine, occurring less than two weeks after a similar blast in the northeast. The explosion destroyed a factory producing adiponitrile, a poisonous liquid, and authorities reported no contamination. The incident raises concerns about safety standards in China, where industrial accidents are common. The blast is the second major chemical plant disaster in China this month, following a devastating warehouse explosion in Tianjin that killed at least 121 people.

site_title: Veil soon to be lifted on new Millennium thriller
summary: Swedish publisher Norstedts is set to release "The Girl in the Spider's Web", the sequel to Stieg Larsson's best-selling "Millennium crime trilogy". The 500-page novel, written by David Lagercrantz, follows Lisbeth Salander and Mikael Blomkvist, and has been shrouded in secrecy due to confidentiality agreements. The book's release has sparked controversy, with some accusing the publisher and author of milking the cash cow, while others praise the novel's anticipation and potential to find an audience.

site_title: No easy choices when it comes to immigration, foreigner policy
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the difficulty in making decisions on immigration and foreigner policy, stating that every option has a cost and a downside. He acknowledged the need to find a balance, but also warned of potential pains and consequences, including economic impact and social changes. The government has implemented various measures to reduce reliance on foreign labor and ensure fairness for Singaporeans, which have shown material results. Lee stressed his responsibility to make decisions that safeguard the country's interests and account to the people.

site_title: Singapore legal officer in 1MDB probe sacked based on contract terms: Malaysia Attorney-General
summary: A Singaporean legal officer, Jessica Gurmeet Kaur, involved in the 1MDB probe, had her contract terminated by Malaysia's Attorney-General Mohamed Apandi Ali, citing terms of service. This move comes after sources revealed her sudden sacking. No further comment was made by Apandi Ali.

site_title: New housing grant, enhanced baby bonus for all Singaporean families: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced a series of measures to support families and their babies, including a new housing grant, an enhanced Baby Bonus scheme, increased Medisave Grant for Newborns, and longer paternity leave. The new housing grant will help couples live closer to their parents, while the Baby Bonus will be increased for every child. The Medisave Grant will cover MediShield Life premiums until age 21, and paternity leave will be extended by an additional week, with the government paying for the extra week. The changes will take effect from January 1, 2015.

site_title: Australian beaches closed after latest shark attack
summary: Australian beaches on the east coast were closed after a 38-year-old man suffered life-threatening injuries in a shark attack while bodyboarding off Lighthouse Beach, about 400km north of Sydney. This incident follows two other shark attacks at a nearby location just weeks prior. The victim was treated at Port Macquarie Hospital and was in a stable condition on Sunday morning.

site_title: National Day Rally 2015: Singapore's next 50 years
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's National Day Rally 2015 emphasized the need for Singapore's survival in the years ahead, covering key issues such as population, education, and housing. The government plans to increase housing grants and baby bonuses, raise income ceilings for HDB flats and executive condos, and raise the re-employment age to 67 by 2017. A general election is expected to be called "soon" to secure a new mandate.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's National Day Rally 2015 on Sunday covered issues that were important to Singaporeans, such as population, education, family and housing.

site_title: GuocoLand group president and CEO retires
summary: GuocoLand's group president and CEO Chia Boon Kuah is retiring at the end of August after less than two years in the role. He will be replaced by Raymond Choong Yee How, a 59-year-old veteran of the financial industry with over 30 years of experience. Chia's departure follows a series of high-profile departures at GuocoLand, including several top executives who left within a year of joining the group. Choong's appointment is seen as an internal transfer, citing his in-depth knowledge of GuocoLand's policies and business values.

site_title: Freeport king's assets unfrozen by court
summary: A Swiss businessman and art dealer, Yves Bouvier, had his assets frozen by a Russian billionaire over alleged mark-ups on masterpieces by Picasso and Van Gogh. However, the Court of Appeal has now unfrozen his assets, ruling that there was no real risk of him dissipating his wealth. The court found that Bouvier was not likely to dissipate his assets due to a lack of evidence. This decision comes after a worldwide Mareva injunction was lifted.

site_title: Singapore Institute of Technology to get new campus in Punggol: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) will relocate to a new campus in Punggol, integrated into the Northshore District and Punggol Downtown. The move aims to provide more degree opportunities to polytechnic graduates and increase undergraduate intake to 3,500 in 2020. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the plan during the National Day Rally, with JTC developing a creative industry cluster nearby. A permanent campus construction timeline has not been revealed.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Improving healthcare in Asia with data
summary: In Asia-Pacific, technology is playing a key role in improving healthcare, particularly for the elderly and those with chronic diseases. The region's aging population and growing middle-class are driving demand for healthcare services, leading to rising costs. To address this, governments are providing subsidies and mandatory medical insurance, while technology is being harnessed to improve productivity, access to expertise, and infrastructure efficiencies. Wearable devices, the Internet of Things, and big data analytics are being used to monitor patients, predict falls, and provide real-time feedback on health risks. Electronic health records and smart city initiatives are also being implemented to improve care and reduce costs.

site_title: Switzerland opens criminal proceedings linked to 1MDB
summary: Switzerland's Office of the Attorney General has opened criminal proceedings against two entities of 1MDB, a Malaysian state investment fund, for suspected corruption, dishonest management of public interests, and money laundering. The case involves alleged financial mismanagement and a US$11 billion debt. This follows communications from the Money Laundering Reporting Office Switzerland and a check by the Swiss financial regulator FINMA on banks' dealings with 1MDB. The move comes amid ongoing investigations into 1MDB's activities in Malaysia.

site_title: AA workers say they face racial taunts, discrimination
summary: A group of Black American Airlines employees at Reagan National and Philadelphia International airports have filed a complaint with US Attorney General Loretta Lynch alleging they face racial taunts, discrimination, and unsafe working conditions. They claim they are assigned difficult tasks and equipment, and have been subjected to derogatory remarks, including the use of the n-word. American Airlines denies the allegations, stating that their training procedures and equipment comply with government safety regulations. The employees are seeking an investigation into their claims, which have been filed with the Federal Aviation Administration and Occupational Safety and Health Administration.

site_title: North, South Korea talk all night, to resume Sunday, in bid to end standoff
summary: North Korean and South Korean officials held a late-night meeting at the Demilitarised Zone (DMZ) on Saturday, resuming talks on Sunday to ease tensions that brought the peninsula to the brink of armed conflict. The talks, which broke before dawn, aim to resolve tensions and improve ties between the two countries. North Korea wants to stop anti-Pyongyang propaganda broadcasts, while South Korea cannot do so without achieving something in return. The United Nations, US, and China have called for calm amid the crisis, which escalated after North Korea fired shells into the South and Seoul responded with artillery rounds.

site_title: Landlords cash out amid Manhattan property boom
summary: Landlords in Manhattan are cashing out amid a surge in property values and rents, with some selling vacant plots of land for record prices. The US$29.4 billion in Manhattan property deals completed in the first half of 2015 is a record, driven by institutional investors seeking investment havens. Developers are seizing the opportunity to profit now rather than moving ahead with construction plans, with the average capitalisation rate for office buildings in Manhattan falling to 4.1%. This glut of capital is making good deals harder to find, sparking concern that US real estate values may be over-inflating.

images.alt_text: There's so much buyer demand that in some situations it's more opportune for landlords to sell rather than follow through on plans for redevelopment or filling buildings with new tenants.

site_title: Syriza splits as Tsipras looks to bolster power with ballot
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is seeking to bolster his power by calling an early election after a group of 25 lawmakers opposed to the country's bailout program, known as Syriza, broke away and formed a new bloc called Popular Unity led by former energy minister Panagiotis Lafazanis.

site_title: Uniqlo to try out 4-day workweek
summary: Uniqlo, a Japanese retailer, will offer a four-day workweek to about 10,000 full-time employees starting in October. The trial, which will include 10-hour workdays and Saturday and Sunday shifts, aims to retain full-time talent and address overwork issues. This move comes as some Japanese companies are rethinking the traditionally long workday, with about 22% of Japanese workers putting in more than 49 hours a week. The trial's success will determine if the perk will be introduced at corporate headquarters and more stores.

site_title: PAP announces line-up for Holland-Bukit Timah GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its lineup for the Holland-Bukit Timah Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in the upcoming Singapore general election. The four-man team, led by Minister Vivian Balakrishnan, consists of Ministers Sim Ann and Liang Eng Hwa, and MP Christopher de Souza. This lineup will defend the GRC against opposition candidates.

site_title: PAP introduces 2 new faces in Pasir Ris-Punggol team
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has introduced two new faces to the Pasir Ris-Punggol team for the upcoming election: former defence chief Ng Chee Meng and Temasek Holdings investment director Sun Xueling. This move aims to refresh the team and provide new perspectives to the constituency.

site_title: HDB, executive condo income ceilings to rise: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced changes to HDB flats and executive condominiums (ECs), increasing income ceilings from $10,000 to $12,000 for HDB and $12,000 to $14,000 for ECs. The changes aim to allow more Singaporeans to buy new flats. Additionally, the Special CPF Housing Grant (SHG) will be extended to cover more households, with the household income ceiling raised from $6,500 to $8,500 and the maximum SHG amount doubled to $40,000. A "Fresh Start Housing Scheme" will also be implemented to help second-time rental households own a two-room flat.

site_title: US passengers overpower gunman who fired in Amsterdam-Paris train
summary: A gunman opened fire on a high-speed train from Amsterdam to Paris on Friday, injuring at least two people before being overpowered by two American passengers. The suspect, a 26-year-old from Morocco or of Moroccan origin, was arrested at a French railway station. He had a Kalashnikov and automatic pistol, and was known to French intelligence services. The motive for the shooting is not immediately known, and counter-terrorism investigators have taken over the probe.

site_title: Oil ends down more than 2% as US drilling points to glut
summary: US oil prices fell below $40 a barrel for the first time since 2009, ending 2% lower on Friday, amid signs of US oversupply and weak Chinese manufacturing. US crude prices dropped to $40.45 a barrel, with Brent oil falling 2.5% to $45.46 a barrel. The decline is attributed to US energy firms adding oil drilling rigs, prolonging a global glut. The market is expected to continue its downtrend, with speculators cutting bullish bets on US crude to the lowest level in five years.

site_title: US: Wall Street plunges on global economic worries
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, with the S&P 500 experiencing its largest daily percentage drop in nearly four years due to fears of a China-led global slowdown. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.12%, the S&P 500 lost 3.18%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 3.52%. The decline was attributed to global economic worries and uncertainty surrounding US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Europe: Stocks suffer worst 1-day fall in nearly 4 years
summary: Europe's stocks plummeted 3.40% on Friday, marking their worst one-day fall in nearly four years, amid growing concerns over China's economy. The FTSEurofirst 300 index closed at 1,427.13 points, its lowest level since January. Investors were spooked by China's Caixin/Markit manufacturing index, which showed the factory sector shrank at its fastest pace in almost 6-1/2 years. The decline also affected Greece's Athens stock market, which fell 2.5% after Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras resigned.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Thaksin's son doubles reward for hunt of suspect
summary: A deadly bomb blast at Bangkok's Erawan shrine killed 20 people, mostly tourists, on Monday. Police are investigating the attack, which they believe was planned and coordinated by a network, and have offered a 3 million baht (S$118,560) reward for information leading to the suspect. Thaksin Shinawatra's son, Panthongtae, has doubled the reward to 7 million baht (S$280,732) for informant and arrest information. The attack is the worst single mass casualty in Thailand's living memory, with experts suggesting it may not have been in the best interest of either side of Thailand's ongoing bitter power struggle.
