site_title: PAP unveils slate in Tampines GRC, ropes in Desmond Choo and new face
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) unveiled its slate of candidates for Tampines GRC, replacing veteran MPs Irene Ng and Mah Bow Tan with Desmond Choo and new face Cheng Li Hui. The move signals a shift to new blood ahead of the upcoming election.

images.alt_text: The People's Action Party (PAP) on Saturday officially unveiled its slate of candidates for Tampines group representative constituency (GRC), with two veteran MPs stepping down to make way for new blood at the coming election.

site_title: Apple raises A$2.25b in Aussie debt debut
summary: Apple has raised A$2.25 billion in its debut Australian debt sale, the largest ever by a non-financial company in the country. The seven-year and four-year notes were sold at yields of 110 basis points and 65 basis points more than swap rates, respectively. The deal eclipses the previous largest non-financial company bond sale of A$1 billion from BHP Billiton in March. The proceeds may be used to return capital to shareholders. Apple's strong credit rating and well-known brand helped attract international and domestic investors.

site_title: The question voters must ask themselves
summary: Singaporean Minister Lawrence Wong says the next general election is about whether voters want to strengthen their "special partnership" with the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) to build an even better Singapore. Wong emphasized the importance of trust between the PAP and the people, and the need for the party to build a better community and provide more services for residents. The PAP has unveiled its four-member team for the newly formed Marsiling-Yew Tee Group Representation Constituency (GRC), led by Wong and Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob.

site_title: North Korea goes on war footing against South Korea as deadline looms
summary: North Korea has put its troops on high alert as a deadline for South Korea to stop anti-Pyongyang propaganda broadcasts approaches. South Korea rejected the ultimatum, prompting China to call for calm and urging both sides to step back. The two countries have exchanged artillery fire, with North Korea launching four shells into South Korea and South Korea firing back 29 rounds. The US has resumed its annual joint military exercises with South Korea, and China has expressed concern about the escalating tensions. Diplomats say the situation is "very, very low" risk of war, but tensions could still rise.

site_title: Currency turmoil can be boon to Latin American exporters
summary: Latin American exporters may benefit from the current currency turmoil, as countries like Colombia, Brazil, and Mexico see record-low foreign-exchange rates, making their exports cheaper. The weaker currencies will boost growth and competitiveness, particularly for manufacturers in countries like Mexico, which is poised to benefit from a stronger US economy. However, experts warn that the gains may be temporary, as the currencies' declines could lead to financial instability and undermine economic growth.

site_title: Perennial, Shangri-La tie up for mixed-use project in Ghana
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings and Shangri-La Asia have partnered to develop a 49,874 sqm mixed-use project in Ghana's capital city Accra. The project, valued at over US$250 million, will feature a hotel, residential towers, office tower, shopping mall, and serviced apartments. The joint venture will be funded through the sale of non-residential components and is expected to be completed by 2019. The investment aims to leverage on the sponsors' experience and network to achieve first-mover advantage in emerging markets.

images.alt_text: ARTIST'S IMPRESSION: The development will have a hotel, residential towers, an office tower, a shopping mall and serviced apartments.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality buys property in Dalian
summary: Frasers Hospitality has acquired a serviced residence in Dalian, China, as part of plans to double its presence in the country. The 259-unit Fraser Suites Dalian is scheduled to open in 2017 and offers an internal rate of return "north of 8 per cent". The acquisition brings Frasers' portfolio in China to 30 properties with over 7,000 keys by 2019, with the company aiming to reach 30,000 keys globally by 2018-19.

site_title: Happy meals in the air
summary: ANA, Japan's largest carrier, offers an authentic Japanese cuisine experience on its flights, including traditional multi-course meals and top chefs' signature dishes. The airline works with renowned chefs to design menus, such as those from Tsuyama and Hakata Ippudo, and serves meals developed by these restaurants, including a signature "full flavor Daichi" ramen. To replicate the restaurant-level dining experience in-flight, ANA employs a team of over 800 staff and uses a bento box system, reheating items separately to maintain freshness.

site_title: Election Digest
summary: The Singapore Democratic Alliance (SDA) released its election manifesto, the first to do so, aiming to build a "Singapore for Singaporeans". The manifesto tackles various issues including the Population White Paper, CPF minimum sum, housing, healthcare, and education. The party also plans to repeal the CPF minimum sum and allow individuals to withdraw their monies. Meanwhile, the SPP-DPP joint team in Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC is taking shape, with former sales manager Law Kim Hwee and training company owner Abdillah Zamzuri joining the team.

site_title: Inflation holds the key to Fed's 'lift-off'
summary: Federal Reserve officials are considering lifting interest rates as soon as September, but inflation holds the key to how far they can go. Despite solid US jobs growth, inflation remains stagnant, with current and former officials warning that "real" rates would rise faster than desired, threatening the recovery. Fed officials must see prices accelerate to justify further rate hikes, and recent research suggests that inflation dynamics have changed, making it harder to predict.

site_title: The three gluts
summary: The global macro outlook is driven by the interaction among three "gluts": the savings glut, the oil glut, and the money glut. The savings glut, fueled by excess global desired saving over global desired investment, depresses low long-term interest rates. The oil glut helps lift demand growth, inflation, and interest rates by shifting income from oil producers to consumers. The money glut, fueled by central bank policies, pushes real interest rates lower. The combined effect of the three gluts is expected to result in global growth, inflation, and interest rates remaining lower than in previous cycles, with a pickup in global economic activity and inflation over the cyclical horizon, and bond yields rising moderately.

site_title: Light and clean
summary: Luca Fantin, executive chef at Bulgari Il Ristorante Luca Fantin in Tokyo, faces challenges in sourcing seafood due to his foreign status. Japanese suppliers are wary of selling to him, but he convinces them by inviting them for dinner, establishing a long-term working relationship. Despite being close to Tsukiji Market, Fantin prefers to buy from local suppliers to suit his contemporary cooking style, transforming traditional Japanese cuisine.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Thieves steal Rodin sculpture in Denmark
summary: A bronze bust of French sculptor Auguste Rodin's "Man with a Broken Nose" was stolen from a Copenhagen museum on July 16, 2015, in broad daylight. The thieves, described as two men of east European appearance, disabled the alarm system a week earlier. Surveillance footage shows them taking down the bust, placing it in bags, and calmly walking out. The police have issued descriptions and reported the theft to Interpol and Europol, suggesting it will be difficult for the thieves to sell the statue. The museum has not estimated the value of the stolen piece.

site_title: Asia's oil market caught in China rivalry
summary: China's top oil traders, Chinaoil and Unipec, are engaged in a fierce rivalry for control of Asia's crude benchmark, driving up Middle East crude prices. The two state-owned firms have been aggressively trading, with Chinaoil buying record numbers of oil cargoes and Unipec selling, resulting in a sharp build-up in Dubai futures. The rivalry has pushed up prices, benefiting Chinaoil, while Asian buyers seek cheaper oil elsewhere or cut refinery runs. Analysts say Beijing is unlikely to intervene, allowing the Chinese pair to displace global players and dominate the Dubai market.

images.alt_text: An intensifying rivalry between China's two top oil traders Chinaoil and Unipec is whipsawing Asia's oil market, pitting the state-owned firms against each other in a battle for control of the region's crude benchmark.

site_title: Bento box
summary: The Mitsubishi Attrage is a compact, entry-level sedan that offers basic point-to-point motoring with some welcomed frills. Despite its utilitarian roots, the car provides a fun driving experience, thanks to its continuously variable transmission and 78hp engine. The Attrage's interior is rudimentary but quality is acceptable, with features like automatic climate control and Bluetooth connectivity. While it lacks grunt for overtaking, the car is enjoyable to drive and corners well, making it a good runabout for daily use.

site_title: Seagull Gayatri lead charge into fourth round
summary: Seagull Gayatri leads the BT Corporate Golf League with 316 points, ahead of Bank of Singapore (OCBC) with 308 points. Boustead is in third place with 305 points. Audi Singapore, Audemars Piguet, and Garuda Indonesia are sponsors offering prizes, including a watch and a hole-in-one Audi A6. The competition continues with the fourth round set to tee off next week, shaping up to be an exciting final three rounds.

site_title: Binjai Rise mortgagee-sale GCB sold for about S$13m
summary: A partially completed Good Class Bungalow (GCB) at 15 Binjai Rise in Singapore was sold for approximately S$13 million, or about S$763 per square foot, after two rounds of auctions and a tender. The property, located next to the Pan Island Expressway, received little interest due to its noisy location. This sale reflects the recent softening of GCB prices, with other similar properties selling for lower prices in recent months.

site_title: The empire strikes back
summary: Turkish designer Sevan Bicakci is showcasing his collection at Edit Lifestyle in Singapore, featuring statement jewelry inspired by Ottoman and Byzantine empires. His designs combine intricate techniques, such as intaglio and mosaic, to create unique pieces. Bicakci's work is influenced by Turkish culture and history, including the Hagia Sophia, and often features miniature representations of iconic landmarks. The collection is priced from $10,000, with some pieces taking over a year to complete. Bicakci's work has gained recognition globally, with boutiques in Istanbul, Dubai, and London, and he is set to present his work in Asia for the first time.

site_title: Oxley's Q4 profit up 70% at S$16.6m; full-year earnings lower
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singapore-based property developer, reported a 70% surge in Q4 net profit to S$16.6 million, driven by a 134% increase in revenue to S$193.8 million. However, the company's full-year profit after tax and minority interests fell 79% to S$60.9 million due to the completion of an industrial development project. Oxley is cautiously optimistic about the business outlook for the next 12 months, citing diversification efforts and strategic partnerships.

site_title: PAP names its candidates for the fights in three single-seat wards
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has named its candidates for the upcoming general election in three single-seat wards: Mountbatten, Hong Kah North, and MacPherson. Incumbent MPs Lim Biow Chuan, Amy Khor, and Tin Pei Ling will defend their seats, with Tin Pei Ling facing a three-way fight against the Workers' Party and National Solidarity Party. The NSP has unexpectedly fielded a candidate in MacPherson, while the WP has yet to announce its candidate for the ward.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

PAP'S YOUNGEST: Ms Tin, who gave birth to her first child two weeks ago, will defend her MacPherson ward as a single-seat candidate this time, instead of as one of the slate of candidates in Marine Parade GRC, like in GE2011.
TWO OTHER SINGLE-SEAT FACES: Ms Khor (left) raked in 70.6 per cent of the votes against her SPP opponent in GE2011 and was the best performer. Mr Lim says he has been working hard on the ground.

site_title: Over the moon
summary: Several Singapore hotels and restaurants are offering unique and creative mooncake flavors for the Mid-Autumn festival. The Fullerton Hotel features a red mooncake box with a golden plum blossom design, while InterContinental Singapore offers a 20th-anniversary collector's edition with maple-glazed Shanghai mooncake. Shangri-La Hotel, Singapore, features custom-made satin boxes with peach-blossom embroidery, and Grand Hyatt Singapore offers adventurous flavors like Lime Margarita Truffle and Peanut Butter, Sea Salt Truffle. Other hotels, such as Orchard Hotel, Peony Jade, and Regent Singapore, also offer a range of mooncake flavors, including durian, chocolate, and tea-infused options.

site_title: Dream teams (Amended)
summary: Companies are partnering to offer a more comprehensive experience for consumers. National Gallery Singapore has partnered with &Co, a collective of industry experts, to create a cafe and museum shop called Gallery & Co. The project, set to open on November 24, will feature a curated retail experience with specially designed products, a cafe, and a museum shop. The team, consisting of Loh Lik Peng, Yu Yah-Leng, Arthur Chin, and Alwyn Chong, aims to create a unique space that infuses art and design into a retail experience.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: China suffers sharpest contraction in factory activity in 6 1/2 years
summary: China's factory activity contracted at its fastest pace in 6 1/2 years, with the Caixin/Markit China Manufacturing PMI falling to 47.1 in August, down from 47.8 in July. The reading is the worst since March 2009, with factory output sinking to a near four-year low, domestic and export orders declining, and companies laying off workers. The contraction adds to concerns about China's slowing economy, which may impact global growth, and has sparked worries of a hard landing.

site_title: A hundred apps bloom in China as millions bank on their smartphones
summary: China's digital banking, investing, and lending have become mainstream, with technology companies such as Tencent, Alibaba, and Baidu leading the way with financial apps. The country's 1.3 billion people and $7.8 trillion of deposits have created a lucrative market for tech companies. Mainland China is where digital innovation is having a significant impact, with over 390 million people registered for mobile banking and digital wallets processing billions of payments. Traditional state-owned banks are struggling to keep up, while private sector companies are challenging them for market share.

images.alt_text: EXPLOSIVE GROWTH: 390 million people in China have registered to use mobile banking - more than the entire population of the US.

site_title: A staunch supporter of the League
summary: Team Centurion, a stalwart supporter of the Business Times Corporate Golf League, has been fielding a team since 2010 and sponsoring the event annually for S$20,000. Led by captain Jeffrey Fones, the team is currently in 12th position, with the key strategy being to score as best as possible. The event is seen as an opportunity for staff, business associates, and friends to socialize over golf and dinner. The team's participation and sponsorship have been consistent, with Fones stating it's a "social game" rather than a competitive one.

site_title: Bangkok blast will hit earnings, hoteliers warn
summary: Bangkok hoteliers warn that a recent bomb attack will impact earnings and reduce revenue growth forecasts this year. The Erawan Group, with its Grand Hyatt Erawan near the shrine, cut its 2015 revenue growth target to 28% from 35% due to reduced occupancy rates. Central Plaza Hotel Pcl, with its Centara Grand hotel near the shrine, is also expected to miss its 2015 revenue target of 20 billion baht. The situation is expected to return to normal in six to eight weeks if no further violence occurs.

site_title: When it comes to China, there's always a catch
summary: China's economic turmoil has investors rethinking their strategies. The country's currency dropped sharply last week, prompting Wall Street to seek opportunities in price differences between the onshore and offshore renminbi. Despite the recent market volatility, hedge funds continue to be drawn to China, with many riding the bull run until it suddenly collapsed. The Chinese government's aggressive intervention to stop the slide has cast doubt on market reform efforts. Investors are finding new ways to play the turmoil, including betting on currencies affected by the renminbi devaluation.

site_title: Silverlake hit by anonymous shortselling report
summary: Silverlake Axis, a Singapore-based software solutions provider, saw its shares plummet 27% on Friday after an anonymous report accused the company of engaging in murky related-party transactions, which allegedly created potential for fraudulent abuse. The report, authored by "razor99", recommended shorting the stock, citing a 42-page document that highlighted the company's complex web of private companies connected to its founder and chairman. The Singapore Exchange queried the company on the unusual price movements, while analysts suggested that the company could fight such allegations by providing more detailed disclosures on related-party transactions.

site_title: Deutsche Bank 'haggis' team out to poach RBS's cashflow clients
summary: Deutsche Bank has formed a team, known as the "haggis" team, to poach RBS's largest cashflow clients as RBS retreats from commercial banking outside the UK. The team, led by Deutsche Bank's global transaction banking team, aims to win lucrative cash and trade management mandates from 200 targeted firms. This move is expected to generate long-term, fee-based income streams for Deutsche Bank and counterbalance its less profitable trading arm. The bank has already secured business from at least 60% of its targeted clients, and RBS will refer thousands of its biggest customers to BNP Paribas.

site_title: Mini debt crisis in China province
summary: A mini debt crisis is unfolding in northern China's Hebei province, exposing weaknesses in the country's US$430 billion loan-guarantee industry. State-backed guarantee companies, such as Hebei Financing Investment Guarantee Group, are struggling to meet guarantees on loans that have gone sour, posing a risk to lenders and the overall financial system. The crisis highlights the challenges facing China's economic revival plan, which relies heavily on the guarantee industry to facilitate finance for smaller businesses.

site_title: Halimah confident of representing residents, even with Speaker role
summary: Singaporean MP Halimah Yacob believes she can effectively represent her constituents despite being the Speaker of Parliament, which restricts her ability to raise concerns in the House. In response to a query, Halimah stated she sees no incompatibility between her roles.

images.alt_text: Madam Halimah Yacob, Speaker of Parliament. She was the first woman to be appointed to the post.

site_title: Rough ride ahead as STI loses grip on 3,000 level
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell below the 3,000-point mark, its lowest level since November 2012, marking the fifth consecutive decline. The index ended the day at 2,971.01, down 38.77 points or 1.3% from Thursday's close. Widespread weakness in the market, with losers outnumbering gainers 368 to 129, and regional markets such as Shanghai and Hong Kong also suffered losses. Analysts attribute the decline to worries over China's economy and the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike.

site_title: Xi said to put population over growth in China economic plan
summary: President Xi Jinping is considering prioritizing population growth over economic growth in China's development blueprint, according to a person familiar with the discussions. This shift could lead to rule changes on healthcare, social welfare, pensions, and possibly lifting family planning caps. The focus on population policies sets the stage for significant changes in various areas, potentially affecting China's economic rise.

site_title: Probe news hits stocks in Pacific Andes stable
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) are investigating Pacific Andes Resources Development (PARD) and its subsidiary China Fishery Group under the Securities and Futures Act for an unspecified offence. This probe led to significant share price drops, with PARD's Singapore-listed stock shedding 28.6% and its Hong Kong-listed parent Pacific Andes International Holdings (PAIH) dropping 30.8%. The companies are required to provide documents and information related to dealings with third parties, and the investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Ultra mien
summary: The Audi A6 1.8 TFSI ultra S tronic is the most efficient engine in its range, consuming just 5.7 liters per 100km and producing 190 hp with 320 Newton-metres of torque. Despite its efficiency, the car delivers a surprisingly enthusiastic drive, accelerating from 0-100km/h in 7.9 seconds. The 2015 Audi A6 has been refreshed with new exterior and interior features, including LED headlights and a new gear lever, while maintaining its luxury and refinement.

images.alt_text: HOST OF CHANGES: On the outside, new Matrix Beam LED headlights with dynamic turn signals make the car look sharper and lower.
HOST OF CHANGES: Inside, there is a new gear lever and a lovely matte wood trim. The windscreen and front windows are double-glazed
HOST OF CHANGES: Inside, there is a new gear lever and a lovely matte wood trim. The windscreen and front windows are double-glazed

site_title: 'Now Showing': Indonesian cinema sector ripe for growth
summary: Indonesia's cinema sector is poised to triple in size over the next decade, driven by the country's growing middle class and increasing demand for entertainment. The sector, currently valued at US$250 million annually, is expected to reach US$750 million by 2025. New entrants, such as Cinemaxx, backed by the Lippo Group, are expanding rapidly, with plans to build 450 screens over the next two years and up to 2,000 screens in the next decade. The sector is expected to drive economic growth and boost the services industry, with competition driving better service and wider geographical spread.

site_title: Keppel hosts 100 seniors on cruise
summary: Keppel Group hosted a charity cruise for nearly 100 senior citizens from the Thye Hua Kwan Senior Activity Centre, as a gesture of appreciation for Singapore's Jubilee Year. The 14-vessel convoy, owned by Singaporeans and permanent residents, cruised around the island's waters, sharing interesting facts about landmarks with the seniors. The event was organized by Keppel volunteers, led by Keppel Land CEO Ang Wee, who emphasized the importance of strong foundations and contributions made by pioneers. The one-hour tour aimed to bring joy and connection to the seniors.

site_title: European banks set for asset-backed debt relief in EU market overhaul
summary: The European Commission proposes a regulation to revitalize the securitization market in the EU, aiming to revive corporate lending and increase credit to small and medium-sized enterprises. The draft regulation would cut the minimum risk weight on securitisations by 5 percentage points to 10%, allowing banks to award a "simple, transparent and standardized" (STS) label without prior checks, and lifting a burden on investors. This is part of the EU's capital markets union plan, estimated to provide 100-157 billion euros in additional credit to households and businesses.

site_title: Ringgit flight continues, currency hits fresh 17-year low
summary: The Malaysian ringgit plummeted to a fresh 17-year low of 4.1855 against the US dollar, falling about one percent. International reserves fell to US$94.5 billion, enough to finance external debt and retained imports. Central bank governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz maintained the reserves are at a comfortable level, but investors remain wary of capital controls and a fixed currency peg. Prime Minister Najib Razak's assurances have failed to boost confidence, with analysts citing a trust deficit stemming from the 1MDB scandal and his personal financial dealings.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian ringgit hit a 16-year low on July 6, 2015

site_title: Toyota to buy 13 million air bag inflators from Takata rival
summary: Toyota Motor Corp plans to buy over 13 million air bag inflators from Nippon Kayaku Co, a move to reduce its risk from potentially lethal Takata Corp inflators. The deal, valued at around $100-150 million, aims to replace high-risk inflators in vehicles that are aging and may become dangerous. Toyota seeks to switch to Nippon Kayaku inflators to meet demand and replace older inflators first, with the goal of reducing recalls and costs.

site_title: SoftBank's hired gun takes high road to ownership
summary: Nikesh Arora, a former Google executive, is investing 60 billion yen (S$688 million) in SoftBank's shares, taking a high-risk approach to ownership. This is a rare move for a tech executive, as most receive stock-based pay schemes. The investment cements Arora's position as the eventual successor to SoftBank's founder, Masayoshi Son. Arora's bold move may also help win support for SoftBank's corporate wagers, including investments in Alibaba and solar energy. However, this approach also carries a significant risk of failure, as seen with former Apple executive Ron Johnson's stint at JC Penney.

site_title: Tasty bites to keep up the energy
summary: Delifrance, a bakery company, has partnered with the BT Corporate Golf League for the second consecutive year as a sponsor. Delifrance supplies 480 savory and sweet items per round to golfers, including mini puff pastries, pizza baguettes, and quiches. The sponsorship costs S$3,864 and aims to increase the company's branding awareness among executive golfers.

images.alt_text: SWEET AND SAVOURY: Delifrance's mini- viennoiseries (above) and mini-quiche. The company is supplying 480 items for each round of the competition.
SWEET AND SAVOURY: Delifrance's mini- viennoiseries and mini-quiche (above). The company is supplying 480 items for each round of the competition.

site_title: Blood thinners: when is it safe to stop?
summary: Patients with significant heart artery narrowing who undergo percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stents are often prescribed blood-thinning medications for 12 months after emergency PCI or 6 months after non-emergency cases. However, stopping these medications too early can lead to blood clots and heart attacks. Current guidelines recommend continuing DAPT for at least 12 months after emergency PCI, but a shorter period can be considered for non-emergency cases. Some studies suggest that second-generation stents with near-complete coverage of stent struts can discontinue anti-platelet treatment, but patients with residual heart artery disease or uncontrolled risk factors should continue a single anti-platelet agent.

site_title: US factory activity slows in August
summary: US factory activity slowed in August, with the manufacturing sector's Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 52.9, its lowest since October 2013. Job creation also slowed, with the index at 52.2, its weakest since July 2014. The strong dollar and global economic uncertainty continued to pressure export sales and client spending. Economists expect policymakers to keep a dovish stance, with the US growth momentum seen as weak.

site_title: US oil prices fall for 8th week after grim China factory data
summary: US oil prices fell for the 8th consecutive week, the longest losing streak since 1986, amid concerns over China's manufacturing slowdown. Chinese factory activity shrank at its fastest pace in almost 6.5 years, increasing worries over lower oil consumption. Global oil benchmarks are near 6.5-year lows, with US crude down 25 cents to $41.07 a barrel. The market is expected to remain in a downtrend, driven by ample supply and concerns over slowing Chinese growth.

images.alt_text: PRICES HEAD SOUTH: Brent oil was on track for its seventh weekly decline, down 30 US cents at US$46.32 a barrel, after settling 54 US cents lower on Thursday.

site_title: Sept rate hike chances fade as markets plunge
summary: Global stocks plummeted on Friday as China's manufacturing sector shrunk for the first time since 2009, citing a 77-month low in the Caixin China general manufacturing purchasing managers' index. Emerging markets crumbled, while developed markets wobbled. Market stress led to a decline in US 10-year bond yields and reduced expectations for a September interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. In contrast, China's central bank is expected to ease further, with analysts predicting reserve requirement ratio cuts to bolster confidence in the economy.

site_title: Fire at Shell's oil refinery in Singapore injures six workers
summary: A fire broke out at Shell's oil refinery in Pulau Bukom, Singapore, on Friday evening, injuring six contractor workers. The workers were sent to the hospital, with two later discharged after outpatient treatment. Shell has offered support and assistance to the injured workers and their families.

site_title: Costa brews up a strategy for the future of coffee
summary: Costa Coffee, a global coffee chain, has doubled its stores globally in five years, driven by the rise of the mobile-work culture and the decline of pubs as a meeting place. The company has over 3,000 outlets worldwide and continues to grow at a 20% compound rate per year. Costa attributes its success to a strong domestic expansion, international network, and self-serve coffee machine business. The company is also embracing technological advancements, such as pre-pay and mobile-payment systems, to enhance customer experience. Despite growth, Costa remains committed to its heritage and quality roasting.

images.alt_text: WE FILL A NEED: Costa Coffee's managing director Christopher Rogers says coffeeshops are comfortable places to relax, clock some 'me' time, meet friends, read or just to sit.

site_title: Weaker Opec members panic as oil slide continues
summary: Weaker Opec members are urging Saudi Arabia to cut oil production due to the eight-week price slide to its lowest levels since 2008. The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts a global oil glut could last until the end of 2016, despite low prices encouraging consumption. Weaker Opec nations, including Algeria, Libya, and Venezuela, are under financial pressure and fear that Saudi Arabia's production strategy will fail. The US Energy Information Administration reports only marginal declines in US petroleum production, and Iran's nuclear deal with the US could lead to a surge in oil supplies.

site_title: PM Lee releases teaser for Sunday's National Day Rally speech
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has released a teaser for his National Day Rally speech, hinting at policies on housing, education, and families, as well as musical entertainment. The speech will take place on Sunday, providing a preview of the government's plans for the country's citizens.

site_title: Japan warns China against frequent yuan devaluations to prop up economy
summary: Japan's Minister of Finance Taro Aso warned China against frequent yuan devaluations to prop up its economy, citing Japan's own yen devaluation of 35% in 2 years. China's factory activity has fallen to its lowest level in over 5 years, causing Asian stock prices to slump. If China intervenes in the market, Japan will face a tough decision on how to respond, according to Aso.

site_title: Reverse innovation in India
summary: Reverse innovation is a growing trend in India, where companies are developing innovative products to address local needs, often at a lower cost. GE Healthcare's low-cost baby warmer is a prime example, designed to handle India's unstable power supply and simplify technology. This approach, known as "reverse innovation," is changing the flow of ideas and saving lives. With 26 healthcare products conceptualized and manufactured in this way, engineers say India is the perfect place to innovate, leveraging local knowledge and intellectual capacity to create affordable solutions.

site_title: Private equity firms bid for Tesco's US$6b South Korea unit-sources
summary: Private equity firms Affinity Equity Partners, KKR & Co, and Carlyle Group have formed teams to bid for Tesco's South Korean business valued at approximately US$6 billion. Three separate teams will compete for the unit, which includes over 900 stores and annual revenue of US$5.9 billion. The sale process reflects Tesco's efforts to improve its financials after an accounting scandal and market share losses in Britain. The final bids are due on August 24, with the potential for Asia's biggest ever private equity deal.

site_title: Caesars said to revive plan talks as bankruptcy probe looms
summary: Caesars Entertainment Corp has restarted talks with senior lenders of its bankrupt unit ahead of a court investigation expected to be completed by November. The discussions aim to win creditor support for a restructuring plan, which would cut nearly half of the unit's $19.9 billion obligations. However, lenders disagree on conditions, hindering the plan's progress. The bankruptcy probe, led by former federal prosecutor Richard Davis, is examining transactions since Caesars' private acquisition in 2008. The company's reorganization plan would create a complex web of new companies with new debt.

site_title: US pilots report surge in drone close calls
summary: US pilots have reported a surge in close calls with drones, with nearly 700 incidents this year, nearly triple the number from 2014. Rogue drones have disrupted air traffic, snarling air traffic, and forced fighter jets to scramble. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has acknowledged growing concern but has been unable to regulate the sales boom of small, largely unregulated remote-control aircraft. Incidents have occurred near airports, the White House, and other sensitive sites, with the Secret Service reporting a rogue drone hovering near President Barack Obama's golf course and military aircraft scrambling to intercept a drone near the White House.

site_title: The perfect spot
summary: The St Regis Osaka is a luxurious hotel situated in the heart of Midosuji Avenue, Osaka's historic tree-lined street. The hotel is a symbol of the city's prosperity and tradition, offering a range of amenities including two world-class restaurants, a spa, and 160 luxurious guestrooms. The hotel's prime location makes it an ideal stopover for travelers heading to Kyoto, and its friendly locals encourage visitors to "eat till you drop" and indulge in the city's street snacks. The hotel's service is renowned for its exceptional 24/7 availability, making it a top choice for travelers.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: North, South Korea stand firm as deadline looms
summary: North and South Korea are on the brink of another clash as Seoul refused an ultimatum to halt anti-Pyongyang propaganda broadcasts by Saturday, threatening military action. North Korea fired four shells into South Korea, prompting South Korea to fire back 29 artillery shells, but both sides reported no casualties or damage. The renewed hostility is a blow to South Korean President Park Geun-hye's efforts to improve North-South ties, which have been frozen since the 2010 sinking of a South Korean navy ship. The situation remains tense, with both sides trading harsh rhetoric.

images.alt_text: SOUTHERN ANGER: South Korean conservative activists with placards denouncing North Korean leader Kim Jong-un at a rally in Seoul on Friday.

site_title: Taking pride in their culinary heritage
summary: Singapore Airlines introduced Peranakan dishes in July 2015 to celebrate Singapore's 50th birthday, offering Ayam Buah Keluak, Peranakan Hokkien Mee Soup, and Traditional Ice Cream Wafers. The airline received positive feedback for the concept, authenticity, and taste. Emirates offers a Middle Eastern option with dishes like traditional Arabic Mezze, while Qantas showcases Australian food from local producers, including the Rockpool Steak Sandwich and Australian wines. These in-flight menus reflect the airlines' efforts to celebrate their respective national culinary heritage.

site_title: Microsoft files antitrust suit against InterDigital
summary: Microsoft filed an antitrust lawsuit against InterDigital, alleging the company has been violating its pledge to offer fair and reasonable licenses on patents related to fundamental mobile-phone technology. Microsoft claims InterDigital has engaged in "abusive licensing practices and unlawful monopolization" in the field of third- and fourth-generation cellular technologies. InterDigital disputes the claims, stating it has a long track record of standards contributions and fair licensing practices. The case is set to be reviewed by a US trade agency before a court ruling.

site_title: India hires "Mr Turnaround" to fix loss-making Air India
summary: India appoints Ashwani Lohani, known as "Mr Turnaround," as chairman and managing director of debt-burdened Air India, aiming to fix the airline's financial troubles. Lohani will focus on modernizing the fleet, selling assets, and reducing fuel costs to return the airline to profitability. Air India, which last made a profit in 2007, is expected to report another operational loss for the 2014-15 fiscal year and sits on 500 billion rupees (US$7.6 billion) of debt. The new boss aims to boost the airline's market share, currently at 15%, and reverse its financial woes.

site_title: Uproar in 'Valley of Gods' over green ruling
summary: A court in India's National Green Tribunal has banned commercial activity around Rohtang Pass in the Kullu Valley, threatening the livelihoods of local businesses and residents who rely on tourism. The ruling aims to protect the environment from pollution and damage caused by vehicle emissions and human activities. The ban includes restrictions on horse riding, paragliding, and food shacks, and has sparked outrage among local businesses and residents who fear for their future. The valley, known as the "Valley of the Gods," is a popular tourist destination and the ruling is seen as a significant blow to the local economy.

images.alt_text: SAVING THE ENVIRONMENT: The tribunal's decision is aimed at protecting Kullu Valley from its hordes of visitors, who are worsening environmental degradation.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Asia is expected to drive and gain from dollar asset diversification as investors seek alternatives to the US dollar amid de-dollarization trends. The region's growth and wealth creation will be key to unlocking investment opportunities. Productivity gains and the adoption of emerging technologies are also expected to contribute to the region's economic growth. Meanwhile, Amundi predicts massive growth in ETFs driven by retail investors in Asia and Europe, and the S&P 500 has reached a record high, suggesting the worst of the trade war may be behind us.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Creative Technology warns that its H2 revenue may fall short of target, with a similar operating loss to the first half of the year. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks continue their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Helen Wong will retire as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long taking over as the incoming CEO. The MAS and PBOC are set to deepen their cooperation in green and transition finance. Additionally, Indonesia detains a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case.

site_title: Greek bond swings more mirage than market
summary: Greek government bonds experienced a 46% return in the third quarter, beating European peers, but most investors are hesitant due to low trading volume. The return is attributed to perceptions of political deals rather than Greece's ability to implement economic measures. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is set to step down, potentially leading to a snap election, which may impact market sentiment. Despite the short-term gains, analysts warn of significant hurdles, including debt burden and state asset sales, making investment in Greek bonds a "political play" rather than a financial one.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to probe senior Russia employee over bribes
summary: Deutsche Bank is conducting an internal probe into possible money laundering at its Russian unit, which has led to an investigation into a senior employee over alleged bribes. Unexplained funds were discovered in accounts controlled by the employee and their spouse. The firm is also examining trading activities with 10-12 Russian broker counterparties. This probe is part of a broader investigation into billions of dollars of trades made on behalf of Russian clients, which has sparked mounting litigation costs and potential overhaul of the firm's management.

site_title: Citic fund unit said to plan US$100 million investment in Uber
summary: Citic-CP Asset Management, a joint venture of China's Citic Group Corp, plans to invest US$100 million in Uber Technologies Inc, with 80% going to Uber and 20% to its China unit. The investment may help Uber compete in China, where the company is expanding with plans to start operations in 50 mid-sized cities. This comes as Uber China is expected to outgrow the US home market by the end of the year and may eventually be listed on the Chinese stock market.

site_title: Banks set for asset-backed debt relief in EU market overhaul
summary: The European Commission is proposing a new regulation to ease capital and oversight rules for asset-backed debt in the EU market, aiming to revive corporate lending and provide 100 billion euros to 150 billion euros in additional credit to households and businesses. The regulation would cut the minimum risk weight on securitizations to 10%, allow banks to award a "simple, transparent and standardized" label to asset-backed securities without prior checks, and lift a burden on investors. This is part of the EU's planned capital markets union to get credit flowing to small- and medium-sized companies.

site_title: France, India to conclude Rafale jets deal within 10 days
summary: France and India are expected to conclude the Rafale fighter jets deal within 10 days, according to a source. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi ordered 36 Rafale fighters in April, and after inconclusive negotiations with Dassault Aviation, the deal was revived. The agreement is aimed at modernizing India's ageing airforce, which faces a major capability gap with China and Pakistan. Terms and conditions, including the unit price of the aircraft, remain to be settled. The deal follows recent export orders from Egypt and Qatar, and talks with Malaysia and the UAE are ongoing.

images.alt_text: A Dassault Rafale combat aircraft performs during the inauguration ceremony of "Aero India 2013" at Yelahanka air force station on the outskirts of Bengaluru, India, in this February 6, 2013

site_title: Cattle, hog markets offer rare bright spot
summary: Global cattle and hog markets are experiencing a rare bright spot due to tightening meat supplies in top consuming nations such as the US and China. US cattle markets are expected to rally after Australia's shipments dwindle, while China's hog prices have reached record highs due to lower production and reduced herd sizes. This could lead to increased demand for pork and support prices for US live cattle and beef. Investors are taking advantage of the trend by investing in pork markets and shares of companies that produce the meat.

site_title: SG50 commemorative notes folders will be reprinted to correct "Yusok Ishak" typo: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will reprint SG50 commemorative notes folders due to a typo in the name of Singapore's first President, Mr Yusof Ishak, which was misspelled as "Yusok Ishak". The corrected folders will be distributed to correct the error.

site_title: Hapag-Lloyd said to speed up Frankfurt IPO plans on good results
summary: Hapag-Lloyd AG, Germany's largest container-shipping line, is speeding up plans for an initial public offering (IPO) to October after reporting a profitable second quarter. The company, which merged with CSAV last year, aims to start a road show for investors next month, depending on market conditions. This move may also help tour operator TUI AG divest its remaining 14% stake in Hapag-Lloyd earlier than expected, as the company returns to profitability with lower fuel costs and efficiency gains.

site_title: Reaping rewards of creative destruction
summary: Kao Corporation's CEO Michitaka Sawada emphasizes the importance of innovation in setting the company apart from competitors. He attributes the evolution of consumer preferences to the development of societies, where people transition from basic cleaning needs to values such as environmental sustainability and efficiency. Sawada believes that continuous innovation is crucial, focusing on breakthrough ideas and incremental additions to value over time. Kao invests 4% of annual sales on research and development, and plans to increase this to 100 billion yen soon. The company aims to grow its global business, particularly in Asia, and is targeting emerging markets such as China and Indonesia. Sawada is optimistic about Japan's market, despite demographic trends, and sees opportunities for growth in the country's beauty and health needs.

images.alt_text: 'The concept of continuous innovation starts with breakthrough innovation; we need great new ideas for products that cause creative destruction. This kind of innovation changes the game.'

site_title: US:Wall St opens sharply lower on China woes
summary: US shares plummeted for a third consecutive day, led by tech stocks, amid China's economic woes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 161.82 points (0.95%) to 16,828.87, its lowest level in 10 months. The S&P 500 dropped 18.15 (0.89%) to 2,017.58, while the Nasdaq fell 59.99 (1.23%) to 4,817.49. Boeing led the decline, falling 2.4% due to its sensitivity to the Chinese market.

site_title: China nearing overhaul of big 3 telecom leadership
summary: China is close to reorganizing the leadership of its three main telecommunications companies as the government prepares to revamp the industry. The chairman of China Mobile's parent company, Xi Guohua, will retire and be replaced by Ministry of Industry and Information Technology Vice Minister Shang Bing. Similar high-level personnel changes are expected at the state-owned parents of China Unicom and China Telecom. The moves are part of the government's efforts to revamp the industry and address concerns about competition and market dominance.

site_title: Oxley's Q4 net profit rises 70%, but full year earnings plummet 79%
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a 70% increase in Q4 net profit to S$16.6 million, driven by a 134% rise in revenue to S$193.8 million. However, the company's full-year results were disappointing, with revenue falling 35% to S$701.8 million and net profit plummeting 79% to S$60.9 million. Despite this, Oxley's board proposed a final tax-exempt dividend of 0.41 cents per share and expressed cautious optimism about the business outlook for the next 12 months.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble amid global selloff
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.5% to 22,409.62, entering a bear market, amid a global selloff and China's weakest manufacturing data since the financial crisis. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index fell 2%, while the Hang Seng Properties Index posted its 13th daily drop, raising concerns about the city's real estate market. The decline follows a four-month slide, with major companies like Cheung Kong Property Holdings and Tencent Holdings Ltd experiencing significant losses. The global economic downturn and China's slowdown are driving the market's decline, with concerns about the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore's stock market closed 1.3% lower on Friday due to a disappointing China PMI report. Silverlake Axis halted trading after its stock fell 27% on a short-seller report. Meanwhile, Singapore banks' loan growth is expected to stay subdued in 2015, but net interest margins are expected to rise as interest rates are expected to increase. The Monetary Authority of Singapore will reprint SG50 commemorative notes folders to correct a typo in the name of Singapore's first President, Mr Yusof Ishak.

images.alt_text: Singapore banks' loan growth will stay subdued over the coming quarters, but the lenders stand to enjoy higher net interest margins as the market expects rates to rise, said a Friday report by Fitch Group's BMI Research.

site_title: India to sell US$1.5b of Indian oil shares on Monday
summary: India plans to sell a 10% stake in state-run refiner Indian Oil Corp Ltd through a stock market auction on Monday, valued at around $1.5 billion. This sale is part of the government's efforts to raise $11 billion by selling stakes in state-run companies to narrow the fiscal deficit. The auction will be managed by Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, and other investment banks, with individual investors allowed to buy the stock at a 5% discount to the final bid price. This is the government's second major asset sale this fiscal year, following a $260 million sale of a stake in Power Finance Corp Ltd.

site_title: PAP's Tin Pei Ling will defend MacPherson SMC
summary: Singapore's People's Action Party (PAP) has confirmed 31-year-old MP Tin Pei Ling as its candidate for the MacPherson single-member constituency in the upcoming general election. Tin Pei Ling, who gave birth to a boy just days prior, made the announcement at the PAP's MacPherson branch office. This marks her second term as MP, following her 2015 election victory.

images.alt_text: Ms Tin Pei Ling, the People's Action Party's (PAP) youngest MP, has been confirmed as its candidate in MacPherson single-member constituency (SMC) for the coming general election.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 2.74 points lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended the day 2.74 points lower, closing at 1,574.67 on the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index. The trading volume was 1.78 billion lots valued at RM2.12 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 470 to 330.

images.alt_text: Malaysian stocks recorded their biggest advance in two years, led by a rally in state-controlled companies, after Prime Minister Najib Razak said the government will tap a fund to support the nation's equities.

site_title: Bhupinder Singh said to be exiting Asian role with Deutsche Bank
summary: Bhupinder Singh, Deutsche Bank's Asia-Pacific co-head of investment banking, is leaving the role after two years, according to people familiar with the matter. Singh will stay for a few months until a replacement is announced. The departure comes as Deutsche Bank revamps its operations globally, amid a global overhaul led by co-CEO John Cryan, who has signaled a reduction in the investment bank's operations.

site_title: Thailand to start 4G auction on Nov 11, raises base price
summary: Thailand's telecoms regulator plans to start the auction of fourth-generation (4G) mobile spectrum on November 11, with a base price of 15.91 billion baht (US$446 million), a 14% increase from the original price. The auction was postponed after the military government took power in May 2014. The move is expected to boost shares of the country's top mobile operators, Advanced Info Service and Total Access Communication.

images.alt_text: Thailand's telecoms regulator will start the auction of fourth-generation (4G) mobile spectrum on Nov 11 and raised the base prices by 14 per cent to 15.91 billion baht (US$446 million), a top official at the regulator said.

site_title: New fires at China explosion site: report
summary: New fires broke out in the Chinese port city of Tianjin, where giant explosions occurred last week, killing at least 116 people and injuring hundreds. The fires, caused by fuel in vehicle tanks and other flammable substances, have sparked fears of toxic pollutants contaminating the air and water. Thousands of tonnes of hazardous chemicals, including highly poisonous sodium cyanide, were stored at the site, with cyanide levels 356 times permitted limits found in water and air. Cleanup efforts, led by over 4,400 soldiers and armed police, continue despite repeated fires.

images.alt_text: Four new fires broke out Friday in the devastation left by giant explosions in the Chinese port city of Tianjin last week, state media reported, as clean-up efforts continued.

site_title: Malaysia's reserves fall to 6-year low of US$94.5b
summary: Malaysia's foreign-exchange reserves fell to a 6-year low of US$94.5 billion in August, down 2.3% from two weeks earlier, amid a currency loss in the region. The decline is attributed to a slump in commodities, slowing economic growth, and capital outflows. The ringgit has weakened to a 17-year low, breaking through its 1998 peg level. Despite this, the central bank's governor stated that reserves are sufficient to finance 7.5 months of retained imports, and the bank has no plan to return to a fixed exchange rate.

site_title: Apple raises A$2.25 billion in record Aussie corporate bond deal
summary: Apple Inc raised A$2.25 billion in its debut Australian corporate bond deal, the largest by a non-financial company in the country. The seven-year notes were sold at a yield of 110 basis points more than swap rates, while the four-year securities were sold at a 65 basis point spread. The proceeds may be used to return capital to shareholders through stock buybacks and dividends. The deal eclipses BHP Billiton's A$1 billion transaction earlier this year, and was managed by Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Deutsche Bank AG, and Goldman Sachs Group Inc.

site_title: Indonesia gives tin miner PT Timah nod to resume exports
summary: Indonesia's top tin miner PT Timah has been granted government clearance to resume exports, with plans to make its first shipment by early September. The company halted exports in August due to new rules on shipments, which aim to crack down on environmental damage and smuggling. Benchmark tin prices have fallen 20% this year, and Timah's exports will be traded on the Indonesia Commodity & Derivatives Exchange. The company will initially trade 100-200 tonnes and will look to increase exports once prices rise above US$17,000 a tonne.

site_title: Grim China data caps worst week of year for stocks
summary: World stock markets experienced their worst week of the year, with the MSCI emerging markets index at its weakest in four years, due to alarming data from China showing its manufacturing sector slowing at the fastest pace since 2009. The Caixin/Markit manufacturing index showed a decline in factory sector activity, fueling fears of a China-led deceleration in global growth. Oil prices also plummeted, with US crude hitting a 6-year low, as investors sought safety in bonds and gold.

site_title: Taiwan stocks end down 3% at lowest level in over 2 years
summary: Taiwan's stocks closed down 3.0% at their lowest level in over 2 years, following weak China and global markets. The decline was further exacerbated by a wider-than-expected contraction in Taiwan's export orders in July. The market's weakness mirrored global trends, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Taiwan stocks closed down 3.0 per cent, finishing at their lowest level since June 2013 on continued weakness in China and other regional and global markets.

site_title: Hot stock: Silverlake tumbles following short-sell report
summary: Silverlake Axis, a software solutions provider, fell 23% to S$0.645 after a short-sell report recommended targeting the stock at S$0.29. The report, authored by "razor99", was released on Thursday night. The exact author or organisation behind the report remains unclear.

site_title: Indonesian stocks slide into bear market as economy stumbles
summary: Indonesian stocks slipped into a bear market as the country's economy continues to struggle. The Jakarta Composite Index fell 2.4% to its lowest close since January 2014, with foreign investors pulling $185.4 million from Indonesian stocks on August 20. The Indonesian rupiah weakened to its lowest level since 1998, while the yield on the government's 10-year bonds rose to an 18-month high. The economy's growth slowed to 4.67% in the second quarter, and company profits dropped 88% of companies tracked by Bloomberg.

images.alt_text: Indonesian stocks entered a bear market as capital outflows accelerate amid a weakening economy and the prospect of higher US interest rates.

site_title: Singapore: Shares close 1.3% down after China PMI report
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 38.77 points to 2,971.01, closing 1.3% down, after China's flash manufacturing PMI came in worse than expected. The five-day rally for Singapore stocks ended, with losers outnumbering gainers 368 to 129. The most actively traded stock, Pacific Andes, plummeted 28.6% to S$0.030. The decline follows a 4.8% drop from last Friday's close.

site_title: Britain: FTSE hits eight month low after China data
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index hit an eight-month low, down 0.6% at 6,327.42, due to weak China data, which raised concerns over global growth and possible deflation. The index is down 3.3% for the week, its biggest drop in 2015, and has been falling for nine straight sessions. China's factories shrank at their fastest rate in 6.5 years, contributing to the global economic slowdown narrative. Precious metals miners rallied, bucking the trend, while chip designer ARM fell 2.5% after a downgrade.

site_title: Veteran MP Amy Khor to defend Hong Kah North single-seat ward in next election
summary: Veteran MP Amy Khor announced her intention to defend the People's Action Party's (PAP) seat in Hong Kah North at the next Singapore General Election. This will be her fourth term in Parliament, with Khor serving as the Senior Minister of State for Health and Manpower. The election date has not been officially announced.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks down 4.27% on weak manufacturing data
summary: Shanghai stocks dropped 4.27% on Friday after China's manufacturing activity gauge fell to its lowest in six years. The Shanghai Composite Index declined 156.55 points to 3,507.74, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 5.39% to 2,039.40. The weak Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reading of 47.1 weighed on market sentiment, with investors concerned about the economy's weakening performance. The Shanghai index lost 11.54% for the week, amid worries over the economy and government support.

site_title: Baht drops for 7th week as blast deepens stocks selloff
summary: Thailand's baht dropped for its 7th consecutive week, with a 1.3% decline this week and 0.1% on Friday, reaching its weakest level since March 2009. The currency has declined 7.7% this year, amid weak local demand and falling exports, and a bomb blast in Bangkok has intensified outflows from equities. The SET Index lost 0.3% to 1,367.91, with global funds selling a net $410 million of Thai stocks this week, contributing to a 3.3% loss since August 14. The economy is forecast to have one of the slowest expansions in Southeast Asia in 2015.

site_title: Euro zone business growth unexpectedly accelerates in August: PMI
summary: Eurozone business growth unexpectedly accelerated in August, with a Composite Flash Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 54.1, driven by steeper price cutting and a buildup of work backlogs. This suggests the European Central Bank's bond-buying program and weaker euro are having a positive impact on growth. However, the increase in price cutting may be disappointing for the ECB, which aims to bring inflation to 2% and has been battling to achieve this target.

site_title: Feels like 1986: Oil on track for longest weekly losing streak in 29 years
summary: Oil prices resumed their downward trend, with the US benchmark on track for its longest weekly losing streak since 1986. Weak global stock markets and a sharp contraction in China's manufacturing activity contributed to the decline. US crude fell 46 cents to $40.86 a barrel, and Brent traded 41 cents lower at $46.21 a barrel. The slump in oil prices follows a similar pattern to 1986, when oil prices slumped due to OPEC's output increase.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall sharply after China factory contraction
summary: European shares fell sharply, tracking a drop in Asian markets, after a survey showed China's factories contracted at their fastest pace since 2009. The FTSEurofirst 300 dropped 1.6% to its lowest level since January, with US stock futures hitting a 6-month low. The Caixin/Markit manufacturing index showed China's factory sector shrinking at its fastest pace in almost 6.5 years, fueling fears of a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy. Global markets are in "panic mode" as the full scale of China's slowdown becomes clearer, according to a market analyst.

site_title: Silverlake Axis halts trading after stock falls 27% on short-seller report
summary: Silverlake Axis halted trading after its stock plummeted 27% following a short-seller report, which recommended shorting the stock with a target price of S$0.29. The report, authored by "razor99", was released on Thursday night and continued to circulate on Friday, contributing to the significant price drop. The Singapore Exchange queried the company about "unusual price movements" and the company called for a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: Australia to abolish tax-free threshold on import retail tax
summary: Australia plans to abolish its tax-free threshold on import retail tax, applying the 10% Goods and Services Tax (GST) to all offshore sales valued over A$1,000, starting July 2017. The move aims to level the playing field for domestic retailers competing with online sellers. Treasurer Joe Hockey cited the threshold's negative impact on businesses and jobs, but collecting the tax from all foreign sellers may be costly and complicated. The plan is expected to pass parliament, but details remain to be finalized.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won sink on global economy, North Korea jitters
summary: South Korean shares and the won plummeted on Friday due to market turmoil over the global economy and escalating tensions with North Korea. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index fell 2% to 1,876.03 points, marking its fifth consecutive weekly decline. The won currency dropped 0.8% to 1,195.0 per dollar, while the credit default swap premium on 5-year South Korean sovereign debt rose to 75.5 basis points, a near 2-year high. North and South Korea exchanged fire across their border, further exacerbating the economic uncertainty.

site_title: Australia: Shares finish week at 8-month low as China worries deepen
summary: Australian shares dropped to an 8-month low, closing 1.4% lower at 5,214.6. The decline follows a weak industry survey from China, deepening concerns about Australia's biggest trading partner. The S&P/ASX 200 index lost nearly 3% for the week. In contrast, New Zealand's NZX 50 index rose 1% for the week.

site_title: Gold climbs to highest level in more than six weeks on Fed view
summary: Gold prices surged to a six-week high on August 21, 2015, after Federal Reserve officials expressed concerns over low inflation, potentially delaying an interest rate increase. The metal rose 1.4% to $1,168.39 an ounce, with a 4.3% weekly gain, amid a slowdown in global growth and a devaluation of the Chinese currency. The Fed's decision may make gold less attractive due to its lack of interest-paying capabilities.

site_title: South Korea Q2 real household income grows at fastest in a year
summary: South Korea's average disposable household income grew 2.5% in Q2, the fastest growth since Q1 2014. This positive trend contrasts with a 0.3% decline in private consumption in the same period. The central bank's interest rate cut and government's supplementary budget may have contributed to the economic growth. The Q2 results suggest a promising outlook for consumer spending in the Asian economy.

images.alt_text: South Korea's average disposable household income grew a real 2.5 per cent in the second quarter from a year earlier, the fastest growth since the first quarter of last year, official data showed on Friday

site_title: Ringgit falls to new record low of 2.97 to Singdollar ahead of foreign reserves
summary: The Malaysian ringgit plummeted to a new record low of 2.97 against the Singapore dollar on August 21, 2015, amid investor concerns over foreign exchange reserve data. The currency had closed at 2.9463 on Thursday. The drop in the ringgit's value was attributed to investors' anticipation of the central bank's ability to defend the currency.

site_title: Lawrence Wong, Halimah Yacob to co-anchor PAP's Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC team
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its Marsiling-Yew Tee Group Representative Constituency (GRC) team, led by Minister Lawrence Wong and Speaker Halimah Yacob. The four-member team also includes backbenchers Alex Yam and Ong Teng Koon. Wong described the new GRC as having a "very rich history and heritage," marking its first representation in Parliament.

images.alt_text: The PAP team for Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC (from left) Lawrence Wong, Halimah Yacob and Alex Yam serving lunch to residents at a Marsiling block party.

site_title: Najib tells detractors to back off
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has defended his leadership, telling detractors to back off amid calls for a vote of no confidence. Najib denied allegations of corruption and abuse of power, stating that the right to his mandate belongs to the people who elected him. Former Premier Mahathir Mohamad has called for a vote of no confidence, alleging abuse of power and corruption by Najib's administration. Najib has reshuffled his cabinet and removed Deputy Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin in response to the opposition's efforts to oust him.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak said no one should try to interfere with or hijack his leadership as former premier Mahathir Mohamad called for a vote of no confidence against him.

site_title: Fed's tightening cycle scenario involves risky bet on inflation
summary: Federal Reserve officials may lift interest rates as soon as September due to solid US jobs growth, but inflation remains a key concern. The Fed's benchmark rate has been near zero since 2008, and policymakers are uncertain about how inflation will behave in the post-crisis world. Recent research suggests that inflation dynamics have changed, and the relationship between unemployment and inflation has weakened. The Fed's inflation target is 2%, but inflation remains stalled, and a rate hike could lead to higher inflation-adjusted rates, threatening the recovery.

site_title: Hot stock: Under-investigation Pacific Andes, China Fishery down by over 50%
summary: Pacific Andes Resources Development and its subsidiary China Fishery Group plummeted more than 50% after regulators announced they are investigating the companies for an offence under the Securities and Futures Act. The investigation involves the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department. Pacific Andes shares fell to S$0.02, while China Fishery lost S$0.065. The companies claim their business operations will continue as normal and are cooperating with the investigation.

site_title: German private sector growth picks up in August
summary: Germany's private sector saw stronger-than-expected growth in August, driven by a 54.0 flash composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), surpassing the 50 mark that separates growth from contraction. This marks the 28th consecutive month of economic expansion, with output and new orders increasing at the sharpest rate in four months. The growth suggests a solid third quarter for Europe's largest economy.

site_title: ANZ to launch sale of US$720m stake in Indonesian's Bank Panin: sources
summary: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) plans to sell a 3.9% stake in Indonesian bank Bank Panin, valued at approximately US$720 million, through a sale process starting next week. Goldman Sachs has been hired for the sale, expected to attract bidders from China, Taiwan, and Japan. The sale is part of ANZ's efforts to raise capital and sell assets amid a domestic regulator's order to set aside more reserves against oversized mortgage books. ANZ has also recently sold its vehicle and equipment finance unit Esanda and was previously in talks with Mizuho Financial Group over the Panin stake.

site_title: Singaporean legal officer in 1MDB probe faces deportation
summary: A Singaporean legal officer, Jessica Gurmeet Kaur, involved in the 1MDB probe, has her permanent residence status revoked and is facing deportation. She was terminated by the Attorney-General's Chambers and had her residence status revoked. Officers from the immigration department were seen looking to serve the deportation order on her, but she was not at home.

site_title: SDA first to release manifesto for coming GE
summary: The Singapore Democratic Alliance (SDA) released its election manifesto, the first party to do so, with a 2,000-word document aimed at building a 'Singapore for Singaporeans'. The manifesto was released ahead of the expected general election, which is widely anticipated to take place next month.

site_title: Oil heads for eighth straight week of falls
summary: Oil prices are expected to decline for the eighth consecutive week, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling 49 cents to $40.83 a barrel and Brent crude tumbling 56 cents to $46.06 a barrel. Global economic growth concerns and a potential slowdown in China are driving the declines. Analysts warn that a supply glut and lack of production cuts could lead to lower prices, potentially reaching $32 a barrel. Oil prices have managed to hold above $40 a barrel, but investors will be watching the weekly US oil rig count for signs of production cuts.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei 225 stock index closes down 2.98%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 stock index closed down 2.98% on Friday, marking its fourth consecutive day of losses, amid fears over the global economy. The Nikkei 225 tumbled 597.69 points to 19,435.83, its lowest close in over three months. The broader Topix index also fell 3.13%.

site_title: Two new faces spotted at walkabout in Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC as SPP-DPP team takes shape
summary: Two new faces, Law Kim Hwee and Abdillah Zamzuri, were spotted at a walkabout in Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC, potentially joining the joint SPP-DPP team in the upcoming Singapore General Election. Law, a 55-year-old former sales and marketing manager, and Abdillah, a 31-year-old training company owner, were seen knocking on doors in Toa Payoh Central. The move suggests the SPP-DPP team is taking shape ahead of the elections.

site_title: Toyota to buy 13 million air-bag inflators from Takata rival: sources
summary: Toyota Motor Corp plans to buy 13 million air-bag inflators from Nippon Kayaku Co to reduce its risk from potentially lethal inflators supplied by Takata Corp, which has linked to eight deaths and over 100 injuries. The deal aims to replace high-risk inflators, primarily from vehicles aged five years or older. Toyota will increase production of Nippon Kayaku inflators from next July to 2020, with the total cost estimated at around $100-$150 million. This move is part of Toyota's proactive strategy to maintain business and reduce risk, as it considers a switch to Nippon Kayaku inflators as a precaution against further recalls.

site_title: China's yuan looks to end week little changed as central bank seeks to calm markets
summary: China's yuan remained broadly unchanged on Friday, ending the week on a flat note as the central bank sought to stabilize the currency and calm markets after a shock devaluation last week. Despite this, many market watchers expect the yuan to weaken further this year as the economy shows signs of weakening. Strategists have revised forecasts for the yuan lower by the end of the year, with bearish bets reaching their largest in over five years.

site_title: China discloses first batch of mutual recognition funds under review
summary: China's securities regulator has disclosed the first batch of mutual recognition funds under review, allowing them to be sold across China and Hong Kong. Nine Hong Kong-based asset management firms submitted applications, with investment targets ranging from Chinese equities to global markets. The move marks another step in China's market liberalisation drive, following the November launch of the "Stock Connect" trading link. The CSRC has accepted applications from over 950 funds, with 100 Hong Kong-domiciled and 850 mainland Chinese funds qualified for the scheme.

site_title: China woes add to Asia FX perfect storm; Korea tensions hit won
summary: Emerging Asian currencies fell on Friday, marking another losing week, amid concerns over China's slowing economy and growing tensions in the Korean peninsula. China's factory sector activity shrank at its fastest pace in 6-1/2 years, while South Korea's won fell 1.8% against the dollar. The Malaysian ringgit hit a 17-year low, and other regional currencies, such as Thailand's baht and Indonesia's rupee, also slid. Analysts predict a "perfect storm" of economic challenges, including slower inflation, weaker demand, and a currency war, which could impact global growth.

site_title: Asia: Stocks tumble as China PMI hits six-year low; gold climbs
summary: Asian stocks plummeted, extending a nine-month low, as China's manufacturing gauge hit a six-year low, prompting a wave of selling across emerging markets and commodities. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index fell 1.9% and the S&P 500 index futures dropped 0.4% after a 18-month low. Gold rose for its biggest weekly advance since January, while US oil slid for an eighth straight week. The sell-off was fueled by concerns over China's economic slowdown and higher US interest rates.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 11.67 points to 1565.74 on Friday, with 97.3 million lots traded worth RM51.2 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 269 to 48.

site_title: Senior EU official says Greek snap elections won't affect bailout
summary: A senior EU official, Thomas Wieser, stated that Greek snap elections, called by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, will have no effect on the financial aid package. The election, held just hours after new bailout cash arrived in Athens, was seen as a step to establish a clearer structure in the Greek government. The EU hopes for further progress in the program by October, when a meeting on debt relief will take place.

images.alt_text: A senior European Union official said on Friday that a snap election called by Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras within hours of new EU bailout cash arriving in Athens would have no effect on the financial aid package.

site_title: PAP incumbent Lim Biow Chuan to defend Mountbatten single-seat ward
summary: PAP MP Lim Biow Chuan will defend his single-seat Mountbatten ward in the upcoming election, marking his bid for a second term. Minister for Social and Family Development Tan Chuan-Jin announced the news at a press conference. No other election-related information is provided in the article.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble gains 4.65% in morning trading
summary: NOBLE Group, a commodity trader, gained 4.65% in morning trading on Friday, following a positive note from Fitch Ratings, which stated the company's second-quarter results reflected a "stable financial profile" and predicted positive cash flow from operations in the second half of 2015. Fitch cited Noble's strong liquidity and reduced bank facilities as key factors supporting its ratings. However, the rating agency warned that any weakening support from major banking partners could result in an immediate negative rating action.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 1.57% lower
summary: Tokyo shares began trading 1.57% lower on Friday, following an overnight sell-off on Wall Street due to concerns over the global economy. The Nikkei-225 index fell 314.87 points to 19,718.65, while the Topix index dropped 1.74% to 1,595.55.

site_title: Dollar slips as Fed rate hike hopes fade
summary: The US dollar fell to six-week lows, dropping 2.7% to 95.711, as market players lost confidence in a September interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Minutes from the last Fed policy meeting failed to provide a clear indication, leading traders to quickly price out a rate hike. This decline in the dollar index reflects growing concerns about global economic stress, with the Fed's decision on interest rates becoming increasingly uncertain.

site_title: Australian dollar slides toward six-year low as Chinese slowdown deepens
summary: Australia's dollar slid toward a six-year low, weakening to 72.98 US cents, after a Chinese manufacturing gauge declined to 47.1, indicating a deepening slowdown in the world's second-largest economy. The decline was attributed to a disappointing reading for the China Purchasing Managers' Index. The Aussie dollar fell 0.5% and New Zealand's kiwi slipped 0.2% against the US dollar. Analysts attributed the drop to "risk off" sentiment in FX markets, with the yen rising.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 1.82% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.82% in early trade on August 21, 2015, following a global sell-off due to concerns over the world economy's health. The Hang Seng Index dropped 414.22 points to 22,343.25. This move joins a broader global sell-off, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: China August factory activity shrinks to 6-1/2 year low as orders tumble
summary: China's factory sector activity shrank to a 6-1/2 year low in August, with a preliminary Caixin/Markit China Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 47.1, below expectations. The decline in domestic and export orders, coupled with factory output and employment, has raised concerns about China's economic slowdown. The move has sparked fears of a hard landing, which could impact global growth and financial markets. Analysts predict the Chinese government may need to increase policy support to combat cooling activity and meet its 7% economic growth target.

site_title: Ringgit drops to 17-year low as falling Brent crude dims outlook
summary: The Malaysian ringgit has dropped to a 17-year low, weakening 8.2% this month, amid falling oil prices and emerging-market selloff. The currency has fallen to 4.1667 a dollar, its weakest since 1998, and is down 16% this year.
