The decline in commodity prices and soft growth in emerging markets, such as China, has renewed worries over global deflationary pressures, weighing on the ringgit. The nation's foreign-exchange reserves have also declined, and global funds have dumped over $3 billion of Malaysian equities this year.

images.alt_text: The ringgit weakened to a 17-year low and led declines in Asia as falling oil prices worsened Malaysia's export outlook amid an emerging-market selloff.

site_title: Malaysia excludes anti-corruption body in new team to probe 1MDB
summary: Malaysia's attorney-general has formed a new task force to investigate the state fund 1MDB, excluding the country's anti-corruption body, the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC). The task force, comprising various government agencies, will focus on the financial and economic aspects of the investigation. The MACC will continue its own investigation into 1MDB, with its deputy chief commissioner stating that the exclusion from the new task force is not a problem. The move has raised concerns about the lack of transparency and accountability in the investigation.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's attorney-general has formed a new task force to investigate state fund 1MDB but it excludes the country's anti-corruption body, local newspaper Sin Chew Daily reported on Friday.

site_title: Singapore banks' loan growth to fall to 3.5% in 2015: Fitch unit's research
summary: Singapore banks' loan growth is expected to fall to 3.5% in 2015, down from 5.7% in 2014, due to a sluggish property market. The economy's real GDP growth contracted 4.6% in Q2, and cooling measures are expected to persist, weakening the rental and sales markets. Despite this, net interest margins are expected to rise as interest rates normalize, supporting local banks' income outlook. The average net interest margin across DBS, OCBC, and UOB rose to 1.87% in Q2, a nearly three-year high.

site_title: Seoul: South Korean markets fall on global economy fears, clash with North Korea
summary: South Korea's markets plummeted on Friday due to heightened tensions with North Korea and concerns over the global economy. The won fell 0.4% against the dollar, and shares dropped 3% as investors fled the market. Despite government assurances, 95% of stock exchange issues fell, with foreign investors buying in small quantities. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index fell 1.9% after the first 30 minutes of trade, before recovering some losses. The tensions grew after South Korea fired artillery into North Korea in response to shelling across the border.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down on Wall Street tumble; tech, chips skid
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 1.8% on Friday, following a decline on Wall Street, particularly in tech shares. The TAIEX index dropped to 7,887.97, after closing up 0.1% the previous session. The slump was attributed to continued signs of a slowdown in China and a 2% drop in the Dow Jones and 2.82% drop in the Nasdaq. Taiwan's export orders contracted by a wider-than-expected margin in July, adding to concerns.

site_title: US oil pulled lower by global stocks; on track for eighth weekly decline
summary: US oil prices fell on Friday, with the US benchmark on track for its eighth weekly decline. The US crude for October delivery dropped 23 cents to $41.09, while Brent crude fell 29 cents to $46.33. Weaker global stock markets and concerns over a Chinese economic slowdown contributed to the decline. This marks the US benchmark's 6-1/2 year lows near $40 a barrel.

site_title: Economists cut Japan growth view again, widening gap with BOJ
summary: Economists lowered their forecasts for Japan's economy, cutting growth expectations to 1.2% for the year, widening the gap with the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) optimistic outlook. This may lead the BOJ to reduce its growth forecast and consider another boost in monetary stimulus. Slower growth could add to headwinds for the central bank, as declining commodity prices and consumer spending reduce inflation prospects. The BOJ may maintain its current pace of asset purchases, despite the revised growth forecast.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks fall 1.48% at open
summary: Shanghai stocks fell 1.48% at open on Friday, extending losses from a 3% drop the previous day due to concerns over the economy and potential removal of government support. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 54.33 points to 3,609.96, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 1.88% to 2,114.89.

site_title: Santos puts itself on the block, stock falls to 12-year low
summary: Santos Ltd, an Australian energy company, has put itself up for sale after a 12-year low in its stock price. The company has received approaches from parties interested in its assets and is looking for a new CEO to replace David Knox. Santos appointed Peter Coates as executive chairman to lead a strategic review, with Deutsche Bank and Lazard advising. The company's shares slid 7% in early trade to A$5.20, citing a 88% decline in underlying net profit due to weak oil prices.

site_title: Tensions rise as North and South Korea exchange fire
summary: Tensions escalated between North and South Korea on August 20, 2015, after North Korea shelled across the border in protest of anti-Pyongyang propaganda broadcasts by Seoul. South Korea responded with artillery fire, with both sides reporting no casualties or damage. North Korea warned of military action if the broadcasts continued, but also expressed willingness to resolve the issue. The US urged Pyongyang to halt provocative actions, and South Korean President Park Geun-hye instructed her military to react firmly to North Korean provocations.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday into sub-3,000 region
summary: Singapore share prices fell to 2,972.05, breaking through the 3,000-point support level, with a 1.25% drop from Thursday's close. This follows declines in the US and Asia, with the S&P 500 hitting a six-month low. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite also fell.

site_title: PwC issues disclaimer of opinion for LionGold's FY14/15 results
summary: Independent auditors PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) have issued a disclaimer of opinion for LionGold Corp's FY2014/2015 financial statements due to insufficient audit evidence on two matters: the company's ability to raise required funding and the impact of investigations into suspected trading irregularities. The company reported a total loss of S$61.34 million and net cash outflow of S$9.5 million. LionGold is proposing to change its auditors from PwC to Baker Tilly, citing reduced costs due to decreased market capitalization and scope of operations.

site_title: Asia stocks head for 17-month low after US shares join selloff
summary: Asian stocks plummet, heading for a 17-month low, as the US shares join a global selloff fueled by concerns over the global economy. The MSCI Asia-Pacific Index fell 1.3% to 132.58, with South Korea's Kospi index dropping 2.7% and Japan's Topix index slumping 1.8%. The selloff is linked to the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike and anxiety over developing markets, including China's economic health and yuan devaluation.

site_title: Taiwan July export orders fall for 4th month on China downdraft
summary: Taiwan's export orders declined 5% in July, marking the fourth consecutive month of contraction, due to a deterioration in demand from China, Taiwan's largest trading partner. China's yuan depreciation has caused global economic uncertainty, affecting Asian economies reliant on Chinese spending. Orders for advanced tech goods fell 14.1% from Chinese clients, while US orders rose 10.9%. Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs warns of a potential full-year drop in export orders, the first in six years, with exports expected to fall 7.1% in 2015.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's export orders contracted for a fourth month in July as demand from China continued to deteriorate, rattling its trade-reliant Asian neighbours and pointing to slower global growth.

site_title: Update: Greece's Tsipras resigns, calls snap polls to beat party revolt
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras announced his resignation and called for snap elections on September 20, amid a rebellion within his hard-left party over the country's massive bailout. The move comes after the bailout was approved by European parliaments and Greece received its first 13 billion euros in bailout cash. Tsipras had worked hard to secure the best possible rescue package, but his party's rebellion left him without a parliamentary majority. The snap elections are expected to determine the future of Greece's debt crisis.

site_title: Dollar sukuk yields losses due to weaker faith in Joko, Najib
summary: Indonesia's dollar sukuk yields have dropped 3.8% since April, while Malaysian debt has fallen 2.6%, amid weakened confidence in government leaders. The decline is attributed to economic slowdowns, falling commodity prices, and capital outflows in both countries. Indonesian President Joko Widodo's reshuffled cabinet and Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak's controversy over donations from the Middle East have contributed to the selloff. Economists expect the risk-off trade to continue, favoring Malaysia on a relative basis due to its higher credit rating.

site_title: Oil prices mixed; US contract rebounds slightly
summary: US oil prices closed mixed Thursday, with West Texas Intermediate (WTI) rebounding 34 cents to $41.14 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude fell 54 cents to $46.62 a barrel. The small rebound may be due to a weaker dollar, which makes dollar-priced crude less expensive and stimulates demand. Analysts say the market is trying to find a footing after a 30% drop in WTI prices since June, with signs of reduced US drilling and potential geopolitical risks suggesting the price tide could turn in favor of production.

site_title: AirAsia's Q2 profit down 33%
summary: AirAsia reported a 33% drop in its Q2 net profit to RM243 million, due to increased operating and financing costs. Despite carrying 10% more passengers and maintaining a load factor of 79%, revenue remained flat at RM1.3 billion. Indonesia was the only market to see a drop in passenger traffic, but loadings and average fares have improved. The airline turned around its performance in the first quarter after a loss in the previous quarter. Shares closed 5.6% lower at RM1.01, its lowest point since May 2010.

site_title: Perennial in JV to develop mixed-use project in Ghana
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings has formed a joint venture with Shangri-La Asia to develop a 49,874-square-metre mixed-use project in Ghana's capital, Accra. The project, valued at over US$250 million, will include a hotel, residential towers, office tower, shopping mall, and serviced apartments. Perennial will buy a 55% stake in the site for US$15.2 million, with the remaining 45% held by Shangri-La. The development is expected to be completed in 2019 and will be funded through the sale of residential and office components.

site_title: EU calls on Greece to stick with reforms, stresses positives
summary: The European Commission urged Greece to stick to its economic reforms, despite Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' decision to call a snap election. The new 86 billion-euro bailout facility was agreed upon last Friday, with Greece receiving its first 13 billion euros. EU officials stressed that swift elections could reinforce support for reforms, while Greek leaders must maintain their commitment to the loan terms. A new government must also implement measures to promote social justice and economic growth, including reductions in spending and tax reforms.

site_title: SIA extends title sponsorship of Singapore Grand Prix for two more years
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) extends its title sponsorship of the Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix for two more years through 2017. The airline had taken over as headline sponsor last year, replacing Singapore Telecommunications, which had held the title for six years. As part of the deal, SIA has also partnered with the race promoter Singapore GP, offering perks such as KrisFlyer miles to F1 fans.

site_title: Uniqlo to try out four-day workweek
summary: Uniqlo, a subsidiary of Fast Retailing, plans to offer a four-day workweek to about 10,000 full-time employees in Japan starting in October. The trial will involve 10-hour work days, with employees working Saturday and Sundays. The move aims to retain full-time talent and address overwork issues in Japan, where 22% of workers exceed 49 hours a week. While the four-day workweek is gaining popularity in the US, its adoption is unlikely to become commonplace globally due to the majority of countries operating on a five-day schedule.

site_title: Coke, Visa among major sponsors visiting Fifa to discuss scandal
summary: FIFA, the soccer governing body, met with major sponsors including Coke, Visa, and others to discuss a corruption scandal that has led to the organization's worst crisis in 111 years. The meeting came after sponsors criticized FIFA following the May arrest of senior officials on corruption charges. FIFA has vowed to reform and increase transparency, but sponsors are pushing for an independent body to lead the reforms. The organization has scheduled an internal reform body, led by Francois Carrard, to meet on September 3.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Perennial, LionGold, Soo Kee, Noble, offshore & marine companies
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings is venturing into Ghana's African continent through a joint venture with Shangri-La Asia to develop a 49,874-square-metre site. LionGold's independent auditors issued a disclaimer of opinion for its FY2014/2015 financial statements due to material uncertainties. Soo Kee Group's initial public offering price fell 18% to S$0.245 after its first trading day on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. Noble Group's credit-rating agency Fitch believes the company can generate positive cash flow from operations in the second half of the year. Offshore and marine stocks plummeted due to a further slide in Brent crude prices.

site_title: Canada puts global trade deal at risk to defend family-run dairies
summary: Canada is at risk of jeopardizing its participation in the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) due to its stance on dairy trade, a key issue in the global trade deal. Canada's "supply management" system, which limits production and imports, has helped small family farms stay in business, but also drives up milk prices. The system is seen as a way to maintain stable farms and communities, but its protection has put Canada at odds with other nations, including the US, which is pressing for market access. The Canadian government's commitment to defending dairy interests may impact Prime Minister Stephen Harper's re-election chances in October.

site_title: Tharman: PAP doesn't go to polls thinking it has 'natural advantage'
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said the ruling PAP does not take Singaporeans for granted and will enter the next general election with a strong track record and plans to improve life. He emphasized that an election is a battle for hearts and minds, and the PAP is working hard to build a better Singapore. The party's five candidates for the Jurong GRC include incumbent MPs and new faces, with plans to improve the area, including renaming the town council and establishing a separate office in Clementi.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Ashley Madison founder emails leaked in new data dump
summary: A second, larger data dump from hackers has exposed emails linked to Noel Biderman, founder of Ashley Madison, revealing more details about the infidelity website's business practices. The emails, which include a "paid delete" option, were leaked in a 20-gigabyte data dump, which appears to be authentic. The breach has exposed millions of email addresses, including those of US government officials, UK civil servants, and high-level executives. Despite the negative publicity, demand for Ashley Madison's services remains steady. The US Defense Department and Postal Service are investigating the alleged use of military and government email accounts on the site.

site_title: Germany expects 800,000 asylum seekers this year
summary: Germany expects around 800,000 asylum seekers this year, a four-fold increase from last year, according to Interior Minister Thomas de Maizière. To cope with the influx, Germany will speed up asylum application processing and increase accommodation, but also calls for European solutions to reduce the burden. The country cannot sustainably absorb 40% of the EU's refugees and asylum seekers, de Maizière said, and may need to close borders opened by the Schengen Agreement if Europe doesn't share the burden more evenly.

site_title: Uber's US driver screening missed criminals
summary: Uber's US driver screening failed to catch registered sex offenders, identity thieves, and other convicted felons, with some drivers not being detected until they were cited for violations. The company's background check system, which relies on personal identifying information, is not foolproof and can be inaccurate, allowing some individuals with criminal records to pass. Uber disputes the claims, stating that its system is not inherently worse than LiveScan, used by taxi regulators, and that neither is 100% foolproof.

site_title: Horror flick with plot that's even dumber than it sounds
summary: The movie Sinister 2 fails to impress audiences with its formulaic storyline, which involves a bogeyman possessing young children to murder their families and create home movies. Director Ciaran Foy and writers Scott Derrickson and C Robert Cargill borrow heavily from predecessors, including the original Sinister, in an attempt to recreate its commercial success. The film's reliance on familiar horror tropes and cliches results in a lackluster viewing experience, failing to deliver the epic scares that fans of the genre have come to expect.

site_title: US: Wall St tumbles on global slowdown concern; Disney slumps
summary: US stocks plummeted on Thursday, with the S&P 500 hitting a six-month low, due to concerns over a slowdown in the Chinese economy and its potential impact on global growth. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.06%, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 2.82%. Consumer stocks, including Disney and Time Warner, led the decline, with Disney down 6% after a brokerage downgrade. The S&P 500 is now down 1.1% year-to-date, and its 200-day moving average was breached for the first time since October.

site_title: Tsipras to quit, Greek polls likely on Sept 20
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is expected to submit his resignation to the country's president on Thursday, clearing the way for early elections on September 20. The move comes after hardliners in his Syriza party rebelled against a bailout agreement with international lenders. Greece has repaid a significant debt to the European Central Bank and has received approval from eurozone finance ministers for a bailout package worth up to 86 billion euros. Early elections are likely, with calls rising in Athens for Tsipras to call the polls as soon as next month.

site_title: Raymond Chia is back, with new outfit in tow
summary: Raymond Chia, former CEO of Chip Eng Seng, has emerged with a new outfit, LGB Corporation, which is developing a 250-room hotel in Adelaide, Australia, and a project in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. The group also plans to consider listing on the Singapore Exchange, pending funding needs. LGB Corporation has acquired a site in Adelaide for A$13 million and is scheduled to begin construction in 2017, with an estimated total development cost of A$175 million. The group is also exploring opportunities in Jakarta and Singapore.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Singapore's AUM jumps 30% to S$2.4 trillion in 2014
summary: Singapore's assets under management (AUM) grew 30% to S$2.4 trillion in 2014, driven by "positive asset inflows arising from Asia's growth dynamism and Singapore's position as a pan-Asian asset management hub". The industry's AUM has expanded at a 14% compound annual growth rate (CAGR) over the last five years, with a net increase of 38 registered and licensed fund managers. Traditional and alternative AUM also saw significant growth, with private equity and hedge fund AUM increasing by 24% and 21% respectively.

site_title: Can anyone thwart Clinton's bid for the party nomination?
summary: Hillary Clinton's presidential bid is facing unexpected challenges, including a strong showing by Senator Bernie Sanders in early primary states and growing concerns about her trustworthiness due to the "emailgate" scandal. Despite her fundraising and media attention, Clinton's campaign is struggling with poor turnout at events and slipping in opinion polls. Meanwhile, potential challengers like Joe Biden and Al Gore are considering entering the race, and the FBI is investigating potential mishandling of classified material on her home computer server. Clinton's campaign managers believe Sanders poses a short-term threat, but Clinton remains the "presumptive" Democratic presidential candidate.

images.alt_text: Mrs Clinton during a a campaign stop in North Las Vegas, Nevada, on Tuesday. Democratic Party leaders are concerned that if the Justice Department launches a probe into the e-mail scandal, her campaign would be dead in the water.

site_title: Fed officials concerned about slow pace of inflation at July meeting
summary: US Federal Reserve officials are concerned about the slow pace of inflation, with overall consumer prices rising only 0.2% over the past 12 months. The Fed is unlikely to raise interest rates in mid-September, as suggested by the uncertain tone of the July meeting minutes. Analysts and investors are also reducing bets on a September rate hike, with the yield on the 10-year Treasury falling to 2.129%. Fed officials are hesitant to raise rates until inflation reaches the 2% target, and some argue that the central bank should wait until prices are rising more rapidly.

site_title: Josh Duggar admits cheating on wife after Ashley Madison hack
summary: Former reality TV star Josh Duggar admitted to cheating on his wife after reports revealed his subscription to the Ashley Madison affair website. He apologized for being the "biggest hypocrite ever" and acknowledged his own personal failures, including secretly viewing pornography and becoming unfaithful. Duggar also resigned from his job at the Family Research Council and canceled his statement referencing pornography. The incident comes after the cancellation of his family's reality show "19 Kids and Counting" due to allegations of child abuse.

images.alt_text: Former reality TV star Josh Duggar on Thursday admitted cheating on his wife after reports that he had subscribed to the Ashley Madison affair website, apologizing for being "the biggest hypocrite ever.

site_title: BOJ worry about fallout from yuan devaluation
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is concerned about the potential fallout from China's yuan devaluation, which may hit Asian demand and Japan's exports. The BOJ has been relying on a solid pickup in overseas demand to fuel its economy, but a slump in oil prices and weak domestic consumption have raised speculation about the need for further monetary easing. While the BOJ is unlikely to act before its October review, policymakers remain sanguine about the yuan's devaluation, but some fear Beijing's action may disrupt the export-driven growth cycle that the BOJ is counting on.

site_title: Qantas back in the black on cost-cutting
summary: Qantas, an Australian airline, has reported a A$557 million annual net profit for the year to June 30, a sharp recovery from a A$2.84 billion net loss in the previous year. The airline's cost-cutting programme and lower fuel prices contributed to the turnaround, with underlying profit before tax reaching A$975 million. Qantas has also placed an order for eight Boeing Dreamliners, highlighting its transformation and growth plans.

site_title: Target gets new COO to fix supply chain issues and fill its shelves
summary: Target Corp has appointed John Mulligan as its new COO to address supply chain issues, which have led to shortages of goods and undermined sales growth. The company blames its complex supply chain for the problem, and Mulligan has promised to improve in-store product stock levels. Target has relied heavily on external distributors for fast-moving consumables, which has led to issues with stock replenishment. Analysts suggest that Target should take control of its supply chain to resolve the problem, a strategy that has been successful for rival Wal-Mart.

site_title: Markel to mix insurance with professional services
summary: Markel International, a UK-based insurer, is exploring the possibility of offering standalone legal-expenses insurance in Singapore. The company, which acquired Abbey Protection in 2014, aims to provide clients with access to qualified lawyers, in addition to paying claims. This move follows research that suggests the market in Singapore is ready for such a product. Markel also plans to expand into tax and consultancy services, leveraging Abbey Protection's expertise. The development ties in with Markel's efforts to innovate its suite of products and engage with specific industry sectors.

images.alt_text: William Stovin, president of Markel International, says it plans for the coverage by its standalone legal-expenses insurance products to include consultations with qualified lawyers, rather than a helpdesk manned by legal assistants.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Brokers' take on Singaporean stocks: 
- First Reit's Q2 results showed stable growth, but its share price correction makes it too early to turn positive.
- Venture Corp's weak ringgit versus the Sing dollar and strong US dollar will benefit its profits, with potential returns of 16% including a 6% yield.
- K1 Ventures' target price is S$0.23, and management will focus on existing portfolio exits and distribute excess cash to shareholders.
- OCBC Investment Research maintains a "hold" stance on First Reit, while DBS Group Research upgrades Venture Corp to "buy" due to currency factors.

site_title: Analysts cite timing and pricing as Soo Kee makes dismal debut
summary: Soo Kee Group, a Singapore-based retailer, made a dismal debut on the Singapore Exchange Catalist board, falling 18% to close at S$0.245 on its first trading day. The IPO price was S$0.30, and the stock was attributed to poor timing and high pricing. The Straits Times Index also fell, and the company plans to use IPO proceeds to expand its retail stores and e-commerce platforms.

site_title: Twitter adds more features to platform for advertisers
summary: Twitter has upgraded its Twitter Publisher Network (TPN) to the Twitter Audience Platform (TAP), enabling advertisers to connect with their audiences beyond the Twitter platform through mobile apps. The upgraded platform allows advertisers to drive two objectives: Tweet engagements and video views, and also includes new creative formats to engage in-app audiences. Initial feedback from advertisers has been positive, with some campaigns doubling reach and lowering cost-per-engagement by up to 30%. The platform is now available globally to all managed clients, with plans to expand to other objectives in the future.

site_title: Najib reiterates commitment to free-market policies
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak reiterated his administration's commitment to free-market policies amid investor concerns over the country's tumbling ringgit and potential capital controls. Despite a 30% devaluation of the ringgit over the past 12 months, Najib assured that the government will not impose capital controls or peg the currency to the US dollar. International ratings agency Standard & Poor's noted that Malaysian companies are well-prepared for the weakening currency, but analysts warn of a growing trust deficit in Najib's administration due to corruption allegations and political manoeuvres.

site_title: Sell-off continues as STI tests 3,000-mark
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) fell 31.47 points to close at 3,009.78, marking a fourth consecutive session of decline, as investors rush for the door due to risk aversion. The benchmark index is down 3.4% since last Friday's close and 6% since the end of July. Uncertainty over the US interest rate hike, slowdown in China's economy, and commodity slump are key factors contributing to the market's decline, with the STI testing the 3,000-mark for the fifth time in three years.

site_title: Pimco bets on capital bonds issued by European banks
summary: Pimco, a US-based investment management company, is betting on capital bonds issued by European banks, seeing them as low-risk investments with additional yield. The company's executive vice president, Anthony Crescenzi, believes European banks are becoming safer and less likely to fail, reducing the risk of investors losing their investments. Pimco is also investing in US non-agency mortgage bonds, which are immune to interest-rate hikes due to the strengthening economy. The company is seeking higher yields in a market characterized by stubbornly low yields, with contingent-capital debt returning 5.6% this year.

site_title: Expect S'pore humour from this Irish comic
summary: Irish comedian Dylan Moran, known as the "Oscar Wilde of comedy," will perform in Singapore early next month as part of his Australasia tour, Off the Hook. Moran, 43, is best known for his UK television series Black Books and has appeared in films such as Notting Hill and Shaun of the Dead. He will bring his sardonic humor to Singapore, which has been praised for its witty and poetic take on everyday life.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: A bigger serving of Dick Lee
summary: Veteran composer Dick Lee is set to perform an upsized version of his 1989 debut album "The Adventures of the Mad Chinaman" at the Esplanade Concert Hall on September 3. The show, directed by Jonathan Lim, will feature Lee's life story set to music, covering his journey until 1998, including his time in Japan and his success in the Chinese market. The performance will be a more intimate show, with a five-piece band and a guest jazz vocalist, and tickets start at S$38.

site_title: Brazil's crisis may spell political change
summary: Tens of thousands of Brazilians marched through major cities, demanding the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff amid a major economic crisis. Rousseff, facing a corruption scandal, appeared calm despite record-low approval ratings. The government is backing the investigation, but the country's economic woes, including high inflation and unemployment, pose significant challenges. The president's leadership is being tested as the economy continues to contract, with Moody's cutting Brazil's investment rating to near-junk status. Despite the turmoil, Rousseff is taking a rare path in Latin America, prioritizing transparency and accountability.

site_title: Bison is the new beef as diners swap steak for grass-fed game
summary: Bison, a grass-fed meat alternative to beef, is gaining popularity due to its perceived health benefits and rejection of factory-farming methods. Restaurants are raising prices, and the meat is now stocked by major retailers. The trend signals a shift towards organic foods and consumers are willing to pay more for the meat, despite its high cost. Bison prices have doubled in the last five years, but demand remains strong, driven by consumer preference for healthier options and the desire to support sustainable farming practices.

site_title: US$ drops as Sept rate hike chances fade
summary: The US dollar dropped 0.2% against a basket of major currencies due to reduced expectations of a September interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, now estimated at around 40%. The euro rose 0.5% to US$1.1178, while the Swiss franc increased 0.3% against the dollar. The Norwegian krone fell to its lowest in over seven months against the euro due to a slowing economy and lower oil prices.

site_title: O&M stocks reel as oil prices hit new 6-year lows
summary: O&M stocks plummeted on the Singapore bourse as Brent crude oil prices hit new 6-year lows, with Sembcorp Marine and Keppel Corp falling to multi-year lows. Analysts divided on whether the sell-down was overdone, with some citing panic and undervalued stocks, while others warned of further downside risks. Triyards, Ezra Holdings' fabrication arm, tumbled to its lowest price since listing three years ago, with analysts noting that certain stocks remain overvalued despite deteriorating fundamentals.

site_title: Europe's sobering warning on jobs
summary: Europe's economy is experiencing weak growth and high unemployment, with the eurozone's GDP advancing only 0.3% in the second quarter. Economist Christian Thimann argues that high wage and compensation costs, rather than a lack of demand, are the main cause of the problem. Countries with high wage costs, such as France and Italy, have seen their profit margins erode, while more competitive countries like Germany have gained an advantage. Thimann warns that reducing labor costs is essential to overcoming Europe's distress, but he is skeptical that this will occur due to differing economic models and national values.

site_title: Finding perfection on the island of Sicily
summary: Wine-maker Peter Vinding-Diers has found a new home on the island of Sicily, where he has finally settled and sunk his roots. A poet by heritage and wine-maker by choice, Vinding-Diers has traveled extensively, including a trip to Singapore in the early 1980s and a stint as a war correspondent in Vietnam, the Middle East, and South Africa. It was in South Africa that he began to learn about wine and wine-making, ultimately leading him to Sicily, where he has found a sense of belonging.

site_title: City buzz
summary: A local theatre company is staging "Takizawa Kabuki" with a modern twist, blending traditional Japanese performances with contemporary elements. The event is part of the city's entertainment scene. Meanwhile, various businesses and organizations are promoting unique initiatives, including a zero-waste future, financial literacy programs, and innovative home design solutions. Additionally, a new restaurant "Thevar 2.0" is offering modern Indian cuisine, while a charity event "NCSS rallies partners to better engage volunteers" aims to improve volunteer engagement. These events showcase the city's diverse offerings and community-driven activities.

site_title: Indonesia's infrastructure promises fail to solve food spoilage problem
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo's administration has failed to deliver on its promises to improve infrastructure, exacerbating food spoilage and price volatility in the country. The lack of coordination among ministries has hindered the spending of a US$22 billion budget allocated for infrastructure projects, including irrigation systems and dam construction. This has led to unstable pricing for staples such as rice, sugar, and chillies, causing financial hardship for rural farmers like Rahmat, who struggles to sell his produce due to spoilage and transportation issues.

site_title: July home resales rise to highest level since February 2007
summary: US existing home sales rose 10.3% year-over-year to 5.59 million in July, the highest level since February 2007. Job gains and low borrowing costs are driving trade-up purchases, supporting the economy. Prices rose 5.6% to $234,000, while inventory fell to a three-month low. The number of homes on the market decreased, and it would take 4.8 months to sell existing homes at the current sales pace. This suggests a tight market, with sales increasing 2.7% to 4.96 million.

site_title: Guangzhou developer cuts target, rules out price war
summary: Guangzhou R&F Properties, China's 15th largest property developer, lowered its 2015 sales target to 55 billion yuan, a 8.3% decrease from the previous year. The company cited volatility in the stock market and uncertainty over the macroeconomic environment. Despite this, R&F expects home sales to recover in the second half of the year. The move was seen as a signal that the company will not engage in a price war to meet its target.

site_title: Australian fund managers seek collateral from banks in swap deals
summary: Australian fund managers are demanding more protection in the A$29 trillion credit and interest-rates swaps market by requiring banks to post collateral in over-the-counter derivatives agreements. Funds are stipulating banks post collateral to protect against insolvency and are expanding the types of collateral they require. This move is seen as a challenge to long-dominant investment banks, with the goal of achieving more equitable protection for Australian investors.

site_title: Courts Asia seeks answers from Mauritius on failed bid
summary: Singapore-listed Courts Asia is seeking answers from the Mauritian government after being snubbed for a bid to acquire Courts Mauritius, a retailer in the island nation. Courts Asia was the preferred bidder, but a rival suitor won the bid, and the company's CEO, Terry O'Connor, has demanded to know why the government disregarded the SA's choice. The dispute centers on governance issues, with Courts Asia accusing the government of not following best practices and not providing transparency. The company is considering taking legal action and is seeking written explanations from the Mauritian government.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: BHP, Glencore lead falls in miner shares
summary: Global mining shares declined amid concern of a sharp slowdown in China, with BHP Billiton Ltd and Glencore plc falling to near seven-year and record lows respectively. Copper and oil prices hit six-year lows, while gold producers bucked the trend, notching gains on strength in the metal's price. The Bloomberg World Mining Index declined 0.5% to its lowest since 2009, while gold prices advanced the most in three months. Investors sought a safe haven, driving up gold prices despite a 4.2% decline in bullion for immediate delivery this year.

site_title: Update: Greece to hold early election on Sep 20, according to govt official
summary: Greece is set to hold early elections on September 20, according to a government official, amid a rebellion in Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' Syriza party and a need to implement a tough bailout programme. Tsipras will resign later on Thursday.

site_title: Japan business mood up, signals recovery after slump in Q2: poll
summary: Japan's business morale improved in August, with a Reuters poll showing a significant increase in confidence, suggesting a possible economic recovery. The Reuters Tankan sentiment index for manufacturers rose to 17, the highest in a year, and retailers' mood rebounded after a sharp drop. The improvement is seen as a positive sign for policymakers, who may deploy fresh stimulus to spur growth. However, the outlook is clouded by a slowdown in China, Japan's biggest trading partner, and weak consumer spending. The index is expected to improve further to 19 in November.

site_title: S$15m B-round financing helps startup Zimplistic find its feet (Amended)
summary: Singapore-based startup Zimplistic secured $15 million in B-round financing to overcome production delays of its automated chapati-making machine, the Rotimatic. The company initially sold out of preorders within a week, with over 8,300 units sold at $599 each. However, production was hindered by growing pains, custom tooling, and sourcing a suitable factory in Malaysia. Zimplistic attributes the delay to fine-tuning and certification, and offers full refunds to preorder customers. The company plans to ship orders in the first half of 2016, a year behind its original fulfillment date.

site_title: Re-organising art museum's collection of 5,000 books
summary: Singapore Art Museum's collection of 5,000 books has been re-organized by artist Loo Zihan into a chronological order of publication, showcasing how the focus of art conversations shifted over the years and the museum's interests developed. The re-organization was done by Loo, one of the five artists shortlisted for the President's Young Talents award, who was given access to the museum's resources centre. The installation aims to reveal the hidden patterns and connections within the collection.

images.alt_text: Loo Zihan, with part of his installation, Of Public Interest: The Singapore Art Museum Resource Room. The artist has arranged the collection chronologically according to publication date to show how the interest of the museum has evolved.,

The other artists on the shortlist are Ong Kian Peng (above); Bani Haykal, posing with his installation necropolis for those without sleep; Ang Song Ming; and Ezzam Rahman, whose Allow Me to Introduce Myself, an installation with talcum powder, second-hand furniture and bell jars, is pictured

site_title: Dark and demented political play
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts features a Hungarian play called "Dementia" by Kornel Mundruczo, staged by Proton Theatre. The dark and unnerving play is set in a mental hospital facing budget cuts and a capitalist takeover. The patients, led by a doctor and nurse, plan a mini-revolt, incorporating various genres and techniques. Director Mundruczo's work is described as a microcosm of post-communist Hungary, with a jolting and bizarre style that blends theatre, music, and film. The play is a rare example of political theatre in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Cycling into the hearts of Singapore
summary: The Bicycle Film Festival 2015, held in Singapore, promotes cycling through movies, music, and arts. Founded in New York City in 2001, the festival aims to change the mindset of urban cyclists and motorists in Singapore. The three-day event features art appreciation, a runway show, movies, and an auction, including a 50-year-old heirloom bicycle passed down three generations. Proceeds from the auction will be donated to the International Committee of the Red Cross. The festival, spearheaded by Lyndon Yeo, encourages coexistence between cyclists and motorists and showcases the positive profile of cyclists.

site_title: In for another round in the never-ending Greek story
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schäuble has secured approval for a third bailout package worth €86 billion for Greece, following a heated debate in the German legislature. The bailout, under the European Stability Mechanism, aims to boost public income and regain trust for the Greek government. However, critics argue that the deal is non-satisfactory and may lead to a never-ending cycle of financial support. The International Monetary Fund's (IMF) involvement is still uncertain, with some economists questioning the economic sense of the deal, citing austerity measures that could hinder economic growth.

site_title: Spelling error on SG50 commemorative notes should never have happened: MAS managing director
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has apologized for a spelling error on the country's SG50 commemorative notes, misspelling the name of the first President, Yusof Ishak, as "Yusok Ishak". The mistake was found in the packaging of the notes.

site_title: Dance riot
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) is hosting an unprecedented 14-choreographer, 21-work dance marathon, which begins on August 21 and concludes with Archive Box 1 and 2 on August 29 and September 5, respectively. The marathon culminates with a unique exchange between choreographers, who will respond to each other's dances to create seven new works. This exchange aims to address the preservation of dance legacy and emotional context. The dance marathon features works by Japanese and Indian choreographers, showcasing some of the most exciting Asian creations in recent years.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Europe: Stocks close lower
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed lower on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.56%, the CAC 40 in Paris down 2.06%, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 2.34%. The declines were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks took center stage.

site_title: Noble issues summons against Arnaud Vagner and Enlighten Ace Limited
summary: Noble Group has issued a summons against Arnaud Vagner and Enlighten Ace Limited, the alleged authors of Iceberg Research's blog, which has questioned Noble's accounting methods. The summons compels them to provide lists of documents and allow inspection of discovery documents. This comes after Noble's share price slumped over 60% following the blog's revelations. The company will keep the market updated on the progress of the litigation. Noble had previously announced it would start legal proceedings against the individuals in March.

site_title: Battered emerging market stocks may offer astute investors opportunities
summary: Emerging market stocks may offer opportunities for astute investors, despite the region's recent struggles. The MSCI Emerging Markets Index has delivered negative returns over the past 3-5 years, with stocks at five to six-year lows. Fund flows have slowed, with non-resident inflows averaging $11 billion a month over the past six months. However, extreme pessimism on EMs may have reached a "capitulation" point, with 32% of fund managers surveyed being underweight, and their cash balances relatively high. Investors should consider differentiated companies with strong currency management and domestic growth themes, and may benefit from investing in well-managed funds.

site_title: Pacific Andes and China Fishery under investigation
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department are investigating Pacific Andes Resources Development and China Fishery Group for an alleged offence under the Securities and Futures Act. The investigation began after the group received a notice on August 18, 2015, requiring it to provide information and documents related to its dealings with third parties from October 1, 2011. The company stated that its business operations remain unaffected and will continue to cooperate with the investigation.

site_title: PAP introduces two new faces for its Jurong GRC slate
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has introduced two new faces to its Jurong Group Representation Constituency (GRC) slate for the upcoming general election. Rahayu Mahzam, a 35-year-old lawyer and cancer specialist, and Tan Wu Meng, a 40-year-old medical oncologist, will join Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, Minister of State for National Development Desmond Lee, and backbencher Ang Wei Neng. The pair aim to provide holistic support to low- and middle-income families and help young people achieve their aspirations.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
The PAP team standing for election in Jurong GRC is made up of (from left) Dr Tan Wu Meng, DPM Tharman, Madam Rahayu Mahzam, Mr Ang Wei Neng and Mr Desmond Lee.

site_title: Noble's 'short-term liquidity manageable, long term uncertain'
summary: NOBLE Group's liquidity position is expected to improve in the next two months, but its long-term balance sheet is uncertain. Credit rating agencies Fitch and Barclays believe the company can generate positive cash flow from operations in the second half of the year. However, if Noble continues to use debt to fund business expansion, its cash flow could remain negative, potentially breaching Fitch's negative rating sensitivities. Analysts also highlight the importance of Noble's major banking partners' support, and the company's ability to address concerns over liquidity and confidence.

images.alt_text: Noble Group's liquidity position in the next two months should improve, but how its balance sheet will fare after that is still a question mark, analysts said, adding that the support of its major banking partners will be critical.

site_title: Yuan as reserve currency: IMF to take more time to consider
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has decided to extend the review deadline for the Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) basket of currencies by nine months, from December 31, 2015, to September 30, 2016, to consider including the Chinese yuan. This move is seen as paving the way for the yuan to join the elite group of currencies that are special-reserve asset currencies. The yuan's inclusion could enhance its global standing and aid its acceptability in trade and capital transactions. The IMF will examine the yuan's role in Hong Kong and other offshore markets.

site_title: JES International ceases operations
summary: Chinese shipping firm JES International has ceased operations, retaining only a "skeletal staff" to control costs. The company has recovered its electronic financial records and is in the process of replacing administrative records for its subsidiaries. JES had previously uncovered financial irregularities against its former CEO and chairman, Jin Xin, and started proceedings against a former employee who absconded with records. The firm's operations have been impacted by these issues, but it continues to work on resolving the matter.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on worries about China, oil weakness
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, with the Dow Jones down 1.02% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also declining. Concerns over weak growth in China and falling oil prices weighed on investor sentiment, with the US benchmark oil contract near the $40-per-barrel level. The losses followed declines in leading European and Asian equity markets, underscoring worries about the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: No audit qualification on cash and bank balances: China Sky
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre's external auditor stated that nothing caused them to believe its cash and bank balances are not true and fair. The auditor clarified that an additional audit procedure regarding the balances did not amount to a qualification or emphasis of matter under International Standards on Auditing. The company's response to queries from the Singapore Exchange was that the auditor's reply was clear in this regard.

site_title: Jobs returning to Spain construction sector while wages go nowhere
summary: Spain's construction industry is creating jobs at the fastest pace in almost three years, adding 32,300 construction jobs in the second quarter. However, wages have dropped 4.4% from their peak in 2010, with many workers facing lower pay, longer hours, and little job security. Despite the economic rebound, unemployment remains high at 22%, and experts warn that wages will never return to pre-crisis levels, leaving many workers vulnerable to long-term unemployment.

site_title: As stocks slide, few see hope
summary: Singapore's stock market is experiencing a decline, with the Straits Times Index (STI) near 3,000-point support. Analysts predict a decline of up to 10% and warn of a long-overdue correction. Weak corporate results, lack of catalysts, and risk aversion among retail investors are contributing factors. The oil and gas sector is particularly hard hit, with some stocks down 40% in a month. Experts suggest that Singapore's market may underperform due to US dollar strength and capital flows out of Asia.

site_title: US existing home sales rise to 8-year high
summary: US existing home sales rose 2% in July to a 5.59 million-unit annual rate, the highest level since 2007, according to the National Association of Realtors. This marks a 10.3% increase from a year ago, driven by gains in the South and West regions. The median home price fell slightly to $234,000 but was up 5.6% from last year, while the supply of homes for sale decreased slightly. The increase in home sales supports the view that the US economy is gaining momentum, potentially leading to interest rate hikes.

site_title: Hitman: Agent 47 muddles along in monotony
summary: Hitman: Agent 47, a reboot of the 2007 film, received lukewarm reception with its Singaporean scenes serving as mere window-dressing for local cinemagoers. The film, directed by Aleksander Bach and written by Skip Woods and Michael Finch, is a shameless attempt to replicate the box-office success of the earlier film, despite featuring prominent Singaporean locations. Despite this, the film's overall tone remains one of monotony.

site_title: India's NSE index posts biggest single-day fall in nearly 4 weeks
summary: India's NSE index plummeted 1.5% on Thursday, its largest single-day drop in nearly four weeks, amid global risk aversion and speculation about Infosys' potential acquisitions. Infosys shares fell 3.49%, weighing heavily on the NSE index. Global markets, oil, and emerging currencies also declined as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The BSE MidCap index fell 2%, with only FMCG and healthcare stocks managing to hold out.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit establishes S$1.5b multi-currency debt programme
summary: OUE Commercial Reit has established a S$1.5 billion multi-currency debt issuance programme, with debt guaranteed by DBS Trustee Limited. The programme allows for notes and/or perpetual securities to be issued in various currencies and tenors, with fixed or floating interest rates. ANZ Banking Group and Standard Chartered Bank are the joint arrangers and dealers for the programme.

site_title: Smartphone makers challenged by China 'saturation'
summary: China's smartphone market has reached a saturation point, with sales down 4% from a year ago in the second quarter. Global smartphone sales grew 13.5% to 330 million units, but China's contribution to this growth was minimal. The report by Gartner found that Samsung remained the top seller, but its overall sales fell 5%. Apple boosted its market share to 14.6% with iPhone sales jumping to 48 million units. The dominant Google Android operating system saw a slight dip, while Apple's iOS accounted for 14.6%. China's saturated market now relies on replacement sales rather than new buyers.

site_title: Thailand reshuffles cabinet to focus on troubled economy
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha has reshuffled his cabinet to focus on the troubled economy, appointing a new finance minister and deputy premier. Apisak Tantivorawong, a former president of state-owned Krung Thai Bank, has become finance minister, while Somkid Jatusripitak, a former finance minister, has been appointed deputy prime minister. The moves aim to spur economic growth, which has consistently missed government targets since the military coup in 2014.

site_title: Singapore's Q2 domestic wholesale trade falls 19%
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade contracted by 18.8% in Q2 due to lower prices of petroleum and chemical products, but adjusted for price changes, it grew 7.6%. The ship chandler & bunkering industry reported a 43.5% decline in sales, while the petroleum & petroleum product industry saw a 25.9% drop. Foreign wholesale trade declined 14.6% year-on-year, but adjusted for price changes, it grew 6.6%. The overall decline in domestic wholesale trade was attributed to the decline in petroleum and chemical product prices.

site_title: Economy would be key topic at any Japan-China summit: Japan govt source
summary: Japan is waiting for details of China's plans for a September 3 event to mark the anniversary of World War II before deciding if Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will visit Beijing for a summit with President Xi Jinping. The summit, which would be the first real Japan-China meeting, is expected to focus on economic matters, including Japan's growing trade dependence on China. Japan is also concerned about China's military parade and its impact on regional tensions. A decision on Abe's visit is pending, with the Japanese government emphasizing the need for a balance between economic cooperation and sensitive historical issues.

site_title: Noble Group said to discuss move to secured financing with banks
summary: Noble Group, a commodity trader, is discussing a move to secured financing with banks, pledging commodity inventories to guarantee some debt. This could boost liquidity and reassure the market, but existing bondholders and lenders may be relegated in potential claims. The talks are preliminary and could end without a deal. Noble Group has lost over half of its value since mid-February due to accounting criticism and is exploring secured credit lines to increase liquidity.

site_title: MDA strongly disagrees with SDP calling its classification of video a 'partisan political move'
summary: The Media Development Authority (MDA) strongly disagrees with the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) over the classification of its online video, Pappy Washing Powder, as a "partisan political film". The MDA maintains its stance, stating the video is indeed a party political film as defined in the Films Act. The SDP had previously criticized the classification, calling it a "partisan political move".

site_title: Update: US oil falls towards US$40 on global glut
summary: US crude oil prices fell to nearly $40 a barrel, their lowest since 2009, due to a global glut fueled by high US production, record crude pumping in the Middle East, and concerns about falling demand in Asian economies. US crude inventories rose to 456.21 million barrels, and imports reached their highest level since April. OPEC continues to pump record levels of oil, adding to the bearish environment. Long-term derivatives markets show the price of oil for delivery in five years' time has collapsed, and Chinese equities fell 3% on Thursday.

site_title: Ito's vision: rejuvenating Omishima Island and coexisting with nature
summary: Internationally renowned architect Toyo Ito has launched a new project on Omishima Island in Japan, aiming to present a lifestyle that coexists with nature and utilizes the natural climate. The goal is to revitalize the island, which has a population of around 6,000 and faces challenges such as population decline and poor transportation options. Ito's project includes creating houses and accommodations that harness the local climate, opening a community center, and developing local specialty goods. The project is being run by Ito and students of the Ito Juku, with several projects already in motion, including the renovation of a former building into a "Home for All" community space.

site_title: China Cinda to buy Guoco property in Beijing for US$1.6b
summary: China Cinda Asset Management Co has agreed to buy a Beijing property from GuocoLand Ltd for 10.5 billion yuan (S$2.2 billion). The property, located in the city's Dongcheng district, includes shopping centers, office buildings, apartments, and hotels. China Cinda will pay 4.56 billion yuan and take on 5.94 billion yuan in liabilities. The deal is part of China Cinda's expansion into the Chinese real estate market, with the company's stock falling 1.8% before the announcement.

site_title: Maximum spending limit in election campaign raised, says Elections Department
summary: The Elections Department in Singapore has raised the maximum spending limit for election campaigns from $3.50 to $4 per elector on the register. The increase is due to inflation and aims to ensure a level playing field for candidates. Exceeding the maximum amount is considered an illegal practice. This change is part of the law governing election expenses.

site_title: AirAsia's profit drops on higher operating costs
summary: Malaysia's budget airline AirAsia reported a 33% drop in second-quarter net profit to 243 million ringgit due to higher operating and financing costs. Revenue remained flat at 1.3 billion ringgit. The airline carried 10% more passengers, but load factor was maintained at 79%. Indonesia saw a 16% drop in revenue and 18% decline in passengers following a plane crash in December. AirAsia X, its long-haul budget airline, reported a net loss of 132 million ringgit. Shares in AirAsia fell 5.6% to its lowest point since May 2010.

images.alt_text: Malaysian budget airline AirAsia reported a 33 per cent drop in its second-quarter net profit on Thursday, due to a rise in operating and financing costs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia shares closed lower on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 5.03 points to 1,577.41. Trading volume reached 1.79 billion lots valued at RM1.77 billion, with 448 losers and 360 gainers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.94% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.94% lower on Thursday due to concerns over China's economic prospects and a stronger yen weighing on exporters. The Nikkei 225 index fell 189.11 points to 20,033.52, while the Topix index slipped 1.49% to 1,623.88.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend drop as slowdown fears take hold
summary: Europe's shares dropped 0.6% on Thursday, extending their losing streak, amid slowdown fears and decreased expectations for a US rate hike in September. Global weakness and commodities took a hit. The European Central Bank's actions may be needed to correct high earnings expectations.

site_title: Standard Chartered PE arm invests in China's online lender Dianrong.com
summary: Standard Chartered's private equity arm has invested US$207 million in China's online lender Dianrong.com, as part of a C-round financing. The investment is aimed at serving small- and medium-sized firms, which are struggling to raise funds due to China's commercial banks shifting away from this sector. This move follows other international investors, including US firm Tiger Global, which bought into Dianrong.com in January. The investment highlights the growing demand for alternative lenders in China's peer-to-peer lending market.

images.alt_text: A consortium partly led by the private equity arm of Standard Chartered PLC has invested US$207 million in China's Dianrong.com, the peer-to-peer online lender said on Thursday, the latest international investor to take a fancy to the firm.

site_title: Samsung to appeal to US Supreme Court in Apple patent case
summary: Samsung is filing a petition to the US Supreme Court in its patent infringement case against Apple, following an appeals court's ruling that found Samsung liable for damages. The petition, to be filed by November, will address design-patent liability and damages. This comes after Samsung won a recalculation of damages, which could affect Apple's award. The case, which involves two tech giants, has drawn unique attention due to their market dominance in smartphones and computers.

site_title: Oil prices dip further after US stock-build, Saudi export rise
summary: Oil prices fell further, dipping below US$47 per barrel, due to a 4% decline in US West Texas Intermediate crude oil and a 2.6 million barrel increase in US crude inventories. Saudi Arabia's oil exports rose 430,000 barrels per day in June, contributing to the global glut. Long-term derivatives market shows a collapse in oil prices for delivery in five years' time, indicating traders do not expect a price recovery soon.

site_title: Attacked by short sellers? Respond ASAP: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) urged companies under attack by short sellers to provide a full response to shareholders, warning of distorted prices. Noble Group, under heavy short selling, saw its share price drop 60% after accounting methods were questioned by Iceberg Research. SGX's Tan Boon Gin stated that companies must be sensitive to the situation and that the exchange will monitor disclosures and trading activities, taking action to maintain a fair market. SGX will also allow a halt or suspension if necessary to prevent prices from being distorted by criticism.

site_title: China halts operations of 3 oil, gas facilities close to residences
summary: China has halted operations at three oil and gas facilities due to safety concerns. The facilities, operated by CNOOC Hangzhou Marketing Company, Shenzhen Gas, and Shenzhen City Shenchanghongyuan Liquefied Petroleum Gas Company, are located near residential areas and schools, exceeding China's distance guidelines for hazardous materials storage. The government cited safety risks and decided to relocate the facilities to comply with regulations. The move comes after a deadly explosion in Tianjin last week, which damaged 17,000 apartments and killed 114 people.

site_title: India cen bank gov Rajan warns of risks from yuan devaluation
summary: India's central bank governor Raghuram Rajan has warned of potential risks from China's yuan devaluation, stating it's not a concern but a "tit-for-tat" action that could lead to a currency war. The rupee has fallen 2% against the dollar since the yuan devaluation, and emerging Asian currencies have seen their worst outlook in years.

site_title: China: Stocks slump again despite signs of govt support
summary: China's stocks plummeted 3.2% in the CSI300 index and 3.4% in the Shanghai Composite Index, amid concerns about the economy's fragility. Despite government-backed investors' efforts to boost confidence, investor confidence remains fragile. Analysts warn that further yuan depreciation will trigger capital outflows, putting pressure on the property market. Shares of companies with investments from state-backed investors rose, but overall market sentiment remains weak.

site_title: Singapore: Shares down 1%
summary: The Singapore market fell 1% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,009.78, due to concerns over the Chinese economy and a decline in Brent crude. The blue-chip index retreated 31.47 points. This marks a reversal from the previous day's 0.4% gain.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore's assets under management (AUM) grew 30% to S$2.4 trillion in 2014, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Domestic wholesale trade fell 18.8% in Q2, partly due to lower prices of petroleum and chemical products. Noble Group Limited's negative operating cash in Q2 is expected to reverse in H2, according to Fitch Ratings. The Singapore market fell 1% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,009.78.

images.alt_text: Singapore's assets under management grew by 30 per cent year-on-year to S$2.4 trillion in 2014, said the Monetary Authority of Singapore on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia PM says economy sound, as fears mount
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak said the country's economy is sound, despite fears over the plummeting currency and slowing growth. The ringgit, Asia's worst-performing currency, fell to 4.12 to the dollar, its lowest level since 1998. Najib ruled out pegging the currency to the dollar and capital controls, citing strong fundamentals. The economy grew 4.9% in the second quarter, but analysts say concerns over corruption, debt, and financial irregularities have shaken investor confidence.

site_title: UK retail sales inch up in July, auto fuels drop
summary: UK retail sales rose 0.1% in July, exceeding expectations, with a 4.2% year-over-year growth. Excluding fuel, sales rose 0.4% on the month and 4.3% compared to last year. A 2.6% fall in auto fuel sales was offset by a 3.6% rise in household goods. The sales of household electrical appliances and furniture also increased, likely due to a pick-up in Britain's housing market. This growth suggests consumers are regaining spending power, but Bank of England officials are monitoring domestic price pressures ahead of a potential interest rate hike.

site_title: RedMart raises US$26.7m, hires Amazon's Colin Bryar as COO
summary: RedMart, a Singapore-based online grocer and marketplace, has raised US$26.7 million in a bridge round led by existing investors, bringing total funding to US$54 million. The company plans to use the funds to expand internationally, grow its business, and launch its On Demand Marketplace and private label offerings. RedMart will also raise a larger Series C round later this year to support these initiatives.

site_title: Singapore's LTA targets tightest spread in years on new bond
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) launched a new bond offering, priced at 2.57% and 3.09% for seven-year and 12-year tranches, respectively. The $1 billion issue aims to raise funds and is considered a tight offering in the weak market. The bonds were priced by DBS as the sole bookrunner, with a possible greenshoe option to increase the issue size by $100 million. The move is seen as a positive sign for the Singaporean economy, despite weak market conditions.

site_title: Asia gold appetite remains tepid, premiums droop
summary: Asia's gold appetite remains subdued, with premiums dropping in India and Hong Kong. Spot gold prices rose to a five-week high of $1,141.75 an ounce after the US Federal Reserve's interest rate meeting. Indian gold suppliers quoted premiums below $1 an ounce for the first time in a month, while Hong Kong premiums fell to around $1 an ounce. The limited demand is attributed to investors' losses in the stock market, particularly in China, where key indexes have slid around 6% this week.

site_title: Malaysia's AMMB sees 4-5% loan growth this year after mortgage push
summary: Malaysia's AMMB Holdings Bhd forecasts loan growth of 4-5% this year, driven by its mortgage segment. The bank attributed the growth to a pick-up in mortgage loans despite a slowing economy and weak currency. Net profit fell 37.6% in the first quarter, mainly due to lower net interest income and weakness in its insurance business. Analysts expect pressure on profit growth to continue into next year due to a bleak economic outlook.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 2015 closing low on broad selloff
summary: Australian shares hit a 2015 closing low, falling 1.7% to 5,288.6, as a broad-based selloff was sparked by concerns over slowing Chinese economic growth and US interest rate uncertainty. Major banks and miners, including Commonwealth Bank and BHP Billiton, led the decline, with Commonwealth Bank falling 2.7% and BHP shedding 3.1%. The S&P/ASX 200 index has now closed below its mid-December 2015 level.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Bomb unlikely to be work of international terrorists, says junta
summary: Thailand's ruling junta has stated that a deadly bomb attack at a Bangkok shrine, which killed 20 people, is unlikely to be the work of international terrorists. The attack, which targeted the Erawan shrine popular with Chinese tourists, has led to the arrest of at least 10 people suspected of involvement. The junta has concluded that the incident is not specifically targeted at Chinese tourists, contradicting initial fears. The investigation is ongoing, but the junta's conclusion suggests that the attack may be domestic in nature.

site_title: Cyanide in waters near China blast site 277 times acceptable level: govt report
summary: Chinese authorities reported that cyanide levels in waters near the Tianjin Port explosion site reached 277 times the acceptable level, despite the city's drinking water being deemed safe. The blasts killed 114 people, and thousands were evacuated due to toxic chemicals in the air. The government has relocated chemical plants away from the area and will conduct third-party assessments to determine compensation for damaged apartments. The Communist party's anti-graft watchdog promised to crack down on corruption and those responsible for violating laws, while maintaining political stability.

images.alt_text: Chinese authorities warned that cyanide levels in the waters around the Tianjin Port explosion site had risen to as much as 277 times acceptable levels although they declared that the city's drinking water was safe.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit 7-month low on continued foreign selling; won flat
summary: Seoul shares plummeted to a 7-month low, closing 1.3% down at 1,914.55 points, as foreigners continued to sell Korean equities for the 11th consecutive session. This marks the longest selling streak since October, with net sales totaling 1.492 trillion won. The won remained flat at 1,185.1.

site_title: AUM in Singapore up 30% to S$2.4 trillion in 2014: MAS
summary: Singapore's assets under management (AUM) grew 30% to S$2.4 trillion in 2014, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore. The robust growth was driven by positive asset inflows from Asia's growth dynamism and Singapore's position as a pan-Asian asset management hub. The total number of registered and licensed fund managers increased to 591, with a net increase of 38.

site_title: Hong Kong: shares close at lowest level this year
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng index fell 1.8% to 22,757.47, its lowest level in eight months, due to sluggish global markets and concerns over China's economy. This marks the fifth consecutive day of decline. The China Enterprises Index also dropped 2.3% to 10,402.72 points.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended barely changed on Thursday, as most Asian markets stabilised after jitters over Turkey's downing of a Russian fighter jet abated.

site_title: Chocolate demand melts in China as stocks and bribes decline
summary: China's chocolate demand has seen a decline due to the government's crackdown on bribery gifts and a stock market meltdown, affecting big international chocolate makers like Hershey. Smaller local chocolate makers are making slight gains, but the market is becoming increasingly crowded. The Chinese government's two-year corruption crackdown and economic uncertainty have led to a decrease in consumer confidence, causing people to opt for less expensive alternatives. The shortfall in demand is impacting the global bulk cocoa market, threatening idle capacity for big processors.

site_title: Gold climbs to 5-week high as Sept Fed hike hopes fizzle
summary: Gold prices surged to a 5-week high, reaching $1,135.20 an ounce, after the Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes indicated a likely delay in September interest rate hikes, citing concerns over US inflation and a weak global economy. This reduces the likelihood of a rate hike, providing support to gold prices. Analysts expect a potential December rate hike, but the near-term outlook for gold remains positive.

site_title: Oil approaches key US$40 level in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices slid to a six and a half year low in Asia, approaching the key US$40 level, after a surprise rise in US inventories fueled concerns of a supply glut. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropped 32 cents to US$40.48, while Brent crude fell 25 cents to US$46.91. The US Department of Energy reported a 2.6 million barrel rise in oil stockpiles, adding to global oversupply concerns. Analysts predict oil could reach levels not seen since the financial crisis, but some expect US$40 to be a strong psychological support for prices.

site_title: New Zealand job ads edge up in July
summary: New Zealand job advertisements rose 0.1% in July, the first increase in five months, according to ANZ Bank. However, the jobless rate edged up to 5.9% in the second quarter, suggesting stagnant employment growth. Economic growth stalls following a strong run, and ANZ expects the jobless rate to remain around its current level for the rest of the year.

site_title: Fitch: Noble's negative operating cash in Q2 2015 to reverse in H2
summary: Fitch Ratings says Noble Group Limited's second-quarter results show a stable financial profile despite increased debt due to working capital expansion. The company's negative operating cash flow in Q2 is expected to reverse in the second half of 2015, driven by its asset-light business model and increased working capital. However, weakened support from major banking partners could result in negative rating action. Fitch believes Noble can generate positive cash flow from operations in 2H15, driven by its business expansion and reduced finance expenses.

site_title: Greece makes debt repayment, minister calls for snap polls
summary: Greece made a 3.2 billion euro debt repayment to the European Central Bank using newly released bailout funds, marking a step towards financial stability. However, the repayment came amid a political crisis after anti-bailout rebels robbed the ruling party of its parliamentary majority. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras must now tackle the crisis and consider calling for snap polls. The repayment was made possible by the approval of an 86 billion euro bailout deal by the ESM European bailout fund.

images.alt_text: Greece made a crucial 3.2 billion euro debt repayment on Thursday using newly released bailout funds, a government source said, as a senior minister argued for rapid elections following a rebellion in the ruling party.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Thai police seek Interpol help to track bomb suspect
summary: Thailand's military government has asked Interpol for help in tracking a suspected bomber who planted a bomb at the Erawan shrine in Bangkok, killing 20 people and wounding scores. The suspect, seen in grainy footage wearing a yellow shirt, is believed to be foreign, but Thai police have not determined a motive or country of origin. An arrest warrant has been issued for the suspect, and police have found no one matching the description had left the country since the attack. The government claims the bombing was aimed at undermining Thailand's economy.

site_title: New Silkroutes, NTT Communications sign MOU to develop big data analytics solutions
summary: New Silkroutes Group signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with NTT Communications to develop big data analytics solutions and cloud-based services in various sectors. The MOU was signed by Digiland Pte Ltd, a subsidiary of New Silkroutes, and NTT MSC Sdn Bhd, a Malaysian telecoms firm. The partnership aims to leverage cutting-edge technology to drive growth in e-government, real estate, healthcare, and energy conservation. New Silkroutes shares rose 0.1 cent to 0.2 cent following the announcement.

site_title: Singapore's Q2 domestic wholesale trade falls 19%
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade contracted by 18.8% in Q2 2015 compared to the same period last year, primarily due to lower prices of petroleum and chemical products. Excluding petroleum, domestic wholesale trade fell 11.6%, while adjusting for price changes, it increased 7.6%. Foreign wholesale trade declined 14.6% due to lower prices, excluding petroleum, it fell 5.1%. Overall, domestic wholesale trade expanded 7.1% in Q2, while foreign wholesale trade grew 7.3%.

site_title: Yuan devaluation puts 'considerable pressure' on South Korean economy: finmin
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Choi Kyung-hwan, stated that China's yuan devaluation puts "considerable pressure" on South Korea's economy due to global financial turmoil. The devaluation has increased volatility in the stock and foreign exchange markets, affecting exporter competitiveness. While the minister acknowledged the potential boost to exports, his comments were seen as a step back from earlier statements. The government is monitoring the situation and preparing for possible responses to risks to the economy, which may be exacerbated by US Federal Reserve interest rate preparations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.84% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.84% in early trade on Thursday, weighed down by losses on Wall Street and concerns about China's economy.
