The benchmark Hang Seng Index dropped 193.98 points to 22,973.87. The decline was attributed to global market uncertainty, with US stocks also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down; plastics, autos weigh
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index fell 0.1% to 8,013.15, weighed down by declines in plastics and autos. The electronics subindex dropped 0.2%, while plastics shed 1.13% and autos 0.95%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$32.445 per US dollar. Despite the decline, Taiwan's stocks were ahead of other regional markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 13.48 points to 1574.51, with losers outnumbering gainers 164 to 43. The market saw a total of 76.2 million lots traded for RM33.6 million.

site_title: China: Shanghai stocks fall 1.04% at open
summary: Shanghai stocks fell 1.04% on Thursday morning, with the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index dropping 39.54 points to 3,754.57. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.94%, or 20.93 points, to 2,201.12. This follows volatile trading the previous day.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank denies issuing circular on fixing orders: spokeswoman
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, has denied issuing a circular banning local banks from taking orders for transactions from offshore banks at the daily fixing rates. The denial comes amid the ringgit's 17-year low, attributed to reduced confidence in the country due to financial mismanagement of a state fund and a political crisis for Prime Minister Najib Razak. The central bank's spokeswoman stated there is no such circular, contradicting earlier reports by The Sun.

site_title: Australian fund managers flex collateral muscles in bank swap deals
summary: Australian fund managers are demanding more equitable protection from banks in the A$29 trillion credit and interest-rates swaps market. Funds are stipulating that banks post collateral in over-the-counter derivatives agreements, and are also increasing the range of collateral they accept. This shift comes after the 2008 Lehman Brothers collapse, which highlighted the risks of bank insolvency in such agreements. As a result, investment funds are now pressing banks to accept a more diverse range of assets, beyond traditional cash and government bonds.

images.alt_text: Australian fund managers are flexing their muscles against long-dominant investment banks, demanding the banks provide them with more equitable protection in the A$29 trillion (S$29.5 trillion) credit and interest-rates swaps market.

site_title: Yuan declines as IMF board delays potential yuan addition to SDR
summary: China's yuan fell 0.06% to 6.3994 per dollar after the International Monetary Fund delayed the earliest date for the yuan to join the Special Drawing Rights basket, pushing back the review to November. The IMF's executive board voted to extend the existing basket by nine months to September 30, 2016. This decision is seen as a message that greater exchange-rate flexibility is needed for the yuan to win reserve-currency status. The yuan's decline follows a 0.08% increase in China's daily reference rate.

site_title: Soo Kee sheds 10% an hour into trading on its debut day
summary: Soo Kee Group, a Singapore-based jeweller, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board, falling 10% to S$0.27 in its first hour of trading. The company's initial public offering price was S$0.30, with 21.1 million shares changing hands by 10am. Soo Kee has 60 retail stores in Singapore and Malaysia, offering jewellery products through three brands. The listing brings the total number of consumer-sector companies on SGX to 161, with a combined market capitalisation of S$141 billion.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday, following declines in US, Japan
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 29.49 points, or 0.97%, to 3,011.76, following declines in US and Japanese stocks. US policymakers delayed interest rate hikes, while US oil prices tumbled to a six-year low, contributing to losses in oil-linked equities. Local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC also fell, with UOB down 1%, DBS down 0.8%, and OCBC down 1.1%.

site_title: Working longer hours increases stroke risk by up to 33%: study
summary: A study published in The Lancet found that working 55 hours or more per week increases the risk of stroke by up to 33% compared to a 35-40 hour work week. The increased risk remained after accounting for smoking, alcohol consumption, and physical activity. The study also found that working 41-48 hours increased the risk by 10%, while working 49-54 hours increased the risk by 27%. The long work week also increased the risk of coronary heart disease by 13%.

site_title: SIA to extend F1 Singapore Grand Prix's title sponsorship until 2017
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) will extend its title sponsorship of the Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix for another two years, until 2017, the airline announced on Thursday. SIA has been the title sponsor since 2014 and expressed excitement to continue showcasing the event globally. The airline's CEO, Goh Choon Phong, stated that the sponsorship will help strengthen Singapore's image as a world-class tourism and sporting event city.

site_title: Australia detains seven young citizens suspected of seeking to join militants
summary: Australian authorities have detained seven young citizens suspected of seeking to join Islamist militant groups in the Middle East. The detainees were attempting to fly to the region, according to Prime Minister Tony Abbott. The country is on high alert for domestic attacks and has intensified efforts to prevent radicalized citizens from joining militant organizations. At least 70 Australians are believed to be fighting in Iraq and Syria, with around 100 Australia-based facilitators supporting them.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott speaks during a visit to a conservation volunteering project in Queanbeyan near Canberra, Australia, 12 August 2015.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slip with dollar as timid Fed highlights growth woes
summary: Asian stocks fell, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index at its lowest level since January, as the Federal Reserve's cautious stance on interest rates underscored global growth concerns. The dollar weakened against major currencies, and US oil fell to $40 a barrel due to a surprise increase in American stockpiles. The Fed's minutes showed concern over slow inflation, and odds of a September rate increase were reduced. China's yuan devaluation also prompted a scaling back of bets on higher US rates.

site_title: Greece to receive 23b euro cash injection ahead of key repayment
summary: Greece is set to receive a 23 billion euro cash injection ahead of a key repayment to the European Central Bank. The bailout package, worth up to 86 billion euros, has been approved by eurozone finance ministers and European parliaments, including Germany's Bundestag. The move aims to revive Greece's shattered economy and keep it in the single currency bloc. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is considering early elections following the austerity bailout, which has split his Syriza party. The deal includes reforms to Greece's health and social welfare systems, as well as its business practices and public administration.

site_title: South Korea central bank chief says easy monetary policy has limits in boosting demand
summary: South Korea's central bank governor, Lee Ju-yeol, expressed skepticism over the lasting effects of easy monetary policy on demand, emphasizing the need for structural reforms for sustainable economic growth. The Bank of Korea has lowered interest rates to a record-low 1.50% to boost demand, but Lee noted that household debt has grown rapidly, posing risks to the financial system. The central bank is closely monitoring economic and financial imbalances, and most analysts predict it will maintain interest rates for the rest of 2015 due to growing household debt and global uncertainties.

site_title: Australian carrier Qantas to buy eight Boeing Dreamliners
summary: Qantas announced it will purchase eight Boeing 787-9 Dreamliners to replace its ageing 747s on international routes. The airline's CEO, Alan Joyce, stated that the Dreamliner is the right aircraft for Qantas' future. This move aims to modernize the carrier's fleet and improve its efficiency. The purchase is expected to support Qantas' growth and expansion plans.

site_title: Oil hits 6.5-year low as US crude supplies rise
summary: US oil prices hit a 6.5-year low of $40.80 a barrel after data showed an increase in US petroleum stocks. West Texas Intermediate and European benchmark Brent oil prices fell $1.82 and $1.65, respectively. The decline is attributed to rising US crude supplies.

site_title: Bitcoin exchange CEO to face new criminal allegations: media
summary: Japanese police plan to re-arrest MtGox CEO Mark Karpeles on theft allegations, accusing him of pocketing US$2.6 million worth of Bitcoin deposits. Karpeles, 30, was previously held without formal charges for three weeks over claims he manipulated data to create US$1.0 million worth of Bitcoin. The re-arrest would reset the clock on how long police can hold him, as Japanese police can interrogate a suspect for 20 days. Karpeles faces questions over the disappearance of 850,000 coins worth US$480 million.

site_title: Aspial enlarges bond placement tranche to S$50m, cutting public tranche to S$25m
summary: Aspial Corporation has revised its bond placement offering, cutting the public tranche to S$25 million from S$50 million. The revised offering allocates S$50 million to institutional and other investors and maintains the same interest rate of 5.25% per annum. The public offer remains open until August 26, allowing investors to apply through various banking channels. The decision was made due to strong demand for the bonds, exceeding the initial S$25 million limit.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Rex, Aspial, Ascott Reit, Parkson Retail Asia, Thakral
summary: REX International reduces capital investments due to low oil prices, making organisational changes to boost management bench strength and reduce costs. Aspial Corporation re-allocates S$25 million from public bond offering to institutional investors, increasing placement amount to S$50 million. Ascott Residence Trust acquires Element New York Times Square West hotel and leasehold interest. Parkson Retail Asia posts net loss of S$59.8 million due to non-recurring items and impairment of financial assets. Thakral Corporation establishes program to buy Australian real estate projects with Aberdeen Asset Management.

site_title: PAP unveils 2 new faces in slate for Jurong GRC; David Ong to contest Bukit Batok SMC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled two new faces in its slate for the Jurong Group Representative Constituency (GRC) in the upcoming general election. Former civil servant Rahayu Mahzam, 35, and oncologist Tan Wu Meng, 40, will join the party's lineup. David Ong, who will contest Bukit Batok Single Member Constituency (SMC), is also part of the PAP's slate. The announcement comes ahead of the general election, marking a significant shift in the party's lineup.

site_title: Indonesia's infrastructure promises fail the chilli challenge
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has failed to deliver on infrastructure promises, exacerbating price volatility in staple foods like rice, sugar, and chillies. The country's poor infrastructure, including lack of refrigeration and transportation, makes it difficult to stabilize prices, affecting rural farmers like Rahmat, who relies on loans and traders to sell his chillies. The government has implemented policies to curb imports and control prices, but these measures have resulted in shortages and price spikes. With 15% of chillies spoiling or becoming too dry for consumption, the government is under pressure to address the issue.

site_title: Greece gets go-ahead for third multi-billion euro bailout
summary: Greece has received approval from eurozone finance ministers to start repaying its debts and reviving its economy with a third reforms-for-rescue package worth up to 86 billion euros. The agreement includes a 23 billion euro payment to Greece, allowing the country to repay a 3.4 billion euro loan to the European Central Bank. The new bailout package includes reforms on Greece's economy, health and social welfare systems, and business practices, with the Greek government expected to implement the reforms with determination.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.14% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.14% lower on Thursday, following a strengthening yen against the dollar. Speculation about a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike receded, and investors cited concerns about the global economy and cheaper oil. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.93%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.83%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index sank 0.80%. The dollar weakened to 123.87 yen, while the euro rose to 137.82 yen.

site_title: Qantas reports FY net profit in quick turnaround from big loss
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd reported a full-year profit of A$975 million, a turnaround from a A$646 million loss the previous year. The result was driven by cost-cutting measures and cheaper fuel costs. Revenue rose 3% to A$15.82 billion. The company's underlying profit before tax exceeded analyst expectations, bringing it close to the A$1 billion mark last reached in 2008. Qantas' quick turnaround is considered one of the fastest in Australian corporate history.

site_title: Ringgit rout: Singaporeans keep calm, shop for Malaysia bargains
summary: Singaporeans are taking advantage of the low Malaysian ringgit to purchase goods and services, resulting in significant savings. Edmund Goh, a 35-year-old Singaporean, paid RM780 for an air conditioning system that would typically cost him S$700 in Singapore. Others are crossing the border for cheaper food, groceries, and massages. The favorable exchange rate is seen as a bargain, with Goh stating that the savings are more than half of the original cost.

site_title: Italian prosecco overtakes champagne in Britain
summary: Italian prosecco has overtaken champagne in Britain for the first time, with sales reaching £339 million, a 72% increase in value in the year to mid-July. Prosecco sales have outstripped champagne in both value and volume, with a 78% rise in volume sales. Despite this, the two most popular champagne brands, Lanson and Moet, still managed to increase sales, indicating consumers are opting for brand-name champagne over cheaper options. This trend is attributed to prosecco's fashionable status and excellent quality, making it the nation's summer drink of choice.

site_title: Soo Kee IPO 1.1 times subscribed
summary: Soo Kee Group's initial public offering (IPO) of 112.5 million shares was 1.1 times subscribed, with the public tranche receiving 30 million shares and the placement tranche being fully placed out. The group raised S$33.75 million, which will be used for network expansion, new product lines, and capital expenditure. The company's market capitalisation stands at around S$168.8 million. CEO Lim Yong Sheng expressed confidence in the company's long-term prospects following the successful IPO.

site_title: Japan business mood up, signals recovery after Q2 GDP slump: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's business morale improved in August, according to a Reuters poll, signaling a possible economic recovery. The Reuters Tankan survey found 516 firms were cautiously optimistic about domestic demand growth, despite a slowdown in China. The news offers a glimmer of hope for policymakers under pressure to deploy fresh stimulus after Japan's second-quarter GDP slump.

site_title: Dollar retreats after Fed minutes dim Sept rate hike prospects
summary: The US dollar retreated against the euro and yen after Federal Reserve meeting minutes suggested policymakers were hesitant to raise interest rates due to lagging inflation and a weak global economy. The dollar index fell 0.7% overnight, reaching a three-week low of 96.474. The euro was steady at $1.1115, while the yen surged 0.9% to 123.915. Analysts expect policymakers to be even more dovish due to recent events, including falling oil prices and China's economic slowdown.

site_title: Rex to preserve cash, focus on Oman and Norway assets amid oil price downturn
summary: REX International Holding is reducing capital investments and focusing on key discovery assets in Oman and Norway due to the oil price downturn, which has fallen to sub-$50 a barrel. The company will moderate its drilling plans and operations budget to concentrate on these assets and sustain them at the current oil price. Organisational changes include appointing an industry veteran as chief operating officer and re-designating roles for Kristofer Skantze and CEO Mans Lidgren to be based in Europe to oversee business operations in Norway and Oman.

images.alt_text: Rex International Holding said on Thursday it is reducing capital investments and focusing on key discovery assets in Oman and Norway to preserve cash due to the downturn in oil pricee

site_title: US: Stocks drop on worries about China, low oil prices
summary: US stocks declined on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 162.61 points (0.93%) to 17,348.73. Fears about the slowing Chinese economy and low oil prices led to significant losses in petroleum-linked equities. Despite Federal Reserve minutes showing policy makers viewed the US economy as "approaching" the point of being able to weather an increase in near-zero interest rates, stocks fell back. A few stocks, including Target, Lowe's, and Hormel Foods, rose due to positive earnings forecasts.

site_title: Bearish Fed minutes send US dollar tumbling
summary: The Federal Reserve's July policy meeting minutes sent the US dollar tumbling after policy makers expressed doubts over labor market tightening and inflation in the short term. The central bank showed concern over China's slowdown and market turmoil, but remained optimistic about the US economy in the medium term. Despite the bearish tone, the Fed's confidence in raising interest rates in September remains, leaving the door open for a rate hike. The dollar fell more than one cent against the euro, finishing at 1.1121.

site_title: Cathay misses estimates on fuel hedging losses
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported net income of HK$1.97 billion for the first six months of 2015, below analyst estimates, due to losses from fuel hedging and declining passenger yields. Fuel hedging losses totaled HK$3.74 billion, while passenger yields dropped 9.3% from a year earlier. Despite this, Cathay's passenger numbers increased 8.8% to 16.8 million and occupancy rose to 85.9%. The airline's shares fell by as much as 7.6% to HK$15.38, extending a losing streak for an eighth consecutive day.

site_title: Neighbourhood opposition to NY skyscraper plan
summary: A developer plans to build a 80-storey skyscraper in Manhattan's Sutton Place neighborhood, sparking opposition from local residents. The project, which would cost around $650 million, is the latest in a series of luxury developments along Billionaire's Row, where at least eight skyscrapers are underway. Residents, including 81-year-old lifelong bachelor Herndon Werth, are fighting the project, citing concerns about the impact on the neighborhood's character and the environment. The developer, Joseph P. Beninati, has already acquired several properties and is seeking to rezone the area to allow for the tower.

site_title: Shark attacks keep Aussies out of the water
summary: A spate of shark attacks in Australia's New South Wales state has led to a decline in surfers and beachgoers, with 11 attacks this year compared to 3 in 2014 and 2013. The attacks, including a fatal incident, have prompted a shark culling debate, with some calling for the protection of sharks as they are mistaken for food. Authorities are seeking a special permit to shoot sharks, while others advocate for alternative solutions, such as electronic shark repellents.

site_title: Federal Reserve sees conditions for rate hike 'approaching': minutes
summary: The Federal Reserve sees US economic conditions "approaching" the point of being able to weather an increase in near-zero interest rates, according to the minutes of the July FOMC meeting. Despite mixed economic indicators, Fed officials considered raising borrowing costs for the first time in over nine years, citing slack in the job market and concerns over China's economic slowdown. The FOMC decided to hold the benchmark federal funds rate at zero, but some experts predict a rate hike at the September meeting due to the economy's overall strength.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve saw US economic conditions "approaching" the point of being able to weather an increase in near-zero interest rates at July's policy meeting, the meeting minutes showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Why large corporates need a 'foreign policy' nowadays too
summary: The UN has announced it will contact AT&T over allegations that the US multinational telecommunications firm helped the NSA wiretap communications at the UN's NYC headquarters. Leaked documents describe AT&T's "extreme willingness to help" with NSA operations and its close partnership with the FBI. The allegations raise concerns about US government surveillance programs and the role of tech firms, potentially damaging their reputation and financial bottom line. This blurs traditional public and private sector concerns of public policy and corporate affairs, highlighting the need for companies to develop strategic "corporate foreign policy" to navigate complex international issues.

site_title: Thakral, Aberdeen tie up for Australian real estate projects
summary: Thakral Corporation has established a programme with Aberdeen Asset Management Asia to invest in Australian real estate projects, focusing on East Coast cities like Brisbane, Melbourne, and Sydney. The programme, called TCAP Australian Mezzanine Programme, will focus on projects in central business districts and developed suburbs. Thakral's subsidiaries will manage the programme, with Aberdeen providing initial investment and access to capital. The programme aims to develop over 1,000 retirement homes in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales, with plans to expand into other major cities in Australia.

site_title: Small China solar projects turn to crowdfunding
summary: China's small-scale solar projects face a funding challenge due to banks' reluctance to lend, citing lengthy due diligence periods. To address this, crowdfunding platforms like Solarbao.com are emerging, aggregating financing from individual investors. Solarbao.com has helped over 50 small-scale projects raise funds, with contributions starting as low as 1,000 yuan. While the model shows promise, experts caution that risk must be lowered for long-term success, and the industry is still in its early stages.

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend drop after US inflation data
summary: European stocks fell on Wednesday, extending a recent losing streak after US inflation data supported expectations of a rate rise. The FTSEurofirst 300 index closed down 1.8%, with brewer Carlsberg and miner Glencore among the worst performers. China's economic slowdown has overshadowed Greece's debt problems, with investors growing concerned about the state of the Chinese economy. Despite this, Chinese stocks rebounded on Wednesday after the central bank injected more funds into the financial system.

site_title: Singapore in 2065: The future won't wait
summary: Singapore aims to become the world's first "Smart Nation" by leveraging advanced technologies and out-of-the-box connectivity platforms. The nation has seen significant growth and development over the past 50 years, but experts warn that the real radical change is still ahead. To stay differentiated and competitive, businesses must invest in these technologies and rethink traditional career paths, creating more diversity and flexibility. The government has introduced initiatives such as SkillsFuture to support continuous learning and address the challenge of an ageing population. By embracing technology, Singapore can unlock its potential and create a dramatically improved quality of life for its citizens.

site_title: China ploughs almost US$100 billion into two banks to boost weak economy
summary: China has injected nearly $100 billion into two policy banks, the China Development Bank and the Export-Import Bank of China, to boost its weak economy. The move aims to guide funds to the real economy, such as exports and infrastructure construction, as the country's economy expanded 7.4% last year, its weakest since 1990. The government has set a target of 7.0% growth for 2015, and has cut interest rates four times since November and lowered the reserve requirement ratio to stimulate activity.

images.alt_text: Investors at a brokerage house in Fuyang, Anhui province. Economists say the funds released from earlier monetary loosening mostly went to the financial institutions and the stock market.

site_title: Apple challenges figures on Apple Music user retention
summary: Apple disputes a survey claiming 48% of Apple Music users stop using the service after a trial, saying 79% of trial users continue to use the service. A MusicWatch survey found 28% of Apple Music users also use Spotify Premium, while 11% use Spotify's free version. Apple's three-month trial period and $9.99 monthly subscription aim to retain users. The company hopes to reach 100 million Apple Music users, a goal also mentioned earlier this month when Eddy Cue said the service had 11 million users.

site_title: Jurong Aromatics said to be in debt restructuring talks with banks
summary: Jurong Aromatics Corp, a Singapore-based petrochemical plant operator, is in debt restructuring talks with banks due to a plunge in oil prices. The US$2.4 billion plant, which began operations in September 2014, has been stalled since December 2014. The company has US$1.53 billion in liabilities and US$68.7 million in accumulated losses. Negotiations are underway with lenders, including BNP Paribas and Standard Chartered, to extend a grace period and avoid receivership.

site_title: Google launches WiFi router OnHub for home use
summary: Google has launched its WiFi router, OnHub, for home use, priced at US$199.99. The router scans the airwaves to find the fastest connection and allows users to prioritize devices for optimal internet speeds. OnHub can be connected to Google's On app to monitor bandwidth and run network checks. The product is manufactured by TP-Link and is part of Google's efforts to expand its smart home offerings, following its acquisition of Nest and its focus on the "Internet of Things" market.

site_title: China's Dalian Wanda plans 15b yuan local bond sale
summary: China's Dalian Wanda plans to sell up to 15 billion yuan (S$3.29 billion) of local bonds, with the first batch of 5 billion yuan expected to be sold this month. The move is driven by the weakening currency, which boosts borrowing costs overseas, and follows the government's efforts to accelerate approvals for onshore fundraising by China's developers, who are stepping up onshore fundraising to reverse a real estate slump.

images.alt_text: China's largest commercial developer is controlled by the country's richest man, Mr Wang.

site_title: Hacked user data from infidelity website Ashley Madison dumped online
summary: Hackers dumped online personal details of over 1 million users of Ashley Madison, a website for infidelity, after threatening to release 37 million customers' data. The stolen data includes email addresses and credit card information stolen in July. The hackers had initially threatened to publish the data, but instead released a cache of information. The incident highlights the vulnerability of online platforms to cyber attacks, posing a significant threat to relationships worldwide.

site_title: Elderly to get more HDB lease options
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has unveiled a new Flexi scheme for two-room flats, offering elderly buyers flexible lease tenure options ranging from 15 to 45 years. The scheme merges two previous programs, allowing seniors to purchase two-room flats with shorter leases, but with restrictions on resale. The new scheme aims to provide a home for the elderly, rather than an investment opportunity. Over 70 BTO projects will offer two-room Flexi flats, with at least 40% reserved for the elderly, and prices will vary depending on lease tenure and location.

site_title: Abenomics targets unlikely to be achieved, say economists
summary: Japan's economy shrank 0.4% in Q2, its second contraction since last year's recession, raising concerns about Abenomics' effectiveness. Economists say the policy is unlikely to achieve its targets, citing a rapidly greying population and insufficient velocity to escape recession. Officials attribute the setback to weather, but economists are increasingly skeptical. The Japanese economy's slow growth and high debt levels pose significant challenges for policymakers.

images.alt_text: Political analysts say Mr Abe is juggling too many balls; he has been keeping his eye particularly on the national security policy, and been distracted from the economy at a critical juncture.

site_title: Joko urges 'massive' cut in red tape to revive growth
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged his cabinet to cut red tape and implement massive deregulation to revive the country's slowing growth, which is expected to miss its target of 5-5.2% this year. The president's administration has only disbursed 10% of funds earmarked for investment, and spending less than 40% of its budget. The slow growth is attributed to waning domestic demand and weakening prices for key commodities. Widodo called for a "massive" cut in bureaucratic requirements to ease licensing for businesses and investment.

site_title: Dish Network's credit rating seen at risk
summary: Dish Network's credit rating may be downgraded if it has to borrow to pay the full US$13.3 billion price for airwaves denied by US regulators. The FCC rejected a discount for two Dish-funded companies, citing the "unprecedented magnitude" of debt from Dish. Analysts predict that borrowing to meet the demand could lead to increased interest costs and downgrades of Dish's credit rating, with Moody's and Standard & Poor's considering downgrades to Ba3 and BB-, respectively.

site_title: Citi says Venezuela may tap its gold reserves
summary: Venezuela may consider selling part of its gold reserves due to cash shortages, according to a Citigroup report. The country's reliance on oil exports and weakening commodity prices has raised concerns about debt repayment. Venezuela holds 11.607 million troy ounces of gold, with 68% in bullion form. If sold, gold prices could see lows maintained, adding to downward pressure. The country faces a near-term crisis amid protests and shortages, with the cost of insuring its bonds at a 12-year high.

site_title: China to raise pork import as hog, sow herds shrink
summary: China, the world's largest pork consumer, will import 45% more pork this year due to a significant reduction in its hog and sow herds. Over the past 18 months, China has culled almost 100 million hogs and 10 million sows, equivalent to the herds in Mexico, US, and Canada combined. This reduction, largely due to over-expansion and reduced profits, has left behind more modern and efficient businesses.

site_title: Volvo upgrades profit outlook despite China slowdown
summary: Volvo Car Group has upgraded its earnings goal for 2015, citing a robust European market that will outweigh a slowdown in China. Despite increasing pressure to discount in China, CEO Hakan Samuelsson expects a "substantial" increase in 2015 profit. Volvo had previously forecast a "clear" improvement in sales and profitability, with the company now focusing on its global presence to balance out softer development in China.

site_title: Mediation: an ideal alternative in healthcare disputes
summary: A mediation process is being considered as an ideal alternative in healthcare disputes, allowing for open communication and resolving misunderstandings without the need for court lawsuits. Studies show that patients often seek clarity and respect, not financial compensation. Mediation, conducted on a "without prejudice" basis, enables doctors and patients to express sincere apologies without fear of appearing weak or guilty. This approach can reduce the pressure of finger-pointing and allow for a more constructive discussion, ultimately improving the healthcare system and reducing stress for both parties.

site_title: New York Met's China fashion exhibition becomes a smash hit
summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art's "China: Through the Looking Glass" exhibition has become a record-breaking hit, attracting 670,000 visitors in its first few weeks, surpassing the previous record held by Alexander McQueen's 2011 show. The exhibition explores Chinese influence on Western fashion and has been extended until September 7. Head of the Met's Asian art department, Maxwell Hearn, attributes its success to a unique creative collaboration between fashion and Asian art departments, sparking interest in Chinese culture and its impact on the world.

site_title: Korean firms reliant on China tourism hit hard by yuan woes
summary: South Korean companies heavily reliant on Chinese tourism have suffered significantly following the yuan's devaluation in August 2015. Companies like AmorePacific and Hotel Shilla Co saw their shares more than double before the yuan's decline, but lost 11% since then. The yuan's weakness is expected to continue affecting Chinese inbound travel, impacting earnings and shipments of Korean cosmetics, hotels, and exporters. This has led to a decline in the Kospi index, with the won weakening to a three-year low against the dollar.

site_title: US$ edges lower as investors await Fed minutes
summary: The US dollar edged down across the board, falling 0.1% against its basket, as investors awaited US inflation data and minutes from the Federal Reserve. Investors sought refuge in the Swiss franc, which hit its highest level for almost two weeks against the euro. Expectations of a Fed interest rate hike by the end of the year, possibly in September, have driven the dollar's 20% surge in the past year. The market will closely watch US inflation data and the Fed's policy meeting minutes for guidance on future interest rate changes.

site_title: Sumitomo yields rise on debt fatigue despite property boom
summary: Sumitomo Realty & Development Co, Japan's third-largest developer, forecasts a record operating income for the third consecutive year due to a property market boom under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's stimulus measures. Despite this, investors are cautious about the company's debt levels, with yields on its bonds increasing by 54 basis points over similar-maturity paper of Nomura Real Estate Holdings Inc. The company's debt-to-equity ratio is high, but analysts argue that unrealized gains on its property holdings mitigate this concern.

site_title: Bangkok bomb blast a reminder of Thailand's fragile political situation
summary: A bomb blast in Bangkok killed at least 22 people, including a Singaporean woman, and injured over 120 others. The attack on a popular shrine was described by Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha as the "worst ever" in the country. Another explosive device was thrown from a ferry pier on Tuesday, but caused no injuries. The incidents have revived memories of Bangkok's troubled past and are likely to negatively impact the country's tourism sector, which has been a recent economic bright spot for Thailand.

site_title: COE premiums rise for small and big cars, open category
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums rose for small, big cars, and the open category after easing in recent weeks due to a spike in COE quotas. COE premiums increased for vehicles 1,600cc and below (S$57,498) and those above (S$62,140), while motorcycles and goods vehicles/buses saw lower premiums. Experts expect COE premiums to remain steady in the next round, which starts in November, due to the availability of COEs.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Rex JV to buy 30% of North Sea licence
summary: Rex International, a Singapore-based oil exploration firm, has agreed to acquire a 30% stake in North Sea licence PL410. The licence contains "interesting exploration targets" being evaluated, with potential drilling in late 2016. Rex's entity, Lime Petroleum Norway AS, will own 30% of the field, while Lundin Petroleum and Statoil Petroleum will own 52.35% and 17.65% respectively. The move comes amid a volatile market and low oil prices, with Rex stating it will remain prudent with capital expenditure.

site_title: Opec strategy to go full throttle begins to backfire
summary: Opec's plan to increase oil production to protect its members' share of the market is facing mounting costs and risks, particularly for vulnerable nations like Algeria, Iraq, Libya, Nigeria, and Venezuela, known as the "Fragile Five". Oil prices have slumped to six-year lows, and Saudi Arabia's budget deficit has reached nearly 20% of its GDP. Analysts warn that if the plan doesn't lead to a recovery by mid-2016, the strategy may be re-evaluated, and some Opec members may question its effectiveness.

site_title: Ringgit and GST take bite out of travel bug
summary: Malaysia's travel association head states that corporate and personal travel have fallen 30% due to the country's new consumption tax and the weakening ringgit. Tourists are instead opting for neighboring destinations with aggressive advertising and promotional campaigns.

site_title: Tata opens contest for a tool that lets F1 fans predict winners
summary: Tata Communications has launched a competition for tech-savvy F1 fans to design a tool that allows users to predict winners and ranks fans based on accuracy. The tool should use practice data and knowledge of the sport. Entries will be judged by a panel of Formula One drivers and technologists, with a US$50,000 prize for the winner. The competition, the second under the F1 Connectivity Innovation Prize, aims to find new techniques for fans to engage with the sport. The deadline for entries is September 8.

site_title: Traders scale back bets on rate cuts as Sydney home prices surge
summary: Traders are scaling back bets on Australian interest-rate cuts as Sydney home prices surge, with July's gain being the biggest on record since 2011. The surge in home prices, driven by record-breaking sales such as Cate Blanchett's expected A$20 million sale and James Packer's A$70 million sale, has raised concerns among central bank policymakers. Despite this, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is still expected to cut interest rates once more by year-end, driven by a decline in the nation's mining industry.

site_title: German Parliament backs Greek bailout with large majority
summary: The German Parliament voted 454-113 in favor of a third bailout for Greece, worth 86 billion euros, with Chancellor Angela Merkel spared a major rebellion. The approval was largely guaranteed due to Merkel's dominant left-right "grand coalition." Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble argued it would be irresponsible not to support the bailout, given Greece's efforts to implement reforms. The decision comes as Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte faces a possible no-confidence vote over his Cabinet's support for the bailout, which has sparked controversy within the eurozone.

site_title: SMEs get some relief with interim access to foreign manpower
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has launched the Lean Enterprise Development (LED) scheme, providing small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with interim access to foreign manpower while they restructure and build a stronger Singaporean core. The scheme allows companies to hire S Pass holders temporarily, while also exploring alternative solutions such as training local workers or hiring master craftsmen. The scheme is a response to feedback from SMEs that tight labor market and current manpower policies are hindering their restructuring efforts. It will be piloted for two years, starting from October 1.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Who's afraid of BlackRock?
summary: BlackRock, with $4-5 trillion in assets, was considered "too big to fail" by the Financial Stability Board (FSB) due to its significant influence in the financial world. However, the FSB recently backed down from bringing large asset managers like BlackRock under similar regulatory control, instead focusing on understanding the risks posed by the sector as a whole. The FSB deemed asset managers, such as BlackRock, to be mere managers of other people's money, rather than holding assets themselves, and therefore not subject to the same level of scrutiny.

site_title: Building a good governance culture
summary: Singaporean companies have improved their corporate governance in recent years, but more needs to be done to address issues such as limited director quality, diversity, and rising compliance costs. Experts recommend that companies provide training for governance issues, particularly for senior executives, and adopt a more active risk management approach. The ability of the board to set a strong tone from the top and ensure that middle management champions good governance is also crucial. Building a robust corporate governance culture is an ongoing journey that requires continuous improvement and adaptation to changing business environments.

images.alt_text: "The board should take a more active role in risk management and know the best ways to mitigate the risks that might affect the company, such as cyber risk and reputation risk," says Mr Yuen
"Good governance requires clear consequence management with evidence of taking action when non-compliances occur," says Mr Low
"Companies need to be more open about the stereotypes of people that they would bring onto their boards," says Prof Suwardy
"There needs to be a clearer and stronger relationship between the efforts invested by management and the outcomes and benefits of effecting good governance practices," says Mr Neo

site_title: US regulator approves 'female Viagra'
summary: US regulators have approved the first "female Viagra," Addyi, a drug made by Sprout Pharmaceuticals to boost younger women's libido if they have lost interest in sex. The FDA approved the drug specifically for acquired, generalised hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) and warned of potential serious side effects when taken with alcohol. Women taking Addyi reported an average of 4.4 sexually satisfying encounters per month, compared to 3.7 in a placebo group. The drug must only be available at certified pharmacies due to the risk of interaction with alcohol.

site_title: Sole focus of new Japan stock index is finding winning shares
summary: A new Japan stock index, iStoxx MUTB Japan Quality 150 Index, has been launched with a focus on finding winning shares rather than promoting capital efficiency. The index selects companies with high return on equity (ROE), cash flow, and consistent profit generation over five years, rather than prioritizing large firms or high market value. This approach beats the JPX-Nikkei Index 400 in back tests and highlights a limitation of the existing gauge, which has been criticized for recommending overpriced stocks. The new index is seen as a step towards "smart beta" or fundamental indexing, a philosophy that aims to group stocks with desirable characteristics to beat past returns.

site_title: Fed's inflation target elusive as July consumer prices up only 0.1%
summary: The US consumer price index rose 0.1% in July, the slowest pace in three months, casting doubt on the Federal Reserve's inflation target of 2%. The median forecast of economists predicted a 0.2% increase. Energy costs rose 0.1% after a 1.7% increase in June, while shelter costs climbed 0.4%, driven by hotel rates. The Fed's policy-making committee next meets on September 16-17, with 77% of forecasters expecting a rate hike.

site_title: Lacklustre earnings, buyback plans hurting China's Internet bonds
summary: China's internet bonds are experiencing a downturn due to disappointing earnings and plans for share buybacks by major companies like Alibaba and Baidu. Alibaba's $4 billion share repurchase and Baidu's $1 billion plan have fueled concerns that finances will deteriorate, leading to a 0.4% loss in technology notes this quarter. The companies' shares have slumped at least 9% this quarter due to tightened controls on web content and crackdowns on fake goods online. Regulatory concerns and macroeconomic issues have also contributed to poor sentiment for tech bonds, causing investors to demand higher yields for Chinese internet bonds.

site_title: Japan rail firm switches on 'drunk spotting' cameras
summary: Japan's West Japan Railways has installed 50 closed-circuit TV cameras at Kyobashi train station in Osaka to spot drunken behavior and prevent accidents involving late-drinking patrons. The move aims to address frequent incidents involving "salarymen" who stumble onto the tracks. The cameras will help rail staff identify and intervene with individuals exhibiting signs of intoxication, reducing the risk of accidents.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Creative Technology warns that its second-half revenue may fall short of target, with operating losses similar to the first half. The company's stock price is set at S$0.30 with a target price of S$0.52. Meanwhile, OCBC's new CEO, Tan Teck Long, is expected to lead the bank after Helen Wong's retirement.

images.alt_text: Street forecasts are not fully factoring in the impact of a 15 per cent decline in the Singapore dollar-Malaysian ringgit exchange rate over the last one year.

site_title: A job half-done for Japan's working women
summary: Japan's working women are experiencing a significant shift in the country's economic and social fabric, with record numbers entering the workforce. Despite this, women are largely confined to dead-end jobs, with more than two-thirds of female labour force entrants entering the lower-tier market. This two-tiered labour system, where some college graduates are funnelled into secure jobs while others are shunted into low-paying positions, is a major drag on the country's economic health. Experts, such as Kathy Matsui of Goldman Sachs, argue that closing this gap is crucial for boosting growth, with estimates suggesting a 13% increase in GDP if female labour force participation reaches parity with male participation.

site_title: Two new faces in PAP's Tanjong Pagar GRC team
summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) has introduced two new faces, Joan Pereira and Melvin Yong, to its Tanjong Pagar GRC team contesting in the upcoming general election. Pereira, 48, joins after serving as director for family life and active ageing at the People's Association, while Yong is a new addition. Sam Tan will defend his Radin Mas seat in the election. The five-member team will contest in the Tanjong Pagar GRC.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: NSP acting sec-gen Hazel Poa resigns, says she strongly disagrees with decision to contest MacPherson
summary: NSP acting secretary-general Hazel Poa has resigned and will not contest the next general election, citing disagreement with the party's decision to reverse its withdrawal from MacPherson SMC. Poa stated she stepped down due to strong disagreement with the party's stance. The move comes after the NSP reversed its earlier decision to withdraw from the MacPherson constituency.

site_title: Apple poised to join busy Aussie bond market
summary: Apple is set to join Australia's busiest corporate bond market with a potential two-part bond deal, following several domestic and offshore companies that have raised A$6.6 billion in bonds this year. The move comes as Australian yields hit record lows, with the central bank cutting its benchmark cash rate to an unprecedented level. Borrowers are taking advantage of low yields, and the emergence of new issuers in the market may signal its "coming of age".

site_title: Indonesian crash search teams recover aircraft's black boxes
summary: Indonesian search teams have recovered the black boxes from a commercial aircraft that crashed in Papua, killing all 54 people on board. The ATR-42 plane vanished nearly 48 hours ago, and teams battled through jungle and rugged terrain to reach the crash site. Low clouds are hindering efforts to remove bodies from the site. The recovery of the black boxes is a significant development in the investigation into the cause of the crash.

site_title: Japan-China summit on the cards, says LDP senior official
summary: A summit meeting between Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Chinese President Xi Jinping is likely to take place in the near future, according to a senior LDP official. Toshihiro Nikai expressed hope for improved bilateral relations, suggesting the issue of sovereignty over the Senkaku/Diaoyu islands should be "shelved" to cool off disagreements. Nikai also backed Abe's re-election as LDP president and prime minister, amid recent protests and speculation about a potential challenge.

site_title: Philippine telco PLDT buys S'pore e-commerce company Paywhere
summary: The digital innovations unit of PLDT has acquired Singapore-based e-commerce platform Paywhere Pte Ltd for an estimated US$5 million. The acquisition aims to boost the growth of the digital economy in the Philippines and other emerging markets. Voyager Innovation, a PLDT unit, made the announcement on Tuesday. The acquisition is part of PLDT's mission to enable digital innovation and economic growth in the region.

site_title: Lawyers want CPIB included in video-recording pilot programme
summary: Singaporean lawyers are calling for the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) to be included in a pilot video-recording program for police and Central Narcotics Bureau interviews with suspects. The Ministry of Home Affairs announced the program in July, which will test video recordings in the first quarter of 2016.

site_title: US home-rental firms trade below IPO prices
summary: US home-rental firms, including American Homes 4 Rent, American Residential Properties, Silver Bay Realty Trust Corp, and Starwood Waypoint Residential Trust, are struggling to persuade investors due to unpredictable expenses and inconsistent earnings. Shares of these companies are trading below their initial public offering (IPO) prices, with some experiencing significant declines. Experts attribute this to the firms' inability to manage costs, particularly during high turnover periods, and their limited ability to raise capital without issuing new stock.

site_title: Debate rages on whether or not US firms should pay interns
summary: A growing number of lawsuits claim US firms are violating labor laws by offering unpaid internships, prompting experts to call for changes. High-profile cases, including those against actresses Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, have sparked debate over the fairness of unpaid internships. The US Department of Labor has issued rules for private-sector companies, but experts argue these rules are unfair and need to be revised, potentially limiting the number of internships available. Some advocate for paying all interns, while others argue this would exacerbate class divisions.

site_title: Some SMEs either unable or unwilling to keep up with tech: IT consultant
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are struggling to keep up with technological advancements, according to IT consultant Lynette Seah. Some SMEs are aware of the need for change but lack the knowledge to balance budget constraints, people processes, and infrastructure. Others are unwilling to adapt, and their succession plans may not be in place for years to come. However, many SMEs and start-ups have successfully adopted technology, and Singapore has the potential to develop its own technology capabilities, which can be exported to the region and beyond.

images.alt_text: "There are young, energetic, technologically savvy folks adopting technology without the blink of an eye."- Lynette Seah, CEO, Alpha7

site_title: Education key to redirecting Indonesia's economy: panel
summary: Indonesia's economy can be redirected by investing in technical education to support its growing manufacturing sector, a panel of experts said. The country's commodity-driven economy lacks jobs in information and communications technology, leading to weak demand for skilled workers. Increasing the quality of human resource development is crucial to achieving economic growth. Despite the government's rising education budget, academic performance remains below average, and non-formal educational programs such as apprenticeships can help improve quality. A shift towards a production-centric economy is also recommended to reduce reliance on imports and enhance food and energy security.

images.alt_text: Investment is an oft-talked-about subject regarding Indonesia, particularly in infrastructure or manufacturing, but education is a commonly overlooked sector, a panel said on Wednesday, the second day of the Asia Pacific CEO Congress.

site_title: Noble needs to listen and communicate more effectively
summary: Noble Group's shares rose for the first time in seven days after its Investor Day, edging up one cent to 42.5 Singapore cents. However, the stock remains volatile, with brokerages imposing trading restrictions due to increased shortselling levels. Noble's CEO Yusuf Alireza stated that the firm's crisis of confidence stems from a lack of understanding of its business model, but critics argue that the company needs to provide more pertinent disclosures to address the questions raised. The firm's presentation, which included additional disclosures on Yancoal and inventory sales, was seen as a step in the right direction but has yet to alleviate market concerns.

site_title: US law firms prepare to sue London banks for forex rigging
summary: US law firms are preparing to sue London banks for their alleged involvement in the foreign exchange rigging scandal. Following a US$2 billion settlement in New York, law firms like Scott & Scott LLP plan to open a London office to pursue UK suits, targeting banks such as Goldman Sachs, HSBC, and Barclays. Authorities have already fined banks over US$10 billion for their role in manipulating financial benchmarks. A court ruling allows ACA Financial Guaranty Corp to pursue a US$120 million lawsuit against Goldman Sachs over allegedly misleading investors in a security known as Abacus.

site_title: CAAS launches two air-traffic R&D centres
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has launched two research and development centres: the MITRE Asia Pacific Singapore (MAPS) and the Air Traffic Management Research Institute (ATMRI). MAPS, in partnership with MITRE Corp, aims to improve air traffic management efficiency and safety in Singapore and the Asia-Pacific region. ATMRI, established with Nanyang Technological University (NTU), focuses on developing ATM solutions through academic research. The centres aim to support Singapore's growth as a centre of excellence for air traffic management, with the goal of handling increased air traffic safely.

site_title: GrabTaxi bags its biggest funding tranche of US$350m
summary: GrabTaxi Holdings, a Singapore-based taxi booking app, has raised its biggest funding tranche of US$350 million, boosting its total funding to about US$700 million. The investment includes US investment firm Coatue Management, China's sovereign wealth fund China Investment Corporation, and China-based taxi-hailing firm Didi Kuaidi. The funds will be used to fuel new offerings, including GrabCar and GrabBike, and expand engineering offices in Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam, and Beijing.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Treasury Wine shares surge after annual earnings beat estimates
summary: Treasury Wine Estates Ltd, the world's largest listed vintner, reported annual earnings of A$225 million, beating analyst estimates. Sales to Asian consumers surged 46% due to increased demand, while earnings in Europe declined by half. The company's shares rose 11% and were 7.3% higher at A$5.91, marking the largest intraday gain since May 2014. The better result gives CEO Mike Clarke more cash to develop new brands and access higher-quality grapes.

site_title: Hazel Poa quits NSP abruptly over party's decision to contest in MacPherson
summary: Hazel Poa, acting secretary-general of the National Solidarity Party (NSP), resigned and withdrew from the upcoming general election after the party decided to contest the MacPherson ward despite earlier withdrawing its interest. Poa strongly disagreed with the decision, citing a desire to avoid a three-cornered fight with the Workers' Party. The party's central executive committee cited feedback from residents in Marine Parade and MacPherson as the reason for the U-turn, with Poa stating her departure would not leave the NSP leaderless.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

The National Solidarity Party (NSP) has lost one of its top leaders: its acting secretary-general Hazel Poa resigned from the party on Wednesday and has pulled out of the upcoming general election (GE) altogether.

site_title: Silicon Valley's best minds are being hunted by unicorns
summary: Silicon Valley's top tech companies, including Google, Uber, and Airbnb, are competing fiercely for talent by offering high salaries and stock packages. The "unicorn" startups, valued at $1 billion or more, are aggressively poaching employees from large tech companies, including Google's mapping unit and Yelp's engineering team. This "employee's market" has led to a surge in recruiting battles, with companies like Uber and Airbnb expanding their workforce and making large offers to attract top talent. The competition is expected to continue, with Google and other companies fighting to retain their employees amidst the talent war.

site_title: Turkey 'swiftly' heading towards snap polls: Erdogan
summary: Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan stated that the country is "swiftly" heading towards early elections due to failed efforts to form a coalition government. The only solution in the current impasse, according to Erdogan, is to follow the "will of the nation."

site_title: US home prices rise faster than pay of young workers
summary: US home prices are rising faster than the pay of young workers, making it difficult for them to save for down payments. According to a Zillow report, the median home price for first-time buyers is 2.6 times their annual income, up from 1.7 times in the 1970s. As a result, aspiring homeowners are spending more time renting and saving for a down payment, with a median age of 33 for first-time home buyers. Rents are also rising, making it harder for people to save for a down payment, with about half of renters spending more than 30% of their income on housing.

site_title: Target raises 2015 earnings forecast for second time
summary: Target Corp raised its 2015 earnings forecast for the second time, citing strong demand for home products and apparel, driving a 2.4% same-store sales rise in the second quarter. The company's earnings per share exceeded its estimate of $1.04-$1.14. This marks the sixth consecutive quarter of sales growth, surpassing analysts' expectations of a 2.2% rise.

site_title: Walmart cuts profit outlook on higher wages
summary: Walmart cut its annual profit forecast due to higher wages for 500,000 workers, investment in online services, and a stronger dollar. The company reported second-quarter earnings of $1.08 per share, below analyst expectations. Comparable sales at US stores rose 1.5% for the fourth consecutive quarter. Walmart lowered its full-year guidance to $4.40-$4.70 per share, citing long-term investments in e-commerce and employee benefits. The company expects its online channel investments to pay off in the long term, despite short-term earnings pressure.

site_title: Singapore chosen as overseas HQ by Alibaba's cloud computing arm
summary: Alibaba's cloud computing arm, Aliyun, has chosen Singapore as the headquarters for its overseas business and a site for its new data centre. The decision aims to expand globally, leveraging Singapore's ease of doing business, comprehensive connections, and robust intellectual property regime. The new data centre will serve the cloud computing needs of businesses in Southeast Asia, focusing on Chinese businesses.

site_title: Norway wealth fund posts first decline in 3 years
summary: Norway's $870 billion sovereign wealth fund experienced its first decline in three years, losing $12.3 billion in the second quarter due to falling global bond and stock markets. The fund's real estate holdings rose 2%, but its bonds declined 2.2% and stocks dropped 0.2%. The decline is attributed to increased yields in major markets and speculation of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Glencore H1 hit by commodities woes, impairment
summary: Glencore reported a first-half loss of $676 million due to the worst commodities market since the 2008-2009 financial crash. This marks a significant decline from the $1.7 billion profit recorded in the first half of 2014. The company attributed the loss to a decline in commodity prices.

site_title: India's petrol imports seen underpinning Asian margins till March 2016
summary: India's strong petrol imports are expected to support Asian margins until March 2016, driven by a shift towards petrol car sales and rising demand. Petrol imports from April to June were the highest in over four years, and India's petrol demand grew 14.17% in the first six months of 2015. State refiners in India are expected to continue importing petrol until the end of the fiscal year, despite a surplus of 310,000 barrels per day.

site_title: Rex International to acquire 30% stake in North Sea area
summary: Rex International, a Catalist-listed oil exploration and production firm, announced it will acquire a 30% stake in North Sea area licence PL410. The licence contains exploration targets, and drilling could take place in late 2016 if a positive conclusion is reached. This acquisition is part of Rex's efforts to evaluate the area's potential for oil exploration.

site_title: Jaitley urges RBI to cut benchmark interest rate
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley urged the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to cut the benchmark interest rate to boost the country's $2 trillion economy, citing cooling inflation. The economy has slowed, with factory output growing 1.6% per month since 2013, and credit growth hitting a two-decade low. Jaitley also emphasized the need to focus on the manufacturing sector to boost economic growth to 8-10%. The RBI had previously cut interest rates three times this year, but Governor Raghuram Rajan maintained that more clarity was needed on inflation before making further cuts.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close lower
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE 100 index down 1.88% at 6,403.45 points. The CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX 30 also declined 1.75% and 2.14% respectively. The decline was attributed to mining and healthcare sectors, while US-EU trade talks were in focus.

site_title: US: Stocks fall ahead of Federal Reserve minutes
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday ahead of the release of Federal Reserve meeting minutes, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 133.05 points (0.76%) at 17,378.29. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also dropped, 0.58% each, as traders await the minutes for signs of interest rate hikes. Analysts warn that the minutes may be over-analyzed and subject to outdated assumptions due to changes in market conditions since the July meeting, including China's currency devaluation and higher oil prices.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Police say two other men seen in bomb footage also suspects
summary: Thai police identified two more suspects in the Bangkok bomb blast that killed 20 people, bringing the total number of suspects to three. The suspects were seen in CCTV footage near the scene, along with a man in a yellow t-shirt believed to be linked to the attack. A sketch of the man in yellow was released by police.

site_title: STI dips, dashing hopes of a clawback
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% or 8.4 points to 3,041.2, ending a day below the 3,050 mark for the first time since February 2014. The decline was attributed to China's economic slowdown, weakening currencies, and US rate hike uncertainties. Other regional markets also declined, with Hong Kong falling 1.3%, Tokyo 1.6%, and Seoul 0.9%. Analysts expect capital outflows to accelerate, with investors repatriating funds and holding on to cash until the market settles.

site_title: Mining giant Glencore reports US$676m first-half loss
summary: Swiss mining giant Glencore reported a first-half loss of US$676 million due to the worst commodities market since the 2008-2009 financial crash. The company's shares have fallen 40% this year, driven by fears of a slowdown in China and impairments at its oil operation in Chad and Optimum Coal mine in South Africa. Despite this, CEO Ivan Glasenberg believes the company is well-positioned to benefit from improving commodity prices.

site_title: Phillip, CIMB, UOB impose curbs on Noble Group share trading
summary: Singapore's top brokerages Phillip, CIMB, and UOB have restricted online trading and imposed curbs on Noble Group Ltd. shares due to volatility. The restrictions include limiting phone orders and requiring large purchases to be paid in cash. Noble's shares have slumped 60% since February due to accounting issues and a decline in global commodity markets. The company has defended its finances, but short interest has surged to a new high, sparking concerns of margin calls and further market volatility.

images.alt_text: Embattled commodity merchant Noble Group is expanding its Singapore oil team to focus on growing regional demand despite a price rout that has hurt some companies trading crude oil and refined products.

site_title: Facebook leads social pack in US, Twitter sputters: study
summary: Facebook remains the dominant social network in the US, with 72% of online Americans using it, according to a Pew Research Center report. This represents a modest 1% increase from last year and a 5-point increase from 2012. The study also found that 62% of all US adults are on Facebook.

site_title: Iceland raises key rate by half-point to 5.5%
summary: Iceland's central bank raised its key interest rate by half-point to 5.5% due to the risk of inflation following collective wage hikes. The bank forecasts inflation to rise to 4% in 2016 and predicts economic growth of 4% in 2015 and 3% in the following years. This is the second interest rate hike in two months, aimed at preventing inflation from rising above the 2.5% target.

site_title: IMF extends SDR update as it eyes inclusion of China's yuan
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has extended the update of its elite currencies basket, known as the "special drawing rights" (SDR), by nine months to September 30, 2016. This move gives more time for adjustment to the potential inclusion of China's yuan in the basket. The review, originally scheduled for the end of 2015, will also adjust the weightings of the four existing currencies: dollar, yen, euro, and pound. The decision could pave the way for China's yuan to become a reserve currency.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended higher on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 2.84 points to close at 1,582.44. The index saw 1.9 billion lots valued at RM1.8 billion traded, with 557 gainers and 259 losers.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Creative Technology has warned that its H2 revenue may be lower than target, with a similar operating loss to the first half of the year. Meanwhile, Singapore's OCBC Bank announced Helen Wong's retirement as CEO and named Tan Teck Long as her successor. The bank's incoming CEO has a background in DBS. London's Heathrow Airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Toyota extends halt to Tianjin operations on health concerns
summary: Toyota has extended its halt to operations in Tianjin, China until at least Sunday due to safety concerns following a deadly chemical explosion. The company has not confirmed the sites are safe and will make up for lost production by scheduling substitute days. Toyota operates two assembly lines near the Tianjin port, which were affected by the blast. The company is taking precautions until the area is deemed safe.

site_title: US consumer prices edge up 0.1% in July
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.1% in July, slowing from a 0.3% gain in June, as the Federal Reserve plans an interest rate increase this year. Food prices rose 0.2% and energy prices increased 0.1%, with gasoline prices offsetting declines in other components. Core CPI, excluding food and energy, rose 0.1% month-over-month and 1.8% year-over-year, in line with the Federal Reserve's target for price stability.

site_title: Singapore: Shares close 0.3% down
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.3% down on Wednesday due to a continued sell-off in commodities, deepening concerns over China's economy slowdown. The Straits Times Index lost 8.4 points to 3,041.2, mainly weighed down by banks. Losers outnumbered gainers 325 to 137, with Noble Group being the most actively traded stock.

site_title: Oil steadies before US energy report
summary: Global oil prices stabilized on Wednesday as investors awaited a US energy report. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell 18 US cents to $42.44 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude rose five cents to $48.86 a barrel. Analysts expect US inventories to decline, but supply remains high due to OPEC's continued output and potential return of Iran's exports. Demand growth is not keeping pace with supply, particularly with China's slowdown, and prices are unlikely to stage a sustained rally.

images.alt_text: Three Chinese energy firms were told by local authorities in China to halt operations, after massive blasts at a warehouse in Tianjin last week raised public concerns that some facilities storing hazardous materials are too close to homes and schools.

site_title: Gold marks time ahead of Fed minutes
summary: Gold remains stable at around $1,117 an ounce as investors await the release of the Federal Reserve's meeting minutes, which may signal a potential interest rate hike. The US central bank's decision could lead to a decline in gold's appeal, but some analysts expect a post-move rally in commodity markets. The housing sector's recovery and strengthening job market also suggest a possible rate hike, but a gradual approach is also possible.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore announced a scheme to help progressive SMEs grow in a manpower-lean economy. Over 70 BTO projects with 2-room Flexi flats will be launched in the next five years. COE premiums were mixed, with small cars and the open category rising. Meanwhile, Jurong Aromatics Corp, a major petrochemical plant operator, is in debt talks after oil prices plummeted. Local shares slipped 0.3% down due to a continued sell-off in commodities and concerns about China's slowing economy.

site_title: 2 new faces in PAP's lineup for Tanjong Pagar GRC; Sam Tan to defend Radin Mas SMC
summary: Labour chief Chan Chun Sing introduced two new faces to his Tanjong Pagar GRC team. Sam Tan, 56, will defend his seat in Radin Mas SMC. The changes come ahead of the Singapore General Election.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Thai court issues arrest warrant for unnamed foreign man
summary: A Thai court issued an arrest warrant for an unnamed foreign man in connection with the deadly Bangkok shrine bombing, which killed 20 people and injured scores more. The suspect is described as a young man with light stubble and a full head of hair, seen calmly leaving a backpack at the Erawan shrine before the bomb went off. Police believe the bomber had accomplices and may have been part of a network. The warrant accuses him of premeditated murder, attempted murder, and bomb-making.

site_title: Thakral announces real estate investment programme with Aberdeen
summary: Thakral Corporation has launched a real estate investment programme with Aberdeen Asset Management Asia, focusing on projects in Brisbane, Melbourne, and Sydney's central business districts. The six-year programme, managed by TCAP Investments Limited, aims to source capital for wholesale and third-party funds. With Aberdeen's backing, Thakral expects greater flexibility in capital sourcing and confidence in delivering strong returns.

site_title: Crude tumbles to six-year low after unexpected US supply gain
summary: US crude oil prices plummeted to a six-year low after the Energy Information Administration reported a surprise increase in US crude stockpiles, with supplies rising 2.62 million barrels last week. Crude imports surged to their highest level since April as refineries reduced operating rates. The decline in oil prices, which has fallen over 30% since June, is attributed to producers maintaining output despite a surplus pushing prices into a bear market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall, Carlsberg slumps
summary: European stock markets fell on Wednesday, extending a losing streak due to concerns over China. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index dropped 0.6%, while Carlsberg plummeted 7% after cutting its profit forecast. The Euro STOXX 50 index also fell 0.6%. This decline follows recent losses, with investors weighing the impact of China's economic situation on global markets.

site_title: Over 70 BTO projects in next 5 years to come with 2-room Flexi flats
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) will launch over 70 Build-to-Order (BTO) projects with 2-room Flexi flats in the next five years. At least 40% of these flats will be reserved for elderly citizens aged 55 and above, offering a flexible lease option ranging from 15 to 45 years. The scheme marries studio and two-room flat types, allowing buyers to choose from 36-square-metre or 45-square-metre sizes, with pricing based on lease tenure and buyer type. Subletting and resale are not allowed for these flats with short leases.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 15.08 points to 1594.68. Gainers outnumbered losers 101 to 54, with a total volume of 37.5 million lots worth RM10.9 million.

site_title: Japan rail firm switches on 'drunk spotting' cameras
summary: Japan's West Japan Railways (JR West) has installed 50 CCTV cameras at its Kyobashi train station in Osaka to detect and prevent drunken passengers from falling onto the tracks. The cameras will automatically detect abnormal behavior, such as unsteady walking or prolonged sitting on benches, and set off an alarm. The move follows a previous change to platform benches, which were rotated to face the platform rather than the tracks. The initiative aims to reduce accidents involving late-drinking "salarymen" and is expected to be expanded to other stations.

site_title: Hot weather, discounts lift Japan department store sales in July
summary: Japan's department store sales rose 3.4% in July from the previous year, driven by hot weather and summer discounts, boosting demand for clothing and cosmetics. Sales of clothing increased 2.8% and cosmetics 18.4%, helping the fourth consecutive month of total department store sales growth. The strong sales are a welcome sign for policymakers, but analysts caution that it's too early to conclude a sustained upturn in consumption, as the figures for October-December will be crucial.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Thai police release detailed sketch of suspect
summary: Thai police have released a detailed sketch of the suspect seen leaving a backpack at a shrine before a bomb detonated in Bangkok, killing 20 people and injuring scores. The unidentified man, with a light complexion, stubble, and glasses, may be foreign or Thai. Authorities are investigating the bombing, which occurred at a shrine in Bangkok.

site_title: COE premiums end mixed
summary: COE premiums ended the latest round of bidding on a mixed note, with increases in all categories. COEs for small cars, big cars, and the open category rose to S$57,498, S$62,140, and S$61,001 respectively. The increases reflect a two-week rise in premiums. The price hikes are attributed to a combination of factors, including rising fuel costs and increased demand for vehicles.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Indonesian president urges new cabinet to spend to support growth
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged his new cabinet to spend their budgets to boost economic growth, which is expected to miss the 5.0-5.2% target. The government has only disbursed 10% of funds earmarked for investment, and capital spending is at 20% of the budget. Widodo aims for a 5.5% growth rate in 2016, and the state budget and regional government budgets have a multiplier effect on the economy. Critics argue that the slow spending is affecting economic growth, with many of Widodo's ambitious plans being hindered by red tape.

site_title: Eurozone yields stabilise as global inflation slowdown fears ease
summary: Eurozone bond yields stabilized after a sharp rise due to a surprise UK inflation increase, easing concerns of a global inflation slowdown. The UK data eased fears of a Chinese economic slowdown fueling inflation, which had driven down yields in recent weeks. Investors now await the US inflation data, with some speculating a potential Federal Reserve rate hike. The European Central Bank's bond buying program may also be extended beyond its scheduled end in September 2016.

site_title: NSP to contest MacPherson SMC after all, setting up potential three-cornered fight
summary: The National Solidarity Party (NSP) has decided to contest the MacPherson Single Member Constituency (SMC) despite earlier withdrawing from the constituency. This move sets up a potential three-cornered fight in the upcoming general election. The NSP had initially withdrawn from MacPherson and Marine Parade Group Representation Constituency (GRC) due to overlapping claims with the Workers' Party (WP). The decision to contest MacPherson is seen as a significant development in the electoral landscape.

images.alt_text: A three-cornered fight looks likely in MacPherson SMC at the next general election, after the National Solidarity Party (NSP) said on Wednesday it is reversing its earlier decision to withdraw from the constituency.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall for 4th session, China worries mount
summary: Hong Kong shares fell for the fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng index declining 1.3% to 23,167.85, amid concerns over China's economy.
