The Commerce Ministry reported that exports could continue to fall in coming months, following an 8.3% drop in July. This gloomy news contributed to investor confidence, leading to a steady stream of negative news about China's economy.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended barely changed on Thursday, as most Asian markets stabilised after jitters over Turkey's downing of a Russian fighter jet abated.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 1.61%
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.61% on Wednesday, following declines on Wall Street and China's main index. Weak trade data hinted at the fragility of Japan's recovery, with the Nikkei 225 index sliding 331.84 points to 20,222.63 yen. The Topix index lost 1.42% to 1,648.48. The decline is attributed to global economic concerns and weak trade data.

site_title: Taxi app GrabTaxi raises US$350m from CIC, investors
summary: GrabTaxi Holdings Pte Ltd raised over US$350 million from investors, including China's sovereign wealth fund China Investment Corporation and hedge fund Coatue Management LLC, in its largest fundraising round. The company has now raised a total of about US$700 million. GrabTaxi competes with Uber Technologies Inc. and counts Japanese telecoms firm SoftBank Corp and Singapore state investor Temasek Holdings as shareholders.

site_title: MOM unveils scheme to help progressive SMEs grow amid a manpower-lean economy
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore announced a Lean Enterprise Development Scheme to support progressive small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in transforming and growing in a manpower-lean economy. The scheme aims to help SMEs become more productive, innovative, and manpower-lean, with a focus on scaling up transformational changes for industries. Temporary manpower policy adjustments will be allowed, including the use of temporary foreign workers, and the scheme will be piloted for two years from October 1, 2015.

site_title: 'Give Greece a chance', Schaeuble tells lawmakers before vote
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble urged lawmakers to support a third bailout for Greece, urging them to give the country a chance for a new start despite no guarantees of success. The 86 billion-euro bailout is expected to be overwhelmingly supported, with a minority of Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservatives voting against it. A significant opposition vote would signal the government's last chance to keep Greece in the euro zone.

site_title: Australia: Shares bounce off 7-month lows on bargain hunting
summary: Australian shares bounced back 1.5% from seven-month lows on Wednesday, with gains across the board, driven by bargain hunting in banks and resources stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 77.05 points to 5,380.2, while New Zealand's NZX 50 index increased 0.7% to 5,750.03. The recovery follows a trough on Tuesday, with the rally expected to continue despite ongoing market uncertainty.

site_title: China: Shanghai stocks reverse loss to close up 1.23%
summary: Shanghai stocks reversed a 5% loss to close up 1.23% on Wednesday, driven by expectations of government support. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 45.95 points to 3,794.11, reversing a day-to-day drop of 5.06%. This marks the largest recovery in three weeks.

site_title: Vard 'not aware' of reason for price plunge; SGX issues 'trade with caution' notice
summary: Shipbuilder Vard Holdings said it's not aware of any information explaining its 28% price plunge to S$0.27. Despite recovering some ground, it remains down 10.7% and 4 cents from its previous close. The company confirmed it's in compliance with SGX-ST listing rules and has disclosed all material information.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Thai police hunt for accomplices of suspected bomber
summary: Thai authorities are investigating a bomb blast at the Erawan shrine in Bangkok that killed 22 people, mostly foreigners, and wounded over 120. A suspect, identified as a young man with dark hair, was captured on CCTV footage, but police believe he may be an accomplice to a bomber. Authorities suspect the attack was aimed at disrupting Thailand's tourism economy. Police are considering ethnic Uighurs as a possible suspect group, despite no official claim of responsibility, and are also investigating domestic and international groups.

site_title: Goldman Sachs's unit obtains Hong Kong banking license
summary: Goldman Sachs has obtained a restricted banking license from the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), allowing it to take deposits of HK$500,000 (S$90,548) and above. This move creates a local subsidiary for the US investment bank to book trades. The license is part of a trend among the world's largest investment banks to set up new subsidiaries in response to post-crisis regulations. Goldman Sachs can now conduct investment banking and capital markets activities, but is limited in taking deposits.

site_title: Ringgit falls with bonds as inflation may spur policy response
summary: Malaysia's ringgit and long-term bonds fell as inflation rose to its fastest pace in a year, sparking speculation of interest rate hikes to curb inflation. The 10-year government bond yield rose to 4.33%, the highest since 2010, and the ringgit dropped 0.5% to 4.1097 per dollar. The economy's expansion slowed to 4.9% in the second quarter, and consumer prices rose 3.3% in July, exceeding expectations. Global investors cut holdings of Malaysian bonds, and the central bank may raise interest rates to anchor macro variables, potentially further weakening the currency.

site_title: China injects nearly US$100b into banks for economy lift
summary: China has injected nearly US$100 billion into two policy banks, the China Development Bank and the Export-Import Bank of China, to stimulate its sluggish economy. The central bank added US$48 billion to the China Development Bank and US$45 billion to the Export-Import Bank of China. The move aims to guide funds to the real economy, such as exports and infrastructure construction, to achieve the government's 7.0% growth target for 2015. This injection follows previous monetary loosening efforts, including interest rate cuts and reserve requirement ratio reductions.

site_title: Singapore's Jurong Aromatics said in debt talks after oil plunge
summary: Jurong Aromatics, a Singapore-based petrochemical plant operator, is in debt talks after a plunge in oil prices. The US$2.4 billion plant, which began operations in September 2014, has stalled production since December due to lack of working capital. The company is negotiating with lenders and suppliers, including BNP Paribas, Standard Chartered, and Glencore, to restructure its debt. If talks fail, some lenders have threatened to tip the company into receivership, prompting shareholders and suppliers to seek a grace period extension.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall, foreigners sell for 10th day; won flat
summary: Seoul shares fell to a seven-month low, closing 0.9% down at 1,939.38 points, amid renewed concerns over China's economy. Foreigners sold a net 1.20 trillion won worth of shares for the 10th consecutive session, marking their longest selling spree since Dec 2014. The South Korean won remained stable at 1,185.3 per dollar.

site_title: Tianjin blasts echo across Chinese economy
summary: A devastating explosion at the Tianjin port in China has caused widespread destruction, killing 114 people and resulting in over $1 billion in losses. The blast, which occurred last week, has severely impacted the city's economy, with major multinational firms such as Toyota and GlaxoSmithKline unable to access their facilities. The port, a key gateway to China's second-largest economy, has been severely damaged, and its operations have been disrupted. The long-term economic impact is uncertain, but analysts warn that the disruption could spread along supply chains and affect the global economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.23% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.23% in early trade on Wednesday, following a major sell-off in Shanghai. The Hang Seng Index added 54.63 points to 23,529.60. This bounce came after a major sell-off in Shanghai, which had dragged down shares in the previous session.

site_title: PAP unveils two new faces in Tanjong Pagar GRC
summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) has announced two new faces, Joan Pereira and Melvin Yong, as part of its Tanjong Pagar GRC team for the upcoming general election. The team, led by anchor minister Chan Chun Sing, also includes Indranee Rajah and Chia Shi-Lu. This marks the first time Tanjong Pagar GRC has experienced an electoral battle, with the opposition party Singaporeans First expressing interest in contesting the constituency. The PAP aims to maintain its 60-year dominance in the area, describing it as a "very special" constituency.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Former civil servant Joan Pereira (left) and retired senior police officer Melvin Yong.

site_title: China: Yuan slips as mainland stocks slide
summary: China's yuan slipped against the US dollar as mainland stocks fell over 2% in opening trades, despite a flat yuan fixing. The yuan had edged lower on concerns a further weakening would hit importers and amid speculation the central bank may not ease policy further. This comes after a 6% drop in stocks on Tuesday, their largest fall in three weeks. Traders remain cautious after the central bank's surprise devaluation of the yuan by nearly 2% on August 11.

site_title: Japan's Kirin to buy F&N's stake in Myanmar Brewery for US$560m: source
summary: Japan's Kirin Holdings is set to buy Fraser and Neave's (F&N) 55% stake in Myanmar Brewery Ltd for US$560 million. The deal comes after F&N agreed to sell its stake to government-backed Myanma Economic Holdings Ltd (MEHL) earlier this month. Kirin, which will be MEHL's nominee, is looking to purchase the stake at the agreed price. The acquisition is part of Kirin's expansion into the Southeast Asian market, following previous interest from SABMiller and Thailand's Boon Rawd Brewery. The deal's announcement could come as early as Wednesday.

site_title: Oil prices fall ahead of US stocks data
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia, with West Texas Intermediate dropping 17 cents to $42.45 a barrel and Brent crude dipping 23 cents to $48.58 a barrel. Analysts attribute the decline to a surplus of supplies from OPEC and a report on US crude inventories, which are expected to decline but remain high due to robust US shale oil production. The slowdown in China and potential return of Iranian oil exports also contribute to the supply glut, making sustained price rallies unlikely.

site_title: China's port authorities to strengthen dangerous goods shipment supervision
summary: China's port authorities will strengthen supervision of dangerous goods shipments following devastating explosions at Tianjin port last week. Port authorities in provinces including Zhejiang, Liaoning, and Guangdong have asked shipping firms to conduct self-inspections to check safety standards. The move comes after over a hundred people were killed by blasts at a warehouse storing hazardous chemicals at Tianjin Port. The authorities have pledged to crack down on any illegal activities, aiming to prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: China: Stocks open down over 2%, extend previous day's sharp fall
summary: China's stocks opened down 2% on Wednesday, extending a sharp 6% fall from the previous day, amid uncertainty over monetary policy. The CSI300 index fell to 3,748.18 points, and the Shanghai Composite Index lost 2.7% to 3,646.75 points. This follows concerns that the central bank may not ease policy further and a weakening yuan could impact importers.

images.alt_text: China stocks open down over 2 per cent on Wednesday, extending previous day's sharp losses amid growing uncertainty over the monetary policy outlook.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall to near 7-mth low; won steady ahead of FOMC minutes
summary: Seoul shares fell to a near seven-month low, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) down 1.3% at 1,931.49 points. Renewed worries over China's economy, following Tuesday's plunge in Chinese share prices, contributed to the decline. Institutional selling and after-effects from Tuesday's sharp fall weighed on the main board, with declining shares outnumbering gainers 7.3 to 1.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit near two-year lows on jittery overseas markets, China
summary: Taiwan's stocks plummeted 1.3% to near two-year lows, extending losses due to sluggish overseas markets and concerns over China. The main TAIEX index fell to 8,074.31, with the electronics and financials subindexes also declining. This marks the lowest level since November 2013.

site_title: Intel, Survivor producers plan show on wearables
summary: Intel is partnering with Survivor producer Mark Burnett to create a reality TV show, America's Greatest Makers, where makers of wearables and smart devices compete to win a $1 million prize. The show, set to premiere in early 2016, will challenge competitors to invent devices powered by Intel's Curie technology. This marks Intel's entry into reality TV, as the company shifts its focus from semiconductors for personal computers to mobile devices and connected objects.

site_title: Cathay Pacific first-half profit up nearly sixfold
summary: Cathay Pacific reported a nearly sixfold increase in first-half profit to HK$1.97 billion, driven by lower fuel costs and increased passenger and cargo capacity. Revenue fell 0.9% to HK$50.39 billion. The airline attributed the growth to a 35% decrease in fuel costs, but missed expectations due to hedging losses.

site_title: Google gets in the WiFi router business
summary: Google has unveiled OnHub, a WiFi router designed to provide fast, secure, and easy-to-use connections for smartphones and tablets. The cylindrical router, priced at $200, allows users to prioritize device connections and is set to be available in US and Canadian stores in the coming weeks. This move marks Google's entry into the WiFi router market, following its acquisition of Nest last year. OnHub aims to simplify home WiFi setup and provide a seamless experience for users.

images.alt_text: Google unveiled a WiFi router Tuesday looking to increase the ease and speed at which people's increasingly indispensable smartphones and tablets connect at home with its services.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday ahead of Fed meeting's minutes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 5.8 points or 0.19% to 3,055.45, ahead of the Federal Reserve's minutes release, which is expected to provide clues on a potential US interest-rate increase. Despite selloffs in Asian stocks for a fourth day, investors await the Fed's decision, with market expectations for a September rate hike falling to 48% from 50% last week.

site_title: Update: Phillip restricts trading of Noble Group shares as shorts surge
summary: Phillip Securities Pte has restricted online trading of Noble Group Ltd. shares due to high volatility, following a surge in short interest. Noble's shares have declined 60% since February, with a 14.15% short interest as of Monday. The company's credit outlook has been cut to negative, and its bonds are trading below investment grade prices. Clients can still trade Noble shares but must place orders through dealers who will assess their backgrounds. CEO Yusuf Alireza defended the company's finances in a meeting with investors.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Pacific Andes, China Fishery, CEFC, Aspial
summary: Pacific Andes and China Fishery requested a trading halt pending an announcement. Pacific Andes' Q3 earnings slumped 90% to HK$37.7 million due to lower sales volume and asset disposal. CEFC International's share price rose over ten-fold since mid-July but warned investors to exercise caution due to uncertain joint ventures. Aspial Corporation issued retail bonds for up to S$75 million with a 5.25% fixed interest rate.

site_title: Hot stock: Vard hits record low, prompts SGX query
summary: Vard Holdings, a Singapore-based shipbuilder, hit a record low of S$0.27 on the stock market, plummeting 28% from its previous close. The company reported a 58.6% decline in net profit for its second quarter, citing lower revenue and declining additions to its order book. Analysts have issued "sell" calls, citing concerns over the company's cash reserves and ability to pay dividends. The Singapore Exchange has queried Vard about the sudden drop, prompting the company to disclose any previously unannounced information.

site_title: Malaysia riskier than Mexico has UBS warning of worse to come
summary: Malaysia's credit-default swaps widened to 180 basis points, the highest level since 2011, due to weak foreign currency holdings and messy politics. The country's foreign-exchange reserves slipped below $100 billion, prompting concerns of a currency selloff. UBS predicts the ringgit will fall to 4.20 by year-end. The central bank may need to raise interest rates to defend the currency, with experts warning of "increasingly meagre" reserves by emerging-market standards. Prime Minister Najib Razak faces scrutiny over a reported $700 million donation into his bank account.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.34%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.34% lower on Wednesday, following falls on Wall Street and a plunge on China's main index. Japan's trade deficit fell 72.3% year-on-year in July, but still widened to 268.05 billion yen. The Nikkei 225 index fell 69.41 points to 20,485.06 yen. Investors are concerned about the Chinese economy, which saw a 6.15% drop in the Shanghai Composite Index on Tuesday.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Bomb shrine re-opens as police hunt suspect
summary: A bomb blast at the Erawan shrine in Bangkok on Monday killed 20 people, including at least 11 foreigners. The attack, which occurred during evening prayers, left 58 injured. Police are hunting a suspect shown on security footage calmly planting the bomb. No one has claimed responsibility for the attack. The victims included Chinese, Hong Kong, Singaporean, Indonesian, and Malaysian nationals. The shrine has since reopened with prayers led by Thai monks.

images.alt_text: Thai monks led prayers Wednesday for the reopening of Bangkok shrine where a blast killed 20 people, as police hunted a man shown on security footage calmly planting what is believed to be the bomb.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble Group shorts advance to record as company defends finances
summary: Noble Group's short interest surged to a record 14.15% on Monday, as investors defended the company's finances after CEO Yusuf Alireza led a five-hour investor meeting in Singapore. Shares rose 3.6% to 43 Singapore cents, their first gain in seven days, as Noble pledged to boost operating profit to over $2 billion in the next three to five years. Despite a 60% slump since February, Noble wants to remain a publicly traded entity, with Alireza stating the pressure has made the company better.

site_title: Japan's July exports rise 7.6% year on year: MOF
summary: Japan's exports rose 7.6% year-over-year in July, exceeding economists' expectations of 5.5%, following a 9.5% year-on-year rise in June. Imports fell 3.2% year-over-year, lower than the estimated 7.9% decrease. The stronger export data suggests overseas demand remains steady.

site_title: How scoring is done
summary: The Governance and Transparency Index (GTI) assesses companies on their corporate governance practices and financial transparency. The GTI score is based on a base score of up to 100 points, adjusted by bonuses and penalties. The index is a tripartite collaboration between NUS Business School, CPA Australia, and The Business Times, covering 639 SGX-listed companies. The GTI is currently in its seventh year, with the latest score released in 2015, providing a snapshot of corporate governance and transparency practices among Singaporean companies.

site_title: E-cigarettes are 95% less harmful than tobacco: UK study
summary: A UK study by Public Health England found that e-cigarettes are around 95% less harmful than tobacco, carrying just a fraction of the harm. Most chemicals causing smoking-related diseases are absent in e-cigarettes, making them a potentially cheap tool to reduce smoking in deprived areas. The study contradicts previous calls for strict regulation of e-cigarettes, instead promoting them as a quitting aid.

site_title: Escaping Najib's Malaysia, investors flee currency, stock market
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak faces mounting pressure amid probes into his bank accounts, with the ringgit slumping 5.6% and the benchmark stock index losing 8.3%. The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission's findings that Najib received RM2.6 billion from donors, not state investment company 1Malaysia Development Bhd, have led to a sovereign bond risk jump and a four-year high. Investors, including PineBridge Investments and Schroder Investment Management, have cut Malaysian sovereign bond holdings and expressed concerns about the outlook for the economy, citing plunging oil prices and an emerging-market selloff.

site_title: Fitch raises Greece rating after new bailout deal struck
summary: Fitch Ratings raised Greece's credit grade to CCC, one notch above junk-bond territory, citing a new bailout deal that reduces the risk of default on private sector debt obligations. The $86 billion rescue deal is deemed tenuous, requiring official debt relief for Greece's finances to become sustainable over the medium term.

site_title: Hackers dump data from cheating website Ashley Madison online
summary: Hackers dumped a large cache of data, including customer information, from the cheating spouses website Ashley Madison, which was stolen a month ago. The data, totaling 9.7GB, was posted on the dark web and includes member account and credit card details. The hackers, known as Impact Team, had threatened to release the data unless the site was taken down, and now claim Avid Life Media has failed to comply. The data has since been shared on other sites, and the company has not responded to inquiries.

images.alt_text: Hackers have followed through on a threat to release online a huge cache of data, including customer information, that was stolen a month ago from cheating spouses website AshleyMadison.com, several tech websites reported on Tuesday.

site_title: Tech will play big part in further Asean integration: panel
summary: Digital technology is set to play a significant role in further integrating the Asean region, benefiting small and medium-sized enterprises and leveling the playing field with multinational corporations. This will enable industries to adapt to new technologies, such as 3D printing, and adopt an "omni-channel" approach to marketing. With digital technology, companies can easily reach consumers across rural and metropolitan areas, and tap neighboring states, taking advantage of frictionless borders and duty-free trade. This will create new opportunities for Asean businesses to expand their reach and tap into the region's growing market.

site_title: Nomura appoints Harry Ng as new head of Asia ex-Japan trust
summary: Nomura appoints Harry Ng as head of Asia ex-Japan trust, based in Singapore, to manage client relationships and estate administration activities. Ng, a former Julius Baer and Merrill Lynch executive, brings extensive experience in wealth planning. He will report to Nobuhiro Sano, head of wealth management of Asia ex-Japan. The appointment demonstrates Nomura's commitment to its long-term growth strategy in wealth management.

site_title: Greek government slightly eases capital controls
summary: The Greek government has eased capital controls, allowing individuals to transfer 500 euros per month abroad and 5,000 euros every three months to foreign students, while businesses can transfer money abroad for exports with certain restrictions. The limit on weekly cash withdrawals remains unchanged at 420 euros. The easing of controls aims to alleviate the impact of the capital controls on businesses and individuals, but the process of getting large bill payments approved by a government commission has been slow, frustrating foreign companies.

images.alt_text: The Greek government on Tuesday revealed it was easing slightly the capital controls imposed on the debt-hit country by allowing individuals to transfer 500 euros (S$774) per month abroad.

site_title: American Airlines to launch LA-Cuba charter flights
summary: American Airlines plans to launch weekly charter flights between Los Angeles and Havana in December, becoming the second major US airline to do so after JetBlue. The flights will serve the growing market of non-Cuban travelers, expanding on American's existing charters from Florida. The move comes as the US and Cuba edge closer to full bilateral aviation relations.

site_title: Rescuers reach Trigana Air crash site, begin retrieval ops
summary: Rescuers reached the crash site of a Trigana Air commercial aircraft that crashed in Indonesia's remote eastern region, killing all 54 aboard. The bodies have been found, and rescue teams are preparing equipment for evacuation and building a helipad. The plane, carrying 49 passengers and 5 crew, vanished in stormy weather on Sunday. The crash site is extremely hard to reach, even for local people. This incident raises concerns about the safety of the Indonesian airline industry, which has experienced several fatal crashes in recent years.

site_title: IAG confirms purchase of Ireland's Aer Lingus
summary: International Airlines Group (IAG) confirmed the purchase of Ireland's Aer Lingus, with offers for 96% of its share capital accepted. Ryanair, which owned 29.8% of Aer Lingus, accepted the offer, making it a condition of the deal that is now unconditional. IAG, which also owns Iberia, acquired Aer Lingus without conditions being met.

site_title: Oil prices higher ahead of US inventory data
summary: Oil prices rose modestly on Tuesday ahead of US commercial inventory data, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate closing at $42.62 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude at $48.81 a barrel. Experts expect a decrease in US crude inventories, but some predict a slowdown in refinery usage and potential additions to US stockpiles, which could send prices lower. Despite this, some analysts believe WTI is bottoming out after a 30% drop in the past two months, and global supply glut is expected to persist until 2018.

images.alt_text: Three Chinese energy firms were told by local authorities in China to halt operations, after massive blasts at a warehouse in Tianjin last week raised public concerns that some facilities storing hazardous materials are too close to homes and schools.

site_title: China home prices rise for third straight month in July
summary: China's home prices rose for a third consecutive month in July, with average new home prices increasing 0.3% from June, according to data from the National Bureau of Statistics. The modest recovery in the property sector, which accounts for 15% of China's GDP, is a welcome boost for the economy, which is heading for its weakest growth in 25 years. Despite a huge overhang of unsold houses, property sales and housing investment improved, with prices in first-tier cities such as Beijing, Shanghai, and Shenzhen leading the recovery.

site_title: Dollar steady, pound up after inflation climbs
summary: The US dollar was largely steady against major rivals on Tuesday, except for the pound, which rose after British inflation data supported expectations of a Bank of England interest rate hike. The pound reached its highest level in nearly seven weeks, while the euro and dollar were influenced by technical factors rather than fundamental data. The Federal Open Market Committee's July meeting minutes, set to be released on Wednesday, may provide insight into the timing of a potential interest rate increase, possibly as early as September.

images.alt_text: The dollar was largely steady against most major rivals on Tuesday except for the pound, which firmed after British inflation data supported expectations of a Bank of England interest rate hike.

site_title: US$ up on rate hike hopes, baht slips after blast
summary: The US dollar rose against the yen and other currencies on Tuesday as strong housing data boosted hopes for a US interest rate hike, while the Thai baht plummeted to a six-year low after a deadly Bangkok bombing. The US dollar edged up to 124.47 yen, and the baht fell to 35.648 against the US dollar, its lowest level since 2009. The bombing threatens to damage Thailand's tourism industry, which is crucial to the country's economy.

site_title: Buying stocks? Just follow the leader
summary: Foreign investors in China's stock market are adopting a "follow the leader" approach, mimicking state-backed institutions that intervene to prop up prices. These institutions, known as the "national team," buy shares opportunistically, especially in heavyweights like PetroChina Co Ltd, and foreign investors quickly follow suit. This trend has led to short-term trading patterns and a widening disconnect between stock prices and fundamental drivers, causing concern among investors. The national team's interventions have pumped billions of yuan into stocks, but trading volumes remain low.

site_title: With China funding, messaging app Kik joins unicorns
summary: Canada-based messaging app Kik has raised $50 million from Chinese Internet giant Tencent, valuing the firm at over $1 billion. Kik aims to build a chat-based ecosystem for American youth, with 70% of its 240 million registered users aged 13-24. The funding is seen as a strategic move by Tencent to expand its presence in the US market. Kik's CEO, Ted Livingston, praised Tencent's understanding of chat and its versatility, which sets it apart from rival WhatsApp. The deal marks Kik's entry into the "unicorn" club of startups with valuations over $1 billion.

site_title: Aspial raising up to S$75m in its first retail bond offer
summary: Aspial Corporation, a Singapore-listed group with diverse business interests, has raised up to S$75 million through its first retail bond offering. The 5-year bonds have a fixed interest rate of 5.25% per annum, payable semi-annually. The funds will be used for general corporate funding, working capital, and investments. The group also announced a proposed listing of its real estate businesses in Australia and Malaysia on the Catalist, with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) having no objection to the plan, subject to compliance with SGX listing requirements.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as Walmart earnings disappoint
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday following a disappointing earnings report from Walmart, with the Dow Jones losing 33.84 points (0.19%) and the S&P 500 shedding 5.52 points (0.26%). Walmart's profit forecast was slashed, causing a 3.4% drop in its stock price. The Nasdaq Composite Index also fell 32.35 points (0.64%) to 5,059.35. The decline in Walmart's earnings weighed on the broader market, contributing to the overall decrease in stock prices.

site_title: Uber sparks car sales boom in India
summary: Uber's popularity in India has sparked a vehicle boom, with car sales increasing 7.5% in the four months leading up to July. Maruti Suzuki's DZire Tour and Toyota's Etios sedan saw significant gains in demand, with sales rising 152% and 28% respectively. The surge in demand is attributed to the rise of car booking apps, which are attracting drivers and fleet operators. Carmakers are responding by offering special deals and expanding their fleets, contributing to a recovery in vehicle sales in India.

site_title: Yuan devaluation likely an orchestrated move to join SDR
summary: China's yuan devaluation may be a deliberate move to join the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Rights (SDR) currency unit, rather than a genuine devaluation attempt. The People's Bank of China's recent gold purchases and a survey by the IMF showing 38 central banks holding renminbi assets suggest a coordinated plan. Beijing's goal is to increase the renminbi's reserve currency status, which would require a more flexible exchange rate policy. The yuan's decline against the dollar may be part of this strategy, which aims to bolster China's global financial clout and conform to international statistical norms.

site_title: US firms see shift in traditional staff reviews
summary: General Electric is joining a growing list of major US companies in piloting a shift away from traditional annual performance reviews, a process that workers and managers alike have criticized as outdated. The company is experimenting with more frequent conversations, an app to share feedback, and considering eliminating performance ratings. This move follows several other companies, including Accenture, Adobe, and Gap, which have already abandoned or modified their annual review systems. The trend is driven by technological advancements and changing workforce needs, with younger generations seeking ongoing feedback and more frequent coaching.

site_title: Fancy paying what you want for dinner?
summary: A New Jersey restaurant owner, Zod Arifai, is offering customers a "pay what you want" menu for the month of August, prompting reactions ranging from anxiety to delight. Researchers' predictions have been confirmed, as diners are forced to develop ad hoc criteria to determine the value of their meals. While some pay less than half the old prices, others overpay, rationalizing their decisions. The experiment aims to study consumer behavior and has been deemed a success, with Arifai finding that 80% of customers are not taking advantage of the offer, despite 20% underpaying.

site_title: CEFC: Discussions on JVs still ongoing
summary: CEFC International, a fuel trader, reported ongoing discussions on potential joint ventures without reaching definitive terms or formal agreements. CEO Lu Da Chuan stated no binding agreement has been entered into. The company's share price has surged over ten-fold since mid-July.

site_title: PM Lee unveils commemorative notes to mark Singapore's Jubilee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong unveiled a set of six commemorative polymer currency notes to mark the country's 50 years of independence. The notes, issued by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, feature a S$50 note and five S$10 notes. The set complements three commemorative coins launched in April, marking the SG50 occasion.

site_title: STB launching S$10m fund to boost tourism product offering
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) is launching a S$10 million "Experience Step-Up Fund" to boost tourism in Singapore. The fund aims to encourage businesses to develop new tourism experiences and improve existing amenities and infrastructure. Proposals for tour development and technology initiatives can be submitted until Feb 5, 2016. The STB has also announced a S$35 million investment in a two-year partnership with Changi Airport Group for joint marketing campaigns globally. This move is part of the STB's efforts to enhance the overall visitor experience and satisfaction in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) is launching a S$10 million "Experience Step-Up Fund" under its Tourism Product Development Scheme - another of its several recent efforts to boost languishing arrivals and tourist spend here.

site_title: Noble avoiding real issues: critics
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted to an 11-year low on Tuesday amid renewed selling pressure, closing at 41.5 Singapore cents after a 9% decline. Critics, including independent research firm GMT Research, say the company has yet to address real issues such as mark-to-market contract valuations. Despite Noble's efforts to boost annual operating income to over $2 billion, short-seller levels have more than doubled in the past month, and the company faces allegations of accounting impropriety. Moody's downgraded Noble's credit outlook to "negative" last week, citing its volatile cash flow and weaker liquidity profile.

site_title: Corporate governance index to cast wider net on stakeholder feedback
summary: Singapore's Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) has announced its seventh annual edition, set to replace the current benchmark in 2016. The new index will adopt OECD principles and a more comprehensive view of a company's stakeholders, including employees, customers, and suppliers. Singtel reclaimed the top spot in 2015, while Singapore Exchange jumped to the second spot. The index's mean score of 47.6 out of 143 in 2015 was the best since its inception in 2009, but improvement was noted in areas such as remuneration disclosure and whistleblower policies. The new SGTI aims to address the limitations of the current benchmark and provide a more complete picture of corporate governance effectiveness.

site_title: Norway SWF cuts off 4 palm oil-linked firms
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund has announced it is divesting from four Asian companies due to environmental concerns over their palm oil activities. The fund, managing $1.2 trillion, will exclude Daewoo International and three other groups from its portfolio, citing "severe environmental damage" from the conversion of tropical forests. This decision is based on an assessment of the risk of environmental damage from palm oil cultivation.

site_title: Petrobras may need to pay US$1.6b in penalties
summary: Petrobras, Brazil's state-run oil company, may face record penalties of up to $1.6 billion to settle US criminal and civil probes into a corruption scandal. The company expects to face the largest penalties ever levied by US authorities, with a settlement process potentially taking two to three years. Petrobras has not begun settlement talks with US authorities, but its lawyers maintain the company was a victim of corruption and bid-rigging.

images.alt_text: Brazil's Petrobras may need to pay record penalties of US$1.6 billion or more to settle US criminal and civil probes into its role in a corruption scandal, a person recently briefed by the company's legal advisers told Reuters.

site_title: YuuZoo buys key assets of China mobile game developer
summary: Singapore-listed social e-commerce firm YuuZoo has acquired key assets of Shanghai-based mobile game developer Camigo Media, including 11 mobile games, 26 million users, and the Camigo brand. The acquisition is valued at less than 0.5% of YuuZoo's issued shares, with YuuZoo chairman & CEO Thomas Zilliacus stating that the deal will help the company build its brand in China and provide "major stickiness" to social media.

site_title: Kim Chuan Drive site sold for S$40m
summary: A freehold industrial site at Kim Chuan Drive in Singapore has been sold for S$40 million, or S$460 per square foot per plot ratio. The buyer, Precise Development, plans to redevelop the site for Business 2 use. The sale price does not include a small development charge that the buyer will have to pay to the state before redevelopment.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
On the site is an old three-storey property that used to house shop lots and domitories; all the units have been vacated.

site_title: Cancer survivor marks SG50 with 50-hour hand-cycle charity ride
summary: Singaporean cancer survivor William Tan, 58, will embark on a 50-hour hand-cycle charity ride from Aug 28 to 30 to raise S$50,000 for needy local and Thai children. The event, 50/50@TJC, aims to support The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, Care Corner Orphanage Foundation, and the Rotary Club of Bugis Junction's "Children in Need" Fund. As a Paralympian and resident physician, Tan is determined to "do more for the community" after beating Stage 4 leukaemia with a bone marrow transplant in 2009.

images.alt_text: Paralysed from the waist down since the age of two due to childhood poliomyelitis, Dr Tan has been championing the raising of funds for needy causes around the world since 1987.

site_title: Challenges stand in way of Asia growth story: top execs
summary: Asia's economic growth story is precarious due to challenges such as a fragile middle class, protectionism, and infrastructure shortages. Executives from leading multinational corporations, including Unilever and Birst, warn that consumers are falling out of the middle class, creating economic tension. Protectionism is also a concern, as countries struggle to build global market competitiveness. Experts, including Parag Khanna, urge greater economic integration and investment in infrastructure, particularly for Asia's second-tier cities, to support the region's growth.

site_title: Abe's speech: moving on without a sense of closure
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's speech on the 70th anniversary of Japan's World War II surrender failed to provide a sense of closure, instead reopening old arguments about Japan's role in the conflict. Abe's speech was criticized for downplaying China's suffering and omitting the "comfort women" issue, which has strained relations with South Korea. The speech's vagueness was also criticized by former Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama, who expressed similar sentiments in a 1995 statement. The article concludes that it's time for Japan to move on and confront its history, rather than issuing more apologies, and that former victims, particularly China, must also move forward.

site_title: Stocks continue to slip on China worries
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a 0.6% drop in the Straits Times Index, with the Hang Seng Index and Shanghai Composite Index also declining 1.4% and 6.1%, respectively. Regional sentiment remains weak due to concerns over China's yuan devaluation. Analysts predict further volatility and a cautious stance, with some forecasting a potential 2.9% drop in the STI. The devaluation of the Chinese yuan is expected to negatively impact other Asian currencies, including the Singapore dollar.

site_title: Android update codenamed Marshmallow
summary: Google has officially named its upcoming Android operating system "Marshmallow" (version 6.0), following a tradition of using sweet treats as codenames. The update includes fingerprint sensors, power-saving mode enhancements, and a streamlined "permissions" model for users. The new version is now available for download, with developers able to develop or update applications for Android. With Android used in nearly 80% of smartphones worldwide, the update is expected to bring improvements to the platform.

site_title: Pushing towards a new frontier
summary: Singapore's corporate governance has made significant progress, with the 2015 Governance and Transparency Index (GTI) showing an all-time high of 47.6 points, up 5 points from last year. This is attributed to the efforts of "middle-tier" companies, which have improved their corporate governance practices. Companies have also shown improvements in specific areas, such as disclosures on whistle-blowing, code of conduct, and director training. However, there are still areas that require attention, including sustainability and remuneration practices, and complacency is not an option as the business landscape continues to evolve.

site_title: End of phone subsidies masks sales slowdown
summary: US wireless companies are shifting away from handset subsidies, booking almost full prices on the day of sale, to boost near-term results and mask industry weakness. Analysts warn of a "huge distortion" as carriers like T-Mobile, Sprint, and Verizon book revenue and profit metrics more rosily. The trend is most pronounced in North America, but is more difficult to cut in Europe due to strong competition. The shift is expected to last only a couple of years before consumers sign up for new plans and pay full price for their phones.

site_title: Piracy, robbery and hijacks a persistent problem
summary: A persistent problem in Southeast Asia, piracy, robbery, and hijacks continue to plague the region, driven by demand for illicit oil and a well-established black market. In the second quarter of 2015, five small tankers were hijacked in Southeast Asian waters, with the International Maritime Bureau (IMB) highlighting a "continuing trend" of maritime attacks. However, enhanced cooperation between regional authorities has led to successful tracking and arrest of perpetrators, with IMB praising efforts to deter further incidents.

site_title: Fallout from bomb blast to dent Thailand's tourism and economy
summary: A bomb blast in central Bangkok killed at least 22 people, including a Singaporean, and injured over 120. The attack is expected to impact Thailand's tourism industry and economy, which was rebounding after the 2014 political unrest. Tourist arrivals rebounded 30% in the first half of the year, but the slowdown will likely hinder economic growth. The Thai baht slumped to its weakest against the greenback since 2009, and the stock exchange dropped 2.56%. Analysts warn of a potential backslide into political turmoil and a deeper economic crisis.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Scouring accounting footnotes to prevent tunnelling
summary: A new framework is proposed to prevent corporate wealth theft through accounting footnotes, specifically related-party loans. Researchers found that firms with high related-party loans (ORecta) are more likely to experience poor performance, regulatory investigations, and share suspensions. A system analyzing footnotes for suspicious changes in related-party loans and revenue can detect potential accounting fraud, complementing post-mortem analysis. Companies with high ORecta measures can be flagged on the Singapore Exchange website to inform investors and prompt companies to curb fraudulent transactions.

site_title: From photos to stem cells, Fujifilm finds a second life
summary: Fujifilm Holdings Corp, a Japanese brand, is shifting its focus from photo-film to science and technology markets, including Ebola drugs, anti-aging lotions, and stem cell research. Chairman Shigetaka Komori has been involved in the company's efforts, as seen in a recent photo shoot. This change in direction aims to capitalize on new opportunities in the healthcare and technology sectors.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's residential market saw a significant boost in July 2015, with 1,594 units sold, triple the sales of the previous year. This was largely due to the high take-up rate of High Park Residences, which accounted for 73% of the month's transactions. Despite this, the market is expected to remain lacklustre, with large incoming supply and a lack of policy catalysts. Analysts maintain a neutral stance, preferring diversified companies like Capitaland and City Dev.

site_title: US inventories cast cloud on second-half growth
summary: US businesses have increased inventories by over $100 billion in the last two quarters, a record back-to-back increase, but sales growth has not kept pace. The inventory-to-sales ratio is at a near six-year high of 1.37, potentially weighing on production and economic growth in the second half of the year. Economists expect inventories to be revised up, adding at least half a percentage point to GDP growth, and potentially slicing off 1.4 percentage points from third-quarter GDP growth.

site_title: Singapore notifies Malaysia of its concerns over higher land tax for Johor waterworks
summary: Singapore has notified Malaysia of its concerns over a revised land assessment tax on Johor River Waterworks, owned by national water agency PUB, which is not required to pay under the 1962 Water Agreement. The tax rate was more than double the next highest rate in the district and was applied to a category created solely for PUB. Singapore has registered its concerns with the Malaysian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and requested Malaysia's Federal Government to address the issue, which Malaysia has agreed to work on with the Johor State Government.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Kepland bullish ahead of completion of IFC Jakarta Tower 2
summary: Keppel Land, a property unit of Keppel Corporation, has completed the topping-off of International Financial Centre (IFC) Jakarta Tower Two in Jakarta's Central Business District. The building is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2016 and has secured tenants such as Servcorp and Tokio Marine. Keppel Land plans to redevelop an existing tower into a 55-storey office tower, increasing its net leasable area. The development is seen as an "opportune" move given rising foreign direct investment in Indonesia and the country's commitment to infrastructural improvements.

site_title: Macy's tests chutes, tablets in dressing rooms to repel Amazon
summary: Macy's is testing high-tech dressing rooms with tablets to help customers try on clothing and reduce returns. The company aims to compete with Amazon, which is expected to disrupt the US$300 billion apparel market. Macy's has revamped its fitting rooms in a California store, allowing customers to browse items on tablets and request sizes without leaving the room. The test could be expanded to other locations, with the goal of increasing sales and reducing returns.

images.alt_text: Macy's is using technology to make it easier for customers to try on items without having to leave the dressing room.

site_title: Amazon won't tolerate 'callous' management practices, says Bezos
summary: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos has responded to criticism of the company's "bruising workplace" culture, urging employees to contact him directly if they have experienced "shockingly callous management practices". In a memo, Bezos said Amazon will not tolerate such practices and encouraged employees to speak up about problems. The criticism comes after a New York Times article reported on workers who suffered personal crises and were unfairly evaluated or edged out by the company. Bezos defended the company's culture, saying it is "friendly and intense" but acknowledged that some employees have been "bruised" by the intense demands.

images.alt_text: Mr Bezos said, in response to the article, "Even if it's rare or isolated, our tolerance for any such lack of empathy needs to be zero."

site_title: Hedge funds ripe for the picking
summary: Hedge funds have become increasingly bearish on US stocks, with a record 22 percentage point disparity between short and bullish positions. This surge in bearishness could signal a buying opportunity, as the market has gone almost four years without a decline of 10% or more. However, past instances of bearishness have preceded rallies, and traders are cautious about timing the market. Despite this, experts believe a short-term contrarian signal may be present, with the S&P 500 poised to break out and potentially move meaningfully.

site_title: Top currency trade stuck in a Fed-induced rut
summary: The US dollar has been stuck near its short- and medium-term averages against the euro since late June, hovering around $1.10 per euro. Despite economic slowdowns in China and a commodity rout, the dollar has risen 0.3% to $1.1078 per euro. The euro's trade balance has improved, and growth is seen as better, but hedge funds' bets on a stronger dollar have almost halved, and the Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates slowly. This has led to a stalemate in the currency trade, with buy and sell orders at $1.10 being nearly equal.

site_title: Indonesia aviation hurt by staff shortage
summary: Indonesia's aviation safety record worsened after a passenger plane crash in eastern Papua province, killing 54 people. The country scored poorly in a 2014 safety audit by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) due to a staff shortage, with only 20% of its "organisation" score meeting the average. Indonesia has developed a plan to address issues, but ICAO auditors won't return until the majority of problems are fixed. The country's aviation market is expected to triple by 2034, but its struggles to hire and train staff are hindering its ability to meet safety standards.

site_title: Housing starts rise in July to highest level in nearly eight years
summary: US housing starts rose 0.2% in July to a 1.21 million annualized rate, the highest level in nearly eight years. Single-family house construction increased 12.8% to a 782,000 rate, while multi-family home construction fell 17% to a 424,000 rate. The median forecast was 1.18 million, and a drop in permits signals additional gains will take time to develop. Low mortgage rates and increasing prices are driving demand, with builder sentiment at a decade high.

images.alt_text: Data showing builder sentiment at a decade high in August underscores the view that the housing rebound will stay on track even as the Federal Reserve is poised to boost borrowing costs.

site_title: GOP candidates favour sanctions in foreign policy
summary: US Republican presidential candidates are likely to adopt a more aggressive foreign policy based on economic sanctions to isolate and weaken US enemies. This strategy, known as containment, can weaken target states but imposes greater costs on American firms, potentially limiting its effectiveness. The use of sanctions has been a classic US diplomatic option, with varying degrees of success, and may become a key component of a Republican president's foreign policy playbook.

site_title: Mormon founder's 34 wives move artist
summary: Artist Leslie O. Peterson created a series of watercolour portraits titled "The Forgotten Wives" to raise awareness about the 34 wives of Mormon founder Joseph Smith, revealed in a church essay. The portraits, created over three months, depict the women, including some who were as young as 14, in their own vibrant personalities and stories. Peterson hopes to change the way Mormon history is taught by bringing these women out of the shadows and celebrating their lives. The series has created buzz in Mormon circles, with many praising Peterson's bold and moving artwork.

images.alt_text: Hairdresser and watercolourist Leslie Peterson holding one of the portraits of Joseph Smith's 34 wives, at the Writ & Vision gallery in Provo, Utah.

site_title: M&A activity in Asia-Pacific at 10-year high
summary: M&A activity in the Asia-Pacific region reached a 10-year high in the first half of 2015, with a total deal value of US$561.8 billion. This represents a 55% increase from the same period last year, driven by a surge in deals involving companies from mainland China. The technology sector was the most active, with 1,562 deals worth US$89.6 billion, while Japan, Australia, and South Korea also saw significant deal activity. Experts expect the momentum to continue into 2016, driven by corporates seeking to streamline capital allocation and build scale across their core businesses.

site_title: China's richest investors cash out of stock market as masses pile in
summary: China's wealthiest investors are cashing out of the stock market, with the number of traders holding over 10 million yuan in shares decreasing by 28% in July. This decline is attributed to weak corporate earnings and high valuations, with the Shanghai Composite Index plummeting 6% in June. State buying efforts have failed to prop up prices, and investors are seeking alternative assets, including Chinese real estate and overseas markets, amid the yuan's devaluation.

site_title: Bullish investors buying Japan and selling US shares
summary: Bullish investors, including BlackRock and Baring Asset Management, are buying Japanese equities and selling US shares due to Japan's stronger earnings growth, low valuations, and loose monetary policy. Japan's Topix index has risen 19% this year, outpacing the S&P 500's 1.6% gain. The Bank of Japan's monetary base expansion is expected to spur higher prices and wage growth, while the Fed's potential interest rate hike is seen as a headwind for US stocks. Japanese companies are forecast to see profit growth of 8.6% in 2015 and 12.2% in the following fiscal year, surpassing US earnings forecasts.

site_title: Emerging markets to stay sluggish for some time: Moody's
summary: Moody's analyst Marie Diron predicts a medium-term trend of sluggish growth in emerging markets, citing factors such as local political concerns, high dollar-denominated debt, and business confidence plummeting in countries like Brazil, Turkey, and South Africa. Diron forecasts a marked recession in Brazil this year, followed by zero growth, and slower Chinese growth for the rest of the decade.

site_title: Asia countries move to claw back undeclared wealth parked in S'pore
summary: Asian countries, including Indonesia and India, are targeting Singapore's low-tax environment to recover undeclared wealth. This move comes as a global crackdown on tax evasion continues, with European offshore hubs already forced to surrender bank secrecy. Singapore-based wealth managers face pressure from this trend, adding to existing pressure from tax information sharing. The push for undeclared funds is part of a broader effort to combat tax evasion and increase revenue for these countries.

site_title: Parliament: Singaporean killed, 7 Singapore citizens injured in Bangkok blast
summary: A Singaporean woman, Melisa Liu Rui Chun, 34, was killed and seven Singaporeans injured in a bomb blast near the Erawan Shrine in central Bangkok on Monday night. The victims were in Thailand for a wedding, with the deceased and her husband among those attending. The incident is under investigation, but no group has claimed responsibility.

site_title: Teachers, allied educators to get pay increase from October
summary: The Ministry of Education announced a pay rise for teachers in Singapore, effective October 1, 2015. Teachers in grades 4-9 will receive a 4-9% increase, while allied educators will receive a 5% increase. The pay increase aims to keep pace with market salaries and signal the importance of teaching as a profession. A single salary structure for graduate and non-graduate teachers will also be introduced, replacing separate structures. The move is part of the government's SkillsFuture initiative to recognize employees' skills beyond academic qualifications.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Singapore has stepped up security, says DPM Teo Chee Hean
summary: Singapore has increased security measures following the Bangkok bomb blast on Monday night, according to Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean. Teo stated that security agencies are closely monitoring the situation and have heightened vigilance. The move comes in response to the incident, but no further details have been provided.

site_title: India's IndiGo confirms order for 250 Airbus planes
summary: India's IndiGo airline has ordered 250 Airbus A320neo jets, its largest ever order, valued at up to $26.6 billion. The contract follows an initial commitment last year and increases Airbus' backlog to over 4,100 A320neo planes.

site_title: Taiwan's Foxconn to invest US$200m in India's Snapdeal
summary: Taiwan's electronics giant Foxconn is investing US$200 million in Indian online marketplace Snapdeal, acquiring a 4.27% stake. This move aims to tap into India's huge potential market, potentially cutting labour costs and boosting iPhone sales. The investment is part of Foxconn's US$5 billion plan to set up a facility in India, sparking concerns in China, where the economy is slowing.

site_title: Big Oil funds campaign against billionaire climate-change activist
summary: Big Oil companies that previously funded a $9.7 million campaign against California fracking laws are now targeting billionaire climate activist Tom Steyer. Steyer has invested millions into the cause, hiring Governor Jerry Brown's former spokesman and challenging Chevron CEO John Watson to a public debate on petrol prices. Steyer's efforts have made him the top individual political donor in the US last year.

site_title: Activist labour unions may check deflationary tendencies
summary: A Labour Party leader's advocacy for restoring power to labour unions in Britain may be linked to addressing global deflationary tendencies. Despite unprecedented central bank liquidity, deflation persists, and some argue it's caused by the emergence of new economic powers and cheap global production. The link to wages is that they have long been in decline relative to national income and corporate profits, failing to drive up inflation. Labour unions may play a key role in compensating for low wage growth and promoting consumer spending, which is a vital missing link in economic recovery.

site_title: Currency squeeze seen punishing buyers of luxury homes in London
summary: International investors who bought luxury homes in London's Battersea Power Station site have seen costs surge 35% due to the stronger pound and slumping real estate values. Malaysian developer Sime Darby Bhd reported that its management and families spent $12.8 million on units costing from $338,000 to $6 million. The first phase is set for completion next year, leaving investors with significant financial losses.

site_title: CEFC says joint venture discussions still ongoing
summary: CEFC International, a fuel trader, reported ongoing discussions on potential joint ventures with no definitive terms or formal agreements. CEO Lu Da Chuan advised shareholders to exercise caution due to the uncertainty of the transactions. The company's stock price closed at 34 Singapore cents, down 2.5 cents or 6.8%, valuing the company at S$1.1 billion.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Airlines offer to waive fees for travellers changing flights to city
summary: Airlines have offered to waive change fees for travelers booked to fly to Bangkok after Monday's deadly bomb blast. Singapore Airlines has received a few requests to cancel flights to Bangkok, following the explosion that killed at least 20 people, including one Singaporean. The move is seen as a gesture of goodwill and support for those affected by the tragedy.

site_title: Melbourne keeps crown as world's most liveable city
summary: Melbourne has been ranked as the world's most liveable city for the fifth year in a row, according to a study by the Economist Intelligence Unit. The Australian city topped the ranking of 140 cities, ahead of Vienna and Vancouver. However, the study found that global urban living conditions have deteriorated due to conflicts and terrorism, with cities like Tripoli, Kiev, and Damascus experiencing significant declines. Mid-sized cities in wealthier countries scored highly, while cities like London and New York suffered from overstretched infrastructure and higher crime rates.

images.alt_text: Melbourne is the world's most liveable city but conflict and terrorism have led to a fall in global urban living conditions more generally, according to a respected British study published Tuesday.

site_title: US housing starts edge higher in July
summary: US housing starts rose 0.2% to a 1.206 million annual rate in July, the highest pace since October 2007. The increase was largely due to single-family home starts, which jumped 12.8%. Multi-family units, however, dropped 17%. Building permits, an indicator of future activity, tumbled 16.3% to 1.119 million. This slowdown follows a strong surge in June, which was revised upward to a 12.3% month-over-month increase.

site_title: Park Hotel Group expands portfolio outside Asia
summary: Park Hotel Group has expanded its portfolio outside Asia, signing a management contract for its first hotel outside the region. The 250-room Park Hotel Adelaide in Australia is set to open in 2018. This marks the group's 12th property across five countries, demonstrating its growing global presence. The contract with Pirie Investments (AUS) highlights the group's expansion plans in the Australian market.

images.alt_text: At the signing ceremony were (from left) Mohd Rafin, Park Hotel Group's chief corporate officer; Allen Law, Park Hotel Group's CEO; Mr Hamilton-Smith; Raymond Chia, CEO and chairman of LGB Corporation; Jonathan Lee, director of LGB Australia; and Jim Williams, architect at GHD Woodhead Adelaide

site_title: OCBC to issue S$500m capital securities as additional Tier 1 capital
summary: OCBC Bank priced a S$500 million non-cumulative non-convertible perpetual capital securities issue at 100% with a 3.80% fixed annual distribution rate. The instrument aims to qualify as additional Tier 1 capital under the Monetary Authority of Singapore's Basel III framework. The issue is expected to be rated A3 by Moody's, BBB- by Standard & Poor's, and BBB by Fitch.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Takata air-bag users VW, Tesla may join US recalls
summary: Volkswagen and Tesla may face US recalls for using Takata air-bag inflators containing ammonium nitrate propellant, despite being the only carmakers to continue using them. Takata has supplied 887,055 inflators to Volkswagen and 184,926 to Tesla since 2011 and 2012, respectively. The NHTSA has asked Takata to list these companies, and investigations may determine the chemical's safety risks, linked to 8 deaths and 130 injuries in 32 million recalled vehicles.

images.alt_text: Mr Kennedy has emphasised the growing role of competitors in making replacement inflators that don't use ammonium nitrate

site_title: Wal-Mart earnings miss estimates; company cuts outlook
summary: Wal-Mart reported weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings, with net profit falling to $3.48 billion, or $1.08 per share, down from $4.1 billion, or $1.21 per share, a year earlier. Analysts had expected $1.12 per share. The company also lowered its full-year forecast, citing weaker-than-expected sales and increased competition. Its shares fell 2.6% in premarket trading.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.06 points to close at 1,579.60 on Tuesday, with 2.25 billion lots valued at RM2.11 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 409-407.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close lower
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed lower on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.37% to 6,526.29 points, and the CAC 40 in Paris down 0.27% to 4,971.25 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropped 0.22% to 10,915.92 points. The decline was attributed to uncertainty over US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Thakral Corp in joint venture for retirement housing in Australia
summary: Mainboard-listed Thakral Corp has entered a joint venture with the Puljich family to develop resort-style retirement villages in Australia. The joint venture company, GTH Resorts, will develop over 1,000 retirement homes in south Queensland and northern New South Wales. The first project, in the Toowoomba region, will cost A$35.7 million and is expected to be funded through internal sources, sales proceeds, and bank loans. The partnership aims to tap into the rising demand for retirement housing in Australia, with a focus on creating "vertically integrated family-owned business" communities.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Bangkok blast: CCTV footage retraces footage of suspect
summary: A bomb blast in Bangkok killed 22 people on Monday during rush hour. CCTV footage shows a suspect entering a Hindu temple, leaving a backpack, and walking towards the Grand Hyatt Erawan hotel. The suspect, identified as a young man with shaggy, black hair, was seen leaving the scene around 6:40 pm. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack, and the military government has not ruled out any group. The blast unleashed chaos, with scenes of blood-smeared pavements and shattered glass at the scene.

site_title: Aussie leads commodity peers lower as oil, Chinese stocks slide
summary: The Australian dollar weakened 0.4% to 73.44 US cents against major peers as metal and oil prices fell, amid concerns the commodities slump will hurt the economy. Goldman Sachs predicts a 30% drop in iron ore over 18 months. The Reserve Bank of Australia maintains accommodative monetary policy, while strategists expect the Aussie to slide to 70 cents by year-end and 68 in Q1 2016. Other commodity currencies, including Canada's and Malaysia's, also fell amid speculation of a global supply glut.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore's most well-governed and transparent company, Singtel, topped the Governance and Transparency Index 2015. Teachers will receive a 4-9% pay raise starting October 1. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong unveiled commemorative currency notes to celebrate Singapore's 50th anniversary. A bomb blast in Bangkok killed a Singaporean woman and injured seven others. The local stock market closed 0.6% lower due to China worries.

site_title: 'Impossible trinity' ends in China as PBOC allows freer yuan
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has allowed the yuan to float more freely, ending the "impossible trinity" of maintaining an independent monetary policy, a fixed exchange rate, and free capital borders. The move aims to boost exports, improve chances of winning reserve currency status from the IMF, and increase monetary policy flexibility. The PBOC has shifted priorities, focusing on domestic monetary policy independence and paving the way for freer capital flows. This change allows the central bank to conduct an independent monetary policy and potentially inject more liquidity into the economy.

site_title: Tianjin blast to strain Chinese insurers: Fitch
summary: Fitch warns that insurance claims from the Tianjin explosions could exceed initial estimates, potentially straining the finances of regional Chinese insurers. Total losses could reach $1-1.5 billion, with local insurers bearing the brunt of the costs. This could undermine the financial performance of some regional players and those with high risk accumulation in the affected areas, according to Fitch.

site_title: US: Equities decline on Walmart, China stock plunge
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday following disappointing Walmart earnings and a drop in the Chinese equity market. The Dow Jones fell 38.81 points (0.22%) to 17,506.37, while the S&P 500 lost 4.45 points (0.21%) to 2,097.99. The Shanghai index tumbled 6.15% amid worries about the Chinese economy. Walmart's earnings forecast was dented by a strong dollar, higher operating costs, and other issues. The decline in US and Asian markets was attributed to regional jitters about China's economic woes.

site_title: Midas secures three contracts worth S$21m
summary: Midas Holdings' subsidiary Jilin Midas Aluminium Industries secured three contracts worth 94.6 million yuan (S$21 million) to supply aluminium alloy extrusion profiles for metro trains in China. The contracts are valued at 38.2 million yuan, 32.7 million yuan, and 23.7 million yuan for Shenzhen Rail Transit Line 9, Hefei Rail Transit Line 1, and Suzhou Rail Transit Line 4, respectively. The contracts are expected to contribute positively to Midas' financial performance in 2015 and 2016.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: European banks to sell a record US$154 billion of loans, PwC says
summary: European banks plan to sell a record 139 billion euros (US$154 billion) of loans this year, led by the UK and Ireland, to meet new regulations and reduce balance sheets. Hedge funds and private-equity firms are buying the loans, seeking exposure to recovering economies. Commercial real estate debt and secured mortgages account for 83% of loans sold so far, with UK banks expected to sell another 42.5 billion euros. The sales are driven by regulations requiring banks to maintain capital buffers and absorb losses.

site_title: Citi lowers gold price forecasts for 2015, 2016
summary: Citi has lowered its gold price forecasts for 2015 and 2016 due to weak economic conditions and fundamentals. The bank now predicts an average gold price of US$1,140 for 2015 and US$1,050 for 2016, down from previous forecasts of US$1,180 and US$1,195 respectively. This decision is attributed to expected dollar strength as the US Federal Reserve tightens financial stimulus measures over the next several quarters.

site_title: Small explosive thrown from bridge over river in Bangkok
summary: A man in Bangkok threw a small explosive from a bridge over the Chao Phraya river, but it landed in a canal, causing no injuries. The incident occurred a day after a bomb at a city shrine killed 22 people, including nine foreigners. The unidentified man claimed the explosive would not have caused harm if it had landed on land.

site_title: Twitter says to accelerate push for content partnerships in Asia
summary: Twitter plans to accelerate its content partnerships in Asia Pacific and the Middle East, appointing Rishi Jaitly, a Singapore-based executive, to boost teams in major markets such as Australia, India, and Japan. Twitter aims to expand into Greater China and Southeast Asia, building on its efforts to carry pictures, video, and interactive content. This move follows the company's aggressive expansion of its capabilities.

site_title: Ley Choon Group bags S$6m contracts from PUB
summary: Ley Choon Group Holdings has secured S$6 million contracts from the Public Utilities Board (PUB) for watermain repairs and supply and laying services. The contracts, worth S$3.5 million and S$2.5 million, are awarded to subsidiaries Pan Alliance Technology International and Chin Kuan Engineering and Contractors respectively, and are not expected to impact the firm's earnings or net tangible assets for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China investigates top work safety regulator after warehouse blast
summary: China's work safety regulator, Yang Dongliang, is under investigation for suspected party discipline and law violations after a Tianjin warehouse explosion killed over 100 people. The State Administration of Work Safety, led by Yang, regulates companies handling hazardous materials. The investigation's details are not provided, and Yang has not commented. This move comes amid pressure on policymakers due to slowing China's GDP growth.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Hong Kong says avoid city, others urge caution after bombing
summary: A bomb attack in Bangkok, Thailand, killed at least 20 people, including Chinese, Hong Kong, and Singaporean citizens. Hong Kong issued a red alert, advising residents to avoid travel to Bangkok, while other governments in Asia urged caution. The Thai government attributed the attack to targeting the country's tourist industry and tarnishing its reputation. Authorities have increased security measures, and officials are investigating the incident without a claimed responsibility.

site_title: PM Lee unveils commemorative S$50 and S$10 notes to celebrate SG50
summary: PM Lee Hsien Loong unveiled six commemorative polymer currency notes to celebrate Singapore's 50 years of independence. The notes, issued by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, include a S$50 note and five S$10 notes featuring designs inspired by significant milestones in Singapore's history. The notes have unique security features, including image movement effects and colour-switching effects, and are available for exchange at major retail banks from August 20 to September 30, 2015, with priority given to Singaporeans.

site_title: China calls on Thailand to fully investigate blast, punish perpetrators
summary: China has called on Thailand to thoroughly investigate the Bangkok bomb blast that killed 22 people, including 4 Chinese tourists, and to punish those responsible. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying expressed strong condemnation of the bombing, stating that 4 Chinese tourists were killed and over 20 wounded. China urges Thailand to take severe measures against the perpetrators.

images.alt_text: China on Tuesday urged Thai authorities to fully investigate a bomb blast in Bangkok that killed 22 people, including four Chinese tourists, and to severely punish the perpetrators.

site_title: China's yuan ends flat as market awaits trading clues
summary: China's yuan ended flat against the dollar on Tuesday, closing at 6.3966 per dollar, after the central bank set a slightly stronger midpoint. The spot market closed 0.04% away from the midpoint, and the offshore yuan was trading 0.82% weaker. The yuan posted its biggest weekly loss on record, touching four-year lows after a surprise devaluation last week. Traders expect further falls amid a sluggish economy, with Morgan Stanley revising its USD/CNY forecast to 6.60 at end-2015 and 6.91 at end-2016.

site_title: China: Stocks slump 6 per cent on fears of further yuan depreciation
summary: Chinese stocks plummeted 6.1% on Tuesday, marking the largest daily decline since July 27, amid fears of further yuan depreciation. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 6.2% as investors took profits after a run-up in prices over the last few weeks. The yuan weakened against the dollar, sparking concerns that Beijing may be intent on a deeper devaluation. The People's Bank of China injected funds into money markets, but investors remain wary of liquidity tightening and potential withdrawal of state support for share prices.

site_title: UK inflation ticks up in July, core inflation hits five-month high
summary: UK inflation rose 0.1% in July, exceeding expectations, driven by higher clothing prices. Core inflation, excluding food and energy, hit a five-month high of 1.2%. The Bank of England warns that low inflation may persist until mid-2016, complicating plans to exit its ultra-easy monetary policy. Despite low inflation boosting purchasing power, it also makes it difficult for the Bank to raise interest rates, which could undermine Britain's economic recovery.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble Group shares erase early gains, hit 6-1/2 year low
summary: Noble Group shares plummeted 6.6% to an intra-day low of S$0.425, erasing early gains, as investors reacted to the company's openness to selling core businesses. The shares had rallied 5% earlier after the CEO's comments. Noble is under pressure due to a weak commodities market and allegations of asset inflation, which the company has denied. This marks the lowest share price since November 2008.

site_title: Outgoing Chief of Defence Force Ng Chee Meng to enter politics
summary: Outgoing Chief of Defence Force Ng Chee Meng has confirmed he will enter politics, promising to consult widely and listen actively. He will seek the best ideas from people and show humility. This announcement comes ahead of a full-regalia parade where he handed over command to Major-General Perry Lim. Ng did not specify which party he would join or when the Singapore General Election would take place.

site_title: Indonesia search team finds black box for Trigana aircraft in Papua: official
summary: Indonesian search teams have found the black box of a Trigana Air passenger aircraft that crashed in Papua's Bintang Mountains district on Sunday. The twin turboprop ATR-42-300 is believed to have hit a peak before crashing into a ravine. The discovery was made at 1.40 local time on Tuesday, according to Transportation Ministry official Julius Arivada Barata. The National Search and Rescue Agency had previously stated the plane likely crashed 7 nautical miles from Oksibil. The cause of the crash remains unknown.

site_title: Toshiba proposes outsider-heavy board, interim CEO to stay
summary: Toshiba proposes a new board of directors consisting of a majority of outsiders to address governance issues following a $1.2 billion accounting scandal. Interim CEO Masashi Muromachi will remain in his role, maintaining stability but potentially disappointing investors seeking a new leader.
