The company will seek shareholder approval at an extraordinary meeting in late September and is expected to report a net loss for the latest financial year. Toshiba also estimates an operating profit of $2 billion for the year.

images.alt_text: Toshiba Corp proposed adding a new slate of outsiders to take a majority of seats on its board of directors, aiming to bolster governance of the laptops-to-nuclear conglomerate following a US$1.2 billion accounting scandal.

site_title: Indonesia central bank holds key rate at 7.50%, as expected
summary: Indonesia's central bank held its benchmark interest rate at 7.50% on Tuesday, maintaining stability in the rupiah. The decision was in line with expectations and follows the last rate cut in February. Annual inflation in July reached 7.26%, the highest this year. The rupiah is the second-worst performing currency in emerging Asia, trading at a level not seen since mid-1998.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end 0.32 per cent lower on China concern
summary: Tokyo stocks ended down 0.32% on Tuesday, with few trading cues and concerns over China's economy. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 20,554.47, while the Topix index remained flat. The market awaited minutes from the US Federal Reserve's last meeting, which may impact global economic sentiment.

site_title: Indonesia revises June trade surplus to US$528m
summary: Indonesia revised its June trade surplus to US$528 million, up from the previously reported US$477 million. The revision was due to increased exports to US$13.51 billion and imports to US$12.98 billion.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge lower after weak Asia trading
summary: European shares opened slightly lower on Tuesday, down 0.3% due to weak Asian trading and thin mid-August volumes. A dip in oil and metals prices affected mining stocks, while a strong performance from Lindt & Spruengli, which reported forecast-beating profits, was the only positive note. Analysts attributed the market's sluggishness to "basic inertia and low volumes."

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end at six-week low on yuan devaluation fears
summary: Hong Kong's key share index fell 1.4% to 23,474.97 points, its lowest close in six weeks, due to fears of a deeper yuan devaluation by China. The Hang Seng index has now experienced its third consecutive losing session. Chinese stocks plummeted as the yuan weakened against the dollar, prompting investors to book profits and concerns of capital outflow. The central bank injected funds into money markets, but short-term interest rates rose, adding to liquidity concerns.

site_title: Australia: Shares end down on renewed China anxiety
summary: Australian shares fell 1.2% on Tuesday, marking their worst monthly performance since May 2012, due to renewed concerns about China's yuan devaluation. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,303.1, following a decline in banks and resources stocks. The yuan's decline against the US dollar reignited fears of a deeper devaluation, hurting the resource-driven economy.

site_title: Flexible working key to keeping older workers and carers in jobs: Regus
summary: In Singapore, 92% of surveyed senior business people believe flexible working is crucial for retaining older workers, while 96% agree it's essential for keeping caregivers in employment. As Singapore's population ages, flexible working offers professionals more control over their schedule, reducing lengthy commutes and allowing them to balance work and family life. It also provides a "bridge" into retirement, helping older workers delay retirement without sacrificing their freedom. This trend is expected to increase as Singapore's retirement age rises and the proportion of caregivers in the workforce grows.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Thai authorities say looking for suspect seen in CCTV footage at blast site
summary: A bomb blast at the Erawan shrine in Bangkok killed 22 people, including 9 foreigners, and injured 123 others. Authorities are searching for a suspect seen in CCTV footage wearing a yellow shirt. The attack, which occurred during rush hour, is believed to have been aimed at destroying the economy, with no one claiming responsibility. Police have not ruled out any group, including anti-government elements or Muslim insurgents, but say the attack does not match the tactics of those in the south.

site_title: PUB not obliged to pay land assessment tax on Johor Water Works: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's PUB is not obligated to pay land assessment tax on Johor Water Works, according to Foreign Minister K Shanmugam. The Kota Tinggi District Council had sought to double the tax rate imposed on the water works, but Shanmugam revealed that the PUB is exempt under the 1962 Water Agreement.

site_title: Noble Group says challenges this year make it a better company
summary: Noble Group, Asia's largest commodities trader, faces significant challenges, including a 60% decline in stock value and a negative credit outlook. Despite these challenges, CEO Yusuf Alireza believes the company will emerge stronger, citing the scrutiny of public scrutiny as a benefit. Noble has rejected criticism, pursued stock buybacks, and vowed to boost annual operating income to over $2 billion. The company is also exploring financing and investment options, including the sale of assets, to cut debt and restore confidence in its credit.

site_title: Moody's cuts India's 2015 growth forecast to around 7%
summary: Moody's lowered India's 2015 growth forecast to around 7% due to lower-than-expected monsoon rainfalls. The ratings agency maintained its 7.5% forecast for 2016, citing risks from delayed government reform plans. Moody's rates India at its lowest investment grade rating of "Baa3" with a positive outlook, citing the country's growth potential despite challenges.

site_title: Rupiah at 17-year low as trade data suggest slowdown worsening
summary: The Indonesian rupiah reached a 17-year low as trade data showed a 19.2% decline in exports and a 28.4% plunge in imports in July, resulting in a $1.3 billion trade surplus. The decline exceeded forecasts and suggests Indonesia's economic slowdown is worsening. The rupiah fell 0.4% to 13,846 a dollar, taking its drop this year to 10.5%. Analysts expect Bank Indonesia to hold its benchmark interest rate at 7.5% amid the economic concerns.

site_title: US oil prices fall to over 6-yr lows as demand outlook weakens
summary: US oil prices plummeted to their lowest in over six years, falling to $41.51 per barrel, due to weak demand and oversupply concerns. Speculators are betting on further price drops, with traders taking huge bets on lower refinery consumption after the US summer. Analysts at BMI Research expect a modest recovery in prices by the fourth quarter, but long-term outlook remains bearish, with oil prices forecast to average $56 and $55 per barrel in 2016 and 2017, respectively.

site_title: 54 bodies found at Indonesian plane crash site, 'no survivors': official
summary: Indonesian authorities have confirmed that all 54 people on board a plane that crashed in remote eastern Indonesia on Saturday have been found dead at the crash site, with no survivors. The Trigana Air plane, carrying 49 passengers and 5 crew, crashed on Saturday. The transport ministry reported that the bodies of the victims have been recovered, but no further details on the cause of the crash have been released.

site_title: Singapore: Shares close weaker on China worries
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 17.7 points or 0.6% to 3,049.65 on Tuesday, amid worries over China's yuan devaluation. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong also fell 1.4%, with the Shanghai Composite Index plummeting 6.1%. The Singapore Exchange warned traders to exercise caution with CEFC International, which dropped 0.025 cents on Tuesday, amidst concerns over a recent surge in its stock price. The market's sentiment remained weak, following a soft session for several weeks.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Thai junta chief says bomb 'suspect' identified
summary: Thai junta chief Prayut Chan-O-Cha said authorities have identified a male suspect seen on CCTV footage near the Bangkok bombing scene, which killed at least 21 people and injured scores more. The suspect is believed to be from an "anti-government group based in Thailand's northeast," potentially linked to the ousted Shinawatra family. This marks a shift in the investigation from southern Muslim militants, who have been fighting a decade-long insurgency in the country's south.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Singaporean woman among those killed
summary: A bomb blast in Bangkok killed a 34-year-old Singaporean woman, Madam Melisa Liu Rui Chun, and injured her husband. Thai Police Major-General Dr Pornchai Suteerakune confirmed the death, stating she died on the spot. The incident occurred in the heart of the Thai capital on Monday night.

site_title: STB launches S$10m fund to boost visitor experience
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has launched a S$10 million "Experience Step-Up Fund" to boost visitor experience and satisfaction in Singapore. The fund will encourage businesses to develop new tourism experiences and improve amenities and infrastructure. STB is inviting proposals for tour development and technology initiatives until February 5, 2016. This is part of STB's efforts to market Singapore as a tourist destination, including a S$35 million partnership with Changi Airport Group and a global marketing campaign.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall, foreigners sell for 9th day; won edges down
summary: Seoul shares fell on Tuesday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closing 0.6% lower at 1,956.26 points. Foreigners sold shares for the ninth consecutive day, netting 1.17 trillion won (S$1.39 billion). The South Korean won also edged down 0.2% to 1,185.0 per dollar. The losses came despite gains in some large-cap firms, and the KOSPI is hovering around a six-month low.

site_title: Gold struggles as US rate hike looms
summary: Gold prices remain stable, trading flat at $1,117.80 an ounce, as investors await a potential US interest rate hike. Despite solid economic signals, including a rise in US homebuilder sentiment and solid jobs growth, investors may have already discounted a rate increase this year. The Fed's decision on interest rates is expected to be released on Wednesday, providing further insight into the central bank's thinking.

site_title: China: Shanghai stocks slump over 5.0% in afternoon trade
summary: China's Shanghai stock index plummeted 5.09% to 3,790.26, its lowest level since July 2015, amid lingering economic concerns and a surprise currency devaluation. Analysts attribute the decline to a lack of momentum and concerns over a potential economic stimulus. The Shenzhen Composite Index also dropped 5.64%, with some investors betting that an improving property market could reduce the need for further economic stimulus.

images.alt_text: China's benchmark Shanghai stock index slumped more than five percent on Tuesday afternoon after failing to hold above the key 4,000 point level amid lingering worries over the economy, dealers said.

site_title: Aspial issuing retail bonds to raise up to S$75m
summary: Singapore-listed Aspial Corporation is issuing retail bonds for the first time to raise up to S$75 million. The five-year bonds have a fixed interest rate of 5.25% per annum, payable semi-annually. The offering includes a public tranche of up to S$50 million and a placement tranche of up to S$25 million. The bonds are due in 2020 and may be expanded to up to S$150 million in the event of over-subscription.

site_title: Teachers, allied educators to get pay raise from October
summary: The Ministry of Education announced a pay raise for teachers and allied educators, effective October 1, 2015. Teachers in various grades will receive a 4-9% increase in monthly salaries, while allied educators will get a 5% increase. Up to 30,000 teachers and 800 allied educators will be eligible. The pay raise aims to keep pace with the market and signal the importance of teaching as a profession. Additionally, a single salary structure for graduate and non-graduate teachers will be introduced, replacing separate structures.

site_title: China's yuan slips even as central bank sets firmer midpoint
summary: China's yuan fell against the dollar on Tuesday, despite the central bank setting a firmer midpoint rate, as traders expect further downward pressure due to the struggling economy. The yuan posted its biggest weekly loss on record and touched four-year lows after a surprise devaluation last week. Chinese home prices rose, suggesting the property market is recovering, but offshore yuan trading was weak, and one-year non-deliverable forwards contracts indicated the yuan's value is expected to decline.

site_title: China: Shanghai stocks up 0.14% in opening trade
summary: Shanghai stocks rose 0.14% in early trade on Tuesday, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 5.46 points to 3,999.13. This follows a securities regulator's promise to support the market for years. The Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.16% to 2,331.14. The improvement in investor sentiment comes after a period of uncertainty due to tariffs.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble opens up 4% before easing after meeting with investors in Singapore
summary: Noble Group's shares opened 4% higher before easing to 2.2% after meeting investors in Singapore. The commodities trader hosted an investor information day and a meeting with sell-side analysts to discuss its business units and recent findings. Phillip Securities has imposed trading restrictions on Noble shares to control credit exposure, limiting online buying. Despite the easing, Noble's shares remain higher than their previous closing price.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Korea's bet to lure tourists: tax breaks on breast augmentation
summary: South Korea is offering a 10% refund on cosmetic surgery for tourists, including breast augmentation, to boost tourism after a 40% drop in visitors due to the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome. The tax break, starting in April 2026, aims to attract more tourists and increase the country's medical tourism revenue, which is expected to reach $4.2 billion by 2020. The move follows a significant increase in cosmetic surgery procedures in South Korea, which accounts for 2% of the population.

site_title: Asia: Shares mostly higher on Wall Street gains
summary: Asian shares mostly rose on Tuesday, lifted by US Wall Street gains and strong housing data. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai rose, while Seoul dipped. The Thai baht slid to its lowest level since 2009 after a bomb attack in Bangkok. Investors await the release of Federal Reserve minutes on Wednesday, which could impact interest rate decisions. Oil prices fell for the seventh week in a row due to global oversupply fears.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.55% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.55% in opening trade on Tuesday, following gains on Wall Street after strong US housing data, indicating a strengthening US economy. The benchmark Hang Seng Index increased 130.91 points to 23,945.56. This rise comes amid a global stock rally, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Bangkok blast toll rises to 21, Hong Kong tourists among dead
summary: A bomb blast at the Erawan shrine in downtown Bangkok killed 21 people, including two Hong Kong tourists, and wounded 123 others. The attack targeted a crowded shrine, with 10 Thais, one Chinese national, and a Filipino citizen among the initial reported dead. The death toll has since risen, with two Hong Kong residents confirmed dead and six injured. The attack drew international grief and condemnation, with the UN Secretary-General expressing shock. Authorities are investigating the cause of the blast.

site_title: More earnings misses than hits in Q2: UOB Kay Hian
summary: Singapore's Q2 earnings season was marked by lacklustre results, with 39% of companies missing forecasts, according to UOB Kay Hian. The report card described the period as "another reporting season to forget." Most sectors suffered earnings contractions, with aviation, oil services, and shipyards leading the decline. The bank sector, however, saw a slight improvement, with DBS and OCBC exceeding market forecasts. The Straits Times Index's 2016 price-to-earnings ratio is deemed "inexpensive," but volatility and lack of catalysts persist, leading to a forecast of a range-bound STI.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.55 points to 1573.09. The market saw 21 million lots traded worth RM6 million, with 92 losers outnumbering 63 gainers.

site_title: Taiwan growth hit by export drop, central bank board member says
summary: Taiwan's economic slowdown is mainly caused by a contraction in exports, according to Hua Nan Financial Holdings Co Chairman Liu Teng-cheng. The island's growth unexpectedly slowed to the least since 2012 in the second quarter, fueled by a six-month slump in exports. The central bank is considering cutting the policy discount rate to stimulate the economy, amid a 5.1% drop in Taiwan's dollar and slower growth in China. This could be the central bank's first rate cut since March 2009.

site_title: Mexican tycoon swept up in Citi probe
summary: The US Justice Department is investigating Citigroup's money laundering controls, focusing on the bank's dealings with companies linked to Mexican billionaire Carlos Hank Rhon. The probe includes examining anti-money laundering practices at Citigroup's Mexico unit, Banamex, and investigating clients involved in money laundering. Hank Rhon, a businessman with ties to Mexico's ruling party, has not been accused of wrongdoing, and his companies claim to have followed best practices. The investigation comes amid pressure for Citigroup to improve its compliance procedures globally.

site_title: France calls off search for MH370 wreckage off Reunion
summary: France is ending its search for the wreckage of missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 after 10 days of searching off the island of Reunion. The search, which began after a wing part was found on the island in July, yielded no results. French authorities stated that their search teams will remain vigilant, but no conclusive evidence was found to link the wreckage to the plane. The search area covered 10,000 sq km and the eastern coastline of the island.

site_title: China, Hong Kong stocks fall as yuan devaluation fears linger
summary: China's stocks fell on Tuesday, with the CSI300 index down 1% and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 1.5%, amid fears of a yuan devaluation. The currency eased against the dollar, sparking concerns about a potential deeper devaluation by the People's Bank of China. Shares in importers, airlines, and property companies also declined, with China Eastern and China Southern airlines falling 3.9% and 2.5% respectively. The yuan's decline reignited concerns about a devaluation, despite the central bank's earlier comments.

site_title: Singapore bankers rattled by Asian moves to chase undeclared wealth
summary: Singapore's low-tax environment is under pressure from Asian countries, including Indonesia and India, seeking to crack down on undeclared wealth. Indonesia is considering a tax amnesty, targeting US$225 billion in funds parked in Singapore, while India is trying to recover an estimated US$340 billion. Singapore banks face a more urgent challenge, with the country committing to automatic tax information sharing from 2018. The move threatens the city-state's reputation as a banking hub, with clients and wealth managers concerned about the impact on client confidentiality and structures.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Bomb in Thai capital kills 19, wounds scores
summary: A bomb exploded at the Erawan shrine in Bangkok, killing 19 people, including three foreign tourists, and injuring scores. The attack, which was described as unprecedented in Thailand, was attributed to a bid to destroy the economy and tourism. Authorities have set up a "war room" to coordinate the response, and security checks have been increased at major city intersections and tourist areas. Initial suspicion falls on Muslim separatists in the south, but the US State Department has not confirmed it as a terrorist attack, and an investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Google's Android update: code name Marshmallow
summary: Google has released its Android 6.0 operating system, code-named Marshmallow, offering enhancements such as fingerprint sensors and improved power-saving mode. The update streamlines app permissions, allowing users to grant permissions as needed without being prompted. Developed by product manager Jamal Eason, Marshmallow aims to improve the overall Android experience, following a tradition of using dessert-inspired names for Android versions. The update is available for developers to download, and users can expect to see widespread adoption as Android remains the dominant mobile computing system.

site_title: China home prices rise 0.3% m-o-m in July, fall on year
summary: China's average new home prices rose 0.3% in July from June, marking the third consecutive monthly increase. However, compared to the same period last year, prices still fell 3.7%. Property sales and housing investment showed signs of improvement, indicating a mixed recovery in the struggling market. China's real estate investment growth continued to slow in the first seven months of 2015.

images.alt_text: Average new home prices in China's 70 major cities rose 0.3 per cent in July from June, a third consecutive monthly rise, National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) data showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Thai baht hits over 6-year low after Bangkok bomb blast
summary: The Thai baht plummeted to a six-year low after a bomb blast at a popular shrine in Bangkok, killing 22 people, including eight foreign tourists, and injuring scores. The attack raised concerns about the country's tourism industry, causing the baht to lose 0.5% and fall to 35.55 per dollar, its weakest since April 2009. The government described the attack as a bid to destroy the economy, further exacerbating the currency's decline.

site_title: Shock and deja vu for foreigners after Thai blast
summary: A bomb exploded in central Bangkok, killing at least 19 people, including one Chinese and one Philippine national, and injuring over 120, mostly tourists visiting a popular shrine. The attack, which targeted the Grand Hyatt Erawan hotel and surrounding shopping centers, has dealt a blow to Thailand's struggling economy, which relies heavily on tourism. Foreigners, including tourists and locals, expressed alarm and a sense of déjà vu, recalling previous rounds of deadly violence in the country. The attack has raised concerns about the safety of tourists and the impact on Thailand's economy.

site_title: A timeline of recent blasts in Bangkok
summary: A bomb exploded outside a Thai capital shrine, killing 19 and injuring over 120. The attack occurred amidst heightened political tension in the nation, with the military and judiciary backing a Bangkok-based elite and the Red Shirt movement opposing them. No group claimed responsibility, but the incident is the deadliest in recent years. It follows a string of smaller bombings in Bangkok over the past five years, including five grenade blasts in 2010.

site_title: Stocks to watch: YuuZoo, Noble, Lizhong Wheel, SATS, SingPost, Japfa
summary: YuuZoo acquired key assets from Camigo Media, including 26 million users and 11 mobile games, for less than 0.5% of YuuZoo's shares, valued at around S$500,000. Noble Group kept options open to preserve its balance sheet, while Lizhong Wheel received a voluntary cash offer for S$0.50 apiece. SATS and SingPost partnered to provide airmail consignment handling services. Japfa invested in a US$200 million premium milk-processing plant in China.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 10.43 points to 3,077.78 on Tuesday, recovering from a 1.5% drop on Monday. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index also gained 0.1% following US gains. Noble and YuuZoo led gains, with Noble up 3.3% and YuuZoo up 6.25%. The market saw 93.6 million shares change hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 86 to 67, as investors reacted to various global economic developments.

site_title: Indonesian rescuers reach crash site, plane 'destroyed': official
summary: Indonesian rescuers have reached the crash site of a plane carrying 54 people, including large sums of cash, and found it "completely destroyed". The ATR 42-300 twin-turboprop aircraft, operated by Trigana Air, lost contact on Sunday while flying in bad weather. Rescuers are still searching for survivors, with slim chances of finding anyone alive, and are also hunting for the flight data recorders to determine the cause of the accident. The plane was carrying 49 passengers, 5 crew, and 6.5 billion rupiah in cash for poor families.

site_title: Qantas sells lease to Sydney Airport's Terminal 3
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd sold its lease on Sydney Airport's Terminal 3 to Sydney Airport Holdings Ltd for A$535 million, retaining exclusive use and management of the terminal until June 2025. The deal is part of Qantas' cost-saving efforts, including freezing capacity and slashing 5,000 jobs, as the airline approaches the halfway mark of its three-and-a-half-year turnaround program. Qantas expects to report a record full-year profit of at least A$900 million. The sale will have a neutral impact on earnings before interest and tax through 2019.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.10%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.10% higher on Tuesday, following gains in US shares. The Nikkei 225 index rose 20.33 points to 20,640.59 yen. US shares rose on Monday due to gains by large equities such as Apple and Disney. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also advanced, with the latter reaching a fresh record. This week's highlights include Wal-Mart earnings and the release of Fed minutes, which may influence interest rate decisions later this year.

site_title: Singtel tops Governance and Transparency Index, with SGX a close second
summary: Singtel has reclaimed its top spot in the Governance and Transparency Index (GTI) 2015, scoring 118 points. Singapore Exchange (SGX) followed closely with 114 points, while Keppel Corporation ranked third. The index, launched in 2009, assesses SGX-listed companies' governance practices, with significant overall progress noted. Starting next year, the index will be revamped under a new framework, the Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI), to better reflect changes in the business environment.

site_title: BuzzFeed moves to Japan in Yahoo partnership
summary: BuzzFeed has partnered with Yahoo Japan to launch a Japanese news website, marking the social news site's first joint venture. The partnership will allow BuzzFeed to accelerate growth in the Japanese market, leveraging Yahoo Japan's local cultural knowledge and established clients. BuzzFeed will hold a majority stake in the venture, maintaining editorial and creative independence. This move follows BuzzFeed's global expansion, with 45% of its traffic now coming from outside the US. The partnership is part of BuzzFeed's efforts to expand its reach and value, with recent investments valuing the company at $2.5 billion.

site_title: Eastern US air traffic system fails, but backups kick in
summary: A recent failure in the Eastern US air traffic system, which affected thousands of flights, was resolved without safety risks due to backup systems. The failure occurred in the En Route Automation Modernization system, which was installed at 20 FAA centres, and was attributed to a recent software upgrade. The system has had a high availability rate since its completion nationwide earlier this year, and the FAA reported no additional failures. Despite the disruptions, air traffic flowed normally on Sunday, and the FAA has taken steps to address the issue.

site_title: Norwegian fund excludes Genting, Daewoo, Posco and IJM over palm oil
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund has excluded four Asian companies, including Genting, Daewoo, Posco, and IJM, due to environmental damage caused by their palm oil activities. The decision is based on "severe environmental damage" from converting tropical forests to cultivate palm oil. The fund, which manages $1.22 trillion, has previously excluded around 60 companies, including Airbus and Wal-Mart, for violating human rights, child labor, or environmental concerns. The move aims to improve practices in the palm oil industry and align with strict ethical guidelines.

site_title: US dollar heads higher helped by housing sector sentiment
summary: The US dollar rose to a new high, its third consecutive gain, driven by improved confidence in the US housing sector. The dollar strengthened against the euro and yen, with a 1.1078 per euro and 124.41 yen respectively. This gain was attributed to the US National Association of Home Builders' construction sentiment index reaching a new high since the 2009 recession. Meanwhile, the Chinese yuan remained relatively unchanged at 6.3949 per dollar, following a devaluation in August.

site_title: Japfa-Food Union JV to develop China milk-processing plant
summary: Japfa Ltd and Food Union Group have formed a joint venture to build a US$200 million premium milk-processing plant in Shandong Province, China. Japfa's subsidiary, AustAsia Investment Holdings, will invest up to US$20 million for a 10% stake, while Food Union will hold the remaining 90%. The plant, expected to commence operations in 2017, will process 300,000 tonnes of milk per annum and supply premium raw milk to the plant. The partnership aims to capture growth and margins in the Chinese dairy market and accelerate Japfa's Greenfields brand in Asia.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: India, EU working to end row over generic drugs
summary: India and the European Union are working to end a trade row sparked by an EU ban on Indian pharmaceutical products. India cancelled a meeting to discuss a stalled free trade accord after the EU imposed a ban on around 700 generic drugs in May. The EU ban is linked to flaws in clinical tests done by India's GVK Biosciences. Both sides are seeking a solution, with the EU offering to lift the ban if fresh test results are submitted. India views the move as veiled protectionism, while the EU maintains it's a minor technical issue.

site_title: Funding Societies is first crowdfunder to partner with trustee
summary: Funding Societies, a peer-to-peer lending company, has become the first and only homegrown Singaporean company to incorporate a trustee registered with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), aiming to build trust between borrowers and investors. This move provides protection against money laundering and guarantees a preliminary assessment of loans in two to three days. Funding Societies predicts other companies will adopt a trustee relationship and expects MAS-registered trustee agencies to become a mandated requirement in the future. The company plans to expand into Malaysia and Indonesia, aiming to grow into the best platform for crowdfunding in South East Asia.

images.alt_text: Amanda Chai

site_title: Park Hotel Group makes foray into Australia
summary: Park Hotel Group has entered the Australian market with a 250-room hotel management contract for Park Hotel Adelaide, set to open in 2018. The deal marks the group's first hotel management contract outside Asia. LGB Corporation, a real estate developer, partnered with Park Hotel Group for the project. The hotel is part of a A$175 million mixed-use development featuring private residences. This collaboration represents a significant milestone for Park Hotel Group, expanding its portfolio to 12 properties across five countries.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore consumer optimism up in 2015: MasterCard survey
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence reached a high of 65.3 index points in mid-2015, according to a MasterCard survey. The optimism was driven by improvements in stock market outlook and quality of life, but declined in employment prospects. This growth is a positive indicator of the country's future, despite uncertain regional conditions. Singapore ranked fifth out of seven South-east Asian markets with the highest consumer confidence, behind Vietnam, Myanmar, the Philippines, and Thailand.

images.alt_text: Consumer confidence in Singapore has gained steadily, reaching a high of 65.3 index points in the middle of the year.

site_title: Startups should fund themselves instead of using debt: HL Finance
summary: Hong Leong Finance's president Ian Macdonald advises startups to fund themselves instead of using debt, citing the risks and limitations of debt financing. He recommends focusing on successful businesses that can repay loans, rather than those in "beyond survival" mode. The bank prioritizes face-to-face interaction with customers and offers customized financing packages, including property financing, equipment financing, and cash-flow financing, to support businesses. Macdonald believes that good old-fashioned interaction is key to a successful relationship with SMEs.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
"We are looking at technology as much as possible but it's all based around the customer's needs," says Mr Macdonald.

site_title: MPA taps tech to manage traffic, safety
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has partnered with IBM to develop and test new data analytics technologies to manage traffic and safety at the Port of Singapore. The two-year collaboration aims to ease traffic congestion and raise safety standards, with the platform integrating real-time data to help ships avoid accidents and detect unusual behavior. With an estimated 130,000 vessel calls annually, the partnership seeks to improve port security and efficiency, addressing Singapore's current lag in regional peers.

site_title: Greek elections 'imperative' for stability: minister
summary: Greece's Energy Minister Panos Skourletis has stated that early elections are "imperative" for maintaining the country's political stability as it implements its third debt bailout. The ruling Syriza party lost a significant portion of its parliamentary majority, forcing Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to rely on opposition parties to ratify the package. A confidence vote is likely, but main opposition parties have indicated they will not back Tsipras, making elections "highly likely" in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras (centre) and Greek Agriculture and Energy Minister Panos Skourletis (left) arrive at Agriculture Ministry in central Athens, Greece, on Aug 5, 2015.

site_title: Oil prices continue downward slide
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, closing at US$41.87 a barrel for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate, down 63 cents from Friday's settlement. The decline deepens a long slide, with WTI losing over 30% in the past two months. The increase in US oil rigs, the sixth rise in seven weeks, has fueled concerns that production won't decrease, putting downward pressure on prices.

images.alt_text: Crude oil prices fell on Monday, deepening a long slide as traders expect US production will remain strong, adding to abundant global supplies.

site_title: Citibank raises more than S$519,000 for ChildAid
summary: Citibank raised over S$519,000 for charity concert ChildAid, exceeding its goal for the fifth consecutive year. The event, which included a golf tournament, aimed to support low-income families through The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The total contribution from Citi since 2002 stands at S$3.8 million, with the charity golf tournament raising over S$2 million in the past four years. A cheque presentation ceremony was held, attended by guest of honour Senior Minister of State Amy Khor, to celebrate Citi's commitment to the community.

site_title: Yuan depreciation, US rate hike seen hurting appeal of HK stocks
summary: Hong Kong investors are facing a decline in their local shares due to a weakening yuan and expected US rate hike. The MSCI Hong Kong Index has fallen less than half the decline of mainland Chinese shares, making it the most expensive relative to the mainland gauge since November. Experts predict that the rate rise will impact Hong Kong developers and retailers, while Chinese companies may outperform in the long run. The yuan's devaluation will also ease deflationary pressure and boost Chinese equities, but investors are becoming increasingly cautious about Hong Kong's prospects.

site_title: US: Disney, Apple advance helps lift stocks
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 0.39% to 17,545.18, the S&P 500 advancing 0.52% to 2,102.44, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 0.86% to 5,091.70. Gains were driven by Disney, Apple, and McDonald's, with Disney rising 1.8% following a Star Wars theme park presentation. Wal-Mart earnings and Federal Reserve meeting minutes are expected to impact the market this week.

site_title: Bond investors wary of Crown's swelling debt, falling profits
summary: Australian billionaire James Packer's casino empire, Crown Resorts Ltd, is raising concerns among bond investors due to swelling debt and falling profits. The company's net debt grew 47% to A$2.5 billion, while earnings dropped 18% in the last financial year. The yield premium over swap rate on Crown's bonds widened to 179 basis points, the most on record, and credit default swaps rose 22 basis points this year. Moody's and Standard & Poor's have maintained a stable outlook but warned of potential downward rating pressure due to major projects and increased leverage.

site_title: Yuan move may mean China is wary of economic shift
summary: China's surprise currency devaluation has sparked concerns that the country's leadership is wary of a shift towards consumer spending and light manufacturing, which could destabilize the global economy. The devaluation, about 3% through Friday, aims to make Chinese exports cheaper on world markets, but could lead to retaliatory measures from trade rivals and impact the US economy, which relies heavily on the dollar as a reserve currency. Despite some economists arguing that the transition is going better than expected, China's leaders seem edgy, and excessive currency depreciation poses a significant risk to global stability.

site_title: Beware tighter rules and pitfalls of buying real estate in Australia
summary: Australia has cracked down on foreign investments in real estate, with a tax office team investigating 462 possible breaches of foreign home ownership rules. Foreigners are restricted to buying new homes, selling to locals, and liable for capital gains tax. The Australian Treasurer has ordered the sale of a $39 million Sydney mansion and plans to introduce a foreign investment register and a fee of at least $5,000 for foreigners seeking to buy real estate. The move aims to curb soaring house prices and a housing bubble, but has raised concerns among business lobby groups and Singaporeans who are also major investors in the Australian market.

site_title: Thai economic growth slows to 2.8% in Q2, outlook dims on yuan fall
summary: Thai economic growth slowed to 2.8% in Q2, driven by weak domestic demand and exports, amid China's devaluation of the yuan. This has dimmed the outlook for the rest of 2015, with the National Economic and Social Development Board citing "major constraints". The Thai government's growth forecast has been trimmed to 2.7-3.2% for the year, down from 3-4%. The slow growth has raised concerns about the legitimacy of the junta, which has promised to hand back power to a civilian government after a new constitution is enacted.

site_title: RBI cautious about raising foreign cap on rupee bond holdings
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is cautious about raising its foreign cap on rupee bond holdings, despite potential benefits, due to market volatility and the impact of global events such as China's yuan devaluation. The current cap of $30 billion is considered low among Asian countries, and allowing higher foreign ownership could boost the market and lower borrowing costs for the Indian government. However, policymakers prefer depreciation to maintain a competitive edge, and the RBI may not lift the cap due to potential counterproductive effects of increased US dollar inflows.

site_title: US benchmark crude prices may rise above Brent, analysts warn
summary: US benchmark crude prices may rise above Brent prices in 2016 due to decreasing domestic production and growing global supply. The US decision to ease export restrictions has created a temporary window for selling domestic crude abroad, but analysts warn that this window is closing. Global output is expected to grow, with Iran set to add up to 1 million barrels per day next year, while US production may decline by up to 10% over the next 12 months.

site_title: Malleable mindsets and supervisor support to teach old dogs new tricks
summary: A study by the Ministry of Manpower and researchers found that older Singaporean workers are less willing to undergo training due to a fixed mindset, believing their abilities are unchangeable. However, when they believe their capacities are malleable, they are more willing to learn and adapt. Supervisorial support is also crucial, with supportive supervisors encouraging older employees to participate in training. The study suggests that employers and supervisors can encourage older workers to adopt a malleable mindset and engage in training by providing opportunities for growth and development, and by challenging them with new tasks and roles.

site_title: Younger son of founder strengthens his hold on Lotte Group
summary: The younger son of Lotte Group founder Shin Kyuk Ho, Shin Dong Bin, has strengthened his hold on the South Korean conglomerate after a shareholders' meeting in Tokyo approved a proposal to establish a stable management structure and strengthen corporate governance. The move comes amid a bitter succession feud with his elder brother, who co-CEO's the company.

site_title: SIA-linked Vistara dangles free tickets to woo passengers
summary: Vistara, a joint venture between Singapore Airlines and Tata, is offering a free premium economy class ticket for every business class ticket purchased as part of a promotion to attract more passengers amid tough competition. The airline aims to boost its load factor, which improved to 71% in May. Vistara's load factor is lower than its competitors, including SpiceJet and IndiGo. The promotion is part of SIA's efforts to spread its wings and build alternate hubs, including in Delhi through Vistara and in Thailand through NokScoot.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Iran deal likely to rain on Obama's summer vacation
summary: US President Barack Obama's summer vacation at Martha's Vineyard is unlikely to be relaxing, as he will likely spend time trying to sell Congress on the Iran nuclear deal. The deal, which aims to lift economic sanctions on Iran in exchange for restrictions on its nuclear program, faces major opposition in Congress, with many Republicans and some Democrats expressing reservations. Obama will make phone calls to try to persuade lawmakers to back the deal, which he believes will protect US interests. The deal requires Congressional approval to lift sanctions, and Obama is preparing for a potential vote in September.

site_title: More Myanmar women drawn to 'bare knuckle' fights
summary: In Myanmar, a growing number of women are taking up the traditional martial art Lethwei, a bare-knuckle kickboxing style that emphasizes head-butting and knockout victories. The sport, which has a history dating back over a thousand years, is gaining popularity among women who are drawn to its intensity and authenticity. Around half of regulars at a Yangon gym are women, who are attracted to the sport's physical demands and the opportunity to challenge traditional gender norms. As Myanmar opens up to the world, women are increasingly participating in sports and taking on leadership roles, including in politics and business.

site_title: It's a 50-50 chance of keeping Potong Pasir: Sitoh
summary: Singaporean MP Sitoh Yih Pin of the People's Action Party (PAP) has announced he will defend the single-seat Potong Pasir constituency in the upcoming general election, despite giving himself a 50-50 chance of keeping the seat. Sitoh, who won the seat in 2011 by a narrow margin, has fulfilled all promises made to residents and will unveil his plans soon. A three-cornered battle is expected, with former National Solidarity Party boss Tan Lam Siong also running as an independent.

site_title: S'pore move to join AIIB natural, critical step: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore has officially joined the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), a China-led institution, as a natural and critical step for the country as an international financial centre and regional business hub. The move is seen as a timely initiative to address the significant infrastructure needs in Asia. With a US$250 million capital subscription, Singapore will hold 0.48% of the AIIB's total voting share. The government believes the AIIB will be a key international financial institution in the region, promoting investment in infrastructure and connectivity, and benefiting Singapore's trade and businesses.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Mrs Teo said initiatives that grow investments in Asia's infrastructure can generate spinoffs for Singapore's economy.

site_title: Robots pick up slack as wages go up
summary: As the minimum wage nears a $15-an-hour increase, the restaurant industry is expected to adopt more labor-saving technology, such as robots and automated cooking systems, to remain cost-competitive. This could lead to job losses, particularly among low-skilled workers, as chains look to reduce labor costs. Industry experts predict that automation could cut staffing levels in half, with remaining employees needing to learn how to operate machines and fix issues. The rise of technology is also expected to streamline operations, improve efficiency, and enhance customer experience.

site_title: Rest of PAP slate to be unveiled in last week of August
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) in Singapore will unveil its remaining candidates for group representative constituencies in the last week of August, following Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's National Day Rally speech on Sunday. The party has already revealed candidates for six group representation constituencies and four single-member constituencies, aiming to provide residents with enough time to make an informed choice. The move is seen as a steady pace to allow residents to digest the announcements.

site_title: Selling resumes after short-covering ends
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 1.5% on Monday, closing at 3,067.35, amid market volatility and weakness in Hong Kong stocks. The decline was attributed to a combination of factors, including anticipation of a Wall Street slide and the recent yuan devaluation. Shares of Ezion and Mercator Lines plummeted 9% and 27% respectively, following disappointing earnings reports and a "Trade with Caution" notice from the Singapore Exchange. Experts warn of continued downside pressure for currencies and equities in Asia, citing historical parallels with the 1990s Asian Financial Crisis.

site_title: S'pore top Asia-Pac commercial property buyer: DTZ
summary: Singapore is the top source of capital for cross-border investment in commercial property in the Asia-Pacific, according to DTZ. The city-state's stable Singapore dollar lowered investment costs, helping it outdo China and the US. Locally-sourced deals include purchases of hotels and land parcels in Australia and Penang. The Asia-Pacific region saw a 7% year-on-year decline in investment activity, while Europe and North America experienced growth. Global investment volumes are expected to increase by 22% to reach $791 billion, driven by low interest rates and demand for real estate.

images.alt_text: Singapore came in third for cross-border investment in the North American region between Q3 2014 and Q2 2015, and the deals included Ascott Residence Trust's US$165 million purchase of Element New York Times Square West hotel

site_title: SATS, SingPost tie up to boost e-commerce volumes
summary: SATS Ltd has partnered with Singapore Post (SingPost) to provide airmail consignment handling services from a new automated facility, SATS eCommerce AirHub, expected to be operational by December 2016. The partnership aims to improve efficiency and space utilization, with SingPost outsourcing its airport consignment operations to SATS. The collaboration is expected to achieve a productivity gain of over 30% and expand e-commerce volumes through the Singapore hub. This makes SATS the first ground handler in the world to own an airside facility, and enhances operational efficiency through single scanning and sorting.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: The art of decoding FOMC minutes amid Fed transparency
summary: The article discusses the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) minutes, which are released every six weeks, providing insight into the Fed's policy decisions. Former officials warn that the minutes can be misleading, as they focus on the deliberations rather than the actual decisions. In other news, Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast, and the UK economy shrunk for the second month, affecting Prime Minister Starmer. Additionally, Singapore's industrial production data is also discussed, and the country's affluents require $1.39 million to retire comfortably.

site_title: 16 killed, 78 hurt in bomb blast in Bangkok aimed at 'destroying economy'
summary: A bomb blast in Bangkok's Erawan shrine killed at least 16 people, including foreign tourists, and injured 78 others. The government believes the attack was aimed at destroying the economy and tourism, with no immediate claim of responsibility. The blast occurred in the heart of the tourism district, near top hotels and shopping centers. Authorities have stepped up security checks and are investigating possible links to Muslim separatists in the south.

site_title: Toyota output down on Tianjin blasts
summary: Toyota Motor Corp will lose its largest Chinese car production site for at least three days due to the Tianjin blasts, which injured over 50 employees. The area's evacuation will prevent Tianjin FAW Toyota Motor Co from operating, with Toyota and Volkswagen AG unable to determine how many of their cars were damaged. The blasts have killed 114 and left 70 people missing, with Premier Li Keqiang investigating the cause. Other carmakers, including Mazda and Mitsubishi Motors, also face production disruptions, with some reporting minor damage to their facilities.

site_title: Vietnam suffering from reliance on coal
summary: Vietnam's coal mining industry is facing criticism due to a recent environmental disaster in Quang Ninh province, where toxic run-off from an open-pit mine contaminated nearby streams and Ha Long Bay, a UNESCO World Heritage site. The disaster has sparked concerns about the nation's growing reliance on coal-fired electricity, contributing to climate change and pollution. Vietnam's demand for power generated by coal is expected to increase 10-12% annually through 2030, despite warnings from the World Bank and UN Development Programme that the policy may not be economically or environmentally sustainable.

site_title: Tech entry amplifies rich-poor gap in troubled area
summary: Tech companies' influx in San Francisco's Mid-Market neighbourhood has exacerbated the gap between rich and poor, despite efforts to integrate. New developments and tax breaks have driven up housing costs, with a single-room occupancy residence costing $65 a night, while nearby luxury apartments rent for over $4,000 a month. Long-time residents face gentrification, and low-paying jobs have created a demand for affordable housing. Companies like Twitter have attempted to address the issue with community projects, but the divide remains.

site_title: Growing number of US states ban powdered alcohol
summary: Nearly two dozen US states have banned powdered alcohol, despite it not yet being available on the market, with New York becoming the latest to enact a ban. The product, marketed as "Palcohol," has been approved by the US Treasury Department's Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau, but states have pushed back citing concerns it will make underage and binge drinking easier. The FDA has stated it does not have the authority to prevent the product from entering the market, but the maker argues that powdered alcohol is safer than liquid alcohol.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ezion Holdings' Q2 FY15 net profit fell short of expectations at US$70 million, down 23% year-on-year, due to cost overruns and fleet re jigging. CIMB Research lowers its FY15-17 earnings per share by 10-29% and maintains an "add" rating with a lower target price of S$1.30. In contrast, OUE's Q2 FY15 net loss of S$16.3 million was attributed to fair value losses in mutual funds, leading Maybank Kim Eng Research to lower its target price to S$1.92 and maintain a "hold" rating.

site_title: The fund manager who made money on Greek stocks
summary: Fund manager Vasileios Antoniadis made money in Greek stocks despite the country's drawn-out bailout talks and market turmoil, with his MetLife Alico M&S Domestic Equity fund rising 4.8% this year. He avoided banks and consumer companies, instead investing in undervalued shares of commodity producers and technology stocks. His fund's biggest positions include Hellenic Petroleum, Hellenic Exchanges, and Mytilineos Holdings, which have gained an average of 9% this year. Antoniadis attributes his success to identifying "healthy companies with growth prospects" and maintaining an overweight position in commodity producers and technology stocks.

site_title: UK's Labour Party may get a leader it doesn't want
summary: The UK's Labour Party is set to elect a new leader, with Jeremy Corbyn expected to win with over half of the votes. This marks a significant change from the previous system, where the leader was chosen by sitting MPs. Corbyn's victory has been predicted by polls, despite some party members expressing dissatisfaction with his leadership style. The new leader will succeed Ed Miliband, who resigned following the Labour Party's poor performance in the May UK election.

site_title: Harnessing the potential of Singapore's people
summary: Singapore's 50-year anniversary of independence is marked by a wave of reflection on the nation's meteoric journey. The country's formula of meritocratic pragmatism has led to a high GDP growth rate and low unemployment. However, Singapore faces challenges in competing with other megacities for talent, particularly in the technology sector, where it ranked last among 20 startup-friendly cities. To stay ahead, Singapore must improve the political feasibility of importing foreign talent, enhance the productivity of its resident labor pool, and attract and retain the right talent. The country's literacy rate and university graduate rate are high, but employee engagement is only 9%, and managers' ability to manage for performance excellence is limited, hindering productivity growth.

site_title: India looks to domestic savings to enhance economy's potential
summary: India's savings rate has hit a decade low of 31% of GDP, making the country vulnerable to fund outflows. Prime Minister Narendra Modi aims to increase the savings rate to 35% of GDP to fulfill the nation's economic potential. HSBC Holdings plc advises this increase is crucial to boost the economy. The current low savings rate is weighed down by sputtering growth and Asia's third-fastest inflation.

site_title: Indonesian rescuers rush to plane crash site
summary: Indonesian rescuers rushed to a remote mountain area on Monday to reach debris from a plane that crashed on Sunday, killing all 54 people on board. The Trigana Air ATR 42-300 twin-turboprop plane, carrying 49 passengers and 5 crew, lost contact with air traffic control during a short flight from Jayapura to Oksibil. The plane was believed to be carrying $661,756 in cash, government funds for poor families. Rescuers are battling dense forest to reach the site, with no word yet on survivors.

site_title: Japan economy again contracts in Q2 on weak domestic, overseas demand
summary: Japan's economy contracted by 1.6% in the second quarter, according to data released on Monday, with domestic consumption and exports contributing to the decline. The contraction, while less severe than expected, shows the Japanese economy is still struggling to achieve steady growth. The government is expected to provide fiscal stimulus to boost domestic spending, while the Bank of Japan may consider additional monetary easing. The economy's recovery remains uncertain, with economists warning of the impact of weak demand from China and other Asian markets.

site_title: Singapore's MFA condemns Bangkok blast; PM Lee says Singaporeans injured are being aided
summary: Singapore's Ministry for Foreign Affairs (MFA) has condemned the Bangkok blast, killing at least 16 people, including foreign tourists, and expressed condolences to the victims' families. The blast occurred on Monday night in Thailand's capital. Singaporean citizens injured in the blast are receiving aid.

site_title: Huge clean-up after Tianjin blasts trigger cyanide fears
summary: A massive explosion in Tianjin, China on August 12 killed 114 people and injured many more, raising concerns over toxic pollutants. The blast at a hazardous goods storage facility stored around 700 tonnes of sodium cyanide, nearly 30 times the allowed amount. Officials face criticism for their response, with state-run media lambasting them for lack of transparency and environmental campaign group Greenpeace finding low levels of cyanide in some areas. A massive clean-up effort is underway, with military and chemical experts involved, and an investigation into possible "abuse of power or dereliction of duty" has been launched.

site_title: Lizhong Wheel's major owner launches voluntary cash offer
summary: The major shareholder of Lizhong Wheel Group, Berkley International, has launched a voluntary cash offer to purchase the aluminium alloy wheel maker's shares at 50 Singapore cents apiece. This offer price is significantly higher than the last traded price and provides a "clean cash exit opportunity" for shareholders. The offer is conditional on a minimum acceptance of 90% of the offer shares, and privatising the firm will allow the offeror and management to focus on the business without incurring listed status expenses.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: S'pore blue chips beckon in yuan-shock aftermath
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) offers an attractive dividend yield following China's yuan devaluation, with yields surpassing regional and global benchmarks. The STI, dominated by large market capitalization stocks, pays out about 3.6% of its current price as dividends, compared to 3.4% for the Kuala Lumpur Composite and 3.3% for the Hang Seng Index. This has led Morgan Stanley to recommend Singapore government-linked companies as potential re-rating candidates, citing their potential for restructuring and improved cash returns for investors.

site_title: Beijing steps up property curbs in red-hot areas
summary: Beijing has implemented stricter property market rules in the red-hot Tongzhou district, aiming to curb speculation. Non-residents and those without social insurance or taxes in the area for at least three years are barred from buying second homes. To buy a first home, individuals must have paid more than five years' worth of taxes or social insurance, with three years registered in Tongzhou. The move aims to prevent bubbles in other big cities, where prices are also surging, and follows China's year-long housing market slump.

site_title: A$25-an-hour waiters threaten growth in Australia, but reform carries political risks
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott's government is reluctant to overhaul the labor market, despite economic growth stagnating, as proposed wage reforms face significant political risks. The current system of pay rates, which double wages for Sunday shifts in some service industries, is seen as outdated and hampers small businesses. A Productivity Commission draft report recommends reducing Sunday rates to align with Saturday levels, but this proposal is likely to be met with resistance from unions and the business community, making major labor market reform unlikely in the near future.

Over 3,000 Singaporeans registered to vote abroad for the next general election. Meanwhile, international news includes Malaysia's plan to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's slowing GDP growth, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

images.alt_text: There are 3,104 Singaporeans who have registered to vote overseas at the next general election as at end-July, said Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean in a written parliamentary reply on Monday.

site_title: Colliers International has new occupier services team
summary: Colliers International has expanded its occupier services in Asia with key appointments and promotions. Sam Harvey-Jones has been appointed managing director of occupiers services Asia, overseeing corporate solutions and transaction management teams. Mark Lampard has been promoted to managing director of transaction management, Asia, while Abhishek Bajpai and Rick Thomas have been promoted to executive director of corporate solutions. The moves aim to enhance Colliers' regional service offer for corporate clients navigating complexities of multi-market portfolios in Asia.

site_title: Some Singaporeans injured in Bangkok bomb blast: Singapore embassy in Thailand
summary: A bomb blast in Bangkok's heart injured some Singaporeans, according to the Singapore Embassy in Thailand. The embassy confirmed that Singaporeans have suffered injuries but did not provide further details.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end day mixed
summary: Europe's main stock markets ended a mixed session, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.01% and Paris's CAC 40 up 0.57%. Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropped 0.41%. The mixed performance was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare shares, while US-EU trade talks were in focus.

site_title: Germany unnerved by scores of xenophobic attacks against refugees
summary: Germany is experiencing a surge in xenophobic attacks against refugees, with scores of arson attacks and physical assaults targeting asylum-seekers. The attacks have sparked a heated national debate over rising racism and intolerance, despite Germany's efforts to lead the European response to the refugee crisis. The incidents have highlighted social tensions in the region and raised questions about what modern Germany stands for. The attacks have been particularly prevalent in former communist east Germany, where diversity levels are low, and have put the country on edge.

site_title: House briefs
summary: Singapore Parliament passed changes to the Employment Act requiring employers to issue itemised payslips and detailed employment records by April 1 next year. Employers committing breaches will face fines. The Organised Crime Bill was also passed, defining an organised crime group as three or more people involved in serious crimes for material or financial benefit. Law enforcement agencies will have enhanced powers and harsher punishments for serious crimes. Meanwhile, international news includes Malaysia's plan to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets and China's GDP growth expected to slow.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Creative Technology warns that second-half revenue may be below target and expects an operating loss similar to the first half of the year. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In other news, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case and Helen Wong is retiring as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor. Singapore stocks are experiencing a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while CGS Investment downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected slowing earnings growth in the second half.

site_title: Morgan Stanley's 'Fragile 5' goes up to 'Troubled 10' in selloff
summary: Morgan Stanley has upgraded its "Troubled 10" list, increasing the number of nations at risk due to China's yuan devaluation from 5 to 10. The list includes currencies from Brazil to South Korea, all of which have high exposure to China. The analysts warn of a lack of global growth and a slowdown in China's economy, which will put its trading partners in the crosshairs. The move has rippled through global markets, weakening currencies and sending developing-nation stocks into a bear market.

site_title: Trade blues in July signal shaky start to second half
summary: Singapore's economy started the third quarter with a rocky note, as July export figures fell 0.8% year-on-year, worse than expected. Non-oil domestic exports declined mainly due to a 2.1% fall in non-electronics shipments, with electronics exports being a rare bright spot. Economists warn that the manufacturing sector faces structural problems and that the decline may prompt the Monetary Authority of Singapore to ease monetary policy. The country's economic growth forecast for 2015 has been pared to 1-2% year-on-year, its slowest growth since 2009.

site_title: Non-profit hospice nets S$1m in donations
summary: Dover Park Hospice in Singapore raised over S$1 million at its annual Sunflower Gala Ball, with proceeds going towards providing hospice care for terminally ill patients. The non-profit organization, founded in 1992, serves over 1,000 patients annually and relies on fundraising and donations to cover 40% of its S$11 million annual expenses. The event featured a dinner, silent auction, and performance by the DPH GEMS Choir, with Health Minister Gan Kim Yong as the guest of honor. The funds will support the hospice's services, including managing end-stage dementia.

site_title: China imports huge volumes of ethanol
summary: China has begun importing large volumes of ethanol, with 56,000 tonnes shipped in the first half of the year, worth $27 million. This marks a significant increase from 2014 and could signal Beijing's intentions to ease restrictions on its biofuels market, potentially transforming the global $40 billion-per-year ethanol industry. The imports are mostly from Brazil and the US, and may be driven by opportunistic buying or China's expanding overseas resource-related assets. If sustained, this could provide relief for US ethanol producers struggling due to low margins.

site_title: AT&T image may be hit by report of NSA ties
summary: AT&T may face a temporary image blow due to reports of its close collaboration with the US National Security Agency (NSA), with documents revealing a "highly collaborative" relationship and an "extreme willingness to help" in surveillance programs. However, analysts expect no long-term impact on the company's business or stock price, citing its compliance with laws and regulations. AT&T completed a $48.5 billion takeover of DirecTV last month to shore up its business, and customer reaction may be muted due to existing assumptions about the company's involvement in surveillance programs.

site_title: Secret strategies behind making money from free mobile games
summary: Japanese mobile game publishers use psychology, art, and big data to monetize free games, drawing players in with engaging narratives, characters, and play modes. They analyze player behavior to identify trends and adjust their strategies, offering rewards and challenges to keep users engaged. Companies like DeNA and GungHo Online Entertainment Inc use data analysts to track engagement and segment users, while also incorporating social media and real-world events to boost revenue. This approach has led to significant success, with Japanese companies dominating the world's top-earning mobile games, including Puzzle & Dragons, which generated $1.3 billion for GungHo last year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Monday, closing at 1,572.54 after losing 24.28 points. The Kuala Lumpur Composite Index saw 2.06 billion lots valued at RM1.95 billion traded, with 149 gainers and 836 losers.

site_title: PwC to return to Noble by year-end to review implementation progress
summary: NOBLE Group has agreed to implement all recommendations from PwC's review of its mark-to-market valuation processes, with the auditor to review progress by the end of the year. PwC, commissioned by Noble's independent board committee, found Noble's approach to be "more sophisticated" but recommended improvements in transparency, comparability, and consistency. Noble will strengthen its internal audit team and formalize procedures for back-testing and stress-testing of its portfolio. The company's CEO, Yusuf Alireza, expressed commitment to continuous improvement, saying Noble is "not perfect" and should always be challenging itself to get better.

site_title: MDA reminds political parties to abide by rules governing party political films
summary: The Media Development Authority (MDA) in Singapore has reminded political parties to abide by rules governing party political films ahead of the general elections. The authority cited the Singapore Democratic Party's "Pappy Washing Powder" clip as an example, stating that such films are banned under Section 33 of the Films Act.

site_title: Parliament: 3,104 Singaporeans registered to vote overseas as of end-July
summary: As of end-July, 3,104 Singaporeans have registered to vote overseas for the next general election, making up 0.1% of the total number of electors. This was revealed by Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean in a parliamentary reply.

site_title: Update: Several foreigners among 27 dead in Bangkok blast, according to local TV
summary: A bomb exploded outside the Erawan Shrine in central Bangkok, killing at least 27 people and wounding scores more. The blast occurred on a motorcycle and scattered body parts across the street. The police confirmed the incident, with Deputy National Police Chief Aek Angsananond stating there was an explosion involving a motorcycle bomb.

images.alt_text: A bomb exploded outside a religious shrine in central Bangkok late Monday, killing at least 27 people and wounding scores more, according to local TV.

site_title: Dollar strengthens as markets shake off yuan scare
summary: The dollar strengthened against a basket of currencies for a third consecutive trading day, driven by market concerns about a China-led "currency war" easing. The dollar index rose 0.2% to 96.711, its strongest in five days, ahead of US inflation data and minutes from the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. Investors now focus on monetary policy divergences between major economies, with the euro expected to remain weak.

site_title: Lum Chang acquires UK commercial property
summary: Lum Chang, a Singapore-based construction group, has signed a deal to acquire Kelaty House in Wembley, London for £25.5 million (S$55.6 million). The 1.03-hectare property is fully leased and has existing planning consent for redevelopment. Lum Chang sees this as a "prime investment opportunity" to expand its UK property portfolio, with plans to review options and make a decision on redevelopment in due course. The acquisition is expected to be completed on August 28, 2015.

site_title: Auditor-General's findings on public agencies very different from those on AHPETC accounts
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that the Auditor-General's Office found lapses in both the Workers' Party's town council and public sector agencies, but the Government's accounts received a clean bill of health.

site_title: Balance sheet our top priority: Noble
summary: Noble Group, a commodities trading firm, held its inaugural Investor Day to address criticisms of its accounting practices and reassure shareholders about its balance sheet. CEO Yusuf Alireza stated that the company is exploring options to preserve its balance sheet, including selling businesses or working with banks to add credit facilities. Despite a 7% decline in shares, Alireza emphasized that the company has strong support from key stakeholders and remains confident in its business. Noble is working to restore confidence in its balance sheet and earnings, with a focus on delivering results and addressing industry challenges.

site_title: New York state factory activity tumbles to lowest since 2009: NY Fed
summary: New York state's manufacturing activity has declined to its weakest level since 2009, according to a New York Federal Reserve survey. The Empire State general business conditions index dropped to -14.92 in August, its lowest since April 2009, with new orders and shipments also falling. However, optimism on future business improved, with the index on future business conditions rising to 33.64. This decline suggests a slowdown in US factory conditions, contrary to expectations.

site_title: US: Stocks open week lower
summary: US stocks fell in opening trade Monday, with the Dow Jones down 120.36 points (0.69%) at 17,357.04. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, shedding 10.77 (0.51%) and 22.51 (0.45%) respectively. The losses follow modest gains last week, as investors await the release of Federal Reserve meeting minutes on Wednesday, which may shed light on the central bank's interest rate increase timing later this year.

site_title: Opec may boost oil output to record with Iran back amid glut
summary: Opec may boost oil production to a record 33 million barrels a day, following Iran's potential return to the group amid a global supply glut. Iran can increase output by 500,000 barrels a day after sanctions are lifted, contributing to the existing surplus of 3 million barrels a day. This decision could be a result of Iran's "big mistake" in backing Opec's 2011 decision to discard individual production quotas, allowing other members to take over Iran's share.

site_title: Will the yuan make it to the IMF basket?
summary: The US dollar is poised to maintain its dominance as a reserve currency, despite growing competition from the renminbi, due to perceptions and trust rather than macroeconomic fundamentals. The IMF reviews its basket of reserve currencies every five years, and the next review is scheduled for November. China's renminbi faces challenges, including high debt levels and a lack of transparency in its markets. The dollar's recent resurgence, despite quantitative easing, has reinforced its status as the supreme currency of choice. The US government's ability to insulate its citizens from policy changes and the dollar's widespread use in global transactions have solidified its position.

site_title: Ringgit's woes made worse by 'unresolved politics'
summary: Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, has plummeted 30% since August last year, largely due to "unresolved politics" surrounding 1MDB, a state-owned strategic investment company. Prime Minister Najib Razak's administration has faced criticism over the company's RM42 billion borrowings and his personal bank deposits. Investors are withdrawing funds, and economists warn that capital controls or a fixed peg are unlikely but cannot be ruled out. A rally is planned to protest against the government's handling of 1MDB, and foreign investors are exiting the market, potentially causing significant economic dislocations.

site_title: Emerging currencies extend worst selloff since turn of century
summary: Emerging-market currencies have experienced their worst weekly selloff since the turn of the century, with a gauge of 20 developing-nation currencies falling 0.3% and the MSCI Emerging Markets Index reaching a four-year low. The decline is attributed to concerns over higher US interest rates, the Chinese yuan devaluation, and the impact on oil prices. This marks the eighth consecutive week of declines, with currencies such as the Malaysian ringgit and Turkish lira reaching record lows.

site_title: Japfa ties up with European dairy firm to develop US$200m plant in China
summary: Japfa Ltd, an agri-food firm, has partnered with Food Union Group to develop a US$200-million premium milk processing plant in Shandong Province, China. The joint venture, worth 10% stake, will be funded by Japfa's subsidiary AustAsia Investment Holdings (AIH) with a US$20 million investment. The plant will manufacture high-value-added dairy products, with Food Union holding the remaining 90% stake.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Airbus plans long-range A350 to fly Singapore-NYC direct by 2018
summary: Airbus plans to develop a long-range A350 variant to enable Singapore Airlines to restore nonstop US flights, aiming for a 2018 launch. The new model would reduce fuel burn by 25% and offer a premium service, targeting the 15,344km route from Singapore to New York. Boeing's 777-200LR currently holds the record, but Airbus believes its A350 can make the trip economically viable. Several other airlines are also interested in a similar variant, which could be available "an awful lot quicker" than Boeing's offering.

site_title: Singapore Air seeks Northeast Asia deals after collapsed Jeju talks: sources
summary: Singapore Airlines is seeking partnerships and investments in Northeast Asia, particularly in China, after a deal with Jeju Air collapsed. The airline aims to access China's vast domestic flights market and is exploring potential partnerships with Chinese carriers, such as China Air Ltd. Despite having a presence in China, Singapore Airlines lacks a codeshare partnership, which would allow for indirect flights. The airline's passenger numbers have fallen 2% from 2007, while global traffic has risen 4.8% annually, with competitors encroaching on its markets.

site_title: PAP's slate for 3 wards, including Aljunied GRC, likely to be known after Sunday's rally: Ng Eng Hen
summary: Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen announced that the People's Action Party's (PAP) slate of candidates for all but three constituences, including the Aljunied GRC, will be revealed before the Prime Minister's National Day Rally on August 23. The PAP lost the Aljunied GRC to the Workers' Party in 2011.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: Developers in Singapore saw a surge in private home sales in July, with 1,594 units sold, compared to 375 in June. Non-electronics shipments dragged down Singapore's non-oil domestic exports in July, while consumer confidence in the country reached a high of 65.3 index points in mid-2015. PAP MP Sitoh Yih Pin gave himself a 50:50 chance of keeping his seat in Potong Pasir. Noble Group's CEO stated the company is open to selling core businesses to boost market confidence. The Straits Times Index dropped 1.5% on Monday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 0.74% lower
