summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.74% lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 176.38 points to 23,814.65, amid concerns over China's yuan devaluation affecting local companies. Investors expect mainland shares to become better value, leading to a decline in Hong Kong shares.

site_title: Singapore Air's Indian unit resorts to free seats to lure fliers
summary: Vistara, Singapore Airlines' Indian unit, is offering free premium economy class tickets to fill seats amid intense competition and low fares in the Indian market. The airline filled about 59% of seats on average in the first half of 2015, compared to SpiceJet's 87%. Vistara's load factor rose to 71% in May, and the airline's fleet will expand to nine from six in the next three months. Industry experts say making premium economy work is crucial for Vistara to avoid a configuration correction.

site_title: National Day Rally on Sunday
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will deliver the National Day Rally speech this Sunday, speaking in Malay, Mandarin, and English. The speech will take place from 6:45pm to 10:00pm. This marks the annual event where the Prime Minister addresses the nation on Singapore's progress and future plans.

site_title: Merkel sees IMF joining Greek bailout as debt relief floated
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed confidence that the International Monetary Fund will join Greece's third bailout, with conditions including eased terms on previous Greek aid loans. Merkel said she has no doubt the IMF will participate starting in October if conditions are met. The move aims to address Greece's debt crisis and support the country's economic recovery, which is crucial for the entire European economy. Merkel's comments came ahead of a vote in Germany's parliament on the bailout package, which is set to unlock Greece's three-year bailout.

site_title: Lizhong Wheel's major shareholder makes voluntary cash offer at 50 Singapore cents a share
summary: Lizhong Wheel Group's major shareholder, Berkley International, has made a voluntary cash offer to purchase the aluminium alloy wheel maker at 50 Singapore cents per share. The offer is made by Tianjin Dong An Brothers, an investment holding firm owned by the Zang family, which owns 64.23% of the company. The offer is backed by irrevocable undertakings from the undertaking shareholders, representing 66.77% of the firm's total issued shares.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Noble Group open to selling core businesses to boost confidence: CEO
summary: Noble Group, Asia's largest commodities trader, is open to selling its core businesses to boost confidence after a bruising accounting dispute. CEO Yusuf Alireza said the company is evaluating options to review core businesses, including shutting down certain businesses or selling them to banks and strategic investors. The move comes after a blogger alleged the company inflated assets by billions of dollars, with Noble rejecting the claims. Despite a thorough review by PricewaterhouseCoopers, Noble's shares have declined 60% since mid-February, citing weak prospects in metals and energy due to China's slowing economy.

site_title: Singapore: Shares close weaker as selling resumes after short-covering ends
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 1.5% to 3,067.35 on Monday, amid weakness in Hong Kong and anticipation of a Wall Street slide. The index fell despite a short-covering event that lifted it the previous week. Key losers included Ezion, which plunged 9% after its Q2 profit missed expectations, and Noble, which slid 7% due to internet trading restrictions. The market's advance-decline score was 110-346, with a weak trading volume of 1.3 billion units.

site_title: Koh Brothers, Heeton unveil Sun Plaza after makeover
summary: Koh Brothers Group and Heeton Holdings unveiled Sun Plaza, a newly improved suburban mall in Sembawang, following a S$33 million asset enhancement drive. The 50:50 joint venture added 5,772 square feet to existing space, bringing total net lettable area to 158,000 sq ft. The mall, near Sembawang MRT and Bus Interchange, has achieved near full occupancy with anchor tenants. The asset enhancement exercise aimed to boost investment property yields through a retail and tenant mix revamp and space optimisation. The new mall is now fully occupied.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Sound system of checks in place in the public sector: Tharman (Amended)
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam assured Parliament that Singapore's public sector has a "sound system" of checks and balances in place to ensure full accounting of public funds. Despite a lapse in the 2014/15 financial year, the Auditor-General's Office's report did not affect its opinion of the government's financial statements. Tharman attributed the government's clean financial record to the robust system of checks and balances, making it one of the cleanest and most reputable administrations in the world.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Goldman sees iron ore slumping 30% on supply, steel outlook
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts iron ore prices will slump 30% over the next 18 months due to expanding supply and a contraction in steel production in China. Despite recent price gains, analysts Christian Lelong and Amber Cai forecast a further 30% decline, citing a "summer of 2015" as a period of calm before the storm. The analysts expect steel production to drop in the third quarter, while iron ore supply growth will resume after operational issues are resolved.

site_title: China audit uncovers misuse of affordable housing funds
summary: China's state auditor uncovered widespread irregularities in the country's affordable housing programme in 2014, including the misuse of 9.4 billion yuan (S$2.07 billion) of funds. The funds were misappropriated for salaries, office expenses, and investments. 485 million yuan in government subsidies and bank loans were obtained illegally by fabricating documents, and 20,600 home owners did not qualify for affordable housing due to fake documents. The audit also found that nearly 1.1 trillion yuan in investment was made for the programme.

site_title: Update: PAP's Sitoh gives himself a 50:50 chance of keeping Potong Pasir seat
summary: PAP MP Sitoh Yih Pin has announced he will run for re-election in Potong Pasir, citing a 50:50 chance of retaining the seat. He won the seat in 2011, defeating Lina Chiam, who had previously held the seat for 27 years. Sitoh faces Lina Chiam and independent candidate Tan Lam Siong in the upcoming general election.

site_title: Developer sales jump to 1,594 private homes in July from 375 units in June
summary: Developer sales in Singapore jumped to 1,594 private homes in July, up from 375 units in June and 511 units in the same period last year. This includes 2,089 units, excluding executive condominiums. The surge marks a significant increase from June and a notable jump from the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Accounts of public sector agencies are reliable, sound checks and balances in place: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that public sector agencies have a sound system of checks and balances in place to ensure proper accounting of public funds. The Auditor-General Office's latest report for FY2014/15 did not affect its opinion of the Government Financial Statements.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality names new chief investment officer
summary: Frasers Hospitality has appointed Mak Hoe Kit as its new chief investment officer, overseeing investment and acquisition strategy for hospitality assets. Kit, formerly with Northstar Group, brings over $3 billion in deal experience to the role. He replaces Eu Chin Fen, who has taken on the CEO position of Frasers Hospitality Trust.

site_title: China regulator urges finance firms to support Tianjin disaster relief
summary: China's securities regulator urged financial institutions to support disaster relief efforts in Tianjin following blasts on August 12 that damaged a large industrial area. The regulator said insurance companies would set up a 24-hour service to handle related claims. The China Development Bank would provide emergency loans to affected businesses and individuals. Initial estimates suggest total insurance losses could range from $1 billion to $1.5 billion. The death toll has risen to 112, with 95 people missing, and scores of businesses have been affected.

images.alt_text: China securities regulator on Monday urged financial institutions to support disaster relief efforts in the northeastern city of Tianjin, and said insurance companies would set up a 24-hour service to handle related claims.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 gaining 0.43% to 6,579.08 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris's CAC 40 also increased, with the latter rising 0.81%. This follows a turbulent week for equities, driven by concerns over the Chinese and Greek economies.

site_title: Philippines can't afford full military modernisation: officials
summary: The Philippines' military modernization efforts are hindered by limited financial resources, with Defence Secretary Voltaire Gazmin stating that the country can only afford a "frugal" upgrade. Despite a proposed 25% increase in next year's defence budget, the government must balance external defence against internal threats like insurgencies and natural disasters. The military has acquired several aircraft and helicopters in recent years, but plans to acquire more advanced fighter jets, like the FA-50, are on hold due to budget constraints. China's maritime expansion in the South China Sea remains a pressing concern.

site_title: PAP's Sitoh Yih Pin to defend Potong Pasir in the coming general election
summary: Singaporean politician Sitoh Yih Pin announced he will defend his Potong Pasir Single Member Constituency in the upcoming general election. This marks his second term in the constituency, which he won in 2015. The announcement was made at a local park in Potong Pasir.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch higher, but energy a drag
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by gains in the healthcare and utilities sectors, but capped by weak energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 11.16 points to 5,367.7, near a seven-month trough. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index gained 0.5%. Despite the market's modest gains, investors remain cautious due to ongoing energy concerns.

site_title: Lotte chief wins key battle in family feud
summary: South Korea's Lotte Group chairman Shin Dong-Bin secured crucial shareholder support in his struggle for control of the family-run retail giant. Shareholders approved corporate governance proposals to be implemented under his leadership, with Lotte welcoming the vote. This marks a key victory for Shin, who is pitted against his father and elder brother for control of the company, the country's fifth-largest conglomerate.

site_title: Oil falls near six-year low as US, Opec keep pumping amid glut
summary: Oil prices have fallen near a six-year low due to a surge in US drilling activity and Opec's potential increase in production. The US saw a 2% decline in oil futures, with West Texas Intermediate trading at $41.82 a barrel. Opec's production may rise to 33 million barrels a day after Iran's sanctions are lifted, further exacerbating the global surplus. US crude stockpiles fell, but remain above the five-year average, with supplies over 90 million barrels above the average. Analysts attribute the oversupply to the market's continued heavy flooding of crude.

site_title: China: Stocks claw back losses but fear further yuan depreciation
summary: China's stocks recovered early losses on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite Index closing 0.7% higher at 3,994.37 points. Despite the gains, fears of further yuan depreciation persisted, with analysts predicting a 5% spot devaluation from the pre-reform level. The central bank's efforts to steady the yuan have been unsuccessful, and market watchers expect the currency to remain under downward pressure due to the weak economic environment. Property stocks led the gains, with the CSI China mainland real estate index rising 2.2%.

site_title: Malaysia seeks help from tech firms to stem "false" online content
summary: Malaysia's Communications Minister Salleh Said Keruak announced that the country will ask Facebook, Google, and Twitter to curb "false" online content in the interest of public safety. The request comes amid controversy over Prime Minister Najib Razak's involvement in the 1Malaysia Development Berhad scandal. The Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission will meet with the social media companies to seek their cooperation in stemming the spread of false information and rumors. The online environment is considered not a lawless space, and action can be taken against those found to have breached the law.

site_title: Firm dollar, yuan worries hurt Asia FX, ringgit near 17-year lows
summary: Emerging Asian currencies declined on Monday due to a strengthening US dollar, with the renminbi and ringgit holding steady despite China's efforts to stabilize the yuan. The dollar rose against a basket of six major currencies after encouraging US producer prices and industrial output data fueled expectations of a September interest rate hike. Malaysia's ringgit slid to near 17-year lows, while Thailand's baht touched a six-year low, amid concerns about exports and capital outflows.

site_title: Indonesian plane searching for missing aircraft spots debris: official
summary: An Indonesian plane searching for a missing aircraft with 54 people on board spotted debris near Oksibil, Papua, on Monday. The Trigana Air plane disappeared in bad weather, losing contact with air traffic control Sunday. Officials had reported a possible crash into a mountain, and villagers had seen debris. The discovery of debris has raised hopes that the cause of the disappearance may be found.

site_title: Beijing tightens grip on home purchases in overheated area
summary: Beijing has introduced stricter rules on property market speculation in the Tongzhou district, a southeastern suburb of the capital. Non-residents and those without social insurance or taxes in the area for at least three years are barred from buying second homes. To buy a first home, they must have paid more than five years' worth of taxes or social insurance, with at least three years registered in Tongzhou. Analysts say this move is unlikely to reverse the favourable policy stance in smaller cities, and home prices remain under pressure due to a huge overhang of unsold houses in small cities.

site_title: Lum Chang to buy Kelaty House in Wembley, London for 25.5m pounds
summary: Lum Chang has agreed to buy Kelaty House in Wembley, London for £25.5 million (S$55.6 million). The 1.03-hectare property is fully leased and has existing planning consent to be redeveloped into a mixed-use development. Lum Chang views the acquisition as a prime investment opportunity to expand its UK property portfolio, with plans to provide a rental income stream. The deal is expected to be completed by August 28, 2015.

site_title: India, EU working to end trade huff over generic drugs
summary: India and the European Union are working to end a trade dispute sparked by the EU's ban on Indian generic pharmaceuticals. The ban, which affects around 700 products, was imposed due to concerns over clinical test results. India's government cancelled talks on a free trade accord with the EU after the ban was formalized, but both sides are now working to resolve the issue. The EU has offered to lift the ban if India submits fresh test results, and New Delhi has expressed a willingness to find a solution. The dispute has raised concerns about India's trade relationships with major European pharmaceutical firms.

images.alt_text: A security guard walks in front of the headquarters of GVK Biosciences, a clinical research company, in Hyderabad, India.

site_title: Mass clean-up after China blasts trigger cyanide fears
summary: A massive explosion in northern China's Tianjin port on August 12 killed 114 people and raised concerns over toxic pollutants. The blast at a hazardous goods storage facility released hundreds of tonnes of cyanide, with officials initially stating the air and water were safe, but residents and relatives questioned this claim. A huge clean-up effort is underway, with military and chemical experts brought in to address the disaster. Authorities have launched an investigation into potential abuse of power and dereliction of duty, and officials have faced criticism over lax enforcement of regulations and ties between business and government elites.

site_title: Singapore monetary policy caught between rock and hard place
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is caught between easing monetary policy to boost export competitiveness after China's yuan devaluation and raising borrowing costs in a slow economy. Speculation of a policy easing in October has revived expectations, but the MAS remains cautious, citing an appropriate current policy. A softer Singapore dollar could squeeze local interest rates, affecting property owners and real-estate investment trusts. Analysts expect the MAS to stay put in October, citing a lack of appetite to lift rates higher.

images.alt_text: Shrinking factory output, an economic contraction and months of falling consumer prices have revived speculation the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) may ease policy at its next review in October.

site_title: Singapore consumer optimism up in 2015: MasterCard survey
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence reached a high of 65.3 index points in mid-2015, according to the MasterCard Index of Consumer Confidence. The survey of 400 people showed improvements in stock market and quality of life optimism, but a decline in employment prospects. The Asia-Pacific region averaged 66.1 index points, down from 68.3 in 2014, with declines in Indonesia, Thailand, and Myanmar. The growth in Singapore's consumer confidence is seen as a positive indicator of optimism for the country's future, marking its 50 years of independence.

site_title: SATS and SingPost ink pact to integrate airmail consignment operations
summary: SATS and SingPost have signed a commercial agreement to integrate airmail consignment operations at the SATS eCommerce AirHub facility, expected to be operational by December 2016. The 6,000-square-metre facility will be located at Changi Airfreight Centre and will serve as the anchor customer for SingPost. SATS will become the first ground handler to own an airside facility, and the integration will enhance efficiency and space utilization for both companies. SingPost will outsource its airport consignment operations at Changi Airmail Transit Centre 2 to SATS when its lease expires in end-2016.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China: Shanghai stocks down 0.44% in early trades
summary: Shanghai stocks fell 0.44% on Monday morning, despite regulators' promises to support the market. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index lost 17.50 points to 3,947.84. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.20% to 2,314.92. The decline was attributed to market volatility, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend stocks rally.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday after poor NODX showing
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened lower on Monday, down 3.71 points to 3,110.54, following a report showing a decline in non-electronics shipments, which dragged down non-oil domestic exports in July. This comes despite Japanese stocks rising after a report showed the nation's economy contracted less than forecast. US stocks ended the week with gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.60% and the S&P 500 reaching a fresh record.

images.alt_text: Singapore share prices opened lower on Monday with the Straits Times Index down 3.71 points to 3,110.54 at 9.08am, following an International Enterprise Singapore report showing a slide in non-electronics shipments dragging down overall non-oil domestic exports in July.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares fall after upbeat US economic data
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.8% against the dollar after upbeat US economic data bolstered prospects of a Federal Reserve rate hike next month. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) dropped 0.6%, with Samsung Electronics and Posco shares plummeting 2.7% and 2.9% respectively. Offshore investors sold local equities for the eighth straight session, worth 130.8 billion won. The dollar rose following US producer prices and industrial data output, increasing speculation of a rate hike next month.

site_title: Ringgit extends emerging-currency slump with oil as yuan steady
summary: Malaysia's ringgit slid 0.8% against the dollar, extending its worst week since 2011, amid concerns over a global oil glut. The currency's decline contributed to a fifth straight loss for the Bloomberg JPMorgan Asia Dollar Index. Meanwhile, US oil prices dropped 1.2% and China's yuan remained steady, fueling speculation that the US dollar will appreciate against other Asian currencies. This comes as investors await the Federal Reserve's first interest-rate increase since 2006, with a September hike now priced around a 50% probability.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.49%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.49% on Monday, following official data showing Japan's economy contracted at a slower rate than expected last quarter. The Nikkei 225 index rose 100.81 points to 20,620.26, while the Topix index added 0.51% to 1,672.87. The gains come after the slower-than-expected economic contraction, which may indicate a potential slowdown in the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks rose 0.49 per cent Monday, after official data showed Japan's economy contracted at a slower rate than expected last quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.19% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.19% in opening trade on Monday, driven by falling oil prices despite China's promise to support its stock market. The Hang Seng Index dropped 45.43 points to 23,945.6.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.40 per cent
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.40% higher on Monday, despite Japan's economy contracting 0.4% in the April-June quarter due to weak consumption and slowing exports. The Nikkei 225 index rose 81.90 points to 20,601.35 yen. Global markets were influenced by solid US data on wholesale prices and industrial production, which lifted the Dow Jones Industrial Average 0.41% on Friday.

site_title: No respite for ringgit as stocks slump adds to oil-related loss
summary: The Malaysian ringgit fell 0.9% to a 17-year low against the dollar due to speculation of further asset dumping amid a deteriorating political scandal involving Prime Minister Najib Razak. The currency's decline added to oil-related losses, as Brent crude prices continued to drop, putting pressure on the oil-exporting nation's finances. The benchmark stock index declined, poised for its lowest close since 2012, and bond risk rose, with 5-year credit-default swaps reaching a four-year high.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore's July NODX fuels concerns over Q3 GDP growth momentum
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 0.8% year-on-year in July 2015 to S$14.26 billion, driven by a decrease in non-electronics exports. The decline affects NODX to top 10 markets, except Hong Kong, South Korea, and Thailand. Economists forecast tepid sequential growth in NODX for the second half of 2015, with some predicting a 1-2% contraction in 2015 NODX growth. This may impact manufacturing output and energy-related exports, with some economists warning of new risks to petrochemicals and marine & offshore engineering.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Asia: Shares mixed after consensus-beating Japan GDP data
summary: Asian shares were mixed on Monday, with Tokyo rising 0.35% after Japan's GDP beat expectations, while Shanghai fell 0.65% despite a government pledge to support China's volatile markets. The US dollar strengthened after solid US data boosted expectations of a rate rise, putting pressure on oil prices. The dollar was quoted at 124.39 yen, up from 124.32 yen, and the euro slid to US$1.1096.

site_title: Thai Q2 GDP grows 0.4% q-o-q, beats forecasts but still tepid
summary: Thai Q2 GDP grew 0.4% q-o-q, beating forecasts but remaining tepid. This growth rate is slightly higher than expected but unlikely to boost optimism about Thailand's economic outlook. The economy has struggled since the military seized power in 2014, with exports contracting and domestic demand remaining subdued. The 2.8% growth from a year earlier is in line with forecasts, but the junta's inability to improve the economy remains a concern.

site_title: Japan's Q2 GDP shrinks annualised 1.6%, first slump since recession in 2014
summary: Japan's economy shrank at an annualised 1.6% in the April-June period, marking the first contraction since the 2014 recession. The decline was driven by weak exports and consumer spending. This follows a revised 4.5% expansion in the first quarter. On a quarterly basis, GDP contracted 0.4%, slightly beating economists' expectations of a 0.5% contraction.

site_title: Oil prices pulled down by shrinking Japanese economy
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as Japan's economy contracted, adding to concerns about a slowdown in Asia's largest economies. US crude traded at $42.07 per barrel and Brent futures at $48.69 per barrel, near six-year lows. Japan's economy shrank at an annualized pace of 1.6% in April-June due to falling exports and consumer spending. Global production remains near records, with OPEC expected to boost crude oil production to a record 33 million barrels per day after international sanctions are removed against Iran.

site_title: Qatar to launch major labour reform for migrant workers
summary: Qatar launches the Wage Protection System (WPS), a major labour reform aimed at ensuring migrant workers' timely wages. The new system requires companies to pay workers either twice a month or monthly, with electronic transfers to bank accounts. Failure to comply will result in fines, recruitment bans, and potential jail sentences. Rights groups, including Amnesty International, welcome the reform but express concerns about implementation and enforcement. The six-month grace period expires on August 18, with further reforms, including the scrapping of the "kafala" system, still needed to address long-standing labour practices issues.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 9.31 points to 1590.81. Losers outnumbered gainers 154 to 48, with a total trading volume of 52.3 million lots worth RM15.2 million.

images.alt_text: Malaysia share prices opened lower on Monday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 9.31 points to 1590.81.

site_title: Noble tumbles ahead of meeting with investors: Will it say enough?
summary: NOBLE Group shares fell 6% on Monday ahead of a meeting with investors, trading at S$0.46 per share. The company will present its interim results and PwC Assurance Opinion, but analysts expect it to provide limited information on specific transactions. A separate meeting with sell-side analysts was held earlier, with one analyst stating that Noble's stock price has dropped 16% over the past week, and the next catalyst will be an update on the approaches received by the company.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down on weak 2015 GDP forecast
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.6% on Monday after the government lowered its GDP growth forecast for 2015 to 1.56%, the lowest since 2009. The TAIEX index closed at 8,305.64, while the electronics subindex declined 0.9% and semiconductors fell 1.55%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.25 per US dollar. The decline was attributed to the weak economic outlook, affecting the sector's performance.

images.alt_text: Taiwan stocks fell on Monday after the government slashed its GDP growth outlook for the year.

site_title: Four killed as small planes collide in California
summary: Four people were killed in a collision between a twin-engine Sabreliner and a single-engine Cessna 172 near Brown Field Airport in San Diego, California. The aircraft crashed on Sunday, causing small brush fires, but no cause for the crash was known. Aviation authorities were investigating the incident.

images.alt_text: Four people were killed on Sunday when a pair of small aircraft collided in southern California near the Mexican border, US media reported.

site_title: Japan economy's Q2 contraction a blow for 'Abenomics'
summary: Japan's economy contracted 0.4% in Q2, its first decline in two quarters, due to weak domestic consumption and slow exports. The contraction, at an annualized 1.6%, was slightly better than expected, but still a blow to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" growth program. Private consumption fell 0.8% and exports dropped 4.4%, with sluggish wage growth and bad weather contributing to the downturn. The data forces the Bank of Japan to push back its inflation target timeline, and economists warn that the recovery may be short-lived.

site_title: China strengthens yuan rate against dollar by 0.01%
summary: China's central bank raised the value of the yuan against the US dollar by 0.01% to 6.3969 yuan per dollar, following a devaluation last week. The move is in line with China's strict currency controls, which allow the yuan to fluctuate by only 2% above or below the reference rate. The decision aims to stabilize the currency and support economic growth amid slowing GDP growth.

site_title: US flight delays linger after FAA computer failure
summary: US flight delays persisted after a computer failure at a regional air-traffic control center, with at least 2,250 flights delayed and over 150 canceled on Sunday. The issue, which affected airports in New York, Washington, and Charlotte, was resolved after a 3-hour delay on Saturday. The FAA attributed 492 delays and 476 cancellations to the malfunction, which was linked to a modernization system installed five months prior. The agency is working to resume normal air traffic operations and has not seen a reoccurrence of the issues.

site_title: Rescuers find 7 bodies after China landslide: Xinhua
summary: Rescuers in northwest China have found 7 bodies from a landslide that buried employee dormitories at a mining company in Shaanxi province. The landslide, which occurred on Wednesday, trapped at least 57 people, and search efforts were hindered by a massive volume of mud and rubble. The incident highlights China's struggles with worker safety in the coal mining sector, where accidents killed 931 people last year.

site_title: Loss-making Artivision ties up with Israeli ad agency McCann
summary: Artivision Technologies has signed a definitive and exclusive agreement with McCann Worldgroup, a leading Israeli advertising agency, to collaborate on programmatic video advertising. The deal may boost Artivision's top and bottom lines, with the potential to generate up to 27 million Israeli shekel in gross revenue over the next six to 18 months. This follows the signing of four other Israeli advertising agency contracts earlier this year, which Artivision expects to increase its consolidated net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Oil prices slide further in Asia
summary: Oil prices slid further in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling 63 cents to $41.87 a barrel and Brent crude down 65 cents to $48.54. The decline follows a global glut of crude supplies and sluggish demand. Oil prices had previously reached their lowest level in six and a half years on Friday. The decline in oil prices is attributed to bearish market sentiment due to the Trump administration's tariff outlook.

images.alt_text: Oil prices resumed their decline in Asia on Monday as a global glut of crude supplies showed no signs of abating in the face of sluggish demand, analysts said.

site_title: New Zealand services activity slips in July
summary: New Zealand's services sector growth slowed in July, with a seasonally adjusted performance of services index (PSI) easing to 56.5 from 58.1 in June. This indicates a contraction in activity, as a reading above 50 signifies expansion. Four of the PSI's five sub-indices fell, while the activity and sales sub-index rose slightly. This follows a similar decline in the manufacturing sector's activity in July, driven by weaker employment and new orders.

site_title: London finance vacancies rise 17%, pushing up pay, survey shows
summary: London's financial-services industry saw a 17% rise in job vacancies in July, with 10,920 openings, according to Morgan McKinley. Starting salaries increased by 22% on average, the largest rise in at least 12 months. UK banks are hiring in compliance functions while cutting jobs in investment banking and trading operations. This comes as total pay in the UK rose 2.4% annually in the second quarter, driven in part by the quieter months allowing employees to renegotiate compensation packages.

site_title: Election digest
summary: Singapore election updates: SPP and DPP are negotiating the terms of their partnership, with SPP chairman Lina Chiam suggesting three SPP candidates and DPP chief Benjamin Pwee encouraging openness on the number of candidates. NSP plans to directly employ staff for a town council if elected, while PPP's Goh Meng Seng invites Health Minister Gan Kim Yong to a healthcare debate. SDP vows a "good, clean campaign" for the elections.

site_title: Merkel defends tough line on Greece, hails will to reform
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel defended her government's tough stance on Greece, saying it spurred Athens to commit to necessary reforms. Merkel stated that the new rescue package, worth up to 86 billion euros, will help Greece "get back on its feet." She credited the package's approval to the intensity of pro-market reforms demanded by eurozone partners, including Germany. Merkel emphasized that further Greek measures are necessary for a successful bailout and vowed to work with MPs to convince them of her government's position. The rescue package is expected to be approved by the Bundestag on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports slide in July
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 0.8% in July, compared to a 4.5% increase in June. The contraction was broad, with all top 10 export markets except Hong Kong, South Korea, and Thailand seeing a decline. Shipments to Japan, Taiwan, and China saw the largest drops. This marks a reversal from the previous month's increase, highlighting a decline in the country's non-electronics exports.

site_title: mm2 Asia to acquire operations at two Cathay cineplexes in Malaysia
summary: mm2 Asia has signed a deal to acquire the business operations of two Cathay Cineplexes locations in Malaysia for RM40 million (S$13.8 million). The two locations, Cathay Cineplex Damansara and Cathay Cineplex City Square, operate a combined 30 screens. The acquisition is expected to be completed by September 30, 2015, and is expected to boost mm2 Asia's net profit and earnings per share. The deal aligns with the company's intention to diversify and expand into film production and cinema ownership.

site_title: Sale of last commodity asset ends 35-year chapter for Goldman
summary: Goldman Sachs has sold its nearly 35-year-old Colombian coal mine, marking the end of its commodity asset investments. This move is part of Wall Street banks' response to US regulators' pressure and poor returns from declining raw materials prices. The sale is the latest sign of the industry's shift away from commodity assets.

site_title: 'Name and shame' global firms avoiding Australian taxes
summary: Australian parliamentary inquiry chairman Sam Dastyari calls for "name and shame" of multinational companies shifting profits offshore to avoid paying Australian taxes. The inquiry's report, to be released Monday, recommends disclosure of tax avoidance settlements above A$100 million. Firms such as Apple and Google have denied using complex structures to reduce their tax burden. The push against tax avoidance is part of a global effort, with the OECD and UNCTAD also tackling the issue, which costs poorer countries an estimated US$100 billion annually.

site_title: Hedge funds boost energy holdings as oil rout brings opportunity
summary: Hedge funds are betting on energy companies that will survive the oil rout, with investments in Cheniere Energy, Pioneer Natural Resources, and Williams Cos. Despite a 60% drop in oil prices, some companies have good assets and are poised for a turnaround. Investors are seeking bargains as revenue falls and banks curtail credit access. Billionaires such as T Boone Pickens and Eric Mindich are adding stakes in energy firms, while others are reducing their positions. The hedge funds' moves suggest the start of a separation between winners and losers in the energy sector.

site_title: Stocks to watch: mm2 Asia, Olam, OUE, ST Engineering, United Engineers, Wheelock
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

mm2 Asia acquired Cathay Cineplexes' Malaysia business for RM40 million (S$13.8 million). Olam International's second-quarter earnings tripled to S$94.7 million, despite lower revenue. OUE Limited posted a net loss of S$16.28 million due to fair-value losses on a mutual fund investment. ST Engineering's net profit dropped 6.1% to S$125 million, while United Engineers saw a 57% decline in net profit to S$17.55 million. Wheelock Properties' net profit plummeted 85.3% to S$17.74 million. The acquisitions and earnings results may impact the performance of these companies in the coming months.

site_title: Rescuers head to crashed Indonesian plane: official
summary: Rescue teams are heading to the site of a crashed Indonesian plane that went missing with 54 people aboard. The ATR 42-300 twin-turboprop plane, operated by Trigana Air, lost contact with air traffic control before reaching its destination in Papua province. Villagers found the wreckage, with officials suspecting bad weather as the cause. The incident marks the 14th serious incident for Trigana Air, which operates domestic services in Indonesia.

site_title: Pebble Beach Concours culminates car-mania week
summary: The Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance has expanded into a week-long event featuring road rallies, races, auctions, and displays. The week includes various car-themed events, such as the Concours d'Lemons, which celebrates some of history's worst cars, and the Concours d'Elegance, where rare and luxurious cars compete for Best-in-Show honors. The event attracts thousands of car enthusiasts and collectors, with expected attendance of up to 25,000 and estimated spending of over $400 million. The event also benefits local charities and boosts the local economy.

images.alt_text: The wheel rim of a 1961 Ferrari SpA 250 GT SWB California Spider up for auction last Saturday.

site_title: Complexities of selling to Britain's health service big obstacle for startups
summary: Startups face significant obstacles in selling their digital health solutions to Britain's National Health Service (NHS), which controls virtually all medical spending. The NHS's bureaucracy and lack of a clear revenue model make it difficult for startups to penetrate the market. Venture capital investors have poured billions into digital health startups in the US, but the equivalent investment in Europe is significantly lower. The NHS is seeking innovation to cut costs, but its complex approval process and limited budget make it challenging for startups to succeed, with some companies struggling to secure funding and contracts.

site_title: Amazon's bruising, thrilling workplace works for some - but wears out many others
summary: Amazon's fast-paced and demanding work environment has led to high turnover rates, with some employees thriving under the pressure and others burning out. The company's culture, known as the "Amazon Way," emphasizes innovation and high standards, but also requires employees to work long hours and tear apart each other's ideas. To retain top talent, Amazon offers generous compensation and opportunities, but also expects employees to be willing to leave and make room for new recruits. The company's approach has been likened to "purposeful Darwinism," where only the most committed and innovative employees survive.

site_title: Luxury goods become bargains in Brazil as real plunges
summary: Luxury goods in Brazil have become cheaper due to the country's struggling economy, with the real's 24% drop against the dollar. Brands like Cartier, Louis Vuitton, and Prada offer significant discounts in Sao Paolo compared to New York, with some items costing up to US$1,000 less. However, these deals are expected to be short-lived as companies prepare to raise prices due to high import levies and sales taxes. The weaker real has made luxury goods more affordable for some Brazilians, but the economic downturn continues to affect the nation.

site_title: Equity markets already sagging prior to yuan devaluation jolt
summary: Global equity markets were already declining due to pricey valuations and investor caution before China's yuan devaluation, which provided a further jolt. A fund manager survey found that investors are overweight cash and hedging against a sharp fall in equity markets, with a net 44% of respondents overweight equities in August. Markets are now looking for an excuse to correct, with some strategists suggesting that cyclically adjusted price earnings (CAPE) ratios should be researched to assess which markets are undervalued or overvalued.

site_title: Brazilians rage against president, corruption
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff faces widespread protests and calls for her resignation, with crowds demanding an end to corruption and economic woes. The protests, the third major anti-Rousseff demonstration this year, drew hundreds of thousands of people across the country, with some blaming her and the leftist Workers' Party for the country's recession and embezzlement probe. Rousseff's approval ratings have plummeted, and impeachment proceedings are possible, with opposition leaders and Congress members considering the move.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators attend a protest against Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff, part of nationwide protests calling for her impeachment, at Paulista Avenue in Sao Paulo's financial centre, Brazil, on Aug 16, 2015

site_title: Canadian dollar following closely behind plunging oil prices
summary: The Canadian dollar has plummeted due to the recent oil crisis, as Canada is the fifth largest oil producer worldwide. The Canadian dollar's value closely correlates with oil prices, making it vulnerable to fluctuations. This has significantly impacted the Canadian economy, with experts warning of potential economic instability.

site_title: System glitch causes 'flypocalypse' at Washington, New York airports
summary: A major malfunction in the air traffic control system centered over Washington caused hundreds of flights to be delayed or cancelled nationwide on Saturday, stranding passengers. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) was unable to determine the cause of the problem, but it was fixed by 4pm. Airlines were left to sort out the scheduling issues, with some passengers facing delays or cancellations up to a day later. The FAA apologized for the inconvenience and worked to minimize the impact on travelers, but many passengers expressed frustration with the lack of communication and information.

site_title: Star Wars theme parks joining world of Disney
summary: Disney is expanding its Star Wars universe with two new theme parks, one in Orlando and one in Anaheim, adjacent to existing Disney venues. The parks will feature immersive experiences, including a battle between the First Order and the Resistance, and the chance to pilot the Millennium Falcon. The parks will also include staffed restaurants with wild creatures from the Star Wars saga. Disney CEO Bob Iger announced the plans after purchasing Lucasfilm for $4 billion, with new Star Wars films scheduled for release until 2019.

site_title: Guesswork continues on timing of US rate hike
summary: US stocks are expected to swing back and forth this week as traders wait for the Federal Reserve's July meeting minutes for clues on the timing of a September interest-rate hike. The Fed's decision is uncertain, with traders and investors weighing the impact on various industries, including retail, media, and the automotive sector, which are undergoing significant transformations. The uncertainty has led to a soap-operatic-like scenario, with odds on the timing of the hike changing by the hour.

site_title: Tough times for Russia's Gazprom as output slumps
summary: Russia's energy giant Gazprom is struggling due to a decline in gas production, increased competition, and tensions with Europe, prompting speculation of a potential breakup. The company's market capitalization has plummeted to around $50 billion, down from over $300 billion in 2008. Gazprom's recent loss of the Ukrainian market and Europe's energy diversification efforts have jeopardized its status as a gas giant, despite its $400 billion deal with China last year. The company's efforts to turn away from Europe are being undermined by Western sanctions and US technology restrictions.

site_title: Bond strategists pressed to earn their keep
summary: Bond strategists worldwide face pressure to generate income as investment houses strive to monetize research. With banks scaling back traditional bond dealing and electronic trading squeezing market middlemen, fixed-income strategists must now translate their work into income through trading commissions. Proposed EU rules requiring investors to pay for fixed-income research directly could further exacerbate the issue, prompting big asset managers to adopt a "best practices" approach and potentially globalize the changes.

site_title: Crisis response should be done with confidence
summary: A dynamic business environment with rapid information dissemination poses significant risks, particularly for small or obscure companies. Recent crises in Singapore's industries have highlighted the importance of having a crisis management framework in place. Companies must define a crisis, understand how risks can escalate, and develop reaction and response capabilities. Effective communication, transparency, and stakeholder engagement are critical to maintaining confidence and stabilizing operations. Boards should adopt a forward-looking approach, and companies must be prepared to respond quickly and positively to a crisis, even if it's low-probability.

site_title: Rising health insurance claims threaten all
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield Plan (IP) insurers face rising health insurance claims, threatening sustainability. Despite expected cost savings under MediShield Life, claims ratios have increased between 2012 and 2014. Insurers may not pass on savings to consumers, while hospitals benefit from higher bill sizes. To stop claims escalation, all stakeholders, including the government, consumers, and insurers, must pitch in. Increasing premiums is unsustainable, and the government must act firmly to address the issue before it gets out of hand.

site_title: Evaluating China after the crash
summary: China's equity market crash has limited direct economic fallout, with officials attributing the crisis to the small number of households participating in the market and the short duration of the rally. The diminished credibility of policymakers is the most significant consequence, as officials were seen as cheerleaders for the rise in share prices and struggled to put a floor under share prices. The government will likely persist with intervention, delaying financial liberalization and reforms aimed at giving the market a "decisive" role. Further stimulus measures are expected to ease credit conditions, but their effectiveness is uncertain due to structural factors such as the decline in the working-age population and lower productivity growth in the services sector.

site_title: Chinese companies face culture shock in foreign markets
summary: Chinese companies are facing culture shock as they expand into foreign markets, particularly in democracies, due to unfamiliar trade unions, independent courts, and public opinion. Despite China's outward investment reaching $103 billion in 2014, experts say it's a sign of weakness, as the country struggles to adjust to stricter regulations and environmental laws abroad. Costly mistakes include damage claims in the US over toxic drywall and lawsuits in Poland over environmental compliance. Chinese companies are learning to navigate unfamiliar waters, but the process is often marked by costly miscalculations and cultural differences.

site_title: Biosensing tools link physiological data to business performance
summary: Biosensing tools are being used to link physiological data to business performance, particularly in high-stakes industries like finance. Companies like hedge funds, banks, and consultancies are installing tracking systems that use wearable devices to monitor heart rate, stress levels, and other metrics. This data is then analyzed to identify patterns that can inform decision-making and improve performance. While some companies are open about their experiments, others are keeping it private to avoid accusations of intrusive behavior. Experts believe this technology has the potential to revolutionize the way businesses operate, but also raises concerns about privacy and morale.

site_title: Starbucks sets its own course in pricing
summary: Starbucks has raised prices for brewed coffee in its stores, despite a global decline in coffee prices, due to rising costs and a desire to maintain profitability. The company, known for its premium experience, has raised prices by 5-20 cents per cup, with the average customer bill increasing by 1%. Starbucks' financial strategy includes hedging and advance purchase agreements to mitigate commodity price fluctuations, allowing it to maintain its pricing strategy. The company's stock has performed well, returning 5.4% since the price increase, while the broader coffee market has fallen 44% since October.

site_title: Beat downturn with homework, fundamentals
summary: Investors are often too cautious during economic downturns, missing out on companies with strong fundamentals, said Roger Montgomery. Companies with growth prospects become cheaper due to people forgetting the fundamentals. Montgomery cited Apple, Essilor, and Qualcomm as undervalued stocks. Independent economist Song Seng Wun advised investors to be selective and do their homework, focusing on fundamentals rather than panic. He also warned about the risks of the Malaysian ringgit falling sharply, but noted that some Malaysian companies are still doing well.

site_title: IMF, the missing piece in Greek debt deal
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has become a key player in the Greek debt deal, pushing for European creditor nations to provide debt relief in order for it to provide cash towards the next Greek bailout. The IMF's chief, Christine Lagarde, stated that Greece's debt has become unsustainable and that the country cannot restore debt sustainability solely through its own actions. The IMF wants Europe to provide significant debt relief, but the latest bailout agreement does not address this issue, instead focusing on austerity measures. This move has sparked criticism, with many economists arguing that the IMF should have made this demand sooner.

site_title: PAP introduces new face in Chua Chu Kang
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled its lineup for the Chua Chu Kang Group Representation Constituency (GRC), featuring Health Minister Gan Kim Yong, Zaqy Mohamad, Low Yen Ling, and new candidate Yee Chia Hsing, who replaces Alvin Yeo. Yee aims to bring a different perspective to decision-making, focusing on grassroots concerns and encouraging volunteering. The team aims to make Chua Chu Kang a "connected community" through improvements in public transport, community spaces, and inter-generational bonding programs.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
(From left) Alvin Yeo, who will be stepping down; new candidate Yee Chia Hsing, currently head of Catalist at CIMB Bank Singapore; Health Minister Gan Kim Yong; Low Yen Ling; and Zaqy Mohamad.

site_title: Market pressure eases but no cause for optimism
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 7.5% for the year, with market pressure easing but no cause for optimism. A surprise yuan devaluation by China's authorities has added weight to the view that the index will remain within a trading range with a downward bias. The US Federal Reserve may delay raising interest rates due to the weak US consumer and the impact of the yuan devaluation on global trade.

site_title: Water park sparks controversy in parched California
summary: Dublin, California is building a $44 million water park amidst the state's worst drought in over a decade, sparking controversy. Conceived over a decade ago, the project was initially met with excitement but now faces opposition due to its water consumption. Officials claim the park will be small and serve only a few residents, but critics argue it sends a wrong message and will be unusable during the drought. The project, expected to open in 2017, has been funded primarily through fees on property developers, with the city contributing $3 million.

site_title: Higher claims, new player could squeeze insurer returns on Integrated Shield Plans
summary: Underwriting profits from Integrated Shield Plans (IP) in Singapore may narrow further due to significantly higher claims and the potential entry of a new player. Only two IP insurers, AIA Singapore and Prudential Singapore, recorded profits every year from 2010 to 2014, with AIA's IP profit increasing to S$142 million in 2014. The industry's profit margin has shrunk, and claims ratio has increased, with the addition of a new player expected to further squeeze insurer returns.

site_title: The next 50 years
summary: Singaporeans are yearning for a brighter future as the country marks its 50th anniversary. Experts weigh in on the key issues of focus for the 2015 National Day Rally, including maintaining the nation's unique culture, adapting to technological advancements, enabling creative talent to flourish, and fostering stable relations with neighboring countries. The business community emphasizes the need for a new vision and strategy to create growth catalysts for the economy, while the government must balance the need for innovation with the challenge of attracting foreign workers and immigrants.

site_title: Growing Singapore physically
summary: Belgian company Dredging, Environmental and Marine Engineering (DEME) has played a key role in Singapore's growth since the 1990s, reclaiming land for industrial use and deepening channels for ships. DEME's local subsidiary, Dredging International Asia Pacific (DIAP), has won significant contracts, including the S$1 billion westward extension of Jurong Island and a S$2.4 billion deal for the Tuas Terminal. The company prioritizes sustainability, using locally sourced material and reducing reliance on imported sand. With a reputation for quality workmanship and a history of over 170 years, DEME faces technical challenges and must balance environmental concerns with economic needs.

site_title: Ringgit volatility tests bond investors' faith in M'sia
summary: Foreign investors in Malaysia's bond markets remain heavily invested despite months of economic and political uncertainty. The ringgit's volatility is testing their faith, with the currency down 14% against the dollar this year. Foreign fund managers hold nearly half of outstanding government bonds, worth RM206.8 billion, and are cautious about further currency volatility. The central bank has sold dollars to support the currency, but analysts believe investors will be concerned about declining reserves and rising hedging costs if the situation worsens.

site_title: Arab Bank settles lawsuit accusing it of supporting terrorism
summary: Arab Bank has settled a lawsuit accusing it of supporting terrorism, three days before a damages trial was set to start. Hundreds of American plaintiffs, including victims of terrorist attacks around Israel, had filed a lawsuit against the bank. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed. The agreement brings an end to a lawsuit that had been pending for years.

site_title: PAP team counting on experience in fight for revived Jalan Besar GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) is fielding a team of experienced MPs in the revived Jalan Besar Group Representation Constituency (GRC), with a combined 60 years of political experience. The team, led by Communications and Information Minister Dr Yaacob Ibrahim, includes veteran MPs Heng Chee How, Denise Phua, and Lily Neo. The PAP team has announced plans to implement 200 improvement projects worth S$20 million over the next five years, and is expected to face off against a Workers' Party (WP) team in the upcoming general election.

images.alt_text: The PAP team at the Kolam Ayer ABC Waterfront. From left: Mr Heng, Edwin Tong who may be redeployed to Marine Parade, Dr Lily Neo, Dr Yaacob and Ms Denise Phua.

site_title: Low oil prices pose threat to Texas fracking bonanza
summary: Low oil prices are posing a significant threat to the Texas fracking industry, particularly in Karnes County, which has seen a surge in oil production in recent years. The price of oil has plummeted to under $45 a barrel, leading to a sharp decline in production and revenue for oil companies and local businesses. Many workers are being laid off, and some have been forced to abandon their recreational vehicle parks and homes. The decline in oil prices is also affecting local tax revenues, with the county tax base dropping by over 20% this year.

images.alt_text: Today, even with the price of oil plummeting, no county in Texas comes close to producing as much crude as Karnes County - 6.8 million barrels in June alone. Twenty rigs operated by giants such as ConocoPhillips, EOG Resources and Murphy Oil continue to churn through hard rock thousands of feet below ground.

site_title: Drug-related offences, overdoses surge in US from 'fake weed'
summary: The US has seen a surge in drug-related offenses and overdoses linked to synthetic marijuana, also known as "fake weed," primarily imported from China. Since this year began, poison control centers have received over 5,200 calls related to the substance, a significant increase from the 3,680 calls in 2014. The addictive and potentially lethal high of synthetic marijuana derives from chemical compounds designed to mimic THC, and its potency can be up to 100 times that of real marijuana.

site_title: European fare that appeals to the local palate
summary: The Disgruntled Chef, Daniel Sia, has revamped his upscale restaurant, The Club, in Ann Siang Road, offering a modern European menu that appeals to the local palate. The restaurant features a French-inspired menu of hearty "small" and "big" plates, with dishes such as grilled eel and foie gras roulade, crispy beef short rib, and chocolate croquette. While the service can be lacking, the food is a success, with a focus on toning down acidity and salt to create a sweeter taste profile. The restaurant has received a rating of 7.5, indicating a "good to very good" dining experience.

site_title: Tianjin death toll rising with scores of firefighters missing
summary: China's Tianjin port has seen a death toll rise to 112, with 95 people, mostly firefighters, missing after massive explosions on Wednesday. Over 720 people remain hospitalized, and 6,300 have been displaced. Officials acknowledge toxins, including sodium cyanide, but claim they pose no risk to people outside the evacuation zone. A fire broke out again at the blast site, prompting further evacuations. Greenpeace urges authorities to conduct a comprehensive survey of hazardous chemicals and make public information.

site_title: Hollywood using bigger screens to tell sophisticated stories
summary: Hollywood is preparing for a spectacular film season with a wave of sophisticated, adult-oriented movies shown in 3D or large-screen formats. Theaters are experiencing higher seasonal ticket sales, and studios aim to attract more adults, particularly in the US. Films like "Everest," "The Walk," and "The Martian" will be released in Imax and premium formats, potentially leading to a significant shift in viewing habits. The industry sees potential for transformation if mature viewers flock to these event films, commanding premium ticket prices and expanding revenue for companies involved.

site_title: Innovate to stay ahead of the curve: top executives
summary: Singaporean companies must adapt and innovate to stay ahead in the next 50 years, according to top executives. To achieve this, they must be nimble, open to change, and responsive to customers' needs. Developing a deeper and broader value proposition is also crucial. Meanwhile, in unrelated news, Singapore stocks have rallied for a 5-day period ahead of GDP data, and OCBC has named Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing Helen Wong.

site_title: Director buying surges, selling stays low
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Buyback activity surged on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) during the holiday-shortened week of August 11-14, with 20 companies making 40 purchases worth S$3.1 million. The buys were sharply up from the previous week's totals. Notable purchases included Nam Cheong Limited, PACC Offshore Services, KSH Holdings, Wilmar International, Sarine Technologies, and insider buys in Frencken Group and Super Group. The buyback activity was also seen in other companies such as FIL Ltd and Mondrian Investment Partners Ltd, with their stakes increasing by 55% and 81% respectively.

site_title: Efforts to preserve artist Henry Varnum Poor's house stall
summary: The historic Crow House, built by artist Henry Varnum Poor in 1920, is in disrepair due to lack of maintenance and funding. The town of Ramapo purchased the property for $1.3 million in 2007 with a grant from the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation. However, seven years later, the house's condition has deteriorated, and its contents, including artworks and furniture, are at risk of being sold. The town's preservation efforts have stalled, and the house's admirers fear it may "die of neglect" if repairs are not made.

site_title: Yuan could go 'either way' if central bank moves in future, says PBOC
summary: China's central bank chief economist Ma Jun says the yuan may move in both directions in the future following its devaluation, as the economy stabilizes. A more market-oriented pricing mechanism will help prevent excessive swings and allow for a more natural fluctuation in the currency. The economy is expected to grow around 7% this year, and the central bank will intervene only when volatility is excessive. China has no intention of participating in a currency war and the future economic recovery will come from domestic consumption, Ma stated.

site_title: Brazil homebuilder MRV reports 32% profit rise
summary: Brazil's largest low-income homebuilder, MRV Engenharia e Participações SA, reported a 32.2% increase in second-quarter profit to 188 million reais (S$75.9 million). Despite an economic slowdown, the company's gross margin rose to 29.2% due to better cost controls. Contracted sales decreased 5.6% and cancellations rose to 29.8% of total sales. MRV's co-CEO, Rafael Menin, stated that the company will maintain a conservative financial position due to economic uncertainties.

site_title: Indonesia aircraft with 54 people crashes in Papua province
summary: Indonesia's Trigana aircraft with 54 people on board crashed in Papua province on Sunday. The aircraft, which lost contact earlier, was found at Camp 3 in the Bintang Mountains regency. Residents reported the plane crashed into Tangok mountain. This incident is the latest in a string of aviation disasters in Indonesia, highlighting concerns over air safety in the country.

site_title: Senior police officer Melvin Yong to replace Lui at Moulmein ward
summary: Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew introduced senior police officer Melvin Yong as the People's Action Party (PAP) candidate for the Moulmein ward, replacing Lui, who is leaving politics after serving the ward since 2006. Melvin Yong will contest in the upcoming general election.

site_title: Corruption eating away at India 'like a termite': Modi
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi warned that corruption is eating away at the country like a termite, stating it must be eradicated from the top down. Despite no allegations of embezzlement under his government, Modi acknowledged work remains to be done. The issue has been exacerbated by corruption scandals involving senior BJP figures, including Foreign Minister Sushma Swaraj and state chief ministers. Modi pledged a corruption-free India, citing his government's efforts to tackle the problem over the past 15 months.

site_title: EZchip rallies on prospects it'll be eating Cisco's lunch
summary: EZchip Semiconductor Ltd shares have rallied 22% after beating earnings estimates and securing cloud data centre deals, fueling hopes that it may not need Cisco as a customer. The company's processors for edge routers in cable and phone networks can now be sold directly to data-centre or telecommunications customers, bypassing intermediaries like Cisco. Analysts see this as a new market expansion opportunity, despite Cisco's SDN solutions seeing 200% year-over-year growth, and most remain cautious on EZchip's prospects.

site_title: PAP team for Chua Chu Kang GRC announced; Alvin Yeo to retire
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its team for the Chua Chu Kang Group Representation Constituency (GRC), with banking executive Yee Chia Hsing joining the team. MP Alvin Yeo will retire from politics, while Alex Yam will move to Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC. The PAP team will compete against the People's Power Party (PPP) in the upcoming elections.

site_title: Elizabeth will become Britain's longest-reigning monarch on Sept 9
summary: Queen Elizabeth will become Britain's longest-reigning monarch on September 9, surpassing her great-great-grandmother Queen Victoria's record of over 63 years. The 89-year-old monarch has led the institution into a new era of popularity despite challenges, including the death of Princess Diana in 1997. She has maintained stability and provided a sense of identity for Britons, with over 250 overseas visits and meeting four million people in person during her reign. With no prospect of abdication, Elizabeth will become the world's oldest living monarch, solidifying her legacy as a constant figure in British history.

site_title: Gaming fans resurrect 80's hit ZX Spectrum
summary: A crowdfunding campaign backed by the inventor of the ZX Spectrum, a 1980s gaming console, successfully raised £100,000 to revive the classic console. The new ZX Vega replicates the original's design and features 1,000 retro games stored in its memory. The campaign's success is attributed to the nostalgia of gamers from the 1980s who want to relive their childhood experience, as well as the simplicity of the games compared to modern consoles. The revival is part of a broader trend of retro gaming, with several companies, including Elite Systems, also announcing plans to revive the ZX Spectrum.

site_title: Nepal's 'ghost schools' hide large-scale corruption
summary: Nepal's anti-corruption watchdog has uncovered over 300 "ghost schools" funded by the government and international donors, despite the schools never opening. The schools were meant for local children but were allegedly used to embezzle funds, with losses estimated at around $1.6 million. The scandal highlights widespread corruption in Nepal's education system, which has led to poor quality education and low enrollment rates. The government has filed court cases against officials and teachers involved, but critics say more needs to be done to address the issue and ensure transparency in education funding.

site_title: PBOC chief economist says yuan may move both ways
summary: China's yuan may move both ways in the future following its recent devaluation, according to Ma Jun, chief economist at the People's Bank of China. The economy is expected to grow about 7% this year, and a more market-oriented pricing mechanism will help stabilize the currency. The central bank has exited regular intervention, and will act when market volatility is excessive. This move aims to balance financial stability with a desire for stronger exports and the yuan's inclusion in the International Monetary Fund's basket of reserve currencies.

site_title: All 7 WP MPs staying put to defend seats
summary: Seven Workers' Party (WP) Members of Parliament (MPs) will defend their seats at the upcoming general election, including Pritam Singh, Muhamad Faisal Abdul Manap, and Png Eng Huat. The WP is likely to field Shamsul Kamar, K Muralidharan Pillai, Victor Lye, Chua Eng Leong, and Chan Hui Yuh for Aljunied GRC. The party's chairman, Sylvia Lim, emphasized the importance of maintaining the Aljunied team intact to seek a new mandate and continue its work in the constituency.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Modi sets 1,000-day deadline to power up India villages
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi set a 1,000-day deadline for all villages to be connected to the national grid, aiming to combat poverty. Despite 69 years of independence, 18,500 villages remain without electricity. Modi's government has already enabled 170 million people to open bank accounts, and he emphasized the importance of empowering the poor to drive development. The move follows his commitment to financial inclusion, with Modi stating that strengthening the base of the pyramid is crucial for overall development.

site_title: Efforts to cool housing have paid off, says Khaw
summary: National Development Minister Khaw Boon Wan stated that efforts to rebalance the Singapore property market have paid off, achieving a fairer balance between buyers and sellers. This comes after four years of efforts to address the imbalance, which had been a major concern in the 2011 general election. Khaw expressed relief at the recent price drops, which he attributed to a "soft landing" for the housing market, allowing all players to make adjustments. However, he noted that conditions could change due to Singapore's small economy's connection to the global market.

site_title: George Soros sells off most of his Alibaba stocks
summary: George Soros's fund has sold most of its Alibaba stake, with nearly 60,000 shares remaining. The sale follows a significant drop in Alibaba's value, which has lost 37% since its initial public offering. The fund initially held 4.4 million shares valued at $370 million but reduced its stake to just 93,494 shares. This move comes as Alibaba's quarterly results showed a slower-than-expected sales growth, disappointing Wall Street. The company remains a major player in the e-commerce industry, but faces competition from Amazon.

site_title: IDA accreditation gives Singapore startups a boost
summary: Singapore's Accreditation@IDA scheme has given eight startups a boost, creating $20 million in government project opportunities and enhancing their credibility and access to large corporations. The scheme, launched in 2014, streamlines the government procurement process, giving accredited companies priority. Since its inception, the program has lined up 125 projects from 50 government agencies. Participating startups report increased confidence and access to new markets, with some already working with prominent agencies like the Singapore Economic Development Board and National Library Board. The program aims to support young companies with great ideas and promote innovation in government services.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lee, founder of Green Koncepts. If Accreditation@IDA could be represented by a hashtag (or two), #SupportLocal or #BuySingapore would be it.

site_title: Prices track China's currency action
summary: China's currency devaluation has led to a fresh blow to oil and base metal prices, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate reaching a 6.5-year low of $41.35 a barrel. Gold and precious metals, however, rose as investors sought safe-haven assets amid concerns over China's economic outlook. The International Energy Agency forecast a prolonged oversupply, while the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries refused to cut output, contributing to the prolonged oversupply and falling oil prices.

images.alt_text: Oil and base metal prices, already hit by oversupply and sagging demand, suffered a fresh blow last week as China shocked markets by devaluing its currency.

site_title: All 7 WP MPs to defend their seats at GE: Sylvia Lim
summary: Seven Workers' Party (WP) members will defend their seats at the upcoming general election, including Sylvia Lim, Low Thia Khiang, and Pritam Singh. The WP's Aljunied GRC team, which won the seat in 2011, will remain unchanged, while Hougang and Punggol East single seat wards will see the WP MPs, Png Eng Huat and Lee Li Lian, retain their seats. The ruling PAP has announced its candidates, including Lee Hong Chuang for Hougang and Charles Chong for Punggol East.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Lim Hng Kiang, Iswaran to lead PAP team in West Coast GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its team for the West Coast Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in the upcoming General Election. Lim Hng Kiang, Foo Mee Har, S Iswaran, and Patrick Tay will form the four-member team. Tay moves from Nee Soon GRC, while Lawrence Wong joins PAP's team for Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC.

site_title: Germany praises Greek stance shift in debt talks
summary: Germany's finance minister Wolfgang Schaeuble praised a shift in Greece's stance in debt talks, calling it "responsible" and "in keeping with commitments". The agreement reached among eurozone finance ministers includes reforms for a third rescue package, worth 86 billion euros. Germany will closely monitor the pace of reforms, ruling out debt writedowns. The package's approval is expected to pass in Germany's parliament, with Chancellor Angela Merkel's governing coalition holding 504 out of 631 seats.

site_title: Plane with 54 on board crashes in remote Indonesian region
summary: A Trigana Air Services twin-turboprop plane with 54 people on board, including 44 adults, 5 crew, and 5 children and infants, crashed in Indonesia's Papua region on Sunday. The aircraft lost contact with air traffic control while flying over a forested area, and efforts to locate it were hindered by failing light and bad weather. No immediate word on survivors has been given, and the cause of the crash is yet to be determined.

site_title: Euro ministers give blessing to Greek bailout, wooing IMF on debt
summary: Eurozone finance ministers agreed to lend Greece up to 86 billion euros, with 13 billion euros to be disbursed next Thursday to pay pressing bills and 10 billion euros set aside at the European Stability Mechanism to bolster Greek banks. The 26 billion euro first tranche of the bailout is contingent on Greek lawmakers' approval of stiff conditions. The move aims to address Greece's debt crisis, with eurozone governments reviewing compliance in October.

site_title: Death toll from Tianjin blasts rises to 85: Xinhua
summary: The death toll from the Tianjin blasts has risen to 85, according to Xinhua. Two huge explosions occurred in an industrial area on Wednesday, causing shockwaves felt by residents in nearby apartment blocks. China defended its firefighters who initially hosed down a chemical warehouse blaze, a response that foreign experts say may have contributed to the explosions.

site_title: 'Beggar thy neighbour' devaluations unlikely: analysts
summary: Veteran financial analyst Jesper Koll believes China's yuan devaluation is unlikely to mark the start of a series of competitive currency devaluations in Asia, contrary to market reaction. Koll notes that the move is a response to real economic forces, aimed at slowing China's economy rather than sparking a currency war. Analyst Kenneth Courtis also disagrees with market hysteria, stating that China's goal remains to elevate the yuan as a trusted reserve currency. However, Koll warns that the devaluation could lead to increased capital outflows if domestic households and institutions perceive rising economic uncertainty.

site_title: Hedge funds take fresh look at General Motors in Q2
summary: Several prominent hedge fund managers, including David Einhorn's Greenlight Capital and Leon Cooperman's Omega Advisors, increased their stakes in General Motors during Q2, despite the company's ongoing struggles with a deadly ignition defect. Einhorn bought 7.9 million shares, while Cooperman's firm added 1.8 million. Other notable investors, including David Tepper's Appaloosa Management and Taconic Capital Advisors, also increased their stakes. The increased investment comes after GM approved a $5 billion stock buyback plan.

site_title: PAP unveils line-up for PM Lee's Ang Mo Kio GRC team; as well as candidates for Sengkang West and Hougang
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its lineup for the upcoming Singapore General Election, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's Ang Mo Kio GRC team and candidates for Sengkang West and Hougang. New additions to the Ang Mo Kio GRC team include Darryl David, a deputy director at Temasek Polytechnic's School of Design, and colorectal surgeon Koh Poh Koon. The PAP also announced IT manager Lee Hong Chuang as its candidate for Hougang SMC. The lineup is part of the party's preparations for the upcoming election.

site_title: Diesel power
summary: The Porsche Macan S Diesel boasts excellent low-end torque and relatively low fuel consumption and emissions compared to its petrol-powered counterpart. With a 3.0-litre V6 turbodiesel engine, it consumes up to 6.3 litres of fuel per 100km and emits up to 159g of carbon dioxide per km. This makes it an attractive option for those seeking a balance of power and economy, despite being priced similarly to the petrol-powered model. The diesel engine's advantages make it a compelling choice for drivers seeking a more efficient and environmentally friendly driving experience.

site_title: Beware 'Third World town councils': Goh
summary: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong warned Singaporean voters against applying different standards of integrity to the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) and opposition parties, stating that this could lead to "Third World town councils" in opposition wards.
