site_title: Eurozone growth slows to 0.3% in Q2 from 0.4% in Q1
summary: The eurozone's growth slowed to 0.3% in Q2, below analyst forecasts of 0.3-0.4%. This marks a slight decrease from the 0.4% growth in Q1, continuing a modest recovery. Despite a European Central Bank stimulus program, inflation and unemployment have remained little changed. The data suggests the eurozone's economic recovery is fragile, and policymakers may face pressure to address concerns about slowing growth.

site_title: Swiber's Q2 earnings fall 81.3%
summary: Swiber Holdings reported a 81.3% decline in pre-tax profit to S$2.21 million and an 8.7% drop in revenue to US$200.2 million in its Q2 FY2015 earnings. Revenue for the first six months fell 12.8% to US$365.1 million, with a net loss of US$3.1 million. The company's net asset value per share decreased to 62.1 US cents, down from 90.6 US cents in the previous year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 0.37% on China unease
summary: Tokyo stocks declined 0.37% on Friday due to concerns over China's economic outlook. The Nikkei 225 fell 76.10 points to 20,519.45, while the Topix index declined 0.21% to 1,664.46. The decline comes ahead of expected downbeat Japanese GDP figures next week.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas says operations won't cover 2015 dividend, capex demands
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil firm Petronas reported a 47% decline in net profit to 11.1 billion ringgit in April-June due to weak crude oil prices and lower sales. To cope, Petronas will draw on reserves and implement further cost savings. The firm aims to meet its 26 billion ringgit dividend promise to the government despite a 10% reduction. Petronas has also received agreements from four of five groups to proceed with the Pacific NorthWest liquefied natural gas project in British Columbia, despite opposition from Canadian aboriginal groups.

site_title: MAS may have more reason to tweak policy after yuan's drop: poll
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), may consider adjusting monetary policy settings following China's surprise devaluation of the yuan. A Reuters poll of 11 analysts found that six believe the yuan's drop could add to the case for MAS to tweak its policy. However, none shifted their views toward monetary easing solely due to the yuan devaluation. The MAS is expected to assess the impact of the yuan's drop on the Singapore dollar and make a decision on its policy settings.

site_title: China's yuan posts biggest weekly loss on record
summary: China's yuan posted its largest weekly loss on record, falling 2.9% for the week, due to the central bank's surprise move to devalue its currency. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.3975 per dollar, firmer than the previous day's closing quote. The yuan had repeatedly touched fresh four-year lows since Tuesday's surprise devaluation by nearly 2%. Analysts predict further volatility and a possible yuan rate of 6.4-6.5 by the end of the year.

site_title: Europe: Shares set for biggest weekly fall in 6 weeks
summary: European stocks are set for their biggest weekly loss in six weeks, down 2.8% from the previous week, following China's decision to devalue its currency. The FTSEurofirst 300 index remained steady on Friday, closing flat at 1530.30 points. Oil and gas firms dropped 0.5% after US crude oil fell below $42 a barrel, not seen since 2009. The rebound from the previous session was partly due to China's central bank reassuring investors about the country's strong economic fundamentals.

site_title: Hong Kong Q2 GDP steady, govt revises up 2015 growth forecast
summary: Hong Kong's economy grew 2.8% in Q2, steady from Q1, driven by private consumption. The government revised up its 2015 growth forecast, citing no impact from weak tourism and China's slowdown. This marks a 0.4% increase from Q1 and a 0.7% increase from Q2 last year. The revised forecast now suggests a 3.1% growth for 2015.

site_title: China's yuan devaluation to pressure commodities: Goldman
summary: China's yuan devaluation signals worsening global economic conditions, putting downward pressure on commodity markets. Goldman Sachs believes the devaluation will lead to bearish effects on the net commodity market, with aluminum and steel prices facing significant downward pressure. A weaker yuan could improve margins for Chinese commodity exporters, but the trade-weighted yuan remaining flat suggests limited competitiveness improvement for the export-led manufacturing sector. China's domestic policy support, particularly fiscal and monetary support, remains crucial to commodity markets.

site_title: PAP reveals Sembawang GRC line-up, includes former Aljunied GRC candidate Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's ruling party, the PAP, has announced its lineup for the Sembawang GRC, including former Aljunied GRC candidate Ong Ye Kung, who will make his second attempt at getting into Parliament. Ong will be joined by newcomer Amrin Amin, a corporate lawyer. This move is seen as a strategic shift by the PAP, aiming to appeal to a broader range of voters.

site_title: Singapore: Shares close mixed on Friday; STI rises amid a weak broad market
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 22.47 points on Friday to 3,114.25, trimming the week's loss to 82 points or 2.6%. The index was boosted by short-covering, but the broad market remained weak, with 195 rises versus 241 falls. Banks and Singtel were major contributors to the STI's movements, with Noble Group and PSC also in focus due to their latest financial releases. The week's gains were despite fears of a currency war and global equity selling sparked by China's yuan devaluation announcement.

site_title: German economy grows by 0.4% in second quarter: data
summary: Germany's economy grew by 0.4% in the second quarter of 2015, slightly short of analyst expectations. This growth, from April to June, was driven by foreign trade, with exports increasing strongly due to the weak euro. Consumer spending and government spending also contributed to the growth, but weak investment hindered it. On a 12-month basis, GDP growth was 1.6%, up from 1.2% in the first quarter.

site_title: Malaysia media group The Edge loses bid to lift printing ban
summary: Malaysia's High Court dismissed a media group's bid to lift a three-month publishing ban imposed by the government in response to investigative reports on alleged financial irregularities linked to Prime Minister Najib's 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB). The Edge Media Group had been suspended due to reports threatening "public order" with allegations of fraud, mismanagement, and misappropriation of funds. A full judicial review is set for September 7. Najib and 1MDB deny any wrongdoing, with the government calling the transfers "donations" from unidentified overseas sources.

site_title: Wilmar buybacks fail to stem stock's biggest drop in 15 months
summary: Wilmar International Ltd, a palm oil trader, failed to stem its stock's biggest weekly decline in 15 months despite conducting three stock buybacks in three days. The company accumulated 0.08% of its shares outstanding for S$15.2 million, but the stock still fell 4.7% this week. The decline was attributed to a surprise devaluation of the Chinese currency, which lowered the price of raw materials. The stock fell 0.7% to S$3.03, extending its decline this year to 6.5%.

site_title: Gold price spike keeps Asian buyers at bay
summary: Asian buyers of gold, particularly in China and India, remained cautious due to a surge in prices, which spiked over 5% in China. Despite a three-week high of $1,126 an ounce, gold prices fell as the yuan firmed after China's central bank stated there was no need for further devaluation. Physical premiums in China and India remained steady, while retail jewellery demand in India was muted due to the spike in prices.

site_title: Indonesia's Q2 current account deficit at 2.05% of GDP: BI
summary: Indonesia's current account deficit widened to 2.05% of GDP in the second quarter, reaching US$4.48 billion, from 1.92% in the previous quarter. The deficit is lower than the 3.97% recorded in the same period last year, driven by improvements in the trade balance. A US$2.5 billion surplus in the financial and capital account helped narrow the overall balance of payments to a deficit of US$2.93 billion.

site_title: China securities regulator says market forces to play bigger role
summary: China's securities regulator announced that market forces will play a bigger role in determining stock prices as the market gradually shifts back to normal conditions. The China Securities Regulatory Commission stated that state margin lender China Securities Finance Corp's role in stabilizing the market won't change for the next few years. This move aims to promote market efficiency and reduce government intervention in the stock market.

site_title: Shanghai: Shares produce largest weekly rise in 2 months
summary: Shanghai's benchmark stock index rose 0.3% on Friday, its largest weekly gain in over two months, as investors became more bullish after concerns about the yuan's depreciation eased. The Shanghai Composite Index increased 5.9% for the week, while the CSI300 index of the largest listed companies in Shanghai and Shenzhen rose 4.3%. The yuan held steady against the dollar after suspected intervention by the central bank. Waigaoqiao FTZ surged 10% and state-owned companies like Luoyang Glass and Guangdong Electric Power saw price increases due to reform expectations.

site_title: Retail sales in June up 6.9% on double-digit surge in motor vehicle sales
summary: Retail sales in Singapore rose 6.9% year-over-year in June, driven by a 85.2% surge in motor vehicle sales. Excluding motor vehicle sales, sales actually fell 3% year-over-year. The Department of Statistics reported these figures in a recent release.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.15% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.15% in early trading on Friday, driven by dealers weighing the impact of China's yuan devaluation and the timing of a US interest rate rise. The Hang Seng Index added 36.22 points to 24,055.02.

site_title: Japan car makers, retailers report minor damage from blasts at China port
summary: Japanese automakers Toyota, Subaru, Mazda, and shipping giant Nippon Yusen reported minor damage from two explosions at the Tianjin port in China. The blasts killed at least 50 people and injured about 700, with some vehicles and facilities affected. Toyota said damage was minimal, while Subaru reported over 100 cars damaged. Mazda noted peeling paint and scratches on its vehicles. Other Japanese companies, including retailers, also reported damage, with some facilities closed due to safety concerns.

site_title: Indonesia presents 2016 budget plan, sees GDP growth of 5.5%
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo unveiled a 2016 budget plan with a 5.5% GDP growth assumption, below the revised 2015 budget's 5.7% but above the current government outlook of 5.0-5.2%. The budget also assumes a stronger rupiah exchange rate at 13,400 per dollar. Infrastructure construction and improved exports are expected to drive investment and consumption growth, despite a weaker-than-expected global economic outlook.

site_title: China to launch nationwide inspection of dangerous chemicals after Tianjin blasts
summary: China will conduct a nationwide inspection of dangerous chemicals and explosives following two deadly blasts in Tianjin that killed at least 50 people. The State Council aims to crack down on illegal activities and strengthen industry safety. This move is seen as a response to the blasts and a lesson learned by the government. The inspection will focus on improving safety standards and preventing similar incidents in the future.

site_title: Ringgit hits new record low of 2.9109 to Singdollar
summary: Malaysia's ringgit reached a new record low of 2.9109 against the Singapore dollar on August 14, 2015, after slumping to a fresh 17-year low versus the US dollar. The fall in oil prices and concerns over exports led to the currency's decline. The ringgit's weakest point since September 1, 1998, was recorded at 4.1180 per dollar.

site_title: Asia: Shares gain as dealers eye dollar, yuan
summary: Asian markets gained in early trade on Friday as dealers weighed the impact of China's yuan devaluation and US interest rate rise expectations. The dollar traded sideways after solid US retail figures fueled hopes of a rate hike. Hong Kong and Shanghai rose, while China's central bank calmed markets with a rate increase. Dealers expect a September rate hike from the Federal Reserve, which may cap share market gains.

site_title: Greek government secures votes to pass bailout in parliament
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's government secured parliamentary approval for a new bailout agreement, crossing the 151-vote threshold with opposition support. The vote came after an all-night parliamentary session, with lawmakers arguing over procedure ahead of euro zone minister approval and disbursement of aid. The deal paves the way for a debt payment next week, following a deepening rift within Tsipras's ruling Syriza party.

site_title: French GDP stagnates in Q2, misses expectations
summary: French GDP stagnated in Q2, missing expectations of 0.2% growth. The economy grew 0.7% in Q1, with inventories weighing down consumer spending. Exports, however, rose 1.7% in Q2, driven by corporate investment growth. French Finance Minister Michel Sapin remains confident in the government's 1% annual GDP growth estimate for the year.

site_title: China's yuan flat after suspected PBOC intervention
summary: China's yuan remained steady against the dollar on Friday after suspected intervention by the People's Bank of China to curb expectations of a depreciation cycle. The yuan's midpoint rate was set at 6.3975 per dollar, 0.03% above the previous close. The spot market traded within a 2% range above the official fixing, after the currency fell for three consecutive days to fresh four-year lows. This move aims to stabilize the market and manage exchange rate volatility.

site_title: Australia: Shares close down for second week after hitting 6-month low
summary: Australian shares fell 0.58% on Friday, closing at a 6-month low, as gold and energy stocks plummeted. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 31.368 points to 5356.500, marking its second straight week of losses. Global oil prices fell sharply, contributing to the energy sector's near 10-year low.

site_title: Australia: Shares up as investors breathe sigh of relief over yuan
summary: Australian shares rose 0.12% on Friday, stabilizing after the yuan devaluation shock, but still on track for a 1.3% weekly loss. The People's Bank of China reassured investors that the yuan's decline was justified by China's strong economic fundamentals. The S&P/ASX 200 index edged up 6.732 points to 5394.600, with the benchmark poised to end the week 1.3% lower.

site_title: Dollar struggles in Asia after lift from US retail sales
summary: The US dollar traded sideways in Asia after a solid retail sales report boosted expectations of a possible Federal Reserve rate hike as early as next month. The report showed US retail sales rose 0.6% in July, beating analyst projections. China's central bank reassured markets by setting its rate marginally higher against the dollar, easing concerns over a sharp yuan devaluation. The dollar traded at 124.42 yen, nearly flat from its US trading value, while the euro ticked up to $1.1155.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.74 points to 1,624.36 on Friday, with volume reaching 29.61 million lots worth RM9.17 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 69 to 68, indicating a positive market trend.

site_title: Nine banks agree to pay US$2b to settle forex rigging suit
summary: Nine major banks, including Bank of America, Barclays, and UBS, have agreed to pay over $2 billion to settle a foreign-exchange rigging lawsuit. The settlements, which are preliminary and require approval from a US District Judge, involve investors who claim the banks manipulated exchange rates. The law firm Hausfeld, representing investors, did not disclose how the sum would be divided among the banks. The agreements are part of a broader effort to resolve foreign-exchange rigging claims, with similar settlements reached by other banks in the past.

site_title: Singapore July exports seen shrinking on weak global demand: Reuters poll
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports in July are expected to contract 2.1% from a year earlier, hurt by weak global demand and reduced factory activity. On a seasonally adjusted basis, exports are forecast to fall 0.8% from June. This contraction follows a stronger-than-expected 4.7% annual growth in June. The slowdown is attributed to slow economic growth in China and other countries.

site_title: Oil prices head for seventh weekly fall
summary: Oil prices are poised for their seventh weekly decline, with US crude falling to a six-year low of $42.06 per barrel. Brent crude also eased to $49.20 per barrel. Investors fear a global supply glut will persist, driving down prices. This is the lowest price for US crude since March 2009. The decline is attributed to a bearish outlook on Trump's tariffs, which has impacted investor confidence.

site_title: IMF urges Spain to keep reform focus ahead of elections
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged Spain to maintain its economic reform focus ahead of a year-end general election. The IMF warned that reversing reforms would create uncertainty and damage the recovery, particularly if external conditions worsen. Spain is benefiting from a weaker euro, which boosts exports and lowers oil prices, but the IMF cautioned that backtracking on reforms could expose the country to external contagions. The IMF's chief in Spain, Helge Berger, emphasized the importance of staying the course on reforms to defend against external risks and generate growth.

site_title: China's regulators told to promote transparency, reduce complexity
summary: China's regulators face criticism from the Financial Stability Board to improve coordination, transparency, and risk management in the financial system. The global watchdog recommends clarifying roles, sharing information, and reducing complexity to prevent policy measures from contradicting each other. This comes as China's policymakers attempt to stabilize the stock market, which has seen a 24% decline since mid-June due to poorly coordinated regulatory responses. The FSB report notes that China is not alone in having regulatory coordination problems and that improvements have been made since the last review in 2011.

site_title: Gold slips as yuan firms, but still set to snap 7-week losing run
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.1% to $1,113.15 an ounce, ending a seven-week losing streak, as China's yuan firmed, calming global markets. The yuan devaluation earlier this week had pushed investors into safe-haven assets, but China's central bank stated there was no reason for the currency to fall further, easing concerns. US retail sales rebounded, renewing hopes for a near-term interest rate hike, which could impact gold prices. Despite the drop, gold has gained 2% for the week.

site_title: India's economic reform agenda hits roadblocks
summary: India's economic reform agenda has stalled due to opposition blockades in parliament, hindering Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to attract foreign investment and revive the economy. The main opposition Congress party has blocked key tax and land reforms, while a plan to overhaul labor laws has yet to be unveiled. Analysts warn that Modi risks failing to deliver on his promises, citing concerns over the stalled bills and the need for clarity on reforms.

site_title: Greek lawmakers debate third bailout deal
summary: Greek lawmakers are set to vote on the terms of the country's third international bailout, with a deal expected to unlock a first tranche of aid. The 85-billion-euro rescue plan has split the ruling Syriza party, with some hardliners opposing the agreement. Germany has expressed caution, requesting further clarifications before giving the deal the nod. A vote is expected to take place shortly after 7am local time, with Greece hoping to avoid a payment default by securing emergency funding.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.37% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.37% lower on Friday, awaiting European and Japanese economic data releases. The Nikkei 225 index fell 77.19 points to 20,518.36. Eurozone GDP figures are set for release, while Japan's three-month GDP will be announced Monday. Worries over China eased as the country reassured markets about the yuan. The dollar fetched 124.41 yen, while the euro traded at US$1.1155 and 138.81 yen.

site_title: Safety fears over Chinese chemical blasts
summary: Residents near the Tianjin port, where explosions killed 50 and injured over 700, are concerned about safety due to the presence of hundreds of tonnes of hazardous chemicals, including sodium cyanide. Officials have not yet identified the materials or cause of the blast. Poisonous chemical cyanide was detected in sewage samples in the area, raising fears for nearby residents. The site's storage facility remains unclear, with officials stating they do not know what materials were at the site or the cause of the blast.

site_title: Japan Post US$11b triple IPO expected on Nov 4: sources
summary: Japan Post Holdings Co is expected to list shares in its holding company and bank and insurance units on Nov 4, in Japan's largest state-owned enterprise sale in nearly three decades. The government aims to sell at least 1.3 trillion yen (S$15.4 billion) worth of shares to fund reconstruction from the 2011 earthquake and tsunami disaster. This is the first tranche of a three-part sale aiming to raise around 4 trillion yen in coming years.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks inch higher; Ta Chong Bank, HTC rally
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 0.12% to 8,321.90, driven by a 10% surge in Ta Chong Bank and a 1.4% gain in HTC. The financial subindex increased 1.4% and the electronics subindex fell 0.6%. HTC announced plans to cut 15% of its workforce and reduce operating expenses by 35%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.134 per US dollar.

site_title: Samsung ramps up Apple challenge with large handsets
summary: Samsung unveiled two large-screen handsets, the Galaxy S6 edge+ and Galaxy Note5, as part of its challenge to Apple in the high-end smartphone market. The devices aim to counter Apple's large-screen iPhone 6 and 6-Plus, as well as its tap-to-pay feature. Samsung also introduced its new mobile payment system. The move is part of the company's effort to maintain its lead in the global smartphone market.

images.alt_text: South Korean technology company Samsung is filing a petition to the US Supreme Court in its long-running patent infringement case against Apple, according to court documents.

site_title: Rents for private apartments, condos, HDB flats down in July: SRX
summary: Rentals for private apartments, condos, and HDB flats in Singapore decreased in July, with a 0.3% month-on-month fall in rents in Core Central Region and a 0.4% dip in Core Central Region's suburbs. The overall rental index for non-landed private homes is down 5.7% year on year and 12.5% compared to its peak in January 2013. Leasing deals for non-landed private homes increased 7.3% year on year, while HDB rents fell 0.7% year on year, with executive flats seeing a 0.5% rental appreciation.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: China: Shanghai shares up 0.55% in morning trade
summary: Shanghai shares rose 0.55% in morning trade, following China's yuan currency fix, which strengthened against the US dollar after three days of falls. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 21.85 points to 3,976.41, while the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.77% to 2,316.48. This marks a positive start to the day for Chinese stocks, which were previously impacted by currency fluctuations.

site_title: US: Stocks little changed on mixed signs in retail
summary: US stocks ended unchanged on Thursday, despite mixed retail sales data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 5.74 points. Retail sales rose 0.6% in July, beating expectations, but department stores Kohl's and Dillard's reported lower-than-expected earnings. Cisco Systems and News Corp also saw gains, while Advance Auto Parts surged 9.2%. Bond prices fell, with the 10-year Treasury yield rising to 2.18%.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher again on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 12.39 points higher on Friday, up 0.4% to 3,104.17, following a 5-day rally. This comes after China's yuan devaluation on Tuesday and Wednesday, which led to a 30.29-point drop. Top gainers included DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank. The market showed resilience despite US tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views, with 78.7 million shares worth S$72 million changing hands by 9:03 am.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China fixes yuan stronger vs dollar, reversing falls
summary: China's central bank has raised the yuan currency against the US dollar by 0.05%, reversing three days of falls, to 6.3975 yuan to US$1.0. The move comes after the People's Bank of China reassured markets that it will seek a stable currency. The change is attributed to a more market-oriented method of calculating the daily reference rate, which will now take into account the previous day's close, foreign exchange supply and demand, and major currency rates. The currency is still subject to a 2% fluctuation limit.

site_title: Corporate taxes to be major agenda item when US Congress returns
summary: US Congress will focus on corporate tax reform when it returns in September, with lawmakers aiming to reduce the high tax rate paid by C corporations. The tax-writing Ways and Means Committee plans to consider proposals such as tax breaks on foreign profits and intellectual property. The shift in focus reflects the influence of C corporations' well-paid lobbyists and the relatively small but significant contribution to federal tax revenues they make. The debate is expected to be contentious, with Democrats and Republicans disagreeing on the extent of tax cuts.

site_title: SGX cautions over CEFC trading on buying by small number of offshore accounts
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has cautioned investors to exercise caution when dealing in the shares of CEFC International Limited due to a large number of offshore accounts buying the company's shares. CEFC announced a share placement of 705 million shares at S$0.35 each, citing a potential joint venture and related funding. This follows a public query by SGX, which issued a Trade with Caution warning after CEFC's response on July 21.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: ST Engineering reports 6% slide in Q2 profit
summary: ST Engineering reported a 6.1% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$125 million for the second quarter, driven by lower finance income and a 27% drop in marine sector revenue. Revenue fell 2.6% to S$1.55 billion, with earnings per share down 4.01 Singapore cents from 4.28 cents a year ago. The decline was attributed to lower shipbuilding and engineering revenue.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Ezion posts 36% drop in Q2 profit
summary: Ezion Holdings reported a 36.3% drop in Q2 profit to US$28.96 million, primarily due to lower revenue and higher cost of sales and servicing. Revenue fell 2.8% to US$90.05 million, with the marine and offshore logistics support services division contributing no revenue. The company attributed the decline to a challenging oil and gas sector environment, with oil majors reducing spending on exploration. For the six-month period, profit declined 23% year-over-year to US$69.97 million.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Oil prices fall on supply glut
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday, with Brent crude dipping 61 cents to $49.05 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate dropping $1.07 to $42.23 a barrel. The decline comes amid an oversupplied market and bearish outlooks from traders, including those related to US President Trump's tariff policies.

site_title: Bank of America investors to vote on CEO/Chair split
summary: Bank of America announced it will hold a special meeting in September for shareholders to vote on splitting the roles of CEO and chairman, a decision previously promised within two years. The move comes after some shareholders pressed for the separation of the two posts. Brian Moynihan has held both roles since last fall. The vote is expected to take place in September, with the outcome uncertain.

site_title: Pardoned Korean tycoon apologises, vows to reform
summary: South Korean conglomerate head Chey Tae-Won, chairman of SK Group, apologized and vowed to reform after being pardoned and released from jail, marking the 70th anniversary of Japan's colonial rule over Korea. Chey, serving his second jail term for multi-million dollar fraud, had previously been released after just seven months and granted a full presidential pardon in 2008. The pardon, part of President Park Geun Hye's second amnesty list, sparked criticism of the president's efforts to reform South Korea's powerful family-run conglomerates.

site_title: Google gets third extension to answer EU case
summary: Google has been given a third extension by the European Commission to respond to an anti-trust case alleging abuse of its search engine market dominance. The two-week extension, which brings the deadline to August 31, follows previous extensions in April and July. The US tech giant initially had 10 weeks to respond after the European Commission lodged the case in mid-April.

site_title: Still heating up the dance floor
summary: Brandon Rubendall and Jenna Rubaii will headline the revamped Broadway production of Saturday Night Fever in Singapore this September at the MasterCard Theatres in Marina Bay Sands. The actors, who have traveled extensively, expressed their gratitude for the opportunity to perform and see the world while doing what they love. Rubendall, who has credits including Spiderman on Broadway, called being paid for his passion "nothing better."

site_title: No reports of S'poreans being injured
summary: Singaporeans near the Tianjin blasts were contacted by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, with 79 registered individuals checked. As of 10am, all were found to be safe. The blasts in China killed 44 people and injured over 500. The Singaporean government expressed condolences to the victims' families and offered consular assistance to affected individuals. The Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City Investment and Development Co confirmed all employees were accounted for, with one sustaining minor injuries.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Otto Marine sinks into the red for Q2
summary: Otto Marine reported a net loss of US$2.72 million for the second quarter, down from a US$16.86 million profit a year ago, due to lower revenue and higher finance costs. Revenue fell 36.4% to US$71.22 million, while loss per share was 0.06 US cents. The company attributed the decline to a challenging oil and gas market, but noted improved vessel utilization rates and plans to strengthen its order book and cost structure. The company warned that market conditions in the marine sector are unlikely to improve significantly in the next year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, Ezion, Genting Singapore, Metro
summary: Olam International reported a 197.6% increase in net profit to S$94.7 million for the three months ended June, driven by a strategy to grow in prioritized platforms while reducing volumes. Ezion Holdings saw a 36.3% decline in net profit to US$28.96 million due to lower revenue and higher costs. Genting Singapore reported a second-quarter net loss of S$16.9 million, affected by a weakening gaming business in Asia. Metro Holdings' net profit more than tripled to S$37.6 million, driven by improved contributions from associates and joint ventures.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Dollar edges up on solid US retail sales report
summary: The US dollar rose modestly against major currencies following a solid retail sales report, with July sales increasing 0.6% to $446.5 billion. Analysts expect this to boost expectations for a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. Market sentiment remains volatile due to concerns about China's slowing economy and depreciating currency, but the dollar's gains offset losses from the previous day.

site_title: APP to 'retire' 7,000ha of plantations to help Jakarta cut emissions
summary: Asia Pulp & Paper (APP) will "retire" 7,000 hectares of commercial plantations in Indonesia to protect carbon-rich peatlands, helping the Indonesian government meet its 26% greenhouse-gas emissions target by 2020. The move, the first of its kind worldwide, is part of APP's commitment to peatland management and follows a self-imposed moratorium on natural forests and new peatland development since 2013. A free and prior informed consent process will be conducted for the affected areas, and remote sensing technology will be used to minimize the impact of peat landscape drainage.

site_title: Seoul: Financial markets closed on Friday
summary: Financial markets in Seoul closed on Friday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. In other news, eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion. The US stock market edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, and traders are brushing off new Trump threats. European markets were boosted by mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Talent spotting through music series
summary: Support for local music is at an all-time high, with festivals and series showcasing homegrown bands. Veteran musician-producer Kevin Mathews is curating two music series, Original Sing and StageFright, to promote budding singer-songwriters. He attributes the growth to a new generation of music lovers and improved musicianship due to music schools. The series have been well-received, with no repeated featured artists and consistently new talent emerging. Mathews stresses the importance of artists promoting themselves to get noticed, citing a successful example of promoting a fresh Sam Willows' first show.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Japan machinery orders down sharply in June
summary: Japan's core machinery orders plummeted 7.9% in June, the largest decline in over a year, amid fears of an economic contraction in the second quarter. This follows soft indicators, including exports and factory output, and has raised doubts about the economic outlook. Policymakers expect the economy to stay on track for moderate growth in the current quarter, but weak data may prompt calls for fresh stimulus. Companies forecast a 0.3% rise in core machinery orders for July-September, down from a 2.9% increase in April-June.

site_title: Greek economy grew 0.8% in Q2, averted recession in Q1: official
summary: Greek economy expanded by 0.8% in Q2, narrowly avoiding recession in Q1, according to the national statistics agency. This growth, however, was largely due to falling prices, and real GDP shrank 0.7% in the second quarter. Analysts say the figures "flatter" the economy, which is still under pressure from capital controls and debt. The European Union forecasts Greece's economy will shrink 2.3% in 2015 and 1.3% in 2016, and a new bailout deal is set to be voted on by Greece's parliament.

images.alt_text: A customer browses a display of shoes for sale beneath a Greek national flag outside a store in Thessaloniki, Greece, on Aug. 11, 2015.

site_title: Modi keeping India on right growth track
summary: India's economic growth remains on track under Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government, despite short-term concerns. Modi has prioritized long-term structural changes, such as cutting rural subsidies and recapitalizing state-run banks, to achieve sustainable growth. The government has also made significant progress in implementing key reforms, including the Goods and Service Tax bill and land acquisition bill. However, concerns about inflation and interest rates persist, and earnings growth remains sluggish. The article concludes that India's economic growth has been compressed, but opportunities for investment exist in quality companies and nascent industries.

site_title: OUE H-Trust posts 7.3% dip in Q2 DPS
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust reported a 7.3% year-on-year drop in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for Q2 2015, reaching 1.52 cents. Despite a 5.1% growth in net property income from its hospitality segment, driven by the newly acquired Crowne Plaza Changi Airport, retail mall Mandarin Gallery's net property income contracted 5.4% due to lower occupancy and fit-out periods. CEO Chong Kee Hiong expects a stronger second half but remains cautious about macroeconomic uncertainties.

site_title: Malaysia's ringgit tumbles to weakest since 1998 as oil retreats
summary: Malaysia's ringgit dropped 1.4% to its weakest level since 1998, extending an eighth week of declines due to falling oil prices and political turmoil. Capital outflows, fueled by foreign funds dumping about $3 billion of the nation's shares this year, have contributed to the decline. The country's export-dependent economy is threatened by a rout in commodity prices and China's yuan devaluation. Despite a 4.9% rise in gross domestic product in the three months through June, the ringgit's decline raises concerns about the nation's economic stability.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's ringgit tumbled to the weakest level since 1998, extending an eighth week of declines as falling oil prices and political turmoil spur capital outflows.

site_title: Global gold demand slides to 6-year low in second quarter: WGC
summary: Global gold demand slumped to a 6-year low in the second quarter, falling 12% to 914.9 tonnes, driven by sluggish prices and a shift to equities. China's gold demand dropped 3% and India's jewellery consumption fell 23%, while investment demand slid 11% and central bank buying declined 13%. Despite this, the World Gold Council expects global demand to reach 4,200-4,300 tonnes in the full year, citing a potential boost from a weaker Chinese yuan.

site_title: Olam's Q2 net profit nearly triples
summary: Olam International reported a net profit of S$94.7 million for Q2 2025, a 197.6% increase from the previous year. Sales fell 16.4% to S$4.8 billion, following a strategy to grow in prioritized platforms and reduce lower-margin businesses. The company declared a dividend of 2.5 cents per share, driven by the transformational acquisitions of McCleskey Mills and ADM's cocoa business, which are expected to contribute to earnings.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Olam International reported on Friday that its net profit for the three months to end June rose 197.6 per cent from a year ago to S$94.7 million.

site_title: China investigates cause of blasts at Tianjin port, firms assess damage
summary: Two explosions at a warehouse in Tianjin, China, on Wednesday killed at least 50 people, including 12 firefighters, and injured 700. The blasts, which occurred about 30 seconds apart, were caused by the storage of toxic chemicals, including ammonium nitrate. Foreign companies, including Toyota and Renault, reported damage to their facilities, while thousands of cars were torched and port buildings reduced to rubble. The owner of the warehouse, Tianjin Dongjiang Port Ruihai International Logistics, was found to have violated packaging standards during a safety inspection two years prior. President Xi Jinping vowed that those responsible would be "severely handled".

images.alt_text: Investigators searched for clues on Friday to identify what caused two huge explosions at a warehouse used to store toxic chemicals and gas at a busy port in northeast China, as foreign and local companies assessed the damage to their operations.

site_title: New addition to Israeli soldier's battlefield weaponry - iPad
summary: During Israel's 7-week Gaza Strip war, iPads played a critical role in battlefield operations, allowing company commanders to access real-time information about militant movements and friendly forces. The mobile wireless device integrated all branches of Israel's armed services, enabling coordinated responses to threats. The system, which has been applied beyond security, also facilitated communication between Israeli surgeons and specialists during a field hospital in Nepal. However, the network faced challenges, including slow speeds and intelligence gaps, and has led to efforts to strengthen cyber defense, including reorganizing cyber units under one command.

site_title: Inspired by tales from the maritime industry
summary: Arts Fission's latest production, "The Mazu Chronicle: Crossing the Maritime Silk Road," is a dance group's exploration of the maritime industry through the stories of six senior citizens who worked on ships. The production, presented in collaboration with The Philharmonic Orchestra, features interviews with veterans who share their experiences, including those from Singapore's early settlers and those who worked on ships during World War II. The piece blends history, mythology, and everyday movement to create a unique narrative framework, with more than 20 elderly performers and 20 dancers on stage.

site_title: Poorer debt outlook adds to Noble's woes
summary: Noble Group's debt outlook has been downgraded by Moody's due to its higher leverage and lower interest coverage, raising concerns over the company's liquidity position and strategic options. The downgrade warns that Noble's current Baa3 rating could be lowered if it fails to improve its liquidity over the next two quarters or if its gearing level continues to rise. This could lead to higher borrowing costs and limit Noble's ability to fund large purchases, affecting its commodity trading business.

site_title: Swimming upstream
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts' commission, "Returning," is an ambitious work featuring eight choreographers, two dozen dancers, and a score of musicians. The piece, centered on the life of a salmon, showcases the strengths of individual choreographers but struggles to integrate their unique sensibilities into a seamless whole. Despite the incongruity, the music, led by Julian Wong, successfully incorporates diverse instruments from Indian, Malay, Chinese, and Western traditions. "Returning" runs at the Drama Centre Theatre until August 15.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Nestle's half-year sales worse than forecast
summary: Nestle reported slightly worse-than-expected half-year sales, falling 0.3% to 42.84 billion Swiss francs, due to a recall of its Maggi noodles in India. Net profit fell 2.5% to 4.52 billion francs. The company attributed its sales decline to slowing economies and cautious consumer spending, particularly in China and the US. Despite this, Nestle maintained its annual sales growth forecast of around 5%, citing organic growth of 4.5% in the first half.

site_title: Meursault - the other white burgundy
summary: A wine enthusiast, Francois Gautier, invited a group of friends to a dinner at Osteria Art in Singapore to share his recently acquired Meursault Perrieres 1990 and Puligny Combettes 1985 and 1990. Meursault, a white burgundy, has a distinctively savory element in its taste profile, almost salty. The dinner featured a wine list including Gran Siècle NV, Laurent Perrier.

site_title: Big Chinese tankers help US export ethane
summary: US shale boom exports ethane to Europe via large Chinese tankers. Sinopacific unveiled a 180-meter-long "dragon-class" tanker to carry ethane from American shale fields to Norway and Scotland for processing into plastics. Low ethane prices, driven by US oversupply, have prompted overseas chemical makers to benefit, with more export facilities and ships to follow, including 48 very large ethane carriers by 2017.

site_title: Tender for two more Dempsey blocks for F&B, retail use
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) and the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) have jointly announced a tender to develop Blocks 17 and 18 Dempsey Road for food and beverage (F&B) and retail use. The tender aims to strengthen Tanglin Village's lifestyle cluster and encourage unique lifestyle concepts. The two blocks within the former army barrack will be developed for F&B and retail use, enhancing the village's position as a unique lifestyle enclave.

site_title: Romantic comedy with an unusual premise
summary: The Singapore Repertory Theatre (SRT) will present a British romantic comedy, "Hello, Goodbye," from September 2-26. The play, written by Peter Souter, tells the story of Alex and Juliet, who are forced to room together and sparks fly as they navigate their relationship. Directed by Lisa Spirling, the intimate play explores modern sensibilities and chemistry between the cast. Tickets range from $15 to $60 and are available from Sistic.com, offering a pleasant counterpoint to local theatre fatigue.

site_title: IMF awaits steps from Europe on Greek debt relief
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is waiting for European partners to decide on a debt relief package for Greece before determining its participation in the country's next bailout. IMF official Delia Velculescu stated that the IMF will assess its participation once the steps on the rescue plan and debt relief have been taken. Greek lawmakers are set to vote on an 85-billion-euro rescue plan, which includes debt relief, with major creditor Germany expressing concerns about the deal.

site_title: Lenovo to cut 3,200 jobs as Motorola handset sales slide
summary: Lenovo plans to cut 3,200 non-manufacturing jobs, approximately 10% of its white-collar staff, due to declining Motorola handset sales and a 31% drop in quarterly shipments. The move is expected to yield $1.35 billion in annual savings. Despite this, Lenovo's CEO remains optimistic about the brand's potential, citing its ambition to rival Apple and Samsung in the smartphone market. The company's quarterly net profit was halved to $105 million, and shares slid nearly 9% following the announcement.

site_title: Alibaba posts slowest sales growth in 3 years
summary: Alibaba Group Holding reported its slowest sales growth in at least three years, with shares falling 5.1% in New York trading. The company's new CEO, Daniel Zhang, faces the challenge of regaining investor confidence, particularly as the Chinese economy cools. Despite this, the company posted strong growth in international commerce revenue, climbing 19%, and mobile transactions more than doubling. Alibaba has also announced an agreement with Macy's Inc to open an exclusive online store on Tmall. The company plans to buy back up to $4 billion of its shares over two years to prop up its beleaguered stock.

site_title: UK rule to speed up shale projects
summary: The UK government has given its communities minister the power to directly approve shale gas permits, bypassing local politicians who have previously blocked such projects. This move aims to speed up the planning process for shale gas projects, which have been delayed due to opposition from local residents and environmental campaigners. The decision also prioritizes appeals on shale gas projects and presents proposals to create a sovereign wealth fund from returns generated from shale gas production. Pro-business groups have welcomed the move, while environmental groups have expressed concerns about local community involvement.

site_title: Abe can usher in new era of Asian ties with message of reconciliation
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to deliver a statement on the 70th anniversary of World War II, aiming to promote Asian ties and reconciliation. However, he faces a delicate balance between appeasing nationalist lobbies at home and meeting the expectations of China, South Korea, and Southeast Asia. Abe needs to convey remorse for Japan's past military actions while navigating the complexities of domestic revisionism. His speech will be closely watched by Asian leaders, who are seeking reassurance from Japan's commitment to historical accountability.

site_title: July retail sales see broad-based gain as consumers spur growth
summary: US retail sales rose 0.6% in July, beating economists' forecasts, driven by growing demand for cars and clothing. The gain followed a revised 0.3% drop in June. Strong employment, cheaper fuel, and rising household spending are fueling consumer growth, which is expected to boost the economy. The Commerce Department report also showed a decline in imported goods and a surge in car sales, with General Motors and Ford Motor Co benefiting from the trend.

site_title: UK trains delinquents as homebuilders face worker shortage
summary: The UK construction industry faces a severe worker shortage, with nearly 1 million builders needed within the next 10 years to meet increasing demand for new homes. To address this, companies like Berkeley Group Holdings and Persimmon plc are implementing innovative recruitment strategies, such as the Street Elite programme, which uses sports coaching to prepare young people for work. The shortage is expected to impact economic growth and housing starts, with subcontractor availability already declining for the 25th consecutive month.

site_title: SIA ends talks on equity investment in Jeju Air
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has ended talks to invest in South Korea's budget carrier Jeju Air, almost five months after initial discussions. The decision not to proceed with the investment comes as SIA expands in Australia, Thailand, and India to tap into growing market shares in Southeast Asia. SIA's CEO did not specify why the talks were cancelled, while Jeju Air decided not to consider the proposal. This move marks a setback for SIA's efforts to build alliances outside Singapore, which is part of its multihub strategy.

site_title: Growth in users driving messaging apps valuations
summary: Messaging apps are attracting high valuations due to growing user bases. WeChat, a 600 million-user app, is valued at US$83.6 billion, while Facebook paid US$18 billion for WhatsApp and Snapchat was valued at US$16 billion. Despite low income generation, these services are seen as building blocks for an ecosystem of e-commerce, transport, and advertising. Experts attribute the growth to people spending more time sending short messages, making messaging apps an attractive technology investment. This trend is driving valuations for other messaging apps, such as Facebook's Messenger and Skype.

site_title: ECB ready to tweak QE if needed
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is prepared to adjust its quantitative-easing (QE) program in response to market turbulence, driven by "unusually low" inflation and "disappointing" economic growth in the euro area. The central bank emphasized its readiness to adapt its asset-purchase programs if necessary, citing sufficient flexibility in their design. This move comes as the ECB continues to monitor the economic outlook, with continued elevated uncertainty calling for alertness.

site_title: Aftershocks of yuan drop may dent Asian economies: analysts
summary: China's yuan devaluation could dent several North Asian economies, including Hong Kong, Taiwan, Korea, Thailand, and Malaysia, due to cheaper exports, slower tourism, and decreased global commodity prices. Analysts warn that these economies may weaken their currencies to cope, but risk further rate cuts and potential overshooting. A 10% yuan depreciation could lead to slower global GDP growth and a hit to countries relying on Chinese demand, with potential losses of 3-4% in GDP for Korea and Hong Kong, and nearly 2% for Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Cheaper Chinese exports, a slowdown in Chinese tourism and further softness in global commodities in the wake of the yuan devaluation could put a dent in several North Asian economies plus Thailand and Malaysia, which may be tempted to weaken their own currencies to cope, analysts said on Thursday while flagging risks of further rate cuts in Thailand and Korea later this year.

site_title: Takata banks on rivals to fix faulty air bags
summary: Takata Corp, the company behind a record vehicle safety recall, is relying on three competitors - Autoliv Inc, Daicel Corp, and ZF TRW Automotive - to produce 68% of the replacement air bag inflators needed by March. This shift reduces Takata's dependence on the automakers it supplies. Over 40 million vehicles have been recalled worldwide due to faulty inflators linked to eight deaths and 130 injuries. Honda, Fiat Chrysler, and Toyota are shifting to alternative suppliers, while TRW and Autoliv are increasing production to meet demand.

site_title: Investment Technology to pay record fine for dark pool violations
summary: Investment Technology Group Inc (ITG) agreed to pay a record fine of $20.3 million for operating a secret trading desk in its dark pool, which misused client order information for its own benefit. The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) found that ITG leveraged data from other users to trade ahead of client orders, violating securities laws. This is the largest fine for dark pool violations. ITG admitted wrongdoing and agreed to the settlement.

images.alt_text: The problem, according to the SEC, is Project Omega had an advantage over all other users of ITG's Posit dark pool: It knew about the trades customers wanted to place.

site_title: Boeing sees no slowdown in demand for its jetliners
summary: Boeing reports strong demand for civilian aircraft, with CFO Greg Smith stating there's no slowdown in demand. Despite concerns over slowing growth in China, airlines from various countries are buying new planes to replace old ones, providing confidence in the current cycle. Boeing is focusing on reducing 787 production costs, with stable 10-per-month production helping find cost savings. The company expects the 787 to turn cash-flow positive by the end of the year and plans to increase cash flow as it reduces losses on the program.

site_title: Fundamental changes needed to stay competitive in ICT sector
summary: Singapore's Infocomm and Media 2025 (IMM) roadmap aims to transform the country into an innovative society by leveraging ICT over the next 10 years. The roadmap builds on past infocomm masterplans, focusing on building infrastructure, talent, and computational thinking. It recommends customized manpower development programs, inculcating computational thinking in primary schools, and improving teaching through technology. The report also addresses digital inclusion and the needs of the elderly, particularly in monitoring health at home. To achieve these goals, existing policies and regulations must be reviewed and updated to keep pace with rapid technological changes.

site_title: Yuan slump spells more gloom for steel, aluminium producers
summary: China's yuan devaluation has led to a surge in steel and aluminium exports, further depressing global prices and threatening the industry. Chinese steel shipments reached a record 62.13 million tonnes in the first seven months of the year, while aluminium sales rose 28%. The devaluation has sparked fears of an Asian currency war and damped bets on a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in September. Indian steelmakers are facing significant challenges, with imports expected to surge to 15 million tonnes, and the country's largest producer, Tata Steel, reporting a 19% drop in earnings.

site_title: Adidas buys warehouse outside Moscow
summary: German sportswear maker Adidas has acquired a warehouse outside Moscow in a deal valued at US$70-100 million. The acquisition comes despite Adidas having reduced its target for new stores in Russia to 30 per year. Adidas has been renting the warehouse since 2012, and the deal is seen as a gesture of confidence in the Russian market. The acquisition is the second-largest deal in the Russian warehousing market this year, following BIN Group's US$200 million purchase of Chekhov I.

site_title: Genting Singapore swings to the red in Q2
summary: Genting Singapore reported a second-quarter net loss of S$16.9 million, down 91% from a year ago, due to slumping VIP volumes and low luck factor. Revenue fell 23% to S$578.1 million, and adjusted Ebitda declined 6% to S$296.5 million. The company attributed the losses to unfavorable gaming market conditions and a significant reduction in its portfolio investments. Genting Singapore will focus on foreign premium mass and mass market segments and remain cautious in granting credit under weak market conditions.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Sinking under the weight of its own ambition
summary: The Crossing II, a disaster/romance epic directed by John Woo, fails to impress with its attempt to incorporate historical events into its narrative. The film tells the true story of the sinking of the Chinese passenger ship Taiping in 1949, but its uneven pacing and lack of emotional depth leave viewers unimpressed. Despite a talented cast, including Zhang Ziyi and Takeshi Kaneshiro, the film's heavy-handed approach to historical drama and romance ultimately sinks under its own weight, resulting in a disappointing conclusion.

site_title: US dollar rebounds as China douses currency war fears
summary: The US dollar rebounded from a one-month low against the euro after China's yuan decline slowed, easing concerns over a currency war. The Swedish crown rose 1.6% to a nine-day high, driven by better-than-expected inflation data. These moves came as investors reassessed the global economic landscape, with the yuan's decline seen as a deliberate attempt by China to gain a competitive advantage. The US dollar's rebound suggests a decrease in currency war fears, while the Swedish crown's surge indicates a positive outlook for European economies.

site_title: Malaysia beats forecasts with 4.9% growth in Q2
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz announced the country's economy grew 4.9% in Q2, driven by private-sector demand, beating forecasts. The official projection for full-year growth is between 4.5% and 5.5%. Aziz quashed talk of capital controls, stating the financial system is more developed to absorb volatility. However, the ringgit's slump has caused pain to consumers and businesses, with economists warning of depleting international reserves and potential economic trouble if not addressed. Aziz remains confident in the economy's resilience and expects steady growth.

site_title: Media's yuan-devaluation reports over-dramatic: Wing Tai
summary: Wing Tai chairman Cheng Wai Keung criticized media reports on China's yuan devaluation, stating it's becoming more market-driven. The company reported a 19% drop in Q4 net profit to S$115.9 million, with revenue rising 20% to S$215.9 million. Cheng attributed the revenue drop to lower contributions from certain projects, but expressed optimism for growth when interest rates normalize. The company has a conservative approach and will not re-enter the subdued property market, focusing on existing investments in China and limiting exposure in Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: Video games movie is pure guilty pleasure
summary: Adam Sandler's film "Pixels" has grossed over $131 million worldwide despite a 17% rating on Rotten Tomatoes. The movie, which parodies video games, follows Sandler's character Sam Brenner as he teams up with childhood friends to defeat alien invaders. Critics panned the film, but it has become a guilty pleasure for fans, particularly those who grew up playing classic arcade games. The movie's success showcases Sandler's ability to appeal to a broad audience with his juvenile humor.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Transport looking for a lane change
summary: The transportation sector is shifting towards sustainable alternatives to combat climate change. Electric vehicles (EVs) and fuel-cell cars are gaining traction, with technology firms pushing for mass-market adoption. Governments like California and China are setting targets for EV sales, while companies like Tesla and Toyota are investing in electric and hydrogen infrastructure. However, the industry faces challenges, including improving battery performance, addressing range limitations, and infrastructure development. Autonomous vehicles are also being explored, with several companies working on driverless cars. Despite these hurdles, the no-oil drive has intensified, with hopes for a significant impact on emissions and oil demand.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Centurion Corp reported a buy rating with a target price of S$0.725, citing confidence in demand for its permanent workers' dormitories. Singtel reported Q1 FY2016 revenue of S$4.21 billion, meeting 24% of full-year forecast, while Boustead Singapore's Q1 FY3/2016 core net profit fell short of expectations. Analysts maintain buy calls for Singtel and Centurion, with target prices of S$4.40 and S$0.725 respectively, while holding Boustead Singapore due to a challenging business environment.

site_title: Private condo resale prices flat in July: SRX
summary: Singapore's private condo resale market remained weak in July, with resale prices of private condominiums and apartments increasing only 0.3% from June, described as "as flat as a board" by SRX Property. Despite this slight increase, property consultants see the market as stabilizing as prices start to match buyers' expectations.

site_title: CityDev's Q2 earnings dip; group has been raising M&C stake
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) posted a 3.2% year-on-year drop in Q2 net profit to S$133.5 million, despite raising its stake in London-listed hotel arm Millennium & Copthorne Hotels to 63% to consolidate more profit. The group's revenue fell 4.2% to S$824.94 million. CDL plans to launch several new projects, including The Criterion in Yishun and a new lifestyle concept at its Sunnyvale, California, freehold mixed-use site.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Singtel's Q1 earnings up 12.8% at S$942m
summary: Singtel reported a 12.8% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$942m in Q1 FY2016, driven by an exceptional gain and improved contributions from associate companies. This translated to earnings per share of 5.91 Singapore cents, up 12.8% from the previous quarter.

images.alt_text: Singtel's household Arpu (average revenue per user) rose one per cent to S$61 and 78 per cent of its broadband customers are on fibre broadband as at June 2015.

site_title: US financial software firm SunGard sold for US$9b
summary: US financial software firm SunGard was sold to Fidelity National Information Services in a cash-and-stock deal valued at approximately $9.1 billion, including debt. The acquisition is expected to complement Fidelity's business and create a combined entity with over $9.2 billion in annual revenue and 55,000 employees. The deal marks a modest return for the private equity firms that initially invested $11 billion in SunGard in 2005, with estimated returns ranging from 1.5 to 2 times their equity investment.

site_title: Greek economy made surprise Q2 surge before capital controls
summary: Greece's economy unexpectedly grew 0.8% in the second quarter, reversing a contraction forecast by economists. This comes as the country was on the brink of capital controls due to a standoff with creditors. The data contradicts recent reports painting a picture of an economy in crisis. However, economists caution that the numbers should be taken with a grain of salt, as domestic demand may have been temporarily boosted ahead of the measures. The EU's statistics office is set to publish second-quarter data for the euro region on Friday.

site_title: 'Singapore must never forget its socialist heart': Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Labour chief Chan Chun Sing paid tribute to late founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew at a National Day dinner, calling on residents to continue his legacy. Lee Kuan Yew died on March 23, aged 91. The tribute came as Singapore prepares for its General Election.

site_title: News Corp taking US$371m write-down on education unit
summary: News Corp is taking a US$371 million write-down on its education unit, Amplify, and will stop producing tablets for schoolchildren. The company is also in talks to sell its remaining education business. Amplify, led by former New York City schools chancellor Joel Klein, was a key part of News Corp's digital education push but is nearing an end. The write-down and exit from the education business are a result of the unit's struggles to achieve its goals.

images.alt_text: Amplify, a much-heralded push by News Corp into digital education, led by Joel Klein, a former New York City schools chancellor, is nearing an inglorious end.

site_title: World loses yuan as anchor of stability
summary: China's yuan, once a global economic anchor, has lost its stability, falling for a third day after the central bank's reference rate dropped 1.1%. This marks its steepest 21-year decline, as the People's Bank of China allows markets to set its value. The move is seen as a shift away from China's long-standing control over the currency's fluctuations, raising concerns about the country's economic influence and potential global economic impact.

site_title: China: There's no basis for continued depreciation of yuan
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), reassured global markets that the yuan's depreciation is not justified, citing the country's strong economic fundamentals. Despite a 3.2% drop in the currency since Monday, the PBOC said the yuan's spot rate is only 0.1% below the official guidance rate, and will continue to trade within a 2% range. The move aims to reassure investors and stem fears of a currency war, but analysts note that poor July economic data and interest rate cuts later this year may fuel further weakening of the yuan.

images.alt_text: Beijing's move to devalue the yuan drew accusations that Beijing was unfairly supporting its exporters.

site_title: Is technology a productivity engine? Debate rages on
summary: A debate rages on whether technology is a productivity engine, with economists John Fernald and Jan Hatzius of Goldman Sachs disagreeing on the impact of technology on the economy. Fernald's research suggests that technology's contribution to productivity growth has slowed, while Hatzius and his team argue that the tech industry's high stock prices and rising profit margins indicate a more positive outlook. The disagreement centers on the reliability of official statistics, which may be overstating inflation and understating productivity growth due to the unique nature of the IT industry.

site_title: Lawrence Wong and Halimah Yacob to co-anchor Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC
summary: Singapore's Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC will be co-anchored by Minister Lawrence Wong and Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob, who will join from West Coast and Jurong GRC respectively. Wong hinted that the full team may include incumbent MPs Alex Yam and Ong Teng Koon, with the PAP aiming to build on their work in the redrawn wards. The GRC will have four MPs, with the team set to unveil its manifesto before the upcoming general election.

site_title: Strong growth in H1 for Allianz Asia-Pacific
summary: Allianz Asia-Pacific reported double-digit growth in revenues for the first half of 2015, with total revenue rising 35.1% to €5 billion (S$7.8 billion) due to strong performances in its property & casualty and life and health segments.

site_title: NZ dairy giant Fonterra at risk of credit downgrade, says S&P
summary: Fonterra, the world's largest dairy exporter, is at risk of a credit downgrade due to high debt levels and a global price slump. The cooperative, which controls a third of the global dairy trade, has seen a 40% decline in global dairy prices since early this year. Fonterra's debt levels are 51% of its equity, and the company has taken steps to address this, including cutting capital spending and business costs. Standard and Poor's has put Fonterra on a negative credit watch, warning that a downgrade could make borrowing more expensive.

site_title: Hong Kong investor GAW to buy a second building in Seattle
summary: Hong Kong-based investor GAW Capital Partners plans to buy Seattle Tower, a 27-storey Art Deco office property, for about US$50 million. The purchase is part of the firm's expansion in the Seattle market, driven by the city's growing tech industry and record-high home prices and rents. This is GAW's second Seattle building acquisition, following a record purchase earlier this month. The firm is also looking for opportunities in other major US cities.

site_title: How Italy's top banks brushed off debt shock
summary: Italy's top banks, including UniCredit, Intesa Sanpaolo, and Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, saw their buffers grow despite a sharp decline in Italian debt, contrary to predictions. Lower loan losses, declines in risky assets, and hedging helped strengthen their finances. This was a surprise, as some analysts had expected a capital hit due to the debt shock. The banks' resilience suggests they are better prepared for future market fluctuations.

site_title: Goodbye to all that
summary: Urban artist Samantha Lo, known as the "Sticker Lady," is closing the chapter on her past persona with her first solo exhibition, LIMPEH Show. The exhibition features portraits of Singapore's first prime minister Lee Kuan Yew and explores themes of humanity and closure. Lo, who was sentenced to community service for her street art, has transformed her artistic style and technique, using mediums such as eggshells and mirrors. The exhibition runs until August 22 at The Substation Gallery and marks a new chapter in Lo's artistic journey.

site_title: Fed's 'lift-off' not quite the sure thing anymore
summary: The Federal Reserve's "lift-off" - the expected interest rate hike - is no longer considered a sure thing. Despite a solid economy, with a 2.3% GDP growth rate in the second quarter and a 5.3% unemployment rate, Fed Chair Janet Yellen has indicated that the timing of the rate hike may be uncertain. The Fed's decision-making body, the FOMC, is expected to meet in September or December, but the economy's performance will influence the outcome. The "lift-off" is now seen as a possibility, but not a guarantee.

site_title: Music festival for the people, by the people
summary: Support for local music in Singapore is at an all-time high, with the 100+50 Bands Festival drawing large crowds and sparking community engagement. The festival, curated by Razi Razak, features 150 acts, including new and established bands, and aims to introduce music subcultures to the masses. The event has also raised awareness and funds for social causes, such as supporting a man in need. The festival's success is seen as a positive influence on the local music scene, with genres like metal and hardcore gaining popularity.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Senior police officer Melvin Yong retiring on Aug 16: SPF
summary: Senior police officer Melvin Yong, 43, is retiring on August 16. His retirement has sparked speculation that he may be fielded by the ruling People's Action Party as a candidate in the upcoming general election. No further details on his potential candidacy have been announced.

site_title: Deaths and destruction follow huge explosions in Tianjin port
summary: At least 44 people were killed and over 500 injured in a series of explosions at a warehouse in Tianjin's port area, China. The blasts occurred after a shipment of explosives detonated, causing widespread destruction and fires. Paramedics treated hundreds of wounded, and firefighters responded to the scene before the explosions. The cause of the detonation is unclear, and an investigation is underway. The incident is the latest in a string of industrial accidents in China, which has a poor industrial safety record.

site_title: Associates, JVs lift Metro's Q1 bottom line
summary: Metro Holdings' net profit for Q1 FY2016 more than tripled to S$37.6 million, driven by improved contributions from associates and joint ventures. Revenue rose 36.8% to S$42.7 million, with strong support from the new Metro Centrepoint store in Singapore and the closing down sale of Metro Sengkang. Profit before tax jumped to S$42.6 million, led by a S$47 million gain on the disposal of EC Mall in Beijing. Earnings per share improved to 4.5 cents, with shares closing trading at S$0.875.

site_title: Samsung Electronics unveils high-end phones in search of sales boost
summary: Samsung Electronics unveiled new high-end phones, the Galaxy Note 5 and S6 edge+, to boost sales after market share fell in the second quarter. The phones feature faster processors, larger screens, and support mobile payment service Samsung Pay. The S6 edge+ has a 5.7-inch screen, while the Galaxy Note 5 has a faster processor. Samsung plans to release the phones this month and expand Samsung Pay to the UK, Spain, and China. The move aims to counter Apple's iPhones and Chinese rivals.

site_title: Leng Beng not too worried about China
summary: Singapore's property and hotels group City Developments Ltd (CDL) is not worried about China's yuan devaluation, with executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng expressing interest in acquiring a deal in China. Despite the devaluation affecting stock markets, CDL notes that China's real estate market is stabilizing in select cities with increased buyer demand. The company is also eyeing potential acquisitions in the UK, particularly in regional areas outside of London, and in Japan. CDL's CEO, Grant Kelley, believes China may surprise on the upside, offering attractive entry points for acquisitions in the next 6-12 months.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Keeping rock 'n' roll alive
summary: Support for local music is at an all-time high in Singapore, as evident from the full houses at recent festivals like Baybeats and Sing50. To capitalize on this trend, passionate music lovers are organizing their own festivals and music series to showcase homegrown bands. TinHill Rockfest, a free open-air rock festival, aims to deliver a musical extravaganza catering to all ages, with Chairman Eugene Yang seeking to appeal to a younger crowd. The event is seen as a nod to the iconic Woodstock festival, but with a modern twist.

site_title: Kumar hearts heartlanders
summary: Comedian Kumar performed free shows at HDB estates across Singapore, adapting his humor to appeal to heartland crowds. The "Kumar's Living Together" series featured four other comedians and focused on lighthearted, relatable topics. The shows were well-received, with audience members enjoying Kumar's toned-down humor and the comedians' candid portrayals of Singaporean life. Kumar's last free show was scheduled for August 15 at Jurong East's Community Plaza.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Kumar bringing his irreverent humour to HDB estates around the island.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Thai Beverage posts 6% net profit growth to 5.86 billion baht, while Kingsmen Creatives reports 42% decline in earnings to S$3.1 million. Hotel Properties Ltd sees 74% net profit rise to S$12.2 million. ST Engineering's president and CEO Tan Pheng Hock is on medical leave after a mild stroke.

site_title: Lui Tuck Yew on comments in support of him: "Like obituaries, eulogies without the flowers"
summary: Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew received a surge of supportive emails after announcing he won't run for re-election, but about 20% of writers expressed regret for not speaking up more against negative comments online. Lui attributed this to the anonymous nature of online criticism. He also expressed appreciation for those who thanked him for his work.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's Q2 profit rises 6.9% to S$80.9m
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation, a Singapore-based land transport group, reported a 6.9% increase in net profit to S$80.9 million for Q2, driven by revenue growth from its bus business. Revenue rose 2.1% to S$1.04 billion, with the bus business contributing 53.3% of overall revenue. The group's operating profit rose 0.8% to S$120.9 million, while earnings per share increased to 3.77 Singapore cents. A dividend of four Singapore cents per share was also announced, up from 3.75 cents in the previous period.

site_title: US retail sales up solidly, boosted by automobiles
summary: US retail sales rebounded 0.6% in July, boosted by increased automobile purchases. This solid momentum suggests steady economic growth at the start of the third quarter. The report strengthens expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike as early as next month. Core retail sales, excluding automobiles, gasoline, and building materials, rose 0.3%, aligning with consumer spending component of GDP. The steadily firming economy may lead to a revised GDP growth estimate, with many economists predicting a 3.0% pace.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close mixed
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mixed on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.04% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.82%. Paris's CAC 40 gained 1.25% to 4,986.85 points. The mixed performance was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were in focus.

site_title: Yuan's fall adds US$14b to Asia's foreign debt burden
summary: The record devaluation of the yuan has increased the foreign debt burden of Asia's companies, adding US$14 billion to their debt costs. The devaluation has led to a decline in currencies across Asia, with the Indonesian rupiah and Malaysian ringgit reaching 1998 lows. This has resulted in higher interest rates and insurance costs for companies, with Indonesian companies likely to be the worst hit. The yuan's devaluation has also led to a surge in demand for premium yields on junk notes, with the spread over Treasuries rising 25 basis points.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Key events and facts include: 
Five classic Singaporean films from the 1950s to 1970s will be screened at Capitol Theatre as part of the Spotlight on Singapore Cinema initiative. Malaysian painter Khoo Sui Hoe's large paintings are on display at Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts, while Keyaki at Pan Pacific Singapore offers Yonezawa Wagyu Beef. An exhibition of photographs from the Twentyfifteen.sg project is on display at the Esplanade until January. Ceramicist Alvin Tan Teck Heng's solo exhibition, Building an Empire, showcases 1,000 wheel-thrown and glazed ceramic rice bowls at One East Asia.
