The dollar's rise is expected to have a positive impact on US exports and stocks.

site_title: CAO appoints new chairman as incumbent retires

site_title: Singapore's shrinking economy worsens bank risk as loans slump
summary: Singapore's banks face increased risk as loan quality worsens, with 2.3% of loan books in a "special mention" category, the highest since 2009. site_title: Japan anxious at lull, US 'giving up', in pan-Pacific trade talks

The talks, which started in 2013, failed to reach an agreement despite early optimism. Disputes over intellectual property protection and dairy market access were major sticking points. Japan and the US are now set to miss a meeting to try to clinch a deal this month, raising concerns about the momentum of the talks.

site_title: South Korea not worried about won fall after China move: official

The South Korean foreign exchange official stated that the won's movement will be closely monitored, but as long as it moves in an orderly manner, South Korea is not worried about a weakening of the currency.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; TSMC jumps on strong July sales

This move comes after a shutdown sparked by public fears following the 2011 Fukushima crisis, the worst atomic disaster in a generation.

A deal is expected to be approved by Greece's parliament and euro zone finance ministers, paving the way for aid disbursements and an initial capital injection of up to 10 billion euros for Greek banks.

site_title: Australia business confidence eases back in July: survey
summary: Australia's business confidence eased back in July, according to a survey by National Australia Bank, slipping 4 points to +4. However, the survey's trend measures suggest a turnaround in the non-mining economy, with the service sector continuing to outperform.

The country's international reserves have declined to $96.7 billion, and investors are increasingly concerned about the growing political imbroglio and the scandal surrounding state-owned 1MDB.

site_title: S&P 500 soon to have 505 listed shares
summary: The Standard & Poor's 500 is set to increase to 505 listed stocks, up from 502, due to a methodology change allowing multiple share classes in S&P indexes. The change will affect three companies: Comcast Corp, News Corp, and Twenty-First Century Fox, which will now have multiple listings. The adjustment will take effect on September 18, coinciding with a quarterly rebalancing.

images.alt_text: The Standard & Poor's 500 will soon contain 505 listed stocks, up from the current 502 listed stocks.

site_title: Noble Group cuts jobs as Q2 profit dips 5%
summary: Noble Group reported a 5% drop in Q2 net profit to US$62.61 million, attributed to commodities weakness. To counter this, the company is implementing cost reduction initiatives, aiming for US$70 million in annual savings. A targeted 16% cut in headcount is expected by the end of the year.

site_title: Market likely to languish amid thin trading
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) is expected to remain stagnant in thin trading volume, with blue chips and penny stocks likely to languish. The index's weakness is attributed to Wall Street's uncertainty over interest rate hikes, with strategists unsure if the first hike will occur in September or December. The Singapore Exchange's (SGX) minimum trading price (MTP) initiative has also been criticized, but its head of listing compliance argues that it will improve the market's quality and integrity in the long term.

site_title: US pipeline overbuild forces executives to seek new opportunities
summary: US pipeline executives have expressed concerns over the rapid expansion of pipeline capacity in the Permian Basin, citing a potential overbuild that may hinder revenue growth. With over 1 million barrels per day of additional pipeline capacity added since 2014, companies are now facing limits, causing temporary imbalances in spot prices and reducing growth prospects. Executives from Plains All American Pipeline, Magellan Midstream Partners, and Sunoco Logistics Partners have reduced growth guidance and warned of a "more conservative assessment" of pipeline volumes and profits due to overbuilt infrastructure.

site_title: Copper bears keep net-short position as stockpiles rise
summary: Hedge funds are increasing their bets that copper prices will fall further, pushing their net-short position to the most bearish since April 2013. Copper prices have been stuck in a slump for over two years, with China's economy showing little signs of recovery. Despite rising stockpiles, futures in New York dropped 1.3% last week, and speculators hold a net-short position of 33,547 contracts. Disruptions at mines in Chile could help stem the decline, but ample inventories are also cushioning supplies.

site_title: New York City orders tests on all cooling towers within 2 weeks
summary: New York City has ordered all buildings with water-cooling towers to assess and disinfect the units within two weeks due to the outbreak of Legionnaires' disease in the South Bronx. The directive, issued by health officials, comes after two more deaths were reported, bringing the total to 10, and at least 100 people have been infected. The order requires building owners to hire an environmental consultant to evaluate and disinfect the towers, with exemptions for buildings that have recently undergone similar inspections. The city expects to provide free legionella testing for affected buildings and may impose legal sanctions on non-compliant owners.

site_title: China developer launches vacation rental online platform to tap unsold homes
summary: Chinese developer Fantasia Holdings Group has launched a vacation rental platform called Home ENE, capitalizing on unsold homes from a property boom. The platform, similar to Airbnb, aims to utilize the homes left vacant. This move rivals Chinese home rental firm Tujia, which recently raised $300 million to expand globally.

site_title: Chinese consumers in no hurry to buy as cars keep getting cheaper
summary: Chinese consumers are not in a hurry to buy new cars due to decreasing prices, with some models experiencing discounts of at least 30% off. Major carmakers, including Audi and Volkswagen, are offering deep discounts and incentives such as subsidized insurance and zero downpayments to boost sales. The slowest growth in new car sales in four years has led to unprecedented offers, with industry sales figures expected to be released soon. This trend may reflect a larger market shift, with the Chinese economy facing challenges and government curbs deterring car buyers.

site_title: Spectacular, despite acoustic challenge
summary: A concert featuring 250 Singapore musicians at the National Stadium drew praise for its scale and song, but was marred by a disappointing sound system. Despite complaints of "noisy" sound on social media, the system improved in the concert's second half. The event, dubbed Sing50, was attended by 41,343 people and featured past and present music heroes. The concert's success was overshadowed by the subpar sound, but overall, it was considered a spectacular event.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Aussie devaluation fails Economics 101 as export income slides
summary: Australia's economy faces challenges despite a 34% devaluation of the Aussie dollar, which has reached a six-year low. The devaluation was expected to boost exports, but instead, the country's trade deficit widened, and most listed exporters are predicted to report shrinking revenues. Commodity prices, such as iron ore and coal, have declined significantly, further weakening the export outlook. Analysts expect the economy to experience sub-trend growth until liquefied natural gas exports kick in, potentially becoming the world's largest exporter by 2018.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GLP sells 5 Japanese properties to Tokyo-listed GLP J-Reit for 38.1 billion yen (S$424 million), matching market value as of June 30. A-Sonic Aerospace expects net loss for Q2 and first-half results. China Cord Blood Corp. received a non-binding offer to acquire its China business for six billion yuan (S$1.34 billion). OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, former DBS veteran, replacing Helen Wong.

site_title: China steel export rises as mills face slowing local demand
summary: China's steel exports rose 9.5% in July to 9.73 million tonnes, the highest level in six months, as domestic demand falters amid a property slump. This surge in exports, which reached 62.13 million tonnes in the first seven months, is attributed to Chinese mills pushing excess production into the international market. The move is expected to continue, with Citigroup forecasting 100 million tonnes of net steel shipments from China this year. Lower steel prices and declining earnings at global producers have led to trade disputes, but may eventually push Chinese producers to cut back on production and exports.

site_title: Curbing global warming: mission impossible?
summary: The US and the world face a significant challenge in curbing global warming due to the strong dependence of economic growth on fossil fuels. President Obama's plan to cut greenhouse gas emissions from power plants is seen as a step in the right direction, but it is considered modest and may not be enough to prevent higher CO2 concentrations. The dilemma is that eliminating fossil fuel emissions would stabilize most human impact on global warming but would also destroy modern economies. Technological breakthroughs, such as better batteries and nuclear power, are seen as potential solutions, but their availability is uncertain.

site_title: Look out for lithium, the next boom metal
summary: Lithium, a key mineral used in electric vehicles, solar panels, and consumer electronics, is poised for a boom due to increasing demand. The rise of Tesla's battery gigafactory and other electric vehicle manufacturers is driving up demand, transforming lithium into a sought-after commodity. With new applications emerging, lithium's use is expanding beyond its current mundane purposes, making it a highly anticipated market transformation. Supply cannot keep up with the growing demand, setting the stage for a significant boom in the lithium market.

images.alt_text: Lithium found in salty water, or brine, is the most cost effective. There are only a few places where lithium is present at high enough concentrations in brines and the most famous is in the Lithium Triangle of Bolivia, Argentina and Chile.

site_title: Aussie home market cooling as banks tighten reins
summary: The Australian home market is experiencing a cooling trend due to regulators stepping in to curb rising prices. In the past three years, home prices have increased by 29%, driven by low mortgage rates and Chinese investments. Banks have begun tightening their lending policies, requiring borrowers to reduce their existing loans before approving new ones, affecting buyers like Nick Hart who had planned to purchase a fifth property. This move aims to slow the market and prevent over-investment.

site_title: Former OCBC chairman Lee Seng Wee, 85, dies
summary: Former OCBC chairman Lee Seng Wee, 85, died peacefully after sustaining a head injury from a fall, with complications arising from the incident. He served on the bank's board for nearly 50 years, including as chairman and CEO from 1995 to 2003. Lee's top achievements include leading the successful acquisition of Keppel Capital Holdings and strategic investments in Bank NISP and Bank of Ningbo. He will be remembered by his colleagues as a "gentle soul" and a gentleman, who valued modesty and kindness.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Lee succumbed to complications arising from a fall. He sustained a head injury during the fall and underwent neurosurgery

site_title: Noble's contract valuation approach in line with rules: PwC
summary: Noble Group's mark-to-market valuation approach for long-term commodity derivative contracts has been deemed compliant with accounting rules and industry practices by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC). The review, prompted by criticism from short-seller Muddy Waters and anonymous group Iceberg Research, found that Noble's valuations were consistent with relevant criteria and more sophisticated than many non-financial companies. However, PwC recommended strengthening Noble's governance and oversight framework and improving information presentation. Noble has accepted the recommendations and taken steps to implement them.

site_title: Asia Pacific Stock Exchange eyeing listings from China
summary: The Asia Pacific Stock Exchange (APX) in Sydney is eyeing listings from Chinese companies despite a recent downturn in Chinese shares. Chairman George Wang hopes to capitalize on the appetite for stock market listings by Chinese companies, which were initially lined up for the Shanghai and Shenzhen A stock markets. However, Beijing froze initial public offerings due to a stock market bubble. Wang believes his exchange can act as a bridge between Chinese companies and Australia's pension funds, potentially reducing volatility in the Chinese market.

site_title: Beyond 50: Singapore's growth strategy shifts
summary: Singapore is shifting its growth strategy to focus on "sector agnostic" innovation and value creation, driven by local enterprises and skills, rather than relying on foreign multinationals and export-led industrialization. The government aims to create innovative products and services, and establish Singapore as a leading centre for value creation in business strategies. This marks a departure from the past, where the focus was on picking winning sectors and attracting foreign investments. The government is also promoting the SkillsFuture initiative to develop innovative and high-skilled teams in every sector, and is targeting growth clusters in advanced manufacturing, applied health sciences, and others.

site_title: Coke funds scientists who shift blame for obesity away from bad diets
summary: Coca-Cola is backing a new non-profit organization, the Global Energy Balance Network, which promotes the idea that weight-conscious Americans should focus on exercise rather than cutting calories. The organization, funded by Coke, claims there is little evidence that diet is the primary cause of obesity. Critics argue that this message is misleading and an effort by Coke to deflect criticism about the role of sugary drinks in obesity. The company has provided $5.5 million in funding to the group since 2008.

site_title: DBS's institutional banking growth to slow
summary: DBS Group Holdings' institutional banking business is expected to slow down this year due to China's cooling economy, but its lucrative cash management services continue to expand at double digits. The business, which accounts for over half of the bank's total income and 60% of its profit, saw a 2% increase in pre-tax profit to S$1.6 billion in the first half of 2015. Despite this, DBS's consumer banking and wealth management unit saw a significant jump in earnings, with a 56% increase in pre-tax profit.

images.alt_text: Ms Wong said the cooling of China's economy will hit DBS's institutional banking business this year. She said China is buying less and "the whole supply chain is affected"

site_title: PAP to unveil full slate of candidates before Aug 23: Eng Hen
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) in Singapore is set to unveil its full slate of 89 candidates for the upcoming general election (GE) before August 23, including the exact constituencies they will contest in. The party's organising secretary, Ng Eng Hen, announced that the first batch of new faces will be introduced on Tuesday, and the full slate will be revealed before the National Day Rally. This marks a significant shift in the party's approach, with candidates' identities and constituencies to be made public before Nomination Day.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: EON's Russian slump bodes ill for fossil fuel spin-off
summary: EON SE, Germany's largest utility, reported a 15% drop in first-half earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (Ebitda) due to Russia's weakening currency. This slump is expected to affect Uniper, EON's fossil fuel spin-off, which will take control of eastern assets, including Russia, where the rouble lost 30% to the euro. Analysts consider Russia's operations underperforming and problematic for Uniper. EON's investments in Russia total 10 billion euros, and the company remains committed to the long-term.

site_title: Tech workers in Finland regroup, refocus
summary: Tech workers in Finland face uncertainty as Microsoft reduces its local workforce by up to 2,300 employees, roughly two-thirds of its Finnish workforce. The move comes after Microsoft acquired Nokia's mobile phone business in 2014 and sold it to Microsoft, leading to significant job losses. Nokia now focuses on telecom infrastructure, leaving many former Nokia employees without jobs. This is not the first time Finland has faced job losses, as Nokia's layoffs in 2012 left 10,000 workers without employment.

site_title: Innovation brings out the human in us
summary: A 1990s prediction that telework would replace physical offices with remote work has not materialized, as technology has instead made face-to-face communication more important. Companies like Google, Facebook, and Apple are investing heavily in sprawling campuses in Silicon Valley, highlighting the importance of proximity in innovation and human connection. Despite advancements in digital technologies, the need for local relationships and in-person interactions remains, with even banks relying on local branches for crucial information.

site_title: Oil, metals and sugar prices slump to new lows
summary: Commodities prices plummeted to new lows last week due to ample supplies and a strong US dollar. Oil prices dropped over 50% since mid-2014, with Brent North Sea crude reaching a six-month low at US$48.55 a barrel. Other metals, such as gold, platinum, and palladium, also hit multi-year lows. The slump is attributed to a global supply glut, high US production, and a strong US dollar discouraging crude purchases. Investors also await additional oil supplies from Iran and disappointing Chinese data.

site_title: Building industry revamps image
summary: Singapore Contractors Association Ltd (SCAL) is revamping the building industry's image to attract young talent amid a slowdown in the residential building sector. SCAL's president, Kenneth Loo, aims to strengthen the industry through initiatives such as upskilling workforce, mechanization, and rebranding the built environment sector. The association has partnered with the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) to implement a five-year roadmap, which includes 10 initiatives to attract local talent and improve productivity. Loo emphasizes the need for moderation in introducing new policies to ensure the industry is prepared for the changing landscape.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: China expects property market improvement to continue in H2
summary: China's top economic planner expects the property market to continue improving in the second half of 2015, providing a boost to the struggling economy. Despite a year-long slump in the housing market, home sales and prices have improved in bigger cities, and the National Development and Reform Commission forecasts consumer prices to stabilize and producer prices to ease. However, domestic demand remains sluggish, and the government may need to roll out fresh economic support measures to meet its 7% growth target for the year.

site_title: China video services take censorship into own hands
summary: China's largest social video websites, including YY Inc, Tian Ge Interactive Holdings' 9158.com, Sina Show, and Guagua.cn, have been found to self-censor content under vague government guidelines, with thousands of words and phrases being monitored and scrubbed from private messages. The websites, which serve over 100 million users, block content related to sensitive topics such as Tiananmen, Falungong, and Uighur separatism, with some phrases being replaced with asterisks. The findings highlight the autonomy with which these services take matters into their own hands to comply with broad government guidelines, often without clear guidance.

site_title: China may replace top market regulator
summary: China's ruling Communist Party is searching for a potential replacement for top securities regulator Xiao Gang, who faces internal criticism over handling this year's boom and bust in Chinese stock prices. Party elders will discuss the matter this summer, with some fearing an immediate change could increase market uncertainty. Xiao Gang, appointed two years ago, has come under fire for his response to market panic and excesses, prompting the central leadership to prioritize market stability. A final decision on replacing him has not been made yet.

site_title: Market shrugs as China slashes US debt stake by US$180b
summary: China has reduced its US debt holdings by about $180 billion, but the market has barely reacted. Other sources of demand, such as banks and mutual funds, have stepped in to fill the void. The US Treasury market remains robust, with foreign buyers holding $6.13 trillion of Treasuries and US commercial banks increasing their stakes by $300 billion. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates soon, and investors are drawn to the high-yielding, low-risk asset. The pullback from US securities by China and Japan is seen as less ominous for the Treasury market, with experts attributing the big overall level of rates to macro and policy stories rather than flows.

site_title: Ambitious Krishnapatnam port betting on policy shift to bring in vessels
summary: A southern Indian port, Krishnapatnam, has built facilities to handle the world's largest ships, but policy changes are needed to bring in vessels due to existing regulations. Foreign ships are barred from moving cargo between Indian ports, and congestion and shallow waters have deterred large vessels from docking locally. India can potentially recover $260 billion in lost shipping trade annually if Prime Minister Narendra Modi scrapes the law. The port's infrastructure is in place, but high container handling charges and lack of intra-port trade opportunities hinder its growth.

site_title: Nokia prepares for return to mobile phones, consumer tech
summary: Nokia, the once-famed mobile phone brand, is preparing to return to the market with a comeback strategy focused on licensing its brand to other companies. The company is hiring software experts, testing new products, and seeking sales partners. Nokia aims to re-enter the mobile phone business through licensing agreements, which would allow other firms to mass-manufacture, market, and sell devices bearing the Nokia brand. The company has already launched an Android tablet and a "virtual reality camera" to herald its return, and will not repeat the mistakes of the past by manufacturing and selling its own products.

site_title: Tension running high in VIX
summary: US stocks have fallen, leading to a surge in options betting on a rise in the Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index (VIX), the most expensive since 2006. The VIX, a measure of market fear, closed at 13.39 last week, more than six points below its historical average. Investors are hedging through calls on the VIX as traders prepare for the worst, building hedges ahead of a potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike in September.

site_title: Japan set to return to nuclear power after hiatus
summary: Japan is set to restart its nuclear power program after a two-year hiatus, with the country's first reactor, No. 1 at the Sendai nuclear plant, expected to reach full capacity by Tuesday night. The reactor's operator announced the restart, following the implementation of tougher safety rules to avoid a repeat of the Fukushima crisis. This move is part of Japan's plan to get four dozen reactors back online, with the government and power companies eager to reduce reliance on fossil fuels. The restart marks a significant step towards Japan's goal of becoming nuclear-independent again.

site_title: Mumbai investors snap up Maharashtra bonds as company sales fade
summary: Mumbai investors have snapped up Maharashtra bonds as the state's 10-year securities were sold at an average annualised coupon of 8.47% in July, the highest since November. This surge in yields came as company sales in the region faded.

site_title: Robots, automation undercut Modi's quest to put Indians to work
summary: India's automation and robotics trend is undercutting Prime Minister Narendra Modi's goal to create jobs for the poor through his "Make in India" campaign. Robots, such as those used at Royal Enfield Motors Ltd's plant in southern India, are replacing low-skilled laborers, boosting productivity but creating a shortage of jobs. India's largely uneducated labor force and broken educational system are not equipped for more complex jobs, and nations like China are becoming more competitive. Experts warn that India may lose out on the manufacturing edge, with the International Monetary Fund's chairman stating that time is not on India's side, and that labor-intensive manufacturing will survive in its present form for only 10 years before machines take over.

site_title: Americans expect to tighten purse strings: NY Fed survey
summary: Americans expect to tighten their purse strings, with household spending growth expectations plummeting to 3.5% in July, the lowest since the survey began in 2013. Home price inflation expectations also fell to 3.2%, while year-ahead gas price inflation predictions dropped to 4.4%. These decreases are attributed to respondents over 40 and those with lower levels of education. The New York Fed survey, which taps 1,200 respondents, suggests a decrease in consumer confidence and spending plans.

site_title: Republicans are not dismissing Donald Trump yet
summary: Donald Trump's performance in the first Republican presidential debate has solidified his position as a leading candidate, despite critics labeling him a "pompous celebrity." Trump's nationalist and populist agenda has resonated with Republican voters, and his criticism of Washington's failure to stem immigration and his protectionist stance on trade have brought together other candidates. While some may view him as a divisive figure, his message appears to be working, and his eventual front-runner in the primary race is likely to continue his populist agenda. Trump's debate performance has also raised questions about the role of entertainment in American politics and the potential for a celebrity candidate to win the presidency.

site_title: A Smart Nation needs a smart asset management strategy
summary: Singapore aims to evolve into a Smart Nation over the next couple of years, leveraging current and emerging technologies to create smart, interconnected urban assets for public benefit. A multi-disciplinary approach is required, involving engineers, scientists, and urban planners to design and implement these assets. An advanced modelling system will be used to validate design, test compatibility, and predict potential failures, ensuring intelligent and adaptive maintenance. Standardized data management and asset management software will be essential in unlocking the full Smart Nation vision.

site_title: Airbnb gives Paris luxury hoteliers a fright
summary: Airbnb is disrupting the luxury hotel market in Paris, offering high-end properties at competitive prices. With over 380 properties available at over €500 ($759) per night, the platform is attracting affluent travelers and even some high-end hotels, which are concerned about the competition. The Bristol Hotel's managing director, Didier le Calvez, warns that the Paris market will become increasingly difficult for luxury hotels, with capacity expected to increase by 60% by 2018. Meanwhile, Airbnb defends its platform, stating that its offerings are unique and distinct from traditional hotels.

site_title: US lawmakers shouldn't politicise the Federal Reserve
summary: US lawmakers are considering ways to politicize the Federal Reserve, including launching an audit of the central bank. However, this effort would compromise the Fed's independence and hinder its ability to set monetary policy. In contrast, the Fed's activist monetary policy helped stimulate a gradual economic recovery during the Great Recession, while lawmakers in Washington failed to come up with a coherent long-term fiscal policy. Fed Chair Janet Yellen warned that the Fed would not have had the courage to take decisive action to control inflation if the current proposals were in place.

site_title: Urban traffic systems vulnerable to hacking
summary: A security researcher, Cesar Cerrudo, tested the vulnerability of Washington D.C.'s traffic system, exposing weaknesses in the city's traffic sensors. He demonstrated that a hacker could potentially gain access to traffic signals, causing gridlock and disrupting emergency services. However, city officials dispute his findings, stating that the probability of a hacker gaining access to the system is "highly unlikely." The city is reviewing the security of its traffic sensors, which were installed about five years ago, after a similar incident in Los Angeles.

site_title: Chinese-style quantitative easing takes shape
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), is implementing quantitative easing policies to support the government's growth programs. The PBOC is financing government-backed projects through state lenders, known as policy banks, rather than directly funding them. This adaptation aims to stabilize prices and boost economic growth, as China's GDP growth is expected to slow. The move is seen as a response to the country's economic challenges, with policymakers under pressure to maintain growth and stabilize the economy.

site_title: DTZ still home to a high-performing team
summary: DTZ, a real estate brokerage firm, has clarified that its high-performing associates are not leaving for Chestertons, as previously suggested. The firm has maintained its top performers from 2014, and has been continuously hiring new associates, including 300 in 2014 and 150 since January. DTZ's ability to provide leading-edge property services remains unaffected, with the company focusing on succession and continuity. The firm's associate director, Wong Wei Chen, stated that "big does not necessarily mean productive" in the industry.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance as technology, resource companies rally
summary: European stocks advanced, driven by technology and resource companies. The Stoxx 600 Index rose 0.7% to 399.82, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto leading gains. Technology stocks, including ASML, also surged. China's stocks rose, fueled speculation of a stimulus package to boost growth. Greece's ASE Index advanced 2.1%, with banks leading gains ahead of potential bailout talks.

site_title: Heathrow trials steeper approaches as runway decision looms
summary: Heathrow Airport is introducing steeper approaches for aircraft to reduce noise for local residents. Currently, planes descend at a 3-degree angle, but from September, they will descend at a 3.2-degree angle on a trial basis until March 2016. The trial aims to minimize noise exposure by reducing the time planes spend at low altitudes. The move comes as the UK government considers a third runway at Heathrow or expanding air capacity at Gatwick Airport, with a decision expected by the end of the year.

site_title: Going international is a risk, but so is doing nothing
summary: Singaporean companies are increasingly expanding globally, with half of SMEs earning revenue from overseas. International expansion can offer cost advantages, increased growth, and better customer service. However, it also comes with risks, such as funding, tax, and regulatory barriers. SMEs must conduct thorough research to identify suitable markets, partners, and financing solutions. Failing to explore international markets is also a risk, as it can limit growth opportunities. With the right approach, international expansion can be a key driver for business growth.

site_title: Dollar slips from nearly 4-month high on rate hike uncertainty
summary: The US dollar slipped from a nearly four-month high on Monday after US Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer expressed concerns about global deflation, casting doubt on the likelihood of a rate hike in September. The dollar index fell 0.04% to 97.528, despite analysts still expecting a rate hike, while the euro rose 0.05% to $1.09710. Fischer's comments reignited uncertainty about the Fed's timing, which had supported the dollar's rally last week. The euro reached its highest level against the Swiss franc since January, and the dollar rose against the yen.

site_title: China considers replacing head of markets regulator: sources
summary: China's ruling Communist Party is considering replacing the head of its markets regulator, Xiao Gang, who faces internal criticism over his handling of this year's stock market boom and bust. The party has sounded out potential candidates, including Huang Qifan, mayor of Chongqing, and party elders will discuss the matter at meetings this summer. The move reflects the party's unhappiness with Xiao's performance, but a final decision has not been made yet.

site_title: Resource shares slump in tandem with weak energy, iron ore and metals prices
summary: Resource companies experienced a horrific bear market due to declining energy, iron ore, and metals prices. Several analysts believe the sector is oversold and undervalued, but a sustainable rally requires commodity prices to reverse and remain high. Companies have announced major retrenchments, and ratings companies warn of credit risks due to dollar borrowing. Analysts, including Barron's, predict a bottom in the market, but others point to the investment overhang in commodity index funds and the negative impact of the US dollar on commodity prices.

images.alt_text: Resource companies have experienced an horrific bear market in tandem with the slide in energy, iron ore and metals prices.

site_title: 50 and beyond: Singapore's economic transformation
summary: Singapore's economy is undergoing significant transformation, with a focus on emerging industries such as sustainable aviation and advanced chip packaging. The government has established a centre to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific region and introduced a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses affected by tariffs. The country is also investing in skills development through initiatives like SkillsFuture. Experts advise graduates to future-proof their careers to mitigate the impact of potential economic crises.

site_title: US$ ekes out gains aided by US rate hike view
summary: The US dollar remained near a four-month high against a basket of currencies on Monday, driven by steady US jobs growth and expectations of a September interest rate hike. The dollar index rose to 97.639, supported by elevated two-year US Treasury yields. Commodity-related currencies, such as the Australian and New Zealand dollars, fell after weak Chinese data raised concerns about a slowing economy. Speculators increased bullish bets on the dollar, with a net long position of $32.77 billion.

site_title: Link grows with innovative designs
summary: Link, a Singapore-based property firm, is collaborating with Pinewood Iskandar Malaysia Studios for its first overseas venture worth S$1 billion. The company, which has won the Enterprise 50 Awards, is known for its emphasis on design innovation and functionality. Founded 20 years ago, Link has completed over 50 projects, including luxury residential and commercial properties. The firm's willingness to adapt and venture out of its comfort zone has contributed to its success. This marks Link's first overseas venture.

site_title: US lawyer Gandhi said to join Fifa task force
summary: US lawyer Samir Gandhi has been nominated to join a task force that will suggest reforms to FIFA, the governing body of international soccer, amid a corruption scandal. Gandhi, who is reorganizing Concacaf, will represent the region alongside Victor Montagliani. Other regional federations have also nominated representatives, with the task force due to submit proposals by September. The reforms aim to address corruption and improve governance, following the arrest of senior FIFA officials in May.

site_title: Landlords, BOE worry about cheap money pushing up property values
summary: London landlords and the Bank of England (BOE) are concerned about cheap money pushing up property values, as amateur investors flood the market with buy-to-let loans. The BOE is worried about the impact of rising interest rates on landlords' ability to afford repayments, with Chancellor George Osborne hinting at new powers to regulate the sector. The buy-to-let market has grown significantly since 1996, with an estimated two million private landlords owning one in five homes in Britain, and experts predict further growth, making it challenging for officials to cool demand for rental homes.

site_title: Precision Castparts deal reinforces Berkshire's transformation
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc has agreed to buy Precision Castparts Corp, an aerospace equipment maker, in a deal valued at $37.2 billion. The acquisition, which will add $10 billion in annual revenue and 30,000 employees, is part of Berkshire's long-term vision to become an industrial giant. The deal follows previous acquisitions such as Iscar Metalworking and Lubrizol, and marks a shift towards industrial operations as Berkshire's equity portfolio is cut back. The purchase is seen as a strategic move to diversify Berkshire's business and capitalize on long-term bets.

images.alt_text: Mr Buffett, who will turn 85 this month, has also shifted his equity portfolio, cutting back on some long-time holdings such as P & G.

site_title: Russian economy contracts 4.6% in second quarter: official
summary: Russia's economy contracted 4.6% in the second quarter, its sharpest decline since 2009, due to lower oil prices and Western sanctions. The recession worsened from the 2.2% contraction in the first quarter, with economists predicting a 3.6% decline in 2015 GDP growth. The country's economic crisis has reached its nadir, with a new drop in crude oil prices sparking a fresh decline in the ruble.

site_title: Former OCBC chairman Lee Seng Wee dies, aged 85
summary: Former OCBC Bank chairman Lee Seng Wee, 85, died peacefully after a fall, with complications arising from the injury. He served as chairman from 1995 to 2003 and led the successful takeover bid for Keppel Capital Holdings in 2001. Lee was also a director of several companies and chairman of the Temasek Trust Board. He leaves behind his wife, three children, and six grandchildren. A private service was held, and donations can be made to the National Neuroscience Institute Health Research Endowment Fund.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Greece and lenders in final push to seal new bailout accord
summary: Greece and international creditors are in the final stages of negotiating a new bailout accord worth up to $131 billion. The deal must be finalized by August 20 to meet a debt repayment to the European Central Bank. Germany has set "strict" conditions, including a link between aid and reforms, as it seeks to ensure Greece meets its commitments. site_title: HTC trading near cash leaves a smartphone brand with no value
summary: HTC Corp's stock plummeted 56% this year, leaving the company's market value near its cash reserves, effectively rendering its brand, factories, and buildings nearly worthless. The company's forecast for third-quarter sales is 48% below analyst estimates, with a forecast loss-per-share five times wider than estimated. Analysts predict the stock will fall below the NT$57 of cash-per-share the company had at June 30, and none of the 22 tracked recommend investors buy the stock, citing a long-term debt-free but struggling company.

site_title: Ringgit near 17-year low as Malaysia forex reserves fall below US$100b
summary: Malaysia's foreign exchange reserves fell below US$100 billion, raising concerns over the ringgit's value. The currency hit a 17-year low of 3.9245 per dollar, with five-year government bond yields rising to 3.856 per cent. The decline is attributed to sliding commodity prices and a graft scandal linked to Prime Minister Najib Razak. The central bank has been selling dollars and buying ringgit, but the currency's weakness persists, with experts warning of further drops in reserves and potential losses for the country.

site_title: Greece hopes to conclude bailout talks by Aug 11
summary: Greece is nearing a conclusion to bailout talks with international creditors, aiming to finalize negotiations by early Tuesday, August 11. The country is seeking up to 86 billion euros in fresh loans to avoid economic collapse and stay in the euro zone. A key sticking point is the size of the bailout, with some EU member states wanting it reduced due to political sensitivity. The Greek side is concerned with addressing non-performing loans in the banking sector, particularly setting up a 'bad bank' to handle them.

site_title: Chinese dragon losing its shine for foreign firms
summary: Foreign firms are experiencing a decline in sales in China, the country's economic slowdown hitting their profits. Major companies such as Volkswagen, UTC, and Apple have reported a 3.9% drop in sales in China, with some attributing the decline to rising costs and increased competition from domestic brands. Despite this, some analysts believe China's economy is still growing faster than other countries, making it an attractive market for foreign companies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.51% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.51% lower on Monday, following a decline on Wall Street due to a solid US jobs report that raised expectations of an imminent Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The Nikkei 225 index fell 106.25 points to 20,618.31. The US Labor Department reported 215,000 jobs added last month, with unemployment holding steady at 5.3%. The report heightened expectations of a Fed rate hike as early as next month, contributing to the decline in global markets.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened 0.51 per cent lower on Monday, following falls on Wall Street as a solid US jobs report raised expectations that the Federal Reserve will soon hike interest rates.

site_title: Jubilant chorus as S'pore turns 50
summary: Singaporeans celebrated the country's 50th anniversary of independence with a grand National Day Parade, marking the occasion with unprecedented displays, nostalgia-themed segments, and a massive fireworks show. The parade honored pioneers of the post-independence era, including the late Lee Kuan Yew, with a video tribute and a special "Five Stars" tribute fly-past. Foreign dignitaries and local leaders attended the event, which also featured performances by popular artists and a display of Singapore's military might. The parade concluded with a massive pyrotechnics display, marking a memorable milestone in the country's history.

site_title: Bullish oil bets boosted too early as price slide continues
summary: Speculators increased bullish bets on oil for the first time in seven weeks, but the move came too early as crude prices continue to slide. The US Commodity Futures Trading Commission reported a 13% increase in net-long positions in crude, but major oil companies and banks are preparing for a longer downturn. West Texas Intermediate crude dropped 4.7% to a six-year low of $45.74 a barrel, with Societe Generale reducing its price forecasts and Chevron Corp lowering its long-term outlook. The persistent global surplus is making companies more pessimistic about a swift price recovery.

images.alt_text: Money managers' net-long position in crude climbed 13 per cent in the week ended Aug 4.

site_title: Foreign hedge funds thrive in China despite strict rules
summary: Foreign hedge funds are operating in a regulatory grey area in China, using speculative trading strategies that are complicating efforts to calm the country's turbulent stock markets. Despite strict investment rules, hundreds of foreign hedge funds and traders are active in Chinese stocks, raising concerns for regulators. This activity is hindering their ability to manage market volatility, further exacerbating the challenges faced by policymakers.

images.alt_text: NO WRONGDOING: Hedge funds have found legal ways to bet on Chinese derivatives and stocks without going through formal investment channels.

site_title: BlackRock bets on its huge data to revive equity funds
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink is betting on utilizing a trillion points of data to revive the firm's underperforming stock-picking business. Despite replacing many of its fundamental active equity managers, several funds have seen a decline in performance, with $7.5 billion pulled from them over the past year. Fink aims to give his stock-pickers an edge by allowing them to analyze data before rivals.

site_title: High banker pay is one hindrance for Frankfurt's tech startups
summary: Frankfurt's tech startups face a significant challenge in the city due to high banker pay, which hinders the growth of the financial technology sector. Despite having a wealth of financial knowledge, Frankfurt lags behind other cities like Berlin, London, and Silicon Valley in attracting fintech companies. Only 11 fintech firms operate in Frankfurt, and the city's high cost base and banker salaries make it difficult for startups to compete. The city's deputy mayor is holding talks with fintech representatives to support the sector, and the CEO of FinTech Group is moving the company's headquarters to a more creative environment to attract young talent and develop a dual studies and apprenticeship program in fintech.

site_title: Missing tanker found off Indonesia; cargo stolen
summary: A Singapore-registered oil tanker, MT Joaquim, has been found 14 nautical miles east of Pulau Rupat, Indonesia, after going missing in Malaysian waters. The tanker was carrying 3,500 tonnes of fuel oil worth $700,000. A 15-ship search operation involving Singapore, Thailand, and Indonesia was deployed. The cargo has been stolen, and the incident is under investigation.

site_title: Emerging markets suffer in Greece's shadow
summary: Emerging markets, including China, Brazil, and others, are facing economic challenges due to a slowdown in global growth, falling commodity prices, and currency devaluations. China's stock market has plummeted 30% since mid-June, affecting small investors and confidence in the government. Brazil's economy and currency have also slid to multi-year lows, while other emerging markets like Mexico and South Africa are experiencing similar issues. Economists attribute the problems to a lack of structural reforms and diversified industries in these markets, which are unable to absorb external shocks.

site_title: Indian borrowers seek short-term fixes as bad debts deter banks
summary: Indian borrowers are seeking short-term debt solutions due to banks' reluctance to lend, with companies turning to commercial paper markets for funding with maturities between 30 days and one year. This trend follows a slowdown in bank lending, the slowest pace in over 20 years. As a result, Indian borrowers are opting for shorter-term fixes to manage their finances, driven by banks' risk aversion.

site_title: Delta upgrades flights to avoid flying empty
summary: Delta Air Lines has begun upgrading some commercial flights to private jets to avoid flying empty. The airline's Delta Private Jets subsidiary will operate the upgraded flights, providing an impromptu private jet experience for elite frequent flyers. The first customers, Jeanette and Bruce Rogovin, reported a surreal experience with minimal cabin noise, likening it to a commuter regional jet. This upgrade is expected to increase revenue for Delta.

site_title: Tesla's response to hacked car sets the bar
summary: Researchers have identified software flaws in Tesla's Model S that could allow remote hackers to shut down a car's engine. However, Tesla quickly deployed a fix over the internet, setting a model for other carmakers to follow. The vulnerabilities required physical access to the car, making them less concerning than recent Jeep Cherokee hack. Experts emphasize the need for carmakers to implement over-the-air patching systems to address the increasing threat of computer attacks, and compartmentalize vehicle electronics to prevent hackers from accessing critical systems.

site_title: Investors give prime London homes a miss
summary: Investors in London's prime neighborhoods, such as Knightsbridge and Belgravia, are avoiding luxury homes due to higher sales taxes introduced by Chancellor George Osborne in December. The taxes, which can reach up to 12% of a home's cost, are deterring even the wealthiest buyers. As a result, buyers are turning to cheaper areas like Hackney, leading to a decrease in demand for luxury properties in London's upscale neighborhoods.

site_title: Embraer, Cessna roll out new models to woo back buyers
summary: Embraer and Cessna have unveiled new business jet models, the Legacy 450 and Citation Latitude, respectively, in an attempt to woo back buyers in the struggling market. Shipments of business jets fell 4.1% in the first half of the year due to weak demand from oil-dependent countries and emerging markets. The new models, which feature luxurious amenities and high-end features, are expected to stimulate demand as the US economy gains steam, with some analysts predicting a return to the same number of business jets delivered this year as last year.

site_title: Weak yen putting BOJ on collision course with Abe government
summary: Japan's yen has fallen 40% to a near 8-year low, reaching a critical level of 125 to the dollar, potentially triggering a new kind of currency crisis. Unlike past crises where the yen was too strong, this time, analysts believe political stresses may be the trigger. The weak yen puts the Bank of Japan (BOJ) on a collision course with the Abe government, as a strong yen can harm exports and economic growth. The BOJ may need to intervene to stabilize the currency, but its actions could be constrained by the government's stance on monetary policy.

site_title: The hard business of being Singapore
summary: Singapore is marking its 50th year of independence, a milestone that highlights the nation's remarkable achievements but also poses significant challenges. Despite its economic success, Singaporeans face an uncertain future, with issues like a widening income gap, resource scarcity, and demographic changes. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's succession and the loss of founding leader Lee Kuan Yew have also created uncertainty. As Singapore navigates its next 50 years, it must balance populist concerns with pragmatic solutions, and its people will need to find meaning and freedom in a rapidly changing world.

site_title: Whistleblowers: the directors' ally
summary: Whistleblowing is a crucial tool for reporting employee misconduct, including fraud, to help companies uncover breaches. The role of the board in supporting an effective whistleblowing policy is essential in creating an environment to prevent and detect misconduct. Key elements of a good whistleblowing policy include a clear process, assurance of protection for whistleblowers, and mechanisms to encourage reporting. The use of rewards for whistleblowers can also encourage reporting, but it's essential to balance the potential for delay in reporting with the need for confidentiality. A strong ethical culture, including clear expectations and mechanisms, is vital to encourage whistleblowing and reduce the risk of misconduct.

site_title: Quantitative easing with Chinese characteristics takes shape
summary: China's central bank is implementing a form of quantitative easing, known as "Chinese-style quantitative easing," to stimulate the economy without risking a debt surge. The People's Bank of China is providing funds to state lenders to finance government-backed programs, rather than directly financing projects or buying securities. This approach allows China to target stimulus towards the real economy, rather than the financial market. The move aims to cushion a slowdown in growth, with producer price deflation deepening and consumer inflation remaining below target.

site_title: Buying among directors falls, selling very low
summary: Directors in Singapore bought back shares worth S$2 million in the week ending Aug 6, with most purchases following earnings announcements by companies. This marks a decrease from the previous week's S$19.84 million in buybacks. Conversely, selling by directors remained low, with only one disposal of S$182,000 recorded. Companies such as Singapore Airlines, Global Logistic Properties, Viking Offshore and Marine, Lian Beng Group, and OCBC resumed buying back shares after announcing their earnings results.

site_title: Apollo buys most of Nicholas Schorsch's holdings
summary: Apollo Global Management LLC is buying the majority of Nicholas Schorsch's real estate holdings, including a $19 billion portfolio, for $378 million in cash and stock. The deal, which includes real estate investment trusts (Reits) and other investments, will give Apollo a 60% stake in a new company called AR Global Investments. The acquisition lifts Apollo's managed real estate assets to $27 billion and its total assets to $182 billion. Apollo aims to capitalize on growing demand for yield-oriented investment solutions.

site_title: Saudi data suggests budget crunch may be several years away
summary: Saudi Arabia's state finances remain strong despite falling oil prices, with the country's foreign reserves totaling $664.5 billion, enough to last at least three years. A study suggests the world may be entering a sustained period of low oil prices, but Saudi authorities have not yet faced a budget crunch. The kingdom plans to issue sovereign bonds to reduce reserve depletion and has room to issue bonds without increasing public debt. Economists expect Riyadh to start reducing spending in some areas, such as energy subsidies, next year.

site_title: 'Sexy cooking men' break kitchen barrier in S Korea
summary: In South Korea, a growing trend is seen as men take up cooking, challenging traditional gender roles. A cooking class for men, dubbed "Sexy cooking men," has gained popularity, with over 50 participants, including 53-year-old Lee Jin-soo, who joins his friends for a cooking session. This shift is attributed to changing demographics, increased female workforce participation, and the influence of reality TV shows featuring male chefs. The trend aims to promote a more equal distribution of household chores, with men taking on cooking responsibilities as a symbol of their commitment to their families.

site_title: Big Oil makes biggest cost cuts in a generation to protect dividends
summary: Big Oil companies, such as Chevron, Royal Dutch Shell, and BP, are making the largest cost cuts in a generation to protect their dividends, risking future growth. The cost cuts total $180 billion this year, the most since the 1986 oil crash. Executives are prioritizing dividend payouts, but this strategy may repeat the patterns of the past, leading to production declines. The companies maintain their multi-year output targets, but experts warn that continued cost-cutting could impact future reserves and production growth.

site_title: German trade surplus may rise to new high this year
summary: Germany's trade surplus is expected to rise to a new record of 8.1% of economic output in 2015, driven by falling oil and gas prices, according to a Finance Ministry document. The trade surplus would have fallen without the decline in oil and gas prices, and critics say it contributes to global imbalances. The European Commission has urged Germany to reduce its trade surplus and stimulate imports, but a recent record 24 billion euros trade surplus widened despite a fall in exports in June.

site_title: NY takes action on 'three-quarter' homes
summary: New York City has taken action on "three-quarter" homes, unregulated dwellings that often house people with addiction or mental illness. The city has moved over 200 residents from overcrowded homes to hotels, but many others remain in substandard conditions. Despite efforts to inspect and address the issue, unscrupulous providers continue to operate, and some tenants report being forced to attend specific substance-abuse treatment programs. The city plans to spend $5 million to inspect and repair homes, and will pay for tenants to transition to permanent housing.

site_title: The F1 boss, the tax probe and the lawyer
summary: Formula One (F1) boss Bernie Ecclestone is involved in a £1 billion tax fight with the British government, with his lawyer Stephen Mullens playing a key role. Mullens was a close adviser to Ecclestone and has seen the inner workings of the F1 series. Ecclestone claims he "gifted" his shares to his ex-wife Slavica, who put them in a trust he cannot access, while HMRC argues he benefited from the trust and should pay taxes. Mullens' involvement in the dispute is unclear, with Ecclestone denying any wrongdoing and Mullens not commenting on his role.

site_title: Release of secret Goldman files will be an exception, says Denmark
summary: Denmark's government has agreed to release secret documents on Goldman Sachs' 2014 investment in Dong Energy, a state-owned utility, after lawmakers complained of lack of access. The government claims the information was too sensitive, but Goldman and the pension funds involved have stated they have no objection to the files being made public. The decision is seen as an exception and not a precedent, with the government warning that stricter transparency standards could deter potential investors and lead to lower bids. The move comes after a controversy surrounding the Goldman deal led to the ousting of the previous government.

site_title: Jakarta urges America to hurry up and raise rates
summary: Jakarta's chief economics minister, Sofyan Djalil, urged the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates as soon as possible to alleviate downward pressure on the Indonesian rupiah. Djalil stated that the rupiah is undervalued and market expectations have already priced in the potential rate hike. He believes the currency will not drop significantly when the US eases monetary policy.

site_title: Nvidia forecasts sales that exceed analysts' estimates
summary: Nvidia Corp forecasts sales of $1.18 billion for the period ending in October, exceeding analysts' estimates of $1.1 billion. This marks the company's highest stock rise in over four years due to strong demand for high-end gaming machines.

site_title: Square's IPO complicated by CEO Dorsey's potential as Twitter chief
summary: Square's initial public offering (IPO) is complicated by CEO Jack Dorsey's potential departure to become Twitter's full-time CEO. If Dorsey leaves Square, the IPO may be delayed or its valuation could decrease. Square has confidentially filed for an IPO and has prepared for the possibility of Dorsey's departure, with advisers considering alternative scenarios. The company's stability and leadership ahead of its planned IPO are now in question, with investors expressing concerns about the potential change in management.

site_title: China video services take censorship into own hands, study shows
summary: China's largest social video websites, serving over 100 million users, operate under hazy censorship policies that grant them broad leeway in deciding what content to block. Researchers reverse-engineered applications and found that these websites monitor thousands of words and phrases, scrub private messages, and block posts or messages at the client or software level. The websites' keyword lists, which include topics such as Tiananmen, Xi Jinping, and Falun Gong, suggest a lack of a "monolithic" set of regulations governing censorship in China.

site_title: Stocks beset by rate hike worries, oil bust
summary: US stocks remain under pressure due to rate hike worries and the oil bust, despite a strong jobs report that suggests a September rate hike may still be in play. The Standard & Poor's 500 is expected to remain in a "giant range" between 2,100 and 2,300 until the Fed acts, with some sectors like banking strengthening while commodities and energy companies continue to decline.

images.alt_text: OIL DEPENDENT: It is expected to be a rocky second half of the year for oil as a further slide in prices could begin to affect the rate of growth on the industrial side of the US economy.

site_title: Athens discussing draft of third bailout deal
summary: Greek government officials discussed a draft of the country's third bailout agreement, worth up to 86 billion euros, with EU/IMF lenders. site_title: TV industry sees digital threat rising as viewing habits change
summary: The TV industry is facing a digital threat as viewing habits shift towards online streaming services. To adapt, TV companies are investing in content and exploring streaming offerings, with Disney CEO Bob Iger viewing Netflix as a potential partner rather than a threat.

site_title: China retains IMF reserve-currency backing
summary: China has retained support from major economies, including Germany and Brazil, for the yuan to be recognized as a reserve currency by the International Monetary Fund (IMF). site_title: 'Sharing economy' creates labour poser
summary: The "sharing economy" has led to a shift of millions of US workers to freelance "gig" work, providing independence but lacking social safety nets. Lawsuits and politician calls for regulation argue that these workers are not independent contractors, but employees entitled to benefits. Policymakers must set clear rules to avoid disputes and uncertainty, with experts suggesting unbundling benefits, decoupling traditional benefits from the workplace, or creating portable savings plans.

site_title: Moxian dreams big: to be next killer app
summary: Singaporean entrepreneur James Tan aims to turn Moxian China into a giant integrated online-to-offline social marketing platform, backed by China's massive population. With a strong backing, Moxian China is poised to become the next killer app, revolutionizing social marketing and changing the face of the industry.

site_title: Falling oil prices hurt Angola's economy as govt cuts spending
summary: Angola's economy is struggling due to falling oil prices, which account for 70% of taxes and 95% of export income. The country's credit profile remains vulnerable, and the World Bank has approved a $450 million loan to help shore up the economy.

site_title: European banks brace for more changes
summary: European banks are bracing for changes under Basel IV, a comprehensive overhaul of the Basel III framework. Banks have expressed concerns over the uncertainty and implementation costs associated with the changes, citing higher operational risk and the European Central Bank's harmonization of rules. The regulator, however, claims to have completed its regulatory reform agenda and is focusing on adjusting existing rules rather than overhauling the framework.

site_title: Oilfield giants have new sales pitch
summary: Oilfield giants Schlumberger and Halliburton are offering a new financing option to crude producers halting work, dubbed "frack now and pay later." The move aims to book sales of new technologies as the companies scramble to generate revenue amid a 60% decline in crude prices. Refracking, a cheaper alternative to drilling new wells, is being promoted as a solution to boost output. However, its potential demand is uncertain, with some analysts predicting it will take time to gain traction.

site_title: American Air, Sabre hit by hackers: sources
summary: A China-backed group of hackers has breached the systems of American Air and Sabre Corp, a travel reservation processing company, as part of attacks on US victims. The attacks are part of a larger pattern of cyber attacks by the same group.

site_title: Pressure to ease policy mounts as China economy falters
summary: China's economy is under pressure to stimulate growth after disappointing data showed a 8.3% decline in exports and a 5.4% drop in producer prices, the lowest since 2009. China's corporate debt stands at 160% of GDP, and the country's corporate debt burden is expected to worsen. The government's target of a 7% economic growth rate for this year may be challenging, with some economists believing the actual growth rate is slower.

site_title: Singapore's largest 'pioneer companies' among those with strong stocks
summary: Singapore's largest pioneer companies, with business foundations dating back to 1960-1969, are among the top-performing stocks on the SGX. The Singapore government's focus on green and transition finance is also expected to drive growth in the country's financial sector.

site_title: Australia probes hundreds of home purchases by foreigners
summary: Australia is investigating hundreds of cases of foreigners unlawfully owning residential properties, with 462 cases under investigation. The government aims to enforce rules that restrict foreign ownership of existing residential properties, with tougher penalties set to be introduced. This crackdown comes amid concerns that foreign investment has inflated the market in cities like Sydney and Melbourne.

site_title: 50 years of peace, safety, stability
summary: Singapore marks 50 years of peace, safety, and stability, with national service playing a crucial role in the country's defense. The Singapore government and businesses are committed to maintaining stability, peace, and prosperity, ensuring a secure future for the nation and its people.

site_title: TV industry sees digital threats rising
summary: The TV industry is facing rising digital threats, potentially disrupting its lucrative business model. With the rise of streaming services like Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon video, viewers are increasingly choosing to subscribe to individual channels or opt for free streaming options. This has led to modest subscriber losses and a decline in shares for major TV groups, including Disney, Viacom, and 21st Century Fox. While some analysts downplay the risks, others warn that the industry's traditional model may be falling apart, with children's channels and sports viewing potentially most vulnerable.

site_title: China July producer prices slump to near 6-year low
summary: China's producer prices fell 5.4% in July, the lowest in six years, while consumer inflation remained at 1.6%, indicating deflationary pressures and sluggish economic growth. site_title: The Ponzi scheme that might pay victims

site_title: New Diet Pepsi: Same silver can, but no Aspartame

site_title: Wishing Singapore a fortuitous tomorrow
summary: Singapore establishes a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, aiming to increase the region's aviation sector. site_title: Jubilant celebrations for Singapore's 50th National Day
summary: Singaporeans celebrated the nation's 50th National Day with a grand parade, attended by 26,000 people at the Padang and over 200,000 more in the Marina Bay area. The parade featured performances by local artists and a special "Five Stars" tribute to late founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew. site_title: Powerful storm hits Taiwan, millions without power, 4 dead
summary: A powerful typhoon, Typhoon Soudelor, hit Taiwan on August 8, 2015, causing widespread damage and disruption. site_title: Singapore has much to celebrate - and look forward to - as it turns 50: PM Lee
summary: Singapore is celebrating its 50th birthday, marked by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's National Day Message. Lee Hsien Loong expressed optimism about the country's future, citing the strength of its people and the nation's ability to press on towards new peaks ahead.
