site_title: BOJ chief hints at shifting inflation-target date again, adjusting policy
summary: BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda hinted at adjusting the central bank's policy to achieve its 2% annual inflation target, citing the impact of oil prices on inflation. The BOJ has left its current policy intact, but Kuroda acknowledged that the timing of the target may change depending on future oil price moves. The BOJ aims to achieve the target within the first half of fiscal 2016, with consumer inflation currently hovering around zero due to low energy costs.

site_title: World's priciest wine is rare Burgundy at US$15,195 a bottle
summary: The world's priciest wine, a rare Burgundy, has sold for US$15,195 per bottle, according to Wine-Searcher. The Richebourg Grand Cru, created by winemaker Henri Jayer, was recognized just after being named a UNESCO World Heritage site. Jayer's wine is part of a list of 50 most expensive wines, with Burgundies dominating the top spots, including Romanee-Conti in second place at US$13,314. The recognition of Burgundy's vineyards as a UNESCO World Heritage site may bring economic benefits for the region.

site_title: Bond traders brace for more turbulence in short-term treasuries
summary: Bond traders expect a high probability of a Federal Reserve interest rate increase in September, with yields on Treasury two-year notes rising 6 basis points this week. The probability of an increase surged to 58% after data showed sustained labor-market growth and comments from Atlanta Fed president Dennis Lockhart suggesting the US economy may merit a rate hike. Traders are paying 6.2% more to protect against swings in two-year notes, with retail sales data set to release on August 13 potentially influencing views on the timing of the Fed's first rate increase since 2006.

site_title: German bonds set to get boost as eurozone inflation seen lagging
summary: German bonds are expected to receive a boost due to eurozone inflation seen lagging at 0.2% in July, far below the European Central Bank's target of close to 2%. This could convince traders that the ECB's quantitative-easing plan will last until September 2016. As a result, Germany's benchmark 10-year bunds rallied, with yields rising two basis points to 0.66%. The news suggests the policy divergence between the ECB and the Federal Reserve remains intact, with the US Federal Reserve potentially raising interest rates in September.

site_title: Athens in 'intense' talks to avoid another loan default
summary: Greece and its creditors held "intense talks" over a new bailout package to avoid another loan default. The talks aim to agree on reforms in exchange for a third bailout of up to $86 billion. The European Central Bank requires an agreement by August 20, when Greece must repay $5.1 billion. Despite progress, sticking points remain, and officials from the ECB, IMF, and European Stability Mechanism continue to work on a draft memorandum of understanding. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras expressed optimism that an agreement will be reached by August 20, preventing another default.

site_title: Dalian Wanda finalising deal for Ironman
summary: Chinese property and investment firm Dalian Wanda Group is in exclusive talks to acquire US owner of Ironman triathlon franchise World Triathlon Corp for over $850 million. This deal would underscore China's increasing appetite for US media assets, particularly in live events and sports brands. Dalian Wanda outbid other potential buyers and is now in negotiations to finalize the deal with private equity firm Providence Equity Partners LLC.

site_title: Mexico's economy starting to flop
summary: Mexico's economy is struggling, with the peso sinking to record lows against the US dollar and growth rates shrinking. The country's first oil auction, aimed at boosting the economy, was a disappointment, with only two out of 14 blocks sold. The government has modified the terms of the contracts for the next auction and faces a string of bad news for its economy, which is Latin America's second largest. The country's poverty rate has also increased, further exacerbating the economic challenges.

site_title: Twitter considers board shakeup, may include exit of Costolo: Bloomberg
summary: Twitter's board is considering a shake-up that may include the exit of former CEO Dick Costolo, Bloomberg reported. The changes aim to make the board more diverse, potentially expanding or shuffling its composition to include directors from various backgrounds. Twitter's interim CEO, Jack Dorsey, may be succeeded by a permanent CEO from a diverse pool of candidates, including Ross Levinsohn, Mike McCue, Kevin Systrom, and Evan Williams.

site_title: Finland could stay out of new Greek bailout - foreign minister
summary: Finland's foreign minister, Timo Soini, suggests the Nordic country could stay out of a planned third bailout deal for Greece, amid growing criticism of the EU and calls for tougher restrictions on immigration. Finland has taken a hard line against bailouts, and Soini says his government won't accept increasing liabilities or cuts in Greece's debts. The EU's bailout fund could be used only within its current capacity, and Soini believes 'Grexit' is the most likely scenario in the long term.

images.alt_text: Finland could stay out of a planned third bailout deal for Greece, the Nordic country's Eurosceptic foreign minister said on Saturday, amid calls from his nationalist party, The Finns, for a more critical stance towards the EU.

site_title: Three European Coca-Cola bottlers to merge
summary: Three European Coca-Cola bottlers, Coca-Cola Enterprises, Coca-Cola Iberian Partners, and the German bottling business, are merging to create the world's largest independent bottler of Coke drinks by net revenue. The new company will operate in 13 countries, including Spain, France, and Britain, aiming to boost sluggish soft-drink sales through greater scale and cost-cutting measures.

site_title: China's July trade surplus down 10% to 263b yuan
summary: China's July trade surplus decreased by 10% to 263 billion yuan, with exports falling 8.9% and imports dropping 8.6%. The decline in exports, mainly due to a stronger yuan, could indicate weak domestic demand. China's economy, the world's second-largest, has been slowing, with growth rates of 7.4% in 2014 and 7.0% in the first two quarters of 2015. The government aims for annual growth of 7.0% in 2015, and recent interest rate cuts have been made to boost the economy.

site_title: Consumer borrowing in US increased more than forecast in June
summary: US consumer borrowing increased by $20.7 billion in June, exceeding forecasts, driven by higher credit-card balances and automobile lending. This surge pushed borrowing rates to a 7% increase in the second quarter, the fastest in a year. The rise in consumer spending is seen as a positive sign for the US economy, bolstering growth in the second half of 2015.

images.alt_text: American consumer borrowing rose more than forecast in June on bigger credit-card balances and a pickup in lending for automobiles.

site_title: EU finds no evidence of illegal activity in Apple's music streaming deals: report
summary: The European Commission has found no evidence of illegal activity in Apple's music streaming deals with record labels and online music streaming services. The investigation, launched in April, did not uncover any evidence of antitrust violations, but the EU will continue to monitor the market. The regulators are seeking information from Spotify and other music streaming services on restrictions Apple places on apps offered through the App Store. This decision comes as the US government also investigates claims about whether Apple's treatment of rival streaming music apps is illegal under antitrust law.

site_title: For Singapore's wealthiest, land is riches
summary: Singapore's wealthiest individuals have built their wealth largely through real estate, thanks to land banks accumulated before independence. Many property tycoons have maintained their wealth over time, with some even passing it down to their children. The concentration of wealth in real estate is a significant factor in the country's economic landscape, with some individuals holding substantial land banks.

site_title: Several foreigners held, at least seven killed in Mali hotel siege
summary: A hotel siege in central Mali resulted in at least seven deaths, including several foreigners, and seven suspects being detained after gunmen stormed the hotel during a shootout with soldiers. At least five troops and two attackers were killed in the initial attack, which targeted a UN mission site. A Ukrainian hostage escaped and reported being with three South Africans and a Russian. The attack is the third in a week in Mali, which is still battling a resurgence in jihadist violence.

site_title: Berkshire profit falls 37% on investment, insurance slump
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway reported a 37% decline in second-quarter profit to $4.01 billion, primarily due to a significant drop in investment gains and an underwriting loss from insurance operations. Operating profit fell 10% to $3.89 billion, despite improvements at BNSF railroad and Berkshire Hathaway Energy units. Revenue rose 3% to $51.37 billion, with book value per share increasing 2% to $149,735. Net investment and derivative gains plummeted 94% to $123 million.

site_title: Tesla's response to hacked car offers a road map for fast fixes
summary: Tesla quickly deployed a fix after cybersecurity researchers discovered six software flaws in the Model S that could allow remote hackers to shut down a moving car's engine. The vulnerabilities were found by Kevin Mahaffey and Marc Rogers, who alerted Tesla and coordinated a fix before the DefCon hacker conference. The fix was made available through the car's infotainment screen, similar to smartphone updates. Tesla's response offers a model for other automakers to address the increasing threat of computer attacks, showcasing a proactive approach to cybersecurity.

site_title: From pariah to acceptance
summary: A recent study, Trial to Assess Chelation Therapy (TACT), has found that chelation therapy significantly reduces heart complications in diabetics with heart disease. The study, which involved over 1,700 patients, showed a 26% decrease in heart complications when patients received chelation therapy with oral vitamins. This benefit was even more pronounced in diabetic patients, who experienced a 41% decrease in heart complications. The US FDA has reviewed the study in a positive light and is supporting a TACT2 study to confirm the results.

site_title: Virgin Australia expects return to profitability by next June
summary: Virgin Australia expects to return to profitability by next June, marking the first time in four years, by shifting long-haul routes to its low-cost Tigerair subsidiary. The airline will move several Bali routes and pull out of flights to Phuket, while adding flights to New Zealand, Fiji, and the Solomon Islands. The move aims to reverse international losses and save around A$162 million on fuel bills. CEO John Borghetti said the company is "on track" to report a return to profitability, but dividend payments are still uncertain.

site_title: China's rush to buy energy assets stalls
summary: China's state-owned energy firms, including PetroChina, Sinopec, and CNOOC, have halted their rapid expansion plans due to the slump in crude prices and increased scrutiny from Beijing's anti-graft campaign. The firms are now focusing on cutting costs and improving returns from existing assets rather than pursuing new purchases. This shift is expected to last for at least three to five years, with some firms considering selling "non-core" assets. The slowdown in acquisitions may have implications for projects in eastern Africa, which require significant investment to exploit.

site_title: US: Stocks drop on worries over cable business, Apple
summary: US stocks declined this week, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.79% and the S&P 500 dropping 1.25%. Cable and media stocks, including Disney and Viacom, suffered double-digit declines due to concerns over the cable business. Apple shares also plummeted 11.6% since its July earnings report, sparking worries about sales in the slowing Chinese economy. Despite this, some biopharmaceutical and food companies saw gains, and the US economy added 215,000 jobs in July, suggesting the Federal Reserve may soon lift interest rates.

site_title: Zynga in US$23m settlement over alleged fraud tied to IPO
summary: Zynga reached a $23 million settlement with shareholders over alleged fraud tied to its initial public offering (IPO) in 2011. The settlement resolves claims that the company concealed declining user activity, masked demand changes, and inflated revenue forecasts. The agreement, which requires judicial approval, removes the distraction of protracted litigation and will not impact the company financially, as insurers will fund the payout. Zynga began struggling after its IPO due to the failure to develop popular games and the rise of mobile gaming.

site_title: China eyes new frontier in rail technology
summary: China Railway Signal's Hong Kong listing marks a push to market Chinese rail technology overseas, particularly in emerging markets. The company values at HK$55.1 billion and will use 20% of IPO proceeds for acquisitions and R&D. The move comes amid a major push to market Chinese railway technology globally, driven by China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative and a government plan to make China an advanced industrialised economy. The company's transportation control system offers high margins and moderate growth potential.

site_title: Lawyer Ghandi said to join Fifa task force amid internal probe
summary: American lawyer Samir Ghandi has been nominated to join a task force at FIFA, amid an internal probe, following the arrest of senior officials on corruption charges. Ghandi, who is reorganizing the regional soccer body Concacaf, will represent Concacaf alongside Victor Montagliani, president of the Canadian Soccer Association. The task force aims to suggest reforms to FIFA, which is seeking to recover from its worst crisis in 111 years. This move comes as FIFA seeks to address corruption allegations and implement changes to its governance structure.

site_title: Honest Company in new private fundraising round: sources
summary: The Honest Company, co-founded by actress Jessica Alba, has launched a new private fundraising round valued at $1.5 billion to $2 billion. The company is on track for an initial public offering (IPO) in the second half of 2016. The fundraising will be used to fund growth initiatives, including the launch of its makeup line and expansion of its retail presence. This is another step towards the company's growth, following its previous fundraising round in 2014, which valued it at $1 billion.

site_title: Irish financiers feed on builders as cheap loans fade into past
summary: Ireland's builders are turning to alternative financiers due to banks' hesitation to lend, as cheap credit dries up. Irish financiers, such as Elkstone Private Advisors, are taking equity stakes in developments and providing high-risk loans to builders with interest rates over 10%. This shift comes after the 2008 real-estate collapse devastated the economy, and banks are now wary of lending. Developers must now secure 30% of project costs from alternative sources, leading to reduced profit margins.

site_title: How brands can continue to thrive
summary: Consumer goods companies have adapted to slow market growth and investor pressure to cut costs, resulting in 10-year-high operating margins. Despite this, nearly half of top-valued companies in 1999 no longer rank in the top 20 by market capitalization in 2015. To thrive, companies should focus on five areas: igniting revenue growth through strategic pricing and selective innovation, taking out and keeping out costs, reinventing their supply chains, future-proofing their capabilities, and building agile teams. By adopting these approaches, companies can overcome future headwinds and maintain their competitive edge.

site_title: Wearable technology creeps into workplace
summary: Wearable technology is increasingly being adopted in the workplace to improve efficiency and productivity. Companies are using devices such as smartwatches and fitness trackers to monitor employee health, track work hours, and optimize logistics. However, this trend raises concerns about employee privacy and the potential for data breaches. Critics argue that wearable technology can create an oppressive working environment and that companies must be cautious in how they implement these programs to avoid damaging staff morale. As a result, many experts recommend pairing wearable devices with robust security measures and obtaining employee consent before collecting and using their personal data.

site_title: EU told Greece on track for possible bailout deal next week: source
summary: Greece is on track to complete a draft deal with international creditors on a third bailout by next Tuesday, with a possible first disbursement by August 20, according to a source. Smooth talks are proceeding, with the Greek government and parliament expected to approve the draft memorandum of understanding and debt sustainability analysis by Thursday. Eurozone finance ministers may endorse an 86 billion euro three-year loan programme for Athens by Friday, completing the deal.

site_title: 215,000 jobs added in July in broad-based gain
summary: The US economy added 215,000 jobs in July, with the unemployment rate remaining at a seven-year low of 5.3%. This marks the third consecutive month of broad-based job gains, indicating companies' confidence in demand despite a tempered global growth outlook. Average hourly earnings rose 2.1% from a year earlier, but wage growth remains sluggish. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates soon, with many economists forecasting a September lift-off, driven by the labor market's continued progress and rising consumer spending.

site_title: Housing Singapore
summary: Singapore's housing market is expected to face challenges with the upcoming Q3 condo launches, particularly those above the S$3,000 per square foot (psf) benchmark. The launch of prime projects may test demand, while US mortgage rates have climbed after five consecutive weeks of decline. Meanwhile, Manhattan rents have reached a record high, with further increases anticipated. The US and UK housing markets also saw significant transactions, including a Goldman Sachs acquisition in Seoul and a rebound in UK homebuyer demand. These trends signal a shift in the global real estate landscape.

site_title: Team KPMG: leveraging on one another's strengths
summary: Team KPMG participated in The Business Times Corporate Golf League 2015, a tradition since its inception in 2010. Partner Barry Lee praises the team's strategy, focusing on enjoying the game and company. He highlights the strength of the team, saying their individual skills complement each other, enabling them to work well together despite varying handicaps. The team aims to "leverage on each other's strengths" to achieve a low score and friendly competition.

site_title: China funds waiting with 'ammunition' to re-enter stock market: state media
summary: China has approximately 300 funds overseeing $223 billion, holding little to no position in the market following a 25% crash in June and July. These funds, known as "ammunition," are waiting to re-enter the stock market at any time, citing a lack of confidence due to government intervention and restrictions on trading. Foreign investors such as UBS and BlackRock have expressed optimism about the regulator's market rescue actions, but many are wary of putting money back into the market due to ongoing intervention. This has led to a delay in China's economic reform push.

site_title: Not all billionaires fulfil their pledges
summary: The Giving Pledge, created by Bill Gates and Warren Buffett, has seen 193 individuals sign the pledge to donate more than half of their fortune in life or death. However, public disclosures show that only two signatories, Michael Bloomberg and George Mitchell, have fulfilled the pledge, donating over $1 billion each. Many others have given away less than half of their wealth, with some using tax planning strategies to minimize their donations. Despite the lack of fulfillment, the Giving Pledge aims to reset levels of giving and inspire society through iconic figures like Gates and Buffett, who have donated billions to charity themselves.

site_title: Alibaba signs exclusive tie-ups with apparel brands
summary: Alibaba has signed exclusive partnerships with over 20 international apparel brands, including Zara and Timberland, to sell their products on its online marketplace Tmall.com in China. The agreements mark Alibaba's efforts to attract big international brands as it competes with JD.com. Financial terms of the deals were not disclosed.

site_title: Co-founder of TWG Tea honoured by Morocco's King
summary: Singapore's co-founder of luxury tea company TWG Tea, Taha Bouqdib, was honored by Morocco's King Mohammed for his contributions to the company's success. Bouqdib was decorated with the Order of National Recompense for his work. The ceremony, which recognized 37 prominent individuals worldwide, took place last Friday.

site_title: Value proposition
summary: The Ford Kuga is a full-size SUV with a long list of standard equipment, including self-levelling bi-xenon headlamps, adaptive cruise control, and a motorised tailgate. Despite a conservative design, the Kuga projects a youthful appeal and offers a comfortable, well-appointed cabin with good-quality materials and generous space. The 1.498cc turbocharged engine produces 180hp and 240Nm, providing respectable fuel economy. However, the Kuga's high price and lack of local popularity in Singapore may hinder its sales success.

site_title: Sing50 rocks crowd of 40,000
summary: Sing50, a 50-year musical journey of Singapore, took place at the National Stadium, featuring 250 local musicians playing iconic songs from the past five decades. The event was organized by The Business Times and The Straits Times, celebrating Singapore's rich musical heritage.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

LIVING LEGACY: It was a night of spectacle and nostalgia as past and present icons of Singapore's music industry performed hits from the past 50 years to a sellout audience at the National Stadium. On stage for the show finale with Dick Lee are SPH chairman Lee Boon Yang, Minister of Education Heng Swee Keat, President Tony Tan and his wife Mary, and SPH editor-in-chief of English/Malay/Tamil Media Group Patrick Daniel.

site_title: China's stock crash spurs shakeout in shadow banks
summary: China's shadow banks, which provide loans for equity purchases, have seen a significant decline in lending after the government banned them from funding stock buying. Loans plummeted by at least 700 billion yuan, a 61% drop from this year's peak, due to stricter regulations. The ban aims to curb debt-fuelled growth and reduce risk, with President Xi Jinping curbing unregulated funding. While some riskier lenders have been culled, experts believe the industry will become more disciplined and transparent in the long term.

site_title: It's Bank of Singapore's day
summary: Bank of Singapore (OCBC) secured the second spot overall in The Business Times Corporate Golf League 2015 with a stableford score of 110 in the third leg at TMCC. The team now has 308 points, behind leaders Seagull Gayatri. Captain Olivier Denis expressed pride in the team's outstanding performance and great team spirit, attributing their success to strong momentum from previous legs. The team plans to maintain their momentum to stay competitive.

site_title: Moody's plans ratings rules that may lift property bond grades
summary: Moody's Investors Service plans to change its rating rules for commercial mortgage-backed securities, potentially raising grades on many deals and increasing business. The firm will adjust its loan-to-value ratios for single asset/single borrower and multi-borrower large-loan transactions after they "performed in line with or exceeded Moody's expectations" following the 2008 financial crisis. This move may bring Moody's more business, but also raises questions about whether the firm is caving to pressure from Wall Street banks. The changes are expected to result in ratings increases of one to three levels on many deals.

site_title: All-conquering Outlander
summary: The Mitsubishi Outlander, Singapore's bestselling SUV, has received a facelift, boosting its appeal with a more edgy design. The updated model features a new continuously variable transmission and improved sound insulation. Despite its large size and ponderous handling, the Outlander offers a comfortable ride and ample cargo space. Its value proposition, with a price under S$130k, has contributed to its popularity, making it a top choice for those seeking a comfortable, upmarket drive at an affordable price.

site_title: Investors exit as funds suffer losses from commodity slump
summary: Investors are exiting hedge funds focused on commodities, with losses averaging in the first half of 2015. Cargill's Black River Asset Management unit and others, including Armajaro Asset Management and Carlyle Group's Vermillion Asset Management, have shut or closed their funds due to dwindling investor demand. The Bloomberg Commodity Index has tumbled 29% in the past year, and commodity-oriented hedge funds now manage $24 billion, 15% below peak levels three years ago. Managers are vulnerable to betting on rising prices, leaving them exposed to the current commodity slump.

site_title: Honda's new sports car a hit with older customers
summary: Honda's new sports car, the S660, has sold out its 8,600 units for this year, with four in five buyers over 40 years old. This is a stark contrast to its predecessor, the S2000, which attracted younger buyers. The company's failure to attract younger customers is attributed to stagnant incomes and efficient public transportation in Japan, where the number of driver's license holders under 40 has decreased by 46% over the past 13 years. Honda plans to restart taking orders in October, but analysts warn it will be a challenge to lure younger buyers.

site_title: Italian-Thai to develop US$500m LNG terminal in Myanmar's Dawei
summary: Italian-Thai Development PCL is in talks with Myanmar authorities to build a US$500 million liquefied natural gas (LNG) import terminal at Dawei industrial zone in southern Myanmar as part of a US$1.7 billion deal to develop the first phase of the Dawei project, which includes a 450-megawatt gas-fired power plant.

site_title: India steel mills seen cutting prices on China export surge
summary: India's steel mills are expected to cut prices by up to 10% due to a surge in Chinese exports and a glut on global markets. Chinese steelmakers maintain production despite economic slowdown, relying on exports to drive sales. This comes as India's steel imports rose 53% in Q2, with average prices set to drop by 1,500 rupees per tonne.

site_title: F&N's Q3 net profit down 9%
summary: F&N, a Singaporean beverage and printing company, reported a 9% drop in net profit to S$40 million for its Q3 2015. Revenue rose 3.7% to S$645.2 million, driven by a 5% growth in its food & beverage segment. Printing and publishing revenue was marginally lower, and earnings were affected by higher operating costs, unfavorable exchange rates, and higher taxation. The company attributed the decline to challenging business conditions in Malaysia and Thailand, with consumer sentiment impacted by economic growth and commodity prices.

site_title: Stolen Stradivarius recovered after 35 years
summary: A 1734 Stradivarius violin stolen 35 years ago from American concert violinist Roman Totenberg's office has been recovered. The US$5 million instrument was taken in 1980 from the Longy School of Music in Boston. Totenberg's heirs plan to sell the violin to raise funds. The recovery was made possible by a luthier's keen expert eye, bringing a happy ending to a long-standing mystery.

images.alt_text: CLASSIC INHERITANCE: The Totenberg sisters posing with the recovered Stradivarius violin in New York. The violin, made in 1734, had been stolen in 1980.

site_title: Singapore ought to loosen up a bit for business, innovation
summary: Singapore marks its 50th anniversary as an independent state, having achieved unprecedented prosperity with a GDP tripling between 2000 and 2013. However, the nation's success is being tested as it faces challenges such as an aging population, high property prices, and a growing divide between rich and poor. The government must balance its paternalistic system with the need for entrepreneurship and innovation, as well as navigate the challenges of slowing growth and the rise of China. Despite these concerns, Singapore remains a stable and secure nation, defying predictions of decline and serving as a model for other countries.

site_title: Oil down, heads for 6th weekly loss on gasoline glut
summary: Crude oil prices plummeted, reaching six-month lows, as gasoline glut and strong US jobs growth fueled a sixth consecutive weekly loss. The dollar's rise against currencies also weighed on oil, while traders awaited the weekly oil rig count reading for signs of rising production. Brent and US crude fell 1.5% and 1.1% respectively, with gasoline hitting 5-1/2 month lows. Analysts predict seasonal refinery maintenance and stock builds could drag on crude futures in coming months.

site_title: China funds buck stock rout to lead global performance rankings
summary: China's mutual funds have dominated the world's strongest performers despite a 30% decline in Chinese stocks since June. Eighty-two of the top-100 best-performing equity mutual funds focus on Chinese stocks, returning 20.5% on average, more than twice the gain in the CSI300 index. Foreign investors are buying more shares, and experts expect the market to consolidate, with valuations for small and mid-cap stocks remaining high. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers, while Chinese banks face challenges from Beijing's consumer lending push.

site_title: Housing: The people's equity stake in S'pore
summary: Singapore's home ownership policy has led to a surge in double and triple home ownership, sparking concerns about policy interventions. The government's goal of 100% home ownership has been achieved, but some now question whether it has gone too far. With Singaporeans owning multiple homes for investment and speculation, the government has introduced cooling measures such as buyer's stamp duty and Total Debt Servicing Ratio framework to curb speculation and maintain affordable housing for Singaporeans. Despite this, home ownership remains a cornerstone of Singapore's society, with over 90% of residents owning their homes, and the government continues to balance providing affordable housing with attracting globally mobile talent and wealth.

site_title: EU officials to review progress in Greek bailout talks
summary: EU officials will review progress in Greek bailout talks on Friday, amid concerns over the pace of negotiations and the need for fiscal discipline. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is pushing for a deal by mid-August, while Germany is skeptical of an early agreement. The European Commission says talks are moving "in a satisfactory way," but a comprehensive reform program is still needed. A bridge loan is possible if talks take longer, with a potential second loan of up to 5 billion euros.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after jobs data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, August 7, 2015, after data showed steady job growth in July, increasing the chances of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in September. The Dow Jones fell 0.18%, the S&P 500 lost 0.14%, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 0.28%.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide on media tumble and US rate rise bets
summary: European stocks fell 0.9% to 397.07, cutting their weekly gain to 0.2%, as media shares declined and US rate rise bets increased. Greece's ASE Index rose 1.5%, while US employers added 215,000 jobs in July, holding the unemployment rate at a seven-year low. The US Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates next month, and investors are uncertain about the drivers of stock growth during the summer period.

site_title: Audi quattro getting into form
summary: Audi quattro is gaining form in The Business Times Corporate Golf League 2015, according to team captain Jeff Mannering. The team is currently in 11th position with 272 points, with players Godfrey Robert and Raju Arivazagan making valuable contributions. Audi Singapore is sponsoring the latest Audi A6 1.8 TFSI ultra S tronic as the Hole-In-One prize for all six games. The team is pleased with the quality golf courses and networking opportunities provided by the competition, citing these as reasons for their return as the presenting sponsor.

site_title: Greece says expects to pass bailout in parliament on Aug 18
summary: Greece's government expects to pass its third bailout package in parliament on August 18, securing fresh loans of up to $94 billion to stave off economic collapse. The scheduled vote comes after a "good climate" in talks with international lenders, according to the Greek government's spokeswoman. This move aims to prevent Greece from defaulting on its debt to the European Central Bank, which is set to make a key payment on August 18.
