site_title: Hedge-fund sector: Singapore's success story set to continue
summary: Singapore's hedge-fund sector continues to thrive, with assets managed locally reaching $33.3 billion at the end of 2014, up from $20.3 billion in 2012. The number of funds managing money from Singapore has grown steadily since 2010, with 289 funds as of June 2015. The industry is subject to strict standards and regulations, but this has not deterred new fund launches and membership in the Alternative Investment Management Association (Aima) has increased by over 40% in the last 18 months.

site_title: India's Tata Motors profits slump on weak China sales
summary: India's Tata Motors reported a 48.70% decline in quarterly profits to 27.69 billion rupees (US$432.66 million) due to weak sales of its luxury British unit, Jaguar Land Rover (JLR), in China. JLR sold half the number of luxury cars in the same period last year, primarily driven by weak Chinese market. Despite a sales increase in India, the company's revenue slid 5.57% and JLR's revenue fell to 5 billion pounds (US$7.76 billion). Tata Motors' reliance on JLR revenue remains a concern.

site_title: China's central bank warns about rising debt levels
summary: China's central bank has warned about rising debt levels, citing an overall increase in financial risks. The People's Bank of China attributed the issue to the government's continued reliance on infrastructure spending to drive the economy. The bank predicted headwinds in the near term due to wide-ranging reforms. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Stock exchanges must improve trading model: Norway wealth fund
summary: The Norwegian Government Pension Fund Global has stated that global stock exchanges are failing to meet the needs of large institutional traders, losing out to private equity in company cash raises. The fund, with $875 billion assets, urges exchanges to adapt and innovate to enhance attractiveness to institutional investors, focusing on large trade execution and maintaining liquidity risk premium. The fund also expresses concern over a drop-off in initial public offerings in the US and Europe, encouraging exchanges to develop new solutions to raise capital.

site_title: European stock funds worldwide attract US$3.3b in week: BofA
summary: Investors worldwide poured $3.3 billion into European stock funds in the week ended Aug 5, marking their 12th straight week of inflows. Meanwhile, US-focused stock funds experienced their third straight week of withdrawals, with $4.3 billion being pulled out. Overall, stock funds attracted $700 million in new cash for the fifth straight week, while bond funds drew in $2 billion after a $400 million outflow the prior week.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Friday, closing at 1,682.65 after a 11.99-point drop. The index saw 1.86 billion lots traded, with 187 gainers and 722 losers.

site_title: Bill Gross says global economy dangerously close to deflation
summary: Bill Gross, a money manager at Janus Capital Group, warns that the global economy is "dangerously close to deflationary growth." He cites the low CRB Commodity Index, which is lower than its 2008 level, as a sign of deflationary pressures. Gross believes the commodity markets provide a more accurate reflection of economic conditions than traditional indicators. His comments come as the global economy faces slowing growth and rising deflation concerns.

site_title: Slide in Malaysia's reserves adds pressure to ringgit and ratings
summary: Malaysia's international reserves fell to $96.7 billion as of July 31, adding pressure to the ringgit, which has reached a 17-year low against the US dollar. The decline in reserves could lead to capital controls, as the currency's volatility prompts concerns about confidence levels. The ringgit's value is expected to slide towards 4.00 to a US dollar, with some projecting it could happen as early as next week. The country's economy and political problems, including allegations of corruption surrounding 1MDB, have contributed to the currency's decline.

site_title: Google, Samsung to issue monthly Android security fixes
summary: Google and Samsung will release monthly Android security fixes to address hacking threats, following the discovery of Stagefright, a bug allowing attackers to access sensitive content. The move comes after security researcher Joshua Drake unveiled the bug at the Black Hat security conference. Android security chief Adrian Ludwig stated that Google will now develop and distribute patches more quickly, with Samsung following suit. The changes aim to protect the over 1 billion Android users from potential hacks and scams.

site_title: China said to consider merging China Shipping Group, COSCO Group
summary: China is considering merging China Shipping Group and COSCO Group, two major shipping companies, as part of efforts to streamline state-owned enterprises. The government may combine the companies or merge some of their operations. Both listed companies have suspended trading due to "major issues" being planned. The merger aims to increase efficiency and competitiveness in the shipping industry.

site_title: China Q2 prelim current account surplus at US$76.6b: regulator
summary: China's second-quarter current account surplus reached US$76.6 billion, according to preliminary data from the State Administration of Foreign Exchange. This represents a surplus on its capital and financial account of US$76.6 billion. The figures are subject to revisions.

site_title: Update: France hunts for more MH370 debris off Reunion island
summary: France launches a search for more MH370 debris off Reunion island, following the discovery of a 2-meter-long flaperon wing part last week. The part was declared by Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak to be part of the Boeing 777 that vanished 17 months ago. French experts are examining the flaperon for clues on the plane's last moments, and helicopters and soldiers are patrolling the island. Authorities hope the search will shed light on the mystery and potentially lead to the recovery of the black box, with some family members expressing hope for closure.

site_title: Basic materials M&A hits seven-year high buoyed by chemicals deals
summary: Worldwide dealmaking in the basic materials sector reached a seven-year high in July, driven by chemicals deals worth US$103.8 billion, a record for the sector. This year's total deals in basic materials are up 90% to US$96.5 billion, with global materials sector deals totaling US$217.1 billion, a 45% increase. Worldwide M&A is up 41% year-to-date, with deals worth US$2,716 trillion.

site_title: Marquee collectibles
summary: Luxury brands are capitalizing on Singapore's 50th National Day celebrations with unique, locally-inspired products. French fashion house Louis Vuitton has created a special Petite Malle bag line using alligator leather dyed and hand-finished by a local tannery. Other brands, including Montblanc, Porsche, Hublot, and MCM, have launched limited-edition collections featuring the Merlion, lion motif, and red dot design. These exclusive items, often priced in the thousands, are seen as a testament to the spending power of the Singaporean luxury consumer, with proceeds from some sales going to support local charities.

site_title: China MH370 families march to Malaysia embassy, demand Reunion trip
summary: Chinese relatives of MH370 passengers marched to Malaysia's embassy in Beijing, demanding a reunion trip to Reunion island, where suspected wreckage was found. The relatives, mostly Chinese, protested near the embassy, calling for Malaysia to organize travel to the island. They claim the Malaysian government is covering up the truth, and want to see the truth themselves. The relatives are frustrated with the lack of communication and cooperation from Malaysian officials, who have refused to send anyone to meet them.

site_title: Malaysia officials visit Goldman office as part of 1MDB probe: sources
summary: Malaysian anti-corruption officials from the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) visited Goldman Sachs' office in Kuala Lumpur as part of their investigation into state investor 1MDB for alleged graft. The visit occurred on July 8, the same day the MACC visited 1MDB's offices. Goldman Sachs is cooperating with the MACC's request for documents, and the bank earned $590 million in fees from underwriting 1MDB's $6.5 billion bond deals in 2012 and 2013. The investigation has contributed to Prime Minister Najib Razak's political crisis and the ringgit's 17-year low against the US dollar.

site_title: Greek deflation steady in July, prices fall for 29th month
summary: Greek consumer prices fell 2.2% year-on-year in July, marking the 29th consecutive month of deflation. This rate remained unchanged from June, with the EU-harmonized rate declining 1.3% from 1.1% in June. The country's deflation has been driven by cuts in wages and pensions and a deep recession, with prices falling 1.3% on average in 2014.

site_title: Mauritius scours remote islands in MH370 debris hunt
summary: Mauritius is searching its Indian Ocean waters for debris from missing flight MH370, with wreckage washing up on the nearby island of Reunion. Two police aircraft have made search flights, and coastguard officers are assisting on remote islands, including Agalega and St Brandon. Despite finding nothing so far, the search continues after France launched new air, land, and sea searches from Reunion. The search follows the confirmation of a two-metre-long wing part from the missing aircraft, the first proof of its tragic end 17 months ago.

site_title: Steadily improving US jobs market supportive of Fed rate hike
summary: US employment rose 215,000 in July, offsetting declines in the mining sector, and wages rebounded after a June stall. The unemployment rate held at 5.3%, a seven-year low. Average workweek increased to 34.6 hours, the highest since February. These signs support a potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike in September, indicating a solidly improving jobs market.

site_title: North Sea oil output to rise to 2015 high in Sept
summary: North Sea oil production is expected to rise to its highest level this year in September, reaching 1.988 million barrels per day, up 5.6% from August. This increase may pressure North Sea price differentials and impact Brent crude futures, which are trading below $50 a barrel due to a global supply glut. Refinery turnarounds are also looming, with plants using less crude due to maintenance work, further weakening North Sea crude differentials.

site_title: Apple helps push US watch sales to biggest drop in seven years
summary: US watch sales plummeted 11% in June to $375 million, the largest drop in seven years, largely due to Apple's release of its smartwatch. The decline was driven by a 24% drop in watches priced between $50 and $999, with fashion brands such as Timex and Guess being particularly affected. Industry experts predict the market for traditional watches will struggle in the short term, with the luxury tracker estimating that 70 brands will be impacted.

site_title: Chinese hedge funds cut exposure to commodities
summary: Chinese hedge funds have reduced their exposure to industrial commodities, citing low returns and a lack of momentum. Zhejiang Dunhe Investment Co Ltd and Shanghai Chaos Investment Co Ltd have suspended or cut trading in metals like copper and petrochemical products. The move follows a 60% rally in Chinese stocks and a 13% decline in the Thomson Reuters core commodity index this year. Funds are now focusing on agriculture, considering long positions in corn, soy, and palm oil to benefit from potential crop damage from an El Nino weather pattern.

site_title: Angry Chinese families seek answers about missing Malaysian plane
summary: Chinese families of missing Malaysian Airlines passengers clashed with police in Beijing, demanding answers about the disappearance of Flight MH370, which vanished in 2014. The discovery of a piece of wing debris on a remote Indian Ocean island, Reunion, has been confirmed by French investigators as coming from MH370, but relatives want clearer information and accuse Malaysia of withholding details. The search continues, with investigators suggesting that someone may have deliberately crashed the plane into the sea.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall the most in more than 3 years
summary: Australian shares fell 2.4% on Friday, their largest drop in over 3 years, due to weaker earnings from ANZ Banking Group and a capital raising through a share sale. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 4% for the week, its biggest weekly decline in two months. The decline was attributed to concerns about the growth outlook for major banks.

images.alt_text: Australian shares bucked a poor performance by Wall Street to edge 0.6 per cent higher on Thursday, aided by a hunt for dividend yield and more merger action.

site_title: Asia-Europe container freight rates drop 25%: source
summary: Asia-Europe container freight rates dropped 24.9% to $833 per 20-foot container, the lowest since 2015, due to overcapacity and sluggish demand. Rates fell 21.4% to Mediterranean ports, 4.0% to US West Coast, and 2.1% to US East Coast. The drop comes after a 177% increase in the previous week, attributed to general rate increases by major shipping companies. Rates generally deemed profitable are around $800-$1,000 per TEU.

site_title: Malaysia reserves fall below US$100b as ringgit slumps
summary: Malaysia's international reserves have fallen to $96.7 billion as of July 31, below the $100 billion threshold, due to a protracted political crisis and the decline of the ringgit currency. The central bank has been selling dollars and buying ringgit since June to stem the currency's slide, but it has still lost about 11% of its value against the US dollar this year. Experts warn of further pressure on the ringgit, citing dollar strength, a deteriorating trade balance, and higher US interest rates.

site_title: UK trade deficit widens in June but balance improves in Q2
summary: Britain's trade deficit in goods widened to 9.184 billion pounds in June, slightly less than forecast, but the total trade deficit narrowed to 4.182 billion pounds in the second quarter, marking the smallest since 2011. Exports in goods rose 6.6% in the three months to June, while imports increased 0.5%. The quarterly trade balance is expected to contribute positively to economic growth in the second quarter, despite business surveys showing British exporters struggling due to weak eurozone demand and a stronger pound.

site_title: Australia's central bank upbeat on economy despite slower growth
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, has tempered expectations of economic growth despite slower growth, citing a shift away from mining-led investment. The economy has grown at a moderate pace over the past year, with signs of improving conditions in the labor market and non-mining sector. The bank lowered its growth forecast for 2016 to 2.0-3.0% and increased its forecast for 2017 to 3.0-4.0%. The central bank also expects the jobless rate to decline and interest rates to stay on hold for an extended period.

site_title: Malaysia scandal fuels fastest foreign exodus as stocks sink
summary: International investors are rapidly selling Malaysian stocks, with a net RM11.7 billion (US$3 billion) pulled out of the nation's shares this year. The benchmark FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index has retreated 4.6% amid concerns over the economic outlook, fueled by a commodities rout and higher US interest rates. The scandal surrounding Prime Minister Najib Razak's personal accounts has also raised doubts about the government's ability to contain the crisis, leading to a slump in the ringgit to its weakest since 1998.

site_title: PBOC vows more flexible yuan movement and greater market role
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has vowed to let the market play a bigger role in setting exchange rates and allowing more flexible movement of the yuan. The bank will maintain the yuan's stability at a "reasonable equilibrium level" to spur global usage and support China's bid to add the yuan to the International Monetary Fund's reserve-currency basket. This move aims to counter the recent 28% slump in the Shanghai Composite Index and declining foreign-exchange reserves.

site_title: China securities regulator to crack down on illegal fundraising via Internet
summary: China's securities regulator announced a nationwide crackdown on illegal equity financing via the Internet, with a focus on crowdfunding. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) will regulate crowdfunding, which is currently banned in China but allowed for institutions to raise capital from select investors. The regulator aims to ensure compliance with rules and protect public interest and financial stability.

site_title: China market turmoil could delay Hong Kong futures plan: sources
summary: Hong Kong's plans to launch China's CSI300 futures contract may be delayed due to growing opposition from Chinese officials, who are unnerved by a recent sell-off in mainland share markets. The Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEx) had hoped to announce the contract launch this summer but faced difficulties from the China Financial Futures Exchange (CFFEX), which has only allowed the CSI300 contract to be traded onshore. The delay could impact the further opening up of the mainland equity market to foreign investors.

site_title: Shell eyes new Brazilian assets ahead of BG deal
summary: Royal Dutch Shell is considering investing billions in Brazil after the planned acquisition of BG Group, which will make it the world's largest liquefied natural gas supplier. Despite low oil prices, Shell plans to sell around $30 billion in assets to improve its balance sheet and focus on its core business. The company has earmarked up to $5 billion for new acquisitions in Brazil, where state-run Petrobras is selling assets worth nearly $14 billion due to a corruption scandal. Shell expects oil prices to return to $90 a barrel by the end of the decade, and its CEO, Ben Van Beurden, plans to be selective in new spending.

site_title: BoJ chief opens door to stimulus as oil prices drop
summary: Japan's Bank of Japan (BoJ) chief Haruhiko Kuroda hinted at potential stimulus as weak oil prices continue to hinder inflation, with the country's near-zero inflation rate below the 2.0% target. Despite a record 80 trillion yen annual asset-buying scheme, the BoJ may expand its easing program if oil prices impact underlying price movements. Oil prices have dropped 50% from mid-2014 levels, and economists expect the bank to act before year's end to boost inflation and kickstart growth.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets down at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets, including the FTSE 100 in London, DAX 30 in Frankfurt, and CAC 40 in Paris, were down at the start of trading on Friday, awaiting US jobs data. European markets had ended Thursday lower, but Greece's ATHEX index rose 3.65% after a five-week closure. Analysts expect a US rate rise next month if signs of improving US economic activity continue, following ADP's estimate of 185,000 private sector jobs added in July.

site_title: Flight 370 probe said to examine repair to tie part to jet
summary: French investigators probing the origin of a Malaysia Airlines plane part found on Reunion island have narrowed their focus to a crucial repair that may link the flaperon to the missing Boeing 777. The part, stamped with a date consistent with the plane's production, shows evidence of a repair that investigators are now trying to match to the carrier's maintenance records. This development raises hopes that other debris may surface, providing a long-awaited symbolic connection to the missing plane and potentially shedding light on its disappearance.

site_title: Eurozone inflationary pressures have dipped: ECRI
summary: Eurozone inflationary pressures have decreased slightly, according to the Eurozone Future Inflation Gauge (EZFIG), which fell to 100.3 in June from a four-year high in May. Despite the decline, inflation remains on a rising trend. Eurozone inflation remained unchanged at 0.2% in July due to a decline in energy prices.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise on hopes China markets are slowly recovering
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.7% on Friday, their highest close since July 31, as investors hope for stabilization in China's stock markets. China's Hang Seng index climbed 1.2% and the China Enterprises Index rose 0.9% for the first time since June 12. However, gains were capped ahead of US data that could prompt a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in September. Over 300 China funds with $161 billion in assets remain on the sidelines, waiting for the right moment to re-enter the market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.29% ahead of US jobs data
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.29% on Friday, ahead of US jobs data, as investors bet on a strong economic report. The Nikkei 225 index gained 60.12 points to 20,724.56, while the Topix index rose 0.34% to 1,679.19. Investors await more Japanese corporate earnings and US jobs data, which could impact the markets.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won slip ahead of US non-farm payrolls data
summary: South Korean shares declined 0.2% to 2,010.23 ahead of US non-farm payrolls data, which could influence the Federal Reserve's rate hike timing. The won slipped 0.1% to 1,167.4 against the dollar. This marks the third consecutive week of losses for the Kospi index. Investors remain cautious due to uncertainty surrounding the US jobs data and the Fed's interest rate decisions.

site_title: Foreign currency reserves hit record in July as franc dipped
summary: The Swiss National Bank's foreign-currency reserves reached a record of 531.8 billion francs (US$542 billion) in July, a 3% increase from June. The franc weakened 1.8% against the euro and 3.2% against the dollar, prompting interventions to stabilize the currency. Despite abolishing the franc's cap in 2011, the SNB remains prepared to intervene if necessary to maintain adequate monetary conditions.

site_title: Virgin Australia forecasts profit as overseas routes go low-cost
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd forecasts a return to profit by next June, ending a four-year losing streak. The airline plans to shift long-haul routes to its low-cost Tigerair subsidiary to reverse international losses. It will pull out of Perth to Phuket flights and add routes to New Zealand, Fiji, and the Solomon Islands. The move is expected to save A$162 million in fuel costs. CEO John Borghetti aims to restore profits to maintain competitiveness with Qantas Airways and deliver returns for major shareholders.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks mostly flat ahead of July exports data, typhoon
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained mostly flat on Friday ahead of July exports data and a typhoon. The TAIEX index closed unchanged at 8,449.58 points, following a 1.2% drop in the previous session. Exports in July are expected to have fallen for the sixth month in a row, suggesting global demand remains tepid. The typhoon and export data will likely influence investor sentiment over the weekend.

site_title: Singapore: Markets closed for public holiday
summary: Singapore's financial markets closed on Friday for a public holiday. The article also covered recent market trends, including a 5-day rally for Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data, and other global market developments, such as a strong rally in the US stock market despite tariff uncertainty. Additionally, news was shared about Airalo raising $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion, and a mandatory offer made by Sam Goi for the rest of PSC.

site_title: Shanghai bourse suspends trading in SSE50 index ETF options contract
summary: The Shanghai stock exchange suspended trading in the SSE50 index ETF options contract on Friday due to technical reasons. No further information is provided on when trading will resume. This halt follows a series of market developments, including ongoing US-EU trade talks and a rally in Singapore stocks, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: BOJ maintains stimulus, sticks with economic assessment
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its monetary policy steady, sticking with its assessment of a moderately recovering economy. The policy board kept its pledge to increase base money at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen through purchases of government bonds and risky assets. This decision was made by an 8-1 vote, reaffirming the BOJ's conviction that inflation will reach its 2% target without additional stimulus.

site_title: Singapore Q2 final GDP seen little changed from flash estimate of -4.6% q-o-q: Reuters poll
summary: Singapore's final second-quarter GDP is expected to be little changed from the flash estimate of -4.6% q-o-q, according to a Reuters poll of 11 economists. The median forecast shows a 1.5% expansion in the April-June quarter from a year earlier, lower than the 1.7% in the advance estimate. This follows industrial production's 4.4% year-on-year decline in June, driven by weaknesses in key sectors.

site_title: China: Shares rise on hopes big sums could enter the market
summary: China's stock market rose 2% on Friday, with the CSI300 index ending the week up 2.4% for its largest weekly gain since July 10. State media and the Chinese government are injecting trillions of yuan into the market, with 300 funds holding over $161 billion in reserve. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 2.3% for its best week since July 24, following Beijing's support measures, including buying stocks and cracking down on short-selling. However, traders warn that investors will be cautious before returning to the market.

images.alt_text: China stocks rose on Friday as state media tried to coax wary investors back into the market, indicating trillions of yuan funds were available to deploy to boost the market.

site_title: France steps up Reunion island search for MH370 wreckage
summary: France launches new air, land, and sea searches on Reunion island for MH370 wreckage, following a confirmed wing part found on the island. The search, which began on Friday, aims to find more physical evidence to solve the 17-month-old aviation mystery. A military plane will survey the Indian Ocean area, accompanied by foot patrols, helicopters, and maritime units. The discovery of the wing part is the first tangible clue to the disappearance of the Malaysia Airlines flight.

site_title: Indonesia central bank sees 2015 inflation at 4.3-4.5% y-o-y, 2016 at 4.5%
summary: Indonesia's central bank expects annual inflation to cool to 4.3-4.5% by the end of 2015, slightly higher than initial estimates. Inflation in July reached 7.26%, the highest this year. The bank also revised its economic growth outlook for 2015 from 5.0-5.4% to 4.5-5.1%. Senior deputy governor Mirza Adityaswara predicted inflation will stabilize at 4.5% in 2016.

site_title: China: Stocks rise at market open
summary: China's major stock indexes rose on Friday, with the CSI300 index gaining 0.9% to 3,866.43 points and the Shanghai Composite Index rising 0.9% to 3,692.61 points. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index declined 0.2% to 24,327.56 points. The gains came despite US trade uncertainty and ongoing tariff threats.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 0.18% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.18% lower on Friday, following a decline on Wall Street due to disappointing US media firm earnings. Investors await Japanese corporate earnings and a Bank of Japan decision. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.17% to 20,629.18, with more than 250 firms reporting earnings. A Bank of Japan decision later in the day is also expected to influence market moves.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 2.43 points to 1692.33 on Friday, with a trading volume of 48.9 million lots worth RM13.5 million. The index saw 127 losers outperforming 53 gainers.

site_title: Google, Samsung to issue monthly Android security fixes
summary: Google and Samsung will release monthly Android security fixes to address the growing threat of hacking. The move comes after a security researcher revealed a bug, known as Stagefright, that allows attackers to access sensitive content even if a malicious message is not opened. The companies aim to limit the effectiveness of the attack on over 1 billion Android users, with most manufacturers updating their software to fix the issue.

site_title: Oil prices set to continue multi-week decline
summary: Oil prices are expected to continue their multi-week decline due to a global oversupply of crude and mixed energy demand prospects. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell to $44.83, while Brent crude traded at $49.73, both on track for their eighth consecutive week of declines. A glut of supply and rising production in the US and Opec output exceeding quota are driving the decline, with Goldman Sachs warning of substantial risks skewed to the downside.

site_title: North Korea puts back its clocks to adopt 'Pyongyang Time'
summary: North Korea has adopted 'Pyongyang Time' by moving its clocks backwards 30 minutes to GMT+8:30, breaking from Japan's time standard imposed over a century ago. The change, approved by the North's rubber-stamp parliament, comes into effect on August 15 to mark the 70th anniversary of the Korean peninsula's liberation from Japan's colonial rule. The move is seen as a symbol of resistance against Japan's historical influence.

site_title: Wearable technology creeps into the workplace
summary: A Swedish entrepreneur has introduced a wearable technology system that allows employees to swipe into their office using an NFC microchip implanted under the skin. The system, tested at a co-working space, has garnered interest from various companies, including security firms and real estate companies. Around 15-20% of employees at the Epicenter co-working space in Stockholm have opted into the program, eliminating the need for traditional key-fobs or electronic entry cards. The technology also enables features such as setting alarms and registering loyalty points.

site_title: Hollande and Tsipras want Greek bailout agreed in late August
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and French President Francois Hollande agree on a new bailout deal by late August, with the European Union and International Monetary Fund seeking up to 86 billion euros in fresh loans. The deal must be finalized by August 20 to avoid a debt payment to the European Central Bank. France has been supportive, while Germany has demanded stringent reforms and austerity measures. A bridge loan may be offered if an agreement is not reached, but Greece only wants to sign up to strict conditions for a full bailout.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.22% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.22% in opening trades on August 7, 2015, defying a negative lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index gained 53.34 points to 24,428.62. This move followed a strong rally in Singapore stocks, which extended its 5-day winning streak ahead of GDP data.

site_title: ANZ Bank shares drop most since 2008 after capital raising plan
summary: ANZ Bank shares plummeted 8.5% to A$29.80, the largest drop since 2008, after a A$2.5 billion share sale to raise capital and profit that missed analysts' estimates. The bank reported lower-than-expected cash profit due to rising bad-debt charges. ANZ is also selling A$500 million of stock to existing shareholders. The share sale is part of the bank's efforts to meet new capital rules.

images.alt_text: Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd. shares slid the most in almost seven years on a A$2.5 billion (S$2.5 billion) share sale to raise capital and profit that missed analysts' estimates.

site_title: Gold in worst weekly slump since 2004 before US payrolls data
summary: Gold prices plummeted, marking its worst weekly slump since 2004, before a US payrolls report that may influence the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates. The metal fell 0.6% this week and is headed for a seventh weekly drop, with some analysts predicting a potential drop below $1,000 and average price of $1,110 this year. The US payrolls report is expected to show 225,000 new jobs and a 5.3% jobless rate, supporting the case for higher interest rates.

site_title: New York Times tops profit estimates on cost cuts; sales ebb
summary: The New York Times Co. reported second-quarter profit of 13 cents a share, exceeding analysts' estimates, despite a 1.5% revenue drop to $382.9 million. The publisher cut expenses faster than revenue declined, with operating expenses falling 4.9%. Digital ad sales rose 14%, while print ad revenue fell 13%. The company has passed the 1 million mark in digital subscribers and is investing in print, including a redesigned magazine and new sections. Net income rose to $16.4 million from $9.2 million last year.

site_title: Global oil glut pressures prices; WTI below US$45
summary: US oil prices fell 49 cents to $44.66 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, closing below $45 for the first time since March, due to a global oversupply of crude oil and weak demand prospects. The WTI contract was also influenced by concerns about the Federal Reserve raising interest rates and potential demand in China. The US is producing crude at high levels, and Opec's output exceeds its quota. The lifting of sanctions on Iran is also expected to impact oil prices.

site_title: Taiwan issues land warning as Typhoon Soudelor nears island
summary: Taiwan issued a land warning as Typhoon Soudelor approached, with the storm expected to strengthen as it nears the island. Travelers were warned to exercise caution and brace for wind and waves. Heavy rains are forecast for Friday and Saturday, prompting flight cancellations and adjustments. This is the fourth typhoon to trigger warnings in Taiwan this year, following Typhoon Chan-hom in July.

site_title: Apple Inc supplier Hon Hai confirms death at China plant after watchdog reports suicide
summary: Taiwan's Hon Hai Precision Industry Co Ltd, a key supplier to Apple Inc, confirmed the death of an employee at its Zhengzhou plant in China, which was reported as a suicide by watchdog China Labor Watch. Hon Hai, the world's largest contract manufacturer, has worked to improve labor conditions following a series of suicides in 2010-2011. The Zhengzhou plant, which makes Apple's iPhone products, has faced criticism for its working conditions. Hon Hai has improved labor conditions since then, but this incident raises concerns about the company's ongoing efforts to ensure worker safety.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slide before US payrolls report as oil rebounds
summary: Asian stocks fell, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific Index down 0.4% and the week's decline at 1.1%, amid concerns over a US payrolls report that may lead to interest rate hikes. Oil rebounded from a 4 1/2-month low. The Australian dollar rose, while the yen is headed for a weekly loss. The US payrolls report is set to be released Friday, potentially adding to evidence the economy is robust enough to support interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Noble redeems US$735m of bonds
summary: Noble Group has redeemed US$735 million of bonds, including US$500 million of senior notes due 2015 and US$235 million of senior notes due 2020. Analysts say this move may indicate liquidity, but short-sellers remain betting on the downside for Noble shares, which have surged 80% in borrowed volume since July 10. Noble's stock price rebounded after the bond redemption, but remains far from its pre-Iceberg report level of S$1.20. The company has assured investors of sufficient funds to meet its obligations and is addressing market rumors over its accounting practices.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Noble Group has fully redeemed US$735 million worth of bonds, a move seen by some observers as demonstrating the ample liquidity that the commodities group talked about this week.

site_title: Russia suspected in cyber attack on US military email
summary: US officials suspect Russia in a sophisticated cyber attack on the Joint Staff's unclassified email network, prompting the Pentagon to restrict access. The attack, identified as a spearphishing email, was traced to Russia, according to a US official. However, another official cautioned that it would take time to firmly attribute blame. The incident highlights ongoing cyber threats against US military networks.

site_title: US tightens visa waiver programme amid foreign fighters concerns
summary: The US has tightened its visa waiver program amid concerns about foreign fighters traveling to Syria and Iraq. The changes require e-passports and expanded use of US air marshals on international flights, affecting 38 countries, including European nations. The move aims to strengthen security and follow concerns raised by lawmakers and the intelligence community, which estimated over 20,000 foreign fighters have traveled to the region since 2011. The US Department of Homeland Security says the new restrictions will improve the ability to screen for lost and stolen passports.

site_title: Downtown Line 2 to open on Dec 27
summary: Downtown Line 2 in Singapore, comprising 12 stops between Bukit Panjang and Bugis, is set to open on December 27. To help residents familiarize themselves with the stations, rides on Downtown Lines 1 and 2 will be free for a short period. This coincides with a fare reduction of up to 1.9%.

site_title: Olam's US$1.3b deal for ADM's cocoa business hits delays
summary: Olam International Ltd's US$1.3 billion deal to acquire Archer Daniels Midland Co's global cocoa business has been delayed for a second time, with the transaction now expected to close in the fourth quarter of this year. The deal would be the largest ever for the Singapore-based commodities firm and catapult it into the top tier of global suppliers to the growing chocolate business. Chicago-based ADM had previously expected the transaction to close in the second quarter of this year.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip back; Novozymes slumps on weak results
summary: European shares fell 0.8% to 1,589.38 points, weighed down by weak corporate results from Novozymes and Deutsche Post. Novozymes slid 13% after earnings fell short of expectations, while Deutsche Post cut its 2015 profit outlook. However, Belgian KBC rose 3% on higher profits, and Britain's FTSE outperformed the region. The decline was partly attributed to weak oil prices and lingering concerns over Greece's debt problems, but economic stimulus measures from the European Central Bank have supported European stock markets this year.

site_title: Bank of England signals early 2016 hike after sterling climb
summary: The Bank of England signaled an early 2016 interest rate hike as Governor Mark Carney said the economy is recovering strongly and wages are rising more quickly. The Bank forecasts inflation will start to overshoot its 2% target in over two years, prompting Carney to warn investors against being too relaxed about the path for interest rates. Only one policymaker voted for a rate hike at the August meeting, which prompted investors to push back their bets on a first rate hike until mid-2016.

site_title: US: Media stock selloff leaves Wall Street bruised
summary: US stocks plummeted on Thursday, with the S&P 500 media index falling 2.12% and notching its biggest two-day loss since the financial crisis. Media companies, including Viacom and Walt Disney, suffered significant declines due to weak earnings reports and fears of viewers shifting to internet-based services. Investors are also nervous ahead of key jobs data on Friday, which could signal the first Federal Reserve interest rate hike in almost a decade, and valuations look stretched, with the S&P 500 trading at a 25% premium to its historical median price-to-sales ratio.

site_title: Epson revamps printer and ink approach
summary: Epson is revamping its printer and ink approach by introducing the EcoTank line, which offers a new model with enough ink to print at least 4,000 documents. The printers will be refillable with a bottle of ink, reducing the need for expensive cartridges. This change aims to alleviate customer anxiety and frustration with the traditional "razor-and-blades" model, which drives customers to purchase more ink. By making the front-end sale, Epson hopes to benefit from being the first mover in this market, with plans to continue offering machines that use traditional cartridges as well.

site_title: Insurer RSA says up to Zurich to decide next move in mooted takeover
summary: Zurich Insurance Group has reiterated its interest in acquiring British insurer RSA, but has stated it won't overpay. Zurich chief executive Martin Senn said any takeover must provide a 10% return on investment before adding debt. RSA shares fell 1.4% as the company's boss Stephen Hester expressed pride in the company's future prospects. Zurich has until August 25 to make a firm offer or walk away from a deal, and has $3.5 billion in surplus capital to spend on M&A activity or return to shareholders.

site_title: Priceless Stradivarius, missing for 35 years, returned to heirs
summary: A 35-year-old Stradivarius violin, worth approximately $5 million, was returned to its heirs after being stolen from a Boston music school in 1980. The violin, made in 1734, was discovered in a locked case in a musician's home by a violin maker and appraiser, who reported it to the FBI. The heirs, Roman Totenberg's daughters, plan to sell the violin to another great virtuoso, with the goal of sharing its unique sound with the world.

site_title: China accuses Manila, Tokyo of joining forces over South China Sea
summary: China accused Manila and Tokyo of joining forces to attack its South China Sea policy at a regional security forum, with Foreign Minister Wang Yi saying the situation is generally stable and no major clash is possible. China claims most of the South China Sea, which passes $5 trillion in ship-borne trade annually, and has built facilities on man-made islands. Wang Yi criticized Japan for building a remote island to enforce its territorial claims and urged the Philippines to respect China's sovereignty. China opposes any actions that widen division or create tensions in the region.

site_title: Not all is lost for trading reps
summary: Remisiers and retail trading representatives (TRs) in Singapore face job insecurity due to poor market conditions and the increasing difficulty of beating high-speed computers. Many TRs are unable to generate sufficient business to cover their firms' costs, and some have even signed a petition to the finance minister, fearing structural issues with the local market. To survive, TRs must adapt to today's technology-driven and low-cost world by evolving viable business models, such as operating in teams and offering advice on multiple markets and financial products.

site_title: Billionaire Packer sells Sydney mansion for record A$60m
summary: Billionaire James Packer sold his Sydney harbourside mansion, La Mer, in Vaucluse for a record A$60 million (S$61 million), surpassing previous Australian records. The six-level property, owned by Packer and his former wife, was reportedly sold in the past week. The sale price was not disclosed, but Fairfax Media reported it sold for A$70 million to Australian-Chinese billionaire Chau Chak Wing.

site_title: China bad loans surging, profit growth slowing, says regulator
summary: China's non-performing loans (NPLs) at banks rose 35.7% in the first half of 2015, reaching 1.8 trillion yuan, according to CBRC chairman Shang Fulin. Banks' profit growth slowed by 13.03 percentage points, totaling 1.1 trillion yuan. NPLs accounted for 1.82% of all loans at end-June. Shang warned that lower profit growth may reduce shareholder returns, weaken banks' ability to supplement capital, and increase risks. The banking sector's credit risks are "beginning to emerge" in the context of China's economic slowdown.

site_title: Inefficiencies hinder Modi's hinterland plans
summary: India's exporters face significant challenges due to inefficiencies in the country's rail and road corridors, leading to high costs and slow transportation times. The government's "Make in India" drive aims to create an export powerhouse, but progress on stalled corridors and lower costs is hindered by political opposition. Exporters, like Avinash Gupta, pay nearly $800 to transport a 20-foot container to Mumbai, compared to $20 in Dubai, exacerbating the pain of weak global demand and a 15% drop in exports.

site_title: IHH says it doesn't have stake in India hospital group
summary: IHH Healthcare Berhad denies having a stake in India's Global Hospitals Group, despite reports suggesting a potential acquisition. The company is in discussions with certain shareholders but has not entered into a definitive agreement. IHH is evaluating growth opportunities in Asia and will make announcements if a transaction is agreed upon. The acquisition was previously reported to be worth 18 billion rupees (S$391 million).

site_title: For families, debris leaves uncertainty in its wake
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak confirmed the wing part of missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, found on Reunion island, came from the aircraft, citing "conclusive evidence." However, French investigators have a "strong presumption" that the debris is from MH370, leaving some families seeking more definitive answers for closure. The discovery validates the hypothesis that the plane crashed in the Indian Ocean but doesn't pinpoint the crash site or reasons for the aircraft's diversion. Relatives plan to meet with Malaysia Air officials in Beijing to demand more information.

site_title: Anglo, Glencore now better buys for PSG
summary: Shaun le Roux, a portfolio manager, is betting on Anglo American plc and Glencore plc emerging as winners in the commodity market amid a selloff. The selloff, driven by concerns over China's economy, a strengthening dollar, and gluts in commodities, has led to a 15% drop in the Johannesburg Stock Exchange's FTSE/JSE Africa Mining Index. Le Roux believes stronger players will survive, citing Glencore's and Anglo's relatively low-cost operations and assets. He expects prices to eventually settle at a level where supply and demand are in balance, making them attractive buys.

site_title: Getting to know Singapore's first president
summary: Singapore's first president, Yusof Ishak, will be the subject of a biopic written and directed by his grand-niece, Zizi Azah. The 34-year-old playwright has delved into his background, speeches, and family interviews to create a dramatic work. The biopic aims to present a well-rounded portrayal of Ishak, balancing facts with imaginative storytelling. This marks Azah's first biopic, following her work on social issues, gender, and race in previous plays. The project seeks to shed light on Ishak's life and motivations, offering a fresh perspective on Singapore's founding leader.

site_title: China funds hold US$161b in "ammunition" to re-enter stock market: state media
summary: China has over 300 funds holding US$161 billion in "ammunition" to re-enter the stock market, according to state media. These funds, which oversee over US$223 billion, have been sitting on the sidelines since a 25% market crash in June and July. China's state media reported that many investors are reluctant to re-enter the market due to price swings and concerns over government intervention. Foreign investors, such as UBS and BlackRock, have expressed support for China's market rescue actions, but some warn that the government's heavy intervention could trigger a fresh slide.

site_title: Singapore music hits new highs
summary: Singapore's music scene is experiencing a resurgence with more locals buying and listening to local music, according to Minister Lawrence Wong. The Sam Willows' song is now No. 1 on iTunes Singapore, surpassing Taylor Swift's song. Wong aims to grow appreciation for Singapore music and inspire young talent. The Sing50 concert, featuring over 70 local musicians, is being held at the National Stadium, with Lang Lang also set to perform, and is expected to draw 45,000 attendees. The event aims to celebrate Singapore's music and talent.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Bollywood Oscar nominee gives back
summary: Bollywood singer-songwriter Jayashri Ramnath, aka Dr Bombay Jayashri, doesn't consider her Oscar nomination for "Pi's Lullaby" as her proudest moment, but rather an early performance that earned recognition from her Carnatic music guru, Lalgudi Jayaraman. Ramnath, 50, was raised in a music-oriented family and moved to Chennai to learn from her guru at age 39. She now runs the Hitham Trust, which provides classical music education to 350 landless farmer children in Manjakkudi, a village where music originated.

site_title: European banks' profit rebound signals revamps starting to pay off
summary: European banks, including the 10 largest lenders by assets, posted a combined profit of 11.4 billion euros in the second quarter, the highest since 2011. This represents a significant rebound from previous years, with all firms reporting at least double-digit profit gains. The profit increase suggests that the industry is starting to recover from past challenges, signaling a positive trend for the sector.

site_title: Londoners hit hard by Underground rail staff strike
summary: A strike by rail unions in London brought the Underground rail network to a standstill, affecting millions of commuters. The strike, which was the second in a month, was over plans for 24-hour all-night services on the weekends. Despite Transport for London's offer of a 2% pay rise and other benefits, unions argued the plans would disrupt their work-life balance. Commuters relied on alternative transportation, with massive queues at bus stops and taxi ranks. The strike was set to last until September 12 when the planned services were due to begin.

site_title: How about a timepiece to mark the Jubilee?
summary: Singapore's 50th independence anniversary is being marked by limited-edition watches from various brands, with prices ranging from $149 to $36,600. Brands such as Patek Philippe, Audemars Piguet, and Longines have created special-edition timepieces, with proceeds going to charity. Some watches, like Ball Watch's Fireman Night Train SG50, have sold out quickly, while others, like Jaeger-LeCoultre's Grande Reverso Night & Day, are highly exclusive. The watches are a way for brands to celebrate Singapore's 50 years of independence and give back to the community.

Various other stories and events are also covered.

site_title: Raising interest rates with zero inflation remains a hard sell
summary: The Bank of England and US Federal Reserve are set to raise interest rates for the first time in almost a decade, despite near-zero inflation rates in both countries. Economies are growing at brisk annual clips, with jobless rates near long-term averages, but inflation remains below target. The decision is puzzling, as it may signal an early exit from quantitative easing, which could delay consumer purchases and weigh down debt servicing. Critics argue that the central banks are "jumping the gun" and that interest rates should remain low to support economic growth.

site_title: TPP talks: no consensus on resumption date
summary: US and 11 other nations failed to reach an agreement on the resumption date of Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) talks due to disagreements over car trade, dairy goods, and next-generation drugs. The talks, which would cover 40% of the global economy, were set to meet in August but no consensus was reached. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe considers the deal crucial to rebooting Japan's economy, while US President Barack Obama's pivot to Asia is also at stake. A new round of talks is expected before the end of the month, but no specific date has been decided.

site_title: 50 years of music making
summary: A Singaporean music industry milestone was celebrated as the country's music scene reached new heights. This marks 50 years of music making in Singapore, with the industry experiencing significant growth and diversification. The country's music scene now boasts a rich mix of genres, including local and international artists. The celebration highlights the evolving music landscape in Singapore, showcasing its unique cultural identity and creative spirit.

site_title: Economy needs major surgery: S Korea's Park
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye has called for "major surgery" on the economy, citing chronic and structural problems. The economy recorded its weakest growth in six years, with a deadly Mers outbreak and poor exports contributing to the slowdown. Park has fallen short on labor market reforms and job creation, and has proposed a salary cap on older employees, a more merit-based pay system, and deregulation of the financial services sector. The government aims to implement these changes to stimulate growth and address youth unemployment, with a goal of achieving one trillion won in tax savings per year.

images.alt_text: MS PARK: Has made a plea for support for her reform drive across the labour market, public corporations, education and the financial sector.

site_title: SG Quirky: The A-Z of SG50
summary: Singapore celebrates its 50th anniversary with various unique aspects of the city-state. The article highlights the quirks that make Singapore stand out, from the nation's love of food and coffee to its tendency to indulge in gossip and social media. Other notable features include the country's hipster culture, its love of loud conversations, and its tendency to prioritize individuality over conformity. The article also touches on Singapore's gentrification, xenophobia, and the country's ability to balance tradition with modernity. Overall, the article showcases the complexities and nuances of Singaporean culture.

site_title: GE plans app store for gears of industry
summary: General Electric (GE) is launching an app store for its "Gears of Industry" platform, connecting sensors to distant computing centers for data analysis on performance, maintenance, and supplies. This move aims to compete with major technology companies in the manufacturing sector.

site_title: Hyflux bottom line hit by lower disposal gains
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water-treatment group, reported a 58% drop in Q2 net profit to S$25.95 million, despite an 18% increase in revenue. The decline was largely due to lower disposal gains, which fell 86% to S$11.75 million. For the half year, net profit dropped 68% to S$31.58 million. The company plans to explore potential divestment opportunities and expects revenue contribution from the Middle East and North Africa region to grow.

site_title: When the sky's the limit
summary: Montrachet, a renowned white wine, was recently tasted at a Château Latour vertical tasting. The 1995 Marquis de Laguiche Montrachet, produced by Maison Drouhin, was served in magnum. The wine's exceptional quality and complexity have made it a standout in the world of white wines, with past experiences at vertical tastings reinforcing its status as a premium wine.

site_title: Driving Singapore
summary: Singapore's car market has undergone significant changes over the past 50 years, shifting from predominantly Western-made vehicles to a predominantly Japanese market. In the 1960s, British and American brands such as Morris and Austin were popular, but by the 1980s, Japanese brands like Toyota and Honda began to dominate. Today, the Toyota Corolla Altis is the most popular car model in Singapore, with the Volkswagen Beetle and Mini Minor tied as top models in the 1960s. Despite rising car prices, the proportion of private cars to total vehicles has remained relatively stable, with Japanese brands continuing to hold a strong market share.

site_title: Victorious executive pay campaigner sets sights on Swiss central bank
summary: Swiss politician Thomas Minder is pushing for changes to the Swiss National Bank's (SNB) governing board, citing the need for a more diverse decision-making body. Minder wants the board expanded from three members to include lawmakers' appointments and a larger governing body. This comes after the SNB's decision to allow the franc to float freely, leading to economic recession, falling prices, and job losses. Minder previously succeeded in limiting executive pay and now seeks to reform the SNB to better represent the country's interests.

site_title: Boeing loses large satellite deal due to trade credit woes, sources say
summary: Boeing loses a satellite contract worth "several hundred million dollars" due to uncertainty about the US Export-Import Bank's future, as ABS terminated the order citing the bank's charter expiration on June 30. This marks the first known casualty of the ongoing debate over the bank's fate, which lends money to US exporters. Boeing chairman Jim McNerney expressed frustration over the refusal of some lawmakers to support the bank, and the company is now considering moving commercial work to other countries with export credits. The bank's charter is set to expire in September or October.

site_title: Peeling back a lifetime of hurt
summary: A mother and son, Guo Xiong, learn more about each other in one supper than they have in their lifetime, revealing shocking contradictions to their previous perceptions. The play, "The Last Supper," written by Matthew Cheng, explores the hurtful relationship between a mother and child, with the father's absence having a devastating impact. The intimate drama, directed by Fong Chun Kit, features flawless performances by Lui Si Lan and Lau Shau Ching, capturing the characters' every hope and frustration, leaving the audience with a deep sense of loneliness and heartbreak.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Majority of firms in 5 big sectors see 2015 sales slide
summary: Companies across Singapore's major sectors expect a poorer sales showing in 2015 compared to the previous year, with 56% predicting a decline. This marks the fourth consecutive year of negative net balances for full-year sales growth expectations. Construction firms were the least pessimistic, with a net balance of minus-15%, while financial and business services saw the worst prospects with a minus-42% net balance.

site_title: Melco Crown to open US$3.2b Macau casino amid slump
summary: Melco Crown Entertainment Ltd plans to open a US$3.2 billion casino in Macau on October 27, joining other casinos to attract Chinese tourists amid a 14-month downturn in the industry. The new resort, Studio City, will feature a Hollywood-themed resort with Asia's highest Ferris wheel and family entertainment. Melco is "actively" in talks with the Macau government on gaming table allocation, hoping to secure 400 tables, and is concerned if the project doesn't meet its requirements. The opening of Studio City is seen as a catalyst for the market, with analysts expecting the resort to focus on the mass market and draw customers beyond traditional casinos.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Metro Group buys Singapore-based food service distributor Classic Fine Foods Group for US$290 million plus an earn-out of up to US$38 million, expanding its premium food service distribution business in Asian mega cities and the Middle East.

site_title: Recapturing the innocence of youth
summary: Hong Kong-based artist Johnson Tsang's exhibition, "Inner Child," opens in Scotts Square, aiming to recapture the innocence and curiosity of childhood. Tsang, 55, believes every adult has an inner child that keeps them curious and open to happiness. The exhibition features 18 porcelain sculptures, including "Who Did It," which reveals his feelings about war, and two collectible figures. Tsang, a self-taught artist, found his true medium in ceramics, which he uses to express feelings and ideas.

site_title: Jakarta block on corn imports to hike poultry prices: trade group
summary: Indonesia's ban on importing corn for feed mills is expected to increase wholesale poultry and egg prices by at least 6% over the next month, according to the Indonesian Poultry Farmers Association. The move, which was made in July to boost food self-sufficiency, has halted shipments of 3 million tonnes of corn, which would have provided jobs for thousands of people. The association warns that this could lead to inflation concerns, with critics saying the policy was too sudden and lacks preparation.

site_title: F4 reboot: far from fantastic
summary: 20th Century Fox's reboot of Marvel's Fantastic Four has received negative reviews, with critics finding it dull and unentertaining. The film, directed by Josh Trank, lacks a sense of humor and features confusing science concepts, including interdimensional travel. This is a departure from the studio's earlier attempts at the franchise, which were also unsuccessful. The film's poor reception suggests that the producers may be better off focusing on the X-Men series, which has proven to be more successful and appealing to a broader demographic.

site_title: Tough time for McDonald's, KFC in China
summary: McDonald's and KFC in China are facing a decline in sales due to a combination of food scares and competition from local alternatives. After a safety scare in 2014, Chinese parents are turning away from the US firms, with many opting for local chains instead. The slowing economy and fierce competition are also contributing to the decline, with sales growth forecasted to slow to around 4% by 2019. Both companies are trying to revive sales by focusing on faster-growing segments and premium offerings, but it remains to be seen if they can regain consumer trust.

site_title: SMEs get help in demand side of business
summary: Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel) and DBS Bank have launched a nationwide campaign, 99%SME, to address the demand side of business for small and medium enterprises (SMEs). The campaign aims to help SMEs generate demand in a challenging global economy. The initiative provides a dedicated website, support videos, and other resources to support SMEs in increasing productivity and managing costs. This move addresses the lack of engagement with SMEs, which are more concerned about generating demand rather than just receiving supply-side support.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Australia confident that search is in the right area
summary: Australian authorities are confident that the search for MH370 is being carried out in the right area after Malaysia confirmed that debris on an Indian Ocean island is from the missing flight. The flaperon debris found on Reunion suggests the plane may have come down near the current search area. Prime Minister Tony Abbott said the discovery is a "step forward" in solving the mystery, while Australian Transport Safety Bureau chief commissioner Martin Dolan noted that "close examination" of the debris is necessary to determine what happened to the plane.

site_title: Religare Health Trust's Q1 profit jumps to S$12.3m
summary: Religare Health Trust reported a net profit of S$12.3 million for Q1 FY2016, a 147% increase from the previous year. Total distributable income rose 7.8% to S$15.4 million, driven by growth in operational revenue and lower trust expenses. Distribution per unit increased 7.4% to 1.94 cents. Revenue grew 10.2% to S$34.3 million, driven by a 3% increase in base fee and higher operating revenue from Fortis Healthcare Limited.

site_title: A forgettable week in the market in run-up to Aug 9
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a weak week, with the Straits Times Index (STI) losing about six points. Volatility in the China market and anticipation of US interest rate hikes provided the backdrop. Stocks like Noble Group and Jason Holdings saw significant price movements, with Noble's shares rising and Jason's collapsing before rebounding. The market's weakness was also attributed to declining volume and a lack of momentum in penny stocks. A report by Schroders suggested a recovery in the world economy, but with a sub-par pace.

site_title: KL says matches prove wing part is from missing MH370
summary: Malaysia confirms a piece of wing found on an Indian Ocean island is from MH370, a missing Boeing 777 airliner with 239 passengers and crew on board. The fragment, known as a flaperon, was matched to the plane through paint color and maintenance records. French prosecutors say more analysis is needed to be certain, but a "very strong presumption" exists based on technical data. The confirmation brings a major breakthrough in the 515-day-old mystery, but the cause of the plane's disappearance remains unknown.

site_title: Standing in his own spotlight
summary: Johnny Marr's solo concert at the University Cultural Centre was a surprise hit, with the guitarist commanding the stage and winning over the crowd with his trademark swagger. Despite initial doubts about his ability as a frontman, Marr delivered a mixed bag of new songs, Smiths classics, and cover versions, including hits like "There Is a Light That Never Goes Out" and "Please Please Please Let Me Get What I Want." The setlist was a mix of old and new, showcasing Marr's knack for writing muscular guitar riffs and his faithful renditions of The Smiths' back catalogue.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Gloom deepens for local firms in Q2: survey
summary: Business sentiment in Singapore worsened in Q2 due to domestic and external factors, including the slowdown in China. A survey of 181 companies found poorer sales, thinner profits, and fewer orders. Economists attribute this to ongoing global economic uncertainty and the need for domestic restructuring. Expectations suggest the negative trend will persist until the US economy recovers, with no clear end in sight.

site_title: Paying the price for emerging market bonanza
summary: Investors face a potential lost decade of returns in emerging markets, with four or five more years of meagre growth ahead. The BRICs, once touted as engines of global growth, are now struggling with deep recessions, slowing economies, and declining currencies. Higher US interest rates and a strong dollar further exacerbate the challenges. Despite the IMF's 4.2% growth forecast for emerging economies this year, analysts predict more trouble, citing concerns over politics, policy, and economic fundamentals.

site_title: Mumbai's property market may see 20% erosion, says fund
summary: Mumbai's property market may experience a 20% decline in home prices over the next year due to a glut of unsold homes and reduced demand. The northern suburbs of Thane and Mulund are expected to be the hardest hit, with prices potentially dropping by 20%. This decline is attributed to the slowing sales velocity and buyers' hesitation to purchase, with developers offering cheaper offers to attract customers. The situation is expected to take at least 45 months to correct, according to a Mumbai-based real estate fund.

site_title: Price accord ends row over Myanmar Brewery
summary: Frasers & Neave (F&N) has agreed to sell its 55% stake in Myanmar Brewery Limited to Myanma Economic Holdings Ltd (MEHL) for US$560 million. This resolves a two-year dispute over the controlling stake in Myanmar's largest brewery, with MEHL holding the remaining 45%. The brewery is Myanmar's biggest beer supplier and largest taxpayer, with 83% market share. The agreement ends a legal battle initiated by MEHL in 2013, which valued the stake at US$246 million, but was later revised to US$560 million based on the April 2013 exchange rate.

site_title: A-Reit exploring openings in Australia, Germany
summary: Ascendas Reit, Singapore's first and largest industrial Reit, is exploring investment opportunities in mature developed markets such as Australia and Germany, targeting a 20-30% overseas portfolio. The Reit's portfolio will remain predominantly Singapore-based, with a focus on long-term sustainable yield-accretive returns. The move aims to strengthen the portfolio and balance risk and growth. Following improved earnings in its first quarter, the Reit's distribution per unit rose 5.5% and its stock price increased by S$0.01 to S$2.41.

site_title: Building a sound employer brand
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) was named Singapore's most attractive employer at the 2015 Randstad Awards, beating out Changi Airport Group and Shell. A strong employer brand is key to attracting and retaining top talent, according to the survey. Key factors include career progression, competitive compensation, and work-life balance, with 50% of employees citing work-life balance as a reason to stay with their current employer. Companies can develop a winning employer brand by understanding their employees' motivations, communicating their core values and culture, and offering unique benefits and programs.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC sets up new board as offer turns unconditional
summary: STATS ChipPAC has set up a new board of directors after China's Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology Co's (JCET) takeover offer was declared unconditional. JCET now holds 90.27% of STATS ChipPAC shares, and the company will be taken private. The new board, chaired by Wang XinChao, includes outgoing directors and 10 new directors, including Tan Lay Koon and Han Byung Joon, who will jointly lead the company. Share trading will be suspended on August 27 due to the high acceptance rate. The offer's closing deadline has also been set as a result.

site_title: Sherlock Holmes faces his own mortality
summary: Sherlock Holmes, directed by Bill Condon, is a slow-paced and sensitive film about an elderly Holmes grappling with mortality and trying to right a past wrong. The story follows three narrative threads, including a 1947 day, a 1947 visit to Hiroshima, and a 30-year-old case involving a woman's melancholy. Despite physical frailty, Holmes remains determined to solve the case and connect with his young housekeeper's son. The film showcases Ian McKellen's portrayal of the iconic detective, highlighting the complexities of human nature and the limitations of logic in explaining the unknown.

site_title: Half a billion dollars to get a gentler climate-change plan
summary: US President Barack Obama's clean-power plan made concessions to the energy industry after spending $502 million on lobbying since the EPA proposed carbon emissions regulations. This is 22 times more than renewable-energy companies and environmentalists spent. The concessions may be related to the $502 million spent by the energy industry.

images.alt_text: CURBING EMISSIONS: The plan will reduce greenhouse-gas emissions from power plants 32 per cent by 2030, compared with a 30 per cent cut in the draft.

site_title: Time for S'pore to embrace telemedicine
summary: Singapore is considering embracing telemedicine to address its healthcare challenges, including a rapidly ageing population and hospital bed crunch. The country's Healthcare 2020 plan aims to improve access to efficient, affordable, and quality healthcare. Telemedicine could increase productivity, enhance patient experience, and reduce costs. With a growing demand for medical consultations, telemedicine could be a solution to alleviate the pressure on hospitals and clinics.

site_title: China revamps stimulus playbook for growth
summary: China's economy grew 7% in the first half of 2015, driven by a boom in the financial sector. However, policymakers aim to balance this growth with infrastructure investment to meet targets. A new round of infrastructure investment is planned, with policy banks expected to issue special bonds and invest in projects favored by the government. This move is seen as a targeted easing to specific areas to boost growth, with policy banks taking equity stakes in infrastructure projects to address financing hurdles.

site_title: Going after a new kind of sound
summary: Kimbra's second album, The Golden Echo, marks a departure from her debut's baroque-pop sound, embracing experimental electro-pop with more layers and dimensions. Released in 2014, the album was recorded after a reality check on her success, featuring collaborations with rockers Daniel Johns and Omar Rodriguez-Lopez. Kimbra's eclectic tastes in music are reflected in the album, and she credits the experience of working with guests to help her reinvent herself. The album's themes are also seen in her live performances, which often feature new styles and energy.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Evoking the mood of a nation
summary: Artist Boo Sze Yang was inspired by the spontaneous turnout of thousands of Singaporeans at the funeral of the nation's first Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew in March 2015. The artist, who turned 50 that year, began working on a series of paintings featuring ordinary people, known as the "proletariat", in response to the emotional event. The series, which includes portraits of people with bowed heads and clasped hands, aims to reflect Singapore's values and the potential for the nation's citizens to come together in times of need.

site_title: Seeing the darkness in a new light
summary: The Singapore Night Festival is set to return for its eighth installment, featuring over 100 performances and light art installations. The festival's creative director, Christie Chua, notes that nighttime events reveal new aspects of spaces, offering a unique ambiance and feel. The festival aims to cater to the more nocturnal crowd, providing a different experience compared to daytime events.

site_title: India's Jaitley says conditions favourable for further rate cuts
summary: India's finance minister Arun Jaitley said conditions are favorable for further interest rate cuts due to low global commodity prices and good summer crop prospects. Jaitley also expects food inflation to remain under control. The central bank kept its policy rate on hold but left room for further easing, depending on inflation and lending rate reductions.

site_title: MH370 proof raises hopes of solving flight mystery
summary: Malaysia confirms plane wreckage from MH370 found on a remote Indian Ocean island, marking the first proof of the flight's tragic end 17 months ago. A two-metre-long wing part discovered on French Reunion island was confirmed by an international team of experts. The finding raises hopes that the mystery surrounding MH370's disappearance can be solved. Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak expressed a "heavy heart" in confirming the debris is from the missing plane, bringing closure to the long-standing aviation mystery.

site_title: Confirmation of debris does little to dispel wildly diverse theories
summary: Confirmation of a wing flap found on the French island of Reunion as coming from Malaysian Airlines Flight MH370 has done little to dispel the diverse theories surrounding the plane's disappearance. Experts and enthusiasts continue to propose various conclusions, including a controlled landing and the notion that the wing part was planted. The investigation remains inconclusive, with officials cautioning that the torn flaperon confirms the plane crashed within the designated search zone, but may not reveal the reason behind the crash.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance Q2 profit dips
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 0.7% year-on-year decrease in net profit to S$13.96 million for the second quarter, with annualized earnings per share at 12.58 Singapore cents. This marks a 3.6% increase in half-year earnings. The company's results contrast with other market trends, with some analysts expressing concerns about revenue and operating losses.

site_title: BoE rate hike closer but timing cannot be predicted: Carney
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney stated that an interest rate hike is drawing closer, but the exact timing cannot be predicted. He believes the decision will become clearer at the turn of the year, influenced by economic developments. This contradicts expectations that two officials would vote for a rate hike this month, with only one doing so.

site_title: Brent oil prices fall after supertanker heading to Asia turns back
summary: Brent oil prices have fallen to a six-month low of below $50 a barrel after a supertanker, the Sea King, heading to South Korea unexpectedly turned back, increasing supply in the North Sea crude market. The move, attributed to trading firm Vitol, reduces price differentials and weakens the Brent benchmark. This unusual move is seen as a negative sign for North Sea crude, which relies on shipments to Asia to clear overhang in the market.

site_title: IBM to buy Merge for US$1b for medical imaging technology
summary: IBM agreed to buy Merge Healthcare Inc for $1 billion, incorporating its imaging management platform with Watson data analytics tool. The all-cash deal is subject to regulatory review and shareholder approval. Merge shareholders will receive $7.13 per share. This acquisition aims to enhance IBM's medical imaging capabilities and expand its presence in the healthcare industry.

site_title: US: Wall St opens little changed ahead of jobs data
summary: US stocks opened little changed on Thursday ahead of Friday's jobs data, which may signal an interest rate hike. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.17%, the S&P 500 lost 0.11%, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 0.18%. Investors took to the sidelines due to uncertainty surrounding the jobs data, which could impact interest rates and the overall market.

site_title: Fresh signs of Dubai's property-market woes
summary: Dubai's property market is experiencing fresh signs of woes, with brokers chasing dwindling home sales as prices fall and deals dry up. The first half of 2015 saw a 47% drop in transactions and an 8% decline in prices since June 2014, according to Jones Lang LaSalle Inc. Brokers, who typically earn commissions rather than a monthly salary, are struggling with reduced income. Despite this, developers continue to start megaprojects, such as Meydan One, which includes homes for over 78,000 residents.

images.alt_text: HARD TIMES: Property deals in Dubai dropped 47 per cent in the first half of 2015 from a year earlier and prices have declined by 8 per cent since June 2014, according to Jones Lang LaSalle.

site_title: Ho Bee Land's Q2 profit jumps 37%
summary: Ho Bee Land reported a 37% jump in net profit to S$16.7 million for the second quarter, driven by a 14% increase in rental income from its Singapore office building. The company's total revenue rose 13.4% to S$31.1 million, with the acquisition of London properties enhancing its geographical diversification. The group's six-month profit surged 73% to S$28.2 million, and its total shareholders' fund reached S$2.6 billion.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Creative Technology warns of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with an operating loss similar to the first half. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks experience a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. OCBC announces the retirement of CEO Helen Wong and the appointment of Tan Teck Long as her successor. Indonesia detains a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case.
