Additionally, MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. CGSI downgrades Grab to 'hold' due to expected slowing earnings growth in H2.

site_title: Update: Malaysia says matches prove wing part is from missing flight MH370
summary: Malaysia confirms a piece of the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370's wing, a flaperon, found on a French island, has been identified as coming from the Boeing 777 airliner. The Transport Minister, Liow Tiong Lai, said matches between the paint color, maintenance records, and a seal on the part confirmed the origin. The discovery brings a major breakthrough in the 515-day-old mystery but does not provide a resolution for the families of the 239 passengers and crew on board. Further analysis is needed to confirm the link.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Creative Technology warns of potential H2 revenue below target and similar operating loss to H1. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. OCBC announced the retirement of CEO Helen Wong and the appointment of Tan Teck Long as her successor. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. London's Heathrow eyes higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Greek aid accord is possible before Aug 20 deadline, EU Says
summary: The European Commission says Greece can still reach an agreement with creditors by August 20, just two weeks before a payment to the European Central Bank. Officials are drafting the bailout program's memorandum of understanding and have made progress in areas such as tax reform and public administration. A deal is considered possible, despite earlier doubts raised by German government officials.

site_title: Egypt's gift to the world: A two-way Suez
summary: Egypt's military regime has launched the New Suez Canal, dubbed as the "gift to the world," allowing two-way traffic and reducing ship waiting time. The expanded 35km channel and widened 37km of the original route were built in just a year, raising US$8.5 billion in crowdfunding from the Egyptian public. Analysts predict the canal's impact on trade flows is unclear, but it's expected to benefit global trade, particularly Asia, and major transhipment hubs. The project is also seen as a way to boost Egypt's economy and attract foreign investment, with projected revenues of US$12.3 billion by 2023.

site_title: ARA Asset Management posts lower Q2 profit on one-off adjustments
summary: ARA Asset Management reported a 21% decline in Q2 net profit to S$16.4 million, due to lower finance income and a one-off adjustment of S$4.1 million. Excluding adjustments, net profit rose 11% to S$16.9 million. Revenue fell 9% to S$36.8 million, and earnings per share decreased to 1.95 cents. An interim dividend of S$0.023 per share has been declared, payable on August 28.

site_title: Round 2 of Opposition talks ends after an hour with claims to just 3 constituencies unresolved
summary: Round 2 of opposition talks in Singapore ended after an hour, with only three constituencies remaining unresolved. The talks focused on constituency allocation and avoiding three-cornered contests between the opposition and the ruling People's Action Party. The Worker's Party and Reform Party leaders were absent, with the WP not attending and the RP chief leaving early. Despite the initial difficulties, party leaders agreed that all but three constituencies would see straight fights between the opposition and the PAP.

site_title: Gold steady near 2010 low ahead of US jobs data
summary: Gold prices steadied near a 2010 low ahead of US jobs data, rising 0.2% to $1,086.56 an ounce. Investors await employment data due Friday, which could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates as early as next month. Gold breached technical support at $1,100 after a deep rout in July, but a looming rate hike dims its appeal, pushing funds towards the dollar. Gold holdings in the world's largest gold-backed ETF fell to 21.47 million ounces, the lowest since September 2008.

site_title: Gates tops Forbes' list of tech billionaires
summary: Bill Gates topped Forbes' list of tech billionaires, averaging 53 years old, a decade younger than all billionaires. US-based tech magnates made up 51 of the 100 richest people in technology, with 33 from Asia and 8 from Europe. Amazon founder Jeff Bezos saw his personal fortune surge, solidifying his position as a leading tech billionaire.

images.alt_text: FIXTURE ON RICH LISTS: Microsoft chief Gates has an estimated worth of US$79.6 billion. Of the 100 richest tech moguls, half are US-based.
AMAZON SHARES JUMPED: Mr Bezos became US$13 billion richer because the online retailer's shares appreciated. He is now at No. 3, and worth US$47.8 billion.

site_title: US jobless claims rise marginally; underlying trend firm
summary: US jobless claims rose 3,000 to 270,000 for the week ended Aug 1, staying below the 300,000 threshold for the 22nd consecutive week. Economists had expected a rise to 273,000. The four-week moving average of claims fell 6,500 to 268,250. Labor market conditions continue to tighten, with the Federal Reserve describing employment gains as "solid" and labor market slack diminishing since early this year.

site_title: Apple Music attracts more than 11m trial members since June 30
summary: Apple Music has attracted over 11 million trial members since its June 30 launch, with nearly 2 million opting for the free family plan. The service, which offers a three-month free trial, is seen as a boost to the music industry, unlike rival streaming services that include a free on-demand tier. Meanwhile, Apple's App Store saw a record-breaking $1.7 billion in transactions in July, and the company has now paid developers almost $33 billion. Apple's revenue rose 32.5% in the most recent quarter, beating expectations.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US declines for fifth week on finances
summary: Consumer confidence in the US declined for the fifth consecutive week, easing to 40.3 in the period ended August 2, the second-worst reading since November. The decline in household finances and attitudes about shopping, despite improved views of the economy, pose risks to consumer spending. The Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index fell to its weakest level since October, with lower-income individuals showing significant pessimism, while higher-income individuals showed improved confidence. A 5.2-point drop in the past two weeks has occurred just 13 times in data back to 1985.

images.alt_text: Consumer confidence declined for a fifth consecutive week as Americans grew less upbeat about their finances and whether it was a good time to shop.

site_title: Thousands evacuated as Taiwan readies for biggest typhoon of 2015
summary: Typhoon Soudelor, the strongest typhoon of 2015, is approaching Taiwan's east coast, forcing the evacuation of over 2,000 from outlying islands. The storm is predicted to strengthen and batter the island between late Friday and early Saturday, with maximum wind gusts of up to 209 km/h. A sea warning has been issued, and ferry services to affected islands have been suspended. The government has warned of potential floods, landslides, and fallen trees, with around 32,000 soldiers on standby for disaster relief.

site_title: HDB resale prices down 0.5% in July: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore dropped 0.5% in July, according to SRX Property's flash estimates, marking a divergence from the HDB index. Consultants interpret this as a sign of stabilizing prices, but not necessarily a price rebound. Resale prices of three-room flats remained flat, while four-room, five-room, and executive flats dipped 0.7%, 1.2%, and 0.9% respectively. Consultants expect further downside in HDB resale prices for the rest of the year, with a potential fall of 1.5% to 3.5%.

images.alt_text: Blk79 Toa Payoh Central is one of the blocks affected by Selective En-Bloc Redevelopment Scheme (Sers).

site_title: Europe moves to reduce risk in US$505t derivatives market
summary: The European Union has implemented new rules requiring banks and investors to send interest-rate swaps trades to a third-party clearinghouse to improve financial stability and market confidence. The mandate, part of the EU's G-20 commitments, aims to reduce the risk of a major financial institution defaulting on payments. The clearinghouse will spread losses among member firms, making the derivatives market safer. The rules, set to be phased in over three years, apply to plain vanilla interest-rate derivatives and have an estimated daily turnover of over $1.6 trillion.

site_title: S$63m Keppel T&T loan for Keppel Datahub 2
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) has entered into a two-year, S$90 million loan agreement with Keppel Land Financial Services Pte Ltd and Keppel Datahub 2 Pte Ltd. Keppel T&T's portion of the loan is S$63 million, to be used for the development of a data centre at 27 Tampines Street 92. The loan is considered an "interested person transaction" due to Keppel Land's indirect 30% interest in Keppel Datahub 2.

site_title: Bank of England holds interest rate at 0.50%
summary: The Bank of England maintained its main interest rate at a record-low 0.50% due to zero inflation. The decision was made by a 8-1 majority, with Governor Mark Carney hinting that the time for a rate hike is approaching. The central bank's cash stimulus remains at £375 billion. The near-term outlook for inflation is muted, with energy price falls expected to continue until mid-2026, keeping inflation below the 2% target.

site_title: IHH says it hasn't acquired stake in Global Hospitals Group
summary: IHH Healthcare Berhad has clarified that it is in discussions with Global Hospitals Group's shareholders for a potential acquisition, but no definitive agreements have been reached. The group has not acquired a stake in the Indian-based company, and any future transaction will be announced according to Bursa Malaysia Securities Berhad's requirements. IHH is evaluating growth opportunities in Asia and has not provided guidance on the potential acquisition.

site_title: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine expects to report loss in Q2
summary: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine Holdings expects to report a net loss in Q2 2015 due to low demand for maintenance of rigs and related goods and services caused by the fall in global oil prices. The group is finalizing its results for Q2 and plans to disclose further details on or before August 14.

site_title: Cosco units to extend delivery dates of floating accommodation units
summary: Cosco Corporation (Singapore) has agreed to extend the delivery dates of two floating accommodation units (FAUs) at the request of a shipowner. The first FAU has been delivered, while the second will be delivered 12 months after its original October 2015 date, and the third FAU will be delivered 120 days later than scheduled in Q1 2017. The extensions are not expected to have a material impact on the company's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the financial year ending December 31, 2015.

site_title: Forex movements hurt Ascendas Hospitality Trust's income in Q1
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust reported a 3.2% increase in Q1 distribution per unit to 1.28 Singapore cents, despite a 2.7% drop in gross revenue to S$52.8 million. The decline was due to the weakening of the Australian and Japanese currencies against the Singapore dollar. Despite this, the trust's Australia portfolio showed strong growth in local currencies, with a 10% year-on-year increase in net property income in A$ terms. The trust will retain up to 5% of income for working capital purposes starting from this quarter.

site_title: Goldman sees oil staying lower for longer to end supply glut
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts oil prices will remain lower for longer to balance the global supply glut, with a supply surplus of 2 million barrels per day. Low prices are needed to offset productivity gains and keep investment minimal. Despite a potential rebalancing by 2016, prices may not rebound due to emerging producers, including Iran, and OPEC's increased output. Goldman maintains a near-term target for West Texas Intermediate of $45 a barrel, citing the oil industry's struggle to earn its cost of capital due to low prices.

site_title: Ho Bee Land's Q2 profit jumps 37%
summary: Ho Bee Land reported a 37% increase in net profit to S$16.7 million for Q2 2015, driven by a 14% rise in revenue from The Metropolis office building in Singapore. The company's acquisition of two London properties has diversified its investment portfolio to S$2.6 billion, enhancing recurrent income and aligning with its growth strategy.

site_title: Hackers turn off Tesla Model S at low speed: FT
summary: Cybersecurity researchers have found six significant flaws in Tesla's software that could allow hackers to take control of the vehicles. Researchers, Kevin Mahaffey and Marc Rogers, took control of a Tesla Model S at low speed, shutting it down by turning off the screens, music, and handbrake. Tesla has issued a patch to fix the flaws, which will be available to all drivers by Thursday. This hack follows a similar attack on Fiat Chrysler's Jeep Cherokee last month, prompting the company to recall 1.4 million vehicles.

site_title: Airbus orders lag Boeing in Jan-July
summary: Airbus secured 408 gross plane orders in the first seven months of 2015, lagging Boeing with 426 aircraft sales. Excluding cancellations, Airbus had 367 net orders from January to July 31, compared to Boeing's 380. The gap narrowed slightly in July, with 26 new orders for Airbus, including 25 A321neo jets.

site_title: China asks port operators to reduce fees
summary: China's transport ministry has asked port operators to reduce fees in a bid to spur the development of its shipping industry. The move, part of efforts to modernize domestic shipping, will limit fees to a few services, including parking and waste disposal. The ministry aims to secure supply chains and align with tax and regulatory reforms. This step is part of China's broader efforts to boost its shipping sector, which is crucial for the country's trade.

site_title: NSP says WP offered to give up MacPherson to avoid three-cornered fight in Marine Parade
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) offered to give up the Macpherson constituency to the National Solidarity Party (NSP) in exchange for the NSP staying away from the Marine Parade Group Representation Constituency (GRC). This came during an opposition parties' meeting on Monday. The NSP's president, Sebastian Teo, confirmed the offer, which was made by WP representatives. The decision was reportedly made to avoid a three-cornered fight in the Marine Parade GRC.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Thursday, closing at 1,694.64 after losing 30.92 points. The Kuala Lumpur Composite Index saw 1.65 billion lots valued at RM2.02 billion traded, with 187 gains and 686 losses.

images.alt_text: Malaysian stocks recorded their biggest advance in two years, led by a rally in state-controlled companies, after Prime Minister Najib Razak said the government will tap a fund to support the nation's equities.

site_title: IAG orders 31 Airbus planes as seeks to modernise Iberia fleet
summary: IAG, the holding company of British Airways and Iberia, has ordered 31 Airbus planes, including 11 long-haul aircraft for Iberia, worth US$4.6 billion. The order includes 8 A350-900 and 3 A330-300 widebody planes to be delivered between 2016 and 2021, enabling Iberia to replace and expand its existing long-haul fleet.

site_title: London Tube strike causes major disruption
summary: London Underground staff staged their second strike in a month, shutting down the subway network due to plans to run 24-hour trains on Fridays and Saturdays from September 12. The strike caused major disruption, with millions of commuters forced to walk, cycle, or take overcrowded buses. The dispute centers on pay and staffing concerns, with the unions rejecting a two percent salary increase offer. The strike is the second network-wide closure in a month, with the unions calling for the launch of the service to be delayed pending further talks.

site_title: Fifa sponsor McDonald's backs independent reform body-group
summary: McDonald's, a FIFA sponsor, has joined Coca-Cola and Visa in urging the governing body to adopt an independent reform commission, following scandals that have plagued FIFA. The campaign group New FIFA Now welcomed the move, saying an independent body is necessary for meaningful change. FIFA President Sepp Blatter will step down in February, and a Reform Task Force, comprising representatives from regional confederations, is set to make proposals in September. The move aims to bring credibility, transparency, and neutrality to FIFA's reform efforts.

site_title: China meddling in stock market seen discouraging return of foreign funds
summary: China's recent intervention in its stock market has discouraged foreign fund managers from returning to the market, with many viewing Beijing's efforts to curb short-selling and restrict shareholder sales as a setback to its economic reform push. Despite the size of China's economy, foreign investment remains limited due to concerns over market regulation and intervention. Fund managers are now adopting a more cautious approach, considering creating balanced products and shifting exposure to bonds over equities, and are only considering a return to the market if Beijing reduces its intervention.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore dropped 0.5% in July, with four-room, five-room, and executive flats being the main drag. Meanwhile, Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. In international news, Citigroup predicts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index, and Thailand's Prime Minister Thaksin is confident his daughter's suspension will be cleared by the court. The UK economy shrunk for the second month, and South Korea's trade chief seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end the week weaker amid thin volume on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped for two days this week, with Thursday's 5.27-point rise only a weak attempt at a National Day rally. The STI lost about six points for the week, with low volume and a decline in interest in penny stocks contributing to the decline. Volatility in the China market and concerns over US interest rates, potentially raised in September, also affected the local market.

site_title: Thailand sets impeachment vote date for former MPs
summary: Thailand's junta-picked parliament has set a vote date of August 14 for the impeachment of 248 former MPs, mostly from the ousted ruling party of Yingluck Shinawatra. The ex-lawmakers face a five-year ban from politics if impeached, potentially decimating the Shinawatra family's political base. They are accused of supporting a constitutional amendment deemed unconstitutional.

site_title: UK industrial output unexpectedly falls in June
summary: UK industrial output unexpectedly fell 0.4% in June, contrary to expectations of a 0.1% rise. Manufacturing output rose 0.2%, but oil and gas production plummeted 5.8% due to maintenance, the largest monthly drop since 2014. This slowdown, combined with weak demand from crisis-stricken Europe and a strong pound, poses a challenge for policymakers seeking balanced long-term economic growth.

site_title: Hyflux earnings plunge 58% in Q2
summary: Hyflux, a water treatment firm, reported a 58% drop in net profit for the second quarter, reaching S$25.95 million, despite an 18% increase in revenue to S$94.8 million. The decline was attributed to lower disposal gains. The company will continue to explore potential divestment opportunities, with Olivia Lum stating that growth in the Middle East and North Africa and divestment opportunities will be key areas of focus. Earnings per share fell to 1.68 cents, significantly lower than the previous year.

site_title: Second phase of Downtown Line with 12 stations to open on Dec 27
summary: The second phase of Singapore's Downtown MRT Line (DTL2) with 12 stations will open on December 27. Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew announced that rides on the Downtown Line, including the six-station DTL1, will be free for a "short period of time" to familiarize commuters with the new network.

site_title: SGX reports increased activity in securities, derivatives and commodities trading in July
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported increased activity in securities, derivatives, and commodities trading in July, with a 15% year-over-year growth. The average daily trading value of securities decreased 7% month-on-month to S$1.1 billion, while total turnover for securities rose 15% year-over-year to S$24.2 billion.

site_title: Malaysian ringgit weakens past 3.9000/dollar for first time in nearly 17 years
summary: The Malaysian ringgit has weakened to 3.9000 per dollar, its weakest in nearly 17 years, amid concerns over a corruption scandal involving the prime minister. Local shares fell 1.2% and government bond prices rose, with the 5-year bond yield reaching 3.708% and the 10-year yield at 4.091%. This decline in the ringgit's value is the first since 1998, when the government pegged it at 3.8000.

site_title: For MH370 families, debris leaves uncertainty in its wake
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak confirmed that a wing part found on Reunion island came from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, but French investigators have a "strong presumption" the debris came from the aircraft. The discovery validates the hypothesis that Flight 370 crashed in the Indian Ocean, but relatives of the 239 people who vanished need more definitive answers before concluding their loved ones died. Investigators will conduct microscopic analyses and chemical studies of the flaperon for clues to the nature of the disaster, but some family members want to see physical evidence before finding closure.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz July sales jump to record on China, Europe demand
summary: Mercedes-Benz reported a record 149,753 car deliveries in July, a 15.2% increase from the previous month, driven by double-digit gains in Europe and China. This brings the seven-month total to a record 1.048 million autos, up 14.7% from the same period last year. China sales surged 41.5%, while Europe sales rose 11.6%. The results mark a significant boost to the luxury division's sales, highlighting strong demand for Mercedes-Benz vehicles in key markets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 0.57% down
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.57% down on Thursday, driven by mixed US economic data and mainland market volatility. The Hang Seng Index fell 138.88 points to 24,375.28, with a turnover of HK$67.30 billion. This marks a decline in the benchmark index.

site_title: Aircraft seat cushions, window panes found on Reunion: Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's transport minister Liow Tiong Lai announced that aircraft seat cushions and window panes were found on Reunion Island, where MH370 wreckage was recovered. The items are being verified by French authorities to determine if they belong to the missing Malaysia Airlines flight. The discovery comes after Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak confirmed a wing component found on Reunion was from MH370 earlier in the day. The search for MH370, which disappeared on March 8, 2014, remains ongoing.

site_title: Stocks in Greece rebound from 2012 low as selloff in banks stops
summary: Greek stocks rose for the first time since markets reopened, with the benchmark ASE Index adding 3.4% to 665.37. National Bank of Greece SA jumped 23%, while Attica Bank SA and Eurobank Ergasias SA climbed over 13%. The rebound comes after a three-day selloff that wiped out more than half the value of banks. The market had been halted due to emergency curbs and capital controls, limiting daily moves to 30%. Greek stocks have lost over 89% of their value since 2007.

site_title: Germany has growing doubts about quick deal on Greek aid: Bild
summary: Germany's government expresses growing doubts about a quick deal on a multi-billion-euro bailout for Greece, with a 3.5-billion-euro debt payment to the European Central Bank due on August 20. Without a bailout deal, Athens will need bridge financing, casting doubt on meeting the August 20 deadline. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras claims Greece is close to concluding a deal with lenders, but Germany's concerns raise uncertainty about the outcome.

site_title: A-Reit explores investment opportunities in mature developed markets
summary: Ascendas Reit (A-Reit), Singapore's largest industrial Reit, is exploring investment opportunities in mature developed markets like Australia and Germany, aiming to increase its portfolio to 20-30% of its total. The Reit's portfolio will remain predominantly Singapore-based, but diversification is expected to strengthen the portfolio and yield long-term sustainable returns. A-Reit reported improved earnings in its first quarter, with a 5.5% increase in distribution per unit to 3.841 cents, and its units rose one cent to S$2.41 on the stock market.

site_title: UK house prices fall first time in five months, Halifax says
summary: UK house prices fell 0.6% in July, marking the first decline in five months, according to Halifax. The average home price dropped to £198,883 (US$311,000). Despite this, the overall trend of rising values is expected to recover, driven by tight supply and economic demand. Halifax's managing director, Stephen Noakes, believes house price growth will remain robust in the near term. The Bank of England is also expected to keep interest rates at 0.5%, supporting demand and holding down borrowing costs.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip as ANZ capital raising sends jitters through sector
summary: Australian shares dropped 1.1% on Thursday, their largest decline in two weeks, as investors sold bank stocks amid concerns over new capital rules. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,610.1. The decline was driven by a sharp fall in the ANZ share price following a capital raising announcement. Despite gains in commodities, the sell-off in bank stocks outweighed the positive impact, leading to the index's biggest one-day decline since July 22.

site_title: Swiss franc hit 5-mth low vs euro, expectations of more SNB action grow
summary: The Swiss franc fell to a 5-month low against the euro, reaching 1.0701 francs, as investors cut positions amid concerns of deflation and pressure on the Swiss National Bank to ease monetary policy. Safe-haven inflows, which supported the franc in recent months, were decreasing. The euro rose 0.3% and the dollar increased 0.2% against the franc, driven by thin trading conditions and interventions by the Swiss National Bank.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise on a weaker yen but gains pared as China slips
summary: Japanese shares rose 0.2% to 20,644.44 on Thursday, driven by a weaker yen, but gains were pared by weaker Chinese stocks and caution ahead of the US non-farm payrolls report. The broader Topix gained 0.5% and the JPX-Nikkei Index 400 climbed 0.5%. Despite the rally, investors remain cautious due to tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Greece's National Bank, Eurobank rebound sharply in early trading
summary: Shares in Greece's National Bank and Eurobank rebounded sharply in early trading on Thursday, reversing a 63% decline in the banking-stock sector over three days. NBG rose 8.8% and Eurobank gained 7.7% as investors appeared to be optimistic about the banks' prospects despite concerns over a potential recapitalization that may hurt existing shareholders.

site_title: Japan's Takata swings to Q1 net profit on higher US sales
summary: Japan's Takata Corp reported a net profit of 3 billion yen (US$24.05 million) in the first quarter, reversing a 38.65 billion yen loss in the same period last year. The company attributed the improvement to higher sales in the US, India, and Southeast Asia. Takata maintained its net profit forecast for the fiscal year at 20 billion yen. The company's air bag inflator safety issues remain a concern, but the profit boost is seen as a positive sign for the company.

site_title: China's version of Airbnb, Tujia, raises US$300m
summary: China's Tujia.com, a vacation rental website similar to Airbnb, has raised $300 million in funding, valuing the company at over $1 billion. The new financing comes from All-Stars Investment Ltd. and CapitaLand's Ascott International. Tujia claims to be China's largest vacation rental website with 385 destinations, primarily focusing on meeting the needs of Chinese tourists overseas, particularly in Southeast Asia. The company has been doubling its performance growth almost every quarter, expanding its services for serviced apartments and home-stays.

site_title: Chinese developers come home to asset-backed securitisation
summary: China's property developers are returning to the asset-backed securitisation market after a three-year absence, driven by lighter rules. Shimao Property Holdings has packaged its future management fees into an asset-backed securitisation worth 1.5 billion yuan (US$243 million), set to start trading next week. The success of this deal could attract more companies to China's securitisation market, following the central bank's April change in rules allowing companies to register with the central bank without regulatory review and approval.

site_title: Weak metals prices drag Rio Tinto H1 underlying earnings down 43%
summary: Rio Tinto's first-half underlying earnings fell 43% to US$2.9 billion due to weak metals prices, particularly iron ore. The company's iron ore division saw earnings decline 55% to US$2.099 billion. Despite a modest recovery in iron ore prices, they remain down 22% this year. Overall earnings were in line with analysts' forecasts, with the company citing a "robust" result given the tough operating environment.

site_title: Aviva Asia posts 18% rise in value of new business in H1
summary: Aviva Asia posted an 18% increase in value of new business (VNB) to £76 million for the first half of 2015, driven by growth in Greater China and South-east Asia. Singapore saw a 29.7% rise in VNB, while China's VNB rose 15%. Globally, the group posted a 25% rise in VNB to £534 million, lifted by the UK and Ireland markets. The company attributed its success to its growth strategy and new joint ventures, with a goal of becoming a top five life insurer in Indonesia by 2025.

site_title: China: Shares fall, investors await economic data
summary: China's stocks fell 0.9% on Thursday, with the CSI300 index closing at 3,831.85 points, as investors awaited economic data and remained cautious despite government support. The Shanghai Composite Index also declined 0.9% to 3,661.99 points. The market's performance was subdued, with some investors waiting for direction from upcoming economic data.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed on patchy US economic data
summary: Asian stocks were mixed in early trading on Thursday due to patchy US economic data. The US service sector expanded 4.3% in July, while payroll firm ADP estimated 185,000 jobs added, below analysts' estimate of 220,000. Tokyo rose 0.66%, while Sydney fell 0.69% on a major bank's share sale, and Seoul lost 0.29%. The Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) rose 0.4% despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Weak yen, returning carmakers throw lifeline to Japan's steel mills
summary: Japanese steelmakers are expected to see a boost in demand as automakers shift production back home due to a weaker yen. The yen's 60% decline in the past three years has prompted automakers to increase domestic production, lifting demand for steel used in cars and construction. Japan's steel output could rise by 700,000 by 2017-18, potentially pushing demand to above 10 million, as car production increases by 700,000. This could lead to an increase in steel production of 5% from 2014 levels.

site_title: China's top bank regulator says bad loans surge, profit growth slows in cooling economy
summary: China's top bank regulator, Shang Fulin, reported a 35.7% surge in bad loans at Chinese banks during the first half of 2015, reaching 1.8 trillion yuan. This rise, combined with a slowdown in profit growth, indicates a cooling economy. Non-performing loans (NPLs) increased by 322.2 billion yuan, while total net profits decreased by 13.03 percentage points from a year ago, totaling 1.1 trillion yuan.

site_title: Singapore Exchange to launch iron ore lump swap, futures
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will launch iron ore lump premium swap and futures contracts on August 31, providing hedging tools for market participants amid volatile iron ore prices. The new contracts will allow for price risk management of iron ore lump, which was previously an unhedgeable risk. Each lot of the swap contract will be 500 tonnes, and each futures contract will be 100 tonnes, with prices set off the Platts iron ore spot lump premium 62.5-per cent China index reference price. This launch follows a record high volume of iron ore swaps, futures, and options in July.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange said on Thursday it will launch iron ore lump premium swap and futures contracts on Aug 31, hoping to provide more hedging tools for market participants managing risks amid volatile prices of the raw material.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets dropped at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.43% to 6,723.69 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris's CAC 40 also declined, with the Bank of England expected to keep its interest rate at 0.50% on Thursday. The drop comes ahead of US jobs data, which could confirm expectations of a Federal Reserve rate rise next month.

site_title: Adidas mulls options for struggling golf business
summary: German sportswear company Adidas is considering options for its struggling golf business, including selling off its Adams and Ashworth brands. The company reported a 15% increase in group sales and a 1% rise in net profit, beating analyst forecasts. Adidas is also restructuring its TaylorMade golf brand, where sales fell 26% in the second quarter. The company is looking to address the decline in golf popularity, particularly in the US, where the sport has seen a significant drop in participation.

site_title: Australian unemployment rate rises to 6.3%
summary: Australia's unemployment rate rose to 6.3% in July, exceeding expectations, despite the creation of 38,500 new jobs. The increase in the jobless rate, which has edged up over the past year to a decade-high, is attributed to the economy's struggles to shift away from mining-led investment. Wages growth remains weak, and business investment outside the mining sector remains soft. The participation rate surged to 65.1% in July, while the Australian dollar slipped to 73.43 US cents following the data release.

site_title: Anger and disbelief from MH370 China relatives over debris
summary: Chinese relatives of MH370 passengers expressed anger and disbelief over the discovery of debris from the missing plane, which Malaysia's prime minister confirmed was from the jet. Many relatives believe their loved ones are alive and being held at an unknown location, despite mounting evidence of a fatal crash. Relatives gathered outside Malaysia Airlines' Beijing office, holding signs and crying, with some calling for the truth and others expressing skepticism about the official explanation.

site_title: Malaysian palm oil producers renew expansion push into Philippines
summary: Malaysian palm oil producers are expanding into the Philippines, particularly in Mindanao, as the country's southern region offers fertile land for palm oil plantations. Following a historic peace deal between the government and Muslim rebels, Malaysian palm oil producers see opportunities to build new plantations. The move aims to complement the local coconut oil industry and capitalize on the Philippines' need for palm oil imports. Malaysia aims to ship at least 500,000 tonnes of palm oil to the Philippines this year, accounting for 80% of the country's imports.

images.alt_text: Malaysian palm oil producers are seeking fresh opportunities in the Philippines, aiming to build plantations in the country's southern region, where a historic peace deal has been forged between the government and Muslim rebels.

site_title: No consensus on next TPP meet; drugs a key hurdle: Japan official
summary: Japan officials failed to reach a consensus on the date for a new round of talks on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a pan-Pacific trade deal, after ministers disagreed on auto trade, dairy goods, and next-generation drugs. The talks, which involve 12 nations, including the US, Japan, and Canada, had early optimism but stalled due to disagreements over biologic drugs and rules of origin for cars. A deal is expected to be reached, with countries committed to concluding the agreement, but a specific date has yet to be determined.

site_title: German orders beat expectations in June as foreign demand surges
summary: German industrial orders rose 2.0% in June, beating expectations and suggesting a likely rise in industry output in the coming months. The surge in foreign demand helped, with 4.8% more bookings from abroad and a 2.0% decrease in domestic orders. The economy ministry expects the economy to expand by around 0.3% in the April-June period, supported by domestic demand and foreign trade. The positive momentum could carry into the third quarter, with recent sentiment indicators suggesting industry will continue to grow moderately.

site_title: Global business growth accelerated in July on order boost: PMI
summary: Global business growth accelerated in July, driven by a boost in new orders and a rise in backlogs of work. The JPMorgan Global All-Industry Output Index rose to 53.4, above the 50 mark that divides growth from contraction. New orders climbed to a three-month high of 54.3, while the service industry's global PMI rose to 53.9. This growth is a positive sign for the global economy, indicating a strong recovery.

site_title: Update: Australia's ANZ unveils US$2.2b share sale; more fundraising seen
summary: Australia's ANZ Banking Group will raise A$3 billion in a share sale to meet tougher capital ratio rules, following a smaller-than-expected offering. The bank aims to boost its Tier-I capital ratio to 9.3%, and analysts predict further capital raises are likely. ANZ's weaker capital ratio and slower response to regulatory changes are expected to require a total of A$9 billion to A$10 billion in capital. The share sale is the first step in meeting the requirements, with other fundraising efforts likely to follow.

site_title: Weighted new business premiums up 3% in H1: Life Insurance Association
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw a 3% growth in weighted new business premiums to S$1.35 billion in the first half of 2015, driven by investment-linked products and a 2% increase in weighted single premium products to S$387.8 million. Despite low interest rates, sales of investment-linked plans increased, while traditional single premium plans declined. Investment-linked products accounted for 20% of total weighted new business premiums, with participating products making up 55%.

images.alt_text: LIA Singapore president Khoo Kah Siang noted that amid the relatively low interest rates, sales of traditional single premium plans dropped while sales of investment-linked plans (both single premium and regular premium) picked up despite the volatile equity market.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 0.75% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.75% in early trading on Thursday, following gains on Wall Street due to mixed economic data and a weaker yen supporting Japanese exporters. US stocks finished mostly higher, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index reaching fresh records. The yen's decline was attributed to expectations of earlier US interest rate hikes, which weakened the currency and bolstered Japanese stocks.

site_title: Metro buys Singapore-based food service group for US$290m
summary: Metro AG acquired Singapore-based restaurant supplier Classic Fine Foods Group for $290 million. The deal comes as the German retailer reported a slowdown in same-store sales, with earnings before interest and taxation falling 17% to 209 million euros. Metro attributed the decline to Easter falling earlier this year, which led to a 0.4% decline in like-for-like sales. Despite the challenge, Metro reiterated its forecast for a slight rise in sales for the 2014/15 financial year.

site_title: Ackman discloses 7.5% stake in Mondelez
summary: Bill Ackman's Pershing Square Holdings Ltd disclosed a 7.5% stake in Mondelez International Inc, valued at about $5.5 billion. Ackman wants Mondelez to grow revenues faster and cut costs significantly, or consider selling itself to a rival, such as Kraft Heinz Co. This move squeezes the company between two prominent activist investors, Nelson Peltz's Trian Fund Management LP, which holds a 3% stake. Mondelez has recently taken cost-cutting measures and raised its share buyback plan.

site_title: South Korea president says economy needs 'major surgery'
summary: South Korea's President Park Geun-hye called for "major surgery" on the economy, citing slowing growth and increasing challenges. The economy recorded its weakest growth in six years in the second quarter, affected by the Mers outbreak and poor exports. Park proposed reforms in the labour market, public corporations, education, and the financial sector to address chronic problems and youth unemployment. She also announced a salary cap for older government employees and plans to deregulate the financial sector, aiming to improve efficiency and reduce waste.

images.alt_text: South Korea's president called on Thursday for "major sugery" on the economy, which faces slowing growth and increasing challenges as she approaches the half-way point of her single five-year term.

site_title: HDB resale prices down 0.5% in July: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices dropped 0.5% in July, according to SRX Property's flash estimate, with four-room, five-room, and executive flats being the main drag. This represents a 4.3% drop from a year ago and an 11.4% slump from the peak in April 2013. Resale volume for HDB flats also contracted, with 1,552 flats sold in July, down 9.2% from June.

site_title: Argentine duo wanted in Fifa scandal fight extradition to US
summary: Two Argentine businessmen, Hugo and Mariano Jinkis, wanted in the US for their alleged involvement in the Fifa corruption scandal, are fighting extradition to the US. The Jinkis, owners of sports marketing company Full Play, were under house arrest in Argentina before refusing extradition to a federal judge. They will now stand trial in Buenos Aires to determine their fate. The US has already indicted another Argentine businessman, Alejandro Burzaco, who is facing racketeering and money laundering charges.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks drop 1.87% in morning trade
summary: Shanghai stocks dropped 1.87% in morning trade on August 6, 2015, extending losses from the previous day. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 69.07 points to 3,625.50, while the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 2.05% to 2,084.89. Despite recent government efforts to stabilize the market, sentiment weakened.

site_title: Oil hovers near multi-month lows, Brent below US$50
summary: Oil prices hovered near multi-month lows on Thursday, with Brent crude dipping to US$49.71 a barrel, its lowest since January 30. Investors sold crude amid concerns about rising US gasoline inventories, which rose more than expected, overriding a drop in crude stockpiles. Experts believe the US has a surplus of crude supply, while the rest of the world is oversupplied, leading to high inventories.

site_title: Seoul: Shares edge down, won steady ahead of key US jobs data
summary: Seoul shares edged down 0.3% to 2,022.97 points ahead of key US jobs data that could influence the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates in September. Foreign selling weighed on the main board, while large caps pressured the index down. The US jobs data is expected to impact market direction and influence investor sentiment.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 4.71 points lower at 1,720.85, with a trading volume of 72.9 million lots worth RM15 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 90 to 71.

site_title: Seoul: Won inches up ahead of US key jobs data; shares fall
summary: The South Korean won rose 0.6% to 1,166.2 against the dollar ahead of US non-farm payrolls data, trimming dollar-long positions. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 0.8%, with Samsung and Hyundai Motor Co Ltd dropping 3.8% and 4.1%, respectively. Foreign and local institutional selling resulted in a net 87 billion won and 145.3 billion won offloaded from the market.

images.alt_text: Seoul shares reversed early losses to close at a three-week high on Thursday as recently undervalued shares extended gains, while foreigners continuously offloaded local stocks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.31% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.31% lower on Thursday, following mixed US economic data that fueled uncertainty among investors. The Hang Seng Index eased 76.98 points to 24,437.18. This move came despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a rise in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices in the US. The uncertainty is attributed to ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff concerns.

site_title: China urges Malaysia to continue to investigate cause of MH370 incident
summary: China has urged Malaysia to continue investigating the cause of the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, after a piece of the plane's wing was found on an Indian Ocean island beach. The foreign ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying called on Malaysia to "earnestly safeguard the legitimate rights and interests" of the victims' families.

site_title: Indonesia orders new Bali airport closure due to volcano
summary: Indonesian authorities have ordered a closure of Ngurah Rai airport in Bali due to ash drifting from Mount Raung, a volcano on Java island. The airport will be closed for several hours starting from midday, causing flight cancellations and travel disruptions for thousands of tourists. This is the fourth shutdown of the airport in recent weeks, during peak holiday season. Ash clouds shot out by the volcano reached 1,000 meters, larger than usual emissions, and air traffic is regularly disrupted by volcanic eruptions in Indonesia, which is home to 130 active volcanoes.

site_title: Britons prefer using smartphones rather than laptops to go online: Watchdog
summary: The UK's telecoms regulator, Ofcom, has found that smartphones have surpassed laptops as the preferred method for Britons to go online. A third of people now use their smartphones first, while 30% use laptops, up from 40% and 22% respectively a year ago. The average daily usage of smartphones has increased to 1 hour and 54 minutes, and users often turn to their phones within five minutes of waking up. Meanwhile, TV viewing has decreased by 11 minutes to 3 hours and 40 minutes per day.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks slip; Apple supplier Largan falls
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.3% on Thursday, weighed down by Largan Precision, a key supplier of Apple Inc, which reported lower-than-expected July sales and cut its August outlook. Largan dropped 7% and sent the electronics index down 0.5%. TPK Holding Co Ltd also fell 3%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.674 per US dollar.

site_title: F&N says MEHL confirms sale of F&N's 55% stake in Myanmar Brewery for US$560m
summary: Frasers and Neaves (F&N) confirmed the sale of its 55% stake in Myanmar Brewery Limited to Myanma Economic Holdings Ltd (MEHL) for US$560 million, following a court dismissal of MEHL's interim injunction application. The sale price is based on the 2013 exchange rate between the Myanmar kyat and the US dollar. MEHL had initially sought a sale price of US$400 million.

site_title: China's steel city feels impact of pollution regulations
summary: China's steel city, Tangshan, is experiencing a significant impact from new pollution regulations, with some firms scaling back production or closing due to weak demand and crippling debt. The city, which produces more steel than the US, is on the frontline of China's efforts to tackle a severe steel capacity glut and reduce smog. The regulations have lifted local steel prices off 20-year lows, providing some relief to the sector. China's efforts aim to help tackle environmental issues and reduce the sector's crippling debt.

site_title: Australia added 38,500 jobs in July as doubts linger over data
summary: Australia added 38,500 jobs in July, exceeding the median forecast of 10,000, but the jobless rate rose to 6.3% due to a surge in labor market entrants. The number of full-time jobs rose 12,400 and part-time employment increased 26,100. Despite this, concerns remain about data volatility and sub-trend growth. Central Bank Governor Glenn Stevens noted the economy is likely to operate with spare capacity for some time, and the Australian dollar traded at 73.28 US cents after the data release.

site_title: China's stock buying spree seen at US$145b with more to go
summary: China's government has injected approximately $145 billion into the stock market to prop up its struggling stock prices over the past two months. This represents 2.2% of the country's free-trade market capitalization. Despite concerns that the government will unwind its intervention, Goldman Sachs predicts that more than $1 trillion remains available to support the market. Chinese shares have lost nearly $3.4 trillion in value since June 12, with the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 30% amid market concerns and an exodus of leveraged investors.

site_title: Ringgit weakens most in Asia as psychological reserves mark eyed
summary: The Malaysian ringgit weakened the most in Asia, dropping 10% due to a decline in foreign-exchange reserves to $100.5 billion, the lowest level since the 2008 global credit crunch. Speculation of Bank Negara Malaysia intervening to smooth out volatility and a slump in oil prices have contributed to the decline, which has reached a 17-year low. The currency's value fell to 3.8905 a dollar, while the US dollar-yen exchange rate strengthened.

site_title: Indonesia stocks seen extending Asia's worst drop on growth risk
summary: Indonesia's Jakarta Composite Index has dropped 12% from its record high, making its price-to-book ratio the cheapest in six years. The economy's slowdown and weak currency limit the central bank's ability to cut interest rates, making shares unattractive to investors. President Joko Widodo's spending plans face challenges, and analysts predict a further 17% decline in the index for shares to become attractive again.

site_title: Time Warner falls as Disney's cable warning spooks sector
summary: Time Warner's shares plummeted 9% after Disney warned investors that more people are cutting the cord and switching to video-streaming from paid TV. Disney cited a decline in subscribers and cut its profit forecast for its cable networks unit. Despite Time Warner's strong quarterly results, boosted by deals with Hulu and game releases, investors were spooked by Disney's comments. Time Warner's revenue rose 8% to $7.35 billion, with its HBO network earning $1.25 per share, exceeding analysts' expectations.

site_title: Female graduates' pay tops men's from science to art history
summary: Researchers at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York found that female college graduates earn as much as or more than their male counterparts in 29 fields, including engineering, art history, and social services. Women earn 16% more in social services and 10% more in industrial engineering, but the gap evaporates by age 35-45. The reasons for the disparity are unclear, but potential factors include discrimination, career interruptions, and changes in corporate recruitment and promotion practices.

site_title: Greek air traffic controller strike disrupts holiday travel
summary: Greek air traffic controllers went on a four-hour strike, disrupting holiday travel and causing 22 flight cancellations and 173 delays at airports nationwide. The strike, which occurred on August 5, 2015, was in response to demands for a system overhaul to bring the air traffic control system in line with European norms. The controllers cited deficiencies in the current structure and procedures as the reason for the strike. The strike occurred during a time of negotiations between Greece's far-left government and international creditors for a third bailout.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC loses free float as offeror crosses 90% stake threshold
summary: STATS ChipPAC's free float falls below 10% after China's Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology Co (JCET) crosses the 90% stake threshold. JCET's takeover offer will suspend trading of the company's shares on the Singapore Exchange. The group intends to take STATS ChipPAC private, with no plans to extend the offer beyond August 27.

site_title: Adidas buys fitness tracking app maker Runtastic
summary: Adidas has acquired fitness tracking app maker Runtastic for 220 million euros, gaining access to 70 million active users and expanding its presence in connected wearables. The deal helps Adidas compete with rivals Nike and Under Armour, which have also been investing in fitness tracking technology. Adidas aims to leverage Runtastic's 20+ apps covering various fitness activities and 18 languages to enhance its offerings and catch up with competitors.

site_title: Asia: Stocks climb on optimism over US economy but bets on a Fed rate hike sink bonds
summary: Asian stocks rose 0.4% as optimism over the US economy boosted the US dollar and copper prices, despite mounting bets on a Fed rate hike. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index advanced, with Japan's Topix index gaining 0.9%. Copper climbed 0.4% and oil near its lowest price since March 19. Market participants expect a September rate hike from the Federal Reserve, with odds climbing to 52% this week. Economists expect the jobless rate to hold at 5.3% in Friday's payrolls data.

site_title: ANZ plans A$3b share raising to meet extra capital rules
summary: ANZ Banking Group is raising A$3 billion in capital through an institutional placement and share purchase plan to meet new capital requirements set by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority. The move follows the regulator's announcement that Australia's four main lenders need to hold an average of A$5.4 billion in capital against potential home loan losses. ANZ reported a A$5.4 billion cash profit for the nine months through June and plans to price shares above A$30.95. The bank aims to accommodate additional capital requirements efficiently and quickly.

site_title: Modi's "port-led" export drive leaves India's hinterland stranded
summary: India's port-led export drive, launched by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, faces challenges as exporters struggle with high transportation costs and inefficient logistics. The country's commercial seaport in Mumbai is doubling capacity to support industrial growth and create manufacturing jobs, but exporters like Avinash Gupta, who supply steel forgings to Europe and the US, are finding it difficult to compete due to high rail cargo costs. The expansion aims to slash costs and transport times, but opposition to a new tax and land acquisition law may delay progress, exacerbating the pain of weak global demand and a 15% drop in exports.

site_title: Tesla stock falls on wider loss, CEO comments on cash need
summary: Tesla's stock fell 6% after the company posted a wider quarterly loss of $184.2 million and said it may raise more cash to offset heavy spending on expanded production. CEO Elon Musk said the company may need additional funds for "risk reduction." Tesla lowered its full-year sales forecast to 50,000-55,000 cars and reported revenue of $955 million, a 24% increase. The company's cash reserves fell to $1.15 billion, and Musk estimated the new storage battery business could generate $400-500 million in revenue in 2016.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding logs significantly lower Q2 earnings
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 17% decline in Q2 net profit to 1.03 billion yuan (S$229.3 million) due to weakening profit margins. Analysts are divided on the company's outlook, with some citing potential benefits from mergers and acquisitions. The company's earnings were lower than expected, raising concerns about the shipbuilding industry's performance.

site_title: Noble says it has fully redeemed its senior notes due 2015 and 2020
summary: NOBLE Group has fully redeemed its senior notes due 2015 and 2020, with no outstanding securities. The US$500 million 4.875% senior notes due 2015 and US$235 million 6.625% senior notes due 2020 were redeemed on August 5, as scheduled. The company had sufficient cash and liquidity to fund the redemption and operations, with around US$15 billion in bank lines and over US$1 billion in readily available cash. This move follows a brief share price rebound after Noble provided assurances on its ability to meet obligations.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) opened higher at 3,192.49 on Thursday, up 1.1 points or 0.03% following a rise in US stocks after technology companies posted better-than-expected earnings. Top volume stocks included CapitaLand, Noble Group, EMS Energy, and Jason Holdings, which rose 1.9%, 1.8%, 4.8%, and 6.9% respectively. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Gold under pressure after US data, rate rise in focus
summary: Gold prices eased on Wednesday, hovering above a 5-1/2 year low, as the US dollar rebounded after initial pressure from weak private sector hiring data. The dollar surged after a stronger-than-forecast private report on the US services sector, pushing gold prices to a 2-month high. The prospect of a US interest rate rise in September has increased the opportunity cost of holding gold, with prices down 0.2% at US$1,085.35 an ounce.

site_title: Oil prices fall after mixed US petroleum data
summary: Oil prices fell after a US government report showed an unexpected rise in gasoline inventories and an increase in oil production amid global oversupply worries. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) fell 59 cents to $45.15 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude fell 40 cents to $49.59 a barrel. The report showed US production rebounded to 9.5 million barrels per day, exacerbating concerns about a global supply glut.

site_title: Microsoft boosts parental leave, on heels of Netflix
summary: Microsoft has expanded its parental leave policy, offering full pay for 12 weeks to new mothers and fathers, plus eight additional weeks of maternity disability, for a total of 20 weeks. This move comes a day after Netflix announced a similar policy. Previously, Microsoft offered four weeks paid and eight weeks unpaid time off for new parents. The change takes effect November 1, providing more support for employees' family needs.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Frasers Centrepoint, Thakral, Wilmar
summary: Noble Group's $500 million senior notes due 2015 have been fully redeemed, affirming its cash position. Frasers Centrepoint Limited reported a 43% jump in net profit to $181.4 million for its third quarter, while Thakral Corporation posted a net profit of $6.86 million, reversing a loss a year ago. Wilmar International's net profit rose 18.8% to $193.6 million on strong demand for oilseeds and grains, despite lower commodity prices.

site_title: Disney shares tumble on worries over cable business
summary: Disney shares plummeted 9.0% to $110.68 after trimming its outlook for its cable television business and facing concerns over the threat to cash-cow ESPN from emerging technologies. Despite an 11% rise in earnings to $2.5 billion and a $1.45 per share profit, sales rose only 5.1% to $13.1 billion, missing analyst forecasts of $13.2 billion. The decline follows a 52-week high closing price on Tuesday.

site_title: Earnings up 43% for Frasers Centrepoint
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Ltd reported a 43% jump in net profit to S$181.4 million for its third quarter ended June 30, 2015, with revenue more than doubling to S$1.01 billion. The increase was driven by project completions in Singapore and China, as well as new income streams from the acquisition of Australand and hotels. The company's development properties segment saw a 375% revenue rise, while its commercial properties segment fell 2%.

site_title: US: Tech leads Nasdaq, S&P 500; Disney sparks media selloff
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, led by tech companies Google and Facebook, as the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.67% and the S&P 500 rose 0.31%. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.06% due to Disney's largest daily drop in almost seven years, after the company cut its profit forecast for its cable networks unit. Despite the decline, Disney's shares are still up 17.3% year-to-date, compared to a 2% gain on the S&P 500.

site_title: Netflix's year-long parental leave raises bar for US employers
summary: Netflix is offering up to a year of paid maternity and paternity leave to its employees, significantly raising the bar for parental benefits in corporate America. The company, which employs about 2,200 people, allows parents to take time off as needed during the first year after a child's birth or adoption. They can return to work part-time, full-time, or go back to work as needed, with the option to take off as much time as they want. This move is seen as a major step forward for parental leave policies in the US.

site_title: Emerging markets set to continue losing altitude
summary: Emerging markets are experiencing a sharp decline, with equities falling 15% over the past three months and price earnings ratios reaching record discounts. This downturn is attributed to a "perfect storm" of factors, including the withdrawal of advanced markets from securitised assets and a fading appeal of emerging markets. The Institute of International Finance notes that these markets, once seen as vibrant and promising, are now suffering a mysterious eclipse, leaving investors wondering why their growth is coming to an abrupt end.

site_title: Wreckage 'conclusively confirmed' as from MH370: Malaysia PM
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak confirmed that debris found on Reunion Island is from MH370, a Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared 17 months ago. The wreckage, including a two-metre-long wing part, was examined by an international team of experts and confirmed to be from the missing plane. French prosecutors said there was a "very high probability" the wreckage came from MH370. The confirmation brings hope to relatives seeking answers, but many still demand to know why the plane went off course and what happened to the main body of the plane.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Noble Group's shares dropped 5.8% to S$0.565 after Invesco Ltd sold 33 million shares, reducing its holdings to 4.5%. Sembcorp Industries is not mentioned in this article.

site_title: Asia-Pac central banks call truce on currency war
summary: Asia-Pacific central banks have temporarily called a truce on the currency war, with Reserve Bank of Australia governor Glenn Stevens and New Zealand's Graeme Wheeler signaling a reduction in pressure to weaken exchange rates ahead of the Federal Reserve's anticipated interest rate hike. This truce may ease pressure on the currencies of major developed economies, with the Aussie dollar and kiwi dollar rising in value. However, experts warn that this is a temporary reprieve, and the impact of a stronger US dollar may still be felt.

site_title: Saudis expand oil price war downstream
summary: Saudi Arabia has expanded its oil price war into the refining sector, becoming the fourth largest refiner in the world. The country has commissioned a new refinery in Jizan and acquired a stake in Korea's S-Oil, aiming to capture market share in Asia. Saudi Arabia's low-sulphur diesel is competing with Asian refiners, potentially sparking a price war. However, Chinese refiners are also producing more petrol, and Indian refiners are shifting away from Saudi Arabia, making it challenging for the desert kingdom to win the price war.

site_title: StarHub Q2 profit up 5% at S$99m
summary: StarHub Ltd reported a 5% year-on-year increase in Q2 net profit to S$99.1 million, with revenue growing 2.3% to S$589.5 million. The telco also secured the UEFA Champions League and UEFA Europa League rights for three years, returning the sports to StarHub TV after a seven-year absence.

site_title: Netflix's new mums and dads get up to a year's paid parental leave
summary: Netflix is offering up to a year of paid parental leave to new mothers and fathers, setting a generous standard in the US. The policy allows new parents to take as many days off as they choose within the first 12 months after a child's birth or adoption. This move raises the bar for other companies and is seen as a key recruiting tool, particularly for female talent. However, some experts note that unlimited time off can lead to less time off being taken.

site_title: Boeing updates jet specifications: more seats, shorter range
summary: Boeing has updated the technical specifications of its jetliners to reflect the actual performance of its planes, which have become heavier due to premium seats and increased passenger and luggage weights. The company increased seat counts on its main wide-body planes, the 787 and 777, but cut the range for all planes, with the 787-9 falling the most. These changes are intended to better reflect the way airlines use the planes, and Boeing has not changed its marketing approach. The updates follow similar revisions made by Airbus.

site_title: Mizuho eyes lucrative US market to boost profits
summary: Mizuho Financial Group Inc, Japan's second-largest bank by assets, is expanding its presence in the US market to boost profits. The bank has lead-managed the three biggest investment-grade security offerings in the US this year and has underwritten $20.9 billion of notes since December. Mizuho aims to take a greater share of the lucrative US market, which has seen record investment-grade security sales. The bank's expansion into the US is part of its strategy to offset declining profits at home due to record monetary stimulus.

site_title: UK rate path steepens before BoE meet, helped by US data and Fed
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates slightly sooner than previously thought, following positive US economic data and comments from a top Federal Reserve official. This is seen as a sign that the US Federal Reserve may hike interest rates in September, which could prompt the BoE to follow suit. Most economists still expect the BoE to hold rates at record-low levels until the US act, but the shift in expectations is driven by the strong US economic data and the Fed's potential interest rate hike.

site_title: Australia 'confident looking in right area' and MH370 will be found
summary: Australian authorities are confident they are searching for MH370 in the right area after Malaysian authorities confirmed debris found on the Indian Ocean island of La Reunion is from the missing flight. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau's chief commissioner, Martin Dolan, stated that the discovery is consistent with their work, but it's too early to determine what happened to the plane. A close examination of the debris is necessary to learn more. The search is ongoing, with the goal of finding the aircraft, which disappeared 17 months ago.

site_title: US trade deficit widens by 7.1% in June, showing effect of firm dollar
summary: The US trade deficit widened 7.1% in June to $43.8 billion, the largest in three months, due to a strong dollar and weak global demand. Imports rose 1.2% to $232.4 billion, while exports remained steady at $188.6 billion. The widening trade gap is a hurdle for economic growth, with economists citing a firm dollar and soft global growth as contributing factors.

site_title: Canada PM to bring back home renovation tax credit
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper is set to bring back a slimmed-down version of a home renovation tax credit, worth C$1.5 billion, for renovations between C$1,000 and C$5,000. The permanent 15% annual credit will apply to homeowners, generating jobs and stimulating the economy. Harper announced the measure ahead of the federal election on October 19, seeking re-election. The tax credit's effectiveness was previously tested from 2009 to 2010, with an estimated C$4.3 billion in economic stimulus.

site_title: For Singapore, pain before greater heights: MAS's Menon
summary: Singapore aims to become one of the top five richest countries in the world by 2065, driven by a culture of innovation, resilience, and cohesion. The country's economy will undergo a painful restructuring phase, with a focus on productivity-driven growth, before transitioning into a phase of regional integration and technological transformation. Singapore will become a hub for advanced industries, including the export of capital and people, and will play a key role in the Asean Free Economic Zone. The country will also prioritize sustainable growth, with a focus on reducing carbon intensity and investing in green industries.

site_title: Indonesia's economic risk persists as growth slides further
summary: Indonesia's economic growth slowed to 4.67% in the second quarter, marking the second straight quarter of decline, as the country struggles to meet President Joko Widodo's 7% growth target. The slowdown is attributed to weak domestic consumption, foreign investment, and commodities exports, with the rupiah currency also weakening. Experts warn that the economy may face further pressure if interest rates are not reduced, and a pick-up in growth may emerge in the second half as the government accelerates spending.

site_title: UK recovery stronger than thought in 2011 - 2013
summary: The UK economy recovered more strongly than initially thought between 2011 and 2013, regaining its pre-crisis size in the second quarter of 2013, three months earlier than previously estimated.

site_title: China property firm enters vacation rental business
summary: China's property firm Fantasia Holdings Group has launched a vacation rental business, Home ENE, to utilize unsold homes. The platform, similar to Airbnb and HomeAway, aims to capitalize on the country's 50 million vacant units. The move is expected to grow the short-term lease market to 10.5 billion yuan in 2015. This follows a similar launch by Tujia, a Chinese home rental firm, which raised US$300 million to expand its business. Unsold apartments in provincial cities are seen as a key source of properties for vacation use, with potential for new tourist destinations to emerge.

site_title: Emerging markets facing perfect storm, says IIF
summary: Emerging markets face a "perfect storm" due to China's weakened imports, despite investors pivoting towards the US. China's trading partners have yet to feel the full impact of recent events, but the Washington-based Institute of International Finance (IIF) expresses doubt over China's commitment to a fully market-driven economy. Emerging markets have declined by 15% in equity and bonds, with yields rising and sovereign spreads widening to over 400 basis points. The IIF warns that falling commodity prices, a strengthening US dollar, and a slowdown in productivity and labor force growth are intensifying headwinds to emerging-market growth.

site_title: Europe investment banks report rise in Q2 equity trading revenue
summary: European investment banks reported a surge in Q2 equity trading revenue, with the value of stocks traded jumping 25% to 1.4 trillion euros. The increase is attributed to volatility and investor interest, driven by a weak euro, improving economy, and unprecedented monetary easing by the European Central Bank. Trading commissions have climbed 23% in the last year, with the top equity brokers being Morgan Stanley, Bank of America, Instinet, UBS, and Credit Suisse. However, liquidity in individual European shares remains a concern, with investors mainly using trading indexes via exchange-traded funds.

site_title: Rebound in US yields helps dollar; euro hits 2-week low
summary: The US dollar surged to a 3-month high against a basket of currencies after Atlanta Federal Reserve president Dennis Lockhart expressed support for an interest rate hike in September. This lifted the dollar index 0.2% to 98.105 and pushed the euro to a two-week low of US$1.0847. The euro's decline was fueled by rising short-dated Treasury yields, making the dollar more attractive due to rate differentials. Lockhart's comments suggest the Fed may hike rates in September, with payrolls data on Friday to influence the decision.

site_title: Cat A, B COE premiums up, open category down
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars increased in the first round of August bidding, with Category A (cars below 1,600cc, 130 hp) rising S$320 to S$56,209 and Category B (cars above 1,600cc, 130 hp) increasing S$2,680 to S$60,789. The premium for Category E, the open category, fell S$2,216 to S$57,885. This uptick was expected, as premiums had reached their lowest for the year in the previous round. Showrooms have seen increased activity, with Volkswagen noting a boost in buyer interest for the new Passat.

images.alt_text: The declines in Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars over the last few months appear to have gotten customers and their pocketbooks into showrooms.

site_title: NY's public housing becomes life-long refuge
summary: New York City's public housing system has become a lifelong refuge for many residents, particularly those with higher incomes. Despite rising rents, these tenants are reluctant to leave, depriving the neediest of homes. The average tenure of public housing residents is 22 years, up from 19 in 2005. The New York City Housing Authority is facing pressure to persuade higher-earning residents to leave, but the agency argues that these tenants are positive role models and contribute significantly to the agency's budget. The federal government has directed NYCHA to lean more heavily on these residents, imposing rent increases to help replace federal subsidies.

site_title: Home Protection Scheme to give out rebates to eligible CPF members
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board is set to distribute premium rebates to approximately 949,000 eligible CPF members under the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) starting in November. The rebates, totaling S$400 or more, are a result of better-than-expected investment returns and lower-than-projected claims. This is the fifth time the CPF Board is distributing premium rebates to HPS members, following previous exercises in 2006. The rebates will be credited to eligible members' CPF Ordinary Account.

site_title: Short-covering keeps STI on an even keel
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.35 points to 3,191.39 on Wednesday, avoiding a fifth consecutive loss through short-covering. Noble Group's volatility contributed to the relief. Sembcorp Industries (SCI) jumped 8.7% after reporting a 24.9% increase in net profit, despite a 5.8% year-on-year drop in revenue. Genting Singapore's shares dropped 8.3% after announcing a significant decline in net profits for the second quarter. US interest rates are expected to rise in December, with Rabobank predicting a rate hike.

site_title: From ghosts to old dogs: Virginia has the weirdest home-sale clauses
summary: In Virginia, homebuyers can now request sellers to disclose if a property was used to manufacture methamphetamine or if a ghost is believed to inhabit it, although neither is legally required. Buyers are also making unusual requests, such as a feng shui evaluation, a pet approval clause, or asking sellers to leave behind unwanted belongings. Some buyers are offering signing bonuses to sellers to make quick decisions, while others are using creative contingencies like a "ghostbusters" clause to negotiate better deals. The unusual requests are common in the competitive Washington, D.C. market.

site_title: Solar player Sunseap raises S$77m for expansion
summary: Sunseap, a leading Singaporean solar energy provider, has raised S$77 million in equity and debt capital to fund expansion plans and increase its contracted solar project capacity to over 160 megawatts. The funds will be used to double capacity and expand into India, Thailand, and the Philippines. The company plans to announce its first offsite clean-energy project in the next six months, which will supply clean energy to a building from a power plant not sited in the building.

images.alt_text: Sunseap Group, one of Singapore's largest and leading providers of solar energy, announced on Wednesday that it has raised S$77 million in equity and debt capital to fund its expansion plans and to hasten the adoption of solar power in Singapore.

site_title: CVS drops Pfizer's Viagra from US drug insurance benefits list
summary: CVS Health Corp has dropped Pfizer's Viagra from its list of US drug insurance benefits, effective January 1, 2016. Patients can get coverage for Eli Lilly's Cialis instead. The decision, made two years before generic competition for Viagra is expected, was not disclosed by CVS. CVS still carries Viagra in its pharmacies for customers with insurance coverage or who pay in full. Pfizer expects US$1.7 billion in sales from Viagra next year.

site_title: SG50 sets social media abuzz - all over the world: Meltwater study
summary: A Meltwater study found that SG50, Singapore's 50th anniversary, generated significant buzz on social media worldwide, with international mentions exceeding local celebrations. The report highlighted the SG50 fish cake and haircut as popular topics. Meanwhile, unrelated news included Malaysia's plan to seize Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's slowing GDP growth, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Foxconn ready to invest US$2b in India if infrastructure gets better
summary: Foxconn chairman Terry Gou announced that the company is prepared to invest up to $2 billion in technology projects in India over the next decade, contingent on infrastructure improvements. Gou specifically highlighted the need for better electricity, transport, and supply chain management. This investment would be a significant boost to India's technology sector, with Foxconn already manufacturing Apple iPhones in the country.

images.alt_text: Mr Gou said Foxconn may build as many as 12 factories in India, though land and power need to be easier to get. He's looking at potential sites in the states of Gujarat, Maharashtra and Andhra Pradesh.
