The central bank's governor stated that average inflation for the full year is likely to fall close to the lower end of the 2-4% target range, amid economic growth slowing to a three-year low of 5.2% in the first quarter.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down on weak overseas markets, local economic outlook
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.1% to 8,500.44 as overseas markets declined and the country's economic outlook remained gloomy, with price weakness persisting for the seventh month. The government is expected to cut its 2015 forecast for the consumer price index. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$31.696 per US dollar.

site_title: China: Stocks fall at market open
summary: China's major stock indexes fell 0.3% at market open on Wednesday, with the CSI300 index at 3,937.62 points and the Shanghai Composite Index at 3,745.65 points. The Hang Seng index in Hong Kong rose 0.3% to 24,466.30 points.

site_title: Nikkei Singapore PMI shows further improvement in business conditions in July
summary: The Nikkei Singapore PMI showed a further improvement in business conditions in July, with a headline PMI reading of 51.3, up slightly from June's 51.1. This marked the second consecutive monthly improvement, signaling robust expansion in output and staff numbers. However, client demand remained muted, with total new work and new export business declining slightly, potentially weighing on overall sector growth in the coming months.

site_title: Update: Asia: Stocks mixed on US rate talk, China fears
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday, with Tokyo and Hong Kong rising, while Shanghai fell 0.26% and Sydney shed 0.70%. A US Federal Reserve official expressed support for a September interest rate hike, boosting the dollar against other currencies. China's market was weighed on by concerns over the country's ability to stem a recent market rout, with investors taking profits after strong gains the previous day sparked by new restrictions on short-selling. The International Monetary Fund also declared "significant work" needs to be done in reviewing China's inclusion in its basket of reserve currencies.

site_title: Australia: Shares sag as banks retreat
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 5,680.4, retreating from a two-month peak, as the banking sector came under pressure following a negative lead from Wall Street. The big four banks, Commonwealth Bank of Australia and National Australia Bank, lost around 0.7% each. In contrast, iron ore miner Fortescue Metals Group soared 10% after reports of a potential stake sale to Chinese groups. A potential US interest rate hike also contributed to the decline, with Wall Street falling overnight.

site_title: China's July services activity quickens to 11-month high: survey
summary: China's services sector activity accelerated to an 11-month high in July, with a Caixin/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reading of 53.8, up from June's 51.8. This growth offset downward pressure from the manufacturing sector, which contracted in July for the first time in two years. The resilient services sector could help support the economy, but policymakers face pressure to address slowing GDP growth.

site_title: Hot stock: Genting shares fall on profit warning
summary: Genting Singapore shares fell 6.11% to 84.5 Singapore cents after the company announced a "significant decline" in net profits for the second quarter due to fair value loss on derivative financial instruments and unrealised foreign exchange translation losses. The group will announce its Q2 financial results on August 13.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Two trains derail in India, at least 12 dead
summary: At least 12 people were killed when two passenger trains derailed in central India, with the death toll potentially rising. The accident occurred when the trains' carriages derailed on a swollen river crossing in Madhya Pradesh state. The Indian railway network, plagued by poor funding and frequent deadly accidents, has pledged to invest $137 billion to modernize its railways.

site_title: Oil prices rebound ahead of US energy, employment data
summary: Oil prices rose 57 cents to $45.74 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, snapping a three-day skid, ahead of US energy and employment data. The rebound is attributed to bargain hunting, but analysts warn that oil prices remain vulnerable due to a supply glut and uncertain demand growth. Traders are also watching the July US jobs report for potential dollar movement, which could impact crude prices.

site_title: IMF staff urges no rush to add China yuan to currency basket
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) staff recommends delaying any decision to add the Chinese yuan to the IMF's Special Drawing Rights basket until after September 2016, citing mixed performance on financial criteria and concerns about disrupting financial market trading. The yuan meets some requirements but is not widely used in North America and has thin trading volumes. The IMF board will decide on the proposal later this month, with European members favoring quick inclusion and Japan and the US taking a more cautious approach.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.17% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.17% higher on Wednesday, defying a lower finish on Wall Street and a slide in Tokyo's opening exchanges. The Hang Seng Index rose 42.3 points to 24,448.42. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a fresh record close on the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq. Despite uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and tariff issues, investors remain positive.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stocks opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.2 points to 1,723.53. Gainers outnumbered losers 98 to 87, with a total trading volume of 49.7 million lots worth RM17.3 million.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 22.95 points lower, or 0.72%, to 3,168.09 at 9:02am on Wednesday, with 124.6 million shares worth S$124.6 million traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 75 to 66, with top volume stocks including Global Logistic, CapitaLand, and Noble.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Singapore share prices opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 22.95 points or 0.72 per cent to 3,168.09 as at 9.02am

site_title: Chinese airlines benefit as oil prices fall to six-month low
summary: Chinese airlines are benefiting from a six-month low oil price, with Air China, China Eastern Airlines, and China Southern Airlines expected to see significant increases in first-half net income. The decline in fuel prices has led to reduced hedging by airlines, with many opting to reduce or eliminate fuel hedges to capitalize on the savings. Fuel costs account for 40% of Asian carriers' expenses, and lower prices are making air travel more affordable, with travel demand in the Asia Pacific region increasing by 6% this year.

images.alt_text: Air China, China Eastern Airlines and other Chinese carriers are expected to benefit the most after oil prices in London fell below US$50 a barrel on Monday to their lowest closing price in more than six months.

site_title: China car market sputters raising concerns from Toyota to BMW
summary: China's car market has slowed, causing concern for major automakers like BMW and Toyota. The slowdown is attributed to a stock-market rout and a flagging economy, leading to reduced consumer spending on cars. BMW may lower this year's profitability goals, while Toyota faces tougher competition due to higher costs and lower prices. Analysts predict the market may worsen, with the Chinese market having grown eightfold since 2000, surpassing the US as the world's largest car market in 2009.

site_title: Audemars Piguet present floral clock for SG50
summary: Audemars Piguet unveiled Singapore's largest floral clock at Gardens by the Bay to commemorate the nation's Golden Jubilee. The 7-meter diameter installation features a mix of annual and perennial plants that change over time. The clock's design ensures a different experience each time it's viewed, with ageing blooms being weeded out and replaced by new plants. The floral clock was unveiled at 6pm on August 4, 2015, by Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan and other officials.

site_title: Update: CapitaLand's Q2 net profit up 5.8%, boosted by fair value gains of China properties
summary: CapitaLand reported a 5.8% increase in Q2 net profit to S$464 million, driven by fair value gains from two Chinese properties. Revenue rose 17.8% to over S$1 billion, with higher contributions from development projects in China. The company recorded a net fair value gain of S$434.5 million, offset by a provision for foreseeable losses in China. Singapore and China markets accounted for 79.6% and 81.8% of total revenue and EBIT, respectively.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: India's multi-billion dollar e-commerce battle heats up
summary: India's e-commerce market is intensifying with multi-billion-dollar investments from Amazon, Flipkart, and Snapdeal. The three companies are engaging in a heated battle for market share, with Amazon investing $5 billion in India to become its largest market outside the US. Flipkart, the largest e-commerce firm, and Snapdeal are also spending heavily to stay ahead. The companies have been involved in a series of public spats, including Twitter trolling and exclusive selling rights disputes. Analysts expect the market to grow to $32 billion by the end of the decade, with Amazon, Flipkart, and Snapdeal competing fiercely for dominance.

images.alt_text: Co-founder and CEO of Snapdeal Kunal Bahl attending a press conference in New Delhi.

site_title: Japan July PMI survey shows services expand, but at slower pace
summary: Japan's services sector expanded in July at a slower pace, with the Markit/Nikkei Japan Services Purchasing Managers Index falling to 51.2 from 51.8 in June. This is the fourth consecutive month the index has remained above the 50 threshold, suggesting a moderate rebound in the economy after expected contraction in the second quarter. The expansion is a slight improvement from the previous month, but still indicates a slowdown in growth.

site_title: Dollar rises as Fed official eyes September liftoff
summary: The US dollar rose against major currencies on Tuesday after Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Dennis Lockhart expressed support for a potential interest rate hike in September, citing a strong economy. Lockhart stated that only a significant economic downturn would deter him from raising rates. This move is seen as a positive signal for the dollar, which has been under pressure due to weak economic data. The Fed's decision on interest rates in September will be closely watched by investors and markets.

site_title: Wing part may be confirmed as from MH370 this week: Australia
summary: Australian officials expect confirmation this week on whether a found wing part is from Malaysia Airlines flight MH370. The flaperon, confirmed to be from a Boeing 777, has been washed up on the Indian Ocean island of La Reunion. Technical experts in France will examine the part, and experts from Australia, France, Malaysia, and Boeing will determine its origin. Australia's search efforts continue in the southern Indian Ocean, despite no confirmed evidence of the plane's wreckage found so far.

site_title: Yangzijiang's Q2 net profit falls 17% on tax expense and drop in other income
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 17% decline in Q2 net profit to 1 billion yuan, primarily due to a 310.2 million yuan tax expense and a 64.7 million yuan drop in other income. Revenue increased 34% to 5.7 billion yuan, driven by a 91.6% increase in shipbuilding-related businesses. The company delivered 11 vessels in Q2, with an outstanding order book of US$4.14 billion. Despite the decline in net profit, Yangzijiang's shipbuilding-related businesses remained a core revenue driver.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Official China paper says investor sentiment has rebounded after stock rout
summary: China's investor confidence in its stock market rebounded in July after government support measures, according to a survey by the China Securities Investor Protection Fund Corporation. Investor confidence rose to 59.6, up 1.9% from June, marking the 14th consecutive month of positive sentiment. The survey found increased confidence in the future of the stock market and improved buying sentiment, despite shares remaining vulnerable to sharp corrections. China's main indexes have tumbled about 25% since mid-June, but have clawed back some ground.

site_title: Foxconn says looking at long-term investments in India
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract maker of electronic products, is considering long-term investments in India to build a technology manufacturing base. Founder Terry Gou plans to develop 10-12 facilities, including factories and data centers, by 2020. This move aims to support India's efforts to establish a robust technology sector, with Foxconn already working with clients such as Apple and Amazon.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall as investors weigh Fed moves, US jobs data
summary: Asian stocks fell 0.3% as investors weighed the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike, following comments from Fed Bank of Atlanta President Dennis Lockhart. US jobs data on Friday is expected to influence the Fed's decision. Japan's Topix index was little changed, while South Korea's Kospi rose 0.1%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index futures increased 0.4%, and Chinese stocks in the US rallied after a 3.7% climb in the Shanghai Composite Index.

site_title: Shell to strengthen Russian hand through Gazprom asset swap
summary: Royal Dutch Shell plans to swap a stake in one of its international energy assets for part of Gazprom's Sakhalin-3 project, strengthening its ties with Russia. The deal aims to give Shell greater involvement in the world's biggest gas reserves, with Russia holding 25% of the world's gas reserves. The swap is part of efforts by Shell, BP, and Total to access Russia's low-cost oil and gas reserves amid sanctions and a slump in crude prices.

site_title: Greek finance minister says bailout deal possible by August 20
summary: Greek Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos expressed confidence that a new bailout deal with creditors could be reached by August 20, when a massive debt payment is due. The talks with the European Union, European Central Bank, and International Monetary Fund are going "at least as well as expected," and Athens hopes to pay the debt with the first instalment of a proposed 86 billion euro bailout. If a deal isn't finalized by August 20, Greece will seek emergency aid to pay the debt, which is currently valued at 3.4 billion euros.

site_title: Nasdaq's second error of day hobbled service dark pools rely on
summary: Nasdaq OMX Group experienced its second outage of the day, affecting a service used by dark pools to report transactions. The Nasdaq TRF, which helps knit together US stock trading, was down from 9:42 am to 12:57 pm. The outage, which lasted approximately 2.5 hours, may have impacted around a third of the market's volume. Any dark pool relying solely on the Nasdaq TRF may have been unable to operate during the disruption, potentially hobbling part of the US stock market.

site_title: World Bank unveils new conditions for loans
summary: The World Bank has unveiled new conditions for loans to its 188 member nations, strengthening environmental and social protections. The framework includes extending labor rights, amending environmental standards, and requiring "free prior and informed consent" from indigenous peoples before projects can proceed. The proposed rules aim to protect the environment and vulnerable communities, but civil society organizations have criticized them as a "dangerous rollback in environmental and social protections."

images.alt_text: Indigenous people participate at the Peru's 194 Independence Day Parade, in Lima, Peru, July 29, 2015.

site_title: Delta bans hunting trophies as cargo after Zimbabwe lion kill
summary: Delta Air Lines has banned the transportation of big-game trophies as cargo, effective immediately, following global outrage over the killing of Cecil the Lion in Zimbabwe. The ban covers elephants, rhinoceros, leopards, buffalo, and lions. The decision, made in response to mounting public pressure, aims to prevent the transportation of wildlife trophies.

site_title: Puerto Rico default adds to island's economic woes
summary: Puerto Rico defaulted on a debt payment of $58 million, leaving the island closed out of the US financial markets. Governor Alejandro Garcia Padilla paid out just $628,000, citing a lack of liquidity. This is the latest in a $72 billion debt crisis, with debt ratings agencies downgrading Puerto Rico bonds to junk status. The default impacts mainly Puerto Rican creditors, including savings and loans, and deepens the island's economic crisis, with unemployment at 12.4% and a massive out-migration underway.

site_title: Time profit beats Street; to outsource more jobs
summary: Time Inc. reported a quarterly profit of 27 US cents per share, beating market estimates, as aggressive cost-cutting offset weak print ad sales. The company plans to outsource hundreds of non-editorial jobs to its Indian operation, while retaining editorial operations in the US and UK. Advertising revenue fell 8.9% to $420 million, and circulation revenue fell 1.6%. Time Inc. forecast current-quarter advertising revenue to fall in the low single digits, excluding items, and shares rose 4% in morning trading.

site_title: US: Stocks finish lower; Apple down 3.2%
summary: US stocks ended lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones falling 47.51 points to 17,550.69, and the S&P 500 dropping 4.72 to 2,093.32. Apple led the decline, falling 3.2% after a disappointing earnings report, while Netflix rose 7.7% after confirming its streaming service launch in Japan. Other notable movers included Allstate (-10.2%), Baxalta (+11.9%), and Alibaba (+1.1%).

images.alt_text: US stocks finished lower onTuesday following a mixed batch of earnings reports and another big decline by technology giant Apple.

site_title: June factory orders rebound on strong demand for transportation equipment
summary: US factory orders rebounded 1.8% in June after declining 1.1% in May, driven by strong demand for transportation equipment and other goods. This marks a hopeful sign for the struggling manufacturing sector.

site_title: Greek bank stocks battered as bailout talks grind on
summary: Greek bank stocks plummeted for a second consecutive day, with the ATHEX index falling 1.22% and banking shares suffering their steepest ever decline. Piraeus, Eurobank, Alpha Bank, and National Bank shares fell 30%, 29.70%, 29.65%, and 28.45%, respectively. Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos expressed confidence in reaching a new bailout deal by August 20, when Greece must pay 3.4 billion euros to the European Central Bank. If a deal is not finalized, Athens may seek emergency aid.

images.alt_text: Greek bank shares on Tuesday took a battering for a second straight day, but Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos insisted Athens and its creditors could reach a deal on a mammoth new bailout in time for a huge debt payment due this month.

site_title: China gets on the warpath against short-selling
summary: China has cracked down on short-selling, suspending major brokerages and unveiling new rules to prevent market collapse. The country's stock exchanges and market watchdogs aim to stop a 30% loss in value since June. Some major brokerages have suspended short-selling businesses, and the new rules make it harder for speculators to profit from hourly price changes. The government's efforts follow a broader crackdown on market instability.

site_title: Investment banks rewarded by volume surge in European stocks
summary: European stocks have seen a surge in volume in the second quarter, with the value of stocks traded jumping 25% to €1.4 trillion (S$2.1 trillion). This is the highest since 2009, driven by improved earnings, a weak euro, and economic growth. Investment banks such as UBS and Deutsche Bank have reported a 30% increase in quarterly equity trading revenue. Despite this, liquidity in individual European shares remains a concern, with investors mainly using exchange-traded funds to trade.

images.alt_text: Investment banks including UBS Group AG and Deutsche Bank AG have reported a surge in equity trading revenue in the second quarter.

site_title: UK sells 5.4% RBS stake at £1b loss, sparking criticism of Osborne
summary: The UK Treasury sold 5.4% stake in Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) for £2.08 billion, resulting in a £1.07 billion loss. The sale price was 170 pence per share, 34% less than the original bailout price. The proceeds will be used to repay the UK's national debt, now 89% of GDP. The government's remaining stake in RBS is 73%.

site_title: Oil climbs back above US$50 after Monday's drop
summary: Oil prices rose 1.7% after dropping below $50 a barrel in London for the first time since January, driven by speculation that the decline was excessive. US oil prices have fallen close to levels that would curb supply growth, according to Petromatrix GmbH. A Bloomberg survey suggests the nation's crude inventories likely declined for a second week.

site_title: Baxalta rejects Shire's US$30b hostile bid
summary: Dublin-based pharmaceutical group Shire rejected US$30 billion hostile bid from Baxalta, citing the offer as "significantly undervaluing" the US firm. Shire CEO Flemming Ornskov expressed a preference for a negotiated transaction to explore the proposed combination. Baxalta CEO Ludwig Hantson stated the company's independent infrastructure and manufacturing operations would provide a platform for growth, and the proposed exchange ratio undervalued the company's true worth.

site_title: Love no longer blossoms for Miss Piggy and Kermit
summary: Miss Piggy and Kermit, the long-running Muppet couple, have announced the end of their romantic relationship. They cited "careful thought" and "considerable squabbling" as reasons for the breakup. Despite their separation, they will continue working together on a Muppets mockumentary series set to premiere on ABC in September. Kermit has moved on, dating a pig named Denise, while Miss Piggy claims she is "staying in the heavens." The breakup was revealed during a promotional event in Los Angeles for the upcoming ABC program, The Muppets.

site_title: US car firms beat estimates with sales near 10-year-high as economy improves
summary: US car sales have reached a 10-year high, driven by improving consumer confidence, affordable petrol, and financing. The Detroit Three and top Japanese automakers beat estimates with sales gains, with Ford, General Motors, and Nissan seeing significant increases. The industry is expected to continue momentum for 18 months, with sales growth driven by economic recovery, vehicle affordability, and employment. Total light vehicle sales rose to 1.51 million, exceeding analyst predictions, and the annualized rate accelerated to 17.6 million.

site_title: MH370's social media hype hurting Malaysia Airlines demand: CEO
summary: Malaysia Airlines CEO Christoph Mueller stated that the extensive media coverage of the search for MH370, fueled by social media hype, is negatively impacting ticket sales in Australia. This coverage correlates positively with demand figures, indicating a significant impact on the airline's business.

site_title: EU-Vietnam free trade deal to remove over 99% of tariffs on goods
summary: The EU and Vietnam announced a free trade deal removing nearly all tariffs, a "milestone" on a region-wide agreement with South-east Asia. The deal, after 2.5 years of negotiations, aims to boost two-way trade to 28 billion euros. It follows a significant growth in trade from 10 years ago, with EU-Vietnam trade increasing three-fold to 42.3 billion dollars.

site_title: How Tom Hayes' Libor dreams ended in a 14-year prison term
summary: Tom Hayes, a former UBS trader, was sentenced to 14 years in prison for his role in manipulating the yen Libor rate in 2006. Hayes, then 28, was part of a scheme to influence the rate, which affects trillions of dollars in loans worldwide. He testified during his trial that he was asked by a broker to help manipulate the rate, and he agreed. Hayes' case marked a significant milestone in the Libor scandal, which led to widespread fines and convictions among major banks. Hayes' sentence was widely seen as a strong message against market manipulation.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Biosensors International Group reported Q1 FY16 sales of US$67 million, a 16% decline year-over-year, and net profit of US$9.5 million, a 4% decline. Despite a downgrade to "hold" by OCBC Investment Research, the company's share price has fallen 23% since their sell call. CWT Ltd's share price rose 15% after market rumors of a potential takeover offer.

site_title: LaunchPad startups show their stuff at inaugural showcase
summary: The inaugural LaunchPad Unveiled showcase at Singapore's startup hub, JTC LaunchPad@one-north, featured 500 startups and 35 incubators. Minister-in-charge of Smart Nation, Vivian Balakrishnan, assured them of a supportive ecosystem, stating that while Singapore may not be Silicon Valley, it can excel in its own unique way. The event highlighted the growth of innovation in Singapore, with various sectors such as AI, edtech, and healthcare represented.

site_title: Kerry returns to Asia as China tensions loom over Asean meeting in KL
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry is set to meet South-east Asian counterparts in Malaysia amid heightened tensions over China's territorial aspirations in the South China Sea. China accuses the US of militarizing the area, while the US has accused China of exaggerating the military threat. The meeting aims to promote regional economic and security ties, but China's growing influence in the region and its plans for artificial islands in disputed waters are expected to overshadow the gathering. The US and China will discuss a proposed code of conduct for the area, with China criticizing "non-regional" countries for interfering in the talks.

site_title: Gold bears dig in as bullion funds lose another US$6b
summary: Gold prices slumped $6 billion in July, the largest drop since 2013, as speculators turned bearish and money managers stayed net-short on bullion for a second week. The value of gold exchange-traded products (ETPs) fell 6.5% in July, with futures prices reaching a five-year low near $1,095 an ounce. Analysts predict prices will drop to $984 by January, with the Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hike this year further curbing the appeal of gold.

site_title: Singapore's easiest days as a finance hub are over
summary: Singapore's status as a leading finance hub is under threat, with its neighbours and rivals gaining ground. The city's efficiency, stability, and low corruption have made it an attractive location, but its lack of economic hinterland and increasing competition from countries like Hong Kong, Thailand, and Malaysia are eroding its advantages. Fees in Singapore for merger advice and securities underwriting have fallen, and companies are increasingly listing on domestic exchanges, with foreign investors preferring to invest directly in these countries.

site_title: Swiss housing bubble risk is at its highest since 1991: UBS
summary: The Swiss housing market is at its highest risk of a bubble since 1991, according to a UBS study. Negative interest rates have driven excess demand for property as an investment, leading to a surge in loan applications for second homes and rising house prices. The Swiss Real Estate Bubble Index rose to 1.37 points in the second quarter, its highest level since 1991, with mortgage volume and house prices climbing 3.5% and 2% respectively. This poses a challenge for the Swiss National Bank to maintain economic stability.

site_title: Internet group submits plan for US to cede domain oversight
summary: A group of international internet experts has released a 199-page proposal outlining how the US government can transfer its oversight of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (Icann) to a global network of interested parties. The proposal, which is up for public comment until September 8, recommends creating a separate subsidiary to operate Icann's technical functions under a contract with Icann. The transition is expected to be completed in mid-2016, with Icann remaining headquartered in California. The proposal aims to maintain accountability and prevent capture by any single constituency.

site_title: Ringgit slips further as oil price, business and consumer sentiments dip
summary: The Malaysian ringgit fell to 3.865 against the US dollar, its lowest level this year, due to sliding oil prices and negative sentiments over 1MDB. A business confidence poll showed a sharp downturn, with the BCI registering 95.4 points, down from 101 points in the previous quarter. Consumer confidence also declined, with the MIER's consumer confidence index registering 71.7 points. The decline in business and consumer confidence is attributed to rising daily living expenses, a new minimum wage, and power tariff hikes.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian ringgit slipped to 3.865 on Tuesday on sliding oil prices and negative sentiments over the debt-ridden strategic investment company 1MDB.

site_title: Barefoot genius aims to end broker rip-offs
summary: Stephane Tyc, a Harvard physics PhD and former high-frequency trading executive, aims to end broker rip-offs by creating a transparent system for investors to check trades. His proposal involves a central data repository recording trades at a 10-microsecond level of accuracy, allowing investors to evaluate whether their brokers got them a reasonable price. The system would be free, but not available in real-time. Tyc's plan has limitations, including not tracking certain market manipulation practices, but experts praise his notion of increased transparency.

site_title: Samsung in uphill battle for mobile market share
summary: Samsung, the world's largest smartphone maker, faces a significant challenge in the mobile market as competitors like Huawei and Xiaomi offer lower-cost Android phones. To remain competitive, Samsung will have to cut margins and prices, despite its success in the premium market. The company's mobile division saw a decline in margins to 10.6% in the second quarter, and analysts predict further declines to 9.3% this year. Samsung plans to launch new, larger-screen premium phones and more affordable handsets to boost sales and maintain its market share.

images.alt_text: Margins at Samsung's mobile division fell to 10.6 per cent in Q2 from 15.5 per cent a year ago. Analysts say Samsung will not be able to compete with Apple in the premium market based on hardware.

site_title: Green energy companies see secure future in Obama's plan
summary: President Barack Obama's Clean Power Plan aims to reduce carbon emissions by forcing utilities to use renewable sources to produce electricity by 2030. This plan provides a degree of stability for renewable energy companies over the next 15 years, as they will have a clear direction to invest in. Despite criticism from Republican presidential candidates, many companies believe the regulation will guarantee their place in the US energy mix and expect investments to accelerate immediately. The plan is expected to be challenged in court, but supporters say the transition to cleaner fuels is already underway.

site_title: Tech lift to productivity overlooked? The Fed doesn't think so
summary: The Federal Reserve may consider raising interest rates due to potential productivity gains from the sharing economy, despite a 1.25% annual growth rate since the 2008-2009 crisis. The "sharing economy" has grown significantly, with companies like Airbnb and Uber, but its impact on productivity and growth is debated among economists. Some argue that official figures may be underestimating productivity growth, which could offset the effects of lower business costs. However, others believe that productivity growth is lower due to various factors, including a decline in quality improvements and difficulties in anticipating new technologies.

site_title: Perennial records S$33.5m profit for 8-month period post-RTO
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings Limited recorded a total profit of S$33.5 million for an 8-month period ending June 2015, following the completion of a reverse takeover in October 2014. Excluding one-off transaction costs, the company's profit was S$44.9 million.

site_title: AsiaPhos back in the black for Q2
summary: AsiaPhos Limited reported a net profit of S$481,000 for Q2, reversing a net loss of S$417,000 in the previous year. Revenue tripled to S$12 million, driven by upstream and downstream business segments. Upstream revenue increased by 139% year-on-year, while downstream revenue surged to S$5.5 million. Despite a negative 5% gross margin, AsiaPhos expects to reverse the loss once market prices of P4 stabilize. The company has also commenced work to expand production capacity and invest in handling infrastructure.

site_title: UBS is upbeat on eurozone
summary: UBS' managing director Patrick Grossholz is optimistic about the eurozone, particularly Germany, citing the European Central Bank's monetary easing and the weak euro as growth boosters. He expects corporate earnings to grow 12-15% in Europe this year. However, he advises investors to steer clear of Greece due to volatility. In contrast, he views Singapore equities as relatively attractive, despite a 5% decline this year, and recommends a 4% allocation to the market. Grossholz also notes that investors should be more exposed to Europe and less dependent on individual stocks or bonds.

site_title: Tokyo and Beijing will get torched by the Olympics
summary: Tokyo and Beijing will host the 2020 and 2022 Summer and Winter Olympics, respectively. The move is seen as a boon for Chinese President Xi Jinping and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who aim to boost nationalism and Japan's economic growth. However, critics warn that the massive spending on infrastructure projects will likely exacerbate pollution, economic overcapacity, and debt in both countries. Local governments in China are under pressure to curtail debt, but are likely to find ways to piggyback on the boom, masking China's worsening debt load. The Olympics may not be the economic game-changer hoped for by Asian leaders.

site_title: Lucky lobsters jamming China flights send US prices to record
summary: US lobster exports to China surged to a record 8,560 tonnes last year, a 22-fold increase from 2009, due to a surge in demand from China where lobsters are at least one-third cheaper than competing supplies. The 18-hour flight from Canada and the US to Shanghai via South Korea has become a weekly routine, with prices reaching an all-time high of US$22.75 a pound. The increased demand is driven by China's growing middle class, which is expected to reach 1 billion people by 2030, boosting demand for higher-value foods like crustaceans.

site_title: Toyota says quarterly profit up 10% to 646b yen, lifts sales forecast
summary: Toyota reported a 10% increase in quarterly net profit to 646 billion yen, driven by a weak yen and cost cuts. Revenue rose 9.3% to 6.98 trillion yen, despite slightly lower vehicle sales at 2.1 million vehicles. Toyota boosted its annual sales forecast to 27.8 trillion yen, citing favorable foreign exchange rates and strong sales in North America. The company also announced an overhaul of its Chinese operations, including adding a new production line to boost capacity by 100,000 vehicles annually.

site_title: Riding the new Silk Road economic belt
summary: Former Singaporean foreign minister George Yeo says China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative aims to revive the ancient Silk Road, a network of trade routes connecting Asia, Europe, and the US. The highway from Hanoi to Shenzhen, where Yeo traveled, has enabled trade between Vietnam and China, and the two countries have formed bilateral agreements to regulate trade flows. The initiative, launched by China President Xi Jinping in 2013, seeks to create a massive trade network, with Singapore playing a key role as a cultural arbitrager and logistics provider. Yeo believes the project's success relies on peace and cooperation among participating countries, and Singapore's role in facilitating project financing and infrastructure development is crucial.

site_title: Commodity units recover some ground
summary: Major currencies closely linked to commodities prices recovered some ground on Tuesday after oil prices steadied, with the Aussie dollar rising 1.5% to its highest in a fortnight. The Reserve Bank of Australia's statement also changed its tone on the currency's decline.

site_title: Safe manning of ships under spotlight
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is hosting the 18th Marine Accident Investigators Forum in Asia, where delegates will discuss marine safety investigations and exchange views on the need for sufficient people to operate ships safely. The UK's Marine Accident Investigation Branch (MAIB) has highlighted the risks of cumulative fatigue, citing the 2014 grounding of the cargo ship Danio, which resulted in a £73,000 fine and costs. Intermanager, an international trade association, is calling for flag states to review minimum manning levels for different types of vessels, taking into account rest hours and fatigue issues, to ensure sustainable and safe manning.

site_title: With US$1.3b and no pink paper, Pearson goes back to school
summary: Pearson Plc, a UK-based education company, is exiting the financial sector with the sale of the Financial Times and The Economist. The company will use the proceeds to shore up its education business, which has lost key US contracts and suffered declining textbook sales. CEO John Fallon aims to invest in the education sector, which is struggling to grow.

site_title: BMW reports drop in Q2 profit, says slowing China clouds outlook
summary: BMW reported a drop in Q2 profit due to slowing sales in China, its first decline in a decade. The company still expects record global sales and pretax profit for the year, but warns that challenges in China could affect its targets. BMW had previously stated that growth in China would be "less dynamic". The company's outlook may be at risk if the Chinese market continues to deteriorate.

site_title: Indonesia builders' US$ bonds outperform despite slowing economy
summary: Indonesian developers have issued almost half of the nation's dollar-denominated bonds, outperforming other industries with a 5.4% return this year, despite a slowing economy. This is attributed to local lending curbs, allowing property firms to bypass restrictions. Their debt has surpassed that of other industries, which have seen a 0.3% loss.

site_title: Bull market losing biggest supporter as Apple caps 10% retreat
summary: Apple's stock slipped 2.4% to $118.44, extending its decline to 11% since February, and breaking below its 200-day moving average for the first time since 2013. This decline is a blow to the bull market, which has struggled to break out of a 90-point range since February. Apple's stock, which accounts for 5.3% of the S&P 500's bull market gains, has fallen nine of the last 10 days, raising concerns about market leadership and a potential price correction.

images.alt_text: Apple got 17.4% of its revenue from China in its last full-year reporting period, Bloomberg data show.

site_title: Rise of Swiss franc exposes limitations of central bank power
summary: The Swiss franc has experienced a significant drop against the euro, with a two-month decline since April last year. Despite this, traders remain optimistic about a potential rally, with options showing a better-than-even chance of appreciation to parity by 2026. This highlights the limitations of central bank power in foreign exchange markets, as seen in Thomas Jordan's struggle to control the franc.

site_title: Chinese consortium to salvage sunken South Korean ferry
summary: A Chinese-led consortium has won the bid to salvage the sunken South Korean ferry Sewol, which sank in April 2014 with over 300 lives lost, including most of the children on a school trip. The ferry remains submerged off the southwest coast, with nine people still unaccounted for. The Chinese consortium will undertake the massive task of raising the 6,825-tonne ship, following a campaign by the families of those still missing for the ferry to be brought to the surface.

site_title: Puerto Rico defaults on bond payment, pays fraction of US$58m
summary: Puerto Rico defaulted on a US$58 million bond payment, paying only US$628,000, due to lack of funds. This marks the first default by the Commonwealth and is the most notable since Detroit's 2013 bankruptcy. The non-payment may lead to litigation with investors and could set a precedent for future payments. Credit agencies, including Moody's, view the event as a default, and investors are concerned about the island's economic and cashflow problems.

site_title: Funds sell more Singapore shares than they buy
summary: Global mutual funds sold more stocks than they bought in the three months to July 29, with net sells of S$1.18 billion compared to net buys of S$965.4 million. The top five stocks among buys were ARA Asset Management and top among sells was Citic Envirotech. The data, provided by ShareInvestor and Ipreo, offers a glimpse into where fund managers are focusing their attention, but does not account for trades by alternative investors and institutional money managers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Singapore companies reported varying financial results for the first quarter of 2015. IPIT swung into a net loss of S$476,000 due to declining property income and rising expenses. PSL Holdings plans to diversify into investments, while SBI Offshore acquired a 51% stake in Graess Energy. Ho Bee Land acquired a prime office in London for S$98 million, and Chip Eng Seng Corporation reported a 14.9% rise in net profit. Other companies, including Riverstone Holdings and Japan Foods Holding, also reported positive earnings growth. The results reflect the challenges facing the Singapore economy amidst global market fluctuations.

site_title: New US airline group backs Gulf carriers in row
summary: A US airline group has formed to support Gulf carriers in a dispute over alleged government subsidies. The US Airlines for Open Skies Coalition, consisting of FedEx, JetBlue, Atlas Air, and Hawaiian Holdings, argues that the subsidies distort competition. The group sent a letter to the Obama administration, opposing a proposal to investigate the subsidies. This move counters a coalition of US airlines and unions, which has called for consultations with Gulf states to address the alleged subsidies. Each Gulf carrier has denied the subsidy claims.

site_title: Greek banks weigh down stocks as bailout talks grind on
summary: Greece's stock exchange fell 1.26% on Tuesday due to a decline in bank shares, with the Athex index suffering its steepest-ever drop of 16.32% on Monday. The country faces a 3.2 billion euro repayment deadline to the European Central Bank on August 20 as talks with creditors continue over the terms of a new bailout.

site_title: UK construction growth slows in July on softer housebuilding
summary: The UK construction industry's growth slowed in July, with the Markit/CIPS UK construction purchasing managers' index falling to 57.1 from 58.1 in June. Housebuilding activity increased at its slowest pace since April, driven by a surge in confidence among construction firms after the national election. The slowdown may reflect easing confidence and challenges in tackling Britain's housing shortage, including long lead times, supplier scarcity, and skill shortages. This marks one of the weakest expansions since mid-2013, highlighting the need for policymakers to address the issue.

site_title: Australia seeking exposure to future US sugar demand in trade pact
summary: Australia is seeking a guaranteed share of future US sugar demand in the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade pact. The country has rejected a US offer of 152,000 tonnes of imports per year, instead pushing for commercially meaningful levels of new access. Australian sugar producers want to tap into growth in US demand, with projections suggesting a 500,000-tonne increase. The negotiations, ongoing since August 1, have been marked by disagreements between US growers and confectioners, who support Australia's proposal, and cane-growers, who oppose it.

site_title: The end of hitchBOT: 'Bad things happen to good robots'
summary: A social experiment robot called hitchBOT, designed to test human trust, was destroyed by vandals in Philadelphia after traveling 300 miles across the US. The robot, assembled from household items, had previously traveled thousands of miles in Canada and Europe without incident. Researchers are focusing on what can be learned from the experiment and exploring future adventures for robots and humans, with no plans to press charges against the perpetrators.

site_title: APTT posts 2.4% rise in Q2 operating earnings
summary: ASIAN Pay Television Trust (APTT) reported a 2.4% year-on-year rise in operating earnings (Ebitda) to S$50.4 million for Q2, driven by higher revenue across TBC's services in Taiwan. Total revenue grew 4.4% to S$82.7 million. The board declared an ordinary distribution of two cents per unit for the quarter, to be paid out on Sept 25. APTT expects full-year revenue and Ebitda to be higher than 2014, with distributions anticipated to be at least equal to 2014.

site_title: Currency effect pushes China's banks to top of global rankings
summary: China's banks have taken the top spots in the world's largest banks by assets, with Industrial & Commercial Bank of China Ltd ranking first at $3.452 trillion and China Construction Bank Corp ranking second at $2.819 trillion. The shift is largely due to the currency effect, where China's banks report in US dollars, giving them a significant advantage over other banks. HSBC Holdings Plc, previously second, now ranks fourth, while US banks are pushed out of the top five due to differences in accounting standards.

site_title: Influencers with big followings get picky about endorsements
summary: Online influencers with large followings are becoming more selective about endorsements, fearing they may appear to sell out. As advertisers increasingly turn to social media influencers to reach young audiences, the tactic's effectiveness is dwindling. Many influencers, like Ricky Dillon, are now choosing partnerships that feel organic and authentic, rather than simply jumping at the opportunity for free products. This shift reflects a growing awareness among influencers that their credibility is tied to their authenticity, and that partnering with too many brands can damage their reputation.

site_title: China dethroned as world's most liquid stock market after curbs
summary: China's stock market has lost its title as the world's most liquid market due to trading halts and regulatory efforts to curb bearish transactions. Daily turnover has averaged $202 billion over the past 30 days, down from $288 billion in July. The decline is attributed to 36% lower volume in Shanghai on Tuesday. The US stock market now surpasses China, with shares traded at $72 billion higher. The shift is attributed to China's efforts to curb market volatility and prevent a bear market.

site_title: Mumbai's Sunteck seeking funds to buy distressed property
summary: Mumbai-based luxury condo developer Sunteck Realty Ltd is seeking private equity funds to buy distressed assets from rivals struggling with record debt. The company plans to leverage its strong balance sheet to acquire assets, build condominiums and offices, and potentially lend its brand to complete stuck projects. Sunteck aims to boost rental income from commercial assets 10-fold to 2 billion rupees in the next three to four years, while maintaining its residential assets at 80%. The move comes as Indian real estate companies turn to private equity amid a funding squeeze.

site_title: Challenging market weighs down bids for West Coast site
summary: A 99-year leasehold private residential site along West Coast Vale with waterway frontage in Singapore fetched just six bids in a tender, down from 18 for a neighboring site in 2013. The top bid of S$551.15 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) is nearly 20% lower than the previous site's top bid. Market watchers attribute the low turnout to weaker market conditions, site-specific factors, and rising interest rates, with some developers conserving their interest for more attractive sites in the second-half Government Land Sales Programme.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: MTI's Second Perm Sec said to be entering politics
summary: Singapore's Second Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of Trade and Industry, Chee Hong Tat, is leaving the civil service, sparking speculation that he is entering politics ahead of the upcoming General Election. Chee, 41, was recently spotted with People's Action Party (PAP) members at community events and will resign on August 11. As a public servant, Chee must leave the civil service if seeking political office. His departure comes after the PAP is set to unveil its new candidates for the election following the National Day weekend.

site_title: StarHub, MDA to put S$10m into local TV and online content
summary: StarHub and the Media Development Authority (MDA) have agreed to spend up to S$10 million on local TV and online content. The funding, under the public service broadcast contestable funds (PCFS) scheme, aims to produce over 80 hours of original content showcasing Singapore's culture and heritage. The content will be showcased on StarHub's channels and available on the telco's internet TV platform, TV Anywhere, free of charge within six months. This is the second time StarHub has received PSB funding, following a successful first wave in 2013.

site_title: Federal Reserve likely to start raising rates later rather than sooner
summary: The US Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates later this year, rather than sooner, as the economy expands at a sustainable rate of at least 2% per annum. The Fed's decision will be driven by data, including job creation, and is influenced by factors such as a falling 10-year US Treasury yield and advice from the International Monetary Fund to wait until next year. A late rate hike is preferred to avoid destabilizing the global economy and to prevent overvaluation of the US dollar, which could dampen growth and job creation.

site_title: Greece should prepare for Grexit - and then not do it
summary: Greece should prepare for a potential Grexit, but not actually execute it, as it could be a disastrous outcome. To prepare, the country needs to address key issues such as printing bank notes, producing coins, and drafting legislation for the new legal tender. Additionally, the Central Bank of Greece must be given a clear mandate and independence to act accordingly. The government must also implement necessary reforms, resolve bank issues, and ensure fiscal discipline. A well-prepared Grexit could lead to a better outcome for both Greece and its creditors, making it a plausible solution.

site_title: ESM Goh to stand in Marine Parade; reveals 'likely' team
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong has announced he will likely stand in the next General Election in Marine Parade, revealing the People's Action Party's (PAP) likely team. Four of the five current team members will remain, except for Tin Pei Ling, whose MacPherson ward will be carved out as a single seat. First-term MP Edwin Tong is expected to join the team, replacing Tin Pei Ling. Goh will explain his decision at the GRC's National Day dinner on Aug 14, amid a closely-contested single seat of Joo Chiat.

site_title: Rajan holds India rate, rebuffing pressure from government
summary: Indian central bank governor Raghuram Rajan kept interest rates unchanged at 7.25% despite pressure from the Finance Ministry to reduce borrowing costs. The decision was seen as a surprise by some economists, who had predicted a rate cut. Rajan cited concerns over inflation and the impact of a weak monsoon and potential US interest rate hikes as reasons for maintaining the status quo. The central bank will continue to monitor the economy and assess the need for further policy easing.

site_title: Apple denies it plans to sell mobile services directly to consumers
summary: Apple has denied plans to sell mobile services directly to consumers, contradicting a Business Insider report. The report claimed Apple was testing a mobile virtual network operator (MVNO) to rent capacity from mobile network operators and sign up its own customers. Apple stated in a statement that it has not discussed or plans to launch an MVNO, and is in talks with European operators about such an arrangement.

site_title: Blackstone, Fortress among bidders for Japan's Simplex
summary: US investment funds Blackstone Group, Fortress Investment Group, and Elliot Management, along with Japanese firms Hulic Co and Kenedix Inc, are shortlisted for the second round of bidding to buy Japan's Simplex Investment Advisors in a deal potentially worth over US$1 billion. The second round of bidding is expected to close by the end of this month. Simplex owns a hotel near Tokyo Disney Resort and a 12-storey office building in Tokyo's Toyosu district, attracting bidders due to rising property values and demand for accommodation.

site_title: Microsoft's offshore profit stockpile crosses US$100b mark
summary: Microsoft's offshore profit stockpile has surpassed US$100 billion, with a 17% increase over the past year. The company's stockpile now stands at US$108 billion, making it the second US corporation to reach this milestone after General Electric. This growth is attributed to Microsoft's profits in low-tax foreign jurisdictions.

site_title: Greece says no significant problems in privatisation talks: FinMin
summary: Greece's finance minister, Euclid Tsakalotos, stated that there are no significant disagreements with lenders on privatisation discussions, saying talks are going better than expected. The main issue revolves around the administration and control of a new transformed privatisation agency, but Tsakalotos expressed confidence that a solution can be reached.

site_title: Positive underpinnings for equities in Asia: BNP fund manager
summary: Asia's equities are expected to stage a bull run over the next five to 10 years due to attractive valuations, economic reform, policy easing, and cash-rich corporates. Asian companies have nearly $1 trillion in cash on their balance sheets, which they can use for buybacks, M&As, and dividend increases. Despite recent weak portfolio flows into emerging markets, Asia ex-Japan is trading at a lower price earnings multiple compared to the US and MSCI World, and has a higher average dividend yield. However, caution is advised on China due to elevated house prices and a mismatch between assets and liabilities.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Swiber secures US$80m pipeline project in Latin America
summary: Swiber Holdings secured a US$80 million pipeline project in Latin America with a global energy company. The contract includes installing monobuoys, pipeline-end manifolds, and a submarine pipeline. The project is expected to boost Swiber's order book to US$1.9 billion, with installation work to commence in Q3 2015 and completion in Q1 2016.

site_title: Bonuses for London commodities and rates trading chiefs plunge
summary: Bonuses for London commodities and rates trading chiefs have plummeted by up to 60% due to plunging commodity prices and low interest rates. Commodity managing directors' bonuses averaged 150,568 pounds (US$234,886) this year, down 60% from 373,000 pounds last year. Rates trading desk bonuses also decreased, averaging 296,902 pounds, down 33% from 460,000 pounds last year.

site_title: In Greece, plastic casts light into shadow economy
summary: Greece's banking crisis has led to an increase in debit card usage, potentially reducing the shadow economy. Since the government imposed controls on euro bills, about one million debit cards have been issued by banks. This shift towards digital transactions is expected to increase transparency and reduce undeclared transactions, which currently account for about a quarter of the economy.

images.alt_text: Pensioners waiting to be issued their bank ATM/debit cards inside a National Bank branch at Iraklio in Crete. About 1m debit cards have been issued by banks since the government closed lenders for three weeks and imposed controls on euro bills.

site_title: King steps down as HSBC chief economist, replaced by Henry
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc announced that Stephen King stepped down as its global chief economist, replaced by Janet Henry. King, who served for 17 years, will remain at the institution as senior economic adviser, working a three-day week and advising key clients. Henry previously led European economic coverage. The changes took effect at the end of last week.

site_title: Twitter's drop to its lowest since IPO may draw takeover offers
summary: Twitter's shares dropped 5.6% to $29.27, the lowest price since its 2013 IPO, after management's tough talk. This move pushed the company's market value below $20 billion, making it a more attractive takeover target for potential buyers like Google. The decline may prompt takeover offers, according to investors.

site_title: Sembcorp Q2 profit up on disposal gain
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 24.9% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$223.56 million in Q2, primarily driven by a one-off gain from selling a subsidiary. The company's utilities segment and marine arm experienced weaker contributions, but its overseas business remains on track. The power plant in India is expected to come online in the third quarter, boosting the group's hopes for growth.

site_title: Coal prices near-decade lows as Chinese demand slumps
summary: Global coal prices have fallen to nearly a decade-low of US$55.50 a tonne due to a supply glut and decreasing demand from top consumer China, which has reduced coal imports by 37.5% from last year. This trend is expected to continue, particularly benefiting emerging economies reliant on coal. However, environmental pressure to curb greenhouse gas emissions from coal-fired power stations may impact the market, with capacity removal needed for prices to reach their bottom.

site_title: Italy in favour of a European Monetary Fund
summary: Italy's finance minister, Pier Carlo Padoan, expressed support for a European Monetary Fund, citing the need for tighter European integration to prevent the eurozone from being hit by future economic shocks. This move is seen as a response to the economic crisis that left several members at risk of crashing out of the eurozone. The idea of an EMF was initially proposed in 2010 and has been endorsed by Portugal, with the aim of reducing the reliance on national parliaments for financial assistance.

site_title: Transportation equipment buoys US factory orders in June
summary: US factory orders rebounded in June with a 1.8% increase, exceeding economists' expectations. Strong demand for transportation equipment, including aircraft, drove the growth. Orders for machinery, electrical equipment, and appliances also rose. The increase suggests a possible revision to the second-quarter GDP growth rate, which was reported at 2.3%. The upward revisions also indicate a stronger business confidence and spending plans.

site_title: Malaysia's new entry free 'discriminates' against Singapore vehicles: Transport Ministry
summary: Malaysia's new entry fee for foreign-registered vehicles, RM20 (S$7.16), imposed on October 1, has been deemed discriminatory against Singapore vehicles. The Ministry of Transport stated that Singapore will consider matching the fee in "some form" after studying its implementation. This decision aims to address concerns that the new fee unfairly targets Singapore motorists, who often use Malaysia's Johor state for daily commutes.

site_title: Bucking global trend, S Koreans pile into gold
summary: South Koreans are on track to buy a record amount of gold in 2015, with first-half sales totaling 1 trillion won (S$1.19 billion). This marks a departure from global trends, as China and India, traditional gold buyers, have seen weak demand. South Koreans are buying gold as a store of value due to low interest rates and concerns about the impact of China's stock market on their equities. This is the first time South Korea has reached this milestone.

site_title: STI flat on weak China data, Wall Street fall
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 1.75 points or 0.05% to 3,191.04, extending its fourth straight day of losses, due to weak manufacturing data from China and an overnight Wall Street fall. The US Federal Reserve's possible rate rise in September remains a concern. In other regional markets, Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng closed little changed.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: UK eyes Asia trade deals in case Brexit really happens
summary: The UK is seeking to strengthen trade links with Asia, particularly Singapore and Malaysia, in the event of a possible Brexit, as a way to contain trade disruptions with the EU. British Prime Minister David Cameron has traveled to South-east Asia to secure trade deals and research and development collaborations. The UK government has also proposed a free trade agreement with the Commonwealth, but this is seen as unlikely. The British government prefers to remain in the EU, but if the UK were to leave, it would likely negotiate an agreement with the EU, modeled on trade agreements with Switzerland and Norway.

site_title: Oil price unlikely to recover as Saudi refining hits market
summary: Saudi Arabia's expansion of refineries is expected to further reduce crude oil prices, as it increases supplies of diesel and jet fuel, forcing other refineries to slow down operations. This oversupply, combined with the US shale boom and record Opec output, has already put pressure on oil prices near $50 a barrel. Storage tanks in Asia and Europe are filling up with diesel and jet fuel, indicating weaker margins and lower runs for refineries, leading to a potential surplus of crude oil.

site_title: Vested interests hamper TPP trade talks
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade talks are stalled due to intractable differences over intellectual property protection among its 12 member nations. Key issues include Mexico's opposition to increased competition in the US truck market and Canada's protection of its dairy market ahead of elections. These disagreements have hindered progress in the talks, which aim to create a comprehensive free trade agreement. The impasse has raised concerns about the future of the TPP, a major economic initiative that could have significant implications for the region's trade and economic growth.

site_title: World hopes for first clues to MH370 mystery
summary: Technical experts in France are analyzing a washed-up plane part from missing flight MH370, raising hopes for clues to the mystery. The 2-meter-long wing part, known as a flaperon, was discovered on the French Indian Ocean island of La Reunion and has been taken to Toulouse for examination. Experts believe the paint and barnacles on the piece may provide information on the plane's origin and final moments, but warn that the analysis may not reveal why the plane diverted off course. The investigation aims to shed light on the final moments of the plane, providing closure for the victims' loved ones.

site_title: Europe: Bank shares lead European stock drop as Greece falls for 2nd day
summary: European stocks declined for the first time in five days, led by bank shares, as Greece's shares fell for a second day. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index dropped 0.2% to 398.75, driven by Credit Agricole's 10% tumble and Total SA's and Eni SpA's losses. Commodity producers, however, rose, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto gaining at least 1.6% as metal prices rebounded. The decline was largely driven by concerns over Greek debt and regulatory issues affecting banks.

site_title: OSIM now a substantial shareholder of Trek 2000
summary: OSIM International has become a substantial shareholder of Trek 2000 after acquiring approximately 8.41% of the company's existing issued and paid-up share capital through a subscription and purchase of new ordinary shares and treasury shares. The acquisition was completed on July 31, 2015.

site_title: India's household inflation expectations up for 3rd straight quarter
summary: India's household inflation expectations rose for a third consecutive quarter, with 10.1% expected within three months, according to the Reserve Bank of India survey. This marks a rise from 9% in the previous survey in March and is the highest since November 2013. Despite this, India's consumer price inflation dropped to 5.4% in June, and the RBI is monitoring the rate of change in households' inflation expectations rather than the absolute numbers. The RBI kept interest rates on hold, citing concerns over a sustained hardening of inflation outside of food and fuel.

site_title: Alibaba hires former Goldman banker Evans as president
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has hired former Goldman Sachs Group Inc partner Michael Evans as its president, tasked with overseeing international expansion. Evans, with no direct e-commerce experience, will lead Alibaba's global growth strategy outside of China. This move signals the company's intention to ramp up cross-border commerce, driven by the potential to connect Chinese consumers with international suppliers. Alibaba's CEO Daniel Zhang sees globalization as the company's key strategy for the coming decades.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has hired former Goldman Sachs Group Inc partner Michael Evans to oversee the e-commerce company's international expansion, a top priority as the firm looks beyond China to sustain its heady growth rates.

site_title: Dollar drops from four-month high as traders weigh US outlook
summary: The US dollar fell 1.6% against the Australian dollar after the Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates unchanged, sparking profit-taking and a re-evaluation of the dollar's strength. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index dropped 0.2% to its lowest level since March 17. Traders weigh the US employment report on August 7 and the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, with a 38% chance of a September rate hike. The dollar's decline supports commodity currencies, including the euro and yen, amidst a rebound in oil prices.

site_title: Start-ups not at risk from German tax plans: government official
summary: Germany's proposed capital gains tax reform, which aims to close a tax loophole, will not deter start-up companies, a government official said. The tax, which would apply to minority shareholdings, has been criticized by the start-up industry, but an exemption for business angels investing in companies under three years old will help. The tax reform is intended to address a potential loophole allowing investors to avoid paying taxes on dividends. Despite concerns, the government hopes to agree on the bill by the end of the year and have it debated in parliament in 2016.

site_title: Platinum reaches 6-year low on China demand concern; gold steady
summary: Platinum prices hit a six-year low due to concerns over slowing demand from China, a key market. The country accounts for 23% of global demand for platinum and palladium. BMW cut production in China, citing slowing sales, and the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike has reduced the allure of precious metals. Platinum fell 1.1% to $956.30 an ounce, while palladium reached its lowest since 2012. Gold prices remained steady at $1,090.60 an ounce.

site_title: Update: Greece upbeat about bailout deal, sees one within two weeks
summary: Greece expects to finalize a multi-billion-euro bailout deal within two weeks, with the deadline for a 3.5 billion-euro debt payment to the European Central Bank set for August 20. The bailout, worth up to 86 billion euros, aims to stave off bankruptcy and keep Greece in the eurozone. Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos said talks are going better than expected, despite "small divergences in views" with lenders. A deal would bring closure to a tumultuous six months, including capital controls and a five-week bourse shutdown, and pave the way for Greece to pay off its debt.

site_title: US: Stocks flat as oil prices rally
summary: US stocks opened little changed on Tuesday as oil prices rallied, following China's announcement of new rules restricting short selling. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.09% to 17,613.30, while the S&P 500 added 0.03% to 2,098.72. Chevron and EOG Resources rose 1.0% and 1.1% respectively, driven by higher oil prices. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index jumped 3.7% in China, attributing the gains to the new measures. Market sentiment remained lackluster, attributed to mediocre economic data and anemic trading volumes.

site_title: EU trade negotiators aim for 2016 US trade pact
summary: EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom aims to finalize the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) with the US in 2016, with the agreement expected to encompass a third of world trade. The deal would include a new procedure for dispute resolution, moving away from private courts and towards a system of pre-designed, pre-selected judges with increased transparency. This comes after the European Parliament gave Malmstrom a mandate to continue negotiations, despite opposition from some EU lawmakers who see the deal as a threat to EU law.

site_title: BBR's Q2 profit plunges 99%
summary: BBR Holdings posted a 99.2% drop in net profit to S$40,000 for Q2, with revenue down 44.2% to S$106.9 million. The company attributed the decline to lower revenue from general construction and property development segments. Despite this, the group has an order book of S$500 million and is focusing on operational efficiency and cost management. The outlook remains challenging, but BBR will continue to leverage its track record in building construction to secure new projects and enhance cost effectiveness.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng's Q2 profit up 15%, lifted by property development division
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation reported a 14.9% rise in Q2 net profit to S$21.4 million, driven by a 59.4% increase in total revenue to S$197.1 million, primarily due to higher revenue from property developments. Revenue from property developments rose 189.2% to S$106.5 million, mainly from the Nine Residences & Junction Nine project in Yishun. Despite a challenging property market outlook, the company sold over 80% of units in High Park Residences in the first week of its launch.

site_title: British oil company investigated for corruption in Somalia
summary: British oil company Soma Oil and Gas, chaired by Lord Michael Howard, is being investigated by the Serious Fraud Office (SFO) for alleged corruption in Somalia. The company denies paying $500 million to government officials to protect an oil exploration deal signed in 2013. The investigation follows claims of corruption, which Soma described as "defamatory".

site_title: Greek says expects bailout deal by Aug 18
summary: Greece expects to conclude a bailout deal with international lenders by August 18, with the drafting of the accord starting on Wednesday. Government spokeswoman Olga Gerovasili said the deal could be reached if EU summit terms are met, with a possible agreement by August 18.

site_title: BMW CEO puts digital trends at centre of strategy review
summary: BMW's new CEO, Harald Krueger, plans to update the company's strategy to fit the digital future of driving, citing intensified trends in digitization and its impact on the automobile industry. The company recently acquired Nokia's high-definition mapping business for €2.5 billion to protect its access to key technology for connected and self-driving cars. Krueger mentioned the need for a comprehensive strategy update, but declined to provide further details, emphasizing the need to adapt to rapidly changing digital trends.

site_title: Deutsche Bank asked to pay former employee US$3m in damages
summary: Deutsche Bank has been ordered to pay former employee Jorge Usandivaras $3 million in damages for breaching his employment contract and violating US labor laws. Usandivaras, the former head of Deutsche Bank's Latin American Strategic Transactions unit, initially sought $4.5 million in compensation. The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) found the bank liable for the damages, following Usandivaras' claims that the bank acted in contravention of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, which protects whistleblowers.

site_title: Malaysia obtains arrest warrant for Sarawak Report founder
summary: Malaysian authorities have obtained an arrest warrant for Clare Rewcastle-Brown, founder and editor of the Sarawak Report whistleblower website. Rewcastle-Brown, based in Britain, is wanted for allegedly breaching a court order related to a libel case filed by Daim Zainuddin. The Malaysian police plan to seek Interpol's assistance to detain Rewcastle-Brown.

site_title: Ukraine sends new debt proposal to creditors in "decisive" week: ministry
summary: Ukraine sent a debt restructuring proposal to its largest creditors on Tuesday, with the International Monetary Fund urging a deal to avoid a moratorium on debt payments. The proposal aims to restructure $23 billion of Ukraine's external public debt, with creditors offering a 5% haircut on the principal. A deadline for a deal is seen as "decisive" by Ukraine's Finance Ministry, which has threatened to halt payments if an agreement is not reached. The IMF's $40 billion bailout package depends on Ukraine making $15 billion in savings via debt restructuring.

site_title: Luxury builder for Bollywood stars keen to buy distressed assets
summary: Luxury condominium developer Sunteck Realty Ltd is seeking private equity funds to acquire distressed assets from rivals struggling with record debt. Chairman Kamal Khetan aims to use the company's strong balance sheet to grow the business, potentially doubling its size. Sunteck plans to build condominiums, offices, and retail spaces, with a focus on commercial properties to boost rental income. However, analysts predict a slow luxury residential market over the next few years, with prices stagnating.

site_title: India's Modi backtracks on pro-business land bill
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has agreed to drop contentious clauses from a pro-business land bill, a move that may hinder long-term economic growth. The bill aimed to simplify land acquisition for infrastructure projects but faced opposition from farmers who saw it as anti-farmer. The exemption of 80% landowner consent for some projects was a key point of contention, and its removal may slow down infrastructure development, locking up hundreds of billions of dollars. This decision may also fuel concerns about India's slow pace of economic reforms.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate posts S$33.5m profit for eight months post-RTO
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a total profit after tax and minority interests (Patmi) of S$33.5 million for the eight-month period post-completion of the reverse takeover (RTO) of St James Holdings in October 2014. Excluding one-off transaction costs, Patmi for the period post-RTO was S$44.9 million.

site_title: Itochu sees China economy under pressure from weak exports, spending
summary: Itochu Corp's Chief Financial Officer Tsuyoshi Hachimura expects China's economy to face strain due to weak exports and consumer spending, but anticipates a gradual recovery by year-end. Concerns include regional construction and real estate markets, municipal bonds, and stock market volatility. The Japanese trading house notes the government's stimulus measures will help China recover.

site_title: China central bank says to support liquidity, credit growth
summary: China's central bank announced plans to support liquidity and credit growth by using policy tools flexibly. The goal is to lower borrowing costs for firms and support key areas and vulnerable sectors. The bank also reiterated its intention to keep the yuan "basically stable" to further improve the exchange rate regime.

site_title: EL Development top bidder for 99-year private condo site at West Coast Vale
summary: EL Development won the top bid of S$314.1 million (S$551.15 per square foot per plot ratio) for a 99-year private condominium site at West Coast Vale. The site, located along Sungei Pandan, can generate 595 homes and features a park connector, offering residents greenery. The Urban Redevelopment Authority conducted the tender, which closed on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Short seller Yu 'wildly bullish' on Greece in euro exit scenario
summary: Greece is expected to exit the euro, and short seller Daniel Yu is "wildly bullish" on the country's stocks, saying he'll buy anything Greek if the country repudiates its debt. Yu believes Greece's debt relief would be a positive event for the economy, and the country's stock market, which has lost 85% of its value since 2007, is due for a rebound. Yu's prediction comes after Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras surrendered to creditors in a July summit, and he believes a Grexit would boost confidence and hope.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 20.46 points to close at 1,723.73 on Tuesday, with 1.34 billion lots valued at RM1.53 billion traded. The market saw 261 gains and 549 losses.

site_title: First eight startups picked for SPH Plug & Play accelerator programme
summary: SPH, Plug and Play, and Infocomm Investments announced the inaugural batch of eight startups selected for the SPH Plug & Play accelerator programme. The startups, chosen from 280 applicants, focus on content creation, online marketplaces, social media, and distribution platforms. The eight selected startups include Bolt, Circus 20/Twenty, Fashory, Imagin8ors, PlusMargin, Snapask, Tutate, and Yellow Elevator. Each will receive a seed funding of S$30,000 and mentorship opportunities from July to October 2015.

images.alt_text: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), Plug and Play, and Infocomm Investments on Tuesday announced the inaugural batch of eight startups selected for the SPH Plug & Play accelerator programme, which was announced in April this year and set up to develop high-growth startups to address challenges faced by the media industry.

site_title: Hot stock update: Noble Group jumps by most since '99, erases last week's drop
summary: Noble Group Ltd surged 28% to 60 Singapore cents, the largest gain since 1999, after bringing forward its second-quarter results announcement.
