The company aims to address "misleading and untruthful information" that led to a 28% slump last week, the biggest drop since the 2008 global financial crisis. Noble's stock is the most shorted on the Straits Times Index, with short interest at 9.7% as of July 31. Analysts expect the stock to rebound, citing the company's recent buybacks and review of accounting practices.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Noble Group Ltd surged 28% in two days, its largest gain since 1999, after bringing forward its results announcement. In other news, Malaysia plans to seize RM3 billion of assets belonging to Daim Zainuddin, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target for the MSCI's global equity index at 1,150. Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident that his daughter will be cleared of ethics charges, while the ASEAN region agrees that Myanmar's election is not a priority. The UK economy shrank for the second month, and South Korea's trade chief seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

site_title: Ringgit erases losses as brent crude rebounds above US$50 a barrel
summary: Malaysia's ringgit erased losses as Brent crude rebounded above US$50 a barrel, easing pressure on government finances. The ringgit closed little changed at 3.8537 a dollar after earlier falling to a new 16-year low. A technical gauge suggested the US dollar was poised to reverse gains, while a report may show Malaysia's exports contracted in June, marking the fifth monthly loss in 2015.

site_title: India central bank chief says may withdraw more funds via bond sales
summary: India's Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan said the central bank may withdraw more funds via bond sales, but will proceed cautiously amid excess liquidity. The RBI kept its policy rate at 7.25% and left the door open to ease further. Any increase in foreign debt limits would come after the US Federal Reserve raises US interest rates, Rajan stated. Foreign investors have nearly exhausted their US$25 billion allocation of government bonds.

site_title: South China Sea tensions flare at Asia security talks
summary: Southeast Asian diplomats urged China to address concerns over its island-building drive in the South China Sea, with the Philippines slamming Beijing's "unilateral and aggressive activities". China insists it won't discuss the dispute, prompting a rebuke from the Philippines. US officials also insist the issue must be raised, calling for a peaceful and cooperative settlement. Beijing claims control over nearly all of the South China Sea, while rival claimants, including the Philippines, Vietnam, and Taiwan, have varying claims that overlap.

site_title: Chinese firms said to approach Fortescue on infrastructure stake
summary: Chinese state-owned firms Hebei Iron & Steel Group Co and Tewoo Group Co are reportedly in talks to acquire a stake in Fortescue Metals Group's infrastructure assets in Western Australia's Pilbara region. The companies may also consider buying stakes in Fortescue's mines. Fortescue, controlled by billionaire Andrew Forrest, has stated its intention to sell minority stakes in mines, railroads, and ports, amid declining iron ore prices. The talks come as iron ore prices have tumbled, with the largest suppliers, including Rio Tinto Group, expanding production during a slowdown in China's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Hebei Iron & Steel Group Co and Tewoo Group Co have approached Fortescue Metals Group Ltd about acquiring a stake in the iron ore producer's infrastructure assets, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: India central bank's Rajan says comfortable with pace of disinflation
summary: India's Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan stated the central bank is comfortable with the pace of disinflation, despite some risks, including households' near-term inflation expectations returning to double digits. The RBI kept its policy rate at 7.25% and left room for further easing. Rajan emphasized the bank's focus on inflation expectations rather than levels, as disinflation is expected to take place given their targets.

site_title: US Department of Justice probes Deutsche trades worth billions: source
summary: The US Department of Justice is investigating billions of dollars in trades made by Deutsche Bank on behalf of Russian clients, involving the use of the US dollar. The investigation focuses on "mirror trades" where Russian clients bought stocks in roubles and simultaneously bought the same stocks in US dollars to move funds out of Russia without informing authorities. Deutsche Bank has informed regulators and law enforcement in several countries and has taken disciplinary measures against some individuals involved in the case. The investigation is part of a broader probe into possible money-laundering transactions by Russian clients.

site_title: Japan Foods' Q1 earnings rise 28.8%
summary: Japan Foods Holding reported a 28.8% increase in Q1 FY2016 net profit to S$1.1 million, driven by higher revenue. Revenue rose 0.8% to S$15.8 million, boosted by an increase in store numbers. Earnings per share increased 27.7% to 0.6 cent. This marks a strong start to the year for the company, with higher revenue and profits attributed to the expansion of its store network.

site_title: Indonesian consumers less optimistic in July: central bank survey
summary: Indonesian consumers showed less optimism in July, with a consumer confidence index of 109.9, down 1.4 points from June. Despite this, the level remains above 100, indicating optimism. Consumers expressed concerns over job availability, income, and economic conditions weakening over the next six months, as well as mounting price pressures. The annual inflation rate remained unchanged at 7.26%.

images.alt_text: Indonesian consumers were less optimistic in July than the previous month, a Bank Indonesia survey showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Riverstone posts 68% jump in Q2 profit
summary: Riverstone Holdings' net profit for Q2 2015 jumped 68.1% to RM27 million, driven by higher demand for gloves. Revenue rose 33.2% to RM129 million, while cost of goods sold increased 27.1%. The company declared an interim dividend of 2.40 sen per share. Executive Chairman and CEO Wong Teek Son expressed caution amid macroeconomic challenges but noted strong demand for products, accelerating the second phase of expansion to increase annual production capacity to 5.2 billion pieces.

site_title: Oil edges back up to US$50 a barrel from six-month low
summary: Oil prices edged back up to around $50 a barrel on Tuesday, rebounding from a six-month low, amid concerns over the economic outlook in China and high global production. Brent crude rose 57 cents to $50.09, while US crude gained 61 cents to $45.78. Despite OPEC's efforts to boost production, analysts predict a weak outlook for oil prices due to a strong US dollar, China's weakening economy, and rising Iranian oil exports.

site_title: Gold up on softer dollar; platinum and palladium at multi-year lows
summary: Gold prices rose on Tuesday as the US dollar weakened, while platinum and palladium hit multi-year lows due to oversupply and sluggish demand. Platinum fell to $940.50 an ounce and palladium to $586.30 an ounce. The metals were also affected by soft US economic data and a sharp drop in gold prices over the past month. A softer dollar relieved pressure on gold, which rose 0.7% to $1,092.33 an ounce.

site_title: Greek residential property price slide gains pace in second quarter
summary: Greek residential property prices declined by 5.6% in the second quarter of 2015, accelerating from a 4.1% annual pace in the first quarter. This marks a 40.5% drop from the 2008 peak, largely due to property taxes, tight credit markets, and a high unemployment rate. The decline is expected to continue, with the European Commission projecting a 2-4% contraction in Greece's GDP in 2015.

site_title: EU announces free trade deal with Vietnam 'in principle'
summary: The European Union announced a free trade deal with Vietnam "in principle" on August 4, 2015, aiming to remove nearly all tariffs on goods traded between the two countries.

site_title: European CEOs shrug off Greece, see recovery gaining pace
summary: European CEOs express optimism about the region's recovery, citing a weak euro, cheaper oil, and the European Central Bank's policies. Companies such as Diageo Plc are investing and hiring, with Ivan Menezes stating "Europe has come back to growth this year." This turnaround is attributed to a strengthening of southern Europe, which had been a drag for years. The improved outlook is driving business confidence, with some companies setting targets for growth and expansion.

site_title: Senior civil servant Chee Hong Tat, 41, resigns from the civil service
summary: Senior civil servant Chee Hong Tat, 41, has resigned from the civil service, marking a possible entry into politics ahead of the upcoming election. His last day of service is August 11.

site_title: UK house prices edge up in July: Nationwide
summary: UK house prices rose 0.4% in July, matching economists' forecasts, after a 0.2% decline in June. This brings the annual growth rate to 3.5%, up from 3.3% in June. The stabilisation of house prices is attributed to a closer alignment with earnings growth.

site_title: Singapore shares close marginally lower
summary: Singapore shares closed flat on Tuesday, ending at 3,191.04 after losing 1.8 points. Nearly 2 billion shares worth S$1.36 billion were traded, with 233 counters rising and 207 falling.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: UK takes 1 billion pounds hit in RBS sell-off
summary: The UK government sold a 5.4% stake in Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) at 330p per share, resulting in a 1.1 billion pound loss, despite selling 2.1 billion pounds. The sale, which marks the start of returning RBS to the private sector, was criticized by opposition politicians as an unnecessary and costly disposal. The UK government is currently sitting on a 15 billion pound loss on its holding, with analysts estimating a potential settlement cost of 9 billion pounds.

site_title: UK construction growth eases on softer housebuilding, engineering: PMI
summary: The UK construction industry's growth eased in July, with a PMI of 57.1, following a four-month high in June. Housebuilding and civil engineering activity slowed, with housebuilding at its weakest pace since mid-2013. The slowdown may reflect a loss of confidence among construction firms after the national election in May. The economy remains reliant on its services sector, and policymakers face challenges in addressing the chronic housing shortage.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries' Q2 profit jumps on divestment gain
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 24.9% increase in net profit to S$223.56 million in the second quarter, primarily driven by a S$54.71 million gain from the sale of a subsidiary, Sembcorp Bournemouth Water Investment. This sale occurred in April 2015. The company's earnings were influenced by this gain rather than organic growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares flat, China gains as Beijing cracks down on speculators
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended flat on Tuesday, down 0.02% at 24,406.12 points, as investors focused on earning reports from blue chips. China's main indexes rose sharply after Beijing announced new measures to curb short-selling, with the China Enterprises Index gaining 0.6%. Air China Ltd led gains with a 9.3% surge, while China Mengniu Dairy fell 4.2%. The measures aim to stabilize mainland markets and curb speculation, prompting Citic Securities and Huatai Securities to halt short-selling services temporarily.

site_title: Swiss housing bubble risk highest since 1991, says UBS
summary: UBS warns that Switzerland's housing market is at its highest risk of a bubble since 1991, driven by negative interest rates and excess demand for investment properties. Loan applications for second homes hit a record high, while mortgage volume and house prices rose 3.5% and 2% respectively. The Swiss National Bank's housing market imbalances have not yet evened out, despite measures to combat rising property prices. The UBS Swiss Real Estate Bubble Index reached 1.37 points, its highest level since 1991.

site_title: Major US airlines end trophy hunter shipments after Cecil outcry
summary: US airlines American Airlines, Delta Airlines, and United Airlines have banned the transport of lion, leopard, elephant, rhino, or buffalo killed by trophy hunters. The ban follows international outcry over the killing of Zimbabwe's Cecil the lion. The move affects the transport of "big five" animals, which were previously allowed to be shipped to the US. Campaigners had called for the ban, and nearly 400,000 people signed a petition to stop transporting exotic hunting trophies. The decision aims to deal a blow to Africa's multi-million-dollar game industry.

site_title: China's First Heavy chairman commits suicide amid anti-graft probe: Xinhua
summary: China's chairman of China First Heavy Industries, Wu Fusheng, 51, committed suicide while under investigation by China's anti-graft watchdog. Wu was found hanging in his office in Qiqihar city, northeastern province of Heilongjiang, on Sunday. The company announced his "sudden death" without providing details. This incident raises concerns amid China's ongoing anti-graft probe, which has led to several high-profile cases and executions.

site_title: BreadTalk stops selling soya milk; confirms that item was repackaged from Yeo's packet drink
summary: BreadTalk has stopped selling its soya bean drink after a photo surfaced of a staff member filling plastic bottles with Yeo's brand soya bean milk, which was repackaged as "freshly prepared". The incident sparked outrage online. The chain confirmed the allegations and apologized for the mistake. This is the second time BreadTalk has faced a product scandal, following a previous incident involving mislabelled bread. The company has yet to comment on the future of its soya bean drink product.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on earnings-day disappointment
summary: European stock markets declined on Tuesday, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index falling 0.3% and the Euro STOXX 50 index weakening by 0.5%. French bank Credit Agricole and German carmaker BMW were among the worst performers after reporting disappointing results, with Credit Agricole slumping 8% and BMW falling 2.7% due to slowing China sales. Weak oil prices also weighed on energy stocks.

site_title: ESM Goh Chok Tong to stand in Marine Parade for next election; reveals 'likely' team
summary: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong announced on Tuesday that he will likely stand in the next election as an MP in Marine Parade. He revealed the People's Action Party's (PAP) likely team for the five-member GRC. Goh Chok Tong has been an MP in Marine Parade since 1976. The announcement comes ahead of the next election, although a specific date has not been announced.

site_title: Euro rebounds after drop on hair-raising Greek stock plunge
summary: The euro modestly rebounded to $1.0966 and 135.95 yen after a 20% drop in Greece's stock market, reviving concerns about Athens' future in the eurozone. The single currency was boosted by a cautious dollar, which lost earlier gains due to weak US and Chinese manufacturing data. The eurozone's inflation and jobless rate remained flat in July, and Standard & Poor's lowered its outlook for the EU from stable to negative. The focus shifts to Friday's US jobs report, which may influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike decision.

site_title: Malaysian PM's critics unbowed despite anti-graft agency support
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak faces ongoing criticism from opposition parties and activists despite an anti-graft agency's statement clearing him of receiving nearly $700 million from the debt-laden state fund 1MDB. The agency acknowledged transferring 930 million ringgit into Najib's accounts but claimed it was a donation. Najib has denied taking any money for personal gain, but critics say his actions to delay investigations and silence dissenters have failed to quell the scandal. The crisis threatens Najib's ruling party, with many UMNO lawmakers rallying behind him but others questioning his leadership.

site_title: Currency traders show no mercy toward Swiss seeking weaker franc
summary: Switzerland's Swiss National Bank (SNB) is struggling to control the value of the Swiss franc, which has dropped 2.7% against the euro in the past two months, despite the bank's efforts to intervene. The franc's value remains 12% stronger than its previous ceiling, and options suggest a 52% chance it will reach parity with the euro within the next year. Experts warn that the SNB's attempts to curb the franc's strength are futile, as foreign-exchange markets can be unforgiving and unpredictable.

site_title: China: Stocks rise as Beijing steps up crackdown on short-selling
summary: China's stocks rose sharply on Tuesday, with the Shanghai Composite Index climbing 3.7% to its biggest daily gain since July 10. Authorities announced new measures to curb short-selling, which contributed to the market's rebound. Major brokerages Citic Securities, Huatai Securities, and Great Wall Securities temporarily halted their short-selling services. Analysts attributed the gains to investors waiting for the government's next move. China's Commerce Ministry also reported low import growth, while Shanghai Zijiang Enterprise and Hebi Janxi Chemical surged 10% in the Shanghai and Shenzhen indices respectively.

site_title: Japan PM adviser sees no need for BOJ easing, looks toward tapering
summary: Japan's Prime Minister adviser Etsuro Honda said there's no need for the Bank of Japan to ease monetary policy to meet its 2% inflation goal, instead suggesting a tapering of stimulus. This stance contrasts with earlier comments and comes as the economy faces steady growth but potential contraction in the April-June quarter. Honda cited the need to assess the impact of a planned sales tax hike and the risk of prices overshooting if additional stimulus is deployed. The BOJ may instead focus on tapering its asset purchases, a move that could influence the yen's value.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 0.14%
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.14% on Tuesday, following US markets lower due to concerns about China's economy. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 20,520.36, while the Topix index decreased 0.01%. Investors remained cautious after weak manufacturing data in China reignited worries about the country's economic health.

site_title: Australia: Shares pare gains as market lacks rate path clues
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 5,697.9, breaching the 5,700 psychological level, despite the Reserve Bank of Australia holding interest rates at record lows without indicating further easing. Financials, healthcare, and consumer staples sectors led gains, while material and energy-related shares were top losers. New Zealand's benchmark index closed down 0.41%.

site_title: BMW says earnings momentum slows on China, rivalry
summary: BMW's second-quarter operating profit decreased 3% due to slowing China sales. The company cited fierce competition, rising personnel costs, and high upfront expenditures as factors contributing to the slowdown. Despite this, BMW still expects to achieve new records for sales and pretax profit in the full year. The company warned that earnings momentum may continue to slow due to challenges in the Chinese market and increasing competition.

site_title: Australia to build new naval fleet in US$65b package
summary: Australia has announced a A$89 billion (S$89.6 billion) shipbuilding package to construct new frigates and patrol boats domestically, with a focus on South Australia. The proposal aims to replace frigates, patrol boats, and submarines over two decades, creating up to 2,500 jobs. The government is currently searching for an international supplier for replacement submarines, with France, Germany, and Japan in the running, and a decision expected in coming months.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble Group surges as trader almost erases last week's slump
summary: Noble Group Ltd surged 23% to 58 Singapore cents, its biggest advance in over six years, after announcing it will release second-quarter results three days early to address "misleading and untruthful information." The stock had plummeted 28% last week and lost over half its value since February due to criticism of its accounting practices. Traders who had shorted the stock may be getting squeezed, indicating the company has good news to share. The stock's short interest is at 9.7% of outstanding shares.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close up 1%; won erases early loss to close flat
summary: Seoul shares rose 1% on Tuesday, rebounding from a near five-month closing low. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 2,027.99 points. The won erased an early loss and closed flat against the dollar after Australia's central bank held interest rates at record lows. Foreign buying in local stocks also bolstered the local currency, closing at 1,165.5 per dollar.

site_title: Singapore Q2 GDP growth figures to be released on Aug 11, 8am
summary: Singapore's Q2 GDP growth figures will be released on Aug 11 at 8am. The data is expected to show a contraction of 4.6% on a seasonally adjusted basis, and 1.7% year-on-year growth, with the manufacturing sector experiencing a 4% contraction. Private-sector economists anticipate the government will narrow its GDP growth forecast to 2-3% from the current 2-4% projection.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Tuesday, easing 15.82 points to 24,395.6, as investors weighed a negative lead from Wall Street. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in US stocks, which edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: India central bank holds rates, leaves door open for more easing
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India, held its policy rate at 7.25% on Tuesday, as expected, while keeping the door open for further easing based on inflation and bank lending rates. The RBI cited concerns over the transmission of its past rate cuts and a "sustained hardening" of inflation outside of food and fuel. The decision comes as the economy grapples with commercial banks' reluctance to lower lending rates, despite the RBI's efforts to ease monetary policy.

site_title: South Korea president replaces health minister after Mers outbreak
summary: South Korea's President Park Geun-Hye replaced her health minister, Moon Hyong-Pyo, amid criticism over the government's response to the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) outbreak, which killed 36 people. The change comes a week after the government declared an effective end to the outbreak. Thousands of schools were closed, and nearly 17,000 people were confined to their homes to restrict the spread of the virus. The government has announced a 22 trillion won stimulus package to support businesses affected by the crisis.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Park Geun-Hye on Tuesday replaced her health minister, who was widely blamed for the government's poor response to the outbreak of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) that killed 36 people.

site_title: China dethroned as world's most liquid stock market after curbs
summary: China's stock market has lost its title as the world's most liquid market due to recent curbs and trading halts. The mainland exchanges' daily turnover averaged $202 billion over the past 30 days, down from $288 billion at the start of July. China's shares traded are now $72 billion lower than those in the US. The Shanghai Composite Index has sunk 27% from its year-high, and authorities have curbed short sales and warned investors against large sell orders. This marks a significant change from the unprecedented boom in Chinese stock trading during the first half of 2015.

site_title: Philippine central bank plans to adopt interest-rate corridor framework next year
summary: The Philippine central bank plans to adopt an interest-rate corridor framework starting next year to better manage liquidity in the financial system. The framework, which uses three separate interest rates, aims to align open market operations with market liquidity needs and strengthen monetary policy transmission channels. The overnight lending rate will serve as the ceiling (6%), the special deposit account rate will serve as the floor (2.5%), and the overnight borrowing or policy rate will be in the middle (4%). The framework must be approved by the central bank's policy-making Monetary Board.

site_title: Toyota books third straight Q1 profit record on cost cuts, currency gains
summary: Toyota Motor Corp posted its third consecutive record first-quarter net profit of 646.39 billion yen, exceeding analyst estimates. Cost cuts and currency gains contributed to the 10% profit increase, despite weaker vehicle sales. Toyota's sales growth was hindered by quality issues and intense price competition in China, where sales declined 0.1% in the first quarter. The company left its full-year net profit forecast unchanged and raised revenue guidance due to higher currency gains.

site_title: Greece: Stock market down 3.64% in early trading
summary: The Athens stock market plummeted 3.64% in early trading on Tuesday, following a record 16.32% drop on its first day of trading after a five-week shutdown. The ATHEX index fell to 643.72 points, its worst drop in nearly 30 years. This decline comes despite a new three-year bailout deal worth up to 86 billion euros being finalized. The reopening of the market comes amid ongoing uncertainty over Greece's economy and its place in the eurozone.

site_title: Former South Korea first lady set for rare North Korea visit
summary: Former South Korean first lady Lee Hee Ho is set to visit North Korea from August 5-8, marking a rare trip to the country. The 93-year-old widow of late President Kim Dae Jung will tour a children's hospital, maternity home, and orphanage in Pyongyang, raising hopes for a thaw in cross-border tensions. The visit, described as humanitarian, may offer a window for resuming dialogue over non-political issues, including family reunions and tourism. Lee Hee Ho's visit comes ahead of the 70th anniversary of the Korean peninsula's liberation from Japanese colonial rule.

site_title: BOJ's Iwata: sees no risks posed by expected Fed, BOE rate hikes
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Kikuo Iwata played down the risk of expected interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve and Bank of England, stating that foreign exchange markets may have already priced in these increases. Iwata dismissed the need for the BOJ to raise rates to prevent the yen from falling too fast, citing the central bank's focus on price stability rather than currency control. The BOJ is expected to keep policy steady at its upcoming meeting, despite challenges to its optimistic forecasts.

site_title: Indonesia to boost fiscal stimulus to help budget disbursement: central bank governor
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Agus Martowardojo announced plans to boost fiscal stimulus by optimizing allocated spending in the budget. The government aims to increase budget absorption in central and local governments to support budget disbursement. This move is expected to provide economic relief and stimulate growth.

site_title: Axa first-half profit climbs 2.3% led by life insurance result
summary: AXA SA, France's largest insurer, reported a 2.3% increase in first-half profit to 3.08 billion euros, driven by higher life insurance premiums. The company benefited from the dollar's gains, which boosted income from its US unit, and an economic recovery in Europe and a stock market rally, attracting more client investments.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 13.29 points to 1,730.09, opening lower on Tuesday. Losers outnumbered gainers 100 to 82, with 35.9 million lots traded worth RM22.5 million.

site_title: Australia's central bank keeps interest rate at 2.0%
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, kept interest rates at a record-low of 2.0% as it maintained the possibility of further easing and dropped calls for a weaker exchange rate. Governor Glenn Stevens stated that leaving the cash rate unchanged was appropriate for this month, citing a need to monitor data over the next few months to inform future policy decisions.

site_title: Ho Bee buys office property in West End London for £45.8m
summary: HO Bee Land Limited has acquired the 110 Park Street office in London's West End for £44.6 million, a five-storey building with 28,000 sq ft of Grade A office space. The property, re-constructed in 1990-1991, will be held as a long-term investment. The acquisition follows a previous deal within a week, marking the company's second prime office acquisition in the area.

site_title: Samsung glamour days over as it fights to save mobile market share
summary: Samsung faces a decline in mobile market share as it battles to compete with rivals Huawei and Xiaomi. The company's mobile division is forced to slash prices and accept lower margins to stay competitive. Despite being the world's largest smartphone maker, Samsung's premium segment is struggling, with margins falling to 10.6% in the second quarter. Analysts predict Samsung will continue to trail Apple in the premium market, with margins potentially falling to 9.3% this year.

site_title: Ringgit falls for 4th day as slumping oil exerts pressure
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell for a fourth day, declining 0.3% to 3.8650 per US dollar, as Brent crude dropped below US$50 a barrel. The currency's weakness suggests the central bank is stepping away from supporting it, and a report on Wednesday may show Malaysia's exports contracted in June for a fifth month in 2015. The nation's foreign-exchange reserves fell to a five-year low in July, and the ringgit has dropped 9.5% this year due to slumping oil prices and higher US interest rates.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed ahead of Australia, India interest rate calls
summary: Asian stocks are mixed ahead of an interest rate decision by the Reserve Bank of Australia, which is expected to keep rates at record lows. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul rose, while Shanghai and Sydney fell. Analysts anticipate Australia to maintain interest rates, but the central bank governor has not ruled out further easing. The mixed market sentiment comes as Chinese demand slows, affecting Australia's resource-driven economy.

site_title: Oil prices rebound in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices rebounded in Asian trade, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) rising 31 cents to $45.48 and Brent crude up 32 cents to $49.84, after falling sharply due to weak Chinese and US manufacturing and supply glut concerns. WTI plummeted $1.95 and Brent tumbled $2.69 on Monday, extending losses of over two percent on Friday.

site_title: Australia: Shares boosted by retail sales, earnings optimism
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Tuesday, driven by strong retail sales data and optimism about earnings. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 41.1 points to 5,720.5, breaching the 5,700 psychological resistance. Consumer discretionary shares, including Harvey Norman and Fairfax, surged, while major banks and energy-related shares fell. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to hold its cash rate at a record-low 2.0% later in the day.

site_title: China: Stocks rise at market open
summary: China's major stock indexes rose at the market open on Tuesday, with the CSI300 index increasing 0.2% to 3,836.67 points and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 0.3% to 3,633.17 points. The Hang Seng index in Hong Kong remained unchanged. The rally was driven by positive market sentiment, with no specific news or events mentioned as the cause.

site_title: China's import growth to remain sluggish: trade ministry
summary: China's import growth is expected to remain sluggish, according to the Commerce Ministry. Despite a slight improvement in imports this year, the ministry notes that the growth is still low. China's export sales unexpectedly rose in June, while imports fell for the fourth consecutive month. The tepid trade flows have raised concerns about the country's economic growth, which is set to slow. The ministry's comments suggest that policymakers may face increased pressure to address the issue.

images.alt_text: China's import growth is likely to remain at a low level, the Commerce Ministry said on Tuesday.

site_title: S&P downgrades outlook for EU after Greece crisis
summary: Standard & Poor's downgraded the European Union's outlook from stable to negative due to the EU's repeated use of its balance sheet to provide financing to member states, including Greece. This decision could lead to a lower grade for the EU in the next two years. The downgrade also follows Britain's decision to vote on leaving the EU. S&P cited the EU's use of its balance sheet as a reason for the revised outlook, highlighting the need for the EU to implement fiscal discipline.

site_title: PSL Holdings plans to diversify business
summary: PSL Holdings Limited plans to diversify its business, shifting from its current logistics and support services to investing in companies and securities through equity and bonds. The proposed change is expected to alter the company's risk profile, requiring shareholder approval. The company will provide more information on the plan in a shareholder circular and convene an extraordinary general meeting to seek approval. This diversification is expected to change the company's business model and risk profile.

site_title: Korea Inc struggles to keep it in the family
summary: The Lotte Group, Korea's largest retail giant, is embroiled in a family feud between its 92-year-old founder and his two sons. The siblings have engaged in bitter feuding, attempted boardroom coups, and personal attacks, causing significant concern for the company. The drama is being played out on television, with the three main protagonists issuing daily threats and accusations. The family squabble has little apparent concern for the impact on the company, which is the country's largest retail giant.

site_title: AVJennings issues higher profit guidance for fiscal year
summary: AVJennings Limited, a Singapore and Australia-listed property developer, has issued higher profit guidance for its fiscal year ended June 30, with expected profit before tax of A$47 million or higher. This is higher than the earlier guidance of A$40 million or higher, due to the completion of several projects in June despite adverse weather in New South Wales. The company remains confident in Australia's strong residential market conditions and expects full-year results on August 20.

site_title: Kuroda flags Japan real-yield drop to show stimulus is working
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yield fell to a record low of 0.405% after the Bank of Japan (BOJ) implemented its stimulus program, with real yields dropping 12 basis points. The BOJ's Governor Haruhiko Kuroda cited the decline in real yields as evidence that its stimulus is working, despite stagnant consumer prices. Projections for inflation over the next decade have climbed 20 basis points, while estimated real yields have fallen, suggesting the BOJ will stick to its current level of stimulus.

site_title: Gold declines with brent below US$50
summary: Gold prices declined 0.5% to $1,081.55 an ounce amid concerns over slackening demand for commodities and US interest rate outlook. Crude oil fell below $50 a barrel, with Brent oil at $49.86, due to supply gluts and Chinese economic slowdown. Asian energy and mining stocks also plummeted, while the Aussie dollar hit its weakest level since 2009. Investors scrutinize US data for clues to the timing of the first rate increase since 2006, driving commodity prices to a 13-year low.

site_title: Australia retail sales top forecasts, trade still a drag
summary: Australia's retail sales beat forecasts in June with a 0.7% increase, the largest rise in four months, while household spending for the second quarter boosted economic growth. However, a trade deficit of almost A$10 billion widened due to sliding commodity prices, potentially forcing the Reserve Bank of Australia to cut rates again despite a record low interest rate of 2%. The Australian dollar rose, but interbank futures still implied a two-thirds chance of rate cuts by year's end.

images.alt_text: Australian retail sales beat forecasts in June with the biggest rise in four months while household spending for the whole second quarter looked to have boosted economic growth, an upbeat outcome that gave the local dollar a lift.

site_title: Euro under pressure after hair-raising Greek stock plunge
summary: The euro plummeted to US$1.0936 and 135.64 yen on Tuesday, following a sell-off in New York and a plunge in the Greek stock market, which revived concerns about Athens' future in the eurozone. Weak US and Chinese manufacturing data also contributed to the dollar's gains, which were limited by the euro's decline. The euro's fall was a result of the Greek market's sharp drop, which heightened worries about the country's economic stability and its potential exit from the eurozone.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CWT, Sinwa, Yongmao, Indiabulls, APTT
summary: Singapore-listed companies reported mixed earnings results, with CWT posting a 14% drop in second-quarter net profit due to a decline in commodity logistics volume, while Sinwa saw a 22% rise in net profit. Yongmao Holdings reported a net loss of 7.4 million yuan, and Indiabulls Properties Investment Trust swung into a net loss. Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) reported a 2.4% year-on-year rise in operating earnings. These results are part of a broader trend of mixed corporate earnings in Singapore.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.42% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.42% lower on Tuesday, following a negative lead from Wall Street and a strong yen. The Nikkei 225 index declined 85.93 points to 20,462.18. The strong yen negatively affects Japanese exporters, making them less competitive abroad and decreasing profits when repatriated. US data showed slightly weaker manufacturing activity and a modest gain in consumer spending, contributing to the negative market trend.

site_title: SBI to acquire 51% stake in assets for JV company at S$13.97m
summary: SBI Offshore Limited has entered into an agreement to acquire a 51% stake in Graess Energy's assets for S$13.97 million. The assets include four solar photovoltaic power plants and systems in Bulgaria. The deal involves SBI acquiring 51% ownership of the assets before they are injected into Graess Energy. The consideration will be paid in cash and new shares issued at a 15.72% premium over the volume weighted average price for SBI shares. The acquisition aims to provide Graess Energy with a track record, expertise, and existing projects in the solar energy sector.

site_title: APTT posts 2.4% rise in Q2 operating earnings
summary: ASIAN Pay Television Trust (APTT) reported a 2.4% year-on-year rise in operating earnings to S$50.4 million in Q2, driven by higher revenue across its service offerings in Taiwan. Total revenue grew 4.4% to S$82.7 million. The board declared an ordinary distribution of 2 cents per unit for the quarter, with full-year distributions expected to be at least equal to 2014. Initiatives to grow TBC's business are ongoing, with a focus on up-selling and cross-selling services and inorganic growth.

site_title: Overseas properties, investment schemes to come under advertising guidelines
summary: Singapore's Advertising Standards Authority (ASAS) has unveiled enhanced guidelines for advertisements on investments, including overseas properties and investment schemes. The guidelines, effective August 12, require clearer warnings, disclosures, and qualifications to highlight potential risks. Advertisements must state what investors are acquiring, accurately depict properties, and not make claims that an investment is safe or risk-free. The guidelines aim to level the playing field between local and overseas developers, increase transparency, and prevent misleading ads. Advertisers and media owners have a three-month grace period to comply with the new requirements.

site_title: US officials eye risks from high frequency trading in bonds
summary: US officials are concerned about the risks of high-frequency trading in the government bond market, citing the "flash crash" in October and excessive price swings. This trading strategy, which can move billions of dollars in fractions of a second, threatens the market's ability to function and investors' ability to fairly value assets. The bond market is already experiencing a decline in liquidity, making it vulnerable to disruptions.

site_title: PetroChina wins dismissal of US lawsuit over alleged bribery
summary: PetroChina has won the dismissal of a US class-action lawsuit alleging bribery and corruption. US District Judge Edgardo Ramos ruled that the plaintiffs failed to show PetroChina made false statements about its corporate governance practices or internal controls. The lawsuit, filed by investors, claimed the company concealed bribery and corruption from April 2012 to December 2013. The judge also found that the individual defendants did not knowingly or recklessly disregard alleged corruption at PetroChina. The ruling marks a victory for PetroChina, which has been embroiled in an anti-graft campaign led by Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Bank of Russia scraps easing pledge, setting policy adrift
summary: The Bank of Russia has scrapped its pledge to continue easing interest rates, leaving economists uncertain about its monetary policy. Governor Elvira Nabiullina's decision, made without mentioning a plan to cut borrowing costs further, has raised concerns about the central bank's ability to address inflation and stabilize the rouble. The move comes as Russia faces a deepening recession and increasing economic pressures.

site_title: China stock exchanges step up crackdown on short-selling
summary: China's Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges introduced new rules to further restrict short-selling, aiming to increase the cost of speculation and ease selling pressure on the market. The rules, effective immediately, prevent traders from borrowing and repaying stocks within a day. This move is part of a broader government effort to stabilize the markets, which have lost about 30% of their value since June. The crackdown follows other measures, including brokerage limits, to prevent a market collapse and maintain investor confidence in the ruling Communist Party.

site_title: Puerto Rico defaults on bond payment, pays fraction of US$58m
summary: Puerto Rico defaulted on a $58 million bond payment, paying only $628,000. The move, which occurred due to a lack of funds, marks the first default by the commonwealth and is the most notable since Detroit's 2013 bankruptcy. Investors may file lawsuits, and a default could lead to restructuring of the island's $72 billion debt. Credit agencies, including Moody's, view the event as a default, which could have broader implications for commonwealth debt.

site_title: HSBC's Q2 profit falls 3.8%; Brazil unit's selloff agreed
summary: HSBC announced a 3.8% decline in Q2 profit due to a selloff of its Brazilian business. The bank agreed to sell its Brazilian unit for $5.2 billion to Banco Bradesco. This move is part of HSBC's plan to cut its global workforce by up to 50,000 as it exits Brazil and Turkey.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) opened lower on Tuesday at 3,185.18, down 7.61 points or 0.2% following a retreat in US stocks. The top volume stocks included Noble Group, Global Logistic Properties, and Golden Agri-Resources.

site_title: Aussie set for six-year low before RBA meets amid commodity drop
summary: The Australian dollar is poised to hit a six-year low before the Reserve Bank of Australia's monetary policy meeting on Tuesday, amid a decline in commodity prices. The Aussie slid with other commodity currencies after disappointing Chinese manufacturing data, deepening concerns about raw material demand. The Canadian dollar remains near an 11-year low, while New Zealand's dollar declined before a milk powder auction. Experts attribute the decline to commodity prices, with USD/CAD breaking higher.

site_title: The death of hitchBOT: 'Bad things happen to good robots'
summary: A Canadian hitchBOT robot, designed as a social experiment to test human trust, was destroyed by vandals in Philadelphia, ending its US journey. The robot, which traveled thousands of miles across Canada and Europe, was torn apart off Elfreth's Alley, the oldest residential street in the US. Researchers at Ryerson University, who devised the experiment, plan to explore what can be learned from the incident and are not pursuing charges. A technology collective in Philadelphia is considering resurrecting the robot.

site_title: AsiaPhos turns profitable for Q2
summary: ASIAPHOS Limited reported a net profit of S$481,000 for Q2, marking a turnaround from a net loss of S$417,000 in the same period last year. Revenue tripled to S$12 million, driven by a 139% increase in upstream revenue and a 360% surge in downstream revenue. Upstream sales of phosphate rocks increased by 139% to 89,100 tonnes, while downstream sales of P4 (a phosphate-based chemical product) rose to 1,900 tonnes. The company's financial performance was attributed to robust growth in both business segments.

site_title: Japan June wages tumble, cast clouds over consumer spending
summary: Japan's inflation-adjusted real wages fell 2.4% in the year to June, the fastest pace in seven months, and nominal wages tumbled by the most in over five years. This decline in wages poses a challenge to policymakers as it could weaken consumer spending.

site_title: Indiabulls Properties Investment Trust swings into the red for Q1
summary: Indiabulls Properties Investment Trust reported a net loss of S$476,000 for Q1, down from a net profit of S$195,000 in the previous year. Property income fell 11% to S$16.2 million, while operating expenses rose 17% to S$10.1 million. Rental income from commercial properties decreased 3% year-over-year to S$23.1 million. The loss was attributed to a decline in property income and rising operating expenses.

site_title: UK to start selling RBS shares with 5.2% stake
summary: The UK is selling 5.2% of its 78.3% stake in Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS), with the goal of raising funds and eventually restoring the bank to private ownership. The government plans to sell approximately 600 million shares over the next five years, with the aim of achieving the best value for taxpayers and supporting the economy. The sale price is expected to rise as the bank's health improves, with UK Financial Investments estimating the RBS share price will increase as more stock is sold to the market.

site_title: 'Fugitive' ex-UBS trader cannot escape US case over Libor: judge
summary: A US federal judge ruled against Roger Darin, a Swiss citizen, in a Libor rate manipulation case. Darin, a former UBS trader, was accused of conspiring with co-defendant Tom Hayes to manipulate yen Libor opinions. Darin's lawyers argued he wasn't a fugitive, but the judge rejected this claim, saying Darin was "flouting judicial process" by remaining in Switzerland. The decision came after Hayes was sentenced to 14 years in prison in a related UK case.

site_title: Microsoft buys firm that boosts sales through games
summary: Microsoft has acquired Texas-based startup Incent Games, developer of FantasySalesTeam, a platform that boosts sales team performance through fantasy sports-style competitions. The platform increases team collaboration, productivity, and drives business growth by getting employees invested in each other's success. FantasySalesTeam will be integrated into Microsoft's Dynamics CRM offering. The acquisition aims to disrupt the traditional sales incentive model with a unique twist combining gamification and fantasy sports.

site_title: Loonie, Aussie, Kiwi set for worst year since crisis
summary: The currencies of Canada, Australia, and New Zealand are experiencing their worst year since the financial crisis, with the Canadian dollar reaching its weakest since 2004 and the Australian and New Zealand dollars near six-year lows. The decline is attributed to plummeting oil prices, a slowdown in China, and hedge funds' bearish bets on the currencies. Analysts predict the downtrend will continue until commodity prices stabilize, and the currencies have fallen over 10% against the US dollar this year, surpassing the 2008 lows.

site_title: Greek stock market suffers record drop as shutdown ends
summary: Greece's stock market plummeted by a record 16.32 points, its worst drop in nearly 30 years, after a five-week shutdown. The ATHEX index fell 16.32 to 668.06 points, with bank shares sinking 30% amid concerns over the country's debt crisis and economic outlook. A new three-year bailout deal worth up to €86 billion has been agreed, but tough conditions have strained Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, who faces opposition from his lawmakers. The economy is forecast to contract by at least 3.0% this year.

site_title: Lucky lobsters jamming China flights send US prices to record
summary: US lobster prices have reached a record high due to a surge in demand from China, where lobsters from North Atlantic waters are significantly cheaper than competing supplies. A Korean Air Lines cargo plane makes a weekly 18-hour flight from Halifax, Nova Scotia to Shanghai, carrying around 60,000 live lobsters. This increased demand has led to a significant increase in exports from Canada and the US, with American prices rising by over a third. The rise in US lobster prices is a result of China's growing middle class and the decline of Western Australia's lobster catch.

site_title: Oil suffers second day of steep sell-offs
summary: Oil prices plummeted on Monday, with Brent crude falling 5.2% and West Texas Intermediate shedding 4.1% after data showed weakening US and Chinese manufacturing and a global supply glut. New data from the US and China, the world's two largest energy consumers, darkened the outlook for oil demand. OPEC refused to cut production, and Iran's oil minister predicted a significant increase in exports after sanctions are lifted. This, combined with record pumping in the Middle East, contributed to the decline in oil prices.

site_title: Dollar gains on euro as Greek stocks plunge
summary: The US dollar gained against the euro on Monday following a 20% drop in Greece's stock market, which revived concerns about Greece's future in the eurozone. The Greek stock exchange plummeted, with some analysts warning that the country may require EU lifelines for the foreseeable future. Meanwhile, analysts expect a heavy week of US economic indicators, including the July jobs report, which could influence interest rates and the dollar's value.

site_title: Rolls-Royce shares rise as activist stake fuels turnaround talk
summary: Rolls-Royce shares rose 4.4% to 829 pence, extending a 11% gain in two days, as activist investor ValueAct became its largest shareholder. ValueAct wants Rolls-Royce to speed up cost cuts in its aero engines unit and may push for divestment of non-aero businesses. The company reported a 32% drop in half-year profits, citing difficulties in its main aero engines business and oil-price related declines. CEO Warren East is focused on adding "pace and simplicity" to restructuring plans. Analysts see the engagement with ValueAct as positive for the stock.

site_title: June spending caps stronger quarterly performance
summary: US households continued spending in June, with a 0.2% increase in purchases, following a 0.7% advance in May. This marked a stronger quarterly performance for the economy, with incomes rising 0.4% for a third month. Consumer confidence is still cautious, and sustained momentum in spending is needed to keep US growth steady, with the economy growing at a 2.3% pace in the second quarter.

site_title: Automakers report strong US sales in July
summary: US auto sales surged 5.3% in July, reaching 1.51 million vehicles, with SUVs driving the growth. Strong demand and lower gasoline prices, averaging $2.65 per gallon, contributed to the increase. Industry leaders like General Motors, Ford, and Toyota reported strong sales, with SUVs and pickup trucks leading the way. The average car price rose 2.6% to $33,453, and the industry's annual rate of sales is at 17.55 million, the third consecutive month above 17 million.

site_title: Researchers find biomarkers for early stage pancreatic cancer
summary: British researchers have identified three biomarkers in urine that can indicate early-stage pancreatic cancer with 90% accuracy. The biomarkers, LYVE1, REG1A, and TFF1, were found to be present in high levels in patients with stage I-II pancreatic cancer, but not in those with chronic pancreatitis or healthy patients. The discovery holds promise for developing a non-invasive, inexpensive test to detect pancreatic cancer before it spreads, with the potential to improve survival rates from 3% to 60% for stage one patients.

site_title: Twitter shares close at all-time low on growth worries
summary: Twitter shares plummeted to an all-time low, closing at $29.25, due to concerns over slow growth and a lack of mainstream following. Despite beating financial expectations with a 61% revenue increase, the company's user base grew by just 2 million, sparking worries among investors. Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey acknowledged the challenges, stating that building a service people love will take time. This marks the lowest closing price since the company's IPO in 2013.

site_title: New US airline group backs Gulf carriers in Open Skies dispute
summary: A US airline group, US Airlines for Open Skies Coalition, has formed to back Gulf carriers in the Open Skies dispute. The coalition, comprising FedEx, JetBlue, Atlas Air, and Hawaiian Airlines, argues against US airlines' claims that Gulf carriers receive unfair government subsidies. The group plans to send a letter to the Obama administration, highlighting the diverse voices in favor of Open Skies agreements. This move comes as the US airline industry continues to challenge the Gulf carriers' market access.

site_title: Small firms, big potential
summary: Aberdeen Asset Management's Kwok Chern-Yeh discusses the potential of Japanese smaller companies, suggesting they offer big returns for investors. This view comes as the investment universe is shifting towards smaller firms.

site_title: Handbag stocks are still carrying too much baggage, analysts say
summary: Analysts downgraded shares of handbag makers Coach and Michael Kors due to continued slumping sales. JPMorgan Chase & Co downgraded Coach to a neutral rating, citing an overhaul that hasn't resonated with shoppers. Piper Jaffray lowered its earnings estimates and price target on Kors, citing inventory buildup at retailers like Macy's and Dillard's. The strong dollar also contributed to sluggish sales of wristwatches in the US and Europe. As a result, Coach fell 4% and Kors fell 7.3%, with both stocks losing nearly half their value this year.

site_title: Japan labour shortages could thwart Abenomics: IMF report
summary: A working paper by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that Japan's severe labour shortages could hinder its economy and undermine Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics policies. The report urges the authorities to increase the supply of foreign workers and learn from countries like Singapore to address the issue. Japan's rapidly ageing population, shrinking workforce, and high job-to-applicants ratio are contributing to labour shortages, which have negative economic implications both in the short and long term.

site_title: Ageing Mittelstand bosses seen as threat to German economic vitality
summary: Germany's Mittelstand, a backbone of the country's economy, is facing a significant threat due to the ageing of its owners without heirs and their reluctance to invest. Around a third of Mittelstand bosses are 55 or older, and this age group is growing four times faster than in the general population. This has led to a record high number of managers seeking to hand over their businesses, but fewer entrepreneurs are interested in taking over. As a result, the Mittelstand risks losing its innovative drive, jeopardizing jobs, and potentially becoming the "sick man of Europe" again.

site_title: US: Stocks drop as oil equities tumble
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 91.66 points (0.52%) to 17,598.20, and the S&P 500 losing 5.80 points (0.28%) to 2,098.04. Oil prices plummeted 4.1% to $45.17 a barrel, affecting petroleum-linked equities. The tech sector declined, with Apple, Netflix, and Tesla Motors falling, while General Motors and Ford rose after reporting better-than-expected auto sales.

site_title: High life on the high seas
summary: Ultra-luxurious cruises offer an unparalleled experience for high-end travelers. The article focuses on these exclusive voyages, but it does not provide specific details.

site_title: Bitcoin exchange CEO manipulated data dozens of times: report
summary: Bitcoin exchange CEO Mark Karpeles manipulated data at least 30 times between 2011 and 2013, according to a report, and is now facing arrest and questioning by Tokyo police over allegedly spending customer deposits worth $12.2 million. Karpeles was arrested for allegedly manipulating data to artificially create $1 million in Bitcoins in 2013. Tokyo has promised to boost efforts to regulate the digital currency, following the collapse of MtGox, which was once the dominant Bitcoin exchange.

site_title: Major bond selloff unlikely: Fidelity
summary: Fidelity's global chief investments officer, Andrew Wells, believes a major bond selloff is unlikely due to low inflation and default risks. Wells sees opportunities in Asian high yield bonds, European credits, and emerging market local currency bonds. However, market uncertainties surrounding US interest rate hikes may cast a shadow over Asia.

site_title: Heartware zone
summary: Former corporate executive Koh Poh Tiong is shifting his business-oriented approach to public service. No specific details about his new role or initiatives are provided.

site_title: Macau casino slump eases for fifth straight month in July
summary: Macau's casino industry saw a revenue slump ease for the fifth straight month in July, with gross gaming revenue falling 34.5% to 18.6 billion patacas. The decline, driven by an economic slowdown in China and Beijing's anti-graft campaign, has been easing since February. Analysts predict a 4.5% gain in 2016, with new resorts opening in the second half of the year expected to draw tourists and revenue back to the industry.

site_title: UK braces for rate hike never experienced by young debtors
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates, potentially for the first time in over six years, in early 2016, according to Governor Mark Carney. This move could impact the UK's fastest-growing economy, as highly indebted households may reduce spending, hindering growth. The rate increase is expected to affect 60% of outstanding variable-rate mortgages, which could lead to higher costs for consumers.

site_title: Looking inwards and outwards
summary: Outbound investment in Singapore is expected to continue due to elevated prices and market consolidation. China urges South-east Asia to support openness amid US tariffs. US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly fell. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio's India IPO has been delayed beyond this year. China unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: VW may find it hard to keep its place as world's top carmaker
summary: Volkswagen (VW) overtook Toyota as the world's largest carmaker by sales in the first half year, achieving its goal three years ahead of target. However, staying on top will be challenging due to stagnant demand in western Europe and reliance on China, which accounts for a third of its global sales. VW's dependence on China poses problems, and its inability to achieve synergies is a weak spot.

site_title: Bigger may be better for health insurers but doubts remain
summary: US health insurers Anthem and Cigna, along with Aetna and Humana, are set to form three giant companies after recent mergers. This consolidation could lead to a significant market share, with the resulting companies controlling nearly half of the American commercial health insurance market. Consumer advocates and experts express concerns that the mergers may harm consumers, citing past experiences with hospital mergers and the potential for reduced competition and higher costs. Regulators will closely monitor the deals and assess their impact on the competitive landscape.

site_title: Swiss border town hit by franc as shoppers defect to Germany
summary: A Swiss border town, Kreuzlingen, is experiencing economic strain due to the strong Swiss franc, which is causing locals to shop in neighboring Germany, hurting domestic retailers. The franc's advance this year has led to a decline in exports and a recession in Switzerland's economy, with growth forecast to lag the euro area. Consumer prices are expected to fall the most in six decades, and unemployment remains steady at 3.3%. While some businesses are not suffering, others, such as clothing stores, are experiencing revenue slumps due to the currency's impact.

site_title: Deadbeat ex-billionaire Batista dares bondholders to seize ship
summary: Brazilian ex-billionaire Eike Batista's oil company OGpar is refusing to pay rental fees on a $500 million oil ship, tied up in a legal battle with bondholders. OGpar claims the vessel is worth nothing due to low crude prices and is producing only 10,000 barrels a day. Bondholders are seeking $70 million in past-due fees, but OGpar's CEO says paying would force the company to shut down. The dispute highlights Brazil's complex and time-consuming legal system, which could tie up creditors' claims for years.

site_title: Vietnam's property market sees rapid turnaround
summary: Vietnam's property market has experienced a rapid turnaround, with construction starting on two of the world's tallest skyscrapers in Ho Chi Minh City and buyers snapping up new projects. Successful transactions have doubled from a year ago, and developers have halved their unsold inventory. The government has relaxed rules on foreign investment, leading to a surge in overseas buyers, with Vingroup holding sales events for foreigners and "Viet Kieu" receiving deposits for 112 apartments in two hours. The market is valued at US$21 billion, with underlying demand driven by Asia's fastest middle-class expansion.

images.alt_text: Apartment buildings under construction near the old residential area of Vinh Tuy village in Hanoi. Developers have halved their unsold inventory from US$6 billion at the peak of the crisis.

site_title: Bears in US pounce on China solar firms as power usage growth slows
summary: US investors are betting on Chinese solar manufacturers as China's power usage growth slows, with traders selling short 22% of JinkoSolar Holding Co's American depositary receipts. China's National Energy Administration expects electricity consumption to rise about 3% this year. This move reflects investors' concerns about the impact of the slowdown on Chinese solar firms.

site_title: Pact between Greece and its creditors deserves a chance
summary: A recent agreement between Greece and its creditors has been met with skepticism, with many predicting Greece's failure and the collapse of the eurozone. However, experts argue that it's premature to make conclusions and that the agreement deserves a chance to take effect. Greece's economy is weak, but it has shown resilience in the past, and the country has the potential to adjust to a more competitive economy. The Greek people will ultimately determine their country's destiny, and casting doubt on their future membership in the EU and eurozone could lead to instability.

site_title: China: undervalued or a bubble?
summary: China's stock market is raising questions about whether it's undervalued or a bubble. Investors should analyze future cash flows to determine their China equity exposure. China has urged Southeast Asian countries to support openness amid US tariffs, while Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a sector revival. China has also introduced new measures to aid employment amid trade tensions. The country's economic future remains uncertain, with investors weighing the risks and potential rewards.

site_title: Report throws light on current trends for energy sector
summary: McKinsey's report predicts the energy sector will shift towards energy services, with coal remaining the top fuel choice in Asia. Distributed generation, digital grids, and new technologies are redefining the power system, allowing customers to opt out of traditional utilities. Coal will continue to grow slowly, while gas will benefit from the shift towards gas-powered vehicles. Solar will grow fast but remain small compared to conventional sources, with photovoltaic installations taking off faster than expected.

site_title: Govt measures to prop up stock market raise PetroChina's volatility
summary: PetroChina's stock price has surged in volatility, with fluctuations reaching 95% of US stocks in the Russell 2000 Index, due to government intervention to prop up the Chinese stock market. The state-linked oil producer's top weighting in the Shanghai Composite Index makes it a target for funds influencing the broader market. Analysts attribute the price distortions to a lack of transparency from authorities about their support measures, leading to speculation and price swings.

site_title: India downplays inflation risk ahead of RBI rate decision
summary: India's Finance Ministry downplays inflation as a primary concern ahead of the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) rate decision on Tuesday. Despite a record divergence between the consumer price index (CPI) and wholesale price index, the ministry believes inflation isn't the country's biggest worry. Economists predict RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan will hold the benchmark interest rate at 7.25% on Tuesday, with most expecting a 25 basis-point cut. The decision comes as investors become less optimistic about Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ability to jump-start India's economy.

site_title: AIG first in S'pore and Asia to cover senior managers against internal probes
summary: AIG Singapore has become the first insurer in Singapore and Asia to offer coverage for senior managers against internal probes, filling a gap in the market. The move comes as the region's market for directors and officers (D&O) liability insurance has grown due to an increasingly litigious climate and more enforcement actions. AIG has seen a 33% increase in gross premiums written for D&O insurance in Singapore over the past two years, with 16% market share of all written policies. This coverage is expected to help protect companies from claims arising from internal investigations.

site_title: Three times unlucky for hapless IMF
summary: Christine Lagarde, IMF managing director, is facing criticism over her handling of Greek debt negotiations. For the third time, IMF staff has disavowed its management over providing loans to Greece, citing unsustainably high debt and shortcomings in reforms. This has cast doubt on her utility in European debt meetings, potentially influencing a decision on her five-year term. German Chancellor Angela Merkel has ruled out further funding unless the IMF participates in new loans, raising concerns of a deal's viability. The IMF's internal divisions may lead to a top-level government decision on Lagarde's renewal.

site_title: China overshadowsAsian markets
summary: China's economic influence continues to overshadow Asian markets, with the country's shares surging on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the stagnant property sector. China has also taken steps to aid employment amid trade tensions, unveiling new measures to support job growth. Meanwhile, the US sees a decline in weekly jobless claims, and Reliance Jio, owned by Indian billionaire Mukesh Ambani, delays its India IPO. These developments indicate a complex economic landscape, with China's influence growing and the US economy showing signs of improvement.

site_title: Lower bus and train fares from December, with opening of Downtown Line 2
summary: Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew announced a 1.9% fare reduction for bus and train fares in Singapore, effective December, to coincide with the opening of Downtown Line 2. The fare adjustment is primarily due to falling fuel prices and aims to make the fare system more accurate. Commuters can expect shorter wait times and less crowded rides in the months ahead, with the Circle Line expected to increase capacity by 60% by mid-2016. The fare reduction will benefit all commuter groups, with SMRT Corporation also offering free travel on National Day, August 9.

site_title: Several major obstacles still in the way of achieving a TPP
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) talks in Hawaii failed to reach a final agreement due to major obstacles, including access to agricultural markets, car trade, and intellectual property protection. The US withdrew its offer of access to its sugar, dairy, and meat markets, citing protection of its cossetted agriculture sector. Intellectual property protection provisions were also a point of contention, with leaked documents suggesting the US aimed to adopt its flawed copyright law globally. Talks will continue, but the US withdrawal has likely dealt a significant blow to the negotiations.

site_title: Chestertons sets up associates arm, targets 300-strong team
summary: Chestertons, a Singapore property firm, has established an associates arm to position itself for a potential market revival when cooling measures are relaxed by mid next year. The associates team, which began setting up in July, currently has 26 members and is expected to grow to 300 by the end of the month, with 70-80 associates joining the team in the coming weeks. This move aims to capitalize on the eventual relaxation of policies.
