Greece committed to implementing pension reforms, including scrapping early retirement and raising the retirement age limit, by the end of October as part of a third bailout deal.

images.alt_text: Greece and its lenders have agreed that new pension reforms will not affect those who were eligible to retire by the end of June, labour ministry officials said on Monday.

site_title: Singapore's PMI falls to 49.7 in July
summary: Singapore's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 49.7 in July, reversing two consecutive months of growth and entering contraction mode. The drop was more than forecast, with economists expecting a reading of 50.1. A reading below 50 indicates a decline in the manufacturing sector.

site_title: Keong Hong unit lands S$107m Raffles Hospital project
summary: Keong Hong Holdings' subsidiary, Keong Hong Construction, has secured a S$107.48 million contract to build a 20-storey medical building for Raffles Hospital Properties. The project, located at Victoria Street/North Bridge Road, will feature two basements and is expected to be completed by August 2017 in two phases.

site_title: Oil falls to near US$50 after Opec monthly supply rise
summary: Oil prices dropped to near US$50 a barrel, the lowest in six months, due to a rise in Opec's monthly supply and concerns over slowing demand in China. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' (Opec) July output reached a record high, while Iran's expected return to the market with 500,000-1 million barrels per day after sanctions are lifted. This, combined with bearish investor sentiment and a slowdown in Chinese manufacturing, has led to a 9% year-to-date decline in oil prices, with Brent crude falling US$1.71 to US$50.50 a barrel.

site_title: US July auto sales see fast start with Fiat Chrysler, Nissan
summary: US auto sales for July exceeded expectations, with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) and Nissan Motor Co. reporting strong gains. FCA's North American unit sold 178,027 vehicles, a 6.2% increase, while Nissan's July US auto sales rose 7.8%, beating estimates. SUVs and pickups drove demand, with FCA's Jeep brand experiencing a 9.7% gain. Industry analysts attribute the surge to cheap lending terms and gasoline prices. FCA's sales-gain streak dates back to 2009, but the company still faces pressure to boost profit and invest in new technologies.

site_title: Americans kept spending in June to end better second quarter
summary: US households continued spending in June, with a 0.2% increase, following a 0.7% gain in May. This capped a stronger quarterly performance for the economy. Incomes rose 0.4% for the third consecutive month. Despite the increase, spending slowed at the end of the quarter, suggesting that stronger wage growth may be needed to boost consumer spending and drive the economy forward.

site_title: Greece unlikely to ask for more ECB liquidity for weeks
summary: Greece is unlikely to request additional emergency funding from the European Central Bank for weeks due to its growing liquidity buffer, which now stands at around 5 billion euros. This increase is attributed to ECB assistance, tax and tourism inflows, and pension payments. Greek banks, which were closed for part of July, rely on ECB emergency liquidity and limit cash withdrawals to 420 euros per week to prevent bank runs. This development reduces pressure on the ECB to provide further assistance to Greece.

site_title: Derivatives market to resume trading: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) announced that its derivatives market will resume trading on Monday night, with a pre-open at 9:30pm, followed by a non-cancel at 9:43pm and trading beginning at 9:45pm. Trading will close as per normal.

site_title: IMF says Western sanctions could cut 9% off Russia's GDP
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that Western sanctions on Russia could cut 9% off its gross domestic product (GDP). The sanctions, imposed in response to the Ukraine crisis, have limited international financing for major Russian banks and energy companies, and high-tech exports to the energy sector. Russia has retaliated with a ban on most Western food imports. The IMF notes that the effects of sanctions will linger, with external access to financial markets and new investment technology affected.

site_title: QT Vascular sets up drug-coating development centre in Singapore
summary: QT Vascular, a medical supplies group, has established a drug-coating development centre in Singapore with the support of the Singapore Economic Development Board. The centre aims to boost research and development efforts in its Chocolate Touch drug-coated angioplasty balloon programme. This move is expected to capitalize on the growing demand for drug-coated balloons, which are rapidly becoming the standard of care for peripheral interventions in Europe and the US, with estimated market values of US$100 million in 2015 and US$600 million in 2018.

site_title: Mauritius joins hunt for MH370 debris
summary: Mauritius has joined the search for debris from Malaysia Airlines' missing flight MH370, following the discovery of wreckage on nearby La Reunion. The country's Deputy Prime Minister, Xavier-Luc Duval, announced that coastguard ships would be deployed to search the Indian Ocean waters. The government is also appealing to private boats and fishermen to report any possible wreckage. Mauritius will undertake every effort to locate any debris, in response to a request from the Malaysian government.

site_title: SGX temporarily suspends derivatives trading
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) temporarily suspended trading on its derivatives market on Monday night due to technical issues. The market was halted at 7:56pm and the exchange stated it is investigating the cause. The suspension is expected to be lifted once the issue is resolved.

site_title: India finance secretary says doesn't wants to curb RBI's powers
summary: India's Finance Secretary Rajiv Mehrishi denied reports that the government is trying to curb the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) powers on monetary policy, following the publication of a draft parliamentary bill that would reduce the central bank's independence. The draft bill proposes changes to the RBI's rate-setting panel and the appointment of its members. Mehrishi stated that the draft bill does not necessarily mean the government is trying to clip the central bank's wings.

site_title: Thailand's AIS Q2 net profit rises 16%, tops forecasts
summary: Thailand's AIS, the country's largest mobile operator, reported a 16% increase in second-quarter net profit to 9.85 billion baht, surpassing forecasts. The company attributed the growth to higher service revenues and lower regulatory costs. AIS now aims for 3% service revenue growth this year, down from its earlier forecast of 3-4%. The company has reduced its investment budget to 36 billion baht from 40 billion baht.

site_title: Sinwa posts 22% rise in Q2 earnings
summary: Sinwa, a marine, offshore supply and logistics player, reported a 22% rise in net profit to S$2.64 million for Q2 2015, driven by growth in customer base and increased sales volume. Revenue rose 7.4% year-over-year to S$40.8 million. The company will pay a special dividend of 2.25 Singapore cents per share, payable on September 3. Despite a bearish outlook in the offshore oil and gas industry, Sinwa plans to focus on its core business and capitalize on opportunities in Thailand.

site_title: Opposition parties meet on Monday night to discuss strategy, avoid three-cornered fights
summary: Singapore's opposition parties met on Monday to discuss strategy and avoid three-cornered fights at the upcoming general election. The meeting, hosted by the National Solidarity Party, brought together leaders of the nine opposition parties, including the Workers' Party, to discuss their strategy and potential alliances. The aim is to prevent a split in the opposition vote and ensure a more unified front against the ruling party.

site_title: French beach returns to public after Saudi royal take-over
summary: A beach in southern France, commandeered by Saudi King Salman for a month-long vacation, has returned to public access after his early departure. Workers dismantled controversial constructions, including an elevator to the king's villa, which were built just two weeks ago. Locals were able to reclaim their beach, with some replanting their parasols as workers completed the restoration. The incident caused uproar among locals, but the beach is now back to normal.

site_title: HSBC sets aside US$1.3b for currency-manipulation penalties
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc has set aside US$1.3 billion to cover penalties for its involvement in the manipulation of benchmark foreign-exchange rates. The bank has faced investigations by the US Department of Justice, Federal Reserve Bank, and other authorities worldwide. This marks the latest in a series of penalties, which have surpassed US$10 billion, with fines varying widely among banks. The ultimate financial impact of these matters remains uncertain due to ongoing investigations.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 21.05 points to close at 1,744.19 on Monday, driven by gains in 324 stocks. Despite 465 losers, the market ended higher with 1.32 billion lots valued at RM1.25 billion traded.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: Noble Group reported sufficient cash and liquidity to fund bond redemption and operations, with net fair value gains falling in the second quarter. Ascott led a S$120m investment in online apartment sharing platform Tujia. The Singapore High Court dismissed an interim injunction against F&N in a Myanmar brewery dispute. The Singapore Exchange introduced evaluated bond prices. The Straits Times Index closed 0.30% lower, following China and Hong Kong stock weakness, and penny stocks' rally lost steam.

site_title: Malaysia investigators meet with French officials on MH370
summary: Malaysian investigators met with French officials in Paris to discuss the latest developments on the missing MH370 airliner. The five-man team, led by Azharuddin Abdul Rahman, arrived at the Palais de Justice for talks with the French investigation team, including a judge, experts, and police. The meeting comes after a piece of airplane debris, confirmed to be a Boeing 777 flaperon, washed up on the French island of La Reunion in the Indian Ocean. The investigation, led by France, aims to shed light on the disappearance of the plane in March 2014, with all 239 people on board presumed dead.

site_title: Notting Hill is worst performer in London's luxury-home market
summary: Notting Hill experienced the largest decline in London's luxury-home market, with prices falling 3.8% over the past 12 months. This decline is attributed to a slowdown in demand due to increased sales tax on high-end homes. Other areas, such as Chelsea and Kensington, also saw price drops, with Kensington experiencing a 0.9% decrease. The City of London and its fringe neighborhoods were the only areas to see growth, with values increasing 6.6% over the period. This marks a significant slowdown in the UK capital's luxury property market.

site_title: Chinese factories face headwinds in July, Europe withstands Greek turmoil
summary: Chinese factories faced the weakest level of conditions in two years in July, with a private survey showing a 47.8 Caixin/Markit China Manufacturing PMI, down from 49.4 in June. This, coupled with similar weak surveys for Taiwan, South Korea, and Indonesia, raises concerns about a global recovery in the second half of the year. In contrast, European manufacturing activity showed resilience, with the Eurozone PMI at 52.4, while the US is set to release its PMI later in the week.

images.alt_text: Economic headwinds facing Chinese manufacturers intensified last month, with conditions deteriorating to their weakest level in two years, while euro zone factories largely shrugged off Greece's brush with bankruptcy.

site_title: Greece: Among stock market falls, some Greek listings outperform
summary: Greece's stock market plummeted 18% mid-session on Monday, but some listings outperformed, suffering smaller losses. Shares of OTE Telecom, Aegean Airlines, and Motor Oil fell 11-17%, while Kordellou rose 4.7%. Analysts see buying opportunities in quality names, citing brighter prospects for non-financial companies like Folli Follie and Mytilineos, which generate most of their revenue abroad and have strong cash positions.

site_title: Malaysia says about US$700 million in Najib accounts are donations
summary: Malaysia's anti-corruption commission has concluded an investigation into Prime Minister Najib Razak's personal accounts, finding approximately US$675 million in donations, not from a debt-ridden state investment company. The probe was conducted transparently and professionally, but the source of the donations remains unknown. This development comes amid Najib's biggest crisis in six years, following the removal of his deputy prime minister and the replacement of the attorney general. The investigation is part of a broader probe into the 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) scandal.

site_title: HSBC sees China economy growing 7% this year despite sell-off
summary: HSBC predicts China's economy will grow 7% this year despite a recent stock market sell-off, citing a jump in wealth management and equities revenues in the first half. The bank's CEO, Stuart Gulliver, believes the sell-off will have a limited impact on revenues. Despite this, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Exor signs definite agreement to buy PartnerRe for US$6.9 billion
summary: Exor, an Italian holding company, signed a definitive agreement to buy reinsurer PartnerRe for $6.9 billion, surpassing a rival bid from Axis Capital Holdings. Exor will pay $137.50 for each PartnerRe share and offer a $3 special dividend per share. The deal ends a prolonged battle for PartnerRe, which had previously agreed to merge with Axis but canceled the agreement after Exor's bid.

site_title: Western companies look hard at China as growth slows
summary: Western companies are reassessing their investments in China due to the country's slowing growth, with many reducing investments, costs, and product lines. The slowdown has led to declining demand, raising concerns about the financial health of Chinese companies. Companies are adapting by cutting production, reducing costs, and focusing on profitability. Some are also reviewing their product lines and credit risks, while others are looking to snap up local companies cheaply. Despite the challenges, executives remain optimistic about China's long-term growth potential.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker in line with China, HK; penny-stock rally loses steam
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.30% to 3,192.79 on Monday, following China and Hong Kong's weakness. The rally in penny stocks, which peaked at an average value of S$0.76, showed signs of strain. Brokers attributed the decline to speculative interest and lack of retail investor participation. China's Caixin China PMI for July dropped to a two-year low, further exacerbating the market's decline. The decline marks a reversal of the market's 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Bus, train fares to be cut by up to 1.9% by year-end: Minister Lui Tuck Yew
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew announced a 1.9% reduction in bus and train fares by year-end, citing reduced fuel costs. The fare cuts are expected to benefit commuters, with the price decrease ranging from 10 cents to 30 cents. The move is seen as a cost-saving measure to help commuters cope with rising living costs.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index ends 0.18% lower after weak China data
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index fell 0.18% to 20,548.11, following weak Chinese manufacturing data and US earnings. However, Honda's shares rose after reporting surged profits. The Topix index remained flat.

site_title: Beijing to limit cars, factories to ensure clean air for war anniversary
summary: Beijing will limit the number of vehicles on the streets and shut factories to ensure clean air during a military parade commemorating the 70th anniversary of the end of World War Two. From August 20 to September 3, the city will halve the number of vehicles allowed, restricting them by licence plate numbers, and impose temporary controls on industry, coal-burning boilers, and construction. This move aims to protect air quality, drawing from experience gained during the 2008 Olympic Games and a meeting of Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation leaders last year.

site_title: Thai election could be delayed to 2017 if charter rejected: minister
summary: Thailand's general election could be delayed to April 2017 if the newly drafted constitution is rejected by a national reform assembly. The military government initially aimed for an election in late 2015 but now seeks more time for reforms. The US and other allies want democracy restored quickly, but a delay is possible if proposed reforms meet opposition.

site_title: CWT posts 14% drop in Q2 profit
summary: CWT, a logistics provider, reported a 14% drop in Q2 net profit to S$26.2 million, mainly due to a decline in commodity logistics volume and trade services. Revenue fell 45% to S$2 billion, while gross profit dropped 16% to S$75.5 million. The company approved an interim net cash dividend of S$0.03 per share. Net asset value per share rose 14% to 132.3 Singapore cents.

site_title: HK regulator fines BNP Paribas US$1.9m for "dark pool" trading
summary: The Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission fined BNP Paribas HK$15 million for failing to execute orders based on price priority for almost 1-1/2 years on its "dark pool" trading platform, known as BNP Internal Exchange. The firm also failed to inform the regulator it had stopped operations for seven months and did not maintain proper trading records. This fine comes as the SFC has barred operators of off-exchange share trading platforms from accepting trades from retail investors.

site_title: Ringgit drops most in four weeks as factory PMI clouds outlook
summary: The Malaysian ringgit dropped to a 16-year low, weakening by the most in four weeks, due to data showing a contraction in factory output and falling oil prices. The Nikkei Malaysia Purchasing Managers' Index and a Chinese index both signaled a contraction, dimming the outlook for the economy. Bank Negara Malaysia is discouraging transactions that would result in selling the ringgit, fueling speculation that the central bank is buying the currency to stem losses.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB says upcoming hearings with PAC postponed
summary: Malaysia's state fund 1MDB has postponed upcoming hearings with the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) due to a notification by the finance ministry. The hearings, initially scheduled for August 4-10, have been rescheduled to be determined later. The decision comes after the PAC chairman was appointed a new deputy home minister, putting a Malaysian parliamentary investigation into a graft scandal at 1MDB on hold.

site_title: China wants no talk of South China Sea at upcoming Asean meeting
summary: Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Liu Zhenmin urged the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) to avoid discussing the disputed South China Sea at their meeting, citing it as a sensitive issue that should not be discussed in the forum. The US is expected to repeat its call for China to halt land reclamation on islands in the disputed waters. China claims most of the South China Sea and has stepped up construction of artificial islands, prompting US criticism and regional alarm.

site_title: Australia: Shares weighed down by China factory survey
summary: Australian shares declined 0.35% on Monday following a weaker-than-expected factory survey in China, the country's largest trading partner. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 19.864 points to 5679.300. This marks the benchmark's first monthly gain since February.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall on China survey, HSBC up after H1 results
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng index fell 0.9% to close at 24,411.42 points on Monday, tracking China's weak factory activity. HSBC rose 1.9% after beating earnings expectations, its largest gain since July 9. Despite this, analysts expect major earnings reports from Hong Kong companies. China shares fell, with Shanghai shares down 1.1% and some investors staying on the sidelines after mainland stocks suffered their worst monthly loss in six years.

site_title: Malaysia's Maybank starts branch operations in Myanmar
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank), Malaysia's largest bank, has commenced branch operations in Myanmar, becoming the first and only Malaysian bank to open a branch in the country. This move comes after the government granted licenses to nine foreign banks, including Maybank, in October to bring in foreign capital to Myanmar's growing economy.

site_title: Greek factory output collapses in July as banks close
summary: Greek factory output plummeted in July, reaching its lowest level in 16 years, due to a bank shutdown and capital controls. The manufacturing sector's purchasing managers' index (PMI) fell to 30.2 points, the lowest reading since 1999, as new orders and purchasing activity declined. The bank shutdown and restrictions on money transfers abroad led to longer delivery times and forced manufacturers to cut jobs. The collapse of manufacturing output sends a worrying signal for the overall health of Greece's economy.

images.alt_text: Greek manufacturing activity plunged in July to the lowest level on records going back 16 years due to a dive in new orders and serious supply problems caused by a three-week bank shutdown, a survey showed on Monday.

site_title: Bitcoin exchange CEO manipulated data dozens of times: media
summary: MtGox CEO Mark Karpeles manipulated the exchange's computer system at least 30 times between 2011 and 2013, according to a report by Japan's Yomiuri newspaper. The alleged data manipulation and fund transfers were made by Karpeles, 30, who was arrested by Tokyo police on Saturday. The report follows the collapse of the once-dominant exchange in 2013 due to fraud allegations. Tokyo has promised greater efforts to regulate the digital currency industry, amid the fresh allegations against Karpeles.

site_title: Eurozone factory growth steady in July despite Greek turmoil
summary: Eurozone factory activity grew faster than expected in July, easing only slightly from June's record pace, despite Greece's turmoil. The country's survey showed its steepest downturn in 16 years. Meanwhile, other Eurozone countries like the Netherlands, Spain, and Italy enjoyed healthy growth, with Spain's expansion being its strongest in over four years. This data is likely to reassure European Central Bank policymakers, who will see the robust growth rates in the manufacturing sector and the resilience of the sector as growth is expected to pick up again following Greece's debt crisis hurdle.

site_title: Plane debris raises hopes about MH370, without resolution
summary: A piece of a Boeing 777 plane, believed to be from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, was found on Reunion island. The discovery has raised hopes that the missing plane may have survived. However, loved ones of the passengers, including the mother of the article's author, remain anxious and prefer the possibility that the survivors are still alive. The finding has sparked a renewed sense of hope, but no concrete resolution has been reached. The discovery has sparked mixed emotions among those affected by the disappearance.

site_title: UK manufacturing growth edges up, still dragging on economy: survey
summary: UK manufacturing growth increased to 51.9 in July, a rise from 51.4 in June, but still below the average of 54.3 since 2013. New orders grew at the slowest pace in nearly a year, at 52.2. This suggests the factory sector is continuing to drag on overall economic growth, with policymakers facing a challenge to achieve balanced long-term growth.

site_title: Oil CEOs' grim outlook rubs off on speculators fleeing market
summary: The world's largest oil companies, including BP, Royal Dutch Shell, and Exxon Mobil, have painted a grim picture of the future, predicting lower oil prices for longer. Hedge funds have reduced bullish bets to the lowest level in five years, and oil prices have dropped 4.7% to $47.98 a barrel. Industry leaders report their worst earnings in years, with supply outpacing demand by 1 million barrels a day through 2016. The US energy sector is preparing for a prolonged downturn, with thousands of job cuts announced in recent weeks.

site_title: Barnacles on debris could provide clues to missing MH370: experts
summary: A piece of plane debris, identified as a 2-2.5 meter wing surface from a Boeing 777, has washed up on the French island of Reunion, sparking hopes that it may hold clues to the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370. The debris is believed to have originated from the southern Indian Ocean, where MH370 is thought to have crashed. Experts are analyzing the debris, including barnacles encrusted on it, to determine whether it came from MH370. The investigation is expected to conclude by Wednesday.

site_title: German manufacturing sector posts modest growth at start of third quarter: PMI
summary: German manufacturing activity rose slightly for the eighth straight month in July, with a PMI of 51.8, above the 50 line separating growth from contraction. Factory output increased for a 27th straight month, but at a marginally weaker rate than in June. New orders from abroad fell for the first time in six months, while manufacturers raised selling prices to compensate for higher costs. This suggests that Germany's deflationary territory was only temporary, according to economist Oliver Kolodseike.

site_title: China: Stocks fall on weak factory activity, some investors stay away
summary: China's Shanghai shares fell 1.1% on Monday, ending at 3,622.99 points, due to weak factory activity and investor caution. A private survey showed China's factory activity shrank more than initially estimated in July, contracting by the most in two years. The CSI300 index rose 0.33% in late trade, while some investors avoided the market after mainland stocks suffered their worst monthly loss in six years in July. China's markets regulator also suspended a trading account of US-based hedge fund Citadel LLC.

site_title: French manufacturing activity shrinks in July: PMI
summary: French manufacturing activity shrank in July, with Markit's purchasing managers index falling to 49.6, below the 50-point threshold. The sector saw declines in output, new orders, employment, and stock levels, driven by weak demand. This marks the first time the index has fallen below 50 since January 2009. The contraction was the fastest rate since April, with firms cutting staff levels for the 16th consecutive month. The data suggests the economic recovery in France remains fragile.

site_title: Greece: Stock market opens 23% down after five week shutdown
summary: Greece's stock market opened 23% down on Monday after a five-week shutdown under capital controls. The National Bank of Greece, the country's largest commercial bank, plummeted 30% in early trading. The bourse was last open for trading on June 26. The market's decline is attributed to the government's efforts to stop a flight of euros from the country.

site_title: Thai central bank seen holding key rate on Wednesday
summary: Thailand's central bank is expected to hold its policy interest rate steady at 1.50% on Wednesday, according to a Reuters poll of 23 economists. Finance Minister Sommai Phasee previously stated that lower interest rates would not help the economy, citing weak investment. The bank cut its growth forecast to 3.0% for 2015, down from 3.8%, amid a weaker baht and sagging exports. The decision comes as Thailand's economy struggles to regain traction after the 2014 military coup.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady, Greek markets set to reopen
summary: European shares were steady on Monday, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index rising 0.3% and the Euro STOXX 50 index flat. HSBC and Commerzbank shares advanced after reporting higher profits, while mining stocks fell due to weak Chinese economic data. The Greek stock market is set to reopen on Monday, with some traders expecting steep losses.

site_title: Gold holds gains as Barclays sees bets on lower prices halting
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,096.29 following a second consecutive week of net-short positions by money managers, sparking speculation of potential short-covering rallies. Despite the price decline, analysts at Barclays see elevated bearish sentiment but note that extreme levels of positions may lead to a bullish risk for gold in the short term. The Federal Reserve's next interest rate announcement on September 17 is expected to influence gold prices, with investors watching for signs of a strong economy to justify rate hikes.

site_title: Greece's economic sentiment dives in July: IOBE think tank
summary: Greece's economic sentiment dropped to 81.3 points in July, its lowest level in almost three years, due to banking restrictions and political uncertainty following a July 5 referendum. The country's capital controls were imposed to prevent bank collapse and widespread uncertainty. This is the result of unfavourable economic developments following the referendum and a wide political uncertainty.

site_title: Britain cuts Lloyds banking group stake below 14%
summary: Britain has reduced its stake in Lloyds Banking Group to below 14%, with the taxpayer's stake now at 13.99%. This comes after Lloyds was rescued at a cost of 20.5 billion pounds to taxpayers during the 2007-9 financial crisis.

site_title: China freezes US fund Citadel's account in war on stock speculation
summary: China's markets regulator has frozen a trading account linked to US group Citadel Securities, amid a government-orchestrated campaign to prop up China's ailing stock markets. The Shanghai and Shenzhen markets have tumbled 30% since mid-June, and the regulator has declared war on "malicious" short selling. The move follows concerns over China's slowing economy and its impact on the global markets. China's markets regulator has been at the forefront of a government-orchestrated campaign to prevent a meltdown in the two main stock markets.

site_title: MH370 investigators to meet in France ahead of wing analysis
summary: Malaysian investigators are meeting in France to coordinate the investigation into missing flight MH370, which disappeared in 2014. A two-metre long flaperon from the Boeing 777 has been found on the French Indian Ocean island of La Reunion, and experts will analyze it to determine its origin. The analysis may provide clues, but experts warn that it may not be conclusive and that finding other debris is unlikely due to the vast distance. The investigation has reopened wounds for the families of the 239 people on board, who are seeking closure.

site_title: Oil hits multi-month lows on record Opec output
summary: Oil prices hit multi-month lows on August 3, 2015, due to record Opec output and concerns about oversupply. Opec's July output reached its highest monthly level in recent history, with Saudi Arabia and other key members prioritizing market share over prices. Iran's planned output increase of 500,000-1 million barrels per day also fueled supply worries. As a result, Brent fell to $51.71 a barrel and US crude fell to $46.73 a barrel, marking the longest weekly losing streak since late 2014.

site_title: Japan calls US spying allegations 'deeply regrettable'
summary: Japan has described US spying allegations as "deeply regrettable", according to the country's top spokesman Yoshihide Suga. The allegations, made by whistleblower group WikiLeaks, claim that Washington spied on Japanese politicians and major firms. Tokyo is checking with the US on the report, issued on Friday, and views the claims as a serious breach of trust between allies.

site_title: To see where euro's headed, take a look at where dollar has been
summary: The euro is expected to follow a similar path to the dollar, with a decline in value this year due to policy divergence between the US and Europe. The European Central Bank's cheap money policies will continue until late 2016, while the Federal Reserve prepares to raise interest rates, making euros cheaper to borrow. As companies repay debt, this will unleash demand for euros, potentially supporting the currency in the long term. Forecasts predict the euro will fall to $1.05 by the end of 2015, before recovering to $1.11 by 2017.

site_title: DBS strengthens transaction banking with senior management appointment
summary: DBS Bank has appointed Iain Taylor as its global transaction services chief operating officer, effective September 15. Taylor, currently head of transaction banking at ASB Bank, will lead the business to execute its growth plans. Under his leadership, the business has doubled in the past three years. DBS aims to make transaction banking a key growth driver, and Taylor's appointment is seen as a strategic move to achieve this goal.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Nokia selling mapping service Here to German car makers for 2.8b euros
summary: Nokia is selling its mapping service Here to German car makers BMW, Audi, and Mercedes-Benz for 2.8 billion euros, a deal expected to be finalized in the first quarter of 2016. Here, a competitor to Google Maps, was previously bought by Nokia from US tech company Navteq for $8.1 billion in 2008. The sale will bring Nokia a profit of 2.5 billion euros and will be approved by competition authorities. The car makers will hold equal shares in Here, ensuring it remains an "open, independent, and creative platform."

site_title: Greece: Blue chip stock index futures open down 15.2%
summary: Greece's blue-chip stock index futures opened down 15.2% on Monday, August 3, 2015, ahead of the market's reopening after a five-week shutdown. The index is down 18% at 202 points, due to capital controls imposed to stem a debilitating outflow of euros. The Athens bourse will open for trade on Monday at 0730 GMT.

images.alt_text: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index gaining 0.43 per cent to 6,579.08 points.

site_title: SGX continues to monitor Noble, notes plans for additional disclosure
summary: SGX continues to monitor Noble Group, a troubled commodities firm, following unusual trading on July 30. Noble announced plans to provide additional disclosures, including Yancoal valuation and inventory sales, to address market speculations and allegations of manipulation. The company also confirmed its ability to fund a US$735 million bond redemption and disclosed satisfactory Q2 performance. SGX stands ready to take action against any market misconduct and will work with authorities as needed.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Rescuers in Myanmar struggle to reach flood-hit areas, toll seen rising
summary: Myanmar's flooding has affected over 150,000 people, with a death toll expected to rise to several hundred in Rakhine State. The disaster, caused by weeks of torrential monsoon rains, has destroyed over 700 houses in neighboring Chin State and damaged more than 970,000 acres of farmland. Rescuers struggle to reach remote areas, with the Myanmar Red Cross Society reporting difficulties in mobilizing volunteers due to the widespread nature of the flooding. The government has responded more proactively than in 2008, with President Thein Sein and the military chief visiting affected regions.

site_title: Gold extends weakness after worst month in 2 years
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to US$1,093.90 an ounce, nearing a 5-1/2-year low, due to expectations of a near-term US interest rate hike, which could lead to a further decline in the non-interest yielding metal. The metal lost 7% in July, its deepest monthly fall since June 2013, and is expected to trade between US$1,050 and US$1,131 through the month. A strong US nonfarm payrolls report could lead to further weakness for gold.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down 1.57% at open
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 1.57% at the open on Monday, August 3, 2015, following a weekend announcement that manufacturing activity in mainland China slowed in July. The Hang Seng Index dropped 386.54 points to 24,249.54.

site_title: Apple pushed down to 3rd in China smartphones for Q2
summary: Apple dropped to third place in China's smartphone market for the second quarter, with Xiaomi and Huawei taking the top spots. Xiaomi led with a 15.9% market share, followed by Huawei at 15.7%. Apple's iPhone sales surged 85% in Greater China, but the company's global ranking was affected by increased competition. Analyst Wang Jingwen said Xiaomi faces pressure to maintain its top position, while Huawei is targeting Samsung in the mid- to high-end market.

site_title: Macau's gambling revenue drops 34.5% in July
summary: Macau's gambling revenue plummeted 34.5% in July, reaching 18.6 billion patacas, as wealthy Chinese punters stayed away due to a government crackdown on corruption. The decline is narrower than the 36% drop in June and is in line with analyst estimates. VIP customers, a major contributor to gaming revenues, have also stayed away. The decline has pressured gaming stocks, with some falling between 10% and 28% this year. Analysts expect revenues to improve in the second half of the year with the opening of Melco's Studio City integrated resort.

site_title: Taiwan's July PMI shrinks for 4th month as export orders slide
summary: Taiwan's manufacturing sector saw a contraction in July, with the PMI shrinking for the fourth consecutive month. New export orders fell to a 34-month low at 43.2, and total new business and new export work declined sharply. Weaker demand in key export markets, such as China, Europe, and the US, was cited as a major contributor. Deflationary pressures intensified, with input prices and output charges falling at faster rates. The data suggests a global economic slowdown will continue to impact Taiwan's growth in the second half of the year.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks tumble as economic woes hit tech firms
summary: Taiwan's stocks plummeted 1.9% on Monday as semiconductor firms, including TSMC and Mediatek, were hit by a worsening economic outlook. The country reported its lowest quarterly economic growth in three years, with exports taking a toll on tech manufacturers. The electronics subindex fell 2.3%, while the semiconductor subindex dropped 3.2%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.609 per US dollar.

site_title: China: Stocks fall at market open
summary: China's major stock indexes opened down on Monday, with the CSI300 index falling 1.2% to 3,772.53 points and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 1.4% to 3,612.93 points. The Hang Seng index in Hong Kong also declined 1.6% to 24,251.35 points.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall 1.1% to near 5-mth closing low; won trims gains
summary: South Korean shares fell 1.1% to near a five-month closing low on Monday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ending at 2,008.49 points. The drop was attributed to weak China factory activity and slumping oil prices, which pressured chemical and refinery firms. The won, however, trimmed its gains, closing at 1,165.9 per dollar, up 0.4% from the previous day's close.

site_title: China's island-building faces scrutiny at Asia security talks
summary: China is facing pressure at Asian security talks over its island-building in the South China Sea, where it is expanding tiny reefs into islands and topping some with military posts to reinforce its disputed claims. The move has fueled fears of a regional arms race and possible conflict. The talks in Kuala Lumpur will also address human-trafficking issues in Southeast Asia and concerns over North Korean missile launches. The discussions come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Indonesia manufacturing activity contracts for 10th month in July: PMI
summary: Indonesia's manufacturing activity contracted for the 10th consecutive month in July, according to a private survey, with new orders declining due to weak economic growth and falling customer confidence. The Nikkei/Markit purchasing manager's index (PMI) fell to 47.3, below the 50 level separating contraction from expansion. The decline in manufacturing activity raises prospects for a central bank interest rate cut in coming months, as Indonesia's economy continues to struggle with high inflation and a fragile rupiah currency.

site_title: Oil prices languish as supply concerns linger
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia on Monday due to concerns about the global supply glut, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropping 36 cents to $46.76 and Brent crude easing 42 cents to $51.79. The OPEC cartel, led by Saudi Arabia, indicated it would not cut output despite a growing global glut, citing its determination to defend market share. The US dollar's strength also dampened demand, with analysts predicting key economic data releases this week will set the tone for crude oil prices.

site_title: HSBC's H1 profits rise 10% on bumper Hong Kong results
summary: HSBC Holdings reported a 10% increase in H1 profits to $13.6 billion, driven by strong results in Hong Kong. The bank also announced the sale of its Brazil unit to Banco Bradesco SA for $7.1 billion. HSBC is considering moving its headquarters from London to Hong Kong, which could boost profits further. The sale of its Brazil unit is part of HSBC's efforts to cut underperforming businesses.

site_title: Bonvests Holdings to buy hotel for A$91.5 million
summary: Bonvests Holdings has agreed to acquire the Four Points by Sheraton Perth hotel in Australia for A$91.5 million. The 4.5-star hotel, built in 1985, features 278 rooms and is managed by Starwood until 2027. The acquisition is expected to be funded by bank borrowings. The hotel is currently owned by HHR Perth Trust and will be acquired through the purchase of all issued shares.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Inflation remains high in Indonesia despite forecast easing
summary: Indonesia's inflation remained high at 7.26% in July, unchanged from the previous month, as consumers stockpiled food and transport tickets ahead of the Eid holiday. This defied Bank Indonesia's forecast of a 7.13% increase. The country's central bank had expected inflation to ease after Eid, but the data showed no change.

site_title: Indian factory growth bucks Asia trend, speeds to 6-month high in July: PMI
summary: Indian manufacturing activity expanded at its fastest pace in six months in July, according to a business survey, with the Nikkei Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 52.7. This growth bucked a weakness seen across much of Asia and was driven by stronger increases in new orders and output, as well as a quick expansion in export orders. Firms resisted passing on higher raw material costs to customers, which will be good news for the Reserve Bank of India ahead of its next policy review.

site_title: Foreigners flee Thai stocks as patience wanes over pledges
summary: Foreign investors are selling Thai stocks at the fastest pace this year, with a net US$774 million in July. The benchmark SET Index fell 4.3% amid concerns over falling exports, weak corporate earnings, and manufacturing contraction. Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha's failure to deliver on infrastructure investments has disappointed investors. The baht is trading near its weakest level in six years, and the selloff suggests international money managers are losing patience with Thailand's economic growth.

site_title: Singapore's water supply from Malaysia reaches critical levels
summary: Singapore's water supply from Malaysia is at a critical point, with the country relying on the Johor River for 60% of its water needs, approximately 250 million gallons per day. Minister for the Environment and Water Resources Vivian Balakrishnan has urged Singaporeans to conserve water use. This comes after Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May, below forecast. The situation highlights the need for Singapore to find alternative sources of water and reduce its dependence on Malaysia's supply.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 7.19 points to 1,715.95. The index saw 40.83 million lots traded worth RM16.94 million, with 108 gainers and 85 losers. This follows a global trend as stocks rally ahead of GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Asia: Stocks near 2015 lows on China economy worry, dollar strong
summary: Asian stocks fell near 2015 lows due to concerns over China's slowing economy and a strong US dollar. China's factory activity contracted more than initially estimated, while commodities like crude oil and copper plummeted. The dollar has risen 7.75% this year, posing a headwind for emerging markets. Net foreign selling from emerging Asia reached nearly $10 billion over the past two months, with valuations suggesting more downside for stock markets.

site_title: Tsipras battling on all sides finds no solace in Greek economy
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras faces significant challenges in reviving the country's economy, which is struggling with high unemployment, deflation, and manufacturing shrinkage. The economy is expected to contract by up to 4% this year, with capital controls and austerity measures exacerbating the situation. International creditors are pressing for further reforms, while economists predict a prolonged recession and limited job growth, despite some optimism about a potential recovery in late 2015.

site_title: Hacked Jeep Cherokee exposes weak underbelly of high-tech cars
summary: Hackers exposed vulnerabilities in the Jeep Cherokee's wireless network, which allows modern cars to access key features like driving directions and restaurant guides. The hack, conducted by Charlie Miller and Chris Valasek, demonstrated how cars can be controlled remotely via Sprint's network, forcing Fiat Chrysler to recall 1.4 million vehicles. Sprint pushed out a network-level fix to block the attack, but the researchers found alternative methods to access the Jeep. Automakers and telecom companies are working on cybersecurity measures, including the development of anti-hacking systems and "kill switches" to remove malicious software from devices.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.37% higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.37% to 3,214.29 on Monday, with 51.4 million shares changing hands. The rally follows a 5-day streak, ahead of GDP data. Regional shares fell, with Asia-Pacific slipping 0.2%, Japan's Nikkei down 0.2%, and South Korea's Kospi losing 0.5%.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Hot stock: Noble rebounds on potential financings, strategic investment options
summary: Noble Group's shares rebounded 2.20% on Monday after the company disclosed it has been approached by several parties for potential financings and strategic investment options. The company's second-quarter results are set for Aug 10, and it assured investors that it has ample funds to redeem its US$735 million bond on Aug 4. Noble's shares opened at S$0.475 and traded at S$0.465, with over 40 million shares exchanged. The news triggered short-covering, according to a broker.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: SGX introduces evaluated bond prices
summary: SGX introduces evaluated bond prices on its website, providing independent evaluations of listed debt securities. The evaluated prices are computed by Interactive Data Corporation and complement information from issuers available on SGX's website. The move aims to enhance transparency and efficiency in the debt securities market, particularly in Asia, where demand for fixed income is expected to grow due to economic growth and infrastructure needs. The evaluated bond prices will benefit both issuers and investors, providing a reference point for their assessment of debt securities.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced evaluated bond prices on its website to provide public access to independent evaluations of SGX-listed debt securities.

site_title: Oil drops for 5th week; US crude in biggest monthly fall since 2008
summary: US crude oil prices dropped for the 5th consecutive week, posting its largest monthly decline since 2008. The decline was triggered by China's stock market slump and record oil production from top Middle East producers. A higher US oil rig count also contributed to the market's downturn. Despite a weaker dollar, heavy hedging activity in gasoline and diesel futures overshadowed crude oil. The decline was also linked to bearish market expectations due to President Trump's tariff announcements.

site_title: China final Caixin manufacturing PMI falls to 2-year low of 47.8 in July
summary: China's factory activity shrank more than initially estimated in July, contracting by the most in two years with a final Caixin/Markit China Manufacturing PMI of 47.8, the lowest since July 2013. This marks the fifth straight month of contraction, with new orders falling and factory output shrinking for the third consecutive month. The weaker-than-expected readings are expected to stoke expectations of more economic support measures, as Beijing struggles to avert a stock market slump and slow China's GDP growth.

site_title: High Court dismisses interim injunction against F&N in Myanmar brewery dispute
summary: The Singapore High Court dismissed an interim injunction against Fraser & Neave (F&N) in a dispute over its stake in a Myanmar brewery. F&N's joint venture partner, Myanma Economic Holdings (MEHL), had sought to require F&N to sell its 55% stake in the brewery for $540 million. However, F&N disputed the valuation, citing a 2013 exchange rate that estimated the stake's fair value at $560 million. The court dismissed the injunction, with F&N to retain its stake in the brewery.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Ringgit falls to 16-year low as China data dims exports outlook
summary: The Malaysian ringgit fell to a 16-year low amid contractions in factory output in Malaysia and China, dimming the outlook for the Southeast Asian economy. The Nikkei Malaysia Purchasing Managers' Index and China's PMI both signaled contractions, while exports are expected to shrink again in June. The ringgit weakened 0.2% to 3.8323 a dollar, and 10-year government bonds rose two basis points to 4.09%. The economic pressure is linked to China's struggling growth and the lower oil price, raising concerns for Malaysia's exports.

images.alt_text: The ringgit fell for a third day amid contractions in Malaysian and Chinese factory output, dimming the outlook for the Southeast Asian economy that's under pressure from a slump in oil.

site_title: South Korea July factory PMI up but activity contracts for 5th mth
summary: South Korea's manufacturing activity contracted for a fifth consecutive month in July, according to a private-sector survey, with the Nikkei/Markit purchasing managers' index (PMI) at 47.6. This is the lowest reading since September 2012, coinciding with the MERS outbreak. New export orders barely budged, and local manufacturers cut back on employment, highlighting the economy's continued weakness due to sluggish global demand and domestic consumption.

site_title: Noble to unveil Q2 results, PwC report earlier on Aug 10 to address allegations
summary: NOBLE Group said it's not aware of financial or material business issues causing its recent share price decline and volatility. The company will unveil its Q2 results and PwC assurance report earlier to address allegations of misleading information. The results will be published on Aug 10, a public holiday in Singapore, along with additional disclosures on Yancoal valuation and inventory sales. This move aims to address allegations and provide key information to market participants.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Australia city home prices jump 2.8% in July: RPData
summary: Home prices in Australia's capital cities surged 2.8% in July, driven by strong demand in Sydney and Melbourne. Annual growth in home values reached 11.1%, with Sydney and Melbourne accounting for most of the strength. Prices rose 3.3% in Sydney and 4.9% in Melbourne, while other cities experienced declines. Regulators have tightened lending standards, but credit growth remains high, fueling pressure on policymakers to hold interest rates steady. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to maintain rates at 2% in its upcoming policy meeting.

site_title: Ascott leads consortium to invest over S$120m in online apartment sharing platform, forms tech council (Amended)
summary: Ascott, a CapitaLand unit, is leading a consortium to invest S$67.69 million in Tujia, a Chinese online apartment sharing platform. The investment will also form a joint venture with Tujia, with Ascott operating serviced apartments in China under a new brand. As part of this, Ascott aims to expand its portfolio in China to 20,000 units by 2020. CapitaLand has also formed a Technology Council to boost its digital efforts, with notable tech visionaries joining to drive its real estate business towards smart communities and seamless online-offline experiences.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Japan July final manufacturing PMI at 5-month high of 51.2, suggests some Q3 recovery
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity expanded at a 5-month high of 51.2 in July, suggesting some recovery in the third quarter after an expected second-quarter slump. The Markit/Nikkei Japan Manufacturing PMI index remained above the 50 threshold for the third consecutive month. New orders and output growth picked up, but export orders fell due to China's economic slowdown. The economy is expected to grow 0.7% in April-June and 2.0% in the current quarter, but concerns remain about the strength of the recovery due to disappointing consumer spending.

site_title: Australia inflation gauge stays tame in July: TDMI
summary: Australia's private-sector inflation gauge rose 0.2% in July, exceeding the 0.1% increase in June, but remained below the Reserve Bank of Australia's 2-3% target. The annual pace ticked up to 1.6%, supporting the expectation of a rate cut if needed. The central bank is likely to keep rates steady at 2% after cutting to an all-time low in May, according to analysts.

site_title: China's manufacturing weakens in July
summary: China's manufacturing sector weakened in July, with both official and Caixin Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 15-month and 15-month lows, respectively. Analysts attribute the decline to weak external and domestic demand, as well as volatile equity markets. The government is expected to implement further measures to support the economy, including credit easing and investment, to stabilize growth. The non-manufacturing PMI, however, remained upbeat at 53.9.

site_title: No plane link to new debris in island hunt for MH370 clues
summary: Malaysia Airlines' missing flight MH370 search on La Reunion island yielded no new clues after locals found metallic debris believed to be from a Boeing 777 wing. Authorities in the Indian Ocean region are still on high alert for potential debris washing ashore. The discovery raised hopes that the wing part could help solve the aviation mystery, but no conclusive findings were made.

site_title: Meet China's stock rescue chief: he never saw the crisis coming
summary: China's state agency, China Securities Finance Corp, was given a $400 billion bailout fund to rescue the stock market after a June crash. The agency, headed by 53-year-old academic Nie Qingping, has been buying stocks and mutual funds since July 6, but its success is unclear. Nie, a professor with 25 years of experience, was blindsided by the crisis and had previously downplayed concerns about debt-funded stock purchases. The agency's role and operations remain opaque, leading to extreme volatility and confusion in the stock market. Nie faces a "Herculean task" to stabilize the market.

site_title: Canada to go to the polls in October
summary: Canada will hold its federal election on October 19, marking the longest electoral contest since 1872. Prime Minister Stephen Harper's Conservative government faces a tough fight against the left-leaning New Democratic Party and centrist Liberals. Harper's nine-year reign is threatened, with polls showing the NDP averaging 32.6% of popular support, ahead of the Conservatives at 31.6% and the Liberals at 25.6%. The election campaign comes amid an economy ravaged by falling crude oil prices, raising questions about Harper's ability to balance the budget.

site_title: London borough seeks crackdown on noisy supercars
summary: London's Kensington and Chelsea borough is considering introducing a Public Space Protection Order (PSPO) to address noise complaints from residents about supercar owners revving their engines, rapid acceleration, and playing loud music on exclusive Sloane Street. The PSPO, based on 2014 legislation, aims to prohibit these activities and impose fines of £100 or potentially prosecution on non-compliance. Residents and local council officials say the noisy drivers are mostly locals or visitors from wealthy countries, and some owners agree with the measure, stating that it will help maintain a positive image for car enthusiasts.

site_title: From open sewage to high-tech hydrohub, Singapore leads water revolution
summary: Singapore has transformed its water management system over the past 50 years, from relying on rationing and open sewage to collecting rainwater, recycling wastewater, and desalinating seawater. The country now collects rainwater from two-thirds of its land and is developing technology to mimic human kidneys. This success is attributed to strong government leadership and collaboration among agencies, making Singapore a model for solving water crises worldwide. The country's innovative approach is being studied by governments facing similar challenges, particularly in Asia.

site_title: Rising to the challenge in Asia's logistics sector
summary: FedEx Express is focusing on solutions for the growing logistics sector in South-east Asia, particularly for e-commerce and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The region is expected to see significant growth, with an average annual growth rate of 5.5% over the next decade. FedEx is boosting its focus on e-commerce, which is expected to reach US$35 million by 2018, and SMEs, which generate 20-30% of all exports in Asean. The company is also expanding its services to vertical industries such as pharmaceuticals and biomedical, driven by the region's rapidly ageing population.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.22% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.22% lower on Monday, following a decline in US shares due to weakness in oil-linked equities. The Nikkei 225 index fell 45.03 points to 20,540.21. This follows a similar trend on Wall Street, where stocks closed lower on Friday due to poor earnings from ExxonMobil and Chevron and a drop in oil prices.

site_title: Noble says has sufficient cash to fund bond redemption, US$15b in bank lines
summary: NOBLE Group says it has sufficient cash and liquidity to fund its bond redemption and operations, with US$15 billion in bank lines available. The company has also assured that it will meet its obligations and operate its businesses. Noble's net fair value gains have fallen again in the second quarter, but operating income and profits remain positive. The company has been approached by potential financings and strategic options, but no guarantee exists for near-term transactions. Noble will release its Q2 results on August 10.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore at 50 seeks smart city makeover as old industries fade
summary: Singapore is marking its 50th anniversary with a plan to transform into a "Smart Nation," aiming to stay competitive by leveraging technology and innovation. The initiative, led by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, aims to create a futuristic city with driverless cars, high-speed internet, and advanced infrastructure. As the nation's traditional industries decline, the Smart Nation plan seeks to revitalize the economy and solidify Singapore's position as a global hub for industries such as electronics and finance. The plan is expected to be a major undertaking, with billions of dollars at stake.

site_title: Fed holding pattern to persist, unless jobs data is spectacular or disastrous
summary: US stocks rose slightly last week, with traders betting the Federal Reserve would hold off on interest-rate hikes. The holding pattern is expected to persist unless employment data on Friday is spectacular or disastrous. The economy is listless, with muted 2.3% GDP growth in the second quarter and corporate earnings growth expected to be 0.9%. Despite sector-level gains and losses, the major stock indices have remained stagnant, with the S&P 500 never moving more than 3% above or below its starting point this year.

site_title: UN states agree post-2015 sustainable development agenda
summary: The United Nations has agreed on a post-2015 sustainable development agenda, consisting of 17 goals and a declaration, to be formally adopted by world leaders in September. The agenda aims to eradicate hunger and extreme poverty, reduce inequality, and combat climate change, with estimated costs ranging from $3.3 trillion to $4.5 trillion annually. The agreement was reached after two weeks of negotiations and is seen as a historic step forward in addressing global challenges. The UN Secretary-General described the agreement as "historic" but warned that the work ahead is immense.

images.alt_text: UN Secretary-General, Ban Ki Moon.

site_title: Mumbai's trash dumps occupy expensive land
summary: Mumbai's three landfills occupy 740 acres, worth around $4.4 billion if sold for housing. The city's high demand for land, combined with the lack of affordable housing, exacerbates the issue. Half of Mumbai's population lives in slums without basic sanitation or safe drinking water, while the average Indian would need three centuries to afford a luxury home in Mumbai. Redeveloping the landfills could free up space for homes, roads, and hospitals, but the cleanup and infrastructure costs are significant, and the government must offer incentives for developers to proceed.

site_title: Korea tycoon comes to the rescue of 2018 Winter Olympics
summary: South Korean business tycoon Cho Yang-ho has successfully revitalized the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, overcoming delays and infighting. Since taking charge of the Pyeongchang Organising Committee for the Olympic Games (Pocog) in August 2014, Cho has made significant progress in building venues, securing sponsorships, and improving relations with the International Olympic Committee (IOC). Despite initial concerns, construction has started and is on track for completion by February, with test events scheduled for the same month.

site_title: Getting innovation on board
summary: Innovation is crucial for companies' bottom line, brand equity, and employee morale, with 60-80% of economic growth attributed to innovation and new knowledge. Despite this, boards often neglect innovation, focusing instead on risk management and oversight. To address this, boards should prioritize innovation by embedding it into their duties in three areas: leadership, strategy and performance review, and risk management. This includes selecting and recruiting innovative leaders, engaging management in innovation strategies, and taking calculated risks to drive innovation.

site_title: Germany wrong to propose temporary 'Grexit': French minister
summary: French Finance Minister Michel Sapin stated that Germany's proposal of a temporary 'Grexit' for debt-laden Greece is "wrong" and contradicts Germany's European commitment. Sapin emphasized that reinforcing the eurozone is the goal, making a temporary exit "not realistic." He also warned that allowing a country to temporarily leave the euro could lead to other countries seeking to exit, which would not solve difficulties through exchange rate manipulation but through structural reforms. This comes as Greece and its creditors continue negotiations on a third bailout plan.

site_title: Eyes on banks as Greek stock exchange to reopen
summary: Greek banks face a critical test as the Athens stock exchange reopens after a five-week shutdown due to the country's debt crisis. Over 40 billion euros have been withdrawn from deposits since December, leaving the top four lenders vulnerable. Stress tests and asset quality reviews will be conducted later this month, with recapitalisation requirements to be determined in the autumn. Greek officials aim to complete the operation before new European regulations come into effect in January, which will shift the cost burden to bank shareholders and depositors.

site_title: Automakers buckle up for more China woe after stock crash saps sales
summary: China's auto sales are likely to contract for the fourth month in a row, following a stock market crash that eroded consumer sentiment. The crash, which wiped out $4 trillion in share value, has led to delayed big-ticket purchases, including cars. Analysts expect July sales to fall more than 2.3% from June, prompting cost-cutting and discounts. Car manufacturers are concerned about the impact of the crash on their sales, with one executive describing the situation as "nailing their nails." The slow economy, growing at its slowest in 25 years, has further exacerbated the decline.

site_title: Qualcomm investors frustrated by move to appease activists
summary: Qualcomm investors are frustrated after the chipmaker's bond value dropped 4.3% amid speculation of a potential split, despite the company's assurances that no decision has been made. The move comes after Jana Partners LLC, a hedge fund with a 1.8% stake in the company, pushed for a strategic review that could include a split of the business. Investors are concerned that a split would make both units less valuable to bondholders, who are also spooked by the involvement of a former Motorola executive on Qualcomm's board.

site_title: NY state selects 5 firms to sell medical marijuana
summary: New York State has selected five companies to sell medical marijuana, with each company required to open four dispensaries statewide within six months. The companies, including Etain, Bloomfield Industries, PharmaCann, Empire State Health Solutions, and Columbia Care NY, will be subject to a 7% tax on sales. The program aims to alleviate pain associated with severe debilitating or life-threatening conditions, with dispensaries planned in major cities such as New York City and Albany. The move follows a national trend towards medical marijuana acceptance, with 22 other states and the District of Columbia already allowing some form of medical marijuana.

site_title: With more options, Great S'pore Sale not so great anymore, say local retailers
summary: Local retailers in Singapore say the Great Singapore Sale (GSS) has lost its appeal, with increasing competition from online retailers, a strong Singapore dollar, and overseas shopping options. Retailers cite dwindling response and reduced sales during the two-month festival. Expenditure by visiting MasterCard cardholders increased 9.9% in the first month of GSS, but local cardholder spending shrank 12.7% this year. Rising competition from online shopping portals, such as Zalora and Lazada, has also contributed to the decline. Experts say brick-and-mortar stores still have a role to play, but must adapt to changing consumer behavior and develop innovative concepts to attract and retain clientele.

site_title: Day of losses seen ahead for reopened Greek bourse
summary: Greek traders predict a 20% or more drop in the Athens General Index on Monday as the Athens stock market reopens after a five-week closure. The expected losses stem from pent-up trading, concerns about Greece's worsening economy, and worries about the future.

site_title: US uses technology to triage nation's potholed roads
summary: The US government is using technology to assess the condition of its potholed roads. Vans equipped with cameras and sensors are collecting data to rate road conditions and devise maintenance plans. Cities and states are using this data to prioritize repairs and stretch their budgets, as Congress dithers over refinancing the Highway Trust Fund. The data collected by these vans is helping officials prevent damage, fix existing flaws, and save money. Over 20 transportation departments across the US are deploying these vans, and some states are using the data to increase funding for road repairs.

site_title: Former teenage soldier hatches millions from Chinese egg futures
summary: A former teenage soldier, Zhang Xiongjie, has made millions by dominating China's egg futures market. His significant earnings highlight the vulnerability of China's nascent futures markets to market instability. Zhang, who spent time patrolling China's border, now enjoys a luxurious lifestyle, driven by his success in the egg futures market, one of China's most obscure financial markets.

site_title: Country singer Lynn Anderson dies, aged 67
summary: Country singer Lynn Anderson, known for her 1970s hit "Rose Garden," has died at 67. She died from a heart attack at Vanderbilt Hospital in Nashville after being admitted for pneumonia. Anderson had a string of hits and won a Grammy for the song, which catapulted her into mainstream fame. She was a "crossover" artist, blending pop, country, and bluegrass genres. Tributes poured in from fellow singer Dolly Parton and fans on social media, remembering her as one of country music's finest.

site_title: Virgin America finds Dallas Love Field its least-dependable airport in US
summary: Virgin America has found Dallas Love Field to be its least-dependable airport in the US, with 24% of departures delayed through May, exceeding LaGuardia Airport's 23%. The surge in flights is due to the expiration of a federal law limiting non-stop destinations, with daily departures at Love Field reaching a record. Virgin America, which operates from two gates with 19 daily departures, faces challenges in maintaining on-time departures, citing a typical number of seven to eight departures per gate.

site_title: Jubilee joy
summary:
