site_title: Pertamina losing 80b rupiah a day from subsidised fuel sales
summary: Indonesia's state-owned energy company Pertamina is losing 80 billion rupiah (S$8.2 million) daily from subsidized fuel sales, amid declining oil prices and a shift in the burden of fuel subsidies to the company. Pertamina's first half profits halved to US$570 million, with the company's losses from fuel sales reaching 12.6 trillion rupiah. The company's domestic fuel sales dropped 8% in the first half, with a 13% fall in subsidized premium petrol sales. Pertamina plans to invest US$4.4 billion this year despite the losses.

site_title: Bank of Korea points to China risk, holds rate at record low
summary: The Bank of Korea held its key interest rate at a record low of 1.5% as it gauges the economy's health amid China's currency devaluation. The decision was unanimous, following four rate cuts in the past year. Economists predict a higher chance of a rate cut due to the yuan's impact on Korea's exports and debt growth. The central bank is closely monitoring volatility in financial markets and awaiting the impact of an extra budget on the economy.

site_title: Pearson to sell 50% Economist stake for 469m pounds
summary: Pearson agreed to sell its 50% stake in the Economist Group for 469 million pounds to its existing investors. The sale includes 27.8% of shares to Exor, the Agnelli family's holding, for 227.5 million pounds, and all B special shares for 59.5 million pounds. Pearson's remaining ordinary shares will be repurchased by the Economist Group for 182 million pounds.

site_title: China just gave Apple's biggest suppliers a welcome surprise
summary: China's central bank devalued the yuan by the most in two decades, benefiting Apple's biggest suppliers, Hon Hai Precision Industry Co and Pegatron Corp. The devaluation, which may help shore up margins at the suppliers, could boost their gross margins by up to 0.5 percentage points. The move may soften the impact of Apple's weak outlook, as the currency change can help the suppliers' bottom line. Hon Hai, which assembles iPhones for Apple, employs over a million workers in China and depends on the US company for half of its revenue.

site_title: South Korea's Park: Time to desperately push for economic reforms
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye urged the country to "desperately" push for economic reforms to achieve sustainable growth, calling for "major surgery" to address problems. The economy is facing slowing growth and increasing challenges. Park's call for reforms comes as Asia's fourth-largest economy struggles to maintain momentum. The government must take significant steps to revitalize the economy and prevent further decline.

site_title: Fed 'close' to hiking rates, US economy near normal: Lockhart
summary: US economy nears normal conditions, Federal Reserve may hike interest rates soon, according to Atlanta Fed president Dennis Lockhart. The economy has made significant gains, with inflation expected to rise in the coming months as the economy strengthens. Lockhart believes the economy has cleared major hurdles, reducing risks from abroad and putting the Fed in reach of its key goal of full employment. Four Fed officials have publicly expressed support for a September rate hike, while others have cited overseas risks and concerns.

site_title: China grants independent refiners licenses to import crude oil
summary: China's Ministry of Commerce granted licenses to two independent refineries, Shandong Dongming Petrochemical Group and Panjin Beifang Asphalt Fuel Co, to directly import crude oil. This move allows these companies to bypass state-affiliated trading companies, which have traditionally controlled the import process. The licenses are part of Beijing's efforts to open up the tightly state-controlled oil sector and boost private participation in the trade ahead of a planned crude oil futures contract.

site_title: Trade in H shares keeps burning investors
summary: MSCI China Index has declined 21% since April due to a stock crash, weak data, and signs of a US rate hike. Despite initial optimism in Hong Kong's H shares, investors have been selling, contrary to predictions of big gains. The article notes that the decline in H shares is a result of a sharp change in market sentiment, with investors now focusing on other assets. The decline in the MSCI China Index has significant implications for the global economy and investors' portfolios.

images.alt_text: 'VALUE TRAP': Hong Kong's Hang Seng H-Share Index ETF, which lured record inflows in April, has recorded withdrawals for the past two weeks.

site_title: Palm rebounds from 11m low on short covering, crude
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures rebounded from 11-month lows, finishing 0.3% higher at RM2,060 (US$534) a tonne, as traders covered short positions and crude oil prices steadied. The benchmark contract had fallen to 2,026 ringgit, its lowest since September 2014, amid an uncertain demand outlook and economic worries in top buyer China. Traders ignored upside from a weak ringgit and dry weather, with prices expected to fall into a range of RM1,997-RM2,031.

site_title: StarHub to commission local programming this year using PCFS funding
summary: StarHub will commission over 80 hours of original local content using PCFS funding, including short-form content for digital platforms. This is the second time the broadcaster has received the funding, following a 2013 award. The content will incorporate PSB values such as celebrating Singapore's culture and promoting the Singaporean identity. Innovative concepts and credible production personnel will be prioritized in the evaluation of proposals.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.41%
summary: Tokyo's benchmark shares index closed 0.41% higher on Monday, driven by positive earning results, despite weaker-than-expected Chinese economic data. The Nikkei 225 index rose 84.13 points to 20,808.69, while the Topix index of all first-section shares gained 0.72% to 1,691.29.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's benchmark shares index closed 0.41 per cent higher on Monday after a see-saw session, as investors weighed positive earning results with weaker-than-expected Chinese economic data.

site_title: 8 startups in first batch of SPH Plug & Play programme
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has unveiled the first batch of eight startups for its SPH Plug & Play accelerator programme, selected from over 280 applicants. The eight startups will participate in a 100-day accelerator programme from July to October 2015, receiving S$30,000 in seed funding and mentorship opportunities. The programme aims to nurture high-growth, innovation-driven startups tackling media business challenges. The selected startups represent various areas, including content creation, online marketplaces, and social media platforms.

site_title: Freer reign for S'pore, HK Reits may see them in riskier areas: S&P
summary: S&P reports that Singapore and Hong Kong's relaxed regulatory environment for real estate investment trusts (Reits) may lead to expanded strategies into riskier areas. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's proposed 45% gearing limit is consistent with recent research, and S&P expects Reits to focus on development activities, higher gearing, and greater flexibility. However, this may increase risks and require more development skills. The impact on creditors' attitudes towards Reits in the next five years is uncertain, but the regulatory trend is expected to continue, supporting growth in the sector.

site_title: Slide in Greek residential property price gains pace in Q2
summary: Greece's residential property prices declined 5.6% in Q2 2015, accelerating the annual pace of decline to 4.1% from 3.9% in Q1. This drop is attributed to a combination of factors, including property taxes, a tight credit market, and a high jobless rate. The decline has reduced household wealth and affected the collateral value on banks' outstanding real estate loans. Greece's economy is projected to contract by 2-4% in 2015, with a recession expected to continue.

site_title: EY's Japanese arm launches internal probe of Toshiba audit
summary: EY's Japanese arm has launched an internal probe into its audit of Toshiba Corp following the electronics maker's $1.2 billion accounting scandal. A team of about 20 audit check specialists is investigating potential problems with the audit process. The investigation aims to complete by the end of August, with the goal of determining whether any issues were identified during the audit.

site_title: Off the beaten path
summary: Investors considering diversifying their portfolios may look into non-traditional fixed income options. A low-profile property trust has made a data centre gambit, potentially offering an alternative investment strategy. Meanwhile, China has urged Southeast Asian countries to back openness amid looming US tariffs, while Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly fell, and Reliance Jio's India IPO has been delayed beyond this year. These developments suggest ongoing market volatility and shifting economic priorities.

site_title: Currency effect makes China's banks world's largest: SNL Financial
summary: China's banks dominate the world's largest banks by assets due to currency fluctuations, with Industrial & Commercial Bank of China holding the top spot at $3.45 trillion. HSBC ranks fourth with $2.67 trillion, and China Construction Bank Corp takes second place. US banks have been displaced from the top five due to different accounting standards. The largest US bank, JPMorgan Chase & Co, would rank first if it followed Chinese accounting principles.

images.alt_text: The list of the world's largest banks by assets is dominated by China due to currency effect.

site_title: German industrial output, exports fall in June
summary: Germany's industrial output fell 1.4% and exports dropped 1% in June, according to data released by the economy ministry. The decline was attributed to factors such as China's slowdown and the Greece crisis, despite the benefits of a low euro and cheap oil. Analysts forecast a small increase, but Natixis and UniCredit revised their predictions to 0.4% growth. The trade surplus narrowed to 22 billion euros, with exports growing 7% in the first half of the year, mainly to non-euro EU countries and other world regions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.15% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.15% lower on Wednesday, despite positive earnings reports and a weaker yen. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 20,490.15, following a decline in US shares, which slid due to Apple's 3.2% drop. Toyota's net profit rose 10% to $5.2 billion, but its stock fell 2.53%. A weak yen is positive for Japanese exporters, making them more competitive abroad.

site_title: Shanghainese leading China's tourism surge in Japan
summary: Shanghainese are driving China's tourism surge in Japan, with a two-thirds increase in Chinese visitors expected this year. The surge is attributed to a weaker yen, improved diplomatic ties, and a desire to experience Japan's culture and people. Shanghai is a major hub, with over 40% of Chinese visitors coming from the city. The influx of Chinese tourists has boosted Japan's trade relationship, with two-way trade reaching $344 billion last year. Despite historical tensions, frequent people-to-people exchanges are seen as a key to improving relations between China and Japan.

images.alt_text: Maikos or apprentice geikos from Kyoto performing a traditional dance during a special event as part of the Kyoto summer travel campaign in Tokyo.

site_title: New York's youth orchestra downsizes to survive
summary: The Little Orchestra Society, a New York City-based youth orchestra, plans to cut its performances next season in half due to financial difficulties. The ensemble, which focuses on classical music for children, will now give 16 performances, down from 28 last season. Despite the challenges, the orchestra is bucking the trend in classical music by attracting younger audiences, with the average age of its audience dropping. The ensemble is also overhauling its children's programming and giving tickets to public school children and their families.

site_title: Global capital spending to fall for 3rd straight year, S&P says
summary: Global capital spending is expected to fall for the third consecutive year, according to a report by Standard & Poor's. Non-financial corporations are anticipated to cut back on investment by 1% in 2015 and 4% in 2016. The decline is mainly attributed to the energy and materials industry, which faces a loss of confidence in commodities. Global capital spending, excluding energy and materials, is estimated to rise by 8%. The report warns that a transition to higher interest rates and lack of visibility on investment returns may hinder company spending.

site_title: Car-parts giant Continental raises 2015 forecast on lower raw material costs
summary: Continental AG, Europe's second-largest car parts maker, raised its 2015 forecast due to lower raw material costs. The company's second-quarter earnings jumped 25% to 1.25 billion euros, with revenue increasing 18% to 10 billion euros. Continental's adjusted Ebit is now expected to reach 11% of revenue, up from an earlier prediction of 10.5%. The company's CEO stated that despite a slowdown in vehicle production in Asia, Continental expects stable business development in the second half of the year.

site_title: Iron ore trade in China climbs to record as volatility rises
summary: China's iron ore trade reached a record high in July with 32.4 million contracts traded, more than tripling from a year earlier. Volatility rose, with iron ore's 10-day volatility hitting a record 94.4 on July 13. Prices fluctuated wildly, falling to a six-year low before rallying into a bull market. Inventories at Chinese ports shrank 0.6% last week, contributing to the market's volatility. The Dalian Commodity Exchange plans to allow foreign access to extend its influence over global raw-material prices.

site_title: Shares of Disney drop after it lowers cable network outlook
summary: Disney lowered its cable network outlook, citing modest subscriber losses and foreign exchange rate impacts. The company now expects mid-single-digit annual operating income growth from 2013 to 2016, down from high single-digit growth. This led to a 6% drop in shares to $114.10, despite a record profit quarter. The media networks segment saw a 4% operating income rise, driven by higher fees from distributors, while the theme parks segment rose 9%.

site_title: Def Con hackers and 'feds' reach an uneasy detente
summary: US spy agencies, including the CIA, NSA, and FBI, may participate in panels and presentations at the Def Con hacker conference in Las Vegas, after a two-year cooling-off period following scandalous revelations about online snooping. Founder Jeff Moss said the agencies must be honest about their activities and face hostile questioning from wary hackers. Deputy Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas gave a presentation on working together to fight cyber threats, but sidestepped questions on building "back doors" for intelligence agencies. A tentative "trust, but verify" relationship is being considered, with the door open for agencies to repair relations and repair trust.

images.alt_text: PLUGGING LOOPHOLES: Def Con volunteers working as 'goons' at the conference have booted out agents of foreign intelligence groups secretly recording goings on at the gathering, says Mr Moss.

site_title: Miss Piggy and Kermit break up ahead of new ABC Muppets show
summary: Miss Piggy and Kermit the Frog announced their separation in a joint statement, citing a desire to focus on their careers. The Muppets, a beloved American pop culture staple, will feature the characters behind the scenes of Miss Piggy's new late-night show in the upcoming ABC revival. Kermit will serve as an executive producer on the show, which will include guests like Reese Witherspoon. The separation was made public ahead of the show's September premiere, sparking hopes among fans that the couple may still have a future together.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks extend losses on yuan jitters; financials, tech down
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell for a second day on Wednesday due to concerns over China's yuan devaluation, which rattled global markets. The main TAIEX index dropped 0.8% to 8,328.12 points, with financial firms like Cathay Financial Holdings declining 3.3%. The electronics sub-index also fell 1%. The Taiwan dollar stabilized at T$0.071 to T$32.009 per US dollar after reaching a five-year low in the previous session.

site_title: How Warsaw got its mojo back
summary: Warsaw, Poland's capital, has undergone a remarkable transformation since its devastation in World War II. The city has been rebuilt with a focus on mixed-use developments, green spaces, and efficient public transportation, earning it a reputation as one of Europe's best-kept holiday secrets. Despite its Soviet-era architecture, Warsaw's charming Old Town, scenic Vistula River, and vibrant cultural scene make it a must-visit destination. The city's resilience and national pride are evident in its many museums, historic landmarks, and local artistic scene, making it a compelling tale of rejuvenation in modern travel.

site_title: China's market turmoil poses hurdle for HSBC's Asia push
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc posted a 10% increase in first-half profit, driven by a surge in income from Asia, where the bank makes 69% of its profit. However, China's market turmoil poses a threat to the bank's turnaround effort, with Mr. Gulliver warning of a softening of results in Asia in the second half. The bank's reliance on Asia will increase following the sale of its Brazilian unit and planned disposal of its Turkish unit. Analysts expect HSBC to continue its efforts to pare back its geographic spread and eliminate jobs, despite the challenges ahead.

site_title: Sembcorp ups stake in India renewable energy business
summary: Sembcorp Industries' wholly-owned subsidiary, Sembcorp Utilities, has subscribed to the entire rights issuance of Sembcorp Green Infra to fund growth in the renewable sector in India. The total investment is 2 billion rupees, increasing Sembcorp Utilities' stake in Sembcorp Green Infra to 64.06%, up from 60%. The investment is expected to have a minimal impact on Sembcorp Industries' earnings per share and net asset value per share for the 2015 financial year.

site_title: Fed not yet decided whether to hike rates in Sept: Powell
summary: Federal Reserve policymakers have not yet decided whether to raise interest rates at their September meeting, according to Fed Governor Jerome Powell. Data on the labor market, particularly, will be key to that decision. Powell stated that nothing has been decided and that the committee hasn't made a decision. The decision will be made at the policy meeting on September 16-17.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve policymakers have not yet decided whether to raise interest rates at a closely watched meeting next month, an influential governor at the US central bank said on Wednesday, adding data on the labour market in particular would be key to that decision.

site_title: Widodo seeks Indonesian reboot as currency pressure mounts
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has reshuffled his cabinet in response to currency pressure and economic slowdown, with six new members appointed to key positions. Darmin Nasution, a former Bank Indonesia Governor, becomes economy minister, while Tom Lembong, a private equity investor, takes over as trade minister. The move aims to address concerns over protectionism and promote free trade. Widodo's 2016 budget and first state of the union address will focus on revitalizing the economy, with a focus on infrastructure development and attracting foreign investment.

images.alt_text: The president, known as Jokowi, revamped his economic team in a cabinet reshuffle on Wednesday as China's currency devaluation spurred further declines in the rupiah.
